headline: CHELSEA GREEN TO BLOSSOM UNDER NEW SCHEME
prcopy: Royal Borough plans to enhance Chelsea Green were given the go-ahead on Friday October 31 in an imaginative scheme that will see improvements to the local landscape, and at the same time ensure the character of the surrounding area is protected for the future.    Improvements to the Green will include an upgrade of the lawn, new high quality period style iron railings and an overhaul of signs around it. The existing mature cherry tree will be retained. Parking and traffic arrangements will remain virtually as they are, with minor changes to assist pedestrian crossing.     Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Planning and Transportation, Councillor Daniel Moylan said: We have listened very closely to the local community and have come up with a scheme for Chelsea Green that really adds something to the area
noteslabel: whilst retaining all of its essential character."    The overall aims of the project are to preserve the long-term attractiveness of the Green and to help maintain the competitiveness of the designated local shopping area."

headline: NIP HOMELESSNESS IN THE BUD
prcopy: The aim of the Royal Borough's Housing Information Day was to prevent homelessness before it actually happens.  By targeting 8000 people on the Borough's housing register the event focussed directly on those most likely to suffer the problems associated with homelessness. The event proved particularly popular, with nearly 700 visitors attending.    Rather than waiting for the homeless problem to occur, the Royal Borough has identified five key groups commonly afflicted by homelessness and provided a range of measures to help each.  The information day was an opportunity to showcase these solutions and give these groups a chance to talk through the options open to them. The groups highlighted are those suffering from rent arrears, overcrowding, domestic violence, the elderly and young people.      Tackling these issues at an early stage is important in Kensington and Chelsea as the residential property market is the most expensive in the country.  This can mean that low-income groups have limited options or choice and homelessness can be a very real prospect.    In the case of young people, evidence shows that when leaving home for the first time they can often find themselves homeless and would benefit from some specialist advice and education services.   Parents evicting children contributed 18 per cent to the Borough's homeless figure during 2002/2003.      Initiatives designed to tackle this include the creation of a mediation service that aims to give parents and children an opportunity to talk through any domestic disputes before making a final decision about leaving home.  Other services include a homeless prevention video in conjunction with schools and the creation of a Young Persons Housing Coordinator.     Other initiatives include:    · Independent legal advice   · Developing affordable ownership properties  · Choice Based Lettings Scheme - Home Connections  · HomeStart - Out of London affordable housing    Cabinet Member for Housing, Councillor Timothy Coleridge said:  We aim to tackle the problem of homelessness at its very source.  It is only the combination of prevention
noteslabel: advice and working with partner agencies that will produce real results.  The Information Day proved popular last year and it looks like this years event has proved even more so. "    Last year the `HomeStart' initiative was the theme for a similar event and provided information and advice for residents looking to solve their housing problems by moving out of the capital.  The scheme has proved a popular option and has directly helped to reduce the number of homeless people in the Borough.  The scheme is due to be stepped up in a deliberate move to reach more households.     One major homeless target has been to reduce the number of families with dependent children staying in Bed and Breakfast accommodation.  The Royal Borough has so far reduced this number from over 200 to just 22.    If you would like any advice on any of these matters

headline: GUIDELINES TO CLEAR UP CONTAMINATED LAND
prcopy: What does the Council expect from a property developer who wants to develop a site in the Borough that may be contaminated?    The answer to this question is now easier to find as the Royal Borough is leading the way in showing developers what they must do. While the Royal Borough does not have the legacy of land contaminated through previous use that some other London boroughs experience, it does have some sites, large and small that might be classified as contaminated.    The document, called `Contaminated land - A guide to help developers meet planning requirements', sets out the technical information required by the Council and the process that it expects a developer to follow.      The result of a project led by the Royal Borough, the publication brings together the work of 11 London councils.     It shows how anyone wanting to develop a potentially contaminated site in the Royal Borough would be expected to:  carry out a detailed investigation of the site  produce a strategy for cleaning up any contamination identified and   produce a report that shows that the site has been cleaned up to the satisfaction of the Council.    Councillor Walker-Arnott, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, Leisure and Waste Management said: We are fortunate not to have the large scale contaminated sites found in other boroughs
noteslabel: but it is important that any site which may be contaminated is addressed in a thorough and correct manner. I hope that the publication of this document will prove a useful tool for anyone intending to embark on developing any potentially contaminated sites in the Borough and make our requirements of them clear."    Copies of the guide are available by calling 020 7341 5716 or by contacting the Environmental Quality Unit at the following address:   Directorate of Environmental Health  37 Pembroke Road  London  W8 6PW"
photolabel: For a copy of the publication 'Contaminated land - A guide to help developers meet planning requirements' contact Jill Hemmings on 020 7361 2790.

shorttitle: The  Royal Borough is leading the way in showing developers what they must do if they want to develop land that may be contaminated through previous use.

headline: OLYMPIC CYCLING COMES TO THE BOROUGH
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is one of five London boroughs to host part of the Olympic Road Cycling races in 2012.

The route of the races has been announced today (Thursday 10 February) by the London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games (LOCOG).

Both races will take place on the first weekend of the Games, the men's race on Saturday 28 July and the women's on Sunday 29 July 2012. These races will give residents and visitors a chance to get close to the action of what will certainly be a spectacular event as it speeds through the borough.

The races will begin in Westminster and enter the Royal Borough at Knightsbridge. They will then run along the Brompton Road to Fulham Road, before crossing into Hammersmith & Fulham, Wandsworth, Richmond and beyond.

A test race will take place this August. This event is an essential part of London's preparations for the Olympic Games in 2012.

Both the test race and the Olympic event will be exciting spectacles, but they will cause some disruption to traffic and services. Fulham Road and Brompton Road may be partially closed to traffic on the race days.

The Council is working with the race organisers and will be asking LOCOG to provide it with further details about the times the roads will be closed and the impact on residents and businesses well in advance of the events. As soon as more details are available the Council will ask LOCOG to organise local briefings.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is one of five London boroughs to host part of the Olympic Road Cycling races in 2012.
shorttitle: OLYMPIC CYCLING COMES TO THE BOROUGH

headline: TRELLICK TOWER INSPIRES NOTTING HILL BAG DESIGN
prcopy:
A ten year-old pupil from Middle Row Primary School has become the latest designer to have their work featured on the Notting Hill Shopping Bag. Chanay Vital's eye-catching design features the iconic Trellick Tower which is around the corner from her school in North Kensington.

The bag is one of a series produced by the Notting Hill Shopping Bag project, a community scheme which aims to reduce plastic bag use, and donates ten per cent of profits to good causes.

Previous bags have featured a `cupcake' design by singer Natalie Imbruglia and drawings by other school pupils in Kensington and Chelsea.

Chanay's limited edition `Trellick Tower' bag costs £4 and it is on sale at stalls and shops on Portobello Road. To buy a bag online visit www.thenottinghillshoppingbag.co.uk

headline: PLANS TO COMBINE COUNCIL SERVICES TAKE LEAP FORWARD
prcopy:
Proposals to combine the first set of services across three West London authorities are set to be discussed by councillors at a series of cabinet meetings in the next week.

Westminster City Council (WCC), Hammersmith & Fulham (H&F) and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea expect combined services to save £35 million a year by 2014/15, with around 500 jobs going in management, back office and support roles. Initial proposals are being developed in adult services, children's services, environmental services, library services and corporate services.

At Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday 4 May the PM gave his backing and said that other councils should be doing the same before looking at reductions in frontline services.

Councillors at three respective cabinet meetings are set to be updated on how proposals are at an advanced stage to:

 combine fostering and adoption services and youth offending services, with the creation of a single Local Safeguarding Children Board. In total this would save nearly £199,000 a year by 2014/15
 combine library services, not only saving local residents £1.4m but also giving them the ability to access libraries across the three boroughs for the first time
 combine environment management teams in Hammersmith & Fulham and Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, saving £1.5 million with a 48 per cent reduction in senior management (14 posts).

Decisions on whether to combine services in these areas are expected to be made in June. That is when councillors will also hear detailed proposals to combine adult services, education services and corporate services. The first appointment across the three councils was made last month when former Westminster City Council Director of Adult Social Care, Marian Harrington was given the task of implementing a combined adult social care commissioning service integrated with heathcare provision.

Hammersmith & Fulham and Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have agreed to share a chief executive from October 2011. The two councils already share senior management posts in legal services, highways and finance.

The cabinets' reports reveal that the majority of residents surveyed support the principle of combining services. Of 1,500 residents who took part in a telephone survey in February, 34 per cent said there should be some sharing of services, with 43 per cent saying that the three authorities should share as much as possible. Only 13 per cent of people were opposed to sharing services.

Collectively, the three authorities must save £100 million by 2014/15. They have each signed a 'Sovereignty Guarantee' to safeguard local autonomy, responsiveness and identity. Each of the councils will retain their own councillors and decision making processes. Services key to local areas, such as housing management, licensing and planning will be not be combined.

The Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell said: "Everyone knows the financial straits councils find themselves in. To protect our services we have taken a difficult and challenging road but as this report shows we are making progress and we are making it happen."

Hammersmith & Fulham Council Leader Cllr Stephen Greenhalgh said: "This is a common sense way of dealing with the big financial pressures facing councils up and down the country. Combining services is not only more cost effective but would also allow us to improve services in many areas such as allowing Hammersmith residents to access libraries in Westminster and vice versa."

Westminster City C Council Leader Cllr Colin Barrow said: "Every penny saved by our planned collaboration will help protect frontline services while local people across the three boroughs will not see any change in the way these services are delivered. In today's tough economic climate when council budgets are being scaled back this is a sensible and pragmatic way to deliver a number of services to our local residents."

The Royal Borough's Cabinet meets on Thursday 5 May, with Westminster City Council and Hammersmith & Fulham Cabinets meeting respectively on Monday 9 May.
keyword4: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: Proposals to combine the first set of services across three West London authorities are set to be discussed by councillors at a series of cabinet meetings in the next week.
shorttitle: Plans to combine council services take leap forward

headline: WHY DON'T YOU GET INVOLVED?
prcopy:
Find out more about uniformed youth organisations and what they get up at the YOU (Youth Organised Uniform) London event on Saturday 21 May, from 1pm to 5pm in Holland Park.

It's free to attend and on the day there will be the Boys' Brigade Gymnastic Display Team and music from the Air Training Corps band. There will also be a fire engine, police dogs and traffic cars as well as a climbing wall.

YOU brings together London's oldest, largest and most experienced uniformed youth organisations where youngsters are encouraged to learn various skills through positive activities, sport, expeditions and learning.

YOU London is working with the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, to increase the number of young people taking part in uniformed youth groups and the organisation is looking to recruit more adult volunteers. There are currently more than 17,000 volunteers working with around 76,000 children and young people across London.

For more information about the event please contact Sergeant Paul Crook on 020 7795 6660 and to find out more about YOU and volunteering visit www.youlondon.org.uk
shortdescription: Find out more about uniformed youth organisations and what they get up at the YOU (Youth Organised Uniform) London event on Saturday 21 May, from 1pm to 5pm in Holland Park.

headline: OFFICIAL OPENING OF NEW NAPOLEON GARDEN SCULPTURE
prcopy:
The latest piece of contemporary art to be unveiled in Holland Park is `The Garden of Earthly Delights' by Daniel Pasteiner. The highly sought after spot in the Napoleon Garden has been used as a springboard for new artists for a number of years.

At the unveiling ceremony last Friday (6 May) Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Cabinet Member for Leisure was joined by the artist and Council officers.

Councillor Paget-Brown said: "The Council has been encouraging new artists with the opportunity to show their work in one of the premier sites for contemporary sculpture in London for over a decade.

"The Garden of Earthly Delights will attract many visitors and I am sure it will generate a great deal of discussion. I am delighted that Daniel agreed to have his art shown in the Napoleon Garden."

Daniel Pasteiner has used objects associated with leisure equipment and suburban gardens to give a sculptural interpretation of Hieronymus Bosch's sixteenth century painting, `The Garden of Earthly Delights', a painting that has been controversial ever since it was first shown.
shortdescription: The latest piece of contemporary art to be unveiled in Holland Park is `The Garden of Earthly Delights' by Daniel Pasteiner.  The highly sought after spot in the Napoleon Garden has been used as a springboard for new artists for a number of years.
shorttitle: Official opening of the new Napoleon Garden Sculpture

headline: HOLLAND PARK BENEFITS FROM PIG SOCIETY
prcopy:
Six British Saddleback pigs have taken up residency in the prestigious Holland Park, using their well-trained snouts to root up and turn over soil in part of the park.

Last year a family of pigs were used to help restore the meadow area of the Arboretum, this year the nearby Oak Enclosure will be their home.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Cabinet Member for Environment, said: "Last year the pigs were a great success. Not only did they effectively turn the soil in the Arboretum, but many visitors to the park, particularly children, thoroughly enjoyed seeing them and learning more about how they live.

"British Saddleback pigs are an environmentally sustainable way of improving Holland Park, as well as giving many people who otherwise would not see pigs an opportunity to see them in a natural habitat. I am delighted that the pigs are back and am sure they will do as excellent a job as the pigs last year. In fact, I believe they are a fine example of the Pig Society in action."

British Saddleback pigs were chosen as they are a very docile breed, noted for their mothering capability and are also known for their grazing ability and hardiness.

Wildflower meadows are one of our fastest disappearing habitats and over 95 per cent have been lost, which means many of our native wildflowers are in decline. These meadows support birds and small mammals and are also home to many invertebrates, including butterflies, grasshoppers and bees.

The pigs turn over bulbs which may reduce next year's flowers. But in the long term the bulbs will benefit from the disturbance and being `chipped' (or split); consequently they are likely to flower more vigorously in following seasons.

The pigs, from Charton Manor Farm in Kent, made the journey up to Holland Park on Friday 13 May and will remain in the park for approximately two months.
shortdescription: Six British Saddleback pigs have taken up residency in the prestigious Holland Park, using their well-trained snouts to root up and turn over soil in part of the park.
shorttitle: Holland Park benefits from Pig Society

headline: SEASIDE BREAK FROM CARNIVAL
prcopy:
Once again, 40 elderly residents will be given the opportunity to enjoy a break away from the hustle and bustle of Notting Hill Carnival, as part of a scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The scheme, now in its eighth year, is aimed at older people living directly on the Carnival route, who may find the exuberance of the weekend too much.

Residents will be driven to the Glastonbury Hotel in Eastbourne on Saturday 27 August and will return to their homes on Tuesday 30 August, once the Council has had time to clear up and the area is quieter.

Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Council, said: "Although the Carnival is an exciting event, we do sympathise with older residents for whom large crowds and loud noise make the weekend a difficult time. Due to the success of previous trips, we have decided to run the scheme again to offer another group of elderly people a break away from the clamour of the Carnival."

All applications will be assessed by Adult Social Care Services and those who have not gone before will be given priority over those who have.

Elderly residents can contact the Council for more information on 020 7361 3175. The closing date to apply for a place is Friday 10 June 2011.
shortdescription: Once again, 40 elderly residents will be given the opportunity to enjoy a break away from the hustle and bustle of Notting Hill Carnival, as part of a scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Seaside break from Carnival

headline: CALL FOR BOROUGH'S BEST TO CARRY OLYMPIC TORCH
prcopy:
The search is on for torchbearers following the announcement that the Olympic Torch will be carried through the borough's streets in the final week before the Games begin.

The London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games (LOCOG) is today (Wednesday 18 May) asking the public to nominate inspirational people from across the capital as torchbearers to give them their moment to shine and have their story celebrated in the run up to the start of the London 2012 Olympic Games.

Running for six weeks from today, the LOCOG Torchbearer Programme to find 2,012 inspirational people who have gone beyond their personal best will see nominations judged by local panels set up throughout the UK, including one for London.

Go to www.london2012.com/olympictorchrelay to make your nomination. The deadline for nominations is 11.59pm on Wednesday 29 June 2011.

Sebastian Coe, Chair of LOCOG said: ``The Olympic Flame will shine a light right across the host city in the final week of the Olympic Torch Relay and I hope people right across London start to think about rewarding someone truly inspirational and give someone they know who has gone beyond their personal best, their moment to shine by nominating them to carry the Olympic Flame.'

Young people in particular from across the capital are encouraged to get involved, with half of the total number of torchbearer places expected to go to people aged between 12 and 24 years of age who are considered leading lights in their local communities.

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I know we have many inspirational people, young and old in the borough, and would urge our residents to take time and nominate someone who has a special story to tell, has sporting talent or has made a real contribution to the life of the community to take part in this historic event.

"Of course we are already very proud to be hosting not only the Olympic volleyball competition but also the cycle road races and I am delighted that the Olympic Torch relay will provide an opportunity to celebrate the achievements of our residents."
shortdescription: The search is on for torchbearers following the announcement that the Olympic Torch will be carried through the borough's streets in the final week before the Games begin.
shorttitle: Call for borough's best to carry the Olympic Torch

headline: DEPUTY YOUTH MP ELECTED BY BOROUGH'S YOUNG PEOPLE
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea's new Deputy Member of Youth Parliament (MYP) has been announced. Lily Barrow, 14, from Holland Park School was elected in a poll of young people from the borough's youth centres.

Lily will work alongside the current MYP, Nathan Akehurst, 18, from Holland Park School, for one year. A new deputy will be chosen at the next election and Lily will take Nathan's place as MYP. This means each young person will get one year's experience before becoming the MYP.

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I'm always very pleased when young people get involved in the community and even more so when they stand up and represent their peers. I am sure that Lily will learn a lot as deputy and I wish her and Nathan all the best in the coming year."

Nathan Akehurst, MYP for Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Congratulations to Lily on her election. I'm looking forward to working with her this year and hope that we'll both be able to make a difference for all the young people who live and go to school in Kensington and Chelsea."

Nathan and Lily can be contacted on ukyp@rbkc.gov.uk or 020 7938 8021.
Visit www.kccentral.rbkc.gov.uk/myp for more information.
shortdescription: Kensington and Chelsea's new Deputy Member of Youth Parliament (MYP) has been announced. Lily Barrow, 14, from Holland Park School was elected in a poll of young people from the borough's youth centres.
shorttitle: Deputy Youth MP elected by borough's young people

headline: CHELSEA RESIDENTS LEAD THE CHARGE FOR LOCAL PLANNING POWERS
prcopy:
Residents in an historic part of Chelsea have won the first stage of their bid to take greater control of local planning decisions, the Government announced last week.

The announcement also comes with a £20,000 grant to the Council to help the residents complete the next stages of the process.

The Council, in partnership with the Chelsea Society and Markham Square Association (MSA), submitted a bid to become a "neighbourhood planning vanguard" back in February. The Government is choosing a number of vanguard areas around the country, Chelsea amongst them, to pilot radical new planning powers for local neighbourhoods contained in the localism bill currently before Parliament.

The next step will be to develop a neighbourhood plan to address the planning challenges facing the part of Chelsea identified in the bid. That plan, if approved by the Secretary of State, would then become a statutory document against which future planning applications would be judged.

Many residents and developers would like to extend their properties and the neighbourhood plan will look at whether, and how, this might be achieved without harming the character of the area or residents' living conditions.

Council officers will provide the Chelsea Society and MSA with ongoing professional support and it is hoped a draft neighbourhood development plan can be prepared during 2011 for submission to the Secretary of State in 2012.

The Chelsea vanguard area is bound by, but does not include Draycott Avenue to the east, Sydney Street to the west, Redburn Street to the south and Pelham Street and Onslow Place to the north. The area is noted for its nineteenth century architecture and high density, high quality homes which command some of the world's highest property prices.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "Nothing animates local politics quite like planning issues. With this initiative we will give our residents a real say in the future of their area. That's what localism is all about and we hope Chelsea will become a model for how localism might work elsewhere."
shortdescription: Residents in an historic part of Chelsea have won the first stage of their bid to take greater control of local planning decisions, the Government announced last week.
shorttitle: Chelsea residents lead the charge for local planning powers

headline: MAJOR ROADWORKS ON KENSINGTON ROAD FROM 4 JULY
prcopy:
Major roadworks on Kensington Road will cause disruption from Monday 4 July until Friday 16 September.

The works, which will take place at the former site of the Kensington Palace Thistle Hotel, involve erecting a large gantry over the westbound carriageway of Kensington Road.

A two-week break in the work is proposed between Saturday 30 July 2011 and Monday 15 August 2011 to ensure the road is restored to its full capacity to allow the Olympic Cycle and Triathlon test events to take place.

By asking that the works take place during the summer months the Council hopes to minimise disruption.

For a large part of the works eastbound and westbound traffic will be reduced to one lane in either direction. This will have a significant effect on traffic travelling along Kensington Road, as well as access to and from De Vere Gardens and Victoria Road. Local diversions will be in place where appropriate. After the gantry has been erected westbound traffic (including high vehicles) will be able to pass under the gantry in two lanes of traffic. Eastbound traffic will also be restored to two lanes.

The developer has already been in contact with local residents associations to discuss these works and will also be carrying out an extensive letter drop in the area. More information will be published on their website and advance road signs will be placed at strategic points two weeks prior to the works commencing to warn road users to expect delays in the area.
shortdescription: Major roadworks on Kensington Road will cause disruption from Monday 4 July until Friday 16 September.
shorttitle: Major roadworks on Kensington Road from 4 July

headline: RESIDENTS GIVE MARKETS THUMBS UP
prcopy:
Nearly three quarters of residents who responded to a Council survey had visited a market in the past six months and Portobello Market was their favourite.

The survey, which was conducted with members of the borough's Residents Panel, also revealed that nearly forty per cent of residents surveyed visited a market once a week or more often. Fruit and vegetables and other fresh produce were named as the main reason for visiting the markets.

Portobello wasn't the only market to be singled out. Golborne Road Market and Partridges Food Market on Duke of York Square were also cited as good places to shop.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Cabinet Member for Environment, said: "We have some world famous markets in the borough and I am very pleased to see that residents use them regularly. It is no surprise that Portobello Market is so popular but it is worth pointing out that we have many other wonderful markets like Golborne, which are well worth a visit."

Most residents surveyed said that the internet was their favoured way of finding information about shopping in the borough, closely followed by local newspapers and leaflets and flyers.

For more details about the survey please go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/consultation
shortdescription: Nearly three quarters of residents who responded to a Council survey had visited a  market in the past six months and Portobello Market was their favourite.
shorttitle: Residents give markets thumbs up

headline: SUSPENDED SENTENCE FOR BREACH OF INJUNCTION
prcopy:
A man who breached an injunction obtained by the Council in April 2011, to prevent him intimidating residents and visitors to 4 Tor Court, Gloucester Walk, W8 has been sentenced to 14 days, suspended for two years, for breaching the terms of the injunction at West London County Court on Friday 3 June.

David Fagan was served with the injunction, which gave the police powers to arrest him if breached, after his behaviour was deemed to be causing a nuisance to people living in and near Tor Court. He was prohibited from entering an area bounded by Holland Park Avenue to the north, Holland Road and Addison Road to the west, High Street Kensington to the south and Kensington Church Street to the east.

When it became clear that he was ignoring the terms of the original injunction he was arrested and brought before the court.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Housing, said: "It is very important that people can enjoy living in their property without being subjected to the type of intimidating behaviour shown by Mr Fagan. This is why we used the courts to obtain an injunction in April. Clearly Mr Fagan thought he could ignore this and carry on with his old pattern of behaviour, but this has resulted in his arrest and this sentence. I am confident that the Council's housing officers and the police will continue to monitor this situation closely."
shortdescription: A man who breached an injunction obtained by the Council in April 2011, to prevent him intimidating residents and visitors to 4 Tor Court, Gloucester Walk, W8 has been sentenced to 14 days, suspended for two years, for breaching the terms of the injunction at West London County Court on Friday 3 June.
shorttitle: Suspended sentence for breach of injunction

headline: BENEFIT FRAUDSTER WITH TWO IDENTITIES
prcopy:
A benefit fraudster was given an eight month suspended sentence and ordered to pay nearly £4,000 compensation to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea at West London Magistrates' Court last Friday (3 June) after pleading guilty to 16 charges - 15 charges of Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit fraud and one charge of fraud against the Department for Works and Pensions.

Ms Shabnam Ansari had been claiming Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit on a Housing Association flat on Earl's Court Road since 2004. Officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea became suspicious when another claim from a different person was started at the same address in Earl's Court. Further investigation revealed that Ms Ansari was living at an address in Acton W3 with her husband and that she was illegally subletting the property in Earl's Court Road.

It also transpired that she had bought a share in another property, had worked at both the Council and also in other employment and was also claiming working tax and child tax credit without declaring her full circumstances. Ms Ansari also used her sister's name to buy property and apply for benefits and had two national insurance numbers.

The judge sentenced Miss Ansari for 16 breaches of the Social Security Administration Act 1992 and said that her fraud would usually have meant a custodial sentence but because of her early guilty plea and her mental health history, two mental health workers accompanied her to the court, he would not imprison her.

The judge sentenced her to pay £3,900 in compensation and gave her an eight month prison sentance, suspended for two years, with a two year supervision order with the probation office. The Council has a current arrangement in place for her to repay the £26,217.68 at a monthly rate or county court proceedings will be taken out against her.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, Cabinet Member for Finance, said: "It is very disappointing to hear about this case. Miss Ansari has deliberately submitted false statements in order to obtain Housing Benefit payments she was not entitled to. This type of case affects us all as she is taking money that should be going to residents who are in genuine need. She also deliberately pretended to be someone else, living two lives, one claiming benefits and the other as a married mother.

"I hope this case will provide a lesson to potential fraudsters that we will take action whenever possible if we discover intentional and systematic abuse of the benefits system."
shortdescription: A benefit fraudster was given an eight month suspended sentence and ordered to pay nearly £4,000 compensation to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea at West London Magistrates' Court last Friday (3 June) after pleading guilty to 16 charges - 15 charges of Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit fraud and 1 charge of fraud against the Department for Works and Pensions.
shorttitle: Benefit Fraudster with Two Identities

headline: NEW MAYOR OF KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA ELECTED
prcopy:
Councillor Julie Mills was elected as the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea for 2011 to 2012 at the Council's Annual General Meeting. In her acceptance speech she pledged to support charities that seek to overcome isolation in Kensington and Chelsea.

The Mayor announced her charities for the year, saying: "There are many things in life that can leave an individual with a sense of isolation. My fundraising will be focussed on three well-established charities, Open Age, Age Concern and the Pepper Pot, and also on two emerging organisations, Second Half of Your Life Foundation and Kensington and Chelsea Foundation. They are all raising money for projects which offer companionship and support for older people whenever they want it.

"The Royal Borough's motto is 'What a good thing it is to dwell together in unity'. I hope that, this year, we can work together to tackle isolation and loneliness, making the words of our motto a reality."

Councillor Mills appointed her husband, Nigel, as the Consort and Councillor Mrs Elizabeth Rutherford as Deputy Mayor. Monsignor James Curry was appointed the Mayor's chaplain.

Born and brought up in Trinidad, the Mayor has represented Norland ward, in the north of the borough, since 2006. Councillor Mills read Law at Liverpool University and was called to the English and the Trinidad Bar. She has a Masters in Art History from London University and is a Justice of the Peace for the City of London.

Councillor Mills has been Lead Member for Planning and Public Realm and subsequently Lead and then Cabinet Member for Housing, Health, Environmental Health and Adult Social Care. She has also sat on the Licensing Committee and the Voluntary Organisations Advisory Board. She is married with two children.
shortdescription: Councillor Julie Mills was elected as the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea for 2011 to 2012 at the Council's Annual General Meeting. In her acceptance speech she pledged to support charities that seek to overcome isolation in Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: New Mayor of Kensington and Chelsea elected

headline: TRANSFORMED BASEMENTS BRING NEW HOUSING TO BOROUGH
prcopy:
Unused space in the basements of Elm Park Gardens is being transformed into homes for Council tenants, key workers and private owners in an exciting development by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Redevelopment at Elm Park Gardens, in the heart of Chelsea, will eventually provide 36 high quality new homes with 23 of the basements being developed privately for sale and 13 earmarked for new Council and key worker homes. The second phase of the scheme to convert these 13 units was completed at the beginning of June.

The homes for sale comprise a mix of studio and one, two and three-bedroom flats. Not only will the proceeds of their sale fund the social housing element of the scheme, the flats themselves will help meet the strong demand for homes in Chelsea. To date seven of the basements have been sold.

The properties fell into disrepair during the war years and were compulsorily purchased by Chelsea Borough Council in 1949. Records show that, by then, the basements were already vacant. Over time they came to house communal heating systems, ducting, electricity units and much else besides. In parts, they were also used by tenants for storage purposes.

"There have been formidable obstacles, legal, technical and practical, to bringing these basements back to life," said Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Housing Services. He added: "I'm delighted to see they have all been overcome.

"Elm Park Gardens has always been amongst the very best council housing in the country. That we have been able to add more affordable properties there, all funded by new homes for sale, is a source of real pride to us at the Royal Borough."

Elm Park Gardens is a Victorian Square, with some post-war additions. Its former residents include Joyce Grenfell, Vladimir Nabokov, Laurie Lee and Elizabeth Frink.
shortdescription: Unused space in the basements of Elm Park Gardens is being transformed into homes for Council tenants, key workers and private owners in an exciting development by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Transformed basements bring new housing to the borough

headline: CYCLISTS TAKE PART IN CYCLE SAFETY EVENT
prcopy:
Cyclists in the borough were offered advice at a joint Council and police cycle safety day on Wednesday 1 June, aimed at making sure cyclists and their bikes stay safe and secure.

A main aim of the day was also to raise cyclists' awareness of HGVs blind spots, and they were given the opportunity to sit in a lorry and experience the blind spots for themselves.

One cyclist said:

"I thought I knew all about blind spots but didn't realise just how difficult it is for drivers to see cyclists who are in front of the lorry as well."

Bike experts from Dr Bike were on hand giving quick safety checks and simple adjustments to bicycles and discussing another cycling hazard - jumping red lights.

At the same time, police officers were also targeting cyclists on Kensington High Street as part of an ongoing campaign to tackle antisocial cycling in the borough. During the operation, a number of cyclists were stopped and given advice on cycling safely and police issued five fines to cyclists who rode through red lights.

Cyclists were also offered the opportunity to have their bikes security marked by TfL, making them easier to identify if they are stolen.

In an attempt to reduce accidents caused by collisions between cyclists and vehicles, the Council runs a number of cycling safety initiatives which include free cycle training for anyone who lives, works or studies in the borough.

For more information call 020 7361 3628 or email road.safety@rbkc.gov.uk.

To find out more about cycling safely in London, please go to www.tfl.gov.uk/cycling
shortdescription: Cyclists in the borough were offered advice at a joint Council and police cycle safety day on Wednesday 1 June, aimed at making sure cyclists and their bikes stay safe and secure.
shorttitle: Cyclists take part in cycle safety event

headline: JENNY JONES BACKS CROSSRAIL STATION IN NORTH KENSINGTON
prcopy:
Jenny Jones, Leader of the Green Party in the London Assembly, has joined calls for a Crossrail station at Kensal in North Kensington.

Jenny Jones said: "I believe that Crossrail must benefit Londoners across the city. A station in Kensal, North Kensington, would vastly improve transport options for local residents who are currently underserved by public transport. The case for a station here is powerful, particularly as parts of the area score just one out of six for public transport accessibility. Crossrail would absolutely transform ease of access for thousands of residents in North Kensington every day, bringing many areas of the capital within far easier reach. As part of tackling climate change and local pollution, we want people to choose public transport over private cars, and a Crossrail station would make it easier to do just that for thousands of North Kensington residents."

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I'm delighted that Jenny Jones is supporting our plans for a Crossrail station in North Kensington. She is quite right, public transport is patchy for our residents in the area and Crossrail could improve the situation dramatically. Major transport projects come along very rarely, and when they do, we want to make sure our residents benefit."
shortdescription: Jenny Jones, Leader of the Green Party in the London Assembly, has joined calls for a Crossrail station at Kensal in North Kensington.
shorttitle: Jenny Jones backs Crossrail station in North Kensington

headline: SAVE THE EARL'S COURT TO OLYMPIA DISTRICT LINE SERVICE
prcopy:
Weekday District line services between Earl's Court and Kensington Olympia will be axed from December 2011 if TfL plans go ahead.

But it's not too late for passengers to protest. TfL has agreed to extend the consultation period until Thursday 30 June 2011 to allow more local people to give their views.

Kensington and Chelsea Council has already expressed its concern to TfL, arguing that Kensington Olympia provides a vital link to Earl's Court and High Street Kensington where passengers are able to interchange with other tube lines.

Any reduction in service, the Royal Borough believes, will have an adverse effect on residents and local businesses.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Transportation and Highways, said: "I would expect TfL to think long and hard before any decision is taken to remove this valuable service. I don't believe that local people have been properly consulted so far and am therefore pleased that TfL has decided to keep its consultation open until the end of June.

"At a time with big developments on the horizon for Warwick Road, and the likely extra demand for Olympia when the Earl's Court Exhibition Centre closes, Tfl's plans seem short termist and unwise."

"I would urge residents and businesses to find out more about these plans and to make their view known to TfL."

Residents can have their say on TfL's plans before 30 June 2011 by writing to London Underground's Customer Service Centre, 55 Broadway, London SW1H 0BD, calling the LU Customer Service Centre on 0845 330 9880 or by emailing enquire@tfl.gov.uk and inserting in the subject line "Olympia District line consultation".
shortdescription: Weekday District line services between Earl's Court and Kensington Olympia will be axed from December 2011 if TfL plans go ahead.
shorttitle: Save the Earl's Court to Olympia District line service

headline: GROUNDBREAKING PLAN TO SECURE FUTURE OF CAPITAL'S LIBRARIES
prcopy:
Three flagship London boroughs are set to combine their library services as part of a groundbreaking move to secure the future of public libraries in the capital.

Westminster, Hammersmith & Fulham and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea councils have drawn up proposals to combine library services, saving taxpayers more than £1million a year and ensuring all of their 21 public libraries remain safe from closure.

Council leaders are next week (w/c: June 20) set to go ahead with the plans which will mean, once fully implemented, residents will gain access to around one million books, hundreds of entertainment and cultural events and scores of weekly skills and education classes.

The move means that a one-year-old, living to the average life expectancy of 81, would need to read at least 26 books every day for the rest of their lives if they wanted to get through the whole Tri-Borough collection. The new arrangements will boost the drive to improve literacy in the capital through increased access to children's libraries and specialised services such as regular homework clubs.

It comes as councils across the country are axing vital library services, with as many as 25 libraries expected to be closed in the capital alone over the next 12 months.

Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Leader Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell said: "We want Tri-borough working to be about much more than just making reductions and this is a very encouraging example of how, by combining our management, we have been able to protect a frontline service and offer more choice as well. We hope to repeat this pattern when we share services in other areas."

The proposals are being backed by the Minister for Culture, Communications and Creative Industries Ed Vaizey MP. "When funding is short, it is important that local authorities find innovative ways to provide this vital service, said Mr Vaizey. "Merging services across three boroughs is vastly preferable to library closures and I hope that other local authorities will come up with their own forward-looking plans for keeping libraries open."

Councillors at three separate Cabinet meetings are set to debate the proposals which also include:
- Combining fostering and adoption services and youth offending services, with the creation of a single Local Safeguarding Children Board. In total this would save nearly £199,000 a year by 2014/15.
- Combining environment management teams in Hammersmith & Fulham (H&F) and Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea saving £1.5 million with a 48 per cent reduction in senior management (14 posts).

The library proposals are part of wider plans to combine some council services across the three boroughs in a bid to save £35 million a year by 2014/15. Adult, children's, environmental and corporate services are also expected to be combined with around 500 jobs going in management, back office and support roles.

Westminster Council leader Cllr Colin Barrow said: "In these tough times, sharing back office functions and management with our neighbouring councils to drive out needless cost is the sensible and practical course of action to deliver savings to local taxpayers and protect frontline services such as our libraries.

"Throughout this process, we will ensure that each council continues to commission its own services and local priorities will still be driven by local people."

Collectively the three authorities must save £100 million by 2014/15. They have each signed a `Sovereignty Guarantee' to safeguard local autonomy, responsiveness and identity. Each of the councils will retain their own councillors and decision making processes. Services key to local areas, such as housing management, licensing and planning will be not be combined.

Hammersmith & Fulham and Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have agreed to share a chief executive from October 2011. The two councils already share senior management posts in legal services, highways and finance.

Cllr Greg Smith, H&F Council Cabinet Member for Residents' Services, said: "When money is tight some organisation's first reaction is to slash services and try to shift the blame. Others think innovatively and develop solutions that save money, increase choice and improve services so they are more accessible and convenient for residents.

"Literacy is a fundamental cornerstone of a modern society and we need to get youngsters off their sofas and into our libraries. This is why we are finding original ways to strengthen and protect as many of our libraries as we can. Residents across the three boroughs will soon have access to more books than anyone could realistically expect to read in a lifetime."
keyword2: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: Three flagship London boroughs are set to combine their library services as part of a groundbreaking move to secure the future of public libraries in the capital.
shorttitle: Groundbreaking plan to secure future of capital's libraries

headline: CARDBOARD CANOES TAKE TO THE THAMES
prcopy:
Cardboard canoes will be taking to the River Thames on Saturday 9 July as part of an event organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Local young people and families, as well as regular kayakers, will be making cardboard canoes on the banks of the Thames before racing them out on the river. The Cremorne Cardboard Canoe Challenge will consist of ten teams of designers racing to build the most river worthy kayak or canoe out of nothing but recycled cardboard and tape.

The event will be a fantastic opportunity for young people to discover what's on offer on their doorstep at the Council's Cremorne Riverside Centre, as well as a chance for families to get together for an affordable day out.

All ages are welcome for the build and barbecue, but children must be aged over nine and have parental consent if they want to set sail in their constructed canoe. The racers will be provided with buoyancy aids and supported by qualified coaches on the bank and in the water.

Council staff are volunteering their time to organise the day, and all proceeds raised will go to the Friends of Cremorne who support the centre and its work with local young people.

As well as having fun on the river there are some great prizes on offer for successful teams, including a signed Chelsea shirt.

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "This unusual event promises to be tremendous fun and a great opportunity for families to try their hand at building a canoe together and then paddling it on the Thames under the watchful eye of our instructors."

The event takes place at the Cremorne Riverside Centre, Cremorne Gardens, Lots Road, Chelsea, SW10 on Saturday 9 July from 12.30pm to 4pm and costs £2 for under 19s, £7.50 for adults and £5 concessions

The centre usually takes local young people, families and adults out on the Thames in more conventional plastic kayaks, running four drop in session a week for young people and trips and events for adult groups. Opened in 2008, the centre has so far enabled over 1,000 young people to get on the Thames in kayaks. Details of future events and regular sessions can be found online at www.rbkc.gov.uk/cremorne
shortdescription: Cardboard canoes will be taking to the River Thames on Saturday 9 July as part of an event organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Cardboard canoes take to the Thames

headline: FIND OUT HOW THE OLYMPIC ROUTE NETWORK WILL AFFECT YOU
prcopy:
Next summer, London will host the world's two largest sporting events, the Olympic and Paralympic Games - the equivalent of hosting 26 major world sports championships together in the same city at the same time.

As part of London's successful 2012 bid, a fast-track road network, called the Olympic and Paralympic Route Network (ORN/PRN), will be created so that athletes, officials, media and others working at the Games can get to events on time.

Transport for London (TfL) is responsible for ensuring this network operates effectively during the Games period, with the minimum of disruption for those who live and work in the capital.

The A4 from Earl's Court Road to Hyde Park Corner, is part of the route which will link Heathrow to the Olympic Park and other competition venues in east London via the A4.

General traffic will still be able to use this part of the ORN and residents and businesses will still have access to their properties. However, to keep traffic moving on the route there will be some temporary changes to the way roads in the area can be used.

Among these changes will be a special lane for official Games vehicles (the athletes, officials, media and others) as well as restrictions on turns into roads, some parking and loading suspensions and changes to bus lanes and stops. Where there is a Games Lane, a separate lane will still be available for general traffic. You can see a map of the route and further information provided by TfL at www.tfl.gov.uk/ORN

TfL will be writing to 22,000 households and businesses located within a 400m radius of the route in August 2011 to provide further information.

Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Cabinet Member for Transportation, said: "The ORN is going to play a vital part in making sure that athletes and officials can get to their events in time during the Games. This will of course lead to some disruption and will mean that people need to use other routes to get around. In order to give as much notice as possible I would encourage residents and businesses to come along to the drop-in sessions in the borough and to make sure they look at TfL's website."


Residents and businesses should look out for communications from TfL and see the attached overview map: www.tfl.gov.uk/ORN.

TfL will also be holding drop-in sessions in the borough, where you will be able to see the plans and speak to the project team.

They will take place at:

The Rembrandt Hotel, Elizabeth Suite, 11 Thurloe Place, London SW7 2RST
 Tuesday, 6 September 2011, 4.30pm to 7.30pm

Meeting Room, St Peter's Eaton Square, 119 Eaton Square, London SW1W 9AL
 Thursday, 8 September 2011, 11.30am to 2.30pm

Sainsbury's, 158a Cromwell Road, London SW7 4EJ
 Friday, 9 September 2011, 4.30pm to 7.30pm

You can send comments to TfL in the following ways:

 Website: www.tfl.gov.uk/ORN and click on `A4 Earl's Court Road to Hyde Park
Corner' to use the online form

 Email: ORNandPRNengagement@tfl.gov.uk

 Write to: TfL Olympic and Paralympic Route Network Engagement
Transport for London
5th Floor, Palestra
197 Blackfriars Road
London, SE1 8NJ

 Telephone: 0845 305 1234 8am to 8pm, Monday to Friday (You'll pay no more
than 5p per minute if calling from a BT landline. Charges from mobiles or other landline providers may vary)

When submitting your views please quote reference 35/001. Please note that the deadline for receiving your feedback on the plans is 14 September 2011.

Any feedback received by TfL will be taken in to account before they begin the statutory consultation process, which is part of the legal procedure for implementing the final measures. The statutory consultation process, which is currently due to start in late October, will be the opportunity for residents and businesses to make formal representation about the proposals and this will be advertised locally.

headline: PORTOBELLO BREWS UP TO SHOW COMMUNITY SPIRIT
prcopy:
Over 1,500 cups of tea were enjoyed when neighbours on Portobello Road came together on Friday 12 August to show the real spirit of the area following the public disorder and damage to local shops and restaurants.

`Operation Cup of Tea' brought Portobello businesses, market stallholders, local politicians and the public together to have a cuppa, eat some cake and discuss the events of the previous days.

The event was organised in just 48 hours by the Council and the Volunteer Centre Kensington and Chelsea. Nearly 40 volunteers helped out throughout the day, brewing 1,500 cups of tea and serving many biscuits and cakes as people chatted and got to know each other.

`Operation Cup of Tea' was supported by local businesses and voluntary organisations and attended by local politicians including Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Sir Malcolm Rifkind MP as well as other local Councillors.

Dozens of local residents donated cakes.

One local resident whose windows had been broken in disturbances said: "You don't know how much this means to me. I have been feeling so down and defeated after what happened but you being out here and all these people working together has completely lifted my spirits and made me feel so positive."

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, said: "This was a wonderful riposte to the ugly scenes witnessed in the local area. I know what the true spirit of our community is and saw it demonstrated as people offered their time, baked cakes and made tea for their neighbours. After all when things get tough there's often nothing better than talking to people over a cup of tea."

More `Operation Cup of Tea' events are now planned due to popular demand from local people, many of whom are now hard at work organising the next one, including ones on Sloane Square, Notting Hill Carnival, and Golborne Road.

For further information about the event and future events contact Caeli.Christianson@rbkc.gov.uk or follow @RBKC_Markets and @KirstyVCKC on twitter for updates.
shortdescription: Over 1,500 cups of tea were enjoyed when neighbours on Portobello Road came together on Friday 12 August to show the real spirit of the area following the public disorder and damage to local shops and restaurants.
shorttitle: Portobello brews up to show community spirit

headline: YOUNG MUMS GO FOR GOLD
prcopy:
Seven young mums from Kensington and Chelsea are raising funds to allow them to complete their Gold Duke of Edinburgh Award (DofE).

The mums, who have previously completed their Bronze and Silver Awards, have formed a group called `Changetogether' to help raise the £15,000 required to take them and their children on the expedition stage of the prestigious award.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was the first local authority to support young mothers to complete the full DofE Award with their children in tow. To date no group in the country has taken on a Gold Expedition but no challenge is too big for these mums.

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I wish these young mothers well in their efforts to raise funds for their Duke of Edinburgh expedition. Over the years the Award has inspired generations of young people to learn new skills and help in their community. It consistently shows the good things our young people are capable of."

So far the group has raised nearly £6,500 for their expedition. This has involved them raising money around Portobello Market dressed in only their pyjamas!

They were also successful in gaining funds from the Duke of Edinburgh Award Jubilee Fund, and are also planning a fun day in Westfield Park in September.

The mums plan to go to Holland for their assessment expedition in May 2012. They will travel for over eight hours a day, for five days, on bikes with the children in trailers, camping at night. They plan to meet with other young mothers in Holland. So please look out for them and show your support. If you would like more information or just to follow their journey please check out their web site www.changetogether.co.uk
shortdescription: Seven young mums from Kensington and Chelsea are raising funds to allow them to complete their Gold Duke of Edinburgh Award (DofE).
shorttitle: Young mums go for gold

headline: PATISSERIE OWNER FINED
prcopy:
A patisserie owner whose shop was found to be filthy by Environmental Health Officers pleaded guilty to five charges under the Food Hygiene Regulations 2006 and was fined £2,100 at West London Magistrates' Court yesterday (Wednesday 17 August) and ordered to pay costs of £2,701 and a £15 victim surcharge.

The court heard that when Environmental Health Officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea visited Reza Patisserie at 345 Kensington High Street, London W8 on 7 June 2010 they found the premises to be filthy, evidence of a mice and cockroach infestation, yoghurt, poultry and sausages stored at unsafe temperatures, and dirty equipment.

The court was also informed that on 20 April 2010 the owner, Mr Gholam Reza Shedy was convicted of one food safety and three food hygiene offences that occurred on 9 December 2008. These offences related to a lack of traceability for caviar, a failure to keep the premises clean, in good repair and a lack of a food safety management system.

Mr Shedy told the court that he had been trading for 30 years and that in recent years his business had been suffering with the introduction of the congestion charge. It was also explained that he has now taken matters very seriously and this month had completed a food hygiene course. A certificate to confirm this was presented to District Judge Williams.

In sentencing, Judge Williams said she had to increase the penalty from the previous conviction as this obviously was not effective. She also commented that the food produced at this premises looked appetizing so she was horrified to see the conditions it was produced in, and she could not believe that dairy products were being kept at 21 °C, given that this is a temperature that is regarded as being comfortable to work in an office environment, the fridges were clearly of little use.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "Clearly the hygiene standards at Reza Patisserie fell way short of what is expected. The public have a right to expect the food they buy to have been stored and prepared in clean conditions. I feel that the fine set is entirely justifiable under these circumstances."
shortdescription: A patisserie owner whose shop was found to be filthy by Environmental Health Officers pleaded guilty to five charges under the Food Hygiene Regulations 2006 and was fined £2,100 at West London Magistrates' Court yesterday (Wednesday 17 August) and ordered to pay costs of £2,701 and a £15 victim surcharge.
shorttitle: Patisserie owner fined

prcopy:

headline: DROP IN TO FIND OUT MORE ABOUT OLYMPIC ROUTE NETWORK
prcopy:
Next summer, London will host the world's two largest sporting events, the Olympic and Paralympic Games - the equivalent of hosting 26 major world sports championships together in the same city at the same time.

As part of London's successful 2012 bid, a fast-track road network, called the Olympic and Paralympic Route Network (ORN/PRN), will be created so that athletes, officials, media and others working at the Games can get to events on time.

Transport for London (TfL) is responsible for ensuring this network operates effectively during the Games period, with the minimum of disruption for those who live and work in the capital.

The A4 from Earl's Court Road to Hyde Park Corner, is part of the route which will link Heathrow to the Olympic Park and other competition venues in east London via the A4.

General traffic will still be able to use this part of the ORN and residents and businesses will still have access to their properties. However, to keep traffic moving on the route there will be some temporary changes to the way roads in the area can be used.

Among these changes will be a special lane for official Games vehicles (the athletes, officials, media and others) as well as restrictions on turns into roads, some parking and loading suspensions and changes to bus lanes and stops. Where there is a Games Lane, a separate lane will still be available for general traffic. You can see a map of the route and further information provided by TfL at www.tfl.gov.uk/ORN

TfL will be writing to 22,000 households and businesses located within a 400m radius of the route in August 2011 to provide further information.

Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Cabinet Member for Transportation, said: "The ORN is going to play a vital part in making sure that athletes and officials can get to their events in time during the Games. This will of course lead to some disruption and will mean that people need to use other routes to get around. In order to give as much notice as possible I would encourage residents and businesses to come along to the drop-in sessions in the borough and to make sure they look at TfL's website."

Residents and businesses should look out for communications from TfL and see the attached overview map: www.tfl.gov.uk/ORN.

TfL will also be holding drop-in sessions in the borough, where you will be able to see the plans and speak to the project team.

They will take place at:

The Rembrandt Hotel, Elizabeth Suite, 11 Thurloe Place, London SW7 2RST
 Tuesday, 6 September 2011, 4.30pm to 7.30pm

Meeting Room, St Peter's Eaton Square, 119 Eaton Square, London SW1W 9AL
 Thursday, 8 September 2011, 11.30am to 2.30pm

Sainsbury's, 158a Cromwell Road, London SW7 4EJ
 Friday, 9 September 2011, 4.30pm to 7.30pm

You can send comments to TfL in the following ways:

 Website: www.tfl.gov.uk/ORN and click on `A4 Earl's Court Road to Hyde Park Corner' to use the online form

 Email: ORNandPRNengagement@tfl.gov.uk

 Write to: TfL Olympic and Paralympic Route Network Engagement

Transport for London
5th Floor, Palestra
197 Blackfriars Road
London, SE1 8NJ

 Telephone: 0845 305 1234 8am to 8pm, Monday to Friday (You'll pay no more than 5p per minute if calling from a BT landline. Charges from mobiles or other landline providers may vary)

When submitting your views please quote reference 35/001. Please note that the deadline for receiving your feedback on the plans is 14 September 2011.

Any feedback received by TfL will be taken in to account before they begin the statutory consultation process, which is part of the legal procedure for implementing the final measures. The statutory consultation process, which is currently due to start in late October, will be the opportunity for residents and businesses to make formal representation about the proposals and this will be advertised locally.

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH SCHOOLS CELEBRATE GCSE SUCCESS
prcopy:
Pupils from Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea schools are celebrating GCSE success after the exam results were announced yesterday (Thursday 25 August).

The provisional figures for Kensington and Chelsea as a whole, for pupils gaining five or more A*to C grades including English and mathematics, is 73 per cent, up from 71 per cent in 2010. The pass rate for the subjects which contribute to the English Baccalaureate continues to be well above the national average.
The provisional results are:

At Holland Park School 98 per cent of students got five or more GCSEs graded A* to C. 77 per cent of the students got five or more GCSEs grade A* to C including English and maths, a ten per cent improvement on results in 2010.

At St Thomas More Language College 94 per cent of pupils achieved five or more GCSEs graded A* to C, with 70 per cent getting five or more GCSEs grade A* to C including English and maths, a five per cent improvement on results in 2010.

At Sion Manning School 56 per cent of pupils passed five or more GCSEs grade A* to C including English and maths, down five per cent from last year.

At Cardinal Vaughan Memorial School 92 per cent of pupils achieved five or more GCSEs graded A* to C and 90 per cent of pupils passed five or more GCSEs grade A* to C including English and maths, the same as last year. 58 per cent of all GCSEs taken were graded at A*to A.

Colin Hall, Head of Holland Park School, said: "These are a marvellous set of results for our students and reflect their hard work and that of the staff. I congratulate them all and look forward to seeing them go on to further success at A level."

Dr Trevor Papworth, Head Teacher of St Thomas More Language College, said: "We are extremely pleased to have achieved our best ever results, as this can only mean that more students than ever from the school can go on to advance their studies on courses of their choice. One can only stand back and congratulate the students for all the effort they have put into their studies and thank those who have supported them. Namely, for the help they have received from their homes, and the extra mile all the staff from St Thomas More Language College have gone to in helping them achieve their potential. I truly thank them for that."

At the Latimer Education Centre all students entered for examinations gained one or more A* to G grades at GCSE or equivalent.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "These are really excellent results. They are a reward for many hours hard work by pupils and teachers in all of our schools and I congratulate everyone concerned. I am particularly pleased to see so many of our young people passing English and Mathematics.

"Results like this show just why we are so proud of our schools."
shortdescription: Pupils from Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea schools are celebrating GCSE success after the exam results were announced yesterday (Thursday 25 August).
shorttitle: Royal Borough schools celebrate GCSE success

headline: RESIDENTS ENJOY SEASIDE BREAK FROM CARNIVAL
prcopy:
Forty-five elderly Notting Hill residents enjoyed a tour of the historic town of Hastings on Bank Holiday Sunday as part of a weekend break away from the noise and crowds of Carnival, thanks to a scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The scheme aimed at older people living directly on the Carnival route is now in its eight year.

Residents were driven to the Glastonbury Hotel in Eastbourne on Saturday 27 August where they enjoyed an evening of dancing. They will return to their homes on Tuesday 30 August, once the Council has had time to clear up and the area is quieter.

Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Council, said: "Although the Carnival is an exciting event, we do sympathise with older residents for whom large crowds and loud noise make the weekend a difficult time. Due to the success of previous trips, we have decided to run the scheme again to offer another group of elderly people a break away from the clamour of the Carnival."

All applications were assessed by Adult Social Care Services and those who had not been on the trip before were given priority.

headline: CARNIVAL CLEAN-UP
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea cleaned up an estimated 180 tonnes of rubbish from the roads of Notting Hill following this year's Carnival.

Some 164 SITA crew worked into the early hours on the operation, which involved 19 refuse trucks and nine mechanical sweepers. The Council also had a big motorway vehicle washing down the roads. The clean-up started at 10pm on Monday 29 August and finished at 3pm on Tuesday 30 August.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, and the Mayor, Cllr Julie Mills, joined one of the refuse crews working on the Carnival clean-up.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, said:

"With hundreds of thousands of people attending the event, there was a considerable amount of rubbish. We are very grateful to our contractor, SITA, and the Council officers who worked exceptionally hard to ensure the streets were cleaned and returned to normal as quickly as possible.

"We also negotiated with the police to keep the roads closed for longer into the night, and this helped tremendously with the clean-up operation. Our priority was to clear the streets as swiftly as possible to ensure minimum disruption for residents, and we expect to be able to recycle a high proportion of the waste we collected."

In 2010 some 241 tonnes of waste was collected by the Royal Borough following Carnival and 99 tonnes (40 per cent) was recycled.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea cleaned up an estimated 180 tonnes of rubbish from the roads of Notting Hill following this year's Carnival.
shorttitle: Carnival clean-up

headline: WHOLE FOODS MARKET FINED £2,000 FOR MISLEADING FOOD LABEL
prcopy:
Whole Foods Market, Kensington High Street was fined £2,000 for failing to inform a customer about the presence of walnuts in one of its products.

At West London Magistrates' Court yesterday (Wednesday 7 September) Fresh & Wild Ltd, the owners of Whole Foods Market, pleaded guilty to labelling and presenting food in a manner that misled the consumer.

The Court heard that on 5 July 2010 a customer visited the deli counter at Whole Foods 63-97 Kensington High Street, and bought one portion of Aubergine Rollatini Spinach for £1.29. The customer who sufferers from a severe nut allergy checked the label and walnuts were not listed in the ingredients or on the label. Shortly after she bought the product, she bit into it and immediately realised that it contained nuts and suffered an allergic reaction, and was admitted to hospital for eight hours in order to be stabilised. The customer sent an email to Whole Foods and copied it to the Council's Environmental Health Food team complaining about the incident.

Whole Foods told the court that this has never happened before and that they have since served over two million customers where it has not happened. Prior to this incident they already had a set of systems in place which addressed the handling of known food allergens, and they believed that the incident was caused by an oversight in which walnuts were accidentally omitted. Following the incident they reviewed their labelling process and have added even tighter controls on the store operations side of the business.

In sentencing District Judge Jeremy Colman said he was impressed with the steps taken by the business. However, the consequences of this matter could have been very different. Thankfully the victim has now made a full recovery. This was a rather unfortunate situation for all those concerned and having considered all the evidence he saw fit to fine Whole Foods Market.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "The public have a right to expect the food they buy is correctly and properly labelled and the fine imposed by the court reflects the seriousness of the failure to label food properly. I am pleased that Whole Foods has reviewed its processes following this incident. If any resident thinks a food product has been labelled incorrectly they should report it to the Council's Environmental Health Food Team."

In addition to the fine the company was ordered to pay £2,321.03 in costs and a £15 victim surcharge.
