shorttitle: Whole Foods Market fined £2,000 for misleading food label

headline: ARTS IN EDUCATION OPEN EVENING
prcopy:
More than 50 arts organisations and cultural institutions will descend on Kensington Town Hall on Tuesday 20 September, as part of a free Arts in Education Open Evening.

From 4 to 7pm, Kensington Town Hall, Hornton St, will open its doors to leading arts organisations such as the English National Ballet, Royal College of Music, Victoria and Albert Museum, Royal Court Theatre, Serpentine Gallery and Cineclub.

The event has been organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Culture and Library Services, and is specially designed for teachers working in the boroughs of Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham, and Westminster. It provides them with an informal networking opportunity to form links with individuals and organisations from across the arts and culture sector, who can complement their work in the classroom. Families, individuals and members of community groups are also welcome.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Mayor, Councillor Julie Mills, will open the event, in the company of guest speaker, the acclaimed children's author Kaye Umansky.

On the day a number of artists will run workshops with specially invited groups of schoolchildren. Children from Ashburnham Primary School will attend a practical workshop with the British Society of Sculptors, Bousfield Primary pupils will have a Q and A session with author Kaye Umansky (best-known for her Pongwiffy series), and children from the Chelsea Open Air Nursery will take part in a poetry workshop.

Attendees will also be treated to performances from Opera Holland Park and the Royal College of Music. Library staff from Westminster, Hammersmith & Fulham and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea will be on hand to promote their services.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said:

"This is an excellent networking opportunity for teachers and pupils from three London boroughs to build relationships with those who can really help bring the curriculum to life and make learning fun.

"I hope that local residents will also come along and find out about the wealth of exciting cultural and artistic opportunities on their doorstep."

For further information contact Alan Kirwan by email at Alan.Kirwan@rbkc.gov.uk or phone 020 7361 3618. Please visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/openday
shortdescription: More than 50 arts organisations and cultural institutions will descend on Kensington Town Hall on Tuesday 20 September, as part of a free Arts in Education Open Evening.
shorttitle: Arts in Education Open Evening

headline: BOOK NOW FOR NOVEMBER'S LONDON HISTORY FESTIVAL
prcopy:
This November some of the country's leading historians and authors are taking part in the London History Festival, organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

In partnership with Waterstone's and sponsored by `History Today' magazine, festival-goers can listen to lectures and discussions from leading authors and historians including Simon Sebag Montefiore, Max Hastings, Norman Davies and Claire Tomalin.

Diverse and thought-provoking topics will be covered including: the power and violence which have shaped the histories of Jerusalem and Russia, women in history, the Second World War at home and on the frontline, and the life and times of Charles Dickens.

The festival takes place from 14 to 24 November 2011 and events are taking place at Kensington Central Library, W8 and also Waterstone's on Kensington High Street (193 Kensington High Street).

Tickets are now on sale and entry to each event costs £5 (£3 for concessions) and booking is advised. Tickets for events at Kensington Central Library can be purchased from any library in Kensington and Chelsea, or by writing to Local Studies, Kensington Central Library, Hornton Street, W8 7RX. Cheques should be made payable to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. Tickets can also be purchased by credit or debit card by calling 020 7361 3010. Tickets for Waterstone's events can be purchased from Waterstone's on Kensington High Street or by calling 0843 290 8419.

Thanks to a partnership with Bloomsbury Publishing, author Richard Van Emden will also be appearing in late October at Kensington Central Library.

Staff at Kensington Palace have created a special collection of books and audio items based on famous people associated with the palace, chosen from the library's extensive biography store. In November this collection will be on special display in Kensington Central Library.

For more information about the festival visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/londonhistory or visit www.londonhistoryfestival.com

headline: BECOME A FOSTER CARER
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is recruiting foster carers for children from the borough.

Foster carers are wanted for children and young people of all ages, faiths and cultural backgrounds. No formal qualifications are needed, but qualities such as good listening skills, flexibility, optimism, patience and resilience are perfect for the role.

Children may be placed for periods from just one night to two years with most returning to their families within six months. In return, the Council provides training and support along with financial assistance.

Residents considering fostering can find out more at information evenings in September and October. The first event will be held on Thursday 22 September, from 6pm to 8pm at Kensington Town Hall, Hornton Street, W8 7NX and the second will take place on Thursday 20 October, from 6pm to 8pm at Isaac Newton Centre, 108A Lancaster Road, W11 1QS.

Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, Cllr Baroness Ritchie, said: "Foster carers have the ability to change a young person's life for the better. It can be challenging but highly rewarding at the same time.

"The Council provides good training and financial support for Kensington and Chelsea's foster carers. I encourage anyone who is considering fostering to attend one of the information evenings."

Two foster carers in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Daniela and Scott, said: "One of the most special experiences for us has been to see how only a little bit of help can sometimes be quite life changing for the families."

For more information about fostering in Kensington and Chelsea, go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/fosterus or call free on 0800 1832400. You can also watch our films of foster carers on our website.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is recruiting foster carers for children from the borough.
shorttitle: Become a foster carer

headline: OPEN HOUSE WELCOMES OPEN SCHOOL
prcopy:
For the first time, one of the Royal Borough's primary schools will be featuring in the London Open House weekend. Taking place on Saturday 17 and Sunday 18 September, Park Walk Primary School will open its doors to the public, for free, to help celebrate the architecture of London.

Park Walk Primary is listed Grade II by English Heritage, and visitors to the school will receive an architect's tour. This will include the exciting lift installation designed to offer more than mere elevation. A lift zone was created which stimulates children's educational curiosity with an impressive display of life size animal murals, whilst the rear face of the lift car is glazed to allow views of nocturnal animals.

The school received recognition for its architecture in 2010 when it won an award for the best nursery toilet facilities in the country, voted for by the British Toilet Association.

The combination of Grade II listed external architecture and the innovations in the lift area, are sure to make an impressive addition to this year's Open House London.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "We are proud that this is the first time one of the Royal Borough's primary schools has featured in the Open House London weekend.

"This is testament to the hard work of the Council staff, architects, the school and English Heritage whose efforts ensured a stunning piece of architecture was enhanced sensitively and in worthwhile manner.

"I would urge local residents to visit the school this weekend to see for themselves how this project has made a significant improvement to the daily experience of the pupils."

headline: BEWARE OF BOGUS CALLERS ROADSHOWS
prcopy:
Elderly residents are being encouraged to beware of bogus callers and scammers through a series of free workshops and theatre performances organised by the Council, police and Age Concern Kensington and Chelsea.

The Safe and Sure roadshows are aimed at senior residents, particularly those living by themselves to help raise awareness of scams and bogus callers as well as build their confidence and take action to avoid becoming a victim.

The first event takes place on Friday 16 September, from 10.30am to noon at New Horizons, Guinness Trust Estate, SW3 2PF.

Other events take place on:

Thursday 22 September from 10.30am at Venture Community Association, 103a Wornington Road, W10 5YB

Thursday 22 September from 2.30pm at Gloucester Court Sheltered Housing, 2 Bassett Road, W10 6JJ

All are free to attend and features role-playing scenarios brought to life by a local theatre company. Council trading standards officers and the police will also be on hand to offer information and advice.

The roadshows will be taking place across the borough throughout September, with the final event on Wednesday 28 September, from 2.30pm at St Mary The Boltons Church, The Boltons, SW10 9TB.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, the Council's Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said:

"Elderly residents can often find themselves being targeted by bogus sales people, fake lottery letters and telephone scams.

"The Safe and Sure roadshows help older residents recognise scams and the role playing scenarios helps to build their confidence in handling these situations."

For more information and a list of dates and venues, contact Tasio Cabello at Age Concern Kensington and Chelsea on 020 8969 9105.
shortdescription: Elderly residents are being encouraged to beware of bogus callers and scammers through a series of free workshops and theatre performance organised by the Council, police and Age Concern Kensington and Chelsea.

headline: HISTORIC PORTOBELLO LOOS RETURNED TO FORMER GLORY
prcopy:
Visitors to the world-famous Portobello Market are now only steps away from two newly restored Edwardian public lavatories, thanks to the Council.

Located in Bevington Road and Talbot Road, the toilets have been sympathetically restored keeping as many original features as possible. The original urinals at Talbot Road have been preserved and characteristic Edwardian-style floor tiles adorn the floors of both toilets.

First opened around 1914, the Bevington Road public lavatories, serving Golborne Road Market, are thought to be the oldest in the Royal Borough. Along with the Talbot Road facilities, which opened a short while later, they are typical of the Edwardian period.

The Talbot Road lavatories were closed during the 1990s but local traders have campaigned for them to be reopened.

Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, said: "Close to 60,000 people visit the market each Saturday so these new facilities will be in much demand. I know that local traders and residents will be pleased with the high quality of work that has restored age-old lavatories to their former glory."

The Talbot Road lavatory will be open Fridays and Saturdays 8am to 6pm, and the Bevington Road lavatory will be open Monday to Thursday 9am to 6pm and Friday and Saturday 8am to 6pm.
shortdescription: Visitors to the world-famous Portobello Market are now only steps away from two newly restored Edwardian public lavatories, thanks to the Council.
shorttitle: Historic Portobello loos returned to former glory

headline: GREEN LIGHT FOR KENSINGTON ALDRIDGE ACADEMY
prcopy:
The creation of a new academy in North Kensington has taken an important leap forward recently with formal approval from the Government of funding of £17.6m as a contribution towards the cost of the construction of the new buildings.

The Lead Sponsor, the Aldridge Foundation, and the co-sponsor, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, have jointly signed an agreement with Schools Minister Lord Hill. The signing of the `funding agreement' is a key milestone in the process of creating the Academy in September 2014.

Speaking for the Aldridge Foundation, its Chairman Rod Aldridge, said: "Confirmation of the way forward is wonderful news for the prospective pupils, parents and the community. It will provide a fantastic environment within which learning and high quality teaching can flourish and a wide variety of choices, both academic and vocational, will be offered. The new buildings will also be an asset for the community and an inspiring example of what can be achieved."

Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough, commented "Our young people badly need a new school in North Kensington and we are going to do all we can to provide them with one. This Government contribution is a massive and very welcome vote of confidence in the scheme we are developing with the Aldridge Foundation."

"But we still have a long way to go. We have to make sure the finances stack up, we have to do a lot more consultation and of course we need to submit a credible planning application. We have a lot of work ahead of us."

The Kensington Aldridge Academy will open in September 2014 on the site adjacent to the Kensington Leisure Centre on Silchester Road. The Academy will be a non-fee paying, non-faith, mixed 11-18 school with 900 11-16 year olds and a sixth form of up to 240.

A new secondary school is urgently needed for North Kensington. Over 50 per cent of local students travel outside the borough for their secondary education. Over 77 per cent of respondents to a recent public consultation were in favour of the Academy.

Several design forums will soon be established to share and discuss the possible design schemes for the Academy with the local community.
keyword3: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: The creation of a new academy in North Kensington has taken an important leap forward recently with formal approval from the Government of funding of £17.6m as a contribution towards the cost of the construction of the new buildings.
shorttitle: Green light for Kensington Aldridge Academy

headline: Blooming success for Royal Borough
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea was again the delighted recipient of a host of awards at `London in Bloom', held at City Hall, last Friday 16 September.

The Royal Borough gained a prestigious Gold in the City category for the second year running. Holland Park also repeated last year's excellent result by maintaining its Gold standard, and was joined by Little Wormwood Scrubs, Cremorne and Kensington Memorial Park. There was also good news for Gunnersbury Cemetery which won Cemetery of the Year and a Gold Award.

As well as these excellent results the borough's parks also secured Silver-gilt awards for Westfield and St Luke's and the borough came second in the Floral Display category.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Cabinet Member for Transportation, Environment and Leisure, said: "It was a fantastic evening last Friday. I am delighted that the London in Bloom judges were able to give the borough such recognition. Residents and Council officers work hard and take pride in how the borough looks and this is a great result for all of them.

"It is good news to see how many of our parks have progressed from Sliver Gilt, to Gold and also the number that have maintained the excellent results from last year. It is particularly gratifying for everyone that the Royal Borough has secured Gold in the City category for the second year running, I would like to say thank you to everyone involved in making the borough's green spaces the wonderful places that they are."

The Council works closely with many groups throughout the year to ensure the borough is always at its best, among these are the Brighter Kensington and Chelsea Scheme, Kensington Gardeners Club and Chelsea Gardens Guild.
shortdescription: Kensington and Chelsea was again the delighted recipient of a host of awards at `London in Bloom', held at City Hall, last Friday 16 September.
shorttitle: Blooming success for Royal Borough

headline: TACKLING SOCIAL ISOLATION
prcopy:
Broadcaster and comedienne Ruby Wax, with singer-songwriter Judith Owen, delighted an audience at Kensington Town Hall yesterday, raising funds for a new centre for social isolation in the north of the borough.

The event was hosted by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Julie Mills, together with local resident Jill Shaw Ruddock, founder of The Second Half of Your Life Foundation. The foundation is opening The Second Half Centre at St Charles Hospital in 2012. The centre is the brainchild of Jill Shaw Ruddock and sets out to challenge the stereotypical image of centres for older people. When open, it will offer a vibrant and exciting range of services to people of all interests and backgrounds.

The Mayor said: "One of my ambitions this year is to help the isolated members of our community. All too often, older people find they have few opportunities to meet others, expand their interests, hone their skills and improve their health. This new centre offers all of those things and much more. It will give people a reason to go out and - like New Horizons in Chelsea - it will provide a hub for activities which promote positive and successful ageing.

"I look forward to opening the centre officially in the New Year, and I must thank Jill for all the hard work she has done to make this happen."

Working in partnership with existing well-established local charities, the centre will be a place where men and women can come together to have fun, connect socially, learn new skills, exercise and benefit from a multifaceted education programme of classes and lectures.
shortdescription: Broadcaster and comedienne Ruby Wax, with singer-songwriter Judith Owen, delighted an audience at Kensington Town Hall yesterday, raising funds for a new centre for social isolation in the north of the borough.
shorttitle: Tackling social isolation

headline: RESTAURANT DIRECTOR BANNED FROM FOOD INDUSTRY FOR TWO YEARS
prcopy:
The director of a restaurant, who allowed his premises to be overrun with mice, causing food to become contaminated, has been prohibited from managing or working in any food business for two years.

Mr Mohamed Eid pleaded guilty at West London Magistrates' Court yesterday (Tuesday 20 September) to six charges in relation to: placing unsafe food on the market; not keeping the premises clean; failing to ensure food was protected from contamination; failing to have adequate pest procedures in place; premises not kept in a good state of repair and condition; and not protecting food from contamination likely to render food unfit for human consumption.

Environmental Health Officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea visited Al Dar III Limited (trading as Falamanki) at 221 Kensington High Street in August 2010, and found the premises, to be infested by mice. They discovered spice mix contaminated by mice faeces and butterbeans and walnuts gnawed by the rodents. The officers also trapped 43 live mice.

The officers closed the premises down immediately.

Mr Eid told the court that he had had health problems and that his manager, who looked after the premises, had allowed conditions to get as bad as they did.

District Judge Williams acknowledged Mr Eid's health problems and took into account the fact that the company is no longer trading, the fact that the restaurant was closed for ten days whilst Mr Eid cleaned it up after the Council's inspection and the fact he pleaded guilty. She also noted that the Council was satisfied with the cleanliness of the premises when he reopened for business.

The judge issued Mr Eid a Community Order prohibiting him from managing, directing and working in any food business for two years. District Judge Williams told Mr Eid that these were serious offences and mice droppings in food could have resulted in customers becoming seriously ill.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "Mr Eid's premises were in a shocking state which put the health of his customers at risk. I am extremely relieved that the Court has supported the swift action of the Council's officers."
shortdescription: The director of a restaurant, who allowed his premises to be overrun with mice, causing food to become contaminated, has been prohibited from managing or working in any food business for two years.
shorttitle: Restaurant director banned from food industry for two years

headline: NEW AFFORDABLE HOMES IN NORTH KENSINGTON
prcopy:
Much needed affordable new homes will be provided following a decision last night (Thursday 22 September) by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet to choose Peabody as its development partner to build 63 new homes on the Silchester Garages site. Thirty of these will be large family homes available through social renting, with the remainder smaller properties for shared ownership.

The provision of new housing was a condition of the development of land at Holland Park School. The planning permission for the school's redevelopment created an obligation to develop 63 units of affordable housing on the Council-owned Silchester Garages site.

Peabody will receive a grant of £2,925,000 from the Council, financed from the sale of part of the Holland Park School site.

The development will help the Council meet its targets for the delivery of new housing of all tenures in the borough. The proposals extend further than the existing planning permission, and will involve the demolition of fourteen one-bedroom flats to enable an extra 15 social rented homes, six shared ownership and 28 homes for market sale to be built. It will also contribute to the regeneration of the Latimer area through improved urban design and a more balanced tenure mix.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Housing, said: "Good quality affordable housing is in great demand in the borough and this development will help to address this need. I am very pleased that we have been able to select Peabody to develop these much needed homes in North Kensington."
shortdescription: Much needed affordable new homes will be provided following a decision last night (Thursday 22 September) by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet to choose Peabody as its development partner to build 63 new homes on the Silchester Garages site. Thirty of these will be large family homes available through social renting, with the remainder smaller properties for shared ownership.
shorttitle: New affordable homes in North Kensington

headline: NEW OPEN SPACE FOR NORTH KENSINGTON
prcopy:
Residents, churchgoers and children will gather this Sunday (25 September) to celebrate the transformation of a dark underused corner of land beside All Saints Church, Clydesdale Road in North Kensington, into a bright pocket park complete with play area and specially commissioned artwork.

The opening of All Saints pocket park is the culmination of a partnership between local residents and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Notting Hill Housing Group, the environmental charity Groundwork and a local Montessori school. The work was undertaken by the Royal Borough Environment Project after an extensive public consultation.

The improvements included completely relandscaping the area, adding new surfaces and plants, thinning the thick tree canopy and adding new play and art features.

The artwork at the front of the site is a memorial to local author and philosopher John Michell and was donated by his friends.

Fr. Jonathan Brownsell, parish priest of All Saints Church, has other reasons to cheer as his church, which owns the land and leases it Notting Hill Housing Group, is marking its 150th anniversary and he is celebrating his 35th anniversary as parish priest.

Praising the community collaboration, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea said: "What better way to celebrate All Saint's 150 anniversary than to transform this underused corner of the area into a bright pocket park with something for all local residents whether they are one or 100-years old. I'd like to congratulate and thank everyone for their help in redesigning this open space and hope it will be enjoyed by many for years to come."
shortdescription: Residents, churchgoers and children will gather this Sunday (25 September) to celebrate the transformation of a dark underused corner of land beside All Saints Church, Clydesdale Road in North Kensington, into a bright pocket park complete with play area and specially commissioned artwork.
shorttitle: New open space for North Kensington

headline: BRENT BACKS PLANS FOR KENSAL CROSSRAIL
prcopy:
The Royal Borough's plan to bring a Crossrail station to North Kensington is now being supported by neighbouring Brent Council.

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I am delighted that Brent Council is backing our plans for a Crossrail station in Kensal. There is now an impressive alliance of councils, MPs and London Assembly Members, cutting across political parties, supporting us. These are joined by local businesses, social landlords and residents' groups who all see the massive opportunity to improve public transport and boost the local economy.

"I hope that those in London and national government, who will eventually make the decision, will see the benefit that this station will bring and deliver Crossrail for Kensal."

Councillor Ann John OBE, Brent Council Leader, said: "Brent Council supports the development of a Crossrail station in the Kensal area. The station would greatly improve public transport for residents and businesses in the south of Brent. The station would mean residents living in areas as Kensal Green, Kensal Rise and Harlesden would be linked to all of London by the most up-to-date public transport system.

"In addition, the building and development of such a major transport infrastructure project would help to not only regenerate Kensington and Chelsea but the south of Brent as well, offering significant new opportunities in terms of jobs and housing for many of our residents."

A station in Kensal would transform accessibility in an area poorly served by public transport and help trigger a major development of the 67 acre former gas works site which is capable of accommodating more than 2,500 new homes as well as new business and community facilities.

The proposals have received much support since Kensington and Chelsea Council announced earlier this year that it had committed to underwrite the £33m construction costs. MPs Karen Buck, Sarah Teather and Sir Malcolm Rifkind, and London Assembly member Jenny Jones, are all behind a new station. London Deputy Mayor Kit Malthouse described the case for Kensal Crossrail as "overwhelming". Other supporters include National Grid, Portobello Antiques Dealers' Association, Cath Kidston, Westway Development Trust, Kensington and Chelsea Chamber of Commerce and Sainsbury's.

For full details of the Council's proposals for Kensal Crossrail, go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/crossrail
shortdescription: The Royal Borough's plan to bring a Crossrail station to North Kensington is now being supported by neighbouring Brent Council.
shorttitle: Brent backs plans for Kensal Crossrail

headline: COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS AND YOUNG ATHLETES SET FOR GAMES TICKETS
prcopy:
People in the Royal Borough who make a positive contribution and commitment to the life of the borough will be eligible for tickets for both the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games.

A nomination process, to help select who the tickets go to, will be launched at the end of this year. As well as nominations for outstanding young sportsmen and women, the coaches and volunteers who are the backbone of the borough's youth and sports clubs, residents will be able to champion volunteers and community workers who give their time and expertise in so many other important areas of our community life.

In March 2011, the Royal Borough's Cabinet decided to buy 100 tickets for the Olympic Games, and on Thursday 22 September they agreed to purchase another 100 tickets for the Paralympic Games.

Paralympic tickets cost less than those for the Olympic Games and range between £10 and £350. Councillors agreed £4,240 to fund the cost of the tickets as a one-off cost from the Better City Life reserves.

One nomination process will select recipients for both sets of tickets.

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Having the Olympic and Paralympic Games on our doorstep is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and one that our young athletes, those who devote themselves to helping them, as well as those who volunteer in other ways, should get a chance to experience at first hand."
shortdescription: People in the Royal Borough who make a positive contribution and commitment to the life of the borough will be eligible for tickets for both the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games.
shorttitle: Community volunteers and young athletes set for Olympic and Paralympic Games tickets

headline: WINNING ARCHITECT ANNOUNCED FOR ACADEMY AND LEISURE CENTRE
prcopy:
The competition to design a new academy and leisure centre for North Kensington has been won by a Studio E-led team that includes sports and leisure specialists LA Architects as well as building engineers Max Fordham and Curtin and Churchman landscape architects.

Based in Hammersmith, Studio E is a multi-award winning architectural practice with several school and leisure centre projects already under its belt. These include the City Academy Hackney, the Skinners Academy Hackney, the Ark Academy Wembley, and sports centres in Watford, in Bathgate and for the American Community School in Cobham.

As well as being familiar with the challenges of building schools and leisure centres, Studio E is also familiar with the Royal Borough. In 1999 it was responsible for the award winning redesign of Emslie Horniman Pleasance, in 2003 it designed the classroom of the future at St Francis of Assisi primary school and more recently it completed the eye-catching sports and IT extension to St Charles Catholic Sixth Form College.

More than 40 firms entered the competition to design the new academy and leisure centre. Studio E was selected from a shortlist of six, following presentations to a panel of councillors together with a representative of the Council's co-sponsor. The shortlisted designs were also on show to local residents at an exhibition earlier this month. Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environment and Leisure and Chairman of the selection panel, said: "The shortlisted designs showed some real energy and ingenuity. We drew great encouragement from them that we will be able to deliver a fine new school and leisure centre for the people of North Kensington."

Studio E will now develop a series of design options for the academy and leisure centre. These will be reviewed by a new community panel consisting of local residents and groups during the autumn before they are presented to the Council's Cabinet in December when a final decision will be taken as to whether or not the project can proceed.

Subject to Cabinet approval, the designs will then form a planning application that is expected to be submitted in April 2012. This will be subject to a full programme of pre-submission consultation with local residents in early 2012. There will also be further statutory consultation as part of the legal requirements of seeking planning permission in the borough. A decision by the Council's Planning Committee is then expected in the summer of 2012.
shortdescription: The competition to design a new academy and leisure centre for North Kensington has been won by a Studio E-led team that includes sports and leisure specialists LA Architects as well as building engineers Max Fordham and Curtin and Churchman landscape architects.
shorttitle: Winning architect announced for academy and leisure centre

headline: FIRST £1M SAVINGS FROM SHARING SENIOR COUNCIL POSTS
prcopy:
The Leaders of three leading councils announced Monday 3 October that the project to share council services across Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster is on track to realise its first £1m of savings by cutting senior management roles. This includes saving:
 £320k by sharing a single Director of Children's Services;
 £320k by sharing a single Director of Adult Services;
 £100k by sharing a single Director of Libraries;
 £150k by combining environmental services across Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea; and
 £120k by making a joint appointment to the Director for Schools' Quality and Standards between Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea.

This news comes as they publish a new analysis of the potential for shared services focusing on seven lessons learnt during the first year of Tri-borough working. The guide to encourage innovation and sharing services was launched at an event with Eric Pickles MP, Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government.

The proposals will protect vital front line services at a time of necessary financial adjustment and will lead to a 50 per cent reduction in the number of middle and senior managers. There will also be a 50 per cent reduction in the overheads attached to front line services to the public.

In the pamphlet `Driving change: leadership, trust and money' they show the success to date of the Tri-borough plan to combine services, including `strong leadership, a robust business case and momentum to change'.

Commenting on the publication of the report, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of Kensington and Chelsea said: "Our initial success shows that our approach offers lessons to other local authorities wanting to follow our lead. It has not been easy but the right mixture of strong political drive, excellent officer advice, high trust, comprehensive communications and forensic attention to the business case for sharing services has already resulted in impressive results. "

Leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Cllr Stephen Greenhalgh commented: "Residents expect us to strain every sinew to deliver better services with fewer resources. One of the ways we can protect the front line is to strip out unnecessary and duplicated management overheads. This report shows how, by sharing the top jobs, it is possible to reduce the bill for senior managers by millions of pounds."

Colin Barrow, Leader of Westminster added: "These proposals offer a better way than cutting services to meet the £100m savings target facing the three councils.

"Our residents will be able to access the best the other boroughs have to offer. We will keep vital services like libraries open and make over one million books available to people across the three boroughs. Our first joint campaign - `Summer in the City' has already offered over 200 summer activities to families from all three councils.

"And we will do all this while making big savings through combining top and middle management jobs."

headline: COULD YOU FOSTER?

headline: ANYONE FOR TENNIS?
prcopy:

headline: FUNDING FILLIP FOR LOCAL INITIATIVES
prcopy:
Residents in each of the borough's 18 electoral wards have the opportunity to access up to £20,000 in community funds to improve their local area and develop neighbourhood initiatives.

'City Living, Local Life' aims to get Councillors and their communities working together to develop practical solutions to local issues, with £20,000 being allocated to each ward.

People who want to find out how to get involved should come along to Tea in the Park this Saturday, 15 October, in Holland Park, near the cafe, between 10am and 3pm. They will be able to meet local Councillors and discuss over a cuppa how they can use the scheme to make a difference.

Similar schemes have already paid dividends for a number of local communities.

In Golborne, locals opted for a "loveGolborne" campaign to encourage local pride and increase tourism. While residents in the St Charles ward tackled antisocial behaviour by young people in the Dalgarno area which resulted in establishing an Air Cadets programme, running a local football tournament and developing a youth outreach scheme. Colville ward residents opted to set up a forum so councillors and local people could discuss what projects they wanted to prioritise. This has resulted in bringing like-minded residents together who are now involved in a variety of projects including community gardening ventures.

Cabinet Member for Civil Society Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen said: "We recognise and celebrate the diversity within our borough, and so this exciting initiative is intended to enable Councillors in all wards to work with local residents on whatever the local priorities might be. There is no central paradigm or strict set of rules; instead, this is true localism in practice.

"This money is not intended to be enough to solve all problems but should help get projects started or provide a fillip to some that are already underway. There is no limit to the number of projects that may be agreed by a ward provided it is within budget. You could even get Councillors collaborating across ward boundaries if this offers a way to address local issues."

For further information email locallife@rbkc.gov.uk, phone the Community Engagement Team on 020 7598 4633 or go to www.citylivinglocallife.org.

headline: TWO BOROUGHS, ONE CHIEF EXECUTIVE
prcopy:
Two of Britain's best local authorities now share a single Chief Executive, following a joint appointment at Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea.

Derek Myers, who has been Chief Executive of Kensington and Chelsea since 2000, will take the helm at both councils after his appointment was ratified by Hammersmith & Fulham Council. (Wednesday 19 October).

The move, which will save the two authorities some £200,000 a year, is the latest in a series of senior management shares between three west London councils.

In May this year Westminster, Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea agreed radical plans to combine a range of services. Children's services, adult social care and libraries are already in the process of being shared and single `Tri-borough' directors have been appointed for each. Under the plan, there will be approximately 500 management and back office jobs lost across the three boroughs.

The overall proposals are expected to save taxpayers in the three authorities £33.4 million by 2014/15 while leading to improvements in many areas. For example, residents will have access to all 21 libraries, with more than one million books, hundreds of entertainment and cultural events and scores of weekly skills and education classes on offer.

While more services are likely to be combined across the three authorities, in some cases it has proved more practicable for now to share between Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea.

Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham will not only share a Chief Executive, but also the management and delivery of environmental services such as waste management, leisure, transportation, licensing and environmental heath. The two boroughs already share a director of legal services and a director of transportation and highways.

"If we are going to protect our frontline services then management and back offices must take the brunt of the savings programme," explained the Leader of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell. "The savings go right to the very top, and one of the reasons that is possible is because in Derek Myers we have someone capable of taking on the role of dual chief executive, notwithstanding its scale and complexity."

Before joining Kensington and Chelsea, Derek Myers was Chief Executive at the London Borough of Hounslow and before that its director of social services. He holds degrees in economics and law and is a qualified social worker.

Derek replaces Geoff Alltimes CBE who is retiring after more than 30 years of service. Geoff has been Chief Executive since 2002 having previously worked as Director of Social Services. Between April 2009 and October 2010 he was chief executive of both Hammersmith & Fulham Council and NHS Hammersmith & Fulham. Geoff joined the Council in 1976 as a social worker team leader.

Geoff is continuing his work for the independent NHS Future Forum, the group commissioned by the Government to listen to the views of patients, staff and the public in looking at ways to modernise the NHS.

Cllr Stephen Greenhalgh, Leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Council, said: "At a time when the state of the nation's finances mean that we have to save millions of pounds, our residents can be assured that we are doing everything possible to cut back office and management costs, not the services they rely on the most."

Cllr Greenhalgh also paid tribute to Mr Alltimes by saying: "Geoff has devoted his life to public service in Hammersmith & Fulham and has been a major force in bringing down the Berlin Wall that existed between health and social care. While he will be sorely missed, the improvements he helped bring about in the way we care for elderly and vulnerable people will leave a lasting legacy."

Mr Alltimes is due to retire on 31 October.

shorttitle: Two boroughs, one Chief Executive

headline: FORGOTTEN HERO REMEMBERED
prcopy:
A historian's quest to find the unmarked grave of a Victoria Cross hero was completed at a dignified ceremony at Brompton Cemetery in Chelsea on Saturday 15 October attended by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Corporal Thomas Hancock was awarded the Victoria Cross for his gallant rescue of Brigadier Hugh Grant, who found himself surrounded after his horse was shot from under him in a fierce battle during the Indian Mutiny in June 1857.

Hancock was severely injured in the rescue attempt and lost his right arm as a result.

He was honourably discharged from the army the following year - ending a 17-year military career that had on occasions threatened to finish in ignominy after being tried three times by a regimental court martial two for drink-related offences. Despite this Corporal Hancock's discharge certificate stated his character and conduct had been "latterly good".
A memorial stone was erected over his grave and a replica Victoria Cross medal placed on top at the ceremony, which was also attended by military historian Brian Horton who worked to locate the grave, and the sponsor of the memorial Charles Ashton.

The inscription reads "Corporal Thomas Hancock, VC, 9th Queen's Royal Lancers".

On his return to England Thomas Hancock joined the Corp of Commissioners and served as a lodge keeper in the Home Park at Windsor from 1859 until 1865. Queen Victoria who met him reportedly described him as a "fine looking man, covered in medals".

He died at the age 48 in a workhouse in Kensington in 1871 after a long and painful illness and was buried in Brompton Cemetery on 20 March 1871.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough Cllr Julie Mills said: "It is an honour to be present at the unveiling of this memorial and to take time to remember and mark the grave of a brave man. He had human failings but when the situation called for it he responded heroically even though it endangered himself. I would like to congratulate Brian Hornton who located the grave and Mr Ashton for sponsoring the fitting memorial."

shortdescription: A historian's quest to find the unmarked grave of a Victoria Cross hero was completed at a dignified ceremony at Brompton Cemetery in Chelsea on Saturday 15 October attended by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Forgotten hero remembered

headline: ENERGY ADVICE FOR EARL'S COURT RESIDENTS
prcopy:
Earl's Court residents are being offered a free home visit and equipment to help lower their utility bills as part of the RE:NEW initiative, a London-wide scheme to increase energy efficiency of homes in the capital.

Home Energy Advisers from Climate Energy will be visiting addresses in Earl's Court to advise residents on how they can improve the energy and water efficiency of their homes. A survey of the property will find out how the home is heated and insulated to determine what energy saving devices can be installed. The advisor will also be able to offer energy-saving tips tailored to your own home.

Letters are being sent by Climate Energy to every home in Earl's Court introducing the scheme and the home visits. All advisors who call on homes in Earl's Court will show their ID badge. If you are unsure about a caller's identity please call the Council's Environmental Health line on 020 7361 3002.

A range of free energy and water saving devices, worth up to £100, can be installed which includes energy saving light bulbs, standby switches and an energy monitor to help see the electricity that is being used in the household. Residents aged over 70 or those in receipt of income related benefits could be eligible for free cavity wall insulation and full loft insulation.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Housing said: "At a time when energy costs are soaring, the RE:NEW scheme is a welcome initiative to help our residents save money on bills."

Advisors will be calling at addresses between early November 2011 and March 2012. To find out more about this scheme please contact Climate Energy on 0800 652 7216 or visit their website www.climateenergy.org.uk/renew

headline: Two wheels tuck into safety message
prcopy:
Motorcyclists in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are being invited to Chelsea Bridge on Saturday 5 November at 10.30am for breakfast to launch the Council's `Roadhug.org' campaign which aims to reduce motorcycle and scooter casualties across London.

The launch is supported by the Ace Cafe and LondonBikers, with members of the police's training course, Bikesafe, attending the event.

Roadhug.org is a four-week campaign to target vulnerable road users in London and increase their road safety awareness.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "Motorcyclists and scooter riders are much more vulnerable than car and lorry drivers and they need to be constantly aware of what is happening on the road. I hope that as many people as possible will take up the opportunity offered by Roadhug.org and give themselves the best chance to enjoy their journey on the road in safety."

headline: ENGLISH APPLES CELEBRATED ON PORTOBELLO AND GOLBORNE ROADS
prcopy:
Shoppers, visitors and traders munched their way through 5,000 samples of apple dishes as part of the English Apple Festival which ran at Portobello and Golborne Road on Friday 21 October and Saturday 22 October.

They got to taste apple and parsnip soup; apple, carrot and cabbage slaw; spiced apple compote with cinnamon and sage; and many other dishes prepared at a pop-up applefest kitchen in Portobello Road market.

Two chefs, Celia Brooks Brown and Sabrina Ghayour, shopped from market stalls before returning to the pop-up applefest kitchen to give cookery demonstrations and tips to visitors.

The Council followed up on its successful Tea in the Park event for City Living, Local Life by serving free cups of apple tea provided by the Golborne Road Cash & Carry.

Local youngsters from St Thomas' School visited the Golborne Road stall on Friday to taste different varieties of English apples and pears.

Nearly 30 volunteers organised by Volunteer Centre Kensington and Chelsea helped out over the two days with everything from organising the events, photography, giving out free samples and literature and setting up and taking down the stall. Five hot takeaway food stalls offered special lunch discounts to volunteers during the event.

The Salvation Army kindly allowed the use of their kitchen facilities to help support and promote the markets.

To celebrate the Festival, Wedge Card launched a selection of seasonal special offers from market stalls and small local independent businesses, many valid through the end of November.

Portobello Road market trader Josie Corney of `Josie Corney Top Quality Fruit' at the junction of Lancaster Road said "Judging by the number of customers who stopped by asking for traditional English apples like Egremont Russets, Cox's and Bramleys, the event was a huge success."

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "This festival was a marvellous opportunity to promote delicious English apples and our fine street markets. I'd like to thank all the volunteers whose efforts made the event such a success."
shortdescription: Shoppers, visitors and traders munched their way through 5,000 samples of apple dishes as part of the English Apple Festival which ran at Portobello and Golborne Road on Friday 21 October and Saturday 22 October.

headline: CYCLING FOR GOLD
prcopy:
Six young mums from Kensington and Chelsea are raising funds to allow them to complete their Gold Duke of Edinburgh Award (DofE).

The group have completed their Bronze and Silver Duke of Edinburgh Awards together with their children, and are now training and fundraising for their Gold expedition, which they have named 'Change Together'. Their plan is to cycle around Holland with their children in trailers in April 2012, becoming the first young mothers in Europe to take their kids with them on a Gold expedition.

The mums have raised over £10,000 with fundraising efforts, including Fun Days at Wornington Green Adventure Centre, a tabletop sale at Lancaster Youth Club, and walking around Portobello Market in their pyjamas, as they look to reach the £15,000 target.

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I wish these young mothers the very best in their efforts to raise funds for their Duke of Edinburgh Gold expedition. The Award has inspired generations of young people to learn new skills and help in their local community. I hope their efforts can motivate other young people to improve their lives too by doing something so rewarding."

Over the October half-term, the mums will be practising for the Holland expedition by cycling with their children in the South Downs, covering a distance of over 100km in five days and camping along the way.

For the past 12 months the mums have been volunteering in their local community, getting physically fit and learning new skills to complete the other sections of the Award. They plan to meet with other young mothers in Holland, look at pregnancy prevention schemes and young parent support groups, as they hope to start a community group themselves to help young parents and educate the community about teen pregnancy in the UK. So please look out for them and show your support. If you would like more information or just to follow their journey please check out their blog www.changetogether.co.uk where they will be sharing their experiences and hopes for the expedition and their futures.

As well as the young mothers going for their Gold Award, five other young mums from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea completed their Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award expedition with their children in September. The mothers from the BREAK 4U programme took to the countryside to walk 24km over two days with their children in baby carriers and off-road prams. It was challenging but highly rewarding for them, and they are looking forward to completing the Silver Award next.
shortdescription: Six young mums from Kensington and Chelsea are raising funds to allow them to complete their Gold Duke of Edinburgh Award (DofE).
shorttitle: Cycling for Gold

headline: BOROUGH BUSINESSES URGED TO PREPARE FOR OLYMPIC GAMES
prcopy:
The London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games is urging businesses in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to prepare for the impact the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games will have next summer.

The Games will be the largest sports event in the world and offer a once-in-a-lifetime chance to showcase London and the Royal Borough at their best.

They are a great opportunity for businesses of all sizes and sectors. Now is the time to begin planning how your business can take full advantage of the Games. However, like any large event, the Games will bring some challenges. If your business is near an Olympic venue or a travel hotspot, you need to start planning as soon as possible to reduce any adverse impact the Games might have on your business.

Kensington and Chelsea is hosting the Olympic volleyball tournament at Earl's Court and more than 12,000 people are expected to attend each day of the 16 days of competition between Saturday 28 July and Sunday 12 August. Local businesses should plan ahead for this.

The men's and women's road cycle races will come through Knightsbridge, Brompton Road and Fulham Road on Saturday 28 and Sunday 29 July 2012. This will mean that roads in the borough and other parts of west London and out to Surrey, will be closed. While the event will attract thousands of spectators along its route traffic and bus routes will be severely affected.

Between 28 July and 5 August the Royal Borough will be staging a spectacular festival to celebrate the Games and the Royal Borough's cultural and scientific heritage in Exhibition Road.
The Government has produced a guide, `Preparing your business for the Games', with contributions from all the organisations involved with delivering the Olympics. It will be reviewed regularly during the next year, so please visit www.london2012.com/business to get the latest advice. You can also visit the London 2012 pages on the Council's website www.rbkc.gov.uk/communityandlocallife/london2012.aspx

The guide provides advice on things you can do before, during and after Games so that you can keep your business running during 2012 and make the most of the opportunities next summer.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, Cabinet Member for Finance and IT and Lead Member for London 2012, said: "The Games will provide challenges but also offer real opportunities to businesses in Kensington and Chelsea. The best way to ensure that your business is able to cope, especially with the impact the Games will have on traffic and public transport, is to plan ahead. This guide, from the Government, is an excellent place to get the information you need."
shortdescription: The London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games is urging businesses in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to prepare for the impact the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games will have next summer.
shorttitle: Borough businesses urged to prepare for Olympic Games

headline: REMEMBRANCE SUNDAY
prcopy:
Some of the bloodiest fighting of World War One took place in the Flanders and Picardy regions of Belgium and Northern France. The poppy was the only thing which grew in the aftermath.

In respect for those who gave their lives for peace and freedom, make sure you wear your poppy with pride on Sunday 13 November, and join the Mayor, Cllr Julie Mills, at the borough's act of remembrance.

The ceremony will start at 10.45am at the war memorial on Kensington High Street with a traditional act of remembrance, the laying wreaths and a minute's silence at 11am, followed by a procession to St Mary Abbots Church for the service of remembrance.

Along with cadets from a number of units and representatives from a range of civilian and military organisations, the Mayor will be joined by: 256 (City of London) Field Hospital (Volunteers), the Royal Yeomanry, the University of London Air Squadron (Volunteers), the University of London Royal Naval Unit and Kensington and Chelsea Parks Police.

There will also be a ceremony outside Sloane Square led by the Deputy Mayor, Cllr Elizabeth Rutherford. It will begin at 10.50am with the act of remembrance at 11am.

Members of the public are most welcome at both events.
shortdescription: Some of the bloodiest fighting of World War One took place in the Flanders and Picardy regions of Belgium and Northern France. The poppy was the only thing which grew in the aftermath.
shorttitle: Remembrance Sunday

headline: NEW TOWN CLERK FOR KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA
prcopy:
The proper conduct of Council meetings at Kensington and Chelsea is in new hands from Tuesday 1 November as Executive Director of Finance Nicholas Holgate assumes the mantle of Town Clerk.

Nicholas Holgate will wear the traditional Town Clerk's wig and gown at municipal ceremonies and also advise the Mayor on points of order and other constitutional issues at full Council meetings.

As well as the civic functions of Town Clerk, he is also taking on a new management role. In addition to his existing responsibilities for finance, information systems and property, Mr Holgate will oversee planning, housing and policy too.

It's all part of major restructuring at Kensington and Chelsea to enable the Council to withstand dramatic reductions in central government grants. A key part of the Council's strategy for responding to that crisis is sharing resources with neighbouring boroughs, one of the most eye-catching examples of which is Hammersmith & Fulham and the Royal Borough sharing Derek Myers as a single chief executive.

Mr Holgate's appointment will enable Mr Myers to focus on his new bi-borough role, and will allow both authorities to retain independent constitutional identities.

"It's a different sort of role and not without challenges," said Mr Holgate. "An arcane point of order can pop up at any moment, so you really need to know your stuff and be on your toes."

A graduate of Trinity College, Cambridge, Mr Holgate had worked at HM Treasury for many years before becoming Chief Operating Officer at the Department for Culture, Media and Sport. He has worked for the Royal Borough for three years.

shorttitle: New Town Clerk for Kensington and Chelsea

headline: COULD YOU ADOPT?
prcopy:
Have you ever considered adopting? The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea needs people to adopt children from a wide variety of cultures and ethnic backgrounds.

The borough is marking National Adoption Week (31 October - 6 November) by making a renewed appeal for adopters, and is also encouraging people to offer adoption to children who usually wait the longest such as sibling groups, older children and those with special needs.

There will be an adoption information evening on Thursday 24 November from 6.30pm to 8.30pm in Committee Rooms 3 and 4 at Kensington Town Hall, Hornton Street, W8 7NX.

Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, Cllr Baroness Ritchie, said: "We are always on the lookout for people from every background to come forward and find out more about adoption. It is a lifelong commitment but adoption is one of the most rewarding things you can do.

"I encourage anyone who is considering adopting to attend the information evening."

Approved adopters in Kensington and Chelsea come from all backgrounds and cultures, and have adopted children from all over the UK. The Council's social workers support suitable applicants every step of the way. Since 2007, 95 per cent of domestic adopters approved by the Royal Borough have been linked or matched with a child within a year of approval.

For more information about adopting, go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/adoptus or call free on 0800 1832500.
shortdescription: Have you ever considered adopting? The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea needs people to adopt children from a wide variety of cultures and ethnic backgrounds.
shorttitle: Could you adopt?

headline: GIVE YOUR VIEWS ON SILCHESTER GARGAGES DEVELOPMENT
prcopy:
The Council has exciting plans for the Silchester Garages site and recently appointed Peabody, one of London's oldest and largest housing associations, to take these forward.

Peabody's proposals will provide 112 new homes on the Silchester Garages site, with 45 larger properties for social rent, 39 smaller properties for shared ownership and a further 28 smaller properties for sale on the open market.

A planning application for the whole scheme will be submitted by Peabody in January 2012 and it is important that residents of the estate are able to put their views and concerns forward.

To enable residents to be involved, the Council and Peabody are planning a number of events including a meeting at 7pm on Tuesday 8 November 2011 in the
Residents' Meeting Room, Ground Floor, Frinstead House, Freston Road, W10 for residents to find out more about the proposals and ask questions.

A Residents' Steering Group will be set up which will meet regularly with
Peabody and representatives from the Royal Borough. This group will look at developing a number of details for the proposals before they are submitted for planning permission, be involved in selecting the contractor, provide feedback about any issues relating to the management of the work and look at the forward plan for managing the estate.

If you are interested in having your say either come to the meeting on Tuesday 8 November, or, if you are not able to attend, contact Ruth Angel on 020 7361 2628 or email ruth.angel@rbkc.gov.uk


There will also be workshops for residents to look at the proposed improvements to the base of Frinstead House at 7pm on Tuesday, 29 November and to discuss landscape improvements to the green area between Frinstead and Markland Houses at 7pm on Tuesday 6 December.

headline: ROYAL-INSPIRED COUTURE COLLECTION COMES TO CHELSEA LIBRARY
prcopy:
Kensington Palace and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have joined forces to promote a royal-inspired couture collection created by children from local community groups which is on display in Chelsea Library from Monday 14 to Friday 18 November.

`A Fabric of Cultures' is an exhibition of seven unique garments designed and produced by Kensington community groups as part of a project with Historic Royal Places, the independent charity responsible for Kensington Palace.

The collection of seven garments were made by nearly 100 children aged between six and eight from seven community groups. The schools and centres involved from the Royal Borough include Ashburham Primary School, Thomas Jones Primary School, Marlborough Primary School, Avondale Park Primary School, Clement James Girls group and Al-Hasaniya Moroccan girls group.

Inspired by the work of British-Nigerian contemporary artist Yinka Shonibare, the designs fuse contemporary art with the history of Kensington Palace, whilst reflecting on the contemporary cultures and identity of its creators. The project was designed to take inspiration from the fashions of the eighteenth, nineteenth and twentieth centuries that the characters of Kensington Palace would have once worn.

The collection is on display in the Chelsea Gallery, Chelsea Old Town Hall, Kings Road, London, SW3 5EZ from Monday 14 to Friday 18 November and on Wednesday 16 November at 6pm, Kensington Palace curator Alexandra Kim will be giving a free talk.

The event also promotes the recent refurbishment of Chelsea reference library which is home to an impressive Fashion and Costume collection that has been given greater prominence in the revamped library's layout.


Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Libraries, said:

"This is a beautiful collection and the intricate stitching and painstaking attention to detail by our young people brings to life the fashion of bygone eras.

"I'd urge residents of all ages to come and see this collection and also check out our refurbished Chelsea reference library which, amongst other things, boasts an impressive selection of fashion titles."

The collection will also be on display from Monday 21 to Friday 25 November in The Tabernacle.
shortdescription: Kensington Palace and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have joined forces to promote a royal-inspired couture collection created by children from local community groups which is on display in Chelsea Library from Monday 14 to Friday 18 November.
shorttitle: Royal-inspired couture collection comes to Chelsea Library

headline: OLYMPIC TORCH TO COME TO ROYAL BOROUGH
prcopy:
The Olympic torch will be carried through streets in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea on Thursday 26 July 2012, the last day of its 70-day journey throughout the UK. This will give local residents and businesses a chance to welcome the Olympic flame just before the Games begin.

Kensington and Chelsea is one of over 1,000 villages, towns, cities and London boroughs announced by the London Organising Committee of the Olympic and Paralympic Games (LOCOG) through which the Olympic Flame will be carried by torchbearers during the London 2012 Olympic Torch Relay which is presented by Coca-Cola, Lloyds TSB and Samsung. LOCOG has worked closely with representatives from a number of sectors in Kensington and Chelsea to devise the route which will travel through each of the 33 London boroughs as part of its journey.

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I am sure that the Olympic Torch Relay will be an exciting spectacle. It will give residents and businesses an opportunity to get into the Olympic spirit and to salute the torchbearers, many of whom will be local heroes, nominated by the public, with inspirational stories to tell.

"It will be an excellent chance to celebrate the Royal Borough's heritage and the different cultures that make up our community."

Sebastian Coe, Chair of LOCOG said: `We are thrilled to confirm that the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea will act as a host location for the Olympic flame on 26 July extending an invitation to people across the borough to welcome the Olympic Torch Relay during its journey around the UK. This is the UK's moment to shine and I want to encourage people in Kensington and Chelsea to start planning how they can be part of this once in a lifetime opportunity and show their support for the inspirational torchbearers chosen to carry the Olympic flame as we count down to the start of the Olympic Games.

The Olympic Torch Relay will start at Land's End, Cornwall on the morning of 19 May 2012. On leaving Land's End, the Olympic flame will travel an estimated 8,000 miles around the UK.

In announcing the villages, towns, cities and every London borough, LOCOG has realised the aspiration of taking the Olympic flame to within an hour's journey time of 95 per cent of the population. In fact, over 95 per cent of the population will be within just ten miles of the Olympic flame next summer. The street by street detail of the route will be confirmed next year.

People are invited to view the interactive map at www.london2012.com/olympictorchrelaymap to find their nearest community through which the Olympic Flame will be carried. Further information will be provided on the Council's website in the coming months on the best views of the flame in the borough.

On the final day of the Olympic Torch Relay, it is LOCOG's intention that the Olympic flame will travel down the River Thames as it makes its way to the Olympic Stadium on 27 July 2012 for the lighting of the cauldron at the Opening Ceremony, signifying the official start of the London 2012 Olympic Games.


End
shortdescription: The Olympic torch will be carried through streets in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea on Thursday 26 July 2012, the last day of its 70-day journey throughout the UK.  This will give local residents and businesses a chance to welcome the Olympic flame just before the Games begin.
shorttitle: Olympic torch to come to Royal Borough

headline: GETTING THE MESSAGE ACROSS ON DOMESTIC VIOLENCE
prcopy:
An event to raise awareness amongst young women about the impact of domestic and sexual violence, and where to get help and advice on the issue, was held on Friday 28 October at the Lancaster Youth Centre in North Kensington.

The `Girls Allowed' event was aimed at young women aged 13 to 24.

Focus groups and one-to-one interviews about the prevalence of domestic abuse, and its links to substance abuse, were organised by the Stella Project.

A number of agencies from both the statutory and voluntary sector were on hand to offer information and advice, including Victim Support, the Community Support Police Team, Coram, Brook, and Connexions.

All the organisations and services provided stalls and interactive activities for the young women to get involved. There were facts and information about famous women who have experienced and survived domestic and sexual violence.

Music was provided by the Ebony Steel Band.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Julie Mills, attended the event and said: "No young woman should have to experience domestic violence and I hope that the young people who attended this event will have learned that help will always be on hand. I would like to thank all the organisations that came together to highlight this issue."

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "It is very important that we shine a light on the issue of domestic violence. `Girls Allowed' got an important message across and showed the wide range of services and organisations that young people can turn to for help and advice."
shortdescription: An event to raise awareness amongst young women about the impact of domestic and sexual violence, and where to get help and advice on the issue, was held on Friday 28 October at the Lancaster Youth Centre in North Kensington.
shorttitle: Getting the message across on domestic violence

headline: CHRISTMAS MARKET FOR PORTOBELLO
prcopy:
Shoppers will be able to get a taste of Christmas at the new Portobello Sunday Christmas Market which will be held on consecutive Sundays from 13 November to 18 December.

The Christmas Market will be open from 10am to 4pm along a stretch of Portobello Road between Lancaster Road and Cambridge Gardens. The road will be closed to traffic and there will be approximately 40 market stalls.

The location and timing of the Christmas Market is intended to complement the Portobello Green Fashion Market and Portobello's Premier Farmers and Fine Foods Market that already operate near the Westway on Sundays.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Cabinet Member for Environment, said: "I hope that residents and visitors to the area come along to the Portobello Sunday Christmas Market to see what is on offer and to get into the Christmas spirit."

Any local schools, charities or community groups interested in helping to organise carol singing or other Christmas-themed events at the market can contact the Street Trading Office by visiting 72 Tavistock Road W11 1AN or emailing street.trading@rbkc.gov.uk.

An official switch-on event for the Portobello and Golborne Road Christmas lights will follow the Sunday Market on 20 November at 5pm. Local resident and television presenter George Clarke will do the honours at the big tree where Tavistock Road meets Portobello Road in Portobello Square.
shortdescription: Shoppers will be able to get a taste of Christmas at the new Portobello Sunday Christmas Market which will be held on consecutive Sundays from 13 November to 18 December.
shorttitle: Christmas market for Portobello

headline: KENSINGTON PALACE CURATED COLLECTION COMES TO THE ROYAL BOROUGH'S LIBRARIES
prcopy:
Kensington Palace staff have shared their insight and knowledge with Kensington and Chelsea Council's Library Service by curating a special collection of books associated with the palace.

Highlights of this collection includes `Portraits' by Mario Testino which includes iconic images of Diana, Princess of Wales and `Dearest Child: Letters between Queen Victoria and the Princess Royal 1858-1861' by Roger Fulford.

New titles have been bought from Waterstone's Kensington High Street especially for this collection which will be on display and available to borrow from Monday 14 November 2011 at Kensington Central Library. This collection will then tour the borough's libraries.

The collection was officially launched on Friday 11 November at 2pm by Kensington Palace staff and the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Julie Mills, Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Libraries and Councillor Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning Policy.

A Kensington Palace storyteller marked the occasion by regaling guests from local community group, Positive Age, and the North Kensington and Notting Hill Gate library reading groups with tales associated with the palace's colourful past.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, said:

"Kensington Palace is one of the Royal Borough's most iconic institutions and this unique collection helps to throw a new light on what is a very important part of our heritage.

"This collection is a first for us and in the future we hope to work with other individuals and organisations to create similar collections in our libraries."
shortdescription: Kensington Palace staff have shared their insight and knowledge with Kensington and Chelsea Council's Library Service by curating a special collection of books associated with the palace.
shorttitle: Kensington Palace Curated Collection comes to the Royal Borough's libraries

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH CALLS ON GOVERNMENT TO RETHINK RELAXATION OF LICENSING LAWS
prcopy:
Pubs and clubs in the Royal Borough may soon be able to put on music without first having to get a licence from the Council if a current Department for Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) consultation becomes law.

Alarmingly the DCMS consultation is not just proposing the deregulation of small-scale events but those with audiences of up to 5,000.

In Kensington and Chelsea there are currently 878 venues which, under the DCMS proposals, would be able to lay on unregulated events. The Council is worried that not only would this result in a sharp increase in noise and nuisance for Royal Borough residents, but a spike in associated antisocial behaviour.

Another implication for the Royal Borough is that it hosts one of Europe's largest events, the Notting Hill Carnival. In the interests of public safety it is essential that the Council and the Metropolitan Police bring Carnival to a close at a reasonable hour. With complete deregulation any premises within the Carnival area could legally provide live and recorded music 24 hours a day over the Carnival period, as long as any alcohol sales they make are within their permitted hours and their audiences are not more than 5,000.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Environment, said:

"Far from being meddlesome, pointless bureaucracy, entertainment licences are actually how we ensure that noise is controlled, that events close down at a reasonable time and that landlords generally act responsibly.

"It's no secret that councils and constabularies are hard pressed right now and indeed for the foreseeable future. We for one simply do not have the resources to cope with a serious rise in complaints and urge the DCMS to rethink its proposals.

"In addition to our formal response to the consultation, I have written to the Secretary of State at the DCMS to express the Council's grave concern about the adverse impact this proposal will have on densely populated inner-city residential areas like Kensington and Chelsea."

You can have your say on the consultation by visiting www.culture.gov.uk/consultations and clicking on the link entitled "Consultation on proposal to examine the deregulation of Schedule One of the Licensing Act 2003".

The consultation closes on Saturday 3 December 2011. Please send your comments or if you have any queries about this consultation to: regulated_entertainment_consultation@culture.gsi.gov.uk

Or by post to:
Nigel Wakelin
Department for Culture, Media and Sport
2-4 Cockspur Street
London
SW1Y 5DH

headline: Second round of consultation on the future of the Earl's Court Exhibition Centres
prcopy:
Residents are once again being asked to give their views and help shape the future of the Earl's Court and West Kensington area.

Earls Court is the 2012 venue for Olympic volleyball. But after that Capital and Counties (Capco), the owners of both Earls Court 1 and 2, are considering redevelopment.

At the same time, Hammersmith & Fulham is looking at the regeneration of the adjoining West Kensington and Gibbs Green Council housing estates. Similarly Transport for London is looking at options for its Lillie Bridge rail depot. The three sites together amount to just over 77 acres, which is larger than the King's Cross redevelopment, making it a site of immense potential.

To make sure that the right development occurs in the right place, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham Council, together with the Mayor of London, are drawing up a planning framework for the area.

This detailed document, called a Supplementary Planning Document (SPD), takes into account a whole range of issues, from affordable housing provision to transport capacity, open space, community facilities and the size, location, design and layout of any new buildings, public spaces and streets. It will also set out a series of requirements to reduce the impact of building work on neighbouring residents and the environment, such as air quality, noise and vibration. The SPD also seeks to improve access between the two boroughs.

A first draft of the planning framework was published for consultation earlier this year (March to April 2011) and comments from residents, businesses and visitors were used to revise this planning framework. Now the boroughs and the Mayor of London want to know what you think about the revised draft planning framework. This planning framework will be used to determine planning applications in the area.

Residents have until Friday 23 December to have their say on this important planning document. To view the SPD, please visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/earlscourtspd

Comments can be sent by email to earlscourtspdconsultation@lbhf.gov.uk, by fax 020 8753 3470 or in writing to:

The Earl's Court and West Kensington Opportunity Area Project Team,

Hammersmith,
