headline: TWO TRI-BOROUGH DIRECTORS APPOINTED FOR ADULT SOCIAL CARE
prcopy:
Two more directors have been appointed as part of innovative plans to combine services across three flagship councils.

Hammersmith & Fulham Council (H&F), the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Westminster City Council are combining back office and management costs in order to save £33 million a year from 2014/15 onwards.

On Wednesday, November 9, Rachel Wigley was appointed as Tri-borough Director of Finance for Adult Social Care. Rachel is currently the Head of Resource Management at the Royal Borough

Martin Waddington has been named as Tri-borough Director of Contracts, Business Intelligence and Workforce for Adult Social Care. Martin is currently Head of Policy and Performance for Housing, Health and Adult Social Care at the Royal Borough.

Both Rachel and Martin will take up post on April 1, 2012 subject to confirmation processes within H&F. They will report directly to Andrew Webster who was named Tri-borough Executive Director of Adult Social Care last month.

The councils expect the appointments to improve adult social care in the three boroughs further by helping residents to live even more independent lives.

By aligning healthcare and social care more closely and having more integrated care management the councils also expect to be able to provide a more efficient, streamlined and responsive service.

The project to share council services across the three boroughs is on track to deliver its first £1m of savings by cutting senior management roles. the savings include:
- £320k by sharing a single Director of Children's Services;
- £320k by sharing a single Director of Adult Services;
- £100k by sharing a single Director of Libraries;
- £150k by combining environmental services across Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea; and
- £120k by combining making a joint appointment to the Director for Schools' Quality and Standards between H&F and Kensington and Chelsea.

By combining services, the three councils will be able to protect vital front line services during the age of austerity and lead to a 50 per cent reduction in the number of middle and senior managers. Collectively the three authorities must save £100 million by 2014/15 and around 500 jobs are expected to go in management, back office and support roles.

In addition to these Tri-borough savings, Derek Myers has taken up post as joint chief executive for H&F and Kensington and Chelsea in a move that will save the two authorities £200,000 a year. Derek has been chief executive of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea since 2000.
shortdescription: Two more directors have been appointed as part of innovative plans to combine services across three flagship councils.
shorttitle: Two more Tri-borough directors appointed

headline: Best Bar None Awards 2011
prcopy:
Embargo 59, a long-established nightclub in Chelsea scooped the coveted Best Bar None `overall winner' for 2011 earlier this week (Wednesday 9 November) at the annual awards ceremony at a packed Royal Garden Hotel, Kensington.

Beating off stiff competition to the overall title, the club was also named `best nightclub'. Embargo 59 has been run by its current owners since 2006, and has taken part in Best Bar None since the scheme began in 2008.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Environment, said: "It is always gratifying to be at the Best Bar None awards, particularly tonight when so many licensees have come along to show their support for the scheme. We want this borough to be a great place to visit and live, and part of that is down to the quality of management of all the licensed premises we have. This is not only the excellence of the service inside, but how you and your patrons treat the streets outside and show respect for residents living nearby.

"Accreditation through Best Bar None shows that you seek to run establishments which residents can see meet high standards. This is bound to be good for business and it is pleasing that so many of you have chosen to sign up to Best Bar None and all it stands for."

A further 46pubs, bars and clubs across the borough were awarded membership of the scheme, with the category winners as follows:

Best Club runner-up - The Roof Gardens

Best Pub - Builders Arms
Runner up - Hereford Arms

Best Bar - Janet's Bar
Runner up - Juju

The Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Julie Mills, added: "Well done to all of you for the hard work you are putting in to being considerate neighbours, as well as ensuring your premises are safe and welcoming to your clientele."

Best Bar None in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is proudly sponsored by Diageo GB and Soundsec Security with support from various partner agencies including NHS Kensington.

To find out more about the scheme, and current members, go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/bestbarnone or call 020 7341 5708. All premises are judged on a range of criteria including safety, training for staff, security, drugs policy, litter disposal and noise control.

headline: APPROPRIATE ADULT RECEPTION
prcopy:
Last night (Thursday 10 November) a reception was held in a packed Mayor's Parlour, Kensington Town Hall, to recognise the work of those volunteers who take part in the Appropriate Adults service.

The Appropriate Adults service's aim is to support young people and vulnerable adults who have been arrested. The volunteers are there to support, advise and assist people who have been arrested, making sure the police act properly and that the detained person understands their rights and what is happening to them.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "I am delighted that we have been able to hold this reception to recognise the important work of all those who volunteer to be an Appropriate Adult. It can be very challenging to help people who have been arrested and find themselves alone in a cell. I would like to say thank you to all those who carry out this important role.

"I know that we all have many demands on our time but I would encourage people to think about becoming an Appropriate Adult.

"If you don't feel that being an Appropriate Adult is the way you would like to volunteer there are many other opportunities in the borough: from being a member of your local neighbourhood watch scheme, to joining a residents association, working with local charities or even becoming a magistrate.

"Volunteering can mean spending a few hours a month helping someone while doing something you already enjoy, whether it's gardening, reading or accountancy. Whatever you do, you can reap the rewards of getting involved in the borough's community life."

The Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Julie Mills, added: "It is always gratifying to meet people who are prepared to put time aside to help others and it is all the more rewarding when they deal with people who are in such a difficult situation. I am delighted we have been able to give some recognition for all the hard work they do."

If you would like to find out more about the Appropriate Adults service or any of the other volunteering opportunities in the Royal Borough call the Volunteer Centre on 020 8960 3722, go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/allofus or email allofus@rbkc.gov.uk to request a booklet about volunteering in Kensington and Chelsea.
shortdescription: Last night (Thursday 10 November) a reception was held in a packed Mayor's Parlour, Kensington Town Hall, to recognise the work of those volunteers who take part in the Appropriate Adults service.
shorttitle: Appropriate Adult reception

headline: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE ADVOCACY SERVICES
prcopy:
This afternoon (Monday 14 November) ADVANCE, the new domestic violence advocacy service for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the City of Westminster was launched at a packed event in St Charles Square.

ADVANCE has been commissioned by the two Councils to take over running their independent domestic violence advocacy service. The joint service will result in a larger more flexible service being available to residents of both boroughs. Eight staff will be working across the two boroughs.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "It is great news that we have been able to work with the City of Westminster to offer this comprehensive service. It is a cornerstone of our plans to increase the safety of domestic violence sufferers and their children, as well as helping to bring the perpetrators to account.

"It is important that residents suffering this abuse know that help is available and that they can come forward in confidence and speak to ADVANCE and get the help they desperately need."

ADVANCE already runs a similar service in Hammersmith & Fulham and Brent. The service is open to women aged 15 and over who are residents of the Royal Borough or Westminster and are experiencing, or have experienced, domestic violence.

The independent domestic violence service in the Royal Borough has been running for five years and has dealt with 217 new and rereferrals between April and September this year, an increase of 41 per cent. This is against the background of an increase of 15 per cent, to 360, in domestic violence offences reported to the police over the same period.
shortdescription: This afternoon (Monday 14 November) ADVANCE, the new domestic violence advocacy service for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the City of Westminster was launched at a packed event in St Charles Square.
shorttitle: Domestic Violence Advocacy Services

headline: CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE RECEIVE OUTSTANDING SERVICES
prcopy:
Children and young people in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are receiving outstanding services according to a report published by Ofsted last week (8 November).

Most of the services, settings and institutions in the Royal Borough, inspected by Ofsted, were judged to be good or outstanding and none were inadequate.

The excellent services delivered by the Council help children and young people in the borough to learn well and stay safe.

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am very pleased that Ofsted's inspectors have rated our Children's Services so highly once again. These services really can make a difference to families and children at the heart of our community and that is why we will continue to make sure that our children and young people get the best possible support.

"Of course, achieving these high standards would not be possible without a great deal of commitment from the people on the front line and I thank them for their efforts."

For more information on the report please visit Ofsted's website - http://www.ofsted.gov.uk/local-authorities/kensington-and-chelsea
shortdescription: Children and young people in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are receiving outstanding services according to a report published by Ofsted last week (8 November).
shorttitle: Children and young people receive outstanding services

headline: ENTREPRENEURS ENTERPRISE CLUB LAUNCHES IN LIBRARY
prcopy:
Enterprise Club a new place where budding entrepreneurs can get business support and advice and build local contacts is being launched in Kensington and Chelsea.

The Kensington and Chelsea Enterprise Club will give people who want to set up their own businesses the chance to share experiences and access professional advice that they might not otherwise be able to afford. The club will also assist those people who have just started their own small business.

The Enterprise Club has been set up by the Portobello Business Centre and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Library Service and meets every month at North Kensington Library from 5pm for two hours.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Libraries, said: "New businesses represent the future of our economy, so we need to make sure that unemployed people with a good idea get the support they need to move into self-employment.

"New entrepreneurs and small business owners in Kensington and Chelsea will be able to swap ideas and talk to guest speakers including people from successful local businesses."
The club will next meet on Tuesday 22 November 2011 and other meetings are planned for Tuesday 20 December 2011 and Tuesday 24 January 2012.

If you would like more information on the Kensington and Chelsea Enterprise Club, attend a meeting or find out how you or your company could get involved please contact The Portobello Business Centre on 02074605050 or email: info@pbc.co.uk

headline: LOAN TO AID DESIGN MUSEUM MOVE
prcopy:
The Design Museum's ambitions to move into the Commonwealth Institute achieved a big step towards financial viability last night (Thursday 17 November 2011), thanks to the offer of a £2.6m loan from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The short-term loan is intended to help the Design Museum meet the terms of a legal planning obligation controlling the future development of the Commonwealth Institute site. Under the obligation, developers must demonstrate that they have at least 70 per cent of the necessary development funds in place before they can start the work.

With major backing from the Conran Foundation, plus support from the Heritage Lottery Fund, the Design Museum was already 85 per cent of the way to meeting the terms. But the rest of the money is mostly tied up in the museum's current building at Shad Thames and can only be realised once the Design Museum relocates to Kensington. In other words, the Design Museum can't sell up at Shad Thames until it has moved to Kensington, but it can't move to Kensington until it has sold up at Shad Thames.

A Council loan resolves this Catch-22 and, subject to planning permission, could enable the museum to complete the move to Kensington High Street if other sources of funds are slow to appear.

"If the Design Museum chooses to take this offer up, this is a low risk, short-term loan with a potentially big return," explained the Leader of the Council, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell. "Not only will we get interest, we will improve the odds of a museum making use of the Institute. That would mean major economic benefits for the High Street and it would also mean the restoration of a wonderful listed building."

Completed in 1962, the Commonwealth Institute is a Grade II* listed building, noted for its marquee-like copper roof. It has been empty since 2002. The Design Museum submitted a planning application for a £22m refurbishment of the building last month. If granted, the Museum plans to relocate to the Institute in 2014.

shorttitle: Loan to aid Design Museum move

headline: ALBERT BRIDGE TO REOPEN
prcopy:
Albert Bridge will be reopening to traffic on Friday 2 December.

Following the most extensive work, funded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Transport for London, on the bridge since it was first opened in 1873; it has been returned to its original looks and will once again be an iconic landmark across the Thames.

The bridge has had major strengthening and refurbishment work which should ensure it will be able to last well into the century.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "I think we can be proud of the level of workmanship in the restoration of Albert Bridge. It proved even more challenging than we originally thought as once the work began we discovered much worse corrosion to the iron and steel in the bridge.

"The amount of work on the bridge has been truly monumental with over 10,000 bolts, 40,000 litres of paint and 1,000 tonnes of grit used during the restoration.

"I hope that residents and all other bridge-users will now be able to appreciate the need for the work we carried out on this unique London bridge, for surely, when lit up the Albert Bridge is one of the most beautiful nightime sights in London."
shortdescription: Albert Bridge will be reopening to traffic on Friday 2 December.
shorttitle: Albert Bridge to reopen

headline: MOTHER SENTENCED FOR SON'S POOR SCHOOL ATTENDANCE
prcopy:
West London Magistrates' Court, on Tuesday 15 November, sentenced a mother of three to three months in jail, suspended for two years, after she was convicted in her absence of failing to ensure her then 12-year-old son attended school regularly between 1 November 2010 and 4 February 2011.

The court was told that the boy, who is not being named to protect his identity, was absent from school 80 out of a total of 110 days and that his mother knew he was not attending school and had no reasonable justification for allowing this.

The prosecution, under the Education Act 1996, was brought by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and is the first time that a custodial sentence has been imposed for such a conviction. The court was told that the woman had previous convictions for a similar offence in 2009 involving the same son and that her eldest son is currently serving a prison sentence.

Sentencing the woman, who had pleaded not guilty, District Judge Clarke said she had no mitigation and that he had enough of all the "tears and excuses". He said "the time for action has come" and that the matter needed "finality" and there had been too much concentration on her as the mother and not enough on the son.

Suspending the sentence he took the unusual step to impose conditions on her sentence. She is to co-operate with the Education Welfare Service of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and to attend all appointments made for the purpose of getting her son back into school. She must ensure that he attends school at least 90 per cent of the time. She must provide medical evidence to the school on any occasion her son is considered too ill to attend and must do so within seven days of his not attending. She was also ordered to pay a contribution of £150 to the Council's costs of £5,000 due to the fact she was on benefits and had been recently evicted from Council housing due to antisocial behaviour and rent arrears.

The court was told that education welfare officers were working with the boy to ensure he had support to settle back into school and make up for the time he had missed.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "Parents have a duty to ensure that their children attend school. A good education is vital for any child's development and welfare. This is clearly a case of a parent failing to ensure that her son went to school and the court has taken a dim view of the mother's actions. We will be monitoring the situation very closely to ensure the welfare of this young boy, an important part of which is regular attendance at school."
shortdescription: West London Magistrates' Court, on Tuesday 15 November, sentenced a mother of three to three months in jail, suspended for two years, after she was convicted in her absence of failing to ensure her then 12-year-old son attended school regularly between 1 November 2010 and 4 February 2011.
shorttitle: Mother sentenced for son's poor school attendance

headline: SAUSAGE CONDEMNED UNDER FOOD SAFETY LAW
prcopy:
A sausage of unknown origin was condemned under the Food Safety Act 1990 by District Justice Clarke of West London Magistrates' Court on Tuesday 15 November when the shopkeeper was unable to explain where it came from, who had supplied it or how it got into the shop's fridge.

The delicatessen-sized sausage was seized, with others, at Rayan Supermarket, 9 Kenway Road, London, SW5, when food safety officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea visited the shop on 7 November. It was not labelled and did not have an ingredients list or sell-by date. Officers removed the sausage from the supermarket.

Mr Youcef Benyahia, on behalf the shop, told the court that he didn't know where the sausage came from or how it got into the shop fridge. He said he thought it was a French/Algerian delicacy but could not give any details of who provided it. He said he would ask for a label `next time'.

District Judge Clarke said: "I don't believe a single word you have said and I think you have told a pack of lies." He ordered that the sausages be condemned, and also ordered that Rayan Supermarket pay the full costs of £869.95 which included the cost of disposing of the food.

Cllr Fiona Buxton, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "It is important that food is properly labelled, that customers know what is in it and what its sell-by date is. It is clear that this sausage did not pass that test. I am pleased that the Court has agreed with the Council's Environmental Health Officers' decision to remove it from sale."
shortdescription: A sausage of unknown origin was condemned under the Food Safety Act 1990 by District Justice Clarke of West London Magistrates' Court on Tuesday 15 November when the shopkeeper was unable to explain where it came from, who had supplied it or how it got into the shop's fridge.
shorttitle: Sausage condemned under food safety law

headline: NEW £3 MILLION HOME FOR BOROUGH'S LOOKED AFTER CHILDREN
prcopy:
Future generations of looked after children in Kensington and Chelsea are to have a brand new, state of the art children's home, the Royal Borough's Cabinet decided last night ( Thursday 17 November).

The £3m home is to be built, subject to planning permission, at East Row, on the corner of Emslie Horniman Pleasance. It will reflect all the latest and best practice in children's homes. In particular there will be greatly improved internal and external space for social and recreational use.

Once the new home is built the present home at Whistler Walk, at World's End, will close.

As a home, Whistler Walk has long been praised by inspectors for its exceptional standards of care. As a building however, it leaves much to be desired. Built in the 1970s, the internal layout feels institutional and doesn't easily lend itself to the creation of a homely, family atmosphere. This fundamental problem cannot be addressed by a refurbishment.

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Despite living in straitened times, with pressure on the public purse, we must ensure our most disadvantaged children get the best possible care and accommodation.

"We could certainly have opted for a refurbishment of the existing home, but this is an opportunity to do something far better, perhaps even to set a new standard. And that is what we have chosen to do. We will have a brand new home, on a park corner, near schools and leisure facilities.

"These are our most disadvantaged children; we mean to do our best for them."

Over a 30 year span, about 300 children will benefit from the new home.
shortdescription: Future generations of looked after children in Kensington and Chelsea are to have a brand new, state of the art children's home, the Royal Borough's Cabinet decided last night ( Thursday 17 November).
shorttitle: New £3 million home for borough's looked after children

headline: RESIDENTS ASKED TO HAVE THEIR SAY ON COUNCIL PERFORMANCE
prcopy:
People who live in Kensington and Chelsea are being asked to join the Council's Residents' Panel and have their say about life in the Royal Borough and how the Council is performing.
The panel is made up of over 1,000 residents who agree to take part in regular consultations. The Council is launching a website for panel members to use, featuring interactive ways to have your say. This will allow instant feedback from panel members on the issues that matter most to them.

Members of the panel have already helped identify ways in which the Council can improve by giving their views on topics including local markets, community safety, parks and the Council's spending priorities.

Panel members can take part in quick, snapshot polls, answer online questionnaires or get involved in more in-depth discussions. They can also register an interest in taking part in an online focus group. This all means that panel members will be able to decide how involved they want to be. Many of the activities will be online, but it is also possible to join the panel and have your say in person if you don't have access to a computer. In addition, residents can access the internet for free in the Council's libraries.

Letters inviting residents to get involved and join the panel will be sent out in the week of 21 November to 10,000 residents, chosen at random from the electoral register.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "The Residents' Panel is a very important touchstone for the Council. Members have a chance to tell us what they think about our services and our plans and their views really do matter. It's a great way to have your say, or give feedback, about what happens in your area."

For more information about the Residents' Panel email consult@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: People who live in Kensington and Chelsea are being asked to join the Council's Residents' Panel and have their say about life in the Royal Borough and how the Council is performing.

headline: CABINET AGREES PLANS FOR NEW MIDDLE ROW PRIMARY SCHOOL
prcopy:
A plan for a brand new £12.7m building for Middle Row Primary School in North Kensington was agreed by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet (Thursday 17 November).

Councillors gave the green light to the project which will see the old Middle Row building demolished and replaced with a new, two-form entry, primary school and a nursery school for 60 children. The school would also include a specialist centre for up to 16 pupils with severe speech and language difficulties.

The plans include proposals to work with a developer to deliver the new school and a residential development comprising 30 flats and houses.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Education, said: "Middle Row Primary School serves its community very well but its building is nearing the end of its useful life. This decision paves the way for an exciting brand new building which will serve generations of North Kensington families for many years to come."

Before any new school can be built the Council will need to obtain planning permission. A programme of public consultation will be announced in due course.
shortdescription: A plan for a brand new £12.7m building for Middle Row Primary School in North Kensington was agreed by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet (Thursday 17 November).

headline: CHILDREN'S CHARITY LUMOS AND COUNCIL HOST VISIT FOR MOLDOVAN DELEGATION
prcopy:
Across the European region one million children live in large residential institutions
that cannot meet their needs. Lumos works to end this practice, supporting governments to introduce family and community services. On 21 and 22 November Lumos and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Family and Children's Services together hosted a study visit for a senior level delegation from Moldova. The visit provided an opportunity for senior personnel and decision makers to understand how high quality services can be provided to support children to live with their families.

The purpose of the visit was to focus on inclusive education, early intervention and child protection. The delegation visited centres for children with disabilities and inclusive schools, as well as foster care and leaving care services within the borough including: St Quintin's Children's Centre and St Mark's Children's Home.

Seeing integrated social services such as these in action will help the Moldovan local authorities develop the community-based services that they need, which are key to the successful implementation of the deinstitutionalisation process.

Georgette Mulheir, Chief Executive of Lumos, said: "Lumos is working to put an end to the systematic institutionalisation of disadvantaged children, across Central and Eastern Europe, by helping to close down institutions and transform care services for children and their families. Study visits are essential to developing and understanding of what constitutes a high quality system of effective health, education and social services. This study visit will help influence change in Moldova, improving the lives of thousands of children and young people.

Cllr Baroness Ritchie, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Services for children and young people in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are acknowledged as being some of the finest on offer in the UK. Our officers were very pleased to meet with the delegation from Moldova and show them just how we go about ensuring we deliver the very best for our children."
shortdescription: Across the European region one million children live in large residential institutions that cannot meet their needs. Lumos works to end this practice, supporting governments to introduce family and community services.
shorttitle: Children's charity Lumos and Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea host study visit for Moldovan delegation

headline: RESIDENTS ASSOCIATIONS STERLING WORK RECOGNISED
prcopy:
Six local resident and tenant associations had their work to improve their neighbourhoods and foster community spirit recognised by the Mayor of Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Julie Mills, when they received Gold Standard Awards.

As well as the award each association gets a grant of £500 to spend on a project it feels would be beneficial for its association or area. Gold standard associations work closely with the Council and are consulted on a number of matters.

Receiving the award on Monday 29 November were the Radnor Walk Residents' Association, Earl's Court Square Residents' Association, Cremorne Residents' Association of the Lots Road area, Earl's Court Society, Wesley Square Residents' Association and Chelsea Manor Court Tenants Association.

Congratulating the six associations on reaching the gold level standard the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Civil Society, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, said: "Resident and tenant associations are at the heart of community life and here in Kensington and Chelsea we are proud to have more than 300 such active associations.

"With their commitment and drive they actively shape the conversations about local areas and inform local decision making. They help to improve their streets, they connect people with their neighbours, and they work closely with us in the Council. I hope they will continue this work and will make suggestions for local ward initiatives that can be developed through the City Living, Local Life programme."

City Living, Local Life is an initiative in which ward Councillors and residents work together to find practical solutions to local issues, and can access up £20,000 per ward per year to help kick-start or match fund specific projects.

Associations that received the Gold Standard Award this year demonstrated commitment to seeking out residents' views and ensuring that these are considered. The scheme was started in 2007 and 22 associations have been awarded a Gold Standard.

Further information about the Gold Standard Award can be found at www.rbkc.gov.uk/goldstandard or by contacting the Community Engagement Team on 020 7598 4633.
shortdescription: Six local resident and tenant associations had their work to improve their neighbourhoods and foster community spirit recognised by the Mayor of Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Julie Mills, when they received Gold Standard Awards.
shorttitle: Residents' associations sterling work recognised

headline: ALBERT BRIDGE RESTORED TO GLORY
prcopy:
Following the extensive refurbishment Albert Bridge has been restored to its original glory and is now open for business as of Friday 2 December.

The works, funded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Transport for London, should ensure it will remain operational well into the century.

Described by the late Poet Laureate, John Betjeman, as: "Shining with electric lights, grey and airy against the London sky, it is one of the beauties of the London river." It is looking very well after its restoration.

Designed and built by Rowland Mason Ordish as an Ordish-Lefeuvre Principle modified cable-stayed bridge, it quickly proved to be structurally unsound and so, between 1884 and 1887 Sir Joseph Bazalgette strengthened it using some of the design elements of a suspension bridge. In 1973 the Greater London Council carried out further strengthening work.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "I think we can be proud of the level of workmanship in the restoration of Albert Bridge. It proved even more challenging than we originally thought as once the work began, we discovered much worse corrosion to the iron and steel in the bridge.

"The amount of work has been truly monumental with over 10,000 bolts, 40,000 litres of paint and 1,000 tonnes of grit used during the restoration.

"I hope that residents and all other bridge-users will now be able to appreciate the need for the work we carried out on this unique London bridge, for surely, when lit up the Albert Bridge is one of the most beautiful nigh time sights in London."

At night the bridge is illuminated with: 3640 festoon lights - which are on the cable chains and toil booths, 240 fluorescent tubes - which light to outer parapet, 190 flood lights - which light the towers, 16 street lights - which light the carriage and footway and navigational lights for river traffic.

shortdescription: Following the extensive refurbishment Albert Bridge has been restored to its original glory and is now open for business as of Friday 2 December.
shorttitle: Albert Bridge restored to glory

headline: GOLDEN GIRL'S TRIP TO THE PALACE
prcopy:
A young woman from North Kensington turned up in style at St James's Palace to receive her Duke of Edinburgh Gold Award from His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh on Wednesday 30 November 2011.

Maisa Mendes, who is originally from Gambia and lives in North Kensington, was chauffeur-driven to the ceremony, along with her mother, in the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's car.

Maisa has worked with the Royal Borough's Youth Sports Development Service for many years, during which time she has completed her Bronze, Silver and Gold Duke of Edinburgh Awards whilst also volunteering at Golborne Youth Club.

Speaking after receiving her award Maisa said: "I'm very grateful to the borough for supporting me through my awards, especially the Duke of Edinburgh Award Accreditation Team, and I'd like to thank the Mayor for being so kind in giving me, and my mum, a lift to St James's Palace in her official car, it made the day so special."

The Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Julie Mills, who attended the ceremony, said: "I was delighted to be able to accompany Maisa to the palace to receive her award from the Duke of Edinburgh. Maisa has put in a lot of hard work to achieve this award and is a credit to herself, her family and the Royal Borough."

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am very pleased that we have been able to support Maisa in her efforts to achieve her Duke of Edinburgh Awards. She clearly is a very motivated young woman who also finds time to help other young people."

If you are aged between 14 and 25 years and would like to find out more about the award or are interested in becoming a volunteer please contact the Council's Duke of Edinburgh officer Tuan Pham 0207 3523931 or email tuan.pham@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: A young woman from North Kensington turned up in style at St James's Palace to receive her Duke of Edinburgh Gold Award from His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh on Wednesday 30 November 2011.

headline: Greater London's Diamond Jubilee Celebrations begin
prcopy:
Holland Park was at the centre of London's civic calendar today (Friday 2 December) as Mayors from across the Capital came to launch Greater London's Diamond Jubilee Celebrations.

Organised by the Lord-Lieutenant of London, Sir David Brewer, representatives of all 32 London boroughs were in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to receive black poplars, which are being planted over the 620 square miles of London, to mark the Queen's Jubilee. Also in attendance was Sir David Attenborough.

Councillor Julie Mills, the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "It is wonderful to welcome all of you here and I thank the Lord Lieutenant for picking Holland Park to host this event.

"A year ago we took responsibility for growing black poplar saplings, generously donated for all the London boroughs by Mr Roger Jefcoate. Our Parks team is looking forward to delivering them in the coming weeks. I think they will be a living reminder of the Diamond Jubilee and it is a marvellous way to mark such a wonderful occasion."

The Lord-Lieutenant said: "The black poplar initiative epitomises the inclusivity that I am seeking to bring to next year's Diamond Jubilee celebrations and I hope that all 7.5 million residents in the 32 boroughs will become involved. I encourage you to participate fully in next year's events whether it is locally or centrally in the national celebrations planned for the June bank holiday weekend."

Black poplar saplings were planted in Holland Park earlier this year to allow them to take root.

The trees used to be a common sight across England, but are now an endangered species. The Queen has recognised this and has had saplings planted on her estates and in the Royal Parks.
shortdescription: Holland Park was at the centre of London's civic calendar today (Friday 2 December) as Mayors from across the Capital came to launch Greater London's Diamond Jubilee Celebrations.
shorttitle: Greater London's Diamond Jubilee Celebrations begin

headline: A WORLD-CLASS STREETSCAPE
prcopy:
After three years of meticulous construction work in Exhibition Road and South Kensington, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's contractor, Balfour Beatty, completed a project this month to create one of the most exciting streetscapes in the country.

The new-look road features a kerb-free single surface with no barriers or street clutter. Visual and tactile lines distinguish pedestrian areas from those used by vehicles. Cars are slowed by a 20mph speed limit.

A stunning chequered granite design runs from South Kensington Station to Hyde Park along the full width of the road from building to building. Kerbs, barriers and street clutter have been removed improving access, particularly for those using wheelchairs, push chairs and motorised buggies. Pedestrians can now walk from South Kensington Station to Hyde Park along a newly created shared space.

Black cast iron drainage channel covers run along each side of Exhibition Road, about four metres out from the respective building lines. Beside the drainage channels, strips of `corduroy' tactile warn blind and partially sighted people that they are moving into or out of vehicle free areas.

Tall, sleek street lighting masts have been designed to complement the grand buildings of Exhibition Road.

The reopening is being marked by a small ceremony to thank the staff and craftspeople who made it possible and the local people who supported the project. The official reopening ceremony will take place on 1 February 2012.

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "It has taken us the best part of ten years to get here but South Kensington and Exhibition Road finally have the setting they deserve.

"For 2012 and far beyond, London now has a unique streetscape that will delight our many millions of visitors and which sets a new standard for urban design."

Councillor Daniel Moylan, Deputy Chairman of Transport for London (TfL), said: "The improvements made to this cultural heartland of the Capital are exactly what the Mayor of London's Great Outdoors programme is seeking to achieve.

"The reimagining of the space has transformed Exhibition Road, improving the quality of life for people living and working in, and for those visiting, the borough. In addition, the uplift in local retail has helped nearby business and dramatically improved the pedestrian experience.

"It is a great example of how TfL and the boroughs are contributing to transform the streets and public spaces in the Capital in advance of the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games."

Leader of Westminster Council, Cllr Colin Barrow, added: "The project at Exhibition Road has made a dramatic impact on the South Kensington streetscape and we are delighted to see the successful completion of these improvements. The streamlined streetscape ensures that the area is at its best for the millions of visitors each year and fits in well with our own streetscape improvements across the City of Westminster."

A larger formal opening ceremony, led by the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, will take place in February. Exhibition Road is the largest project in the Mayor's London's Great Outdoors programme, which aims to revitalise public space across the Capital.
shortdescription: After three years of meticulous construction work in Exhibition Road and South Kensington, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's contractor, Balfour Beatty, completed a project this month to create one of the most exciting streetscapes in the country.
shorttitle: A world-class streetscape

headline: CARERS' RIGHTS DAY
prcopy:
Last Friday (2 December) was Carers' Rights Day. A national awareness raising day, it gave an opportunity for carers to find out more about the services on offer to them and for groups who help carers to meet and discuss the challenges they face.

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves launched the `Carers' Rights Advice and Information Day: Money Matters'. It offered an opportunity to meet a host of groups and join in workshops looking at everything from fuel poverty, debt awareness, credit unions and housing benefit changes to Lasting Power of Attorney, personal budgeting and switching energy suppliers.

The day also saw the launch of the latest Carers' Joint Strategy for 2011 to 2014. A joint publication between the Council and NHS Kensington and Chelsea it aims to raise the profile of carers, help provide them with information and services to improve their health and wellbeing, give carers more choice and control over decisions that affect them and improve the life opportunities of young carers.

Councillor Hargreaves said: "I am delighted to be here to open this Carers' Rights Day. Carers do a vital job, often without the help and recognition they deserve. It is heartening to see how many groups are here that can offer help and advice and I would encourage anyone who is a carer to get in touch and find out what can be done to make it easier for them. It is important to remember you are not alone."

If you are a carer or know a carer and want to find out more about what is available call Social Services line on 020 7361 3013, email socialservices@rbkc.gov.uk or visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/peoplefirst

headline: BUSINESSWOMEN SUPPORT DUKE'S AWARD
prcopy:
A leading group of businesswomen heard about the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's commitment to supporting young people take up the challenge of The Duke of Edinburgh Award (DofE) on Tuesday 29 November.

The DofE's Women in Business group, which was attended by HRH the Countess of Wessex, heard how the Council's lead officer on The DofE Award, Louisa Guthrie, got involved with the Award while growing up on a council estate in west London. Louisa explained that the Award had made such a huge impact on her that she decided to become a youth worker, giving more young people the chance to do it. Louisa is currently leading the UK's first group of young mums through their Gold DofE Award.

Louisa said, "I wanted to give teenage mums the chance to do their DofE. It was going to be a challenge, but it would give them the chance to get back on their feet, gain skills and eventually get into work. We started with the bronze, taking their babies on expedition. Now they are doing their Gold, the babies are children, and the mums are all working, in education or training."

HRH The Countess of Wessex, said: "We hear about the number of young people out of work, education or training on a daily basis and I believe the DofE has never been more relevant. We know that employers look for the DofE on young people's CVs, it could help them get that essential first job."

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am very pleased that young people in the borough are taking on the challenge of completing their Duke of Edinburgh Awards under Louisa's guidance. Time and time again the Award shows the positive contribution young people make to the life of our community."

The Women in Business group is made up of senior figures from a wide range of industries and sectors in support of the charity. Many of those attending the event had first-hand experience of The Duke of Edinburgh's Award through their own children's participation. The event was sponsored by investment management company, Williams de Broe. It took place at Bonham's Auction House.

The Duke of Edinburgh's Award is for all young people (14 to 24) and more than 280,000 participants do their DofE every year. It is highly valued by employers, and participants and leaders alike believe the DofE develops the skills, confidence and commitment needed to get into work.
shortdescription: A leading group of businesswomen heard about the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's commitment to supporting young people take up the challenge of The Duke of Edinburgh Award (DofE) on Tuesday 29 November.
shorttitle: Businesswomen support Duke's Award

headline: HAVE YOUR SAY ON LIFE IN THE ROYAL BOROUGH
prcopy:
People who live in Kensington and Chelsea are being encouraged to join the Council's Residents' Panel and give their opinion on Council's services. Those who have received their invite in the post can take the opportunity to register online at www.rbkc.gov.uk/residentspanelregistration

The panel is a sample of residents, usually between 1,000 and 2,000, who agree to take part in regular consultations. The letters inviting people to join the panel were sent out in November to 10,000 residents, chosen at random from the electoral register.

Current members of the panel have already helped identify ways in which the Council can improve by giving their views on topics including local markets, community safety, parks and the Council's spending priorities.

Panel members can take part in quick, snapshot polls, answer online questionnaires or get involved in more in-depth discussions. They can also register an interest in taking part in an online focus group. This all means that panel members will be able to decide how involved they want to be. Many of the activities will be online, but it is also possible to have your say in person if you don't have access to a computer. In addition, residents can access the internet for free in the Council's libraries.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "The Residents' Panel is a very important touchstone for the Council. Members have a chance to tell us what they think about our services and our plans and their views really do matter. It's a great way to have your say, or give feedback, about what happens in your area."

For more information about the Residents' Panel email consult@rbkc.gov.uk

Those who have received their invite in the post can take the opportunity to register online at www.rbkc.gov.uk/residentspanelregistration
shorttitle: Have your say on life in the Royal Borough

headline: NEW PUBLIC TOILETS WIN NATIONAL AWARDS
prcopy:
Two newly refurbished public toilets that serve Portobello and Golborne Road markets have won five awards in the 2011 'Loo of the Year Awards'.

The toilets, at Bevington Road and Talbot Road, were refurbished by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and reopened for public use this year.

Talbot Road toilet was judged to be the National Category Winner in England for Full Time Attended Public Toilets.

The toilets scooped two of 240 Local Authority Public Toilet Five Star Awards, one each for Talbot Road and Bevington Road.

The attendants at both facilities were rated as five star.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Cabinet Member for the Environment, said: "I am very pleased that these excellent public toilets have been recognised nationally in the Loo of the Year Awards."

headline: PARTNER INITIATIVE TO HELP LOCAL JOB SEEKERS
prcopy:
People who find it difficult to get a job such as young people, over 50s, ex-offenders and people suffering from mental health issues will now get special help from the North Kensington Jobcentre Plus thanks to a Council-led initiative.

The Government-funded partnership between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Jobcentre Plus, Kensington and Chelsea Volunteer Centre, Open Age and Connexions was launched on Wednesday 7 December by Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society for the Royal Borough, at the North Kensington Jobcentre Plus.

Support on offer will include one-to-one careers advice, physical health and fitness training, work experience placements and skills training.

Councillor Feilding-Mellen, said: "This partnership allows a number of public sector organisations and charities to work together to offer a joined-up approached to the challenges of finding a job for a variety of groups of people in our borough.

"I am delighted to be here today to mark this occasion and I am sure that in the coming months many of the Royal Borough's residents will be helped by the cooperation this partnership offers."

Georgette Budhram of Kensington Jobcentre Plus said: "The skills and qualifications gained through the placements with local groups will be invaluable for jobseekers in Kensington and Chelsea and will give them the support they need to get back into work.

"This is a great example of Jobcentre Plus working in partnership with local authorities and charities to give tailored and specialist support to jobseekers."

Anyone wanting to take part in the programme will need to be referred by a Jobcentre Plus adviser in the North Kensington office. For more information phone 0845 604 3719.

headline: TRADING AND ADVERTISING NEAR OLYMPIC VENUES
prcopy:
The London 2012 Olympic Games begin in fewer than 250 days and the clock is ticking not just for the world's top athletes but for businesses in Kensington and Chelsea that want to trade or advertise close to Earls Court, the venue for Olympic volleyball, or along the route of the road cycle races, which includes Knightsbridge, Brompton Road and Fulham Road.

By the end of February, outdoor traders need to have secured permission to operate at Games-time in 27 special `Event Zones', usually stretching no more than 200 metres from stadiums and sports facilities. Similarly, only advertisers which obtain approval will be able to advertise in these areas, with the deadline for public applications also being 29 February 2012.

The rules, now online, will ensure that spectators and those taking part in the Olympic and Paralympic Games can access venues easily and safely, and that the Games have a consistent look, without unauthorised marketing close to Earls Court and along the route of the cycle road race.

Restrictions on advertising and outdoor trading are a requirement of the contracts that host cities sign with the International Olympic Committee. They are now common practice at major international sporting events.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "I would urge all businesses close to Earls Court and along Knightsbridge, Brompton Road and Fulham Road to familiarise themselves with the restrictions on outdoor trading and advertising that will be enforced throughout the Olympic Games."

London 2012's website - www.london2012.com/advertisingandtrading -
explains where the rules on advertising and outdoor trading near venues will be implemented (with a postcode checker), how they will be enforced and when they will apply. It spells out the application process and criteria for authorisation, includes a detailed guide and shows examples of practices that do not require authorisation, or that can only be carried out if authorisation has been obtained.

The Advertising and Trading Regulations cover all trading in open public places within `Event Zones' during the periods in question - including roads and any land that the public has access to, and all forms of advertising. However, a number of exceptions mean that certain forms of trading and advertising do not require authorisation.

Examples of activities where no authorisation is required are deliveries of food and newspapers, advertising on buses and taxis carrying passengers through an Event Zone, advertising inside a building, and most existing shop signage.

Authorisation has to be obtained for open air trading activities including selling from temporary buildings like marquees, busking and collecting for charity. It will also have to be obtained for advertising on billboards and poster sites, for example, but authorisation will be reserved primarily for sponsors of the Games.

Advertising that is not expected to be permitted includes advertising by non-sponsors which aim to engage in `ambush marketing', such as temporary advertising, distributing direct advertising literature, and arranging for advertising giveaways in an Event Zone.

The public application process for advertising is open until the end of February 2012, and applications can be made to the London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games (LOCOG) by email or post.

Applications for permission to trade outdoors need to be made to the Olympic Delivery Authority (ODA) by the same date and will shortly be able to be made online. There is a right to ask for a review of the two organisations' decisions by the ODA, which is a public body.
The ODA is responsible for enforcement of the Regulations around Earls Court and along the route of the road cycle race.
ODA Chief Executive, Dennis Hone, said: "Our aim is to make sure that spectators can get to watch the sport they have paid for - without delay and without risk. That means limiting, for just a few weeks next summer, advertising and trading in public places on roads and pavements in the busiest areas close to Earls Court and along the cycle road race course. These are sensible regulations designed to make life easier for the public, the police, the transport system and ultimately for legitimate traders too."

shorttitle: Trading and advertising near Olympic venues

headline: MAN SENTENCED FOR HOUSING BENEFIT FRAUD
prcopy:
A man who falsely claimed housing benefit from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea whilst living in the London Borough of Haringey was sentenced to six months imprisonment, suspended for 18 months at Wood Green Crown Court on Monday 5 December 2011 by Mr Recorder A.R.H. Newham QC.

Mr Hanad Mohamoud of Omnibus House, Redvers Road, Haringey was also ordered to complete 200 hours unpaid work and was made the subject of a four-month tagged curfew (so he must be inside his property between the hours of 7pm and 5am).

Investigators from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Corporate Investigation Group became concerned about a housing benefit claim made by Mr Hanad Mohamoud following a separate investigation into his partner. She was also arrested and prosecuted for making a false housing benefit claim in the Royal Borough whilst living in the London Borough of Haringey.

Following a joint investigation with the Metropolitan Police, Mr Mohamoud was arrested and interviewed at Hornsey Police Station. He later pleaded guilty at Wood Green Crown Court to one charge of dishonestly obtaining housing benefit amounting to £23,359

Cllr Warwick Lightfoot, Cabinet Member for Finance and IT, said: "Thanks to some smart work by Council officers, this man's fraudulent claim for Housing Benefit has been stopped and the court has punished him. We remain vigilant and will not hesitate to prosecute people who systematically claim benefits fraudulently.

headline: GIRLS SUM UP THEIR IDENTITY WITH SWEETS AND MOBILES
prcopy:
It was Made in Chelsea with a twist when a bunch of girls from local youth clubs in Kensington and Chelsea launched their book Girl's Identity in which they used photos of themselves and things they use every day to cast a light on life in the Royal Borough.

The result of the two-year collaboration between girls from eight youth clubs is a snapshot of the varied lives enjoyed by a group of diverse young women growing up in this central London borough. The project was coordinated by the Council's Youth Arts Team.

The girls reacted to the project in different ways. Most of them did not want to use their faces in the book but chose to photograph objects that mean a great deal to them. The Moroccan girls' group used their dresses as to reflect their ethnic origins. The young women from the Chelsea Estates Youth Group chose to represent themselves with a poster showing items from their daily life: an Oyster card, lip-gloss, mobile phones and a set of keys while another poster features jelly beans and other sweets.

The captions on these and other photographs reflect their belief in themselves and their perception of growing up in London in the 21st century.

"Have faith and you'll go far" is the caption on a demure photo of hands against ethnic dresses.

"Life is about growing up and being who you are" says the caption of a picture of teenagers from the Golborne Youth Club who chose to show their faces and stare unsmilingly but self-assuredly at the camera.

Speaking at the launch at Chelsea Theatre SW10, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Mayor, Cllr Julie Mills, said: This book provides an invaluable record of life for young women living in the borough today. I want to congratulate all the girls who contributed and thank them for the care they took in choosing the photographs which succinctly capture the diversity and reality of living here.

"Their vibrancy and honesty is captivating and I am delighted to be able to display them and copies of the book in the Mayor's Parlour at the Town Hall until the New Year."

Copies of the book are also available from the borough's libraries.
shortdescription: It was Made in Chelsea with a twist when a bunch of girls from local youth clubs in Kensington and Chelsea launched their book Girl's Identity in which they used photos of themselves and things they use every day to cast a light on life in the Royal Borough.

headline: CHECK OUT WHICH ROADS WILL BE BUSIEST DURING THE OLYMPICS
prcopy:
Hosting the Olympic and Paralympic Games is a huge logistical challenge, similar in scale to having the FA Cup Final, Wimbledon, concerts across the Capital and the London Marathon all on the same day, every day, but over several weeks. The Games will have an impact on roads and public transport in Kensington and Chelsea, particularly in the Earl's Court area and along the route of the Olympic cycle road races.

TfL has developed an online planning tool, available at www.tfl.gov.uk/2012, to help people understand where and when roads will be at their busiest. This shows the additional journey time for those road journeys between various areas across London, at different times of the day. For example, in the morning peak, TfL expects journeys between Notting Hill and Wandsworth to increase by 30 minutes."

According to TfL around 70 per cent of Greater London's road traffic will be unaffected.

Days 1, 2, 6, 8 and 11 of the Games look particularly busy in the borough and would be good days to avoid driving in Kensington and Chelsea if possible. Severe disruption will be experienced on days 1 and 2 due to the Olympic cycle road races which take place that weekend with Knightsbridge, Brompton Road and Fulham Road closed to traffic and many other roads affected.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, the Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea said: "It is clear that as well as being an exciting spectacle the Olympic Games will mean more traffic on certain roads and busier stations on parts of the network. The way to minimise the impact of this is to plan ahead. TfL will be providing information on its website in the run up to and during the Games themselves and I would encourage residents and businesses to look carefully at this information."

TfL expects that two thirds of Tube and DLR stations will see no impact in terms of additional time taken to board a train. However, on the busiest days, there will an additional three million journeys in London as people watch the Games and attend cultural events, meaning the road and public transport networks will be much busier than usual in certain locations.

TfL's 2012 website also has useful information on delays expected at some of the busiest Underground stations in London. TfL will be adding to these, including some Royal Borough stations, in the coming weeks.

The Games will have an impact on roads and public transport in Kensington and Chelsea, particularly in the Earl's Court area and along the route of the Olympic cycle road races.

headline: GO AHEAD FOR NORTH KENSINGTON ACADEMY AND LEISURE CENTRE
prcopy:
Ambitious plans for a new school and leisure centre in North Kensington were given the go ahead last night (Monday 12 December) by the Cabinet of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

After carefully considering a number of design and cost options, the Cabinet committed to funding a new academy and a brand new leisure centre. This decision amounts to a massive £57.8m investment in the Notting Barns ward - one of the most deprived parts of the Royal Borough.

Demand for school places in the north of the borough is high, and a new school will help to address this shortage. The Government has already pledged £17.6m towards building the new academy and the Council has committed an additional £10.4m to ensure the school is built to the same high standard as Chelsea Academy. Co-sponsored by the Council, the lead sponsor of the academy is the Aldridge Foundation. The academy will seek to embed entrepreneurship and expressive arts at the heart of the curriculum.

The Council has also decided to commit £24.7m towards building a new leisure centre. The current leisure centre was built in the 1970s and is coming to the end of its useful life. An option to refurbish the existing leisure centre was rejected after architects estimated that full refurbishment would cost in the region of £14m, and would only extend the centre's life by ten years. The brand new centre should last up to 50 years.

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said:

"This decision is very good news for North Kensington and represents part of the Council's ongoing commitment to the redevelopment and regeneration of the area.

"We are prepared to invest the cash necessary to really tackle the disparity between the north and south of the borough. This initiative will not only help to address the shortage of school places but give the community brand new leisure facilities to enjoy for decades to come.

"However, before we submit a planning application we have a lot more work ahead of us and promise that we will continue to involve and listen to people every step of the way."

Following the Cabinet's decision, Chairman of the Aldridge Foundation, Rod Aldridge, said:

"The additional funding will enable us to provide an incredible Academy school for the young people of North Kensington and parents will be proud of the high standards we are aiming for. It will also be a valuable community asset, from which the local residents will benefit.''

The preferred option also includes the provision of some new housing along Bomore Road. A more detailed appraisal of this element of the project will be undertaken in the coming months.

The Council's plans for an academy and leisure centre will then form a planning application that the Council aims to submit in June 2012. A decision by the Council's Planning Application Committee is then expected in the summer of 2012.

For more information on the project please visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/kalc

headline: ENTREPRENEURS WIN BACKING FOR MARKET PITCH
prcopy:
Two young entrepreneurs are looking forward to trading on the world famous Portobello Market after being named winners of the Royal Borough's Market Enterprise Launch Pad 2011.

Jo Hawtree, who is starting a men's fashion label called `Gunsmoke & Lavender', and Emily Ellen Dell, who sells bespoke art on canvas under the name `Girl on a Swing', have each won £1,000 in start-up funds, six months rent-free market stall space on Portobello Market, a support package from the Prince's Trust and free business insurance. The project was funded by the John Lyon's Charity and run by the Council's Education Partnership Team.

The announcement comes on the day the retail guru Mary Portas launched her Government commissioned review of Britain's High Streets.

Seven young entrepreneurs were selected to pitch their ideas to a panel of judges, last Friday 9 December, including representatives from the Council, the homeware designer Cath Kidston, Circle Sports, the Prince's Trust, John Lyon's Charity. The judges commented that it was difficult to select two winners as all the business ideas were viable though some were better suited to a market environment than others.

Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Council, said: "Congratulations to Jo and Emily in beating off the competition and winning their stalls in London's finest street market.

"I know that a stall on the Portobello Market has been the springboard that has helped launch successful businesses in the past."

headline: MAYOR'S CHARITY CHRISTMAS CAROLS
prcopy:
An evening of Christmas carols and readings at Our Lady of Victories Church, in aid of the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's charities, was enjoyed by hundreds of people on Monday 12 December.

The Mayor, Councillor Julie Mills, is supporting four local charities that work with isolated older residents. They are: Age Concern Kensington and Chelsea, Open Age, the Second Half Centre and the Pepper Pot Centre.

The congregation heard festive readings from author Sebastian Faulks, Jamie Laing from the television show `Made in Chelsea', actress Claire Bloom, Chelsea Pensioner Marjorie Cole and Lord Cadogan, as well as from those who use some of the organisations that will benefit from the Mayor's fundraising efforts.

After hearing and singing some of the nation's favourite carols, concert goers enjoyed mince pies and wine.

Speaking after the event, the Mayor said: "I am delighted that so many people were able to come to Our Lady of Victories to enjoy the carols and the readings. I'd like to thank all the readers for their wonderful contributions. All the money raised will go to my nominated charities that do so much to tackle the issue of social isolation which, particularly at Christmas, can affect so many people."

headline: WHAT'S GOING ON IN YOUR LIBRARY?
prcopy:
Next year an exciting range of events for people of all ages are coming to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's libraries.

As part of the Bloomsbury season, historians and novelists will give a rare insight into their latest works through a series of special talks. The programme kicks off on Thursday 12 January with Anna Reid delving into the history of Stalinist Russia by discussing her book Leningrad: Tragedy of a City under Siege.

In March critically acclaimed author Lady Antonia Fraser comes to Kensington Central Library to discuss her most recent book Must You Go? which celebrates her life with Harold Pinter.

BBC Correspondents Richard Hamilton and Mark Harper will also be on hand in March to discuss their latest books and answer questions about their experiences as foreign correspondents.

Throughout February there will also be a number of fun events for children and families, including a workshop to celebrate the Chinese New Year, a cartoon workshop and a mask making session.

Tickets are on sale in all of the borough's libraries and are priced at £5 (£3 concessions). Payments by credit or debit card can be made via Librariesline on 020 7361 3010. Events for children, young people and families are free.

For a full list of events please visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/libraries
shortdescription: Next year an exciting range of events for people of all ages are coming to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's libraries.
shorttitle: What's going on in your library?

headline: MARKET TRADERS GET POWER SUPPLY
prcopy:
In the New Year market traders operating on the northern stretch of Portobello Road are set to get an electricity supply thanks to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Currently this part of Portobello Road between Cambridge Gardens and Golborne Road does not have an electricity supply for the market traders and does not benefit from the same level of footfall as the heart of Portobello Road. The Council wants to regenerate this under-used area and strengthen the link between Portobello and Golborne Markets.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for the Environment, said:

"This investment is part of the Council's ongoing commitment to the regeneration of the Royal Borough's markets.

"Installing a power supply is a practical way of helping us give our market traders the infrastructure they need to maximise trading."

The works will take part in two stages at a total cost of £199,865.75. The first stage will deliver the new electricity supply to traders between Acklam Road and Raddington Road in January 2012. The second stage will provide the new supply to traders between Raddington Road and Golborne Road and will be installed in February and March 2012.

headline: COACHING CAN KICK OFF JOB OPPORTUNITIES
prcopy:
A trainee football coaching programme, run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, may help five unemployed young men from Kensington and Chelsea into the job market.

The four-month `Trainee Football Coaching Scheme', run by the Council is a bespoke education and training programme for unemployed young people in the borough who have aspirations to become football coaches.

The programme enables up to six young people to develop and gain valuable practical coaching experience through working with children and young people in both a school and community setting.

Based at Westway Sports Centre the coaching scheme works intensively with the young trainee coaches and focuses on the development of the key attributes and skills required to be a good quality young coach. Each of the five trainees has gained their FA Level One coaching qualification and has completed over 120 hours of both practical coaching sessions with local primary schools, and a variety of coach development sessions.

The scheme acts as a stepping stone to part-time employment and apprenticeship opportunities within the local community. Local employers such as Westway Sports Centre, QPR Community Sports Trust, Chelsea FC Community Foundation, New Hope Academy and Active Planet have all supported this programme and have integrated young coaches into their programmes.

Leroy Gravesande, one of the five trainees, said: "This scheme has given me the confidence and abilities I need in order to progress and become a better football coach. I now hope to gain part-time coaching work or an apprenticeship position to gain additional experience."

Councillor Baroness Ritchie, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Schemes like this play a big part in bringing out young people's talents. I hope that this coaching programme will act as a launch pad into employment for these five young people."

For further information about the scheme please contact the Youth and School Sports Development Team by emailing sports.development@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: A trainee football coaching programme, run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, may help five unemployed young men from Kensington and Chelsea into the job market.
shorttitle: Coaching can kick off job opportunities

headline: EQUIPMENT TO MAKE LIFE EASIER COMES TO HIGH STREET
prcopy:
From Monday 9 January, people who need help with day-to-day tasks such as bathing, getting dressed or preparing meals can get equipment to make things easier from accredited high street shops. The type of equipment available includes raised toilet seats to help with getting on and off the toilet, bath boards to help get in and out of the bath, walking sticks and a range of items to help in the kitchen.

Residents, who have been assessed as eligible by Health or Social Services staff, will receive a `prescription' entitling them to receive the equipment free of charge, from one of the accredited retailers.

It is also possible to pay extra towards a version of the equipment that is more to individual taste. For example, a different model or a different colour to suit the home environment.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Adult Social Care and Non-executive Director at NHS Kensington & Chelsea said: "Sometimes a piece of simple equipment, or the right gadget, can make all the difference to a person's quality of life.

"The accreditation scheme means that residents can visit local retailers, confident that they will receive accurate information on the equipment, whether they choose to buy it themselves or be assessed and receive a prescription."

Prescriptions are only issued for simple aids to daily living. These are usually small items such as raised toilet seats which cost less than £100. Accredited retailers will supply a range of such items on the local high street. This equipment can also be bought, without a prescription, from retailers approved by the Council according to the Department of Health's national accreditation criteria.

Larger pieces of equipment, known as `complex aids to daily living', are not available by prescription. These are things such as a battery-powered mobile hoist to help people get in and out of bed.

Residents who feel they may need this equipment can contact Social Servicesline on 020 7361 3013 or email socialservices@rbkc.gov.uk and request an assessment. A professional will then assess them and provide the items required, ensuring they meet the person's needs and can be used safely.

There will be a launch event on Friday 27 January at Kensington Town Hall for residents who would like to find out more about the equipment and the national accreditation scheme. If you are interested in attending and would like more information contact Sharon Thurley on 020 7361 2425 or email Sharon.thurley@rbkc.gov.uk

You can visit our website www.rbkc.gov.uk/peoplefirst for information about community equipment and other support available.
