headline: REPRESENT THE BOROUGH AT THE LONDON YOUTH GAMES
prcopy:
The Balfour Beatty London Youth Games 2012, Europe's largest sporting event for young people, takes place at Crystal Palace National Sports Centre on Saturday 30 June and Sunday 1 July 2012. The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea wants to recruit young sportsmen and women (aged between eight and 18), who live or go to school in the borough, to represent it at the games.

With over 42 sports in the games there is a great choice on offer and the Council wants as many young people as possible to come along to the trials and training sessions.

The sports involved range from archery and fencing to kayaking and weightlifting and include the more traditional football, swimming, netball and basketball.

The borough also wants to recruit disabled athletes to take part in swimming, athletics and Boccia.

Cllr Baroness Ritchie, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Events at the London Youth Games are always keenly contested and I expect that in Olympic year we will see some very impressive performances."

"I hope that lots of young people come forward to take part in our training sessions and trials and I wish those selected to represent Kensington and Chelsea the best of luck at the games."

You can find out more about what's on offer and how to get involved by emailing the Youth and School Sports Development Team sports.development@rbkc.gov.uk

Or check out their Facebook page: RBKC Youth and School Sports Development Team

headline: LITTLE WORMWOOD SCRUBS STRIKES GOLD
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea celebrated its first gold in Olympic year on Monday night (27 February) when it was recognised for the transformation of Little Wormwood Scrubs.

The Mayor of London's `Safer Parks Award' recognises the high levels of public satisfaction with the park, including the positive impact on the local community and the reduction in crime and antisocial behaviour over the past three years.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Environment, said: "It is a great result for all those who have been involved in refreshing Little Wormwood Scrubs. We have been working hard to improve the park and offer more opportunities for residents to enjoy all that it has to offer.

"I would like to thank the Royal Borough's park's team and the Park's Police for their dedication over the past few years. We have worked closely with the Friends of Little Wormwood Scrubs and have already gained a Green Flag and London in Bloom Gold award for the park."

The Council has put in significant funds to develop the park and also secured funding from the Mayor of London's Parks scheme.

Working with boroughs, the Mayor's Safer Parks Award scheme provides opportunities to revitalise public space, making a big difference to London's quality of life and helping create a safer city.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea celebrated its first gold in Olympic year on Monday night (27 February) when it was recognised for the transformation of Little Wormwood Scrubs.
shorttitle: Little Wormwood Scrubs strikes gold

headline: POPULAR BOROUGH SCHOOLS OVER-SUBSCRIBED
prcopy:
Secondary schools in the Royal Borough continue to be exceedingly popular and heavily over-subscribed as parents from across London vied for a place for children due to start in Year 7 next autumn.

Figures released last week (Thursday 1 March) show that there were 3,325 applications, an increase on last year, for the borough's five secondary schools, Cardinal Vaughan, Holland Park, Chelsea Academy, St Thomas More Language College and Sion Manning.

Kensington and Chelsea's schools are amongst the best in the country and this fuels demand from parents. Last year 73 per cent of GCSE students in the borough's schools achieved 5+ A* to C GCSEs including English and mathematics.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Education, said: "Kensington and Chelsea Council invests heavily in education. To cope with the increased demand we are planning to build a new secondary school in North Kensington and expect to submit a planning application later this spring so that more local children can benefit from an excellent Royal Borough education. In 2009 we opened Chelsea Academy in the south of the borough and this has quickly proved to be an extremely popular school."

This year over half of children applying got into their first choice school and 83 per cent got at least one of the top three choices on their application form.

headline: REGENERATING CREMORNE WHARF
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is exploring proposals for regenerating the Cremorne Wharf site.

Over the years, Cremorne Wharf, which is owned by the borough, has been used for a series of industrial activities including a waste management facility, a base for street cleaning and a winter salt store.

Today, the site is no longer a base for Council operations and the Council wants to bring forward a proposal that benefits the local community, creating new private and affordable homes on the river, small business space and a river walk which will link to its neighbour, Lots Road Power Station.

Friday 9 March from 4.30pm to 7.30pm
Saturday 10 March from 9.30am to 1pm
Venue: Chelsea Academy, Lots Road, London SW10 0AB

headline: WELCOME OUR HEROES HOME
prcopy:
Make sure our army heroes get the welcome home they deserve by lining the streets of Kensington for a special parade this Saturday, 10 March.

The Royal Yeomanry, the oldest Territorial Army Yeomanry Regiment within the Royal Armoured Corps, will march with bayonets fixed, drums beating and colours flying to mark its return from active service - many recently returned from Afghanistan.

Accompanied by mounted outriders and armoured personnel carriers, the march will start from Holland Park at 11am and continue along Kensington High Street, Kensington Church Street, along Holland Street and finish at Kensington Town Hall.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Julie Mills, who will take the salute opposite High Street Kensington Tube Station, said: "I encourage residents and visitors to show their support and cheer on the troops as they march through the borough."

The Commanding Officer of the Royal Yeomanry, Lieutenant Colonel Newton Astbury said: "We are delighted to be able to exercise our Freedom of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and for the borough to welcome our soldiers back to the UK that have recently served overseas. It's a special honour that we are able to do this in our own right and we are very grateful that the borough is supporting us in this way. The regiment and the borough have a long and enduring friendship and it's significant that the borough will also be signing its Armed Forces Community Covenant during the reception that follows our parade."

The Royal Yeomanry (experts in detecting and dealing with chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear threats) has over a 100-year history of defending Britain at home and overseas.

For further information on the parade contact the Mayor's Office on 020 7361 3659.
shortdescription: Make sure our army heroes get the welcome home they deserve by lining the streets of Kensington for a special parade this Saturday, 10 March.
shorttitle: Welcome our heroes home

headline: ST QUINTIN CHILDREN ENJOY DREAM TRIP TO EURO DISNEY
prcopy:
A meeting with Woody and other characters from Toy Story and breakfast with Mickey and Minnie Mouse were just some of the highlights of a dream trip to Euro Disney for 27 children with disabilities who attend the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's St Quintin Centre in North Kensington.

The trip, which was arranged as part of the Centre's ongoing holiday project, gives children a chance to have a break apart from their parents.

For some of the children, all of whom have complex needs, this was their first time away from their parents. They were looked after by 28 staff.

Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Education, said: "The children were so excited to meet Woody and other Disney characters on their trip to Euro Disney. I'd like to thank the staff and volunteers who looked after them on what, while an exciting time, would also have been difficult as for many it was the first time away from their family."

Yaseen el Darrett (8), said: "I had a brilliant time especially eating my breakfast with Goofy. We went on Space Mountain, it went upside down and we all screamed."

The St Quintin Centre has now been open for nearly two years and has established itself as a leading provider of short breaks for disabled children.

It is the first port of call for families with a disabled child. On offer are Saturday and afterschool activities, holiday activities, family days out, a playgroup for under fives and parent pampering sessions.

The Centre also has a project where an adapted caravan on the south coast can be hired for a family holiday.
shortdescription: A meeting with Woody and other characters from Toy Story and breakfast with Mickey and Minnie Mouse were just some of the highlights of a dream trip to Euro Disney for 27 children with disabilities who attend the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's St Quintin Centre in North Kensington.
shorttitle: St Quintin Centre children enjoy dream trip to Euro Disney

headline: COMMUNITY AWARD FOR EXHIBITION ROAD
prcopy:
The new-look Exhibition Road was hailed as an example to follow by the Institute of Civil Engineers (ICE) at its prestigious annual awards ceremony. The Institute recognised the transformation of an unwelcoming and cluttered thoroughfare into an attractive open space for pedestrians by naming the project the winner of the Community Award category.

The award recognises projects which improve public space and infrastructure and enhance the living and working environment for the local community. Winning projects must demonstrate innovation, creativity and social value.

The judges said: "We really liked Exhibition Road because for the first time in London it makes an attempt to rebalance people and vehicles. We would love to see the messages from that extended to the wider UK."

Responding to the award, Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I am delighted that the Institute of Civil Engineers recognised the work that has been done on Exhibition Road to make South Kensington a more vibrant, welcoming area for visitors and residents alike.

"We have been planning this work for many years and I would like to thank the Council officers for their hard work and the support of TfL and the City of Westminster, without which this would not have been possible. Finally, of course, I would also like to thank my former deputy, Daniel Moylan, for his vision and drive in starting the scheme. The case for improving our public spaces has had no more articulate or determined advocate than Daniel Moylan. "

Among the other projects shortlisted for awards were the redevelopment of Broadcasting House, refurbishment of Blackwall Tunnel, part of the redevelopment of Kings Cross and The Shard.
shortdescription: The new-look Exhibition Road was hailed as an example to follow by the Institute of Civil Engineers (ICE) at its prestigious annual awards ceremony.  The Institute recognised the transformation of an unwelcoming and cluttered thoroughfare into an attractive open space for pedestrians by naming the project the winner of the Community Award category.
shorttitle: Community Award for Exhibition Road

headline: COUNCIL SETS BUDGET
prcopy:
The Council of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea set its budget for the next financial year at its meeting in Kensington Town Hall last night (Wednesday 7 March).

The meeting heard that despite the UK's slow recovery from recession, and necessary reductions in Government funding for the borough of £9 million, the Council would seek to protect its services, maintain financial stability and continue to make the Royal Borough a better place to live.

Nor will the 2012-13 budget rely on increases in council tax to fill the gap. In fact council tax will be frozen for the third year in a row, thanks in part to a ring-fenced grant from the Government.

Leader of the Council, Sir Merrick Cockell, said: "Although we have to reduce our spending, we are doing all we can to deliver services of good, often excellent, quality, making sure they are targeted at those most in need. Last month, 85 per cent of residents told us they were satisfied with the way the Council is working for them, up from 80 per cent in 2011.

"To maintain these high standards, we are sharing services with City of Westminster and Hammersmith & Fulham wherever that makes sense. This will make a big contribution over the next four years and beyond. We can also maintain an ambitious capital programme, including the new Kensington Aldridge Academy and the rebuilding of Kensington Leisure Centre."
shortdescription: The Council of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea set its budget for the next financial year at its meeting in Kensington Town Hall last night (Wednesday 7 March).
shorttitle: Council sets budget

headline: USE DIRECT DEBIT FOR CHANCE TO WIN £25,000
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea residents stand a chance of winning £25,000 if they pay their council tax by Direct Debit before 5pm on 12 July 2012.

The Royal Borough is working with 17 other London local authorities and Bacs Payment Schemes Ltd (Bacs), the not-for-profit organisation behind Direct Debit, to offer council tax payers the opportunity to win this prize.

Residents who already pay by Direct Debit will be automatically entered into the prize draw.

Other residents can register to pay their council tax by Direct Debit by phoning the Council on 020 7361 3007 or by returning a completed paper instruction - this can be found on the Council's website www.rbkc.gov.uk/counciltax

Cllr Warwick Lightfoot, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Finance, said: "Direct Debit is a much cheaper and more efficient way for councils to process payments, and the money we save can be used for the benefit of local residents. Council tax bills will be delivered in March and we are encouraging as many people as possible to look out for the prize draw information included, switch to Direct Debit, and be in with a chance of winning the £25,000."

Dawneth Perry, market sector manager at Bacs, commented: "We are very pleased to be supporting the 17 participating local authorities in this exciting Direct Debit promotion. Paying your council tax by Direct Debit can save you time, help you gain greater control on your finances and offers peace of mind that you will not miss a payment.

"Direct Debit enables customers to benefit from a safe, trusted, reliable and hassle free payment method, while giving them the chance to win a fantastic cash prize, and helping their local council to save money at the same time. We have estimated that last year's campaign saved almost £350,000 across the participating boroughs and the conversion of council tax payers to Direct Debit will continue to deliver savings for those local authorities year-on-year."
shortdescription: Kensington and Chelsea residents stand a chance of winning £25,000 if they pay their council tax by Direct Debit before 5pm on 12 July 2012.
shorttitle: Use Direct Debit for chance to win £25,000

headline: OPERA HOLLAND PARK SPREADS ITS WINGS
prcopy:
Opera Holland Park, the opera company founded in 1996 and run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, is set to become an independent company if the Royal Borough's Cabinet agree at its meeting on Thursday 22 March. The new company's first season as a private company will be the 2013 summer season.

Both the Royal Borough and Opera Holland Park want it to become a private company and a charity because it will allow the opera to work more commercially outside of local government. The Royal Borough will continue to support the company and its summer festival with a new funding agreement that will ensure that the opera's popular accessibility schemes and cheap or free seats continue.

Currently sponsored by Investec Wealth & Investment, Opera Holland Park has grown by leaps and bounds since its first production in 1996. It now has a turnover of about £3 million and receives an annual subsidy of about £450,000 from the Royal Borough. The average season occupancy for OHP has exceeded 95 per cent since 2001.

This new direction is supported by the Friends of Opera Holland Park, who will be closely involved in the future of the company.

A board, lead by distinguished media lawyer, trustee of OHP Friends and supporter of OHP, Martin Kramer will oversee the company's transition to full independence He will be joined on the shadow board by Chris Cotton, John Grumbar and Colin Fletcher.

Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, the Cabinet Member for the Arts said;
"Our aim is to ensure the company has the brightest future possible and we will continue to work closely with it as grant funders of the company. The people running the company have everything it takes to ensure that their many supporters rally round and help turn OHP into an even greater success.

"Our commitment to the company is as strong as ever and we want it to flourish. At the same time the Council, in tough times, will have reduced the financial risk to the Council and given Opera Holland Park the freedom to determine its own destiny and to grow in new and exciting ways."

David Colver, the Chairman of The Friends of Holland Park said:
"The Friends of Opera Holland Park have been a major contributor to OHP for over ten years. We look forward to working with the Council in the next phase of this process; to help establish the best way forward for the company and to consolidate its position as one of London's cultural jewels. Accessibility has always been a driving principle of OHP and we are pleased to see it remaining at the core of the company's future. We intend to play a full part in supporting the company in the years to come."

Michael Volpe. General Manager of OHP said;
"For some years, James Clutton, OHP's Producer, and I have become ever more convinced that the company will need independence from the Council if it is to flourish in what will be the company's `adult' life. Our work has enjoyed enormous critical success for many years and it is time to spread our wings and fly the council's nest. It is a very exciting time ahead for the company and our thousands of supporters."

shortdescription: Opera Holland Park, the opera company founded in 1996 and run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, is set to become an independent company if the Royal Borough's Cabinet agree at its meeting on Thursday 22 March. shorttitle: Opera Holland Park spreads its wings

headline: MUMS NAIL BEAUTY COURSE
prcopy:
A course that aims to give women a helping hand into the beauty therapy industry has been completed by 34 women in Kensington and Chelsea.

Organised through the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's children's centres the course originally focused on working with acrylic nails but proved so popular that the participants, most of whom are busy mothers, asked for the programme to be extended to contain extra modules, including one on starting a business that would enable them to begin work as mobile beauty therapists.

Their positive experience has inspired the women to plan and organise a special training day in the borough's children's centres where they will share some of their new skills with other local parents.

Certificates were presented to all those who have passed the course at a special ceremony, on International Women's Day (8 March 2012).

This International Women's Day event was organised single-handedly local parent Roya Scotland, who is now working as a volunteer liaison officer for children's centres. Roya said: "I found it very hard to find work after being made redundant. Whilst on maternity leave I saw the opportunity to do courses and training through the children's centres and am now a Volunteer Parent Liaison Officer for our children's centres. I am now confident that my future is bright - thanks to all the training I'm on my journey to success."

The International Women's Day Event also celebrated the success of local women who have progressed from attending breastfeeding classes to successfully completing training as La Leche League Breastfeeding Counsellors. These women are now able to volunteer in the borough's breastfeeding cafes to support other mothers. Women who have undertaken this training have, in the past, also been successful in gaining employment as maternity assistants attached to local hospitals.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Well done to all the mothers who have completed this course. I know they have enjoyed it and hope the new skills they have learned will help them find work in the very popular beauty therapy sector."
shortdescription: A course that aims to give women a helping hand into the beauty therapy industry has been completed by 34 women in Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Mums nail beauty course

headline: TRI-BOROUGH PROGRAMME BOOSTS SAVINGS TARGETS TO £40M
prcopy:
An ambitious shared services programme between Westminster, Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea councils has scaled up its savings target to £40 million a year across the three boroughs by 2015/16, up from £33 million a year forecast previously.

The three London councils announced their ambitions for the extra £7m of savings, which have been identified within the corporate services portfolio, in a new tri-borough progress report which was tabled on 7 March during a meeting between the three councils' leaders and Communities Secretary Eric Pickles.

The report highlights a number of key achievements by the three councils one year on from their original plans to share services, including:

 We have reduced the number of senior and middle managers across the three boroughs by 50 per cent and have dramatically reduced the cost of our executive pay bill

 We have made our funds go further. We announced our first £1m of savings in October 2011 and are on-track to deliver the original target savings of £7.7m by 2012/13 and £33.4m by 2014/15. We are also ambitious that we will save a further £7m a year by 2015/16

 We have protected front-line services by combining children's services, adult social care and library services across the three boroughs, and have started to share environment services across Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea councils. Nearly four in five (79 per cent) of tri-borough residents are now satisfied with the way their council is running the area, up from 77 per cent from the start of 2011

 We have shown how honest comparison across three sovereign authorities can help identify new and better ways of working and increasing pace across our three organisations.

Commenting on the latest tri-borough achievements, Communities Secretary Eric Pickles said:
"This report shows how councils can make sensible savings through sharing back office services, joining forces to procure and cutting down on middle management whilst protecting frontline services.

"The success of the tri-borough programme is testament to the innovation and forward thinking of Westminster, Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea."

Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Leader Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell said: "The decisions we took to share services have resulted in significant savings which is good news for our residents. What is also good news is that we have identified new ways of working that mean we should be able to improve the quality of some of the services that we are providing our residents."

Westminster City Council Leader-elect Cllr Philippa Roe said: "The tri-borough programme is already providing significant savings by allowing us to reduce management and back-office costs. The fact we have now scaled up our savings target to an ambitious £40m a year by 2015/16 illustrates just how much potential there is within this programme to respond to tough budget challenges while helping us protect, and in many cases improve, the frontline services we offer to our residents."

Hammersmith & Fulham Council Leader Stephen Greenhalgh said: "We have reduced management costs by 38 per cent including sharing a chief executive. Through shared contract arrangements, we are driving down the price of the services we buy. These back-office savings mean we have been able to cut council tax in Hammersmith & Fulham and our partner boroughs are freezing theirs, all without the service cuts seen elsewhere. At a time when other councils are looking to close libraries, we have kept all our libraries open."
shortdescription: An ambitious shared services programme between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster and Hammersmith & Fulham councils has scaled up its savings target to £40 million across the three boroughs by 2015/16, up from £33 million a year forecast previously.
shorttitle: Tri-borough programme boosts savings target to £40m

headline: SMOKERS INVITED TO 'TAKE THE LEAP' ON NO SMOKING DAY
prcopy:
Local smokers are invited to `Take the Leap' this No Smoking Day, with the support of their NHS Stop Smoking Service.

National No Smoking Day takes place on Wednesday 14 March, and this year's theme is a strong nod to the upcoming global sporting event; London 2012. Central London Community Healthcare NHS Trust (CLCH) runs the NHS Stop Smoking service in Kensington and Chelsea, and Westminster, and is encouraging local residents wanting to give up smoking to use this day as their springboard.

CLCH is running a range of events across both boroughs in the lead-up to and on No Smoking Day. The events give the public the opportunity to speak with specialist Stop Smoking advisors, do a carbon monoxide assessment and book an appointment at a local NHS Stop Smoking clinic.

Ivan Okyere-Boakye, CLCH Senior Manager for Health and Wellbeing, said; "Each year over a million people quit smoking on No Smoking Day. This campaign is great news for smokers as it creates a supportive environment for them to quit and highlights the local sources of help and advice available. If you are a smoker and think the time is right, why not take the leap and get the support you need to make it happen."

Details of No Smoking Day 2012 events in Kensington and Chelsea and Westminster can be found below. All stalls will be running from 9.30am to 4.00pm.

Monday 12 March - stall on the corner of Kings Road and Royal Avenue, SW3
Tuesday 13 March - stall at reception St. Charles Centre for Health and Wellbeing, W10 6DZ
Wednesday 14 March - stall at reception of Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, SW10 9NH
Wednesday 14 March - stall in the main foyer, Westminster City Hall, SW1E 6QP
Wednesday 14 March - stall at Lisson Grove Health Centre, Gateforth St, NW8 8EG

CLCH offers free NHS stop smoking support in a wide range of settings across both boroughs, including pharmacies, GPs and clinics. Specialist advisors offer one-to-one, group and telephone support, along with effective medications available on prescription or from a stop smoking pharmacist.

headline: ARTS & CRAFTS MARKET RETURNS TO PORTOBELLO
prcopy:
The Arts & Crafts market is returning to Portobello Road following a major investment by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

A dozen traders selling a variety of mostly handmade goods including fine art and photography, upcycled denim and vintage vinyl, drawing and illustration, jewellery, handicrafts, stoneware and more have taken advantage of a special introductory offer aimed at injecting vitality into the newly-refurbished square between Basing Street and Portobello Road (`Portobello Square').

Arts & Crafts traders include award-winning photographer Steve Ullathorne, Corinne White of Eco-rinne, and Karl Hildebrandt of Carlos the Jackal. Later this summer, on Saturday 30 June, the market will welcome Market Enterprise Launch Pad winner Emily Ellen Dell to her first day selling original `Girl on a Swing' canvases and souvenirs featuring unique drawings and paintings of many local and London landmarks.

The market will have its official relaunch on Saturday 24 March but ahead of this, on Saturday 17 March (and on 24 March), it will host a pop-up bookbinding workshop by Make, Thrift London. Interested members of the public can find details on how to book a place by following @rbkc_markets on Twitter, liking www.facebook.com/rbkcmarkets or visiting www.rbkc.gov.uk/streetmarkets

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "We are happy to welcome stallholders back to the new, improved Arts & Crafts market in Portobello Square, and wish them prosperous and rewarding trading. The Council's £550,000 infrastructure and public realm investment in the square will not only benefit market traders, but also residents, visitors and local businesses for years to come."

The six stalls closest to Portobello Road will have access to new electrical points embedded underground, and the square will benefit generally from new high-quality paving, lamp columns, tree lighting, circular benches, and come Christmas time, a tree pit designed to hold a 20-foot live Christmas tree - sure to be a real attraction during an important time of year for market traders.
shortdescription: The Arts & Crafts market is returning to Portobello Road following a major investment by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Arts & Crafts market returns to Portobello

headline: MINISTER VISITS GOLBORNE YOUTH CENTRE
prcopy:
Children's Minister Tim Loughton MP today (Monday 12 March) visited young people from Kensington and Chelsea who have struggled at school and are turning their lives around.

The children's minister met youngsters who have taken part in The Prince's Trust xl club, which is run in partnership with the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea at Golborne Youth Centre.

The xl club helps young people who are struggling at school to develop their skills and confidence and improve their grades.

The minister heard how one young man, Kieran, had tackled problems with literacy and numeracy with the help of The Prince's Trust course.

At 14, Kieran had very few aspirations for the future - he found school difficult and his confidence and self-esteem was extremely low. At this time, his attendance record was so poor that he had little chance of completing any GCSEs.

"I hated school so I tried to avoid going as much as possible," explains Kieran. "I was embarrassed about my reading and writing skills so I avoided going to lessons and my confidence was extremely low."

However, as part of the xl club, Kieran received one-to-one support to help boost his skills and self-esteem from the staff at Golborne Youth Centre. As his confidence improved, he started to take part in group activities and was even able to help with scriptwriting when the group produced a short film.

"The xl club really helped me to improve my reading and writing and feel more confident in my abilities. It also helped me find out what I was good at and what I wanted to do with my life."

Kieran's attendance record improved dramatically and, by the end of the course, he completed The Prince's Trust Level 1 qualification - the first qualification he had ever received.

Today, Kieran is studying at college and feeling optimistic about his future. He is taking part in a painting and decorating course at Kensington and Chelsea College and hopes to find a job after the course.

Kieran says: "I don't think I would have stayed on in education if it wasn't for The Prince's Trust and Golborne Youth Centre, and I know that the skills I gained on the course will really help me to get a job in the future."

Tanesia, 15, told the minister how The Prince's Trust xl club had helped boost her skills and confidence and improve her performance at school.

"Before I joined the xl club, I had very low self-esteem and was bullied a lot," explains Tanesia. "I didn't get on with other people in my class and was struggling in most of my subjects."

However, as part of the course, Tanesia got the one-to-one support she needed to focus on her education. She also took part in team-building activities and trips outside of school which helped her develop her interpersonal skills and improve her relationships with other pupils.

"Thanks to The Prince's Trust xl club and the youth workers at Golborne Youth Centre, I feel much more confident about my future. I'm working hard towards my GCSEs and plan to go to college in September," says Tanesia.

Children's Minister Tim Loughton MP said: "As Charlie Taylor, the Government's behaviour adviser, said this week, we need to help schools tackle these issues early on, and ensure that where pupils have to be excluded, they get the right support and education to get back on track.

"It's fantastic to see The Prince's Trust xl programme helping young people re-engage with learning to develop a sense of achievement from which they can regain momentum in mainstream education or training."

The Prince's Trust xl club is run as part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's School Engagement Programme (SEP) which helps young people who are struggling at school to re-engage with education. The effectiveness of the programme is due to the efforts of the Council's youth workers. They engage with the young people and help them develop positive skills and attitudes so they can make the most of every opportunity offered on the Alternative Education Programme.

As well as working with The Prince's Trust, the Council works with partners such as Kensington and Chelsea College to offer vocational training opportunities in subjects like childcare, multi-skills with construction, painting and decorating, graphic design and hair and beauty.

So far the SEP has achieved notable success, with all year 11 learners taking part in post-16 placements on college courses or training and employment. Across the UK, 88 per cent of young people taking part in The Prince's Trust xl programme go on to work, education or training.

Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "For many reasons some pupils struggle to engage fully at school. These young people need specialist support in a setting away from their schools which is just what our School Engagement Programme provides.

"With the support of partners like the Prince's Trust and its excellent xl programme we make sure these children do not slip through the net and in most cases we are able to help them complete a study programme and find work placements."

The Prince's Trust helps change young lives. It gives practical and financial support, developing key workplace skills such as confidence and motivation. It works with 13 to 30-year-olds who have struggled at school, have been in care, are long-term unemployed or have been in trouble with the law. Last year, more than three in four young people supported by The Trust moved into work, education or training.
shortdescription: Children's Minister Tim Loughton MP today (Monday 12 March) visited young people from Kensington and Chelsea who have struggled at school and are turning their lives around.
shorttitle: Minister visits Golborne Youth Centre

headline: YOUNG SQUASH PLAYERS AND FOOTBALLERS WANTED FOR YOUTH GAMES

headline: YOUNG ARTS AWARD WINNERS CELEBRATED
prcopy:
The creative talents of young people in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea were celebrated last night (Wednesday 14 March) at the borough's Arts Award winners event in the Mayor's Parlour.

Over 100 young people, who had achieved their Arts Award in the past three and half years, attended the event designed to highlight the excellent work being done throughout the borough to support young people's creative aspirations. It was also an opportunity for some to demonstrate their artistic skills by exhibiting their art work or performing.

Jonathan Franco, the borough's first Gold Award winner, who attended the celebration, said: "Completing my Gold Award has been a very big experience for me because I have learnt to become much more independent as a filmmaker. For me it's recognition of all my achievements and it makes me feel so proud of myself."

The Arts Award encourages young people to develop their talents in a wide range of creative arts across many settings. In recent years this has included projects in drama, visual arts, dance, singing, filmmaking and script writing.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "It is very clear that we have some incredibly creative young people who have been able to use the Arts Award to develop their artistic skills.

"I would like to thank all the staff who have worked so hard to make this such a success story for the borough and would encourage young people to find out more about the award and how they can get involved."

To find out more about the Arts Award go to www.artsaward.org.uk

For information on how to get involved in the Arts Award in Kensington and Chelsea email jane.o'sullivan@rbkc.gov.uk or call the Achievement Team on 020 7352 3931
shortdescription: The creative talents of young people in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea were celebrated last night (Wednesday 14 March) at the borough's Arts Award winners event in the Mayor's Parlour.
shorttitle: Young Arts Award winners celebrated

headline: HOTELS ALL ABOVE BOARD?
prcopy:
Hoteliers in Earl's Court are being reminded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Trading Standards officers to make sure they describe their accommodation and facilities accurately on websites, especially in the run up to this summer's London 2012 Olympic Games and Paralympic Games.

Inspections by the Council's Trading Standards team has found that half the hotels visited are using photographs and descriptions online that do not match up to what the officer saw on his visit.

Misdescriptions included statements about lifts going to all floors when they don't, flat screen TVs that don't exist in all rooms, exclusive hotel-branded toiletries that were not available and photos of rooms described as 'immaculate' or 'beautifully appointed' which, in reality, only applied to two rooms whilst the others were shabby and in need of renovation.

Other issues included unclear credit card surcharges, confusing cancellation policies and hotel websites that give no details of business ownership and other basic information that customers should be able to see.

Officers also found two online booking agents that act for many of the budget hotels in the area, claiming to be linked to London 2012 and using London 2012-related logos without the authorisation of The London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games Limited (LOCOG). Some hotels were also using LOCOG's logos and wording that may make people think they are associated in some way with the London 2012 Games when they are not. These logos and such wording have since been removed.

Trading Standards is also warning consumers to watch out for fake accommodation websites that have recently sprung up. These websites often use accommodation that does not exist and once money has been taken the website will go offline and money will be lost. If accommodation looks too cheap to be true then treat it with suspicion and contact Trading Standards for advice.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "We want to make sure that people who book hotel accommodation in Earl's Court get what they pay for and that means hotels must describe their rooms and facilities accurately.

"Our inspections show that sadly not all hotels are doing this. Our officers have also found good budget hotels in Earl's Court that have accurate websites and their standard of facilities and customer service is very good indeed, so we are certainly not trying to tar everyone with the same brush. Where we find that the descriptions do not match the reality we will take what steps we can to make sure that this is addressed by the hotel owner and, with the agreement of LOCOG, we are directing hotel owners to the `London 2012 Brand Protection Guidelines for the Tourism Sector' so they understand how they can advertise their hotels in light of the London 2012 Games without infringing the rights of LOCOG."

If you have any concerns about a hotel in Kensington and Chelsea contact trading.standards@rbkc.gov.uk or call 020 7361 3002
shortdescription: Hoteliers in Earl's Court are being reminded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Trading Standards officers to make sure they describe their accommodation and facilities accurately on websites, especially in the run up to this summer's London 2012 Olympic Games and Paralympic Games.

headline: READING WITH A TWIST
prcopy:
During April the Royal Borough's libraries are all participating in CityRead London which aims to get everyone reading and talking about books.

To mark the 200th anniversary of Charles Dickens' birth Oliver Twist has been chosen as London's first ever CityRead which launches across the capital on Monday 2 April 2012. Indeed the great author has a link to the borough, in 1836 he married Catherine Hogarth at St Luke's Church, Chelsea.

As well as opportunities to borrow Oliver Twist (and other works by Charles Dickens), the Council's library service has organised events for children, families, young people and adults to do with the book, the author and Victorian London throughout April 2012.

The exciting programme launches with a special exhibition of images from the Victorian era illustrating the social life and concerns of Dickens and other reformers. It will be on display in Kensington Central Library from Monday 2 April to Saturday 7 April before touring the rest of the borough's libraries.

Other highlights include Lucinda Hawksley (Dickens' great great great granddaughter) talking about her latest book Charles Dickens. There is also a walking tour of Chelsea to see the places mentioned by Dickens and a Victorian card game for children.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Libraries, said:

"Even though Charles Dickens was born two hundred years ago it is fair to say that his novels and short stories have lost very little of their appeal.

"We want to get the whole borough reading and discussing Oliver Twist and I'd urge residents of all ages to discover or rediscover a great classic."

For more information on all the events available please visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/cityreadlondon
shortdescription: During April the Royal Borough's libraries are all participating in CityRead London which aims to get everyone reading and talking about books.
shorttitle: Reading with a Twist

headline: EXHIBITION ROAD WINS AGAIN
prcopy:
The kerb-free, single surface Exhibition Road was recognised as a success last night (Wednesday March 21) when it won the London Transport Award for `Excellence in Walking and Public Realm'.

This is the second award for Exhibition Road in a matter of weeks. Earlier this month the Institute of Civil Engineers named it the winner of its Community Award category, which recognises projects that improve public space and enhance the living and working environment for the local community.

In clinching another prestigious award for Exhibition Road, the Royal Borough saw off competition from seven other short listed local authorities. The London Transport Awards are in their ninth year and are organised by the Transport Times.

Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, said: "It gives me great pleasure to hear that Exhibition Road has been recognised as an excellent public realm at the London Transport Awards.

"The project to transform the area was a lengthy one, but by thinking imaginatively about how the space could be used we have not only transformed the road but improved the quality of life for people living and working nearby and will offer the millions of visitors expected this year a welcoming and enjoyable experience."

The Royal Borough's former director of Transportation and Highways, Graeme Swinburne, was honoured at the ceremony receiving an award for `Lifetime Contribution to Transport in London'.

Mr Swinburne worked for the Council for 16 years. In 2006 he became joint director for Transportation and Highways for the Royal Borough and Hammersmith & Fulham. He retired in June last year.

For a full list of winners go to www.transporttimesevents.co.uk

shorttitle: Exhibition Road  wins again

headline: VISION FOR A NEW URBAN QUARTER AT EARL'S COURT
prcopy:
A blueprint to guide future development in the area of the Earls Court Exhibition Centres was approved last week (Thursday 22 March 2012) by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Jointly produced by Hammersmith & Fulham (H&F) and the Royal Borough, in partnership with the Mayor of London, the Supplementary Planning Document (SPD) sets out a vision for a new urban quarter spanning the two boroughs which will provide thousands of new homes, a minimum of 7,000 new jobs, new retail units, community facilities and new cultural facilities.

Earls Court is the 2012 venue for Olympic volleyball. But after that Capital and Counties (CapCo), the owners of both Earls Court 1 and 2 and other land in the area are intent on redevelopment. At the same time, Hammersmith & Fulham is looking at the regeneration of the adjoining West Kensington and Gibbs Green housing estates. And similarly Transport for London is looking at options for its Lillie Bridge rail depot. Together these three holdings make Earl's Court a site of immense potential.

The SPD makes sure that the redevelopment of the site is coherent and delivers benefits for local people and for London as a whole, while protecting the residential amenity of existing residents. It sets out expectations for developers seeking planning permission on key issues such as affordable housing, transport capacity, open space, community facilities, the creation of a new cultural destination and the size, location, design and layout of any new buildings, public spaces and streets.

It seeks to improve connections between the two boroughs, which are currently divided by rail lines and the exhibition centres. The SPD contains a series of requirements to reduce the impact of building work on local residents.

The current planning application is now undergoing further public consultation and any future planning applications for the area will be judged against the SPD.

"This is one of the most important development opportunities we have ever faced as a Council," said Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. "We are determined to get it right, for local people, and for London as a whole. That's what this SPD is all about."

The adoption of the SPD follows three separate consultations that took place between October 2010 and December 2011. The final draft of the SPD was consulted on between November and December 2011, drawing 335 written responses raising over 3,500 comments. At each stage of consultation, the comments raised have been considered and where appropriate used to inform the SPD. The Council wishes to thank everyone involved in its production.

You can view the adopted SPD at www.rbkc.gov.uk/earlscourt
shortdescription: A blueprint to guide future development in the area of the Earls Court Exhibition Centres was approved last week (Thursday 22 March 2012) by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Vision for a new urban quarter at Earl's Court

headline: LIBRARY WEBSITE HELPS BOROUGH'S JOBSEEKERS
prcopy:
Job seekers in Kensington and Chelsea are being encouraged to use the borough's libraries and its specialist jobseekers' website as a one stop shop to help them find employment.

The borough's libraries are an excellent source of information and have free wifi enabling library members to view online job advertisements, courses and qualifications and get advice on preparing a CV.

Even when the libraries are closed members can still log in and use the 24-hour online reference library including dictionaries, encyclopedias and access to newspaper archives.

The jobseekers' website acts as a portal to a number of online courses designed to help improve important skills including English and mathematics. And there are also online courses intended to help improve computer literacy. It features guides ranging from how employment agencies work to how to present yourself with confidence at a job interview.

The website also has useful information and advice for those thinking of branching out into setting up their own business.
All the libraries have computers linked to the internet. These can be booked by library members for a maximum of one hour per day. This can be broken down into smaller sessions, such as four 15-minute sessions, or two-30 minute sessions. Members have a total allocation of 300 minutes per week.
Regular careers advice sessions are held at Chelsea library and include information on writing and presenting your CV and job search techniques. Find out more about what your local library has to offer at: www.rbkc.gov.uk/leisureandlibraries/libraries/jobseekers

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education and Libraries, said: "The information and technology available in our libraries and on our website can really help someone who is looking for a job.

"From free wifi, careers information and a wealth of newspapers and periodicals there is something to help in any search for a job."

headline: FUNDING AVAILABLE FOR NEIGHBOURHOOD IMPROVEMENT IDEAS
prcopy:
Residents and community groups in Hans Town, Redcliffe, Campden and Pembridge wards in the south and the centre of the borough are being invited to come forward with ideas to improve their neighbourhoods with the possibility of getting up to £20,000 to implement their proposal.

`City Living, Local Life' is a ward-based initiative in which the Council has allocated £1.4 million to fund community projects agreed by ward councillors over the next four years.

The scheme, which started in the north of the borough, has already paid dividends for a number of local communities. In the St Charles ward residents addressed the problem caused by the antisocial behaviour of some young people in the Dalgarno area and established an Air Cadets programme, ran a local football tournament and developed a youth outreach scheme.

In Golborne, locals opted for a "loveGolborne" campaign to encourage local pride and increase tourism and promote the Golborne Market.

While in Holland Ward some disused land at the junction of Russell Road and Russell Gardens has been transformed into community kitchen gardens with 40 plots made available to 100 green fingered residents who want to grow their own fruit and vegetables.

In Brompton Ward Councillors are considering setting up a website where residents can report breaches of table and chairs licensing agreements.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Civil Society, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, said: "I am very keen for residents to contact their Councillors if they have ideas about how their neighbourhoods could be improved and to discuss with them the best way to bring this about.

"This money isn't intended to meet the full costs of all the projects, but it can help get projects going or provide a boost to an existing local initiative. In fact, it need not be limited to one ward as Councillors could collaborate across ward boundaries."

To find out more visit www.citylivinglocallife.org or email locallife@rbkc.gov.uk

headline: NEGLECTED SITES TRANSFORMED INTO COMMUNITY KITCHEN GARDENS
prcopy:
Three new community kitchen gardens are being launched in the Royal Borough Kensington and Chelsea providing over 100 residents with the opportunity to grow their fruit, vegetables and herbs.

The community kitchen gardens located in North Kensington at Russell Road (opposite the junction with Russell Gardens), Ruth House (Kensal Road) and Robinson House (Bramley Road) have all been developed on former derelict or unused land.

Russell Road kitchen garden which has 40 raised beds will be formally opened by the Mayor of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Julie Mills on Saturday 31 March at 1pm. It is the borough's second biggest kitchen garden and provides facilities for nearly 100 green fingered residents.

To celebrate the opening plot holders are invited to come along and get some free gardening advice and take part in some communal planting.

Russell Road garden is on land owned by Family Mosaic Housing Association. The other gardens are on sites owned by Catalyst Housing Associations, L&Q Housing have also worked in partnership with Family Mosaic and the Council to deliver the scheme.

The project is part of the Royal Borough Environment Project, the Housing Regeneration Programme and Decent Neighbourhoods initiative which aim to improve the environment and make social housing cleaner, greener and safer.

The Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for the Environment and Deputy Leader, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, said: "I am delighted that we now have over 500 residents able to grow their own vegetables in these kitchen gardens. Outside of the City of London we are the smallest and most densely populated borough in the country but by putting underused land to good use we are now able to introduce people to the relaxing and healthy hobby of gardening.

"In addition, the gardens promote a great sense of community and provide an opportunity for people to get to know one another."

Since 2009 the Royal Borough has transformed 30 derelict sites, including one disused tennis court, into thriving gardens.

Prior to the launch of the initiative, the Council had no allotments, but now thanks to the scheme the borough has more than 300 kitchen gardens tended by over 500 residents.

Most of the sites were provided to the Council for free. Surveys have shown that 97 per cent of residents say the scheme has improved their environment, while 71 per cent of garden holders say it has improved their quality of life.

Plots are allocated on a first-come first-served basis and the only criterion for plot holders is that they are resident in the ward.

Each garden features planters which vary in size, but the average plot is approximately 1.5m x 2m, allowing residents to grow a variety of different produce but keeping the plots a manageable size.

Plot owners are encouraged to grow a wide variety of vegetables and fruit, such as daily basics like potatoes, tomatoes, onions to more exotic produce like chillies, peppers, and pumpkins.

The Council has two new community gardeners Will Gould and Lisa Wilkinson who are available to provide free gardening support and advice to all plot holders.

The new Environment Apprentice, Chris North, is also available to assist. To ensure that Chris has first hand experience he was given his very own plot to garden at Russell Road.

headline: OPTIONS EXPLORED TO STOP TIME BEING CALLED ON ROYAL BOROUGH'S PUBS
prcopy:
A new planning document which looks at ways of protecting the Royal Borough's pubs is currently out for public consultation.

Since 1980 there has been a 35 per cent decline in the number of public houses in Kensington and Chelsea from 168 to 110 today - equating to an average of two pubs closing each year.

Many pubs in the Royal Borough are architecturally important and one option the Council is exploring is getting local people to draw up a list of those they would like to see protected. Another alternative is to stop the loss of drinking establishments including public houses (Class A4 uses) where a public house makes an important contribution to community life.

The Royal Borough recognises that restaurants, cafes, shops and banks also have a vital role to play and other options look at the implications of protecting these too.

Despite the economic downturn, residential land values in Kensington and Chelsea can command huge sums of money and as such they out compete any other use. This policy seeks to protect uses that have lower land values, but remain of high value to the community.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said:

"We have put together this document because we believe that it's important to look at ways we can protect those places which perform a vital community function. We've lost a lot of pubs over the years and want to do what we can to make sure that the tradition of a pint and a chat in the local pub doesn't vanish because of our high residential land values.

"We fear than without any intervention the risk is that the Royal Borough could become a homogenised high quality residential area."

The consultation is open until Tuesday 24 April. For more information please visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/pubs
shortdescription: A new planning document which looks at ways of protecting the Royal Borough's pubs is currently out for public consultation.
shorttitle: Options explored to stop time being called on Royal Borough's pub

headline: HOLLAND PARK STUDENTS SUPPORT BARNARDO'S
prcopy:
The Chief Executive of Barnardo's visited Holland Park School (Thursday 29 March) and met students and staff who have named Barnardo's as the school's chosen charity.

Anne Marie Carrie visited the school to thank everyone for their support and to talk about the work of the UK's largest children's charity.

During her visit she watched Holland Park's production of Shakespeare's Macbeth which saw teachers embracing their acting skills and starring in a modern adaptation of the play. Money raised from the production will be the school's first donation.

Joining her for the much anticipated performance were students from Fox Primary School, Avondale Primary School and Barnes Primary School along with school governors and representatives from the Council.

Commenting on her visit, Anne Marie Carrie said: "I am absolutely thrilled that the school has picked Barnardo's as its chosen charity.

"We are so grateful for Holland Park's support and are very excited about working with the school.

"The school's fundraising activities will prove invaluable in raising vital funds for the work of Barnardo's in helping disadvantaged children and young people across the UK."

Head of Holland Park School, Colin Hall, said: "It is always a pleasure and privilege to work with Anne Marie Carrie, a committed and powerful advocate for children and young people. We are delighted to support Barnardo's. So delighted indeed, that colleagues who profess no liking for the theatre have dutifully learnt their Shakespeare to raise money."

Anne Marie was previously the Executive Director for Family and Children's Services in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

For more information on the work of Barnardo's, please visit www.barnardos.org.uk

shorttitle: Holland Park Students support Barnardo's

headline: MAKE YOUR TRAVEL PLANS FOR AN OLYMPIC SUMMER
prcopy:
Research findings out today (Friday 30 March) from Transport for London (TfL) show that despite 84 per cent of Londoners being aware that travel will be affected during the London 2012 Games, less than one in eight have actually decided how they may need to change their travel plans during this time.

The findings from the research have prompted TfL to recreate a live version of one of its popular advertisements, showing weightlifters squeezing out of a busy tube carriage, in order to encourage the public to use the www.getaheadofthegames.com website and, if necessary, make alternative travel plans ahead of the Games this summer.

The recreation of the weightlifter-themed `Get Ahead of the Games' video will be available soon at http://www.youtube.com/user/GAOTG .

Ben Plowden, Director of Planning, TfL Surface Transport, said: "During this summer's Olympic and Paralympic Games there will be certain times and places when London's transport systems will be very busy.

"The `Get Ahead of the Games' campaign is playing a critical role in encouraging the travelling public to plan ahead and ensuring London and the UK keep moving as the nation prepares to celebrate the biggest summer of sporting and cultural events in its history. By recreating this ad with real-life weightlifters and Londoners, we hope to encourage more people to start making alternative plans for their travel this summer."

Councillor Warrick Lightfoot, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Lead Member for London 2012, said: "It is clear that as well as being an exciting spectacle the Olympic Games will mean more traffic on certain roads and busier stations on parts of the network. The way to minimise the impact of this is to plan ahead. TfL will be providing information on its Get Ahead of the Games website in the run up to and during the Games and I would encourage residents and businesses to look carefully at this information."

With information on how journeys could be affected, alternative routes and updates on what stations to avoid and when, www.getaheadofthegames.com is the one stop shop for people travelling in London this summer. As well as the wide-range of information available through that website and www.tfl.gov.uk, London's travelling public will also be able to get live travel updates on Twitter, via the @GAOTG handle.

The `Get Ahead of the Games' website will also be offering a selection of `after work' offers from The Sanctuary Spa, Madame Tussauds, Apollo Cinema and London theatres. During the 2012 Games these companies will offer special deals to encourage people working in Games transport hotspot areas to make the most of what London has to offer and delay their journeys home to outside peak hours. For more information on how to `Get ahead of the Games', please visit www.getaheadofthegames.com, and follow live travel updates here www.twitter.com/GAOTG.
shortdescription: Research findings out today (Friday 30 March) from Transport for London (TfL) show that despite 84 per cent of Londoners being aware that travel will be affected during the London 2012 Games, less than one in eight have actually decided how they may need to change their travel plans during this time.
shorttitle: Make your plans for an Olympic summer

headline: Best Bar None 2012
prcopy:
Bars, pubs and clubs in Kensington and Chelsea are being urged to join the Best Bar None (BBN) scheme which is entering its fifth year in the Royal Borough. The scheme recognises licensees who demonstrate excellent management standards.

BBN encourages bar owners and managers to ensure their pubs and clubs are crime-free and that their customers do not disturb their neighbours. In 2011 Embargo 59, a long standing nightclub situated on the King's Road in Chelsea, was the overall winner; it has been a member of the Best Bar None scheme since it began. Embargo 59 has continued to raise its own standards, works in partnership with the Council and others and also displays excellent management practices.

The scheme currently has 47 pubs, bars and clubs across the borough; it continues to be one of the largest schemes in the country and is still supported by Diageo Great Britain.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Environment and Leisure, said: "The Best Bar None scheme is now firmly established in the Royal Borough and is recognised as a mark of a well-run, safe and welcoming place. I encourage everyone who runs a pub, club or bar to take part and give your business the best possible chance to attract more customers."

Landlords and managers of all the borough's pubs, bars and clubs will be able to submit applications for this year's membership between 16 April and 18 June, with the awards presentation in November 2012.

To get an application form and for more information go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/bestbarnone or email bestbarnone@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Bars, pubs and clubs in Kensington and Chelsea are being urged to join the Best Bar None (BBN) scheme which is entering its fifth year in the Royal Borough.  The scheme recognises licensees who demonstrate excellent management standards.
shorttitle: Best Bar None 2012

headline: PREPARING FOR OUT OF HOURS DELIVERIES DURING OLYMPIC GAMES
prcopy:
With the Olympic Route Network passing through the Royal Borough, the cycling road race routed along Knightsbridge, Brompton Road and Fulham Road and the volleyball competition at Earls Court, the road network in the borough is going to be under pressure during the Olympic and Paralympic Games from 28 July to 9 September. Traffic restrictions during this time will have an impact on delivery and servicing for businesses in the borough, almost certainly leading to an increase in `out of hours' activity between midnight and 6am.

This may be a problem for those businesses where delivery times are restricted by planning permission or premises licence conditions, because deliveries that take place outside the specified hours may be in breach of conditions, and could be open to enforcement action by the Council.

The Council will ensure a balance between its wish to support the Games and help businesses, alongside its statutory planning and licensing duties with regards to `out of hours' delivery activity.

Businesses should look carefully at their delivery routes to see if deliveries can be reduced or combined, and should consider stocking up in advance as far as possible, or using one vehicle for deliveries from multiple suppliers or for several nearby businesses at one drop-off point.

It is recognised that the Games may cause difficulties for businesses, and the Council will take a reasonably flexible approach provided servicing and deliveries are carried out in a responsible and sensitive manner in accordance with the TfL code.

However where businesses are not mindful of their neighbours enforcement action could be taken. Complaints about late night noise from servicing activities will be handled in the usual manner, through the usual channels, and problems will be assessed case by case and our policy will be monitored throughout the Games, and revised as necessary.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Planning, said: "We recognise that the traffic restrictions that will be in place during the Olympic Games will have an impact on delivery and servicing for businesses in the borough. We urge business to plan now to see if they can change the way they operate and to contact us if they need to apply for a variation. Of course we will look to be flexible where we can provided businesses act in a sensible and considerate manner."

If you would like clarification about planning conditions please contact the Planning Information Office at the Town Hall on 020 7361 3012 or planning@rbkc.gov.uk.

If you would like to consider applying for a minor variation under the Licensing Act 2003 to suspend any conditions that may restrict your delivery/rubbish collection times, or have any other questions relating to licensing during the period of the Olympic Games, please contact the Licensing Team on 020 7341 5152 or licensing@rbkc.gov.uk.
shortdescription: With the Olympic Route Network passing through the Royal Borough, the cycling road race routed along Knightsbridge, Brompton Road and Fulham Road and the volleyball competition at Earls Court, the road network in the borough is going to be under pressure during the Olympic and Paralympic Games from 28 July to 9 September. headline: WE DO LIKE TO BE BESIDE THE SEASIDE
prcopy:
Once again, 40 older residents will be given the opportunity to enjoy a break away from the hustle and bustle of Notting Hill Carnival, as part of a scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The scheme, now in its ninth year, is aimed at older people living directly on the Carnival route, who may find the exuberance of the weekend too much.

Residents will be driven to the Glastonbury Hotel in Eastbourne on Saturday 25 August and will return to their homes on Tuesday 28 August, once the Council has had time to clear up and the area is quieter.

Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Council, said: "Although the Carnival is an exciting event, we do sympathise with older residents for whom the very large crowds and loud noise can make the weekend a difficult time. Our previous trips to the seaside have been a great success and that's why we have decided to run the scheme again to offer another group of elderly people a break away from the clamour of the Carnival."

Older people living directly on the Carnival route whose health may be affected by the weekend can apply for a place on the trip. There are a limited number of places available so all applications will be assessed. People who are eligible, but have not been on a trip before, will be given priority.

Residents can contact the Council for more information on 020 7361 3175. The closing date to apply for a place is Friday 1 June 2012.
shortdescription: Once again, 40 older residents will be given the opportunity to enjoy a break away from the hustle and bustle of Notting Hill Carnival, as part of a scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: We do like to be beside the seaside

headline: BOROUGH LIBRARIES SUPPORT CITYREAD LONDON
prcopy:
A scheme to get more people reading and talking about books is being promoted by libraries in the Royal Borough.

As part of Cityread London, Dr Peter Clark OBE will lead a 45-minute guided walk in Chelsea on Tuesday 17 April (2pm to 4pm) taking in places mentioned in the works and correspondence of celebrated author Charles Dickens. The walk will be followed by a talk at Chelsea Library.

Peter Clark's latest book, Dickens's London, contains five walks around modern-day London, with information about Charles Dickens's life, times, and literature at every point. These five walks also serve to interweave today's London with the city during Dickens' lifetime, and overlay his experiences onto our current situation. The book is highly evocative of the author's times and attitudes to the areas in which he lived, worked and based his novels.

Later in the week (Thursday 19 April) Dickens' great great great granddaughter Lucinda Hawksley will talk about her latest book `Charles Dickens' at the Kensington Central Library.

While many people know about Dickens the novelist, far fewer know about Dickens the man. Lucinda will talk about the lesser-known aspects of Charles Dickens' life including what he was like as a husband and father, his talent for acting, his desire to be a detective and his love of travelling. She will also talk about his social conscience, the changes he made in his society and why he still remains relevant today. The talk takes place between 6.30pm and 8pm.

Younger readers can go along to Chelsea and North Kensington libraries on Wednesday 11 April to have a go at creating cartoon characters based on some of Dickens' fantastic characters. The Miko Cartoon workshop encourages youngsters from 11 to 15 to use their creative imagination and visual references of costumes and streets to develop cartoon characters living in Victorian London.

Places are limited so please book your place in advance. The workshops take place at Chelsea Library between 11am and 12.30pm and at North Kensington Library between 2.30pm and 4pm.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Libraries, said: "Our libraries are giving great backing to the Cityread campaign. And what better way than to promote reading in London than to celebrate the 200th anniversary of the birth of Charles Dickens, an author whose description of parts of London live long in the memory."

Ticket and booking details:
Tickets £5 (£3 concessions) per adult event
Tickets for adult events are on sale at all Kensington and Chelsea libraries.
Payments in person or by post should be made in cash or by cheque only. Please make cheques payable to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. Payments by credit or debit card can be made via Librariesline on 020 7361 3010.

Events for children, young people and families are free of charge but booking in advance may be required, see individual events for details.

For more information on all the events available visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/cityreadlondon
shortdescription: A scheme to get more people reading and talking about books is being promoted by libraries in the Royal Borough.
shorttitle: Borough libraries support Cityread London

prcopy:

headline: RARE CHANCE TO EXPLORE HOLLAND PARK'S WILDLIFE AREA
prcopy:
The public will get a rare chance to explore the wildlife area of Kensington's Holland Park on Saturday 28 April.

This mainly wooded area is only open to the general public four times a year. In spring it's a joy to behold as the woods are filled with new life and growth.

Come along and enjoy a peaceful walk in the woods and discover what creatures lurk in the wildlife pond. Staff from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Ecology Service will be available to answer questions.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Council, said: "This really is a great opportunity to see a part of the park that is closed to the public for much of the year. The woodland area really is very beautiful and offers a wonderful habitat for wildlife."

The open day is suitable for all ages and takes place between 2pm and 6pm.

For more information email ecology.centre@rbkc.gov.uk or telephone 020 7938 8186.
shortdescription: The public will get a rare chance to explore the wildlife area of Kensington's Holland Park on Saturday 28 April.
shorttitle: Rare chance to explore Holland Park's wildlife area

headline: KENSINGTON PALACE BY NIGHT
prcopy:
Over 250 residents got a rare chance to explore Kensington Palace out-of-hours at a special event organised by the Council, on Wednesday 11 April.

The event gave guests who might not normally visit the borough's cultural attractions an intimate account of Queen Victoria's extraordinary life through the palace's new exhibition - Victoria Revealed.

Guests included representatives from tenants' and residents' associations, migrant and refugee communities, the traveller community based at Stable Way and residents of the Wornington Green estate in North Kensington.

Opened by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Julie Mills, the evening included speeches from the Head of Kensington Palace, Natasha Woollard and Head of Access and Learning Dr David Souden.

Commenting on the event the Mayor said: "It was a really wonderful opportunity for residents to visit the palace and see the splendid restoration. The exhibitions are very interesting. There is something for all, and the grounds and the park are now once again open for visitors to enjoy. We all enjoyed the evening and are grateful to Kensington Palace for arranging this special visit."

Mouna El-Ogbani, from Al-Hasaniya Moroccan Women's Centre, said: "This event was an opportunity for me and my children to visit Kensington Palace. We enjoyed the history and the stories about Queen Victoria."

Abdulkadir Abukar, a service user and Trustee of Hodan Somali Community, said: "This event was very important for me and my colleagues as new British nationals. It gave us an insight into the great history and identity of this country. This gave us a sense of belonging and being part of this society. It was great to see so many people of different backgrounds all enjoying the event."
shortdescription: Over 250 residents got a rare chance to explore Kensington Palace out-of-hours at a special event organised by the Council, on Wednesday 11 April.
shorttitle: Kensington Palace by night

prcopy:
