headline: BE AWARE OF ONLINE ACCOMMODATION SCAMS
prcopy:
Trading standards officers in Kensington and Chelsea are again warning consumers about the perils of falling for property rental scams following recent reports of consumers being conned out of hundreds and sometimes thousands of pounds for properties that do not exist for rent.

Scam websites are expected to increase in the run up to the Olympics as visitors scramble to find suitable short term rental accommodation in London, so it is important that thorough checks are made prior to parting with any money.

Many of the scams originate from abroad but the websites use `.co.uk' website addresses and will contain bogus contact addresses, fake domain name information and phone numbers that either call forward to abroad or go dead. In one case they have even hijacked another legitimate company's name to place on their website to make it look more credible.

Trading Standards has closed down two websites recently. One case involved Myholidaylets.net where a Scottish resident is alleged to have lost £1,500 after booking a non-existent flat in Camden for the Olympic period and another involved Youstayapartments.co.uk where a Malaysian visitor lost £1,000 for a flat off the King's Road that isn't available for rent. Three more sites advertising expensive city pads in Kensington and Mayfair are being looked into with a view to having them taken offline as soon as possible but more are expected as consumers realise they've been scammed or become worried about lack of proper documents and receipts etc.

Many of the scammers will ask for money to be sent by money transfer or by BACS and once the money has gone it is extremely unlikely that it can be recovered.

Trading Standards advises consumers to check and check again before parting with any money. Businesses that don't want to answer questions, or are elusive, are best avoided.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "This is a rather nasty way of parting innocent people from their money and we will continue to be vigilant and take action to close down these sites when we find them.

"But the public need to do some very thorough checking before sending their money. The old adage that, if it looks too good to be true then it probably is, is a good one to follow in these cases."

Scams can be reported to the Citizens Advice Consumer Service on 08454 040506 or Trading Standards on 020 7361 3002 or trading.standards@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Trading standards officers in Kensington and Chelsea are again warning consumers about the perils of falling for property rental scams following recent reports of consumers being conned out of hundreds and sometimes thousands of pounds for properties that do not exist for rent.
shorttitle: Be aware of online accommodation scams

headline: NOTICE OF ELECTION FOR BROMPTON WARD
prcopy:

Nomination packs for prospective candidates are available from the Elections Office by calling 020 7361 3444 or from Kensington Town Hall, Hornton Street, London, W8 7NX.

headline: COMMUNITY GARDENER CARRIES OLYMPIC FLAME
prcopy:
A woman who helped get people involved in community gardening in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has carried the Olympic flame.
Sarah Milner Simonds, from Burnham-on-Sea, carried the torch through Dunster Village in Somerset on Monday 21 May.

Sarah who is now the Horticultural Programme Manager at Bridgwater College said that: "the honour of carrying the flame in the medieval village of Dunster is almost overwhelming. To think that the flame has come all the way from Athens and will ignite the cauldron in the Olympic Stadium on 27 July 2012 at the start of the Games is incredible. I was determined to do Somerset proud on the day and not drop the torch in my excitement"

Nominated for her inspirational work as a community gardener in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Sarah got people out of their homes to meet their neighbours and grow fruit and vegetables. They would then tend the crops together, share the produce and Sarah would invite local chefs into the gardens to cook (often outdoors) with the participants.

This work took place on disused pieces of land; creating allotments where once people dumped rubbish.
Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I am delighted that Sarah's work in our community gardens led to this well-deserved nomination to carry the Olympic flame."
shortdescription: A woman who helped get people involved in community gardening in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has carried the Olympic flame.
shorttitle: Community gardener carries Olympic flame

headline: REPORTED BURGLARIES DOWN IN THE BOROUGH
prcopy:
There was a reduction of 5.2 per cent in the number of burglaries reported to the police in 2011/12, down to a total of 980.

This is only the second time in the past 12 years that reports of residential burglary in the borough have fallen below 1,000. In 2000/01 residential burglaries were at a high of 2,558.

One of the methods used in the Royal Borough to make it harder for the burglar is to help people secure their homes. Advice and sometimes even grants have been made available to help make residents' homes more difficult for the criminal to break into. Target hardening, as this scheme is known, has proved popular with landlords, people living in burglary hotspots and those who have been burgled previously.

Cllr Rock Fielding-Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "Burglary is an upsetting and unsettling crime, so this reduction is to be warmly welcomed.

"I am very pleased that even in these difficult financial times we have managed to ensure that funding was found to maintain our target hardening project, which is just a part of our overall strategy of making Kensington and Chelsea as hostile to criminals as possible.

"Of course, there is no room for complacency and we will continue to work with the police and other agencies to make it as difficult as possible for anyone who thinks they can burgle the homes of our residents."

Superintendent Alisdair Ferguson, Head of Operations at Kensington and Chelsea Police, said: "We have had another good year in fighting crime. We have achieved reductions in burglary and improved performance in bringing offenders to justice. Reducing burglary will continue to be our focus and this year I aim to reduce these offences even further.

"This will be challenging, especially with the financial constraints being felt across the public sector.

"There are a number of things you can do to stop yourself becoming a victim of burglary. Now the warmer weather is upon us we all leave our windows open. Unsecured windows and unlocked doors are open invitations to burglars and opportunist criminals. Make sure you lock your doors and windows before you go out, even if for a short time, last thing at night and when you go on holiday."

The reduction of burglaries in the borough bucks the general trend in London where a 4.9 per cent increase was reported by the police in April.

To find out more about protecting your property from burglary and for enquiries about crime prevention grants, contact David Cunningham, Burglary Reduction Project Manager in the Community Safety Team on 020 7795 6660 or email commsafe@rbkc.gov.uk

End
shortdescription: There was a reduction of 5.2 per cent in the number of burglaries reported to the police in 2011/12, down to a total of 980.
shorttitle: Reported burglaries down in the borough

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH IS TOP DOG
prcopy:
Efforts by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to encourage responsible dog ownership including regular microchipping, free neutering vouchers for dogs with behavioural problems and an annual family dog show have been recognised in the 2012 Dogs Trust Honours awards.

The Council and Dogs Trust also work with young people on court orders to assist them in completing their community reparation. The young people are taken to the Dogs Trust's re-homing centre in Harefield to work with Dog Trust staff to socialise and train dogs waiting to be re-homed. The Dogs Trust also facilitated comprehensive courses with young people on responsible dog ownership, making them more aware of the impact on society of badly behaved dogs.
The Council's Parks Police have microchipped over 60 dogs at its regular monthly Dog Days which take place in the borough's parks in partnership with the Dogs Trust.

Clarissa Baldwin, Dogs Trust chief executive, said: "Over the past five years, Dogs Trust Honours has been raising awareness of the amazing role dogs play in our lives and how we repay that loyalty. The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has excelled in promoting responsible dog ownership and ensuring the area is a safe and happy place for dogs, dog owners and non-dog owners alike. Dogs Trust is delighted to recognise their continuing efforts and positive approach to dog ownership."

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am delighted that the Dogs Trust has given us its Local Authority Champion Award. Dogs can enjoy a very special place in people's lives and give great pleasure.

"We want to do our bit to help people, especially young people, look after their dogs responsibly and organise a number of events and activities to do this.

"I would like to thank all the staff who have worked so hard to make sure that dogs remain our best friends."

The Local Authority Champion award recognises those local authorities that look out for dogs and give consideration to policies that affect dogs in their area.

The awards ceremony on 21 May saw the UK's most heroic canines rub shoulders and paws with dog loving celebrities as the winners of the 2012 Dogs Trust Honours were revealed at London's Honourable Artillery Company. Over 30 dogs and 200 humans celebrated the fifth Dogs Trust Honours - the awards ceremony which celebrates the unique relationship between man and dog.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's award saw Park's Police Sergeant Mark Thompson and Grace Fredericks from the borough's restorative justice team presented with the Local Authority Champion award by Made in Chelsea star, Funda Onal.



-ENDS-
shortdescription: Efforts by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to encourage responsible dog ownership including regular microchipping, free neutering vouchers for dogs with behavioural problems and an annual family dog show have been recognised in the 2012 Dogs Trust Honours awards.
shorttitle: Royal Borough is top dog

headline: FROM CONFLICTS TO PUBLISHING - LIBRARY EVENTS
prcopy:

What will happen once UK and US forces pull out of the country? There will be opportunities to ask questions and join in the debate.
The session will run from 6.30pm to 8pm.

On Tuesday 19 June you can find out from Juliet Pickering, a literary agent with A P Watt, the oldest literary agency in the world, how the publishing process works and what the current publishing trends in the UK are. Juliet will also talk about the role of a literary agent: why an agent is necessary and how to go about getting one yourself. The talk will be followed by a question and answer session.

headline: CHELSEA HACKNEY LINE REVIVAL
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has warmly welcomed the revival of plans for the Chelsea Hackney line.

The rail scheme has been dormant for several years but was back on the radar this week following the publication of an authoritative study by the business group, London First.

The study, led by former Transport Secretary, Lord Andrew Adonis, argues that by the late 2020s, there will be a critical need for new rail capacity in central, south-west and north-east London, even after the completion of Crossrail, Thameslink and the current Tube upgrades.

Planning for how to meet that need must start now and the best way to do so, argues the report, is a second "Crossrail" line connecting these parts of London.

The idea for Crossrail 2 - or the Chelsea Hackney line as it has traditionally been called - has actually been around for decades. And the Council has been a keen supporter of the idea for almost as long.

"Our Capital needs that transport capacity and our country desperately needs growth," said Leader of the Council, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell.

"Now is the time to secure both Crossrails taking every opportunity along the routes to create investment and growth. That means a station at Portobello and one on the King's Road."
The route safeguarded for the Chelsea Hackney line back in 1991 includes a station on the King's Road and the Council support for the scheme is based on the need to relieve congestion in the Chelsea area and provide residents with easier access to the West End and City.

The London First study has suggested that the route could be modified to run to Clapham Junction as well as Euston, where it could provide direct access to the new HS2 link
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has warmly welcomed the revival of plans for the Chelsea Hackney line.
shorttitle: Chelsea Hackney line revival

headline: ACADEMY AND LEISURE CENTRE PLANS SUBMITTED
prcopy:

a new academy providing much needed school places as over 30 per cent of local students currently travel outside the Royal Borough for their secondary education
a state-of-the-art leisure centre to replace the current facility
creating more usable green space and an improved Lancaster Green
improving access and creating better links to the area
new homes to help fund the scheme.

Over the past two years the Council and the Aldridge Foundation have consulted widely on the emerging proposals through a series of drop-in events, workshops and exhibitions. The local community has also been kept informed through newsletters, a residents' forum, the leisure centre user group and through the Council and academy websites.

The outcome of the planning application is expected in September. If given the go-ahead a phased construction programme would begin in the autumn of 2012 with the Kensington Aldridge Academy opening in September 2014. Construction of the leisure centre will coincide with the academy programme with the aim of the new centre opening at the same time as the academy.

The planning application will soon be available online, please visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/kalc to view the application and have your say. Alternatively, visit the Planning Information Office, Ground Floor, Kensington Town Hall, Hornton Street W8 7NX

headline: FIND THE JUBILEE GEMS
prcopy:

If your child is aged between five and 12, join them on the search for diamonds, which will take in some of the best known names in retail. Children can win a selection of fabulous prizes including £100 of toys from Peter Jones, afternoon tea at the Royal Garden Hotel, family tickets for `The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe' and a private tour of the War Horse exhibition at the National Army Museum.

Diamond prospectors can take to the King's Road or Kensington High Street and will need to visit each shop shown on the entry form (available online at www.rbkc.gov.uk/diamondhunt and also in the Central Library, Hornton Street or Chelsea Library, King's Road) and search for a picture of a red, white or blue diamond then write down the colour of each diamond on their form.

Completed forms must be handed in to any of the participating shops or returned to the Council at Kensington Town Hall by Wednesday 6 June.

The diamond treasure hunts are for children accompanied by their parents, and will run throughout the bank holiday weekend from Saturday 2 June to Tuesday 5 June 2012.

The successful entrants will be drawn at random and the winners of the star prizes will be invited to a ceremony the following Saturday afternoon (9 June 2012) at the National Army Museum Jubilee Exhibition on Royal Hospital Road where prizes will be presented by the Mayor of the Royal Borough.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Planning, said: "The Diamond Jubilee will be a time of great celebration and family fun. I am delighted that so many of our wonderful retailers are getting into the spirit of the Jubilee and taking part in the search for diamonds. I would like to thank all those that have donated such magnificent prizes.

"Young people have very keen eyes so I expect that all of the borough's diamonds will be found."

headline: OFSTED RATE BOROUGH'S CHILDREN'S SERVICES AS GOOD
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's safeguarding and looked after children's services are considered amongst the best in the country after an Ofsted report judged them to be good across the board.

The inspection is intended to ensure that all the relevant services in an area that ensure the safety and well being of children are up to scratch.

Inspectors noted that the Council and its local partners have a considerable history of achieving good outcomes for children who need safeguarding and protecting or who are looked after. They found an established culture of continuous improvement and a progressive attitude, supported by a strong political commitment and desire to build quality services.

New demands on the services were said to be met with rapid and imaginative responses and the Council was seen to be continually searching for efficient use of its resources.

The inspectors reported that Councillors and officers continually focus on the needs of children and seek the views of families and service users.

A survey of 19 children and young people undertaken by Ofsted as part of the inspection found that 17 reported that they felt safe or very safe (two did not respond).

Referrals to the Council are responded to quickly and children seen promptly. Risks were judged to be appropriately assessed in conjunction with partners.

The views of children, their parents and carers are actively sought by Councillors and professionals as part of commissioning services and the inspectors found clear evidence that these consultations influenced and shaped services.

Services for Looked after Children benefited from strong leadership and management across the authority. Inspectors noted that there was a shared vision among Councillors that drives the Council, as a corporate parent, to ensure that each Looked after Child and young person has every opportunity to achieve.

The children and young people who contributed to the inspection reported generally good levels of satisfaction with the service and a significant majority considered that being in care had improved their lives.

The relationships between children and their social workers was highlighted with over 85 per cent of children and young people reporting that the relationship was good.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "There was much for us to be encouraged about in this latest Ofsted report. It is clear that the services children and young people receive in the borough are of high quality.

"But we can and will always strive to do better. Some of these children are amongst the most vulnerable people we deal with as a Council and our responsibility to them is a great one. This is why we will never be complacent and why we will always look to improve.

"The challenge we face now is to keep up our high standards at a time when budgets are reducing. Our decision to share services with our neighbours in Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster means that we can preserve vital front line functions."
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's safeguarding and looked after children's services are considered amongst the best in the country after an Ofsted report judged them to be good across the board.
shorttitle: Ofsted praise for borough's children's services

headline: NEW LIBRARY FOR COLVILLE PRIMARY SCHOOL
prcopy:
Children at Colville Primary School will be able to enjoy a world of reading thanks to the opening of its new library, to a fanfare of trumpets, on Friday 1 June 2012 by Councillor Christopher Buckmaster, the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The library has been a product of the efforts of the whole school community as staff and parents put in a lot of hard work during their free time to bring it to fruition. This is not the only recent project to improve the school facilities as the Royal Borough agreed to provide over £420,000 to fund two brand new classrooms for reception children with direct access to their own dedicated play area.

The library project was helped by donations of 4,000 books from volunteer organisations, Thomas's Schools Foundation, Strawberry Fields Nursery and Junior League of London. This included one child who decided to forego birthday presents and collected one hundred books. In addition, Foyles Foundation confirmed £15,000 of funding to ensure an extensive non-fiction collection.

Junior League of London, a long-term supporter of the school, has financed shelving in the library. Furthermore, the organisation held two one-day events with 12 volunteers to label many of the books.

The Mayor said: "I was delighted to be invited to Colville Primary School to open its exciting new library. It is clear to me that everyone is quite rightly very proud of it and I know that it will play a vital part in inspiring reading for many years to come for Colville's pupils."

Mr Jagdeep Birdi, Headteacher of Colville Primary School, said: "Our children are continually challenging themselves to achieve and this library will unleash their reading skills on wealth of children's literature."

"I'm ecstatic because I can't wait to go inside and read the new books," said Luleida, aged eight.

"It is the most awesome space," added Mohammed, aged ten.

"I feel really excited because we have loads of books," said Luis, aged eight. Whilst Arnez, also eight years old, said, "I'm excited because my mum won't have to buy books."

The Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, said: "We all recognise the great value of reading for a child and it is the very foundation of their education. Having a well-stocked library will give them the best possible start and I hope the pupils get a lot of joy from having such a fantastic selection of books at their fingertips. I know staff and parents put in a lot of hard work to make it happen."

After the unveiling of the new library, children, staff and parents were able to join in street party festivities to celebrate the Queen's Diamond Jubilee.
shortdescription: Children at Colville Primary School will be able to enjoy a world of reading thanks to the opening of its new library, to a fanfare of trumpets, on Friday 1 June 2012 by Councillor Christopher Buckmaster, the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: New library for Colville Primary School

headline: GOLBORNE CHILDREN'S CENTRE GRADED OUTSTANDING
prcopy:
Golborne Children's Centre in North Kensington has been judged by Ofsted to be an outstanding school, the highest grade it can award, following an inspection in May.

The inspector made the judgement after looking at specific areas including the achievement of pupils, quality of teaching, behaviour and safety of pupils and leadership and management of the school - and the school was given the grade of `outstanding' for every category.

Children are said to thrive in the school's safe and calm environment where they are highly motivated to learn, encouraged by high expectations from their teachers.

The children's academic and personal skills are also reported to be outstanding.

As well as celebrating festivals from a number of faiths, the children at Golborne enjoy tending the school's vegetable beds and caring for their newly hatched chicks. There is strong emphasis by the staff on developing the children's numeracy skills and reading, and children make outstanding progress and reach attainment levels above those expected by the time they leave the nursery.

The school's highly effective leaders and managers were praised as was the overall high quality of teaching.

Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Clearly Ofsted was very impressed with the Golborne Children's Centre.

"Here is a school where learning is nurtured in a calm and safe environment. The result of this is that the children enjoy being there and parents have confidence in the school.

"I would like to thank all the staff for their efforts and congratulate them on this outstanding report."
shortdescription: Golborne Children's Centre in North Kensington has been judged by Ofsted to be an outstanding school, the highest grade it can award, following an inspection in May.
shorttitle: Golborne Children's Centre graded outstanding

headline: COMPUTER SAYS NO TO CROSSRAIL
prcopy:
The people of North Kensington and south Brent have no use for a Crossrail station that would dramatically shorten their journeys to key destinations across the Capital; or at least so say the computers used by TfL transport planners.

Modelling undertaken by TfL as part of their investigation of the case for a station on the old gasworks site at Kensal produced the surprise result last year it has emerged*, but the Council is taking the news in its stride.

"This is such an eccentric outcome that I can't believe it will have a bearing on the final decision," said Deputy Leader of the Council, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown.

"But I do wish we could get away from these narrow technical arguments, none of which seem substantial or difficult to overcome. The big picture is that our economic and regeneration case is overwhelming. This is exactly the sort of project our residents need, this landlocked part of north-west London needs and that our national economy needs."

The Council has been leading a campaign to bring a station to the north of the borough for many months. That campaign has the support of MPs, MLAs, the London Borough of Brent, housing bodies and hundreds of local businesses and residents, all of whom seem to think a station would be a tremendous benefit to one of the largest areas of deprivation in London.

The station, which the Council recently dubbed Portobello, would enable the development of the 67-acre brown field site in which its sits. That site would accommodate some 2,500 new homes, and create thousands of new jobs.

A recent report by economic analysts, Regeneris, suggested that there was a stronger case for a station on the site than at any other confirmed station site outside of east London. In fact Regeneris concluded that had the Kensal site been looked at from the outset, it would certainly have been included in the original Crossrail plans.
shortdescription: The people of North Kensington and south Brent have no use for a Crossrail station that would dramatically shorten their journeys to key destinations across the Capital; or at least so say the computers used by TfL transport planners.
shorttitle: Computer says no to Crossrail

headline: STRATEGY FOR SUSTAINING CHILDREN'S CENTRES UNVEILED
prcopy:
The Council has today (Friday 8 June) unveiled its strategy for keeping all eight of its children's centres open and well funded, despite sharply declining resources.

In common with every local authority, Kensington and Chelsea is coping with unprecedented reductions in central government support. Between 2011 and 2015 its overall grant will fall by some 26 per cent.

As a big spending department Children's Services is having to play its part in that. Through Tri-borough service sharing it is already delivering significant savings. But it must find a further £1.6m next year (2013/14) and £1.51m in 2014/15.

The key aim of the strategy is to contribute to those savings without reducing the number of childcare places or sacrificing service quality, especially for children from disadvantaged backgrounds who often benefit most from the range of early years services provided at children's centres. Another objective is to provide Royal Borough residents with an Early Years Service that is comparatively more generous than elsewhere in the capital.

Currently the Royal Borough has eight children's centres, for which there is a complex set of management arrangements: some centres are managed by the Council, others are schools with boards of governors. They are organised into two locality groups, one north of Kensington High Street, the other south.

The proposals will now nominate one children's centre in each group to take a lead role but all the other centres would play their part in delivering the full range of children's centre services across the locality, with activities spread across the week and around the centres to avoid duplication.

This reorganisation will simplify management and reduce management costs while protecting front line services.

A further major benefit would be that the borough's children's centres would then be treated by Ofsted as just two inspection units rather than eight as at present. This dramatic reduction in the inspection burden would also save money, and reduce stress.

The vital full day childcare provided by children's centres will no longer have to be provided directly by the Council. Kensington and Chelsea has a thriving private and voluntary sector with the proven capability to provide high quality care at lower cost than the Council can manage.

Under these new arrangements childcare places for disadvantaged children would be purchased by the Royal Borough rather than provided directly. But children's centres will continue to be "universal" and open to all the community.

In-depth consultation will shortly get underway with staff, centre users and the wider public and final decisions will be taken only after the consultation has concluded.

"Everyone understands the economic context that our country and indeed the whole of Europe finds itself in," said Cabinet Member for Education, Cllr Elizabeth Campbell.

"We are very proud of what our Early Years Service has achieved and we are focusing hard on reducing management back office functions so that those achievements can survive these lean years.

"We don't want Royal Borough children to miss out on Early Years services, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds.

"I believe we have the right strategy for doing that, one that is even capable of delivering some improvements and we are now going out to explain it and debate it with our staff, service users and the public."

Children's centres are defined as places where integrated services are available to children and families to support them in meeting their full potential. They are intended for families with young children. As well as childcare, services may include health visitors, breastfeeding support, early learning, parenting support plus more specialist services like speech therapy, healthy eating, money management and advice on employment and training.
shortdescription: The Council has today (Friday 8 June) unveiled its strategy for keeping all eight of its children's centres open and well funded, despite sharply declining resources.
shorttitle: Strategy for sustaining children's centres unveiled

In the meantime, the Council is holding a public exhibition to share the architect's final designs on Thursday 21 June from 4.30pm to 8pm. The exhibition will take place in the Lower Hall of Notting Hill Methodist Church on Lancaster Road, W11 4AH.

a state-of-the-art leisure centre to replace the current facility
creating more usable green space and an improved Lancaster Green
improving access and creating better links to the area
new homes to help fund the scheme.

Over the past two years the Council and the Aldridge Foundation have consulted widely on the emerging proposals through a series of drop-in events, workshops and exhibitions. The local community has also been kept informed through newsletters, a residents' forum, the leisure centre user group and through the Council and academy websites.

The outcome of the planning application is expected in September. If given the go-ahead a phased construction programme would begin in the autumn of 2012 with the Kensington Aldridge Academy opening in September 2014. Construction of the leisure centre will coincide with the academy programme with the aim of the new centre opening at the same time as the academy.

The planning application will soon be available online, please visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/kalc to view the application and have your say. Alternatively, visit the Planning Information Office, Ground Floor, Kensington Town Hall, Hornton Street W8 7NX
shortdescription: A planning application for a new leisure centre and academy in North Kensington has been submitted to the Royal Borough and a decision is expected in September.
shorttitle: Invitation to academy and leisure centre public exhibition

headline: FIRST CROSS-BOROUGH NEIGHTBOURHOOD FORUM FORMS
prcopy:
Residents in Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith and Fulham are getting together to write a neighbourhood plan for their local area.

They may be from different postcodes, but the St Helen's Residents' Association in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Woodlands area residents in the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham are making a joint bid to become a Neighbourhood Forum using new neighbourhood planning powers granted by the government.

Neighbourhood Forums, as introduced in the Localism Act 2011, are designated community groups that can use these neighbourhood planning rights to shape development and growth in their area through the production of a neighbourhood development plan.

The area that they intend to focus their proposals on stretches north from the Westway to Dalgarno Gardens, east to St Helen's Gardens and St Mark's Road and west to Wood Lane.

If designated, the new St Quintin and Woodlands Neighbourhood Forum will put its proposals to the public and will invite local residents and businesses to comment on its neighbourhood plan, before submitting it to the councils for formal consultation, examination and eventually a local referendum.

The Neighbourhood Forum would seek to build local consensus around a set of detailed planning policies governing issues such as rooflights, basement development, eco retrofitting, and supporting local shopping parades and the Latimer Road employment area.

Councillor Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Planning, said: "We are great supporters of Neighbourhood Planning and were one of the first councils in the country to give the thumbs up to an application.

"This is our second application, and it's possibly another first as it straddles two boroughs and involves our neighbours in Hammersmith & Fulham. The two boroughs must now consider the application and we will report back in due course."
shortdescription: Residents in Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith and Fulham are getting together to write a neighbourhood plan for their local area.
shorttitle: First Cross-borough Neighbourhood Forum forms

headline: AMAZING STREET ART COMES TO ROYAL BOROUGH STREETS
prcopy:
The streets and public spaces of Kensington and Chelsea provide the backdrop for a fortnight of interactive arts, drama and music during the sixth InTRANSIT Festival of Arts (Friday 13 to Friday 27 July).

Organised by the Council, this year's festival reflects the Olympic spirit with many of the events combining artistic creativity with physical activity such as biking and walking and parkour running.

Highlights of the festival include a Portobello Arts Day, the Big Dance Bus on the King's Road and an amazing large-scale three dimensional illusionistic street painting at Portobello Square by the internationally renowned street artist Edgar Mueller.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "InTRANSIT goes from strength to strength and this year's programme promises to be better than ever.

"There really is something in it for everyone, adults and children alike. You don't get too many opportunities to tame dragons or attend Suffragette rallies on Portobello Road or head down to the King's Road for a dance workshop brought to you by a classic Routemaster bus, so find out more about what InTRANSIT has to offer and come along and get involved."

To find out more about all that is happening during the InTRANSIT Festival of Arts 2012 go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/intransit

Find out the latest news via Twitter by following @RBKCculture and check out the Facebook page www.facebook.com/RBKCculture for any updates.
shortdescription: The streets and public spaces of Kensington and Chelsea provide the backdrop for a fortnight of interactive arts, drama and music during the sixth InTRANSIT Festival of Arts (Friday 13 to Friday 27 July).
shorttitle: Amazing street art comes to Royal Borough streets

headline: CHILDREN'S DIAMOND JUBILEE TREASURE HUNT SPARKLES
prcopy:
Children with a keen eye for treasure won some fantastic prizes in the Council's diamond treasure hunt on the King's Road and Kensington High Street over the Jubilee bank holiday weekend.

Over 100 children aged between five and 12, accompanied by their parents, embarked on the search for diamonds, taking in some of the best known names in retail. In total, 32 retailers and other organisations got involved from the King's Road and the Kensington High Street Retail Forums, contributing some fantastic prizes.

The children's quest was to visit each participating shop and search for a picture of a red, white or blue diamond before writing down the colour of each diamond on their form.

The successful entrants were drawn at random and the lucky winners of the star prizes were invited to a ceremony on Saturday 9 June at the National Army Museum to have their prizes presented to them by the Mayor and Mayoress of the Royal Borough.

Star prize winners who attended the ceremony with their families were: Ryan Trancas who won a hamper and £50 voucher from Whole Foods Market; Maithili Pittea who won afternoon tea for six at The Royal Garden Hotel; and Oliver Kelly who received £100 of toys from Peter Jones, including a Ferrari challenge toy race track and vintage Paddington teddy. The fourth star prize winner was unable to attend but won a private tour of the War Horse Exhibition at the National Army Museum.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Christopher Buckmaster, said: "I was delighted so many children took part and it was a pleasure to award them these great prizes for their efforts in our Jubilee treasure hunt. I know they had a lot of fun doing it and it is fantastic that so many wanted to take part despite the bank holiday weather. I am sure that this treasure hunt will have made the Diamond Jubilee even more memorable for all the children who participated.

"We are very grateful to all the shops and organisations which took part and for those contributing these wonderful prizes. It certainly was a great way for the community to come together and add to the festivities of this memorable Jubilee weekend."
shortdescription: Children with a keen eye for treasure won some fantastic prizes in the Council's diamond treasure hunt on the King's Road and Kensington High Street over the Jubilee bank holiday weekend.
shorttitle: Children's Diamond Jubilee treasure hunt sparkles

headline: WELFARE TO WORK IN ACTION
prcopy:
A new project designed to help social housing tenants into work and training is getting underway in Kensington and Chelsea.

Its aims are to link social housing tenants on benefits with employment and training opportunities in the borough, especially opportunities provided by social landlords.

In addition the Council is encouraging landlords to club together when commissioning employment and skills initiatives so they get better value for their money, help more people and provide a more coordinated approach so that tenants on benefits can get into work or training.

The project is part of the Council's response to profound changes in the welfare system including a benefit cap of £26,000 per year and the possibility of time limited tenancies. Amongst other things, the Council is providing advice and support to residents subject to the benefit changes and supporting a range of employment and training initiatives.

"Whatever political view one takes of the welfare reforms," said Cllr Tim Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Housing "most of us can agree that worklessness harms the individual and society and that training leading to employment is the answer.

"Right now we have a lot of landlords doing a lot of things to help, often with their own tenants in mind. We hope that by taking on a coordination role the Council can help them do more for more people."

The project will run for 18 months and the impact will be monitored throughout.
keyword1: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: A new project designed to help social housing tenants into work and training is getting underway in Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Welfare to work in action

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH WINS LONDON YOUTH GAMES REGATTA
prcopy:
For the first time, young people from Kensington and Chelsea have won the London Youth Games Regatta at London Docklands on Saturday 9 June.

The borough's unprecedented achievement was due to their team victory in the Kayak sprint, third place in the kayak slalom and respectable seventh place finishes in both the rowing and sailing competitions.

Around 900 young people from 30 boroughs took part in the competition, more than three-times the number who took part in 2008 across rowing, kayaking and sailing.

There were some stand-out performances in the kayak sprint from the borough's three Khlaf siblings. Fifteen-year old Sophie won gold in the Cirrus junior female race. 12-year-old Oliver narrowly missed out on gold in the boy's lightning race, finishing second, before 14-year-old Alexandra Khlaf won the silver medal in the Cirrus junior male race.

In the kayak slalom, the borough finished third overall. Tobias Koralek-Martin won a bronze medal in the male senior slalom race before Oliver Khlaf convincingly won the male junior slalom after a best run of 84 seconds.

Kensington and Chelsea also had teams competing in the sailing and rowing competitions and finished a respectable seventh in both. The points they accumulated were enough to help them win the overall Thames Water Regatta for the first time ahead of Tower Hamlets and Hackney.

Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said:

"What a fantastic result for our young people and I'd like to congratulate them on their victory and for training hard all year round.

"I'd also like to thanks our Youth and School Sports Development Team for coordinating, recruiting and selecting the young people who went on compete at the London Youth Games."
shortdescription: For the first time, young people from Kensington and Chelsea have won the London Youth Games Regatta at London Docklands on Saturday 9 June.
shorttitle: Royal Borough wins London Youth Games Regatta

headline: TRI-BOROUGH COUNCILS ON COURSE TO SAVE £40 MILLION
prcopy:
A progress report published Monday 19 June reveals that Hammersmith & Fulham, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Westminster City Council are on track to save £40 million a year by 2015/16 by combining services and management costs.

This is helping to keep council tax bills in three areas amongst the lowest in Britain, while protecting front line services.

The Tri-borough councils are sharing £300 million of services and, in doing so, cutting management costs in half with 175 senior posts going.

The 'One year on' progress report reveals how 62 senior and middle management posts have already gone in the three areas that have been initially combined: Children's Services, Adult Social Care and Libraries, equivalent to a 45 per cent reduction in senior and middle management.

Combined environmental services between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham has resulted in seven management posts being lost. The two authorities now share a chief executive. Later this month the Tri-borough councils will share their learning and experiences with other local authorities at a conference at Kensington Town Hall.

This financial year £7.7 million of savings will be made across the three authorities. The eventual £40 million-a-year total savings shared between the three authorities represents around 7.3 per cent of Hammersmith & Fulham's total net budget expenditure.

Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, the Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea said "It is up to other councils to decide whether combining services makes sense. Many have already gone down this route. We stand ready to share our learning and experience to help others make ends meet."

Cllr Nicholas Botterill, the new Leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Council, said: "A year ago our plans were seen as radical, now they are seen as commonsense. Sharing costs, overheads and expertise is not only bringing down the cost of delivering services it is leading to better and more effective services."

Cllr Botterill pointed to the fact that library users can now borrow books in any of the three areas. The councils are also pioneering work to support 1720 troubled families. With every £1 spent on troubled families, £2.10 is saved for the taxpayer in avoided costs. The programme is helping families to turn around their lives, assisting them in repairing complex family issues while also supporting them into employment, education or training.

The `One year on' report reveals how the plans are supporting the transfer of power locally. Employee mutuals have been launched in areas around support for schools, youth services and ICT support services. People with longer-term care needs are being offered personal budgets, ward budgets are being extended in two of the boroughs, while Westminster and Hammersmith & Fulham are piloting neighbourhood budgets in Queens Park (Westminster) and White City (Hammersmith & Fulham).

A sovereignty guarantee signed by the three councils ensures local accountability and decision making, with each individual council responsible for their own budgets, policies and service specification.

Cllr Philippa Roe, Leader of Westminster City Council, said: "Sharing services is not just about reducing cost, important as that is in this age of austerity, it is about improving lives and innovation."

The first Tri-borough joint campaign `Summer in the City' offered summer activities across the three authorities. The programme is being repeated this year and will be launched at a youth engagement event taking place at Chelsea FC next Saturday (June 23) called "The Big Shout".

Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government, Eric Pickles, said: "The success of the Tri-borough approach is testament to the innovation and forward thinking of Westminster, Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea.

"Its councillors and officers are my London 2012 heroes for making such creative savings to protect frontline services, all while keeping council tax bills down helping families and pensioner with their cost of living.

"No council should even contemplate cutting services before they have considered following this example of how to join forces with neighbours to share back office services, procure better, slash in-house management and cut overhead costs. Potentially £2 billion of taxpayers' money could be saved if other councils were able to copy such sensible savings across the country."

To read the report, 'One year on' go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/triborough

shortdescription: A progress report published Monday 19 June reveals that Hammersmith & Fulham, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Westminster City Council are on track to save £40 million a year by 2015/16 by combining services and management costs.
shorttitle: Tri-borough councils on course to save £40 million

headline: PAY COUNCIL TAX BY DIRECT DEBIT FOR CHANCE TO WIN £25,000
prcopy:
Households across Kensington and Chelsea have just one month left to act if they want to be in with a chance of winning a £25,000 prize. All they need to do to be entered into this prize draw is sign up to pay their Council Tax bill by Direct Debit before 5pm on 12 July 2012.

The Council Tax prize draw promotion is being run by 17 London local authorities and Bacs Payment Schemes Ltd (Bacs), the not-for-profit organisation behind Direct Debit. Residents living in Kensington and Chelsea, Barking and Dagenham, Barnet, Brent, City of Westminster, Ealing, Enfield, Hammersmith and Fulham, Haringey, Harrow, Hillingdon, Hounslow, Islington, Lambeth, Lewisham, Redbridge and Southwark are all eligible for entry into the draw.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Finance, said: "Direct Debit is a much cheaper way for us to process payments and the money we save can be used for the benefit of local residents. Switching also helps the resident to budget and we're encouraging as many people as possible to switch to Direct Debit and be in with the chance of winning the £25,000 prize."

To enter Kensington and Chelsea residents must register to pay their Council Tax bill by Direct Debit before 5pm on 12 July 2012. They can simply return a completed paper Direct Debit Instruction to the Council; sign up to Direct Debit on the Council's website www.rbkc.gov.uk/counciltax; or give them a call to set up a Direct Debit over the phone 020 7368 8906. Residents who already pay their Council Tax bill by Direct Debit will be entered into the prize draw automatically.

Last year's £25,000 prize was won by a Southwark resident, while in 2010 the winner lived in Haringey. This year's winner will be drawn on 17 July 2012.
For more information on the prize draw and how to sign up to Direct Debit visit www.ddwinner.co.uk or contact your local council.

headline: FINANCIAL HELP FOR YOUNG PEOPLE IN THE ROYAL BOROUGH
prcopy:
Young people in the Royal Borough who need financial help to alleviate hardship or get into education or training can apply for support from the Kensington and Chelsea Youth Grants Fund.

The grants, which are funded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, are available for young people aged between 13 and 19 (or up to 25 for those with learning difficulties or disability).

This year the fund has three themes:

Helping Hand grants - which can fund young people experiencing hardship and who are in severe financial need. The money can be used to buy food, pay rent arrears, utility costs, medical costs and other costs. Grants made will be from £100 to £500.

Future Youth grants - will be used to help get young people into education, training or employment. The money can be used to buy equipment or tools, pay for courses leading to qualifications, travel costs for work and other costs associated with finding work or new skills. Grants made will be from £100 to £500.

Unity in the Community grants - will fund youth and community projects and can be applied for by groups of three or more young people. The money can be used to set up projects in their area or local youth club. The project must benefit other young people and be youth-led. The projects can include sport, arts and cultural events. Grants made will be from £100 to £1,000.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I want young people in the borough to be aware that this fund is there to help them. It can provide a financial helping hand in hard times, or pay to get the sort of qualification or training that can land a job."

Applications can be made between July 2012 and February 2013, or until the fund runs out.

To find out more about the Kensington and Chelsea Youth Grants Fund or for an application pack, contact the Youth Participation Team on 020 7938 8022 or email the Youth Forum at youthforum@rbkc.gov.uk.

End
shortdescription: Young people in the Royal Borough who need financial help to alleviate hardship or get into education or training can apply for support from the Kensington and Chelsea Youth Grants Fund.
shorttitle: Financial help for young people in the Royal Borough

headline: HELP GIVE CHILDREN A VOICE
prcopy:
`Give Children a Voice' provides funds that can be used by community groups and voluntary organisations who work with children in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. The grant can be used to set up a `children's forum' to help make sure that the views of children and young people are heard on a range of issues.

The grants, which are funded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, follow the success of its own Children's Forum, and will include travel costs, the purchase of small items of equipment, refreshment costs, publicity and printing costs and training to set up a forum.

A proportion of the grant can be used to pay for staff that help deliver the project.

The forum must be for children aged eight to 13 who live, study, attend a project or centre in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Applicants can apply for up to £1,000.

To find out more about the `Give Children a Voice' grant scheme or for an application pack, contact the Children's Participation Team on 0787 587 8859 or email Herta Queirazza, Children's Participation Coordinator, at herta.queirazza@rbkc.gov.uk
