shorttitle: Help give children a voice

headline: ENERGY SAVING SCHEME BENEFITS BOROUGH HOMES
prcopy:
A scheme to reduce fuel bills for Kensington and Chelsea residents and reduce the amount of CO2 produced by homes in the borough has proved to be a great success.

More than 1,300 homes in Kensington and Chelsea have benefitted from the RE:NEW energy saving scheme.

Over the past few months residents in the borough have been offered free home visits from energy assessors in a bid to lower their utility bills and reduce carbon emissions. The RE:NEW initiative is a pan-London scheme funded by the GLA and run in collaboration with the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Tailored advice was given to residents on saving energy in their homes and energy saving measures were installed where appropriate. Residents were given 2,194 energy saving light bulbs, 755 standby switches, 769 energy display monitors and 815 water saving showerheads. A range of other energy saving devices were fitted which will save up to 218,108 tonnes of CO2 production.

Cllr Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Housing, said: "The RE:NEW scheme has proved to be a great success. The energy saving equipment given to residents, or installed in their homes, will help save them money and reduce the amount of CO2 produced in the borough."

This current phase of the RE:NEW scheme has now come to an end but advice and assistance are still available through the Healthy Homes scheme on 0808 202 6204.
shortdescription: A scheme to reduce fuel bills for Kensington and Chelsea residents and reduce the amount of CO2 produced by homes in the borough has proved to be a great success.
shorttitle: Energy saving scheme benefits borough homes

headline: OLYMPIC TORCH TO COME THROUGH THE BOROUGH
prcopy:
The penultimate day of the Olympic torch's epic journey around Britain sees it come to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The torch will arrive in the borough at approximately 1.30pm on Thursday 26 July when it will cross Chelsea Bridge into Chelsea Bridge Road, passing the Royal Chelsea Hospital (home of the Chelsea Pensioners), before heading to Sloane Square and along King's Road. It then leaves the borough before re-entering along Kensington High Street where it will be greeted by a choral fanfare in Holland Park by the only civic run opera company in the country, Opera Holland Park, at approximately 2.30pm. The choir of 150 professional and amateur singers will be accompanied by the City of London Sinfonia. There will also be a `come and try' sports day for everyone on Holland Park's sports field.

The torch will then leave the borough again for Hammersmith and Fulham before returning for its final leg along Notting Hill Gate before heading into Westminster.

The Royal Borough invites all our residents to welcome the torch and cheer on our local torchbearers as they carry the flame on its journey to the Olympic Park.

There will be some disruption to traffic in the Royal Borough on the day, but the Council is working closely with LOCOG and TfL to minimise the disruption and help residents and businesses plan their day around it.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, Member Lead for 2012, said: "Having the Olympic torch relay will be very exciting and I am sure that residents and visitors will enjoy seeing the procession.

"Opera Holland Park and the City of London Sinfonia will put on a fabulous performance, backed by a wonderful community choir to welcome the torch and its bearers. Do come along to Holland Park to join in the fun.

"Of course, the torch's convoy will cause some disruption to traffic and public transport and it is important that residents and businesses are prepared for this."

Holland Park will see a host of activities throughout the day for visitors to enjoy. These range from operatic performances and `Minute Maestro' where the audience can have a go at conducting the orchestra to sporting demonstrations and new sports to try for all the family.
shortdescription: The penultimate day of the Olympic torch's epic journey around Britain sees it come to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Olympic torch to come through the borough

headline: TWO YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS TO TRADE ON PORTOBELLO MARKET
prcopy:
Two young entrepreneurs, Jo Hawtree and Emily Ellen Dell, whose business ideas have won them trading pitches on the world famous Portobello Market are preparing for their first day's trading on Saturday 30 June.

Jo, who is starting a men's fashion label called `Gunsmoke & Lavender', and Emily Ellen, who will sell bespoke art on canvas under the name `Girl on a Swing', won six months rent-free market stall space after been named winners of the Market Enterprise Launch Pad (MELP) last December. In addition to the trading pitch the pair also won £1,000 each in start-up funds and a support package from the Prince's Trust.

Emily Ellen said: "Time seems to be running away but I'm confident that it will all come together. With the help of the Council's Education Business Partnership team I was able to hold my first art exhibition at the Louise Blouin Foundation and got some great feedback.

"After winning MELP I instantly created a checklist of all the things I needed to achieve before the launch date. This involved sourcing various printing firms and working out the best way to buy in bulk and save money. I've started producing my art work on gift cards, book marks, post cards and, of course, still keeping up my canvases. Everything I purchase is logged so I can keep up to date with my funds. I'm currently in the process of setting up a meeting with HMRC so then I'll be fully prepared to deal with my tax when I start selling my work."

Jo Hawtree has been equally busy since winning last December. She's exhibited at the Ideal Home Show and Imperial College Rag Week Fashion Show and is working with a promotion company, Lottarox Agency, to have her label worn by emerging new musical talents.

Jo also got a loan from The Prince's Trust. Jo said: "I am really excited to have a space to trade on Portobello Market and cannot wait to meet my customers."

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Jo and Emily have worked very hard to prepare the pitches for the launch. Having a pitch on such an iconic market is a real opportunity for any business starting out and I wish them every success trading."
shortdescription: Two young entrepreneurs, Jo Hawtree and Emily Ellen Dell, whose business ideas have won them trading pitches on the world famous Portobello Market are preparing for their first day's trading on Saturday 30 June.
shorttitle: Two young entrepreneurs to trade on Portobello Market

headline: EXHIBITION ROAD WINS RIBA AWARD
prcopy:
The kerb-free, single surface Exhibition Road has won its third award since opening officially in February 2012.

Its architects, Dixon Jones, were recognised in the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) awards, winning the design competition to integrate vehicle and foot traffic and provide an attractive pedestrian environment without unduly compromising the road's role as a key transport link.

The new-look road features a kerb-free single surface with no barriers or street clutter. Visual and tactile lines distinguish pedestrian areas from those used by vehicles. Cars are slowed by a 20mph speed limit.

A stunning chequered granite design runs from South Kensington Station to Hyde Park along the full width of the road from building to building. Kerbs, barriers and street clutter have been removed improving access, particularly for those using wheelchairs, push chairs and motorised buggies. Pedestrians can now walk from South Kensington Station to Hyde Park along a newly created public space.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "In Exhibition Road London now has a unique streetscape that will delight its many millions of visitors and which sets a new standard for urban design.

"The quality of this design has been recognised by RIBA and I'd like to congratulate all associated with the project at Dixon Jones."
shortdescription: The kerb-free, single surface Exhibition Road has won its third award since opening officially in February 2012.
shorttitle: Exhibition Road wins RIBA award

headline: TfL URGES RESIDENTS TO PLAN OLYMPIC TRAVEL
prcopy:
Following the hugely enthusiastic welcome for the Olympic torch relay on its journey around the UK and the great success of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee, Transport for London (TfL) and London 2012 have set out plans for managing the London 2012 Games road events and issued travel advice to spectators planning to attend.

The Capital is being turned into a massive sporting and cultural venue, including 13 road events being held across London and Surrey during the course of the Games, in addition to live sites and cultural events.

The road events, which include road cycling, marathon, triathlon and race walking, offer a great opportunity for many to see Olympic and Paralympic sport and very large crowds are expected to attend.

TfL is working with London 2012, the Metropolitan Police, boroughs and councils across London and Surrey to ensure the road events are a great success.

Information on the road event race routes, the impact on road and public transport networks and how to plan ahead is also available at www.GetAheadoftheGames.com

With just five weeks to go to the London 2012 Olympic Games, people across the country are finalising their plans. Hundreds of thousands of spectators are expected to attend each road event and, given the road event routes, viewing capacity in central London will be very limited.

TfL and London 2012 issued the following advice to spectators to ensure people enjoy the best possible Games-time experience:

Advice to spectators:
 If you are planning to attend a road event, please arrive early, be prepared to wait for several hours and think carefully about bringing small children;
 Pack food and water, sun cream or waterproof clothing, depending on the weather;
 Think about the best viewing option for you, your friends and family. For some, it may be better to view the event at one of the many Live Sites across the UK or on TV at home, with friends, at a pub or local community centre;
 For the Road Cycle Races on Saturday 28 and Sunday 29 July in particular, try to `stay local' and enjoy the events as they pass through your local community;
 Have a back-up plan. If it gets really busy, you might want to enjoy one of the wealth of free events, cultural and entertainment opportunities on offer across the UK and during London's summer like no other. Find out what's happening and sign up for updates at www.molpresents.com and download the London 2012 `Join In' app;
 If you are intending to travel - plan ahead. Go to www.GetAheadoftheGames.com which has all the tools and information you need about Road Events and how to plan your journey.

TfL also repeated its advice to motorists and urged those in road event areas not to get caught out by the road closures necessary to stage the events.

Advice to motorists:
 Motorists are advised to avoid central London, around the Olympic Route Network (ORN), venues and the road event courses;
 Don't get caught out - you will not be able to cross the race route by road;
 On road event days road closures will be in place from early morning;
 Instead, please use public transport, cycle or walk.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Member Leader for 2012, said: "We are only weeks away from the Games and it is very important that people who live and work in the borough are aware of the key dates and plan for the disruption that will occur.

"I would urge people to check out key websites such as www.getasheadofthegames.com to make sure they are aware of just when and where travel disruption will be at its worst."

Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, said: "London is gearing up to become a huge and wonderful sporting and cultural venue as we welcome the world for the Games. The Road Events offer a great opportunity to see some of the world's top athletes in competition and to experience the numerous other attractions London has to offer.

"Given the huge numbers of people who will be in London for the Games, it is really important that people follow our travel advice and plan ahead."

The majority of road events start and finish in central London, but some - including the Cycle Road Races and Cycling Time Trials - pass through south-west London and Surrey. The Cycling Road Races on Saturday 28 and Sunday 29 July will take place on routes passing through Westminster, Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham, Kingston upon Thames, Wandsworth and Richmond upon Thames, as well as other parts of Surrey.

To ensure the safety of athletes and spectators, road races need to take place on secure roads and closures and parking restrictions will need to be put in place on the days of the competitions. These will be managed to keep disruption to a minimum and all roads will be opened as quickly as possible after the events have finished. After the events, barriers will need to be removed, road signs, traffic lights and islands reinstated, roads thoroughly cleaned and crowds dispersed before roads can be reopened safely.

The majority of road events will be held at weekends and some competitions will only take place for a few hours beginning in the morning. Where possible, roads will be reopened and restrictions lifted by the late afternoon or early evening. No roads will be closed overnight apart from the roads needed to build the Cycle Time Trial venue at Hampton Court Palace.

A wealth of free events and cultural events will be happening in London's `Summer Like No Other' as part of the `Mayor of London Presents' programme. For more information and to find out how to get involved visit www.molpresents.com.

For more information on events in the capital and across the UK, as well as ideas on how to get involved wherever you are, download the official London 2012 `Join in' app.
shortdescription: Following the hugely enthusiastic welcome for the Olympic torch relay on its journey around the UK and the great success of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee, Transport for London (TfL) and London 2012 have set out plans for managing the London 2012 Games road events and issued travel advice to spectators planning to attend.
shorttitle: TfL urges residents to plan Olympic travel

headline: FLYING THE FLAG FOR THE ARMED SERVICES
prcopy:
The Armed Forces Flag was raised at Kensington Town Hall this morning (Monday 25 June) and will be flown during the week leading up to Armed Forces Day (Saturday 30 June).

Councillor Christopher Buckmaster, Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, was joined by a detachment from the Household Cavalry under the command of Major Charlie Meredith-Hardy. Members of the Regiment have been working closely with youth organisations in the Royal Borough in recent months, helping young people to develop their skills, especially around team work, leadership and confidence. An Army Cadet detachment, which recently formed in Kensington, is affiliated to the Life Guards.

Armed Forces Day aims to raise public awareness of the contribution made to the country by those who serve and have served in Her Majesty's armed forces. It also gives the nation an opportunity to show support for the men and women who make up the armed forces community: from currently serving troops to service families, veterans and cadets.

The Royal Borough has a long standing and close relationship with the armed forces having given the Freedom of the Borough to seven regiments and hosted many parades, including one by the Royal Yeomanry in March 2012 and the recent Diamond Jubilee March Past which saw over 200 troops parade down Kensington High Street.

The Council was one of the first in London to sign the Armed Forces Covenant and has held an annual reception for the armed forces for the past 20 years.

The Mayor said: "We owe a great debt of gratitude to past and present members of the armed forces and are proud to be able to demonstrate that throughout this week by flying the Armed Forces Flag."
shortdescription: The Armed Forces Flag was raised at Kensington Town Hall this morning (Monday 25 June) and will be flown during the week leading up to Armed Forces Day (Saturday 30 June).
shorttitle: Flying the flag for the armed services

headline: BOROUGHS ARE BEST FOR YOUTH JOBS
prcopy:
The number of young people in west London who are not in employment, education or training (NEET) is the lowest it has ever been - bucking the national trend.

The latest figures published by the Department for Education show that in Hammersmith & Fulham, only 4.8 per cent of young people aged 16 to 19 are NEET well below the national average of 6.1 per cent. That is a massive drop of 11.1 per cent since 2005 when the NEET figure was 15.9 per cent.

Together with neighbouring boroughs Kensington and Chelsea, and Westminster, who are part of the Tri-borough agreement to share children's services, the figure still remains lower than the national average, standing at 5.4 per cent.

The news comes just days after the successful youth event, The Big SHOUT, where hundreds of young people aged 13 to 19 from all three boroughs were brought together for the first time. The young people met at Chelsea Football Club which has been working closely with the councils to host and support the event.

Young people were given the chance to visit a CV and employment skills surgery to brush up on their interview techniques, find out how to write a CV and receive job advice. It is just one of the many ways in which the boroughs are helping more young people into employment and training. The councils are also offering six young people work experience placements during the summer.

Chelsea FC Club Ambassador, Graeme Le Saux, said: "The Big Shout is a great opportunity to bring the young people together through the boroughs and youth councils and offer them a whole range of opportunities to explore and see what is available to them in the local area."

The day also included workshops and Question and Answer sessions with leading figures from the councils, health trusts and the Met Police, discussing issues such as sexual and emotional health, and communication between young people and the police.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "These are difficult times for young people and it is important they have as many opportunities as possible to develop skills and confidence to help them shape their future.

"We want to support them and to ensure we are delivering what they need and to make sure they are aware of what training and help is available. It is all about giving young people meaningful opportunities to develop skills, such as the football coaching scheme, which can lead to a qualification and perhaps a full time job."

Remi Smith, 21, from Kensington, had been unemployed for almost two months when he found support and training through one of several schemes provided in the Tri-borough areas. Remi, who had previously worked in Marks and Spencer, was helped onto the scheme by local careers advisors in both Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham. He is now two months through the `Let Me Play' 30-week coaching programme. Trainees study for six qualifications, including an NVQ in sport and fitness, coaching and functional skills in maths, science and English. They also receive breakfast every morning, training clothes and the chance to apply for bursary funding, among other benefits.

Remi said: "I was looking to pursue a career in football coaching and I was pointed in the direction of Let Me Play. I had an informal interview, where they outlined what was expected of me if I got on the programme and then they accepted me. The scheme offers me practical and theoretical skills, and has helped give me experiences and skills I wouldn't have otherwise.

"It's been really good - the tutors are friendly and informative, and they give us advice and help when we need it. We also get to plan coaching sessions and then put them into practice to see how they work.

"It's been productive, I've assessed my goals and what I want out of life, and it's made me look forward to my future. Now I've got a positive outlook."

Remi is now hoping that once he completes his NVQ he will be considered for a coaching role working with Fulham or even as a member of the Let Me Play team, when the company hosts a range of sporting sessions over the summer holidays.

Other projects in the Tri-borough areas that are helping more young people than ever get into education, employment or training include Street Elite, Fulham FC Foundation, Reed in Partnership (London Volunteering) and Fast Forward.

Cllr Helen Binmore, Hammersmith & Fulham's Council's cabinet member for Children's Services, said: "We are proactive in our approach to helping young people into training, education and employment, and make sure we are talking and listening to our young people, understanding what they want to achieve in their lives.

"We allow them to take control of their destinies, by helping to build confidence and boost their morale while improving their skills, often by linking job training to sports, for example as we do with Chelsea, Fulham and QPR football clubs. And we also offer opportunities through work experience schemes, apprenticeships and early intervention through, for example, our youth clubs."

The 300 young people at The Big SHOUT were joined by former Chelsea, Southampton and England footballer Graeme Le Saux, England basketball star Melita Emanuel-Carr and British rapper Joe Black, while staff from the councils were on hand to offer advice and guidance.

Councillor Nickie Aiken, Cabinet Member for Children, Young People and Community Protection at Westminster City Council said: "Our local young people are facing unprecedented challenges in getting the right training and experience and then nailing that all-important first job - and we owe it to them to provide all the support we can.

"The Big SHOUT proved young people are up to the challenge and ready to grab every opportunity that comes their way. I hope the event has given them a fresh perspective on training, CV-writing and other important career skills that will help them make a real impact on the jobs market in the future."

The Summer in the City events guide was also launched, which showcases hundreds of council led events available to young people across west and central London this summer.
keyword3: the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: The number of young people in west London who are not in employment, education or training (NEET) is the lowest it has ever been - bucking the national trend.
shorttitle: Boroughs are best for youth jobs

headline: SIX HUNDRED AND NINETY MILLION NEW REASONS TO SAY YES TO A CROSSRAIL STATION FOR PORTOBELLO
prcopy:
A Crossrail station on the site of the old Kensal Gas Works could boost the local economy by £690m and create 2,000 new jobs, according to a study published this week by economic analysts, Regeneris.

The report suggests the economic growth could be created in six ways. Construction of the station and related development would make the largest contribution to employment, with 770 new jobs created. The catalytic effect a station would have on the development of the Kensal site would make the largest financial contribution: a station, says Regeneris, would turbocharge the development of the 67-acre site adding approximately £300m in economic benefits.

There would also be a significant impact on local consumer spending with the demand for goods and services created by an influx of new residents adding 360 jobs and £140 million to the local economy.

The station would also boost the area as a business location adding a further 150 jobs and £100m, while the reduction in journey times for local residents and business would create benefits worth another £90 million.

Finally Regeneris also estimates the improvement in accessibility to all parts of London would assist 500 local residents into jobs leading to direct and indirect economic benefits valued at £10 million.

In the report, Regeneris also highlights several other economic benefits where the values are more difficult to gauge. For example, changes in perception of the area created by a new station; increases in land and property prices; reduced journey times to education and training facilities; the impacts of association with the Crossrail brand; decreases in congestion; and the opening up of a northern entrance to Portobello Road and Golborne Road Markets.

Welcoming the report, the Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, said: "Our country desperately needs jobs and growth and this report is yet more evidence that we are ready and able to provide both in significant quantities.

"It really is time for Crossrail to say yes to our Portobello station."

The report is the second published by Regeneris this year (see www.rbkc.gov.uk/crossrail). In February it published the results of its investigation into the regeneration arguments for a Crossrail station. After looking at a wide range of measures of deprivation, it concluded that Kensal has a stronger regeneration case for a Crossrail station than any other location outside east London and that, had it been assessed at the outset of the Crossrail project, it "...would almost certainly have been included in the top six opportunity station hinterlands" identified by the London Development Agency as deserving a station on deprivation and equality grounds.
shortdescription: A Crossrail station on the site of the old Kensal Gas Works could boost the local economy by £690m and create 2,000 new jobs, according to a study published this week by economic analysts, Regeneris.
shorttitle: Six hundred and ninety million reasons to say yes to a Crossrail station for Portobello

headline: FIND OUT MORE ABOUT TRAVEL DURING THE OLYMPIC GAMES
prcopy:
With only five weeks to go before the start of London 2012 residents can find out more about how to get around London during the Games at a roadshow organised by Transport for London.

The Get Ahead of the Games information road show takes place on Thursday 5 July at Sainsbury's Ladbroke Grove between 2pm and 8pm.

Local people can pop in and find out how the Games will affect their road, bus, train and Tube travel, and how to make their journeys easier. Transport for London staff will be on hand to answer questions about the Olympic Route Network and Games Lanes, Road Events, road restrictions and closures, hotspot stations and bus diversions in the local area.

headline: INVESTMENT IN TAVISTOCK SQUARE
prcopy:
Tavistock Square has been transformed following over £500,000 investment by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Transport for London.

The square remains a pedestrian area but now has porphyry paving and a new Sweet Gum (Liquidambar Styraciflua) tree. To the north there is a raised table, crossing Basing Street, making a clearer link between the square and the park opposite and improving access to Westbourne Park Underground station.

The arts and craft market helps to sustain the vitality of the square and the six dedicated arts and crafts market stall spaces all now have electric power supplies.

Commenting on the improvements to Tavistock Square, Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "It is great to see the improvements to this key staging point on Portobello Road. We have been working hard to improve North Kensington and provide residents and visitors with an improved streetscape.

"I think that everyone who comes to the square will be pleased with what they see and it is worth noting that it now feels more part of its surrounding area. Its relationship with Tavistock Gardens is much better and I hope it will mean more people will come to the square and Tavistock Gardens."

The works followed consultation with residents of the area and requests from Colville Area Forum.

New lighting was also installed in the square and matches the existing Portobello Road lighting. New festoon lighting has also been placed in the two largest trees in the square.

A new circular bench has been placed around one of the trees, nearest Portobello Road and informal seating has been placed at each end of the square in the form of spherical bollards.

Two new shrub planters with lavender, rosemary and Mesembryanthemums and new tree surrounds around the base of all the trees have also been installed.
shortdescription: Tavistock Square has been transformed following over £500,000 investment by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Transport for London.
shorttitle: Investment in Tavistock Square

headline: ST LUKE'S GARDENS TRANSFORMATION
prcopy:
Over £2 million of improvement works on St Luke's Gardens has now been completed. The Gardens have a new playground and new Astroturf pitch. There is a `Teen area' which has climbing boulders and the park has a new amenity building. Access has been improved to allow anyone into all parts of the park and general landscape of the Gardens has been refreshed.

There has also been work to conserver the listed perimeter wall and new, ornamental railings and gates have been installed.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Environment and Leisure, said: "I am pleased that the works at St Luke's Gardens are now completed. The gardens with their new railings and planting now provide a handsome setting for St Luke's church for the first time in many decades. We have a long-term policy of upgrading all the Borough's parks to keep pace with the aspirations of local residents.

"I'm sure that all the regular users of the gardens will enjoy the improvements and am delighted that the Council has been able to undertake this major upgrade to such an important green space in the heart of Chelsea."
shortdescription: Over £2 million of improvement works on St Luke's Gardens has now been completed.  The Gardens have a new playground and new Astroturf pitch.  There is a `Teen area' which has climbing boulders and the park has a new amenity building.  Access has been improved to allow anyone into all parts of the park and general landscape of the Gardens has been refreshed.
shorttitle: St Luke's Gardens Transformation

headline: COUNCIL CALLS ON TfL TO RESPECT RIGHT OF WAY
prcopy:
Transport for London (TfL) intends to press on with plans to restrict a public right of way across the Kensington Olympia footbridge, despite protests from local residents.

To reduce ticketless travel TfL says it needs to install gates which would restrict access to the bridge which also serves as an important shortcut across the tracks between Russell Road and Olympia Way.

TfL has promised that a residents' pass scheme will preserve the shortcut for local people, however access for the wider public will be lost under the plans.

The local authorities either side of the tracks - Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea - having received evidence from large numbers of residents, have written to TfL and Network Rail setting out their opinion that this popular pedestrian shortcut should be considered a right of way which must not be restricted in any way.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I'm afraid that TfL's offer to issue a pass that would allow residents to continue to use the footbridge misses the point that, in our opinion, there is strong evidence that indicates there is already an established right of way over the bridge."
shortdescription: Transport for London (TfL) intends to press on with plans to restrict a public right of way across the Kensington Olympia footbridge, despite protests from local residents.
shorttitle: Council calls on TfL to respect right of way

headline: THE EVOLUTION OF TAVISTOCK SQUARE
prcopy:
Tavistock Square is to be the canvas for the internationally renowned street artist Edgar Mueller.

Famed for his amazing 3D illusional art, Mueller will create `Evolution' in the west London square. It will take Mueller and his team of assistants five days to transform the square into an interactive artwork after which members of the public can actively place themselves in the finished artwork and thereby become part of Mueller's fantastical illusion.

Organised as part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's InTRANSIT Festival of Arts, Evolution promises to get cameras snapping.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Council, said: "I'm very much looking forward to seeing what Edgar Mueller is going to do with our square. His work certainly gets people talking and more importantly it gets them involved.

"Take the opportunity to go along to Tavistock Square to see Edgar and his assistants at work and when they are finished put yourself in the picture."

Edgar Mueller and his team will be working on `Evolution' from 9 to 13 July, and the public can step into the artwork between 14 July and 31 July.

For more information about InTRANSIT and how to get involved visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/intransit

shortdescription: Tavistock Square is to be the canvas for the internationally renowned street artist Edgar Mueller.
shorttitle: The Evolution of Tavistock Square

headline: THE DRAGONS AND SUFFRAGETTES OF PORTOBELLO ROAD
prcopy:
Dragons and Suffragettes will be taking over Portobello Road on Saturday 14 July as part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's InTRANSIT Festival of Arts.

Children will love the chance to get up close and personal with Epico the dragon, as the gallant Knight Sir Aurelious Jones bids to tame the beast.

Epico is the biggest, brightest and most beautiful dragon west London has ever seen and a child will be selected by the finger of fate to take part in a quest for the brave.

Organised by Creature Encounter, an established street arts company, this event promises to captivate the young and a few adults too.

The event takes place in Powis Square on Portobello Road at 1pm, 2.15pm and 3.30pm, and each performance lasts approximately 30 minutes.

There is also an opportunity to step back in time to 1913 when Mrs Emmeline Pankhurst was recruiting supporters for the right for women to vote. Come along and witness what a Suffragette rally might have been like as Spectrum Drama, a leader in historic theatre events, brings the struggle for votes for women to the streets of west London.

Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "It's not every day that you can take in one of London's finest street markets and bump into dragons and Suffragettes, but then again InTRANSIT doesn't happen every day.

"I hope that as many people as possible can come along, enjoy the market and have some real fun as this fine street theatre comes to the borough."

The Suffragettes will be making their case on Portobello Road on Saturday 14 July between 1pm and 4pm.

For more information about InTRANSIT and how to get involved visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/intransit

Find out the latest news via Twitter by following @RBKCculture and check out the Facebook page www.facebook.com/RBKCculture for any updates.
shortdescription: Dragons and Suffragettes will be taking over Portobello Road on Saturday 14 July as part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's InTRANSIT Festival of Arts.
shorttitle: The Dragons and Suffragettes of Portobello Road

headline: DIAMOND JUBILEE WALK
prcopy:
Holland Park's 60th year as a public park was marked by the opening of the Diamond Jubilee Walk, in recognition of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee. The Walk, previously known as the Lavender Walk, is situated in the Dutch Gardens.

The event was hosted by the Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Nick Paget-Brown and opened by the Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Christopher Buckmaster; together with the Deputy Lord Lieutenant, Hon. Alderman Richard Walker-Arnott. The Leader of the Council, Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell was also present, as well as a number of other Councillors and former Councillors, Friends of Holland Park, residents and staff.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown welcomed everyone saying: "It's good to see so many familiar faces here, former colleagues and current ones, representatives of the Friends of Holland Park and many others. We come here today not only to recognise Her Majesty, celebrate 60 years of Holland Park as a public open space but also our fine Parks Police and to launch this year's London in Bloom."

The Mayor said: "I am delighted to be able to unveil the plaque to mark the dedication of the new Diamond Jubilee Walk. Holland Park has thousands of visitors a year and it is a fantastic way to remind them, and ourselves, of the hard work and commitment that has marked our Queen's reign."

The Parks Police were then presented with Diamond Jubilee medals, made to celebrate the work of the armed forces and emergency services throughout the country. The Deputy Lord Lieutenant presented all the Parks Police officers present with their medals.
shortdescription: Holland Park's 60th year as a public park was marked by the opening of the Diamond Jubilee Walk, in recognition of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee.  The Walk, previously known as the Lavender Walk, is situated in the Dutch Gardens.
shorttitle: Diamond Jubilee Walk

headline: COUNCIL SEEKS TO SECURE TRELLICK'S FUTURE THROUGH NEW DEVELOPMENT
prcopy:
Whether land at the foot of Trellick Tower could be developed in order to help meet the cost of maintaining the iconic building will be one of the key issues explored in a study just commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The Council is engaging architectural and specialist historic building consultants to advise on the development potential of Council-owned land which forms part of Erno Goldfinger's original overall design. There are two sites:

 The first fronts onto nearby Elkstone Road. Formerly occupied by an elderly people's home and day centre, the site has been vacant since 2008 and is currently in temporary use as a coach park.

 The other site lies to the south and immediately below the Tower. It includes playspace, parts of the pedestrian walkways, stairs and basement car park/storage area, plus the ground floor of Trellick itself, which is currently in social use.

The consultants' brief is to come up with options for the redevelopment of the sites, including proposals for the layout and height of buildings, ideas for making best use of open space and plans for improving routes for vehicles and pedestrians. Key to the project will be how the character, appearance and setting of Trellick Tower are to be preserved and enhanced.

Trellick is Grade II listed, placing it in the top eight per cent of listed buildings in the country*. Now in its 40th year, It needs considerable capital investment to maintain it in good order.

Commenting on the study, Cabinet Member for Housing and Property, Cllr Timothy Coleridge, said:

"We need new homes, new facilities and new economic activity in this part of the borough. But while we plan those, it must make sense to see if in some way development can also help resolve some of the financial challenges of maintaining Trellick Tower for the next 40 years."

As part of the study, the consultants will be involving local residents in discussions about the development of the sites, sharing with them the options as they emerge.
shortdescription: Whether land at the foot of Trellick Tower could be developed in order to help meet the cost of maintaining the iconic building will be one of the key issues explored in a study just commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Council seeks to secure Trellick's future through new development

headline: FREE RUNNING THROUGH THE BOROUGH
prcopy:
Simulate the exhilarating experience of being a freerunner with `RBKCParkour' on Saturday 21 July, a part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's InTRANSIT Festival of Arts.

From 2pm to 4pm on Saturday 21 July, visitors to Portobello Pop-Up Cinema (3 Acklam Road, W10 5TY) can be part of an interactive art installation and replicate traversing urban landscapes in Kensington and Chelsea through the skill of freerunning.

Parkour originated in France and the main purpose of this discipline is teaching people how to move through their environment, advancing around obstacles by vaulting, rolling, running, climbing and jumping.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Parkour is a very exciting way of moving around a city and its finest exponents seem to make it look effortless, which I'm sure it's not.

"If you've never seen parkour in action and want to experience what it's like as part of this innovative art installation come along to the pop-up cinema and give it a go."

Karen Palmer is a freerunner and an award winning artist. Her work explores the physiological aspects of being a freerunner and the psyche of the parkour experience. Karen's practice has evolved into interactive art in the public realm as she strives to simulate this experience.

The event is free and no booking is required.

For more information about InTRANSIT and how to get involved visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/intransit

shorttitle: Freerunning through the borough

headline: STUDENTS AND PUPILS ARTISTIC TALENT RECOGNISED
prcopy:
The artistic talents of pupils and students from 33 schools were showcased at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's 13th annual Schools Art Exhibition on 26 June at Leighton House Museum.

A prize-giving ceremony marked the opening of the exhibition which was attended by the artists, aged from three to 20, parents and teachers.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Christopher Buckmaster, and Councillor Mrs Frances Taylor presented certificates and cash prizes to the children whose work was selected for display.

Nine young artists received Highly Commended awards from The Park Gallery in the drawing/painting category.

Among the borough's schools, Bevington Primary School got the top award for applied art, with second place going to Chelsea Children's Hospital School, while third place in the drawing/painting category went to Holland Park School.

Independent schools in the borough also featured strongly, Ashbourne College came first in the drawing/painting category and was also awarded the Leighton Prize. Garden House School came second with Hill House School close behind in third place for applied art.

The prizes were supported by Flow Gallery (applied art), The Park Gallery (drawing/painting) and The Friends of Leighton House (Leighton Prize).

The exhibition celebrates work produced in schools across the Royal Borough, while the project as a whole is designed to encourage children and young people to pursue and develop their interests and talents in art.

Commenting on the exhibition the Mayor said: "The standard of art produced in our schools for this exhibition was truly exceptional. It is clear for all to see that we have many talented young artists, nurtured and encouraged by truly dedicated art teachers."
shortdescription: The artistic talents of pupils and students from 33 schools were showcased at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's 13th annual Schools Art Exhibition on 26 June at Leighton House Museum.
shorttitle: Schools Art Exhibition

headline: COUNCIL CONSULTS ON THE FUTURE OF THE KENSAL SITE
prcopy:
A largely derelict 67-acre site in central London, capable of accommodating up to 3,500 new homes, is the subject of a major consultation by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Local residents and businesses are being asked to comment on three illustrated options for the Kensal Gasworks site as the first stage in the process of creating a 'Supplementary Planning Document' against which any future planning applications will be judged.

The first option looks at what might be achieved on the site without a Crossrail station. The second and third options consider how the development might be boosted if the Council's campaign to bring a Portobello Crossrail station to the site succeeds.

A station would enable a more intense development, with far more homes, employment, commerce and community facilities. Option three, for example, envisages a waterside style development with 3,500 homes, a reinstated canal basin and a new bridge across the rail tracks.

In a recently published report, leading economic analysts Regeneris estimate that a Crossrail station would supercharge the value of the site, creating 2,000 new jobs and adding £690 million to the local economy.

"Our research has already shown the tremendous difference in value between a development with a station and a development without," said Cabinet Member for Planning, Cllr Tim Ahern.

"Our view is that our economy needs that additional growth and our people need those extra homes, jobs and facilities. But we don't take up these positions in a detached way. Our ambitions for the site were developed with local people who now have a further opportunity to comment on our direction of travel and influence the development that eventually takes place."

"The Kensal site matters, to our residents and to the London economy."
shortdescription: A largely derelict 67-acre site in central London, capable of accommodating up to 3,500 new homes, is the subject of a major consultation by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Council consults on the future of the Kensal site

headline: KITCHEN GARDEN BLOOMS MINUTES FROM FASHIONABLE SLOANE AVENUE
prcopy:
Two hundred years ago Kensington and Chelsea was famed for its market gardens and nurseries. Today this tradition is undergoing a modest resurgence thanks to a programme to turn underused corners of land into community kitchen gardens. The community kitchen gardens allow residents to grow their own fresh fruit and vegetables.

The latest in a line of unused sites to be transformed into a community kitchen garden with 15 `aplotments' for green fingered residents is Wiltshire Close Community Kitchen Garden located just a short walk from the haute couture shops and high-end fashion boutiques of Sloane Avenue in the borough's Hans Town Ward. This garden will be opened on Saturday 7 July by the Mayor of the Royal Borough Cllr Christopher Buckmaster.

Also, to celebrate the Queen's Diamond Jubilee over 100 fruit bushes (raspberry, blackberry and gooseberry) and fruit trees (apple, pear and plum) are to be planted across the various community kitchen gardens in the borough. Three heritage fruit trees donated by Brighter Kensington and Chelsea will be planted to mark the opening of the Wiltshire Close garden.

Since 2009 the Royal Borough has transformed 35 derelict sites, including one disused tennis court, into thriving gardens.

Prior to the launch of the initiative, the Council had no kitchen gardens/allotments, but now thanks to the scheme the borough has more than 300 kitchen gardens tended by over 500 residents.

Today this tradition is undergoing a modest resurgence thanks to a programme to turn underused corners of land into community kitchen gardens.  The community kitchen gardens allow residents to grow their own fresh fruit and vegetables.

headline: EXPLORE, MAP, INVESTIGATE
prcopy:
July is the time to try some walks with a difference in Kensington and Chelsea as part of the borough's InTRANSIT Festival of Arts.

Get close to urban nature at the Nature Safari trail on Wednesday 25 July from 4.30pm to 7.30pm. Head into the urban jungle of Portobello Green and use your eyes and ears to explore the environment. You will have a chance to look for connections between your life and the animals and plants that find a life alongside our busy streets.

The Nature Safari trail, which is free, is led by Geoff Sample, a naturalist, author and specialist in wildlife sound and Andrew Stuck, a consultant on walking and the city environment.

Alternatively, if you want to take a step back in time to the Victorian era try the Ruskin Walk which explores the neighbourhood familiar to the polymath John Ruskin. Discover the area around Leighton House Museum where Ruskin played a pivotal role in bringing the Pre-Raphaelites to fame and fortune.

The walk, created by Martin Fidler, takes place on Thursday 26 July from 6.15pm to 7.45pm. Tickets are £5 and booking is required

If you want to create a map of your walk, try the Map Ramble, an exploratory investigation of Kensington Park on Saturday 21 July between 11am and 1pm.

After a couple of hours spent rambling, participants share their discoveries and the issues triggered by their ramble. The trail is free but booking is required.

For more information about meeting points and to book go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/intransit

Follow the events on Twitter @RBKCculture or check out Facebook www.facebook.com/RBKCculture.
shortdescription: July is the time to try some walks with a difference in Kensington and Chelsea as part of the borough's InTRANSIT Festival of Arts.
shorttitle: Explore, map, investigate

headline: BIG DANCE IN THE ROYAL BOROUGH ON FRIDAY 13 JULY
prcopy:
As part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's InTRANSIT Festival,
Big Dance will be turning World's End Place, on the King's Road, into an energetic dance space. At 4.30pm, the quirky Big Dance Bus will pull up and roll out the ultimate dance floor, providing a unique space for some of London's best dance groups to showcase their work.

Come and experience spectacular performances from professional dancers and local groups and join in the dance workshops for free! This special celebration of world dance is an experience not to be missed.

Or why not make the short trip to the beautiful Duke of York Square (near Sloane Square) for our Big Dance Pop-Up Screen: Shall We Dance? event, where you can revel in an evening of glitz and glamour inspired by the golden age of the Hollywood musical, the iconic pairing of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, and the sublime music of George Gershwin?

From 7pm, watch performances from all-American dance group `Tabor', and marvel at extracts from English National Ballet's highly-acclaimed Strictly Gershwin. There's the chance to join in, too - Benny Maslov will be leading a ballroom workshop with his all of his usual flair, and Theatre Workout will be providing a specially-prepared workshop based on the latest West End hit, Top Hat. Then, as the sun sets over the Square, settle down for a screening of the 1937 film Shall We Dance? on our enormous outdoor cinema screen. You'll be dancing the whole way home!

Booking for the Big Dance Pop-Up Screen: Shall We Dance? event is free and can be done at www.thelunacinema.com/shallwedance

headline: SANDPIT AT HOLLAND PARK
prcopy:
Join in the fun for an afternoon of games designed by artists, musicians and writers for `Sandpit' on the Orangery Lawn at Holland Park this Sunday 15 July, from 2pm to 5.30pm.

The family-friendly event is free and the games are all about spectacle and movement, so expect processions, performance, frantic bolting-about for the energetic, thinking games for the cerebral and walking games for the more sedate.

The streets and public spaces of Kensington and Chelsea will provide the backdrop for a fortnight of interactive arts, drama and music during the sixth InTRANSIT Festival of Arts (13 to 27 July).

headline: DOG OWNERS URGED TO CLEAN UP
prcopy:
A campaign urging dog owners to clean up after their pets was launched on Thursday 4 July by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Council officers handed out dog pooh bags and spoke to dog owners reminding them to dispose of their dogs' mess responsibly. It is not enough to simply bag the mess and leave it on the highway - it should then be placed in bins or owners can bag it and take it home with them. More than 50 bright coloured markers were left for 48 hours in Cathcart Road, The Boltons and Westfield Park to highlight the amount of dog mess left.

New signs have gone up across the borough, with the key message `Good dog owners clean up. Bad dog owners don't! Bag it and bin it'

Dog fouling is an issue that causes residents concern. Not only is it unpleasant, and messy but it carries harmful bacteria that can cause infections and toxocariasis, which can lead to blindness. Failure to clean up dog waste carries an £80 fine and a maximum penalty of £2,500 if the case goes to court and results in a conviction.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Council, who attended the launch event and spoke to residents about the campaign and how the Council is tackling the problem through targeted enforcement work, said:

"Dog owners and walkers should not be leaving their dogs' waste for others to deal with, it is antisocial and unpleasant.

"Highlighting the problem with bright markers will hopefully bring home the message. There is no dog pooh fairy; it is up to owners and dog walkers to clean up after their dogs and not to leave bags on the pavement which is unpleasant for everyone."
shortdescription: A campaign urging dog owners to clean up after their pets was launched on Thursday 4 July by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Dog owners urged to clean up

headline: PORTOBELLO CROSSRAIL STATION THE MISSING LINK IN RENAISSANCE OF PORTOBELLO ROAD
prcopy:
World famous Portobello Road is to be extended northwards as part of a major regeneration scheme in North Kensington.

The extension is a key element in the redevelopment of the Wornington Green estate, which is being entirely rebuilt to double the number of homes. As part of that scheme, traditional street patterns that disappeared when the estate was built back in the 1960s and 70s will be reinstated.
Before the estate was built, the Portobello Road continued northwards until it connected with Ladbroke Grove. After the redevelopment it will do so again, terminating at the eastern corner of the 67-acre Kensal site which is the focus of separate, even larger regeneration ambitions.

If a Council-led campaign to bring a "Portobello" Crossrail station to the Kensal site succeeds, thousands of new homes, plus an array of new businesses and community facilities would become economically viable.

In fact, the Council is currently consulting on a range of development options for Kensal. One of the options under discussion for example, envisages a waterside style development with 3,500 homes, a reinstated canal basin and a new bridge across the rail tracks.

In a recently published report, leading economic analyst, Regeneris, estimates that a Crossrail station would create 2,000 new jobs and add £690 million to the local economy. And in an earlier report Regeneris showed there was a stronger case for a station on the Kensal site than at any other confirmed station site outside of east London, concluding that had Kensal been looked at from the outset, it would certainly have been included in the original Crossrail plans.

"Taken together, the new Wornington Green, the redevelopment of the Kensal site and the step change in transport options provided by a Portobello Station would utterly transform this large, disadvantaged neighbourhood and give a massive boost to the local and London economy ," said the Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell.

"That's the big picture and we are doing everything we can to get the Crossrail authorities to see it before it is too late."

Wornington Green developers, Catalyst Housing Ltd, are long-standing supporters of the Portobello Crossrail campaign.

"A Portobello station would make a real difference to our existing tenants and those buying into our development in terms of the quality of life and economic opportunity north and south of the Harrow Road," said Rod Cahill Catalyst's Chief Executive.

"That's why we agree that it is time to say yes to a Portobello Crossrail station."

As well as contributing to wider regeneration, the hope is that the extension of Portobello Road and a new Portobello station would together help to secure the future of Portobello and Golborne Markets. Not only will the extension to Portobello have new retail space at ground floor level it will connect with the eastern end of the Kensal development site on which the station would be built. That station would be capable of delivering new day trippers from the east and west of the Capital and eventually from the Midlands once HS2 is complete.
shortdescription: World famous Portobello Road is to be extended northwards as part of a major regeneration scheme in North Kensington.
shorttitle: Portobello Crossrail station the missing link in renaissance of Portobello Road

headline: MAYOR AND CHELSEA PENSIONERS WELCOME OLYMPIC TORCH
prcopy:
The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster, will welcome the Olympic torch to the borough after it crosses Chelsea Bridge on Thursday 26 July.

Cllr Buckmaster will be accompanied by the Mayoress, Mrs Anne Hobson, Baroness Hanham and a group of Chelsea Pensioners, some of the borough's most recognisable and venerable residents who live in the nearby Royal Hospital Chelsea.

The torch is expected to arrive in the borough, via Chelsea Bridge, at approximately 1.20pm before moving up Chelsea Bridge Road towards the Royal Hospital Chelsea.

The Mayor said: "I will be delighted to welcome the Olympic torch to the borough on behalf of the residents of Kensington and Chelsea. The torch is creating a great deal of excitement as it makes its way around the country and I am sure that it will receive a marvellous welcome as it passes through the borough.

"From the moment it is greeted by our Chelsea Pensioners all associated with the torch will know they are in a very special borough and this will be confirmed when the torch enters Holland Park later in the day to the sounds of some magnificent singing courtesy of Opera Holland Park and a community choir."

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH ON SONG TO WELCOME OLYMPIC TORCH
prcopy:
The Olympic torch will be welcomed into Holland Park on Thursday 26 July with a choral fanfare provided by the performers of Opera Holland Park, a choir of 150 amateur and professional singers all accompanied by the City of London Sinfonia.

The build-up to the torch's entrance promises to be great fun. Opera Holland Park will give members of the public a chance to become a `one minute maestro' when anyone can take the opportunity to briefly conduct the orchestra.

Budding Simon Rattles can pick up the baton and see what it's like to put the orchestra through its paces while it plays the overture to Rossini's William Tell, Mozart's overture to the Marriage of Figaro or the high paced thrills of Offenbach's Orpheus in the Underworld, probably better known as the can-can.

The professional performers will also show off their vocal range with some stirring solos including the flower duet from Lakme by Delibes, Nessun Dorma from Turendot by Puccini, Torreador from Carmen by Bizet and O donna e mobile from Rigoletto by Verdi.

There will also be full chorus excerpts including Jerusalem by Parry and the Hallelujah Chorus from Messiah by Handel.

In addition to this musical feast there will be a whole host of sporting activities taking place in the park.

From 10am right up until the torch arrives, people can have a go at a `come and try' sports day for all the family. National sporting organisations will be doing demonstrations and running a range of sporting-related activities. Local organisations will be providing information on sports activities and ways to get involved.

End

headline: TRADERS FLOCK TO TEST THEIR WARES ON PORTOBELLO AND GOLBORNE MARKETS
prcopy:
A promotion by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to encourage people to try their hand at market trading on Portobello and Golborne Markets attracted 57 new traders during National Love Your Markets fortnight.

The traders did business at over 100 sites between 23 June and 7 July with some using the opportunity to trade for two or three days so they could market test their products.

The sites were available from the Council for just £10 a day and attracted people selling a wide range of products which included home wares, men's and women's fashion, homemade cosmetics, children's clothes, gourmet cookies and sauces and marinades.

For some, like Patsy Adjei and her friends Nancy Nettey, Mimi Boateng and Miranda Nettey-Adjei, it was an opportunity to market test the interest in their brightly coloured African print fashion, home ware and jewellery which they sell under their own brand `Afrique Chique'.

Patsy explained: "We had been collecting items for over two years but had not taken it further. But I decided to take action when I was at church and my preacher said that ideas will just stay ideas unless you turn them into action. This struck a chord so I went home and took action and started researching how we could sell our goods and found out about the taster stalls and booked one.

"The reaction on the first day from both visitors and other market traders was so positive we booked another two days on Golborne Market and are applying for a regular trading licence."

Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, said: "The aim of the initiative was to give people who had ideas about what they would like to sell an opportunity market test their ideas. I am delighted that many who traded for one day came back and took stalls for additional days and some are applying for regular licences.

"Our markets are known throughout the world for their character and vibrancy and attracting new traders will help maintain this tradition."

Two young entrepreneurs who each won trading pitches for six months rent free and £1,000 in start up funds in a competition run by the Council, in conjunction with the Prince's Trust and John Lyon's Charity, also started trading during the fortnight.

Emily Ellen Dell who produces art and craftworks under the label `Girl on a swing' and men's fashion designer Jo Hawtree launched their businesses at the revamped Portobello Square to music, song and a fashion show winning applause from an audience which included the Leader of the Council, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell and other Councillors with an interest in Portobello.

shorttitle: Traders flock to test their wares on Portobello and Golborne Markets

headline: MOD DECLARES LAW ON HOARDING
prcopy:
The Ministry of Defence (MOD) has given the green light to legal action by the Council against an unsightly hoarding at 206 Brompton Road.

Residents are angry that a large illuminated advertising hoarding was put up last year without consent

Following initial discussions with the Council the MOD indicated that it would have the advertisement and supporting structure removed but, to date, it has remained in place and is still in use.

As it is Crown Estate land the Council has no powers to remove the hoarding or to insist that it needs planning consent. The only avenue open was to persuade officials at the MOD of the impact the hoarding is having locally and to appeal to them to consider the views of residents.

The MOD has now agreed that action can be taken against the company that controls the hoarding, King Media Limited, under section 296A(2) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

Cllr Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Planning, said: "This hoarding is an eyesore and has annoyed residents and frustrated our planners. I am grateful the MOD has given permission for us to take action and I hope that we will be able to have the hoarding brought down in the near future."
shortdescription: The Ministry of Defence (MOD) has given the green light to legal action by the Council against an unsightly hoarding at 206 Brompton Road.
shorttitle: MOD declares law on hoarding

headline: MUTUAL YOUTH
prcopy:
The Youth Service will leave the Council to become an independent body, the Royal Borough's Cabinet agreed last night (19 July 2012).

Starting in April 2013, the service will become an "employee-led mutual (ELM)" with its 175 staff owning shares in the company and having a say in its management.

Operating four youth centres itself and working out of several others run by the voluntary sector, the Service also works directly with the community. Amongst other roles, it provides guidance and support for 13 to 19 year olds and particularly those in difficulty. That guidance and support takes many forms including intensive one-to-one work, music, sport, education and experiencing the great outdoors.

The Service is a recognised leader in the field and its new mutual status will free it to provide services to others.

"We have built the service up over many years so that it is the best in London," said Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, Cllr Elizabeth Campbell. "But everyone understands the national financial situation. Rather than see the team stifled by year-on-year cuts, we have decided to free it so that it can trade its undoubted skill and experience to others. We hope there will be a bright future for the Youth Service ELM."

As well as continuing to provide services to Kensington and Chelsea, the ELM will market itself to other bodies, something it is already doing with some success. It has won contracts with Hammersmith & Fulham, a London Primary Care Trust and a number of schools.
shortdescription: The Youth Service will leave the Council to become an independent body, the Royal Borough's Cabinet agreed last night (19 July 2012).
shorttitle: Mutual Youth

headline: MAYOR GREETS WINNER OF HISTORIC THAMES BOAT RACE
prcopy:
Five competitors fought fiercely for Doggett's Coat and Badge last Friday, in a boat race that has been taking place on the River Thames each year since 1715. This year's victor was Merlin Dwan of the London Rowing Club in a time of 24 minutes and 28 seconds.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Christopher Buckmaster, greeted the competitors at the end of the four miles and seven furlongs course that stretches from London Bridge to Cadogan Pier in Chelsea.

Mysteriously, this annual event passes largely unnoticed, despite the thrilling races it often provides and its impressive longevity; the Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race is a mere whippersnapper in comparison, starting in only 1829.

Thomas Doggett was an Irish actor and comedian who came to London around the year 1690. After playing many parts at Drury Lane he became its manager.

The Watermen of the Thames, who were much more numerous than they are today, were then the equivalent of the modern taxi driver. They were licensed to row passengers along and across the River Thames. No doubt Doggett relied heavily on their services. A staunch Whig, opposed to any restoration of the Stuarts, he funded the race to commemorate the first anniversary of the accession of the Hanoverian George I.

Thomas Doggett himself organised the race until his death in 1721. In his will, he instructed his executors to endow the race, which was to be managed by Mr Edward Burt of the Admiralty Office. Mr Burt was apparently unwilling to assume the burden laid upon him by Doggett and it was arranged that the executors should pay over to the Worshipful Company of Fishmongers the sum of £300 and that the Company, which added £50 to the fund, should henceforth carry out Doggett's wishes.

The Fishmongers' Company has faithfully complied with their undertaking ever since, despite the not inconsiderable rise in costs since 1721.
shortdescription: Five competitors fought fiercely for Doggett's Coat and Badge last Friday, in a boat race that has been taking place on the River Thames each year since 1715.  This year's victor was Merlin Dwan of the London Rowing Club in a time of 24 minutes and 28 seconds.
shorttitle: Mayor greets winner of historic Thames boatrace

headline: ANNUAL JOBS FAIR CONTINUES TO DELIVER
prcopy:
Over 600 people were given the chance to find out about job opportunities, apprenticeships and ways to impress potential employers when they attended the annual Jobs, Advice and Training Fair on Wednesday 18 July at the Ilec Conference Centre.

The event, organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, in association with Jobcentre Plus and Hammersmith & Fulham council, attracted 628 visitors.

There were a variety of workshops providing invaluable advice on effective CVs and interview skills, working in hospitality, setting up your own business and applying for voluntary work. Jobcentre Plus staff were also on hand to support those searching for work. Among the diverse range of stalls at the fair were IT company Agilisys, the Royal Garden Hotel, the Prince's Trust and the London Fire Brigade.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "This event has once again proved to be beneficial for residents. The aim was to provide support for those struggling to find employment and assist them in targeting jobs which they may not know are out there. The workshops were informative and the wide range of stalls offering opportunities in so many different sectors was eye-opening".

Brent Sayder, a recent graduate said "it has been a great chance to gain advice, which I did not have at university, on how to adjust my CV when applying for specific jobs. To hear from the employers about what they expect from potential employees was invaluable".
shortdescription: Over 600 people were given the chance to find out about job opportunities, apprenticeships and ways to impress potential employers when they attended the annual Jobs, Advice and Training Fair on Wednesday 18 July at the Ilec Conference Centre.
shorttitle: Annual jobs fair continues to deliver

headline: CHORAL FANFARE WELCOMES OLYMPIC FLAME
prcopy:
Olympic fever hit the streets of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea today (Thursday 26 July) as huge crowds lined the route to cheer on the Olympic Torch.

As the torch entered the borough it was welcomed by the Mayor, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster and representatives of some of Chelsea's most famous residents, the Chelsea Pensioners.

Famous fictional characters got their chance to join in the celebration when Patsy Stone and Edina Monsoon from Absolutely Fabulous better known as Joanna Lumley and Jennifer Saunders took the torch from Duke of York Square and carried it along the King's Road.

A community event in Holland Park was the main focus of the torch's stay in the borough which saw arts and sports combine into a fantastic celebration of culture and sporting endeavour.

Opera Holland Park led the way in welcoming the torch with an exciting programme of operatic classics supported by a community choir and the City of London Sinfonia. Members of the public joined in and even took turns in conducting the orchestra!

On the nearby sports field people had a chance to try out a whole range of Olympic sports including hockey, judo, volleyball and badminton.

The Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, said: "This was a fantastic welcome for the Olympic Torch. The sun shone, the opera and choir were in great voice and there was a chance to try out some Olympic sports.

"Our residents and visitors lined the streets across the borough and I am sure that this will have been a wonderful experience for the torch bearers and one that they will never forget."
shortdescription: Olympic fever hit the streets of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea today (Thursday 26 July) as huge crowds lined the route to cheer on the Olympic Torch.
shorttitle: Choral fanfare welcomes Olympic flame

prcopy:

headline: INVESTING IN CIVIL SOCIETY
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is making an extra £739,000 available to the voluntary sector over the next three years, despite the dramatic decline in its own financial position.

Agreed by Cabinet in June 2012, the extra money will boost to £1.5 million the pot available to voluntary groups for innovation.

Bids for the cash have to be in by 5 October and to succeed bidders will need to show how they are offering a new service, reaching a new client group or that they are a new group, not currently receiving a grant.

In particular the Council will be looking for proposals that address its own priorities of tackling social isolation, supporting people into work and training and encouraging greater neighbourliness, civic participation, and self-help.

Critically important for bidders will be to convince the Council that they have a business plan that can make them financially sustainable and less reliant on public-sector grants in the years ahead.

"There is every likelihood that Council funding will be even further reduced over the next few years," said Cabinet Member for Civil Society, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen. "Therefore, we are making this extra effort now to enable the local voluntary and charitable sector to find innovative ways to become more efficient and self-funding in the future.

"We have long supported voluntary sector organisations because we believe they are a fundamental part of a strong and healthy community. But we think they can play an even more important role in tough financial times as the state is able to do less, and that is why we are investing even more into the sector now."

For more information contact www.rbkc.gov.uk/communityfunding

or call the Community Engagement Team on 020 7598 4633 or email communityengagement@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is making an extra £739,000 available to the voluntary sector over the next three years, despite the dramatic decline in its own financial position.
shorttitle: Investing in civil society

headline: PLANS FOR A NEW CHILDREN'S HOME IN NORTH KENSINGTON
prcopy:
Plans are taking shape for a new state of the art children's home in North Kensington and residents will soon be able to have their say on the plans.

The £2m home at East Row, on the corner of Emslie Horniman Pleasance, was agreed in principle by the Royal Borough's Cabinet back in November 2011. The idea is that it will reflect the very latest and best practice. In particular there would be greatly improved internal and external space for social and recreational use.

However, to achieve planning permission, the Council must first satisfy stringent planning standards and keep local people informed about and involved in the development of the scheme.

That will involve plans being published on the Council's website at www.rbkc.gov.uk/eastrow and at least one public exhibition, which has already been scheduled for Thursday 20 September at the nearby St. Mary's Roman Catholic Primary School. In the meantime local residents can email ERCH@rbkc.gov.uk if they have any concerns or questions.

If the new home is built, the present home at Whistler Walk, World's End Estate, will close. As a home, Whistler Walk has long been praised by inspectors for its exceptional standards of care. As a building however, it leaves much to be desired. Built in the 1970s, the internal layout feels institutional and doesn't easily lend itself to the creation of a homely, family atmosphere. This fundamental problem cannot be addressed by a refurbishment.

"We look after our children very well in the Royal Borough and they feel safe and secure and do well in exams," said Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Children Services. "This new home will help us maintain that tradition. It will be a house rather a part of an estate, it will be next to the park, and near a fine new academy we are building."

East Row will be a nine bedroom house divided into five bedrooms and four individual bedsits, standing on the site of the disused lodge next to Emslie Horniman Pleasance. This parcel land is situated between the multi use games area and Voysey Gardens.
shortdescription: Plans are taking shape for a new state of the art children's home in North Kensington and residents will soon be able to have their say on the plans.
shorttitle: Plans for a new Children's Home in North Kensington

headline: DRAMATIC MAKEOVER FOR NORLAND ROAD
prcopy:
A pedestrianised part of Norland Road is to have a dramatic makeover to improve its appearance and protect it from illegal traffic.

Transferred to the Council's ownership from Hammersmith & Fulham as a result of boundary changes in 1996, the section of Norland Road south of Queensdale Road has been closed to vehicles since 1983.

But the bollards restricting access have repeatedly been removed so that cars can illegally enter in search of parking spaces. And since the opening of the nearby Westfield shopping centre, the problem has worsened. When the bollards have been removed, vehicles create a hazard in what is supposed to be a peaceful residential haven where children can play. And they also regularly damage the paving.

However, while Westfield has led to more cars, it has also sharply increased the number of pedestrians, meaning that far more people will enjoy the new Norland Road about to be created.

The proposal is to introduce robust, new vehicle barriers as part of a wider renovation scheme that will include new street lighting, trees and granite paving that will transform the streetscape.

"Norland Road is a haven for local people but also a minor gateway to North Kensington," said Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Council.

"I'm delighted to be giving the green light to a scheme that will serve both functions, keeping illegal parkers out and providing a beautiful street for pedestrians to pass through on their way to Westfield or north to Portobello."

The scheme will cost £635,000, of which £485,000 is coming from TfL's allocation to the Council for transport improvements, the remainder from the Council's own Streetscape budget.
shortdescription: A pedestrianised part of Norland Road is to have a dramatic makeover to improve its appearance and protect it from illegal traffic.
shorttitle: Dramtic makeover for Norland Road

headline: SUMMER IN THE CITY KAYAKING FUN
prcopy:
If Team GB's kayak teams have inspired you but you don't feel you're quite ready for the challenge of white water slalom, why not give the sport a try on the more calm waters of the Grand Union Canal.

This summer children and young people aged from nine to 19 can take up a paddle and enjoy supervised canoeing and kayaking classes at the Canalside Activity Centre.
