headline: GOLD AWARD WINNER MEETS THE DUKE OF EDINBURGH
prcopy:
A young mum from Chelsea, Harmony Vasadidi-Ladi addressed over 250 guests, including HRH the Duke of Edinburgh, at an anniversary dinner at Windsor Castle about her experiences and challenges undertaking her Duke of Edinburgh Gold Award. Harmony who, with four other young mothers from the borough, raised over £18,000 to fund their Duke of Edinburgh Award Gold expedition to Holland.

Harmony along with Emily Mailes, Laura Pham, Rennice Mitchell and Hayley Anglim were the first young mums to complete their Gold Exhibition with their children in tow, quite literally, as they cycled around Holland.

Speaking after the diner Harmony said, "Going to Windsor Castle, meeting the Duke of Edinburgh and talking in front of all the guests was one of the best experiences of my life."

headline: MARKETS PROVIDE GAMES RELIEF

headline: CHECK OUT YOUR FAVOURITE RESTAURANT'S HYGIENE SCORE
prcopy:
Customers visiting food outlets in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are being encouraged to check out premises' hygiene ratings on the Food Standards Agency website www.food.gov.uk/ratings

The Council's Environmental Health Officers inspect all restaurants, takeaways and pubs in the borough to check that their hygiene standards meet the legal requirements. They are then rated on a scale ranging from 0 at the bottom, which means `urgent improvement necessary', to a top rating of 5 which means `very good'.

The ratings are intended to give consumers a glimpse of what is going on in the kitchen when they eat out, or behind the scenes at the places they shop, so decide about which place they prefer to visit.

After the inspection all businesses are given a sticker and certificate and encouraged to display it prominently at the entrance.

Mrs Fiona Gooley from W8 Catering in Abdingdon Road, Kensington which received a top rating after it was recently inspected said: `We are delighted to achieve a 5 out of 5 rating, it is nice to know that food businesses such as us receive recognition for our efforts. We hope it will lead to increased customers who will choose W8 with confidence and provide an incentive for other food businesses to improve their standards in turn.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "This is a very useful scheme which allows residents to make informed decisions about which restaurants they visit or which food outlets they choose to shop at. The ratings are based on findings of inspections by the Council's Environmental Health Officers who will often make surprise visits so they can to get a proper view of what goes on in the kitchens and back rooms. It also helps officers in their work as it highlights premises which need attention."

headline: NINE DAYS OF WONDER: EXHIBITION ROAD SHOW DRAWS TO A CLOSE
prcopy:
Exhibition Road Show, commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to celebrate the Olympics in London, ended in spectacular fashion on Sunday, with a 120-piece marching band and the Mike Westbrook Band's `Off Abbey Road' playing the event out. Over nine days 60,000 visitors witnessed unforgettable culture, science and entertainment. Everyone came together to celebrate London's Olympic Games on Exhibition Road through music, dance, acrobatics, art, science and literature.

Road Show was conceived by the Royal Borough as a celebration of the Olympic Games on London's most elegant road, and the event highlighted the openness and accessibility of the space.

The Exhibitionists, the event's resident troupe of young dancers and circus performers, proved a popular draw. Whether suspended by a harness from the front of Imperial College, striking a breathtaking pose on the balcony of the V&A, or in perfect formation on the road, the Exhibitionists brought a unique excitement and energy to the programme.

Inspired by an international music programme spanning classical, contemporary, pop and folk music, visitors danced on Exhibition Road, swinging to the retro sounds of GI Jive, silently moving to the bass-heavy Kidnap Kid & Woz, and following the beat of Ebony Steelband. Hotly tipped Sam Lee played his unique brand of folk music, while rising star Josephine Oniyama proved once again that she's a massive British talent. There was also a memorable moment when a 17-year old busker was given an impromptu spot on the main stage, to a rapturous reception. Simon Fisher Turner's newly commissioned score for Herbert Ponting's `The Great White Silence' also provided a special moment as the classic film accompanied by the live score was projected onto the side of the Natural History Museum.

Science in all its diversity was explored through workshops, a handmade particle accelerator and guided tours of the Science Museum.

Road Show's three visual art commissions investigated unique aspects of the natural world; from Katie Paterson's `Campo del Cielo, Field of the Sky', a 4.5 billion year old meteorite outside the Royal Geographic Society to a bird's eye commentary from high up in the V&A provided by Graeme Miller's `On Air', to Tomas Libertiny's `The Agreement', an intricate, living sculpture made by bees.

Visitors to Road Show found much to engage them: vintage games re-imagined with `Games for the Games'; some very special readings from `Road Stories', including a reading of Russell Hoban's last story by his son Jake; and a delicious array of food from the street traders' collective Eat St.

Cllr Warwick Lightfoot, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member responsible for 2012, said:

"I'm pleased with the success of Exhibition Road Show. It demonstrates the creative and scientific expertise of Kensington and Chelsea. From workshops that explored patterning in the natural world to Irish dancing in the road,
Exhibition Road Show had something to entertain, stimulate and delight everyone. 98 per cent of the visitors to the event who were surveyed told us that they thought that Road Show was good, very good or excellent. That's a lot of people taking home good memories of the Royal Borough. Exhibition Road Show certainly helped contribute to London's Cultural Olympiad."
shortdescription: Exhibition Road Show, commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to celebrate the Olympics in London, ended in spectacular fashion on Sunday, with a 120-piece marching band and the Mike Westbrook Band's `Off Abbey Road' playing the event out. Over nine days 60,000 visitors witnessed unforgettable culture, science and entertainment. Everyone came together to celebrate London's Olympic Games on Exhibition Road through music, dance, acrobatics, art, science and literature.
shorttitle: Nine days of wonder: Exhibition Road Show draws to a close

headline: TRANSPORT AND TRAVEL ADVICE DURING THE PARALYMPIC GAMES
prcopy:
With Sunday's closing ceremony bringing the Olympic Games to an end, there is now a break in which to enjoy the build up to the opening of the Paralympic Games on Wednesday 29 August. The Paralympics then run until Sunday 9 September. Although smaller in scale than the Olympic Games, the roads and public transport across London will still be much busier than normal for the duration of the Paralympics, plus most London schools will have returned from their summer break by this time.

During the break between the Olympics and Paralympics, some traffic measures will remain in place, but many restrictions will be lifted until a few days before the start of the Paralympics, when a Paralympic Route Network (PRN) will be introduced. Just like the ORN, the PRN connects the venues, accommodation and transport hubs across London. In Kensington and Chelsea, the A4 forms part of the PRN and there will be temporary traffic changes in place on this route, including the use of Games Lanes.

All changes when in operation will be clearly signposted on the route.

For further details about the PRN, including an overview map of the PRN in London and an interactive tool to find details about road changes in specific locations, visit the Paralympic Route Network page on www.GetAheadoftheGames.com

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea said: "London's public transport system and road network operated well during the Olympic Games because people planned their journeys to avoid hotspots and busy times.

"I would urge residents and businesses to plan again for the Paralympic Games which, while smaller in scale than the Olympic Games, are taking place when schools are open again."

TfL's advice to motorists during the Paralympic Games is:

Plan your travel during the Paralympic Games and, if necessary, allow more time for your journey.

Avoid driving around the PRN routes and venues, particularly around the Olympic Park in Stratford and on the A102 approach roads north and south of the Blackwall Tunnel.

Roads into and around the City of London will be busier than usual, so plan your journey and allow more time.

headline: SILVER SUNDAY
prcopy:
Residents and local organisations are being asked to lend their support to a day of events to celebrate the lives of older people.

Silver Sunday will take place on Sunday October 7 and is being piloted by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council, Hammersmith & Fulham.

The day will see a variety of events held to champion the older generation and their contribution to society and all three councils are encouraging local organisations to arrange events and activities to take place on the day.

Cllr Fiona Buxton, Cabinet Member for Adult Social Care at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Silver Sunday is a great opportunity to celebrate the contribution our older residents make. We hope everyone will join in and make it an enjoyable day. There is something to suit all tastes from language classes, to getting to grips with email and the internet, to choosing from a range of exercise or dance classes."

Cllr Marcus Ginn, H&F Council Cabinet Member for Community Care, said: "Silver Sunday will be a fantastic day when we can all think a little about the wonderful contribution that older people make to the world we live in. Events held on Silver Sunday will give older people the opportunity to stay active and try new things, at the same time as meeting new people and combating loneliness."

Cllr Christabel Flight, Westminster City Council's Champion for Older People, said: "Recent figures show that alarmingly, up to a third of people over the age of 75 say they are lonely, while a quarter say they do not leave their house for days on end. Silver Sunday is a special day to celebrate older people and has been created specifically to help address this sad situation.

"I hope that local schools, churches, neighbours, friends and families will take this occasion to put on events and entertainment for older people so they can again become engaged in society and participate in their communities."

Silver Sunday also aims to improve relationships between the young and old. As part of this, all schools in the three borough's will be encouraging their pupils to make a card for their grandparents or an elderly neighbour.

Events will be publicised on the respective council's website and at www.silversunday.org.uk

If you are organising a Silver Sunday event in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea please email information@rbkc.gov.uk with details of your event and to have it included in any council publicity for the day.

headline: WOMAN GUILTY OF FALSE BENEFITS CLAIM
prcopy:
A woman who falsely claimed benefits was sentenced to ten weeks in prison, suspended for 12 months and ordered to pay £2,500 compensation at Isleworth Crown Court last week, Friday 17 August 2012.

Ms Kazia Podkowka of Ladbroke Gardens, Kensington W11 was charged with 21 counts of Dishonestly Making a False Representation under Section 111A(1)(a) of the Social Security Administration Act 1992 with regard to her claiming Housing and Council Tax Benefit.

Ms Podkowka received the benefits between 2009 and 2011, during which time she held several undisclosed bank accounts holding up to £38,000.

She pleaded not guilty, claiming that whilst she admitted her statements on benefit forms were 'incomplete' she was not dishonest in failing to disclose these accounts. She was found guilty of 19 charges on 23 July, when sentencing was adjourned until last week to allow for a pre-sentence report. This found that Podkowka was vulnerable both physically and mentally. This and her age (60) were the reasons the judge felt an immediate custodial sentence would be harsh, but that a community sentence would in her opinion be too lenient.
shortdescription: A woman who falsely claimed benefits was sentenced to ten weeks in prison, suspended for 12 months and ordered to pay £2,500 compensation at Isleworth Crown Court  last week, Friday 17 August 2012.
shorttitle: Woman guilty of false benefits claim

headline: FLASH FASHION HITS PORTOBELLO AND GOLBORNE MARKETS
prcopy:
Portobello and Golborne Road markets will be transformed into an open-air catwalk by prowling models showcasing autumn/winter 2012 menswear, womenswear, accessories and jewellery borrowed from market stalls and local shops on Saturday 22 September 2012 between 11am and 4pm.

Drawing attention to the market's longstanding place as a source of inspiration for designers like Paul Smith and Vivienne Westwood, and celebrating its role as a fashion talent incubator, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the Portobello and Golborne Management Committee (PGMC) have commissioned an event as unique and diverse as the market itself: FLASH Fashion.

Timed to coincide with London Fashion Week, FLASH Fashion will be a lively and unpredictable `flash' presentation, with models emerging from crowds of visitors to interact with traders and members of the public, and have their photographs taken by volunteer paparazzi. Among other locations, they will wander through Acklam Village Market and the Portobello Green Arcade. Photo backdrops will include the famous Blue Door from the film `Notting Hill' and the iconic Grade II* listed Trellick Tower. The models will converge on Portobello Square at 2pm to become part of live window displays reflecting the season's main fashion trends.

Items borrowed from shops and stalls will include a range of new, vintage, bespoke, second hand, upcycled, ethical, fair trade, one-off, mass-produced, British-made, and imported clothing and accessories. Real people will be cast as models, reflecting a range of body types, ages and backgrounds to reinforce the themes of diversity and inclusiveness.

The celebration will include a fashion film day at the Portobello Pop-Up Digital Microplex Cinema (program details will be announced after 6 September).

To complement the event, an online Portobello Look Photo Challenge is being organised on Facebook and Flickr (flickr.com/groups/flashfashion). The deadline for submissions is 8 September. Finalists will be announced on Saturday 15 September and their work exhibited in Portobello market during the event, with shopkeepers, stallholders and members of the public invited to vote for their favourite until 3pm. Three winners will be announced at 3.30pm and will receive prizes donated by local businesses.

FLASH Fashion's Project Coordinator is 23-year-old Ceyda Sezer of North Kensington, who is participating in the Council's Graduate Work Experience Scheme. A model herself, Ceyda has said: "conceiving and managing such a groundbreaking and ambitious event has been an incredible opportunity for me. Collaborating with the local retail community and capturing the diversity of Portobello and Golborne has been both challenging and exciting, but also seems essential for a market where fashion is so ingrained in the history and culture."

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Portobello and Golborne markets are much more than fantastic places to shop. They have a special atmosphere and spirit that reflect our community and attract visitors from across the world.

"We know that editors, photographers and models visit Portobello and Golborne Road market during London Fashion Week to get inspired, spot trends, and even do a bit of bargain hunting. I am sure that FLASH Fashion will capture the independent spirit and distinctive character of our markets perfectly."
shortdescription: Portobello and Golborne Road markets will be transformed into an open-air catwalk by prowling models showcasing autumn/winter 2012 menswear, womenswear, accessories and jewellery borrowed from market stalls and local shops on Saturday 22 September 2012 between 11am and 4pm.
shorttitle: FLASH Fashion hits Portobello and Golborne markets

headline: EXCELLENT GCSE RESULTS FOR ROYAL BOROUGH SCHOOLS
prcopy:
Pupils from Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea schools are celebrating GCSE success after the exam results were announced yesterday (Thursday 23 August).

The initial figures, which are provisional, show the borough's schools are bucking the trend and achieving higher than average results. The average for pupils gaining five plus A*to C grades including English and mathematics is 80 per cent, up from 73 per cent in 2011, compared with a national average of 58 per cent in 2011.

At Holland Park School 99 per cent of students got five or more GCSEs graded A* to C. An impressive 90 per cent of the students got five or more GCSEs grade A* to C including English and mathematics, 13 per cent up from 77 per cent in 2011. These results make the school one of the highest performing non-selective state schools in the country.

At St Thomas More Language College 93 per cent of pupils achieved five or more GCSEs graded A* to C, with 70 per cent getting five or more GCSEs grade A* to C including English and mathematics.
At Cardinal Vaughan Memorial School 92 per cent of pupils achieved five or more GCSEs graded A* to C and 89 per cent of pupils passed five or more GCSEs grade A* to C including English and mathematics, the same as last year.

At Sion Manning school 67 per cent of pupils achieved five or more GCSEs graded A* to C including English and mathematics, up from 55 per cent in 2011.

Colin Hall, Head teacher of Holland Park School, said: "We are delighted with a marvellous set of GCSE results. They are another record-breaking year for the school and represent such dedication from students and teachers. Congratulations all round".

Dr Trevor Papworth, Head teacher of St Thomas More Language College, said: "We are delighted to celebrate the continued success of our students which reflects the hard work and dedication shown by them. Let us not forget the great support they have received from their homes and the enormous contribution made by staff at St Thomas More Language College, which we thank them for."

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "These excellent results are a reward for many hours of hard work by pupils and teachers in all of our schools and I congratulate everyone concerned. I am particularly pleased to see so many of our young people passing English and mathematics. The fact that 90 per cent of students at Holland Park School achieved this feat, a substantial increase since last year, is particularly pleasing given the large scale construction project the children and staff have worked around.

"Results like this show why we are right to be so proud of our schools."
shortdescription: Pupils from Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea schools are celebrating GCSE success after the exam results were announced yesterday (Thursday 23 August).
shorttitle: Excellent GCSE results for Royal Borough pupils

headline: KAYAKERS TO CARRY PARALYMPIC TORCH
prcopy:
Two intrepid kayakers from the Cremorne Riverside Centre have been chosen to carry the Paralympic torch along Whitehall next Wednesday (29 August).

Harry Parker, a soldier who lost his legs in Afghanistan and Felix Daglish, aged 12, are both regular users of the riverside facility operated by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea that introduces people to a range of water sports on the Thames. Harry said: "Paddling out of Cremorne has been great for my rehab. A bit of adventure was missing after my injuries but kayaking now provides that. The community kayaking centre is a great facility."

Felix will be joined by his father, Simon Daglish, who set up the charity Walking with the Wounded. Walking with the Wounded funds both the retraining and re-education of wounded servicemen and women with the aim of helping them find long-term employment after they have left the Armed Forces.

Commenting on the occasion, Simon said: "Felix and I are immensely privileged and excited about carrying the torch with the wounded many of whom have taken up
paddling with Felix at Cremorne"

Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am delighted Harry, Felix and Simon have been chosen to carry the torch. I am sure the torch relay will prove inspirational and be a fine curtain raiser for the Paralympic Games."

headline: CARNIVAL CLEAN-UP 2012
prcopy:
Close to 200 tonnes of rubbish were cleared from the roads of Notting Hill following this year's Carnival.

Over 200 of the Council's contractors, SITA UK, worked into the early hours of Monday and Tuesday mornings in an operation which involved over 30 refuse trucks, mechanical sweepers and transit vans. The team also employed a large motorway vehicle to wash down the roads. The clean-up started at 10pm on Monday 27 August and finished at 3am on Tuesday 28 August.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, joined one of the refuse crews working on the Carnival clean-up.

Commenting on the scale of the task Councillor Paget-Brown, said: "This year was a bumper year for visitors to Notting Hill Carnival. With hundreds of thousands of people attending there was an extensive amount of rubbish. Our contractor, SITA UK, and Council officers worked exceptionally hard and deserve a gold medal. They ensured the streets were cleaned and returned to normal before anyone got up for work.

"Our priority is always to clear the streets as swiftly as possible to ensure minimum disruption for residents."

Commenting on the clean-up, SITA UK's Gary O'Hagan, Contract General Manager, said: "We have helped the Council clear up the streets of Kensington and Chelsea after the Carnival for over 17 years, so we are well practiced in getting the streets back to normal.

"The waste collected will be converted into electricity, saving natural resources and turning rubbish into something valuable."
shortdescription: Close to 200 tonnes of rubbish were cleared from the roads of Notting Hill following this year's Carnival.
shorttitle: Carnival clean-up 2012

headline: USERS OF MENTAL HEALTH SERVICES TACKLE FOOTBALL COMPETITION
prcopy:
A football tournament involving users of mental health services in the borough was watched by ex-England international Luther Blissett, who also presented the prizes.

The tournament, which was organised by the Oremi Centre, London Cyrenians and Smart Project featured ten teams and was part of measures designed to promote good mental health and social inclusion.

The main competition was won by Tasha Tigers and the shield tournament was won by North Kensington Rangers, who represented the Oremi Centre.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, Cabinet Member for Adult Social Care, said: "I'd like to congratulate all the players who took part in this competition and all the staff and volunteers who organised it. Getting people involved in a good game of football is just one of the ways that the Council and local voluntary groups can help improve mental health and tackle social isolation."
shortdescription: A football tournament involving users of mental health services in the borough was watched by ex-England international Luther Blissett, who also presented the prizes.

headline: RESIDENTS SOURCE DRINKNG FOUNTAIN
prcopy:
Visitors to St Luke's Gardens in Chelsea can now quench their thirst with fresh water from a smart Italian water fountain courtesy of the Sydney Street and District Residents' Association.

The Residents' Association was given a grant of £500 from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea when it achieved a Gold Standard status and decided to use the grant to buy a water fountain for the benefit of park users and promote the use of tap water rather than bottled water.

The cast iron fountain, with a brass tap, was formally unveiled by Council Leader Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell to the delight of some thirsty school children on Friday 7 September.

Finding a suitable fountain to complement the 125-year-old Grade II listed park had proved quite a challenge as most modern designs are very utilitarian and not in keeping with the area. Fortuitously association member, Kim Taylor Smith, spotted just the right design during a trip to Pisa, Italy and tracked down the manufacturer. Mr Taylor Smith explained: "The fountain was shipped to the UK and installed by the Royal Borough. It was originally painted a bright green but we gave it a coat of dark green paint in keeping with the park."

Speaking at the unveiling of the fountain Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell said: "St Luke's Gardens is a very popular park and I'm sure its visitors, especially youngsters, will be grateful that there is fresh water on tap thanks to the thoughtfulness and generosity of the Sydney Street and District Residents' Association. Using the grant in this way reflects the spirit of the Gold Standard Award which is about building community spirit through doing things that matter to people such as installing this splendid drinking fountain."

headline: GREEN ADVICE FOR BOROUGH'S BUSINESSES
prcopy:
Businesses in Kensington and Chelsea can now join organisations across five other London boroughs to receive 12 hours of free advice from qualified environmental specialists to help them reduce their costs and save money by `going green'.

The Greening Business Programme provides a dedicated business advisor who will undertake an assessment of a site to identify areas where cost savings could be made, write a bespoke action plan with a focus on low or no cost changes which can be made and then help them to implement the actions.

Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Nicholas Paget-Brown, said: "I hope as many businesses in the Royal Borough as possible avail of this free assessment and advice. Helping the environment makes economic sense, sometimes by making small changes a business can make significant savings by reducing its utility bills and cutting waste disposal costs."

Businesses participating in this project could benefit in a number of ways. For example, by adopting some simple yet effective measures, firms could reduce their energy and water consumption, therefore making financial savings through having lower utilities bills. The advisors can help to develop an effective active environmental policy which is often a prerequisite to be in a position to tender for larger commercial contracts.

Brian Albuquerque, Greening Business Programme Manager said "Quite often, small changes can make a big difference so it is great that the Greening Business programme is able to provide a much needed service to support businesses across the six London Boroughs."

The project is part funded by the European Regional Development Fund so is available free of charge for eligible businesses and the support is also available to businesses in Barking & Dagenham, Richmond, Merton, Southwark and Wandsworth.

For more information on Greening Business or to book an appointment with one of our advisors please contact Christina Parnell-Harris on 020 8944 5501 or email greeningbusiness@mccbusinesssolutions.co.uk

Businesses can also self refer to the programme via www.surveymonkey.com/s/GreeningBusiness

headline: READ THE ANNUAL REPORT TO TAXPAYERS
prcopy:
The annual `Report to Taxpayers' has been published and provides an overview of what the Council has been doing over the past year and how it has spent residents' money.

Against a background of a sustained freeze in public spending the Council has pressed on with work to protect front line services and, where possible, to improve them.

It has made substantial savings by combining some services with neighbouring Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster councils. Over £33 million will be saved by 2014-15.

The report highlights some of achievements of the last year including keeping all libraries and leisure centres open with plans well underway to transform the North Kensington Leisure Centre into one of the best in London.

Despite the tough economic circumstances 84 per cent of residents agree that the Council is doing a good job compared with a London average of 72 per cent.

Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "This report shows residents just how their money is being spent and how the Council is dealing with the challenge of providing high quality services at a time when the amount of money in the public purse is much reduced.

"It also clearly shows that despite the economic constraints we remain an ambitious borough with exciting plans for news schools, housing and leisure facilities."

The report is available on the Council's website
http://www.rbkc.gov.uk/councilanddemocracy/howthecouncilperforms/performancemanagement/reporttotaxpayers.aspx
shortdescription: The annual `Report to Taxpayers' has been published and provides an overview of what the Council has been doing over the past year and how it has spent residents' money.
shorttitle: Read the annual Report to Taxpayers

headline: PRIMARY SCHOOLS LEAD THE WAY
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea primary school pupils have achieved the best results in the country for progress in English and mathematics from Key Stage 1 (age seven) to Key Stage 2 (age 11). The results published yesterday (Thursday 20 September) by the Department for Education show that 96 per cent of pupils progressed by two national curriculum levels in English, and 94 per cent by two national curriculum levels in mathematics, when the national progress rates were 89 per cent and 87 per cent respectively.

The borough also performed well at the end of Key Stage 2 overall, where 11 year old pupils were third nationally for the percentage achieving Level 4 in English and mathematics (86 per cent compared with 80 per cent nationally), and for individual subject achievement Kensington and Chelsea was second nationally for mathematics and sixth nationally for English.

Commenting on the results Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "The borough is proud of its schools. I am pleased to learn that the progress our children make in English and mathematics between Key Stage 1 and Key Stage 2 is the best in the country as these are very important subjects and a good indicator of how effective our schools are. I would like to congratulate the pupils on their success and thank our teachers for the hard work that has made these results possible."

headline: GO AHEAD FOR MAGNIFICENT NEW ACADEMY AND LEISURE CENTRE
prcopy:
Plans for a magnificent new academy and leisure centre in North Kensington were given the go ahead last night (Wednesday 26 September) by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The new Kensington Aldridge Academy and Kensington Leisure Centre will not only provide local people with a much needed new school and state-of-the-art leisure centre, the development also includes an enhanced children's park, a much improved Lancaster Green and new homes for sale that will help fund the scheme.

In December 2011 the Council committed £40.2m of funding to the project. Together with a £17.6m contribution from the Government towards the Academy, the development represents a £57.8m investment in North Kensington.

Over the past two years the Council and the Academy's sponsor, the Aldridge Foundation, have consulted widely with the local community and their feedback and comments have been incorporated into the final designs.

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said:

"This is a landmark day for the North Kensington community and represents our ongoing commitment to investing in great facilities for our residents.

"Despite the challenging economic climate we are proud to be able to build a new academy and leisure centre which are going to make a vital contribution to local life for decades to come."

Sir Rod Aldridge, chairman of the Academy's lead sponsor The Aldridge Foundation, said:

"This is a big step towards opening a great new Academy which will deliver high standards of education for local children, building on success already achieved in neighbouring primary schools. The Kensington Aldridge Academy will be an environment where learning and entrepreneurial attitudes are valued, and will bring real benefits for its students and the local community."

The Council has chosen the Leadbitter Group to build the entire project, as they have a proven capacity to deliver first-class developments.

A phased construction programme will get underway next month with the Kensington Aldridge Academy opening in September 2014 for the first term of Year 7 pupils.

The existing Kensington Leisure Centre is expected to close on Monday 24 December. Construction of the leisure centre will run in parallel with the academy so that both new buildings can open together in 2014.


For more information visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/kalc and www.aldridgefoundation.com/kensington-academy
shortdescription: Plans for a magnificent new academy and leisure centre in North Kensington were given the go ahead last night (Wednesday 26 September) by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Go ahead for magnificent new academy and leisure centre

headline: NEW MUSIC HUB FOR WEST LONDON
prcopy:
More children will have the opportunity to develop their interest and skills in music following the launch, last night (Tuesday 25 September), of an exciting collaboration between an iconic music venue, major seat of learning, world class orchestra and three London councils.

The Royal Albert Hall, Royal College of Music and Aurora Orchestra have teamed up with the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster City councils to give all young people aged five to 18 in the boroughs the chance to sing, learn an instrument or play with other children as part of an ensemble or choir.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Children's Services at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea said: "I am delighted that we now have the Music Hub. We have been working with the world class music organisations for many years and they have helped us offer some wonderful opportunities to our children.

"The new opportunities presented by our Tri-borough working with Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster, together with Royal Albert Hall, the Royal College of Music and the Aurora Orchestra means that all our school children are now able to benefit from the chance to discover the joy of music and who knows, maybe become the next Nigel Kennedy or Ed Sheeran."

Chris Cotton, CEO of the Royal Albert Hall, commented: "It is unprecedented for a venue to be involved in strategically planning music education in schools and alongside the Royal College of Music and Aurora Orchestra we're extremely honoured to have been appointed in this role. One of our key aims as a charity, as it is with our partners, is to inspire, influence and champion the future of music in the UK and we believe we can make a real difference to the children and offer further arts education to schools in our surrounding boroughs. We look forward to developing some inspiring education programmes with our new partners."

Moira Sinclair, Executive Director of the Arts Council England, added: "The new hubs will, over time, see a significant shift in the way music education is delivered, both in and out of school. We have chosen a variety of organisations to work together in their local area. By pooling resources and developing powerful collaborations, we believe that access to inspiring music making for children and young people will be improved, more opportunities for outstanding teachers to learn from each other will be created and the range of musical experiences on offer will grow. I look forward to seeing the results."

At the launch in the Royal Albert Hall music was performed by Inspire Works, Royal College of Music Ensemble, Inner Voices and the BBC Symphony Orchestra Ensemble, demonstrating the wealth of musical talent the Hub can draw upon.

The event was attended by head teachers of the 150 schools in the three boroughs, as well as mayors, councillors and other dignitaries.

Over £171 million of funding is being invested in 122 hubs across the UK, with each being responsible for their local area.
shortdescription: More children will have the opportunity to develop their interest and skills in music following the launch, last night (Tuesday 25 September), of an exciting collaboration between an iconic music venue, major seat of learning, world class orchestra and three London councils.
shorttitle: New Music Hub for West London

headline: LOOK PHOTO CHALLENGE
prcopy:
The unique look of two of London's most fashionable markets was on display at an amateur photography contest on Saturday 22 September.

The Portobello and Golborne LOOK Photo Challenge, organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, received 59 entries each seeking to capture `the look' of North Kensington's famous Portobello and Golborne Road markets.

Judged by the stallholders, shopkeepers and shoppers: Jax Etta came first, with Henry Hales and Andy Teo coming second and third respectively.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster, who handed out the prizes, said: "Our fabulous markets don't just sell fantastic fashion, they are often at the cutting edge of inspiring new looks. I think this was perfectly captured by many of the amateur photographers who took part in this competition. I congratulate the winner Jax Etta."

The winning images will be exhibited at the Ground Floor Bar in Portobello Road until the end of October.
shortdescription: The unique look of two of London's most fashionable markets was on display at an amateur photography contest on Saturday 22 September.
shorttitle: LOOK Photo Challenge

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH TAKES GOLD
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea celebrated yesterday (Tuesday 18 September) as it gained a host of awards at the annual `London in Bloom' awards, held at Richmond Park.

Kensington and Chelsea secured Silver-Gilt in the City category. Holland Park won a Gold Award for the third year running, as well as Large Park of the year. Gold was also secured for Avondale Park, Westfield Park, Cremorne Gardens, St Luke's Gardens and Kensington Memorial Park. Gunnersbury Cemetery was again recognised, for the second consecutive year, with Large Cemetery of the Year and a Gold Award.

As well as these excellent results the borough also secured second place in the Conservation Award for its work in Little Wormwood Scrubs and third place in the Floral Display Award.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Environment and Leisure, said: "I am delighted that we have had such a good year at London in Bloom. The hard work of staff and residents throughout the year to make the borough look as good as it does has been recognised by the judges. I'd like to thank everyone who has help to maintain the high standards that the borough is known for. I would also like to thank London in Bloom for the Chairman's Award.

"It is gratifying to see how many of our parks have received a Gold Award, we are rightly proud of them and work hard to maintain and improve them every year."

The Council works closely with many groups throughout the year to ensure the borough is always at its best, among these are the Brighter Kensington and Chelsea Scheme, Kensington Gardeners Club and Chelsea Gardens Guild.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea celebrated yesterday (Tuesday 18 September) as it gained a host of awards at the annual `London in Bloom' awards, held at Richmond Park.

headline: LIGHTING UP NOTTING HILL'S SKYLINE
prcopy:
The Notting Hill evening skyline is being brightened up with a new feature thanks to the installation of an illuminated 7.5 metre high Ring Stack sculpture on the Marsh and Parsons estate agents office building on Kensington Park Road, W11.

Ring Stack, designed by Adam Barker Mill, was commissioned by the Notting Hill Gate Improvements Group (NHIG) to reflect the importance of Notting Hill as one of London's cultural hubs and capture the post-Olympic spirit of London.

The proposal received support from the Council's Public Art Panel and from local ward Councillors. The Council contributed £9,000 towards the cost of the artwork from its Section 106 public art funding and City Living, Local Life initiative, both of which helped to support the NHIG fundraising efforts.

The sculpture consists of 12 continuous 1.3m circles, stacked together. At night, a beam of electric light will be projected through the middle, creating the image of 12 circles of white light floating in the night sky.

Cabinet Member for Planning Policy Cllr Tim Ahern said: "Notting Hill is well known for its bohemian character and the Council is pleased to be able to support this unique light sculpture in a small way which, as the evenings draw in. will brighten up the area."

Tim Burke, Project Director of the Notting Hill Gate Improvements Group which organised the project, said "It's a public sculpture that exclaims: `Look! London is an artistic city and Notting Hill is not some postcard, but an innovative place to live!'

The Ring Stack is on view on the roof of Marsh & Parsons' Notting Hill office (2-6 Kensington Park Road W11) until March 2013.

headline: RESIDENTS UNLOCK ACCESS TO ONE MILLION BOOKS AS THREE BOROUGHS SHARE LIBRARY CARDS
prcopy:
Residents, workers and students in three London boroughs are set to gain access to more than a million books and a range of specialist collections as their councils launch a `One Library Card' policy.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council, and Hammersmith & Fulham Council will launch the `One Library Card' system on Wednesday 3 October.

From this date, residents can use their existing library card to borrow books and access a full range of facilities at any of the 21 libraries across the three boroughs. So for example, someone living or working in Kensington and Chelsea will then be able to use their existing Kensington and Chelsea library card to borrow books and other items from libraries in Hammersmith & Fulham or Westminster.

The move means that a one year old, living to the average life expectancy of 81, would need to read at least 26 books every day for the rest of their lives if they wanted to get through the entire Tri-borough collection.

To mark the launch of the new system, Hammersmith-based artist Gianandrea Traina has crafted a sculpture made entirely out of books to spell the number `1,000,000' in Victoria Library, reflecting the number of books which will be available to residents across the three boroughs under the new library card system.

The Tri-borough councils agreed last year to combine the management of several of their departments, including libraries, to save money and protect front line services.

Commenting on the launch of the One Library Card, Westminster City Council Leader Cllr Philippa Roe said:

"We are firmly committed to keeping our libraries open, and the launch of the One Library Card is proof that our tri-borough programme is not only helping to save money and protect our libraries, but it is dramatically improving our existing service.

"The One Library Card effectively unlocks one million books, as well as access to specialist book groups and collections, for people who live, work or study in our three boroughs. This is a huge victory for literacy in London and will revolutionise the role our libraries can play in central and west London."

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Leader, Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, added: "Through tri-borough we will continue to offer excellent library services with a strong focus on innovation and development to meet the current and future needs of our local communities. By combining senior management and working closely with our neighbours we are ensuring that our libraries will continue to thrive at a time when library services in other parts of the capital are under pressure."

The benefits of the new One Library Card do not just stop at borrowing books. Residents, workers and students in the three boroughs will now be able to do all of the following:

 Borrow books, DVDs, CDs and games from any tri-borough library
 Use computers at any library across the three boroughs (there are a total of 470 PCs available for public use)
 Use study facilities in any library
 Benefit from better opening hours - for example, nine libraries open on a Sunday across the three boroughs
 Attend events at any library, including events for babies and children
 Join reading groups or other activity groups at any library
 Access specialist collections across the three boroughs, including some rare items and items of national significance. Collections include the music collection at Victoria Library, fashion collection at Chelsea Library, art and design collection at Westminster Reference Library and a collection of fine art books at Fulham Library.

The One Library Card is the latest way in which the Tri-borough arrangement between Westminster, Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham is making library services better for residents and offering greater value for council tax payers' money. The innovative programme, which also involves combining management between the councils' children's services, adult social care and pensions and treasury departments, is on track to save £40m a year across the three authorities by 2015/16, enabling the boroughs to keep important services like libraries open for residents.

H&F Council Leader Cllr Nicholas Botterill said: "This `library passport' means that lucky West London residents can now access more free books than they could ever have dreamt of.

"Libraries are a gateway to a world of knowledge, excitement and inspiration. In an age when so many local authorities are lazily closing their branches, we are proving that by thinking innovatively, it is possible to save millions of pounds of taxpayer's money and actually enhance the services our residents receive!"

shortdescription: Residents, workers and students in three London boroughs are set to gain access to more than a million books and a range of specialist collections as their councils launch a `One Library Card' policy.
shorttitle: Residents unlock access to one million books as three boroughs share library cards

headline: HAVE YOUR SAY ON NHS REORGANISATION
prcopy:
A major reorganisation of the NHS in north-west London is planned and the Council is asking residents to make sure they have their say on proposals.

NHS North West London has prepared a consultation document `Shaping a healthier future' which outlines options for the five major hospitals in north-west London.

On Tuesday 11 September the Health, Environmental Health and Adult Social Care Scrutiny Committee hosted a Special Public Meeting on `Shaping a healthier future in North West London' at Kensington Town Hall. More than 150 people attended.

The proposals have been assessed by the Council which favours Option A (Major Acute Hospitals at: Chelsea and Westminster, Hillingdon Hospital, Northwick Park, St Mary's and West Middlesex). However, there are a number of concerns for which the Council has asked for reassurance:

 That all NHS and Foundation Trusts in north-west London post-implementation of the proposals are financially robust.
 That the new system will have sufficient capacity to provide services to what is likely to be a growing and ageing population. This relates to reduction in bed numbers especially but also to out of hospital provision.
 It would like external reassurance that Chelsea and Westminster and St Mary's have the capacity to meet increased demand from A&E closures at other hospitals
 If the A&E department was to close at Charing Cross the Council wants to be reassured that there are satisfactory plans for the future use of the Charing Cross site and relocation of specialties currently interdependent with the A&E Service.
 It is concerned at the poor quality of buildings at St Mary's so would like to see the detail on the plans to build capacity there
 That there were robust plans in place to stop bed blocking and delayed discharge. It is recognised that this Council needs to contribute towards this.
 That out of hospital recommendations made by the Council are addressed by NHS NWL.
 On the timings for the delivery of the programme. The Council has asked what are the triggers for making changes to the plans if things are not working out as expected?

Cllr Fiona Buxton, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Adult Social Care, said: "We have looked at the options outlined in the consultation document in great depth. The Chelsea and Westminster Foundation Trust has a modern hospital building which achieves excellent clinical outcomes on the Fulham Road. It should continue to provide a full Accident and Emergency Service.

"There are still a number of areas of concern for which we are seeking assurances. Amongst these are that all NHS and Foundation Trusts in north-west London should be financially robust after implementation of the proposals and that the new system will have sufficient capacity to provide services to what is likely to be a growing and ageing population. This relates to reduction in bed numbers especially but also to out of hospital provision."

Cllr Mary Weale, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Chairman of the Health, Environmental Health and Adult Social Care Scrutiny Committee, said: "I was very pleased that so many local people attended the public meeting to examine these important proposals. We have decided that Option A is our favoured proposal but it is very important that as many people as possible have their say on the future of major hospitals in the area. This is why I would encourage people to study this document and send their comments to NHS North West London."

For more information on the consultation go to: www.healthiernorthwestlondon.nhs.uk/contact-us

Comments can be sent by 8 October to: consultation@nw.london.nhs.uk
shortdescription: A major reorganisation of the NHS in north-west London is planned and the Council is asking residents to make sure they have their say on proposals.
shorttitle: Have your say on NHS reorganisation

headline: CALLING FOR NOMINATIONS
prcopy:
London's summer of 2012 will be long remembered for the festivities that accompanied the Queen's Diamond Jubilee and the fantastic Olympic and Paralympic Games.

At the heart of these inspiring events were the volunteers who gave their time and expertise to welcome visitors from all over the world to London and the Royal Borough.

It is widely acknowledged that all those who volunteered made a magnificent and defining contribution to the summer's events.

The Mayor and Deputy Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea plan to show their appreciation to the volunteers with a reception at the Mayor's Parlour, Kensington Town Hall on Wednesday 7 November.

If you know of someone who helped make this summer so memorable for fellow residents and visitors we want to know. You can nominate a volunteer to attend the reception by contacting the Mayor's Office on mayor@rbkc.gov.uk or 020 7361 3659.

So whether it's a person who helped to organise a street party to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee or a hardworking London 2012 Games Maker or Ambassador from the borough, the Mayor and Deputy Mayor want to say thank you.

I think that their efforts made this summer a very special one and it is right that we should thank them for all their hard work and good humour."

headline: NOUR FESTIVAL SHINES A LIGHT ON ARABIC CULTURE
prcopy:
Some of London's best know institutions including the V&A and Science Museum have joined forces with the Royal Borough in Kensington and Chelsea to deliver the two month long Nour Festival of Arts to show case Middle Eastern and North African art and culture.

Nour was created by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea at Leighton House Museum and has expanded this year to include the V&A, Science Museum the Muslim Cultural Heritage Centre, the Ciné Lumière, The Tabernacle and the Mosaic Rooms.

Speaking at the launch at the V&A (Monday 1 October 2012) the Royal Borough's Deputy Leader, Councillor Nicholas Paget-Brown, said: "In just two years the borough's Nour Festival has grown into one of the most important festivals exploring Middle Eastern arts and culture in the UK. Not only is it part of our commitment to bringing international cultural excellence to the borough, but it also fosters closer ties and understanding with this part of the world and our Arabic speaking communities in the area.

"The involvement of the V&A, Science Museum and other leading venues is a testament to the quality of success of the Festival to date. With their involvement we can reach new audiences and explore new avenues into the region, its cultures and art forms."

A feature of Nour 2012 is the organisers' call to cultural organisations, big and small, across Kensington and Chelsea to get involved with events that:

reflect and celebrate the arts and culture of contemporary Middle Eastern and North African regions

promote film, literature, music, visual arts, fashion, dance, cuisine

demonstrate artistic excellence and work that is thought-provoking and challenging

Nour Festival 2012 includes:

British Palestinian author Selma Dabbagh as festival Writer-in-Residence. Known most recently for her acclaimed novel Out of It, Selma will deliver a series of workshops on writing and publishing on the following dates.

A programme of major concerts at The Tabernacle, Notting Hill, including local musician and composer Reem Kelani, Tunisian singer-songwriter Amel Mathlouthi, and Lebanese musician Charbel Rouhana.

Leighton House Museum will host a ground-breaking exhibition of work by photo-journalist Bradley Secker highlighting the often forgotten plight of gay and lesbian refugees from the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region.

headline: MAYOR LAUNCHES MAGIC WAND APPEAL TO HELP BRAIN TUMOUR RESEARCH
prcopy:
The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster, has pledged to use his Mayor's Charitable Appeal to raise funds for the Brain Tumour Research Campaign and buy a £250,000 Sonowand, a vital piece of neurosurgery equipment, for Imperial College's Charing Cross Hospital.

Brain tumours cause more deaths in children and adults under 40 than any other cancer in the United Kingdom and are on the increase by over two per cent a year but less than two per cent of national cancer research funds go to brain tumour research. It has the lowest survival rate of all cancers.

Speaking at the launch of the Mayor's Annual Charitable Appeal, 'The Magic Wand Appeal', on Thursday 11 October at Kensington Town Hall, Cllr Buckmaster said: "I aim to increase public awareness of the desperate need for more funding and to raise funds for research at Imperial College's Charing Cross Hospital, ultimately to create there an International Centre of Excellence in Brain Tumour Research. All donations or funds raised by my appeal will go directly to the research.

"The specific aim of my appeal is to purchase a new and revolutionary surgical tool called the Sonowand: a state of the art neuro navigational system that converts pre-operative MRI scans into a virtual reconstruction of the brain, enabling surgeons to operate more accurately."

Consultant neurosurgeon and chairman of the Brain Tumour Research Campaign, Mr Kevin O'Neill, said that statistics proved patient survival and outcomes are better if Sonowand equipment is available during surgery.

Imperial College's Charing Cross Hospital is one of only two units in the country with a Sonowand. It treats over 300 tumour cases per year but demand is growing. Recent estimates from the National Cancer Intelligence Network indicate that approximately 840 Londoners are diagnosed with a brain, central nervous system or intracranial tumour each year and currently over 2,500 people are treated in London hospitals for tumours relating to the brain or central nervous system.

The Mayor's Christmas Carol Concert on Thursday 6 December is one of a series of events planned to raise funds for the Sonowand and Brian Tumour Research Campaign.

If you would like to donate to the Mayor's Appeal or book tickets for the Carol Concert email mayor@rbck.gov.uk or phone 020 73612431 or 020 73613659

headline: MAGNIFICENT NEW HOLLAND PARK SCHOOL BUILDING COMPLETED
prcopy:
Holland Park School, one of the country's first and most famous comprehensive schools, is moving into a magnificent new building.

Work on the £80 million project finished in October 2012. The new six storey building is divided into two distinct halves, separated by a central atrium stretching the full length of the building and linked by a series of walkways on each level.

Key features include:
 large, well designed classrooms
 modern Information and Communication Technology (ICT)
 full disabled access
 excellent informal spaces for social interaction
 a learning resource centre
 significantly improved facilities for the sixth form
 high quality dance, drama, arts, science and technology facilities
 improved opportunities for community
 a more secure learning environment

Specifically on sport and play there is:
 a 25m swimming pool
 a four court sports hall
 a fitness suite
 a synthetic turf all-weather sports pitch
 retention of the existing tennis courts
 a four tennis court-sized multi-use games area (`MUGA')
 improved landscaping across the site
 sports lighting
 informal covered play/teaching areas in addition to informal, social and habitat areas

This replaces the 1950s buildings which were dispersed across what by central London standards was an unusually large site.

It was realised that by consolidating all school activity into a single, large building on the northern part of the site, the land to the south could be released for sale to help meet the cost of the new school. And this being Kensington and Chelsea, the land values were such that there was a good chance the sale might pay for the school outright.

Though the new Holland Park is now on a smaller site, in every other way it is larger than its predecessor.

As described above, the school was on a large site but because of the configuration of the buildings and landscaping, much of that space wasn't suitable for sports or even just informal play.

Outdoor pitches at the school took the form of a tarmac area where falls could easily result in injury.

The new school will not only provide an increase in the amount of space for formal and informal games, that space will also be of greatly superior quality and of far more benefit to future students.

Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Holland Park is already an outstanding school with good discipline and excellent exam results. Now it has some of the best facilities anywhere in the state sector too. It's a proud moment for the Council, the school and our contractors."

Colin Hall, Head of Holland Park, said: "We are thrilled to have reached the closing stages of a journey that began over a decade ago and which has benefited from the enthusiasm and guiding hand of the Royal Borough.

"We think our new building is `iconic', dynamic, original and wonderfully constructed. It is a new London landmark, setting a new standard for such public buildings.

"We have every confidence that our students will imbibe its splendour and repay the investment by continuing to succeed so spectacularly.

"In a year of all time record results for the school, it is a splendid moment in time to begin a new chapter of history in the new Holland Park School."

Sir John Baker, Chair of the Governing Body, said: "The new School building is, quite simply, magnificent. We have watched it rise out of the ground with great anticipation and now we can see it, experience it, live in it and work in it.

"We are rejoicing in its fusion of design and functionality. We are proud of our school and proud of our new building: we will redouble our energies to ensure that Holland Park School continues to provide the very best in comprehensive education for our students and to repay the faith of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the community in the investment it has made in this wonderful building."

To pay for the school, the Council has sold the southern part of the old school site for residential development. Planning permission has been granted for 72 homes. The homes will be arranged in a U-shape around a central landscaped courtyard and include a children's play space. All will be built to lifetime homes standards. Pedestrian and vehicle access will be from Campden Hill.

As planning gain, the Council has funded two outstanding residential developments, one on Ifield Road, in Chelsea, the other at Silchester Garages in North Kensington. At Ifield Road, it has paid for 20 new units of social housing, at Silchester, 63 units of affordable and intermediate housing.

The sale of the southern site has generated £105 million. From the outset the Council has set out to build the optimum new school for Holland Park, the specification is therefore unusually high. Nevertheless the sale not only pays for the school outright it has funded two high quality developments of affordable housing and it will also contribute a very substantial sum towards the construction of other new schools in the borough.

Construction of the school building was completed in September 2012. Pupils will move in during the autumn half term. The temporary school will then be removed so that work on the pitches and landscaping can begin; that is scheduled to complete in November 2013.
shortdescription: Holland Park School, one of the country's first and most famous comprehensive schools, is moving into a magnificent new building.
shorttitle: Magnificent new Holland Park School building completed

headline: BOROUGH PUPILS EXCELLENT GCSE RESULTS CONFIRMED
prcopy:
Pupils at schools in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are second in the country when it comes to their performance in GCSE exams, according to figures released by the Department for Education yesterday (Thursday 18 October).

In total 80 per cent of pupils in the borough's schools achieved five or more A* to C (including English and mathematics) GCSEs, placing the borough second in the national table behind only the Isles of Scilly. The national average for maintained schools was 58 per cent.

Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am very proud of the standard of education the borough's schools provide. Our position in these national tables reflects a tremendous amount of hard work by teachers and pupils."

headline: A CHANCE FOR YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS TO TEST THEIR SKILLS ON PORTOBELLO AND GOLBORNE MARKETS
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and The Prince's Trust launch the third year of their enterprise project to find young entrepreneurs.

The Market Enterprise Launch Pad (MELP) is a free project that offers young people (aged 16 to 24) the chance to develop the skills they need to succeed in business. The project is funded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and The John Lyon's Charity and aims to address the social and economic imbalance that young people face in the current labour market with youth unemployment still rising within the capital.

Entrepreneurs on the project will have the opportunity to pitch their business idea to a panel of expert judges to win a stall space on the Portobello and Golborne Road Markets.

The MELP 2013 will begin early February and will last four weeks, those taking part will be partnered with a business mentor who will support them to develop their idea and business plan. They will also be able to attend practical workshops and visit businesses to learn from professionals. Again, this year the Council is working with The Prince's Trust to kick start the MELP with the Explore Enterprise programme. This programme gives young people a chance to explore what is to be an entrepreneur and therefore make a better informed decision on how to progress with their aspirations.

There will again be expertise and on-hand support from many entrepreneurs specialising in various fields such as marketing, branding and developing an online presence. Business support will again include Cath Kidston Ltd, which welcomes potential young entrepreneurs into its HQ and provides masterclasses on elements of running a successful business.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Council, said: "This is an excellent opportunity for young people with a business idea. Portobello and Golborne markets provide an excellent place to put your business skills to the test."

MELP culminates with completion of a draft business plan and the opportunity to pitch to a panel of judges. Two lucky young people will win:

 £1,000 start-up funds
 A market stall for six months rent-free on the world famous Portobello and Golborne Road Markets
 Free business insurance
 A support package from their business mentor

To Apply: You must complete a registration form and return it to:
Leah Anderson-McCollin, Room G34, The Isaac Newton Professional Development Centre, 108a Lancaster Road, London W11 1QS or via email Leah.Anderson-McCollin@rbkc.gov.uk.

Deadline for applications is Sunday 25 November 23.59. Interviews will be held week commencing 10 December 2012, venue to be confirmed.

headline: BOROUGH RACER REACHES KARTING FINAL
prcopy:
One of the borough's looked after children has clinched a place in the national amateur karting final.

The driving prowess of Tijan (16) has seen him win a succession of races to reach the final of the Red Bull Amateur Karter at Buckmore Park in Kent. The winner will be chosen to represent the UK in the world finals in Italy in December.

Tijan is extremely dedicated to his sport and, as a looked after child, receives support from the Council.

Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Well done to Tijan for making the final which is a big achievement in itself. He clearly has a great deal of talent and determination and I wish him the best of luck when he takes on the top karters in the country.

"I would also like to thank everyone at Whistler Walk who has helped Tijan and made it possible for him to compete at such a high level."

Tijan said: "I've been karting since I was 11 and have constantly improved and progressed to the point where I regularly compete and win against others.

"Karting means a lot to me as I am extremely passionate about my racing as it is a sport I love. I have been supported right through with the help of my carers, family and the borough. I am planning to continue karting and start competing in the Rotax Max Series in the future. With this in mind I am hoping to attract a sponsor after I compete in the UK finals in order to fund my development through my racing career.

"Life is very busy at the moment. I'm studying hard at college during the day and concentrating on my karting at evenings and weekends, but it's good to be busy!"

headline: BREWING UP IDEAS
prcopy:
Some 300 residents stopped for Tea Together with Councillors and local voluntary organisations in Holland Park last Saturday 20 October and shared ideas about how the area could be improved by tapping into grants from the City Living, Local Life initiative.

headline: COUNCIL'S PARTNERSHIPS WITH THE VOLUNTARY AND COMMUNITY SECTOR RECOGNISED
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea is in line for a national award in recognition of the effective partnerships that exist between the Council, voluntary, community and health agencies in the Royal Borough.

The Compact Awards 2012 are given to local areas with an outstanding commitment to the Compact, a written agreement between the local public sector and voluntary and community sector which sets out ways of working that improves their relationship for mutual advantage.

Kensington and Chelsea was one of the first areas in the country to agree a Compact. The local Compact group, which has representation from the Council, Kensington and Chelsea Social Council, local NHS and representatives of the local voluntary and community sector, has been shortlisted as one of four best practice areas for the partnership category of the awards.

Over the past year the group has undertaken a number of actions to ensure the Compact remains effective, locally relevant and supports strong relationships across voluntary and public sectors.

headline: THREE BOROUGHS LAUNCH NEW ONLINE BOOK GROUP
prcopy:
The traditional book group is set to get a twenty-first century makeover as three London councils launch a new online forum to discuss books and promote reading.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council, and Hammersmith & Fulham Council will launch the new online group, `Text Tribe' on Tuesday 6 November at Kensington Central Library with a special appearance by bestselling author Mark Billingham.

The three councils' libraries and archives teams have created the new group in partnership with the Reading Agency and Arts Council's Digital Skills Sharing Project.

The group's first book for discussion is Mark Billingham's crime novel Sleepyhead, and publisher Little, Brown have already given away 120 free copies of the book in preparation for the launch event.

Text Tribe is aimed at adult residents of the three boroughs and there is no limit on numbers of members. The group's aim is to promote reading and literature in a way that fits in with modern lifestyles and uses technology to bring people together.

The group will change book every one to two months, and future book choices and directions for the group will be dictated by feedback and suggestions from members. The forum is also open for more general discussions of books people are reading, outside of the current book choice for the group.

The Text Tribe group is the latest announcement for the three London councils' Tri-borough libraries and archives service, which is part of a wider programme between the local authorities to combine senior and middle management, save money and keep libraries open across the three boroughs.

Commenting on the new online book group, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Libraries, Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, said: "By combining our service delivery we are not only keeping all our libraries open but through Text Tribe we will provide 24/7 access to a reading group and give people the opportunity to discuss at anytime what is exciting or annoying them about the books they are reading."

Westminster City Council's Cabinet Member for Community Services, Cllr Lee Rowley, added: "A lot of Londoners are so busy they scarcely have time to read a book, let alone put regular time aside for attending a book group meeting. So we're hoping this new online forum will encourage Londoners to read more while better reflecting their busy lives and increased use of technology.

"It will also help local readers to exchange opinions on the books they're reading with a more diverse array of people. It's good news for reading and literacy in London, and the latest in a string of innovative announcements from our tri-borough libraries service."

Cllr Greg Smith, Deputy Leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Council, said: "The online reading group shows once again that by thinking innovatively, it is possible to improve the library service we offer to residents. By combining library management, we have been able to secure the future of all our 21 branches - but you do not even need to visit a library to reap the benefits of this scheme."
Speaking ahead of the launch event, author Mark Billingham said: "Reading groups are a hugely important way to spread the word about books and to share the pleasure of a good read with others. New technologies and the rise of social media gives us more scope to reach wider audiences, allowing us to enjoy the simple pleasure of talking about books with like-minded friends, no matter the time or place."
