headline: SWEEPING REFORMS TO NEW TENANCIES IN KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA
prcopy:
Armed forces personnel and people with genuine local connections will receive greater priority for council housing as part of a package of sweeping reforms to new tenancies in Kensington and Chelsea.

The reforms, if adopted by the Council's Cabinet next week (21 March 2013), will be the subject of twelve weeks of public consultation and scrutiny. They include measures that will transform not only who can get a Council home, but also on what terms.

Amongst the key proposals is an end to lifetime tenancies. All future tenants would be issued with a 12 month introductory tenancy. Providing its terms aren't broken, they would then be eligible for either a two, or more typically, a five year tenancy.

Tenancies would not be renewed if at the end of their term:

 the property has become too large for the household's needs
 household income has grown to more than £50,000 for one and two bed flats and £65,000 for larger properties
 savings and investments other than for pension purposes exceed £25,000
 the tenant or tenant's partner has acquired a legal interest in another property suitable for occupation
 there has been a serious breach of the tenancy agreement including rent arrears or antisocial behaviour.

As well as tightening the terms of tenancies, the Council also proposes to tighten the rules on which households qualify for Council and Housing Association homes. If adopted, the new allocations policy would generally rule out people who have not been in the borough for at least three years. People with high incomes and significant savings would not make the list either.

However, extra points would be awarded to households where at least one member is in paid work for 16 hours a week or more. Serving and former members of the armed forces and bereaved partners of forces personnel would also attract extra points.

"Our existing tenancy and allocation policies belong to a time when councils were able to build new homes and the turnover of the existing stock was far higher," said Cllr Tim Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Housing. "We now need to make sure that this scarce and precious resource goes only to the right people. For us that means those in the greatest need, those with real roots in our borough, those who work and contribute, and those who have served our country. That is what these proposals are all about.

"We now want to hear what our residents and the wider public have to say."

Should the new policies be adopted, the Council intends to remove from its housing register those households with such low priority that they have no realistic prospect of ever getting a Council or Housing Association home. Last year the Council let 550 properties but it has nearly 9,000 households on its housing register, nearly 6,500 of which are neither homeless, chronically overcrowded or in pressing medical need and therefore have little hope of being offered a social housing tenancy.

"A lot of people are currently able to join our housing register who in fact have very low priority and therefore very few housing points or often no housing points at all," explained Cllr Coleridge.

"It is better to offer people realistic housing advice as to where they can find suitable accommodation than to give out totally unrealistic expectations that leads to many people waiting years for an offer that will simply not happen."

Subject to the Cabinet's decision, public consultation on the new policies gets under way on 1 April 2013 and will conclude on 25 June 2013. The Cabinet will then make a final decision on adoption in late summer 2013.
shortdescription: Armed forces personnel and people with genuine local connections will receive greater priority for council housing as part of a package of sweeping reforms to new tenancies in Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Sweeping reforms to new tenancies in Kensington and Chelsea

headline: REMEMBERING THE EAST JAPAN TSUNAMI AND EARTHQUAKE
prcopy:
Representatives of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the ambassador of Japan joined members of the Japanese community earlier this week (11 March) to mark the second anniversary of the earthquake and tsunami which hit Eastern Japan and unveil a plaque from the Emperor of Japan, thanking the British people for their help after the tsunami and earthquake.

The Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough, Councillor Nicholas Paget-Brown and the Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Christopher Buckmaster represented the Royal Borough. Mr Keiichi Hayashi, the Japanese Ambassador, read a message from the Japanese Emperor personally thanking the people of Britain for their aid two years ago.

Welcoming Mr Keiichi Hayashi, Councillor Paget-Brown said: "Thank you for coming on such an important day. It is two years ago today since the sad events in Fukushima and the surrounding area took place.

"We, in the Royal Borough, and in Britain as a whole, have a strong connection with the people of Japan and it is an honour for His Imperial Highness, the Emperor to choose our borough for a plaque to commemorate the help British people gave immediately after the tsunami and earthquake."

The Mayor added: "I remember where I was when the news of the terrible disaster appeared on television. The room fell silent as we watched the awful pictures of what was unfolding in Japan.

"I would like to express our deepest sympathy to you all and let you know that we were all thinking of you and sharing your grief."

Mr Hayashi said: "Amidst our despair, we were greatly encouraged by the heart-warming messages of support as well as the most generous material assistance we received from the Government and people of the United Kingdom.

"The plaque will play a valuable role both in reminding visitors to the Park of what happened on that fateful day and in making them aware of the selfless contribution of so many Britons to the efforts to bring relief and succour to the survivors of the catastrophe."

The Fukushima Garden was created after the East Japan earthquake and is part of the Kyoto Garden, which was originally opened in September 1991 by HRH Prince Charles and His Imperial Highness The Crown Prince of Japan as a part of the Japan Festival celebrations.

shorttitle: Remembering the East Japan tsunami and earthquake

headline: OAK BRIDGE EMBODIES COMMUNITY SPIRIT
prcopy:
Meanwhile Gardens, a community run park in North Kensington, which provides an oasis of green in a densely populated borough now has a new oak bridge with built- in-benches for residents to sit and enjoy the park.

The bridge provides a link to the wildlife garden which is maintained by Kensington and Chelsea MIND a charity which provides horticultural training for people with long term mental health issues. It is dedicated to the memory of the late Jamie McCullough who helped found Meanwhile Gardens and worked to transform the four-acre site from a derelict wasteland to the multi-activity community park it is today.

Made from recycled oak timbers, it was designed by landscape architect Adam Thomas and paid for by the Western Riverside Environmental Fund.

Speaking at the opening on Tuesday 12 March, the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster said: "Meanwhile Gardens provides an oasis of green and calm in a busy and densely populated urban area and acts as a focal point for the local community. It has established a tradition of working with communities and organisations to build team spirit.

"This beautiful and intricate bridge is a fitting testament to that spirit of partnership and will no doubt be enjoyed by local residents and visitors alike for many years to come. I would like to congratulate everyone associated with the project."

In addition to the wildlife garden the park features a play hut for children, paddling pool and skatebowl.

headline: TWO-WAY CYCLING SUCCESS FOR ROYAL BOROUGH
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea won a London Transport Award in the cycling category at a ceremony on Thursday 14 March.

The award is for the Council's two-way cycling scheme, in which cyclists are able to travel both ways along sections of a number of one-way streets in the borough. The Mayor's Vision for Cycling in London report described the scheme as "brilliantly led".

These changes have been designed to make cycling more attractive and allow riders to take the most direct route to their destination, as well as preventing situations in which one-way streets force cyclists onto busier main roads. The streets now have `Except cycles' signs below the existing `No Entry' signs together with signs and markings warning drivers that cyclists are allowed to travel in the opposite direction. This was only possible after the Council persuaded the Department for Transport to allow it to use this intuitive and simple arrangement of signs, which was previously not permitted. All councils are now able to use this arrangement.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Transport, said:

"We are delighted to be recognised for our pioneering cycling scheme with this London Transport Award. We have always been keen to work with cyclists in Kensington and Chelsea to help them move more freely around the borough.

"The underlying principle for introducing two-way cycling in these streets is that it allows cyclists to avoid very busy roads and in some cases they even provide a more direct route."

"We have closely monitored road safety statistics in the participating one-way streets. The figures have stacked up and shown that two-way cycling poses no more of a danger to motorists, pedestrians or cyclists."

There is a map of the two-way cycling schemes on the Royal Borough's cycling web page rbkc.gov.uk/cycling

It is important to remember that there is no blanket exemption from one-way restrictions for cyclists, with the only exemptions indicated by signs.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea won a London Transport Award in the cycling category at a ceremony on Thursday 14 March.
shorttitle: Two-way cycling success for Royal Borough

headline: COUNCIL CALLS TIME ON ICEBERG HOUSES
prcopy:
Stricter planning rules could spell the end of mega-basements in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Six weeks of public consultation on the proposed policies will get underway on 21 March 2013. Designed to introduce a sense of proportionality to basement proposals, the draft policies include:

a reduction in the extent basements can intrude into the garden, from 85 per cent to 50 per cent, with that 50 per cent being a single area of space.

a restriction to a single storey in most cases, with exceptions only being considered for large comprehensive developments.

an outright ban on basement developments under, or in the gardens, of listed buildings or where basements already exist, though again exceptions might be considered on very large sites.

the compulsory installation of pumps to prevent flooding from sewers.

The move follows a study by the leading engineering consultancy, Alan Baxter and Associates, into the impact of multiple basement developments on the built and natural environment in Kensington and Chelsea.

Commenting on the new draft policies inspired by that report, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, Cllr Tim Ahern, said:

"We do not argue for a ban on basement development, only for a better balance between them and the amenity of our other residents. If the cumulative impact of scores of schemes that take months and years to complete is to damage the wider quality of life in our borough I believe we have a right to take that into account.

"Just as important, we want to preserve our garden space in its green, leafy and flowering form. In particular we want trees to grow and thrive and they simply can't do that in thin soil that's principal purpose is to cover over a dwelling space.

"We also need to retain our soak away areas and for that you need space wide enough and deep enough. Basements that are storeys deep do not help.

"Finally, Kensington and Chelsea is an important heritage area with thousands of listed buildings. Increasingly it's clear that major basement developments can be structurally very challenging. Because of that increased risk to the fabric of our precious heritage assets we believe we should adopt the precautionary principle and reduce the risk by limiting the scale of some of the developments we have been seeing here.

"But now it's time for the public and the professionals to have their say. We will listen carefully and our proposals will be examined by an Independent Inspector later in the year, after which we will take a final decision."
shortdescription: Stricter planning rules could spell the end of mega-basements in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Council calls time on iceberg houses

headline: THAI RESTAURANT FALLS FOUL OF FOOD HYGIENE STANDARDS
prcopy:
A restaurant in All Saints Road is counting the cost of falling foul of food hygiene standards after being ordered to pay £5,015 yesterday (Tuesday 19 March 2013) at West London Magistrates' Court.

The court heard that when Kensington and Chelsea's environmental health officers visited Café De Thai, 23 All Saints Road, London W11 1HE on 12 April 2012 the premises had to be closed because officers found a severe and widespread mouse infestation. There was evidence of gnawed packets of rice and uncooked prawn crackers and mouse droppings were found on food contact surfaces.

The restaurant was not kept clean, there was a failure to provide hot and cold running water and there had been a failure to keep stored foodstuffs protected from contamination. It therefore posed a risk to public health and was immediately closed.

Mr Leo Jubbang, the Director of Café De Thai Limited, pleaded guilty to four food hygiene offences and was fined £3,000. In addition he was ordered to pay the Council's £2,000 costs and a £15 victim surcharge.

Mr Jubbang told the court that he had only been trading since 2009 and that his business had been suffering due to the current financial climate. In sentencing the magistrates took account of the economic downturn in fining him but also noted that the conditions found at the premises were disgusting.

Councillor Fiona Buxton, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said:

"When officers visited this restaurant they found a serious mouse infestation and shut the premises immediately. I am relieved that the court has handed down this substantial fine and hope it sends a clear signal that unhygienic conditions will not be tolerated in the borough."
shortdescription: A restaurant in All Saints Road is counting the cost of falling foul of food hygiene standards after being ordered to pay £5,015 yesterday (Tuesday 19 March 2013) at West London Magistrates' Court.
shorttitle: Thai restaurant  falls foul of food hygiene standards

headline: GUIDELINES ANNOUNCED TO LIMIT SIZE OF 'SUPER-PRIME' PROPERTIES AND ENCOURAGE INCREASE IN AFFORDABLE HOMES
prcopy:
Planning guidelines to help limit the size of `super-prime' residential properties and encourage an increase in the number of affordable homes have been announced by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

With economic turbulence overseas, property in Kensington and Chelsea is often seen as a safe investment for wealthy foreign investors. These buyers are able to invest huge sums of money in very large residential units over 350 sq m sometimes known as `super-prime'.(1) The Council now proposes to restrict the size of very large residential units in a scheme to 25 per cent of the overall floor space.

There will also be restrictions on creating very large units by amalgamating existing properties, except where this restores a house to a single unit, which had been previously split into flats.

These restrictions closely follow the Council's recent move to set limits on the scale of basement development in the borough. Highlights of these new policies include a reduction in the extent which basements can extend into the garden, a restriction to a single storey and an outright ban on basement developments under, or in the gardens, of listed buildings, or where a basement already exists.(2)

Measures to encourage an increase in the number of affordable homes being built in the borough include raising the threshold where affordable housing should be built on site to 2,400 sq m. By doubling the threshold, the Council believes it will be more realistic for developers to build affordable homes as part of new developments instead of off-site.

Other changes require developers to make a financial contribution towards affordable housing on all schemes below the 2,400 sq m threshold. This will be charged per square metre and on the entire floor space with the removal of the previous 800 sq m `tax free' element.

Councillor Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said:

"Property in Kensington and Chelsea has long been attractive to foreign investors and while we do not want to discourage international investment we want to restrict the proliferation of `super-prime' properties to ensure there remains a balance in property sizes.

"Having some of the most expensive land values in the country means it is a constant challenge for us to build affordable homes in the Royal Borough.

"We believe that by raising the threshold for affordable housing to be built on site, combined with an increase in financial contributions from developers, we can achieve a meaningful increase in the number of affordable homes we deliver."

The Council is consulting on its housing and basement policies for six weeks from Thursday 21 March 2013.

headline: DOGS WAG TAILS IN AID OF MAGIC WAND
prcopy:
Dogs of all shapes, sizes and temperaments will help raise money for the Brain Tumour Research Campaign (BTRC) and Charing Cross Hospital with the Magic Wand Dog Show on Saturday 13 April at Dove House Green, just off King's Road, Chelsea.

Celebrity judges will be on hand to judge the 15 fun and competitive classes such as scruffiest in show, best in show, waggiest tail, most like owner and cutest puppy. Other attractions on the day include a range of fun stalls, a doggy fashion show and fire engines for young children to sit in.

BTRC was chosen by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster, as his charity after a close friend was diagnosed with a brain tumour. Brain tumours are the biggest cancer killers of children and adults under 40 and have the lowest survival rate of all cancers.

So far Cllr Buckmaster has raised over £100,000 which will go towards buying a ground breaking surgical tool called the SonoWand for Charing Cross Hospital. The SonoWand creates a virtual reconstruction of the brain enabling surgeons to operated more accurately. The hospital already has a SonoWand but demand is growing and it desperately needs another upgraded version.

Estimates from the National Cancer Intelligence Network (NCIN) indicate that approximately 840 Londoners are diagnosed with a brain, central nervous system or intracranial tumour each year and currently over 2,500 people are treated in London hospitals for tumours relating to the brain or central nervous system. According to NCIN the North West London area, which comprises the Charing Cross Hospital, has the best results in the UK for one, three and five year survival rates for brain cancer.

If you would like to donate to the Mayor's Charity or want more information on the dog show go to www.wayahead-btrc.org/
keyword3: Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chels
shortdescription: Dogs of all shapes, sizes and temperaments will help raise money for the Brain Tumour Research Campaign (BTRC) and Charing Cross Hospital with the Magic Wand Dog Show on Saturday 13 April at Dove House Green, just off King's Road, Chelsea.
shorttitle: Dogs wag tails in aid of Magic Wand

headline: NEW PLAY SCHEME AT WORLD'S END
prcopy:
A new play scheme for disabled children was formally opened on Tuesday 26 March at Ashburnham School on the World's End Estate.

The facility operates as a satellite service of the successful St Quintin Centre - based in North Kensington - and will be open on Saturdays and during school holidays.

Housed in a newly-refurbished bungalow, St Quintin South offers a variety of facilities, initially for up to ten children, including an arts and crafts room, a reading room and a special eco garden.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am sure that this new play scheme will provide great facilities and fun for the children. Everyone connected with the St Quintin Centre has vast experience of providing support to disabled children and their families.

"I would like to thank Ashburnham School for all its support which means that this important facility has a welcoming home in the south of the borough."
shortdescription: A new play scheme for disabled children was formally opened on Tuesday 26 March at Ashburnham School on the World's End Estate.

headline: FOX PRIMARY'S TABLE TENNIS STARS DO BOROUGH PROUD AT NATIONAL FINAL
prcopy:
The boys and girls table tennis stars of Fox Primary School are celebrating after excelling at the National Schools Table Tennis Finals at the Hinckley Leisure Centre in Leicestershire.

The boy's team featuring, Kidi, Teddy, Benji and Marco picked up the bronze medal narrowly missing out on the silver medal.

The girls, Tibby, Federica, Honor and Lucia, went one better, getting their hands on the silver medal and missed out on gold by a nail-biting single game. There were some heroic efforts all round, but amongst all the cheers and tears there were some standout performances from Benji and Federica, with Federica taking a game off the highest ranked England Under-11 girl.

The tournament was the climax to a year-long qualifying process and marks the conclusion of a three-year coaching project at Fox Primary jointly sponsored by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, The London Table Tennis Academy (LTTA) and Fox Primary.

After the excitement of the weekend it's back to training for the Fox Stars as they prepare for their National Individual Events and the annual London Youth Games. Training takes place every Friday evening at the Council's Table Tennis School of Excellence held at the Chelsea Academy 5pm to 8pm (£2) during term time.

All students in the borough are welcome to attend irrespective of their age or level of play. Work is already well advanced in creating successful borough teams for the coming season and Fox Primary look particularly determined to continue their successful run. You wouldn't bet against them becoming London Primary School Champions for a third successive year.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Well done to the boys and girls from Fox Primary. A silver and bronze from the same school at a national final is a fantastic achievement.

"Of course, the children's obvious talents have been supported and nurtured by their teachers, coaches from the Council and the London Table Tennis Academy. I would like to thank them for all their efforts."
shortdescription: The boys and girls table tennis stars of Fox Primary School are celebrating after excelling at the National Schools Table Tennis Finals at the Hinckley Leisure Centre in Leicestershire.
shorttitle: Fox Primary School's table tennis stars do borough proud at national final

headline: AN EXPLOSION OF YOUNG ARTISTIC TALENT
prcopy:
The opening night of Art Explosion at Chelsea Theatre on Friday 22 March provided a showcase for local young people's art, poetry, music and dance.

Young people who took part in a cross-borough art competition sent in a fantastic range of pieces, including sculpture, collage, photography and painting. These were displayed while other young people entertained the crowd with spoken word poetry.

First prize went to John O'Donoghue (19) from World's End for his portrait painting.

The competition was judged by Harold Offeh, a contemporary artist who works in a range of media including performance, video, photography and interactive and digital, who said: "I was completely blown away by the amount of creativity on display here. Choosing a winner was really difficult, but John obviously has real talent. I hope winning this competition really encourages him."

On Saturday 23 March almost sixty young people took part in Dance Explosion at the theatre with performances showing off their dance moves and musical skills. The event was organised by the Council and was described by one young participant as simply "the best event I have ever been to".

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "It is very clear that we have some real artistic talent here in the borough. I'd like to thank all the young people who have exhibited and congratulate John on his winning entry."

The art exhibition is on display at the theatre until Monday 15 April.
shortdescription: The opening night of Art Explosion at Chelsea Theatre on Friday 22 March provided a showcase for local young people's art, poetry, music and dance.
shorttitle: An explosion of young artistic talent

headline: REDCLIFFE WARD COUNCILLOR NOMINATED FOR MAYORAL ELECTION
prcopy:
Councillor Charles Williams has been nominated by the Conservative Party Group to stand for election as Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Born in Liverpool in 1948 Charles Williams read Natural Sciences at Gonville and Caius College Cambridge and has worked in the City and for several Not for Profit organisations. He has served as Chief Finance Officer of the Churches Conservation Trust, a charity which cares for over 300 redundant churches, and, until his retirement in 2013, worked for the British Association of Art Therapists. He served as a member of Lambeth Borough Council from 1977 to 1986.

Charles Williams was first elected to the Council in 2006 as Councillor for Redcliffe Ward, which he continues to represent. He is vice-chairman of the Planning Applications Committee and of the Health, Environmental Health and Adult Social Care Scrutiny Committee.

He has served as a governor of the Chelsea Open Air Nursery School; and is the Council's representative on the Council of Governors of Central and North West London NHS Foundation Trust. He is Treasurer of the Brighter Kensington and Chelsea Scheme, a borough-wide gardening competition which is supported by the Council, and a member of the Kensington and Chelsea Community Police Engagement Group.

If elected, he will appoint his wife, June to be his Mayoress; they were married in 1998. Mrs. Williams worked as an occupation therapist until her retirement and has lived in the Royal Borough since 1970. Councillor Williams will appoint the Reverend. Ginny Thomas from St. Mary the Boltons as his Chaplain and will take Trinity Hospice as his charity.

Councillor Williams said: "It is great honour to be selected to stand for election as Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

"I hope, if elected, to meet as many as possible of those who give their time to voluntary work in the Royal Borough and thank them for what they do for our community."
shortdescription: Councillor Charles Williams has been nominated by the Conservative Party Group to stand for election as Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Redcliffe ward Councillor nominated for Mayoral election

headline: LAUNCH OF CITYREAD 2013
prcopy:
A novel capturing a snapshot of London life has been revealed as the title for the second annual capital-wide book club.

This year's chosen book for Cityread 2013 - set up to promote the capital's libraries and reading - will be Sebastian Faulks's novel `A Week in December.'

Libraries across Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster and Hammersmith and Fulham are hosting a number of events from Tuesday 2 April.

It will follow the success of the scheme's debut in 2012, when thousands of Londoners rediscovered Charles Dickens' classic `Oliver Twist' and enjoyed hundreds of related events, workshops and screenings across the capital.

Mr Faulks, whose satire is a panoramic snapshot of London life, the people and issues that affect them, said it was an honour for his title to be picked.

He said: "I'm delighted that `A Week in December' will be Cityread London's chosen book for 2013.

"I began the book with the intention of writing a modern Dickensian novel in which London played a key part so it's great to be following Dickens himself as the Cityread London selection.

"I do hope Londoners enjoy reading and discussing the book, and hope that it goes some way towards reflecting the nature of this extraordinary city."

Other events will include free literary and history talks, creative writing workshops, exhibitions, a photographic competition and an online reading group. They will be included in a talk by Antony Clayton, author of `Subterranean City: Beneath the Streets of London' at Paddington Library on Thursday 4 April.

An exhibition `Trains, Trams and Buses: Images from the History of Transport in Kensington and Chelsea' will be touring libraries throughout the borough.

While Hammersmith and Fulham libraries are running 'A Week in April' - a photography competition inspired by Faulks's book.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Libraries, said: "We are proud to be supporting Cityread London for the second year running.

"Across our three boroughs we have a programme of exciting events and I'd urge people to pop into their nearest library and check them out."

Councillor Steve Summers, Westminster's Cabinet Member for Community, said:

"Our libraries are a fantastic and much-loved resource.

"It is events like Cityread that will remind anyone who hasn't visited their local library for a while why they are so important and what they are missing."

Councillor Greg Smith, Hammersmith and Fulham Council Deputy Leader, said: "Literacy is a fundamental cornerstone of a modern society and we need to get residents off their sofas and into our libraries with events like this.

"This is why we are finding original ways to strengthen and protect as many of our libraries as we can.

"Residents across the Tri-borough area now have access to more books than anyone could realistically expect to read in a lifetime."

For the full list of events taking across the three boroughs check:

shortdescription: A novel capturing a snap-shot of London life has been revealed as the title for the second annual capital-wide book-club.
shorttitle: Launch of Cityread 2013

headline: GRAB YOUR CHANCE TO BECOME A MARKET TRADER
prcopy:
Over 300 market pitches on Portobello Road, Golborne Road, and Portobello Green Fashion Market at the Westway are up for grabs during Love Your Market Fortnight which runs from 15 to 29 May.

Anyone can apply for a stall for just £10 a day and use it as an opportunity to trade and market test their wares.

Last year a similar event attracted over 57 would-be traders who sold a range of products including: homeware, men's and women's fashion, homemade cosmetics, children's clothes, gourmet cookies and sauces and marinades.

In January Portobello and Golborne markets were named the best outdoor markets in the country by the National Association of British Market Authorities (NAMBA). Both markets attract millions of visitors every year drawn by the eclectic mix of goods on sale.

This year the markets will be used as the backdrop to launch Love Your Market Fortnight, which is organised by NAMBA. Two hundred of the pitches will be on Portobello and Golborne markets which are managed by the Royal Borough. The remaining 100 pitches will be located on Portobello Green Fashion Market which operates on Westway Development Trust land.

The Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, said: "This is a great initiative which gives people an opportunity to try their hand at trading and market testing products. We are delighted to be working with the Westway Development Trust for this year's Love Your Markets Fortnight which has allowed us to offer 300 pitches to new traders.

"This is a great opportunity to experience the character and vibrancy of these wonderful markets at close quarters."

For more information and to register your interest in a market stall email marketevents@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Over 300 market pitches on Portobello Road, Golborne Road, and Portobello Green Fashion Market at the Westway are up for grabs during Love Your Market Fortnight which runs from 15 to 29 May.
shorttitle: Grab your chance to become a market trader

headline: £25,000 PRIZE UP FOR GRABS IN COUNCIL TAX PROMOTION
prcopy:
One lucky Royal Borough resident could scoop £25,000 after the Council teamed up with Bacs Payment Schemes Ltd (Bacs), the not-for-profit organisation behind Direct Debit, to offer council tax payers a chance to win the life changing prize.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is one of 17 London boroughs taking part in the prize draw promotion, with residents living in Barnet, Brent, City of Westminster, Ealing, Enfield, Hammersmith and Fulham, Haringey, Harrow, Hillingdon, Hounslow, Islington, , Lambeth, Lewisham, Southwark, Tower Hamlets and Wandsworth all eligible for entry into the draw.

To be in with a chance of winning the £25,000 prize, Royal Borough residents must register to pay their council tax bill by Direct Debit before 5pm on Friday 12 July 2013. They can simply return a completed paper Direct Debit Instruction to the Council; or sign up to Direct Debit on the Council's website www.rbkc.gov.uk/counciltax or set up a Direct Debit over the phone by calling 020 7361 3005. Residents who already pay their council tax bill by Direct Debit will be automatically entered into the prize draw.

Last year's £25,000 prize was won by a Southwark resident. This year's winner will be drawn on Thursday 18 July 2013.

For more information on the free prize draw and how to sign up to Direct Debit visit www.ddwinner.co.uk or contact your local council.

headline: PUBS, BARS AND CLUBS GET CHANCE TO BE THE BEST
prcopy:
The Royal Borough is launching its annual Best Bar None awards, aimed at recognising the best pubs, bars and clubs in Kensington and Chelsea and giving them a chance to demonstrate their excellent management standards.

Landlords and managers of all the borough's pubs, bars and clubs will be able to submit applications for this year's membership from Monday 8 April to Friday 7 June, with the awards presentation taking place in November 2013.

Best Bar None encourages bar owners and managers to make their pubs and clubs crime-free and to make sure customers do not disturb their neighbours.

In 2012 the Drayton Arms, a pub on Old Brompton Road and one of the founder members of the scheme, was the overall winner for the second time. The Drayton Arms has continued to raise its own standards, work in partnership with the Council and others, and also displayed excellent management practices.

Leigh Philips, Manager of the Drayton Arms, said: "We are all incredibly proud to have won the Best Pub and Overall Winner award for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Best Bar None scheme for a second time.

"Having participated in the scheme since its inception, I have found it valuable to have an independent review each year of our policies and procedures in relation to the reduction of crime and disorder, and the health, safety and welfare of our guests, neighbours and team.

"It is great to have our high standards recognised by the Council and partner agencies, and, since winning, we have benefitted from an increase in footfall from both locals and tourists alike."

To get an application form and for more information go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/bestbarnone or email bestbarnone@rbkc.gov.uk

The scheme currently has 48 pub, bar and club members across the borough; it continues to be one of the largest schemes in the country and is supported by Diageo Great Britain.

headline: ON-STREET BOOST FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLES
prcopy:
The first two on-street electric vehicle charging points in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea opened for business yesterday ( Thursday 4 April).

Sites at Seville Street in Knightsbridge and Talbot Road in North Kensington have
been chosen by the Council because they are in locations that are highly visible and
attract a large number of visitors.

The special pay and display bays will be reserved for charging vehicles at all times and are operating as part of `Source London', the London-wide membership scheme for electric vehicle owners. Drivers will have to pay for parking in the bay but the electricity is free and there are no parking charges overnight.

Each charging point has both a 13 amp three pin socket and a 32amp seven pin socket, accessible with a `Source London' swipe card.

All electric vehicle drivers will continue to enjoy discounted parking fees when
charging their vehicles in one of the six the charging points in Kensington Town Hall
car park.

The new charging points have been introduced by the Council under an experimental Traffic Management Order for a maximum period of 18 months. They will be kept under review and a decision will be taken on whether to make the scheme permanent.

Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I hope that these new, highly visible electric charging points will help promote the use of electric vehicles across London, which will go a long way to reducing the pollution associated the petrol or diesel engine."

Nick Fairholme, TfL director responsible for Source London, said: "These new charge points are a very welcome addition to the Source London scheme which has over 1,000 publicly accessible points across the capital. This guarantees that our members are never far away from a charge point when they need one. The growth in the electric vehicle market is very encouraging and by building the infrastructure to support these vehicles, we expect them to become even more accessible."


For more details about Source London see https://www.sourcelondon.net/
shortdescription: The first two on-street electric vehicle charging points in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea opened for business yesterday ( Thursday 4 April).
shorttitle: On-street boost for electric vehicles

headline: PEDESTRIAN ACCESS MAINTAINED ACROSS KENSINGTON OLYMPIA STATION FOOTBRIDGE
prcopy:
Residents and Councillors have welcomed TfL's decision to keep the footbridge at Kensington Olympia Station open for pedestrians who, for many years, have used it as a shortcut.

TfL had been looking at ways to reduce the number of people travelling without a ticket and to improve security by installing ticket gates at both station entrances.

When the plans were announced last year local residents, the Royal borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham expressed concerns that the gates would block the walking route used by the local community across the station via the bridge between Russell Road and Olympia Way.

After working closely with both boroughs TfL has confirmed that it has found a way to install ticket gates while retaining the station as a shortcut. This will be achieved by dividing the station and bridge to a paying side and a free side. A fence will segregate the pedestrian route and an additional fourth staircase will be constructed to avoid congestion on the existing single staircase at the Olympia Way side of the station. This measure will keep the free and paying sides completely separate and the platforms will be inaccessible from this segregated pedestrian route.

Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "This is very good news. TfL has listened to our concerns and its decision to preserve pedestrian access over the footbridge at Olympia is to be welcomed. Residents and Councillors from both sides of the bridge have campaigned hard to preserve the status quo and will be delighted that this long- established route will not be blocked by ticket gates."
shortdescription: Residents and Councillors have welcomed TfL's decision to keep the footbridge at Kensington Olympia Station open for pedestrians who, for many years, have used it as a shortcut.
shorttitle: Pedestrian access maintained across Kensington Olympia Station footbridge

headline: YOUNG FOOTBALLERS THANK THEIR SPONSOR
prcopy:
A company that has sponsored young footballers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea received a signed football shirt from the players, as a thank you, following the team's recent trip to Cannes in the south of France.

On Wednesday 10 April boys from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Under-11 football team presented Cadogan Tate with a framed football jersey. The boys had travelling to Cannes to take part in a youth football tournament as part of the International Town Twinning process that has been in existence since 1970 between Kensington and Chelsea and Cannes.

The Royal Borough has taken part in the A.S Cannes International Youth Tournament for the past twelve years. Organised by the Council, a borough representative under-11's football team from local schools has been selected. The tournament brings together boys from a wide range of backgrounds and would not have been able to continue without the sponsorship received from Cadogan Tate.

Cadogan Tate has been working with the Council since 2011 and is pleased to sponsor the Under-11 football team. Paul Haynes, Director of Cadogan Tate said "It is very gratifying to know that, through our sponsorship, we are able to help some of the youngsters in the borough experience international competition and to know that for many it will be their first trip abroad." Stuart Ashe, General Manager added "I was fortunate enough to attend the tournament last year and it was great to see how the squad came together. We hear of boys who still talk about their trip to France, even years later."

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am very pleased that our young footballers have presented Cadogan Tate with a signed football shirt to thank the company for all its support. The annual tournament in Cannes is much more than a football competition. It is a chance for the boys to experience another culture, bond together and, of course, play to a high standard."

headline: CELEBRITIES GO TO THE DOGS TO HELP BRAIN CANCER CHARITY
prcopy:
Dogs, broadcasters and actors will join forces this Saturday 13 April near Chelsea's fashionable King's Road to help the hundreds of Londoners who each year are diagnosed with brain tumours and who face dramatically shortened lives as a result.

The Magic Wand Dog Show is being organised by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to raise funds for the Brain Tumour Research Campaign (BTRC) and also buy a neuro-surgical tool called the SonoWand for Charing Cross Hospital.

Celebrity judges include broadcasters Jonathan Maitland, Anna Webb, singer and X Factor mentor Sinitta and actor Honor Blackman.

Each year brain tumours cause more deaths in children and adults under 40 than any other cancer in the United Kingdom. Brain tumours are on the increase by over two per cent a year, but less than two per cent of national cancer research funds go to brain cancer research which has one of the lowest survival rates of all cancers.

In London alone some 840 people are diagnosed with brain, central nervous system or intracranial tumours each year and at present over 2,500 people are treated in the Capital's hospitals for brain or central nervous system related tumours.

The dog show which starts at 10.30am will be held at DoveHouse Green and features 15 classes including scruffiest in show and most like owner. Anyone who cannot make the dog show can still enter their pooch for a virtual show at www.wayahead-btrc.org and help raise much needed funds in the process.

Speaking about the appeal neurosurgeon and BTRC co-founder Kevin O'Neill said that the Sonowand can make surgery safer, more accurate and more complete. "This results in patients living longer and has the opportunity to reap the benefits from the other research we are producing", he added.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Cllr Christopher Buckmaster said: "All too often we hear of the most dreadful illnesses which strike suddenly and can prove to be life-threatening. The news is devastating for the individuals and those close to them. In their desperation all they want is a magic wand that can be waved to make the whole ghastly situation just go away.

"Sadly my appeal cannot be for a wand of that sort but I am raising money for a type of wand - one that will be a significant help to neurosurgeons when they operate on brain tumours."

He chose the appeal after a close friend was diagnosed with a brain tumour and has raised over £100,000 since last October.

To contribute to the appeal email mayor@rbkc.gov.uk or go to www.wayahead-btrc.org

shorttitle: Celebrities go to the dogs to help brain cancer charity

headline: SIR MERRICK TO STEP DOWN
prcopy:
Local Government Secretary Eric Pickles MP is leading the tributes to Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell who has announced today (Tuesday 16 April) that he is to step down as Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Elected Leader in 2000, Sir Merrick's record of success at the Royal Borough has helped establish him as a leading figure in UK local government.

From 2006 to 2010 he was Chairman of London Councils, the representative body for the Capital's 32 local authorities. And in 2011, he was chosen by other council leaders to head up the Local Government Association, the national voice for England's councils.

He was knighted for services to local government in 2010.

"I have worked with Sir Merrick for many years and he is a true public servant and local champion," said Eric Pickles.

"Under his leadership the Council has achieved some incredible things for the residents of Kensington and Chelsea. The Tri-borough initiative he helped spearhead is a shining example of shared services savings to all in local government."

Sir Merrick has led Kensington and Chelsea during a period in which it has been repeatedly recognised as one of Britain's best performing local authorities. It has consistently achieved some of the highest resident approval ratings in the Capital while its residents have enjoyed one of the lowest council taxes in the country.

As Leader he was the driving force behind the ambitious `Renewing the Legacy' programme, the largest building programme in Kensington and Chelsea since the post war slum clearances.

He personally led the long campaign for a new secondary school in Chelsea which, in 2010, delivered the Chelsea Academy. The school won the Public Building of the Year Award in 2011 and is already rated as "outstanding" by Ofsted.

He was also closely involved in the project to rebuild Holland Park School. Pupils took up occupation of their new school at the end of 2012. From the outset the Council set out to build them a school to "match the very best in the country." The scheme was funded by a private land deal so profitable that it also paid for two affordable housing schemes and contributed significantly to the costs of the new academy for North Kensington currently under construction.

Amongst a number of other public realm projects, Sir Merrick led the team responsible for the multi-award winning Exhibition Road streetscape scheme.

An early test of his leadership was the shock discovery that the Home Office had placed Kensington and Chelsea on a list of the 20 areas most affected by crack. Dens were springing up in the Royal Borough almost weekly and the authorities appeared impotent to deal with the crisis. Sir Merrick was one of the principal architects of the 2002 `crack house protocol', a then unique and highly controversial commitment to close crack houses and evict the tenants within six weeks of the crack trade being confirmed as active at the premises. He also authorised the Council's pioneering use of `S222 injunctions' to ban dealers from the borough. A series of evictions and injunctions swiftly followed and the crack den crisis eased.

In more recent years he has helped design the Council's response to the financial crisis and the consequent dramatic falls in Government funding. A key element of that response is the influential `Tri-Borough initiative', a radical back office and service sharing arrangement with Westminster and Hammersmith & Fulham that will yield at least £10 million worth of savings to the Council by 2015.

"It's been my good fortune to work alongside an unusually talented and dedicated group of councillors and officers," said Sir Merrick.

"Together I think we have done a good job for our residents. Our services have been excellent, our taxes low. And in the days when there was a lot more money around we didn't squander it, but used it wisely to build for the future.

"It's a record we can be very proud of."

A new leader will be elected by the Council on 22 May 2013.

Sir Merrick intends to remain as Chairman of the LGA for a further year and to continue to serve the people of Stanley Ward as one of their elected representatives on the Council. In addition the Mayor of London Boris Johnson has recently appointed him to the deputy chairmanship of the London Pensions Fund Authority.
shortdescription: Local Government Secretary Eric Pickles MP is leading the tributes to Cllr Sir Merrick Cockell who has announced today that he is to step down as Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Sir Merrick to step down

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH REDUCES CARBON EMISSIONS
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is in the top two best performing London boroughs when it comes to monitoring and reducing energy use and carbon emissions. This is based on the overall Carbon Reduction Commitment (CRC) table recently published by the UK Environment Agency. The Royal Borough is rated 55th overall out of over 2000 biggest private and public organisations in the UK.

This outstanding performance has been made possible by the delivery of a number of projects which have contributed to lower carbon emissions. These include street lighting projects, solar photovoltaic panels on Kensington Town Hall roof, fuel efficiencies in its waste fleet, and making more efficient use of its estate. In 2011/12 the Council's carbon emissions had reduced by 13 per cent compared with 2007/8 baseline. The Council estimates that this reduction has saved £406,000 in 2011/12 from its reduction in energy/resource use.

headline: HAVE YOUR SAY ON FUTURE OF BOROUGH'S FIRE STATIONS
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is urging residents and businesses to have their say on the future of the London Fire Brigade.

The London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority is consulting on its Draft Fifth London Safety Plan and it is important that residents and businesses in the Royal Borough take the chance to study the proposals and let decision makers know what they think.

A public meeting about the plans will be held in the Small Hall at Kensington Town Hall, W8 on Monday 10 June between 7pm and 9pm.

The plan sets out how the fire and rescue service could be delivered over the next few years. Amongst other things, it includes plans for target times for getting to incidents and details of how savings of nearly £30m could be made. These proposals involve the closure of 12 fire stations in London, including Knightsbridge and Westminster, and the removal of 18 fire engines across the capital, with one of Chelsea Fire Station's two engines going. The proposals also include the reduction of 520 fire fighter posts.

These fire stations cover one of the busiest areas in London with more visitors, tourist attractions and governmental and diplomatic premises than anywhere else in the country.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society, said: "The proposals contained in the Draft Fifth London Safety Plan would see the closure of one fire station in the borough and also one in nearby Westminster as well as Chelsea Fire Station losing an engine. This is clearly of concern to the Council and to the residents and businesses, not only of Kensington and Chelsea, but also of Westminster. It is very important that residents and businesses look at the proposals and make their feelings known."

For full details of the plan proposals and to take part in an online consultation go to www.London-fire.gov.uk/LSP5

If you would like a copy of the plan and consultation document call 0800 9888 569

The consultation runs until Monday 17 June 2013.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is urging residents and businesses to have their say on the future of the London Fire Brigade.
shorttitle: Have your say on the future of the borough's fire stations

headline: THE UK'S FIRST BI-BOROUGH CHIEF EXECUTIVE TO STEP DOWN
prcopy:
The UK's first chief executive to lead two unitary local authorities at the same time has announced he is planning to step down at the end of the year.

Derek Myers was appointed as Chief Executive of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea in 2000. In October 2011 he also took the helm at neighbouring Hammersmith & Fulham following radical plans to combine a range of services, cut management costs and protect front line services.

With Hammersmith & Fulham electing a new leader last year, and Kensington and Chelsea about to choose a new leader following Sir Merrick Cockell's decision to step down after 13 years in charge, Myers has decided that now is the right time to go to allow the two council leaders to appoint a new joint Chief Executive, ready for the next round of challenges.

The move will allow the two councils to advertise in June and enable a managed handover later in the year.

Sir Merrick Cockell, outgoing Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Under the guiding hand of Derek Myers Kensington and Chelsea has been one of the best performing councils in the country according to both the Audit Commission and Ofsted. Most importantly, the Council has consistently achieved the highest resident satisfaction ratings in London.

"You simply don't get our level of performance, over so many years, without a first rate chief executive."

Councillor Nicholas Botterill, Hammersmith & Fulham Council Leader, said: "By taking on the challenge of joint Chief Executive Derek led the way in reducing management costs while helping to improve council services in many areas. Derek has devoted his life to public service and has been a major force in the Tri-borough plans to improve the lives of residents by sharing best practice and reducing duplication and waste."

Announcing his decision, Derek Myers said: "I have had the best job in local government for 13 years and a total of 16 years as a London chief executive and it seems right to get out of the way and let someone else have a go. In time, I hope to use some of what I have learned in other places.

"I'm very pleased to say that although there have been many challenges I've had enormous fun and had the privilege of working with extremely dedicated councillors and officers every day to help individuals fulfil their potential, preserve their independence or just enjoy living in a marvellous part of London."

Kensington and Chelsea was one of only three councils to be continuously assessed by the Audit Commission as Excellent. The London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham recently reduced its council tax again with a composite reduction of 17 per cent since 2006.

Derek Myers was Chair of SOLACE for four years until autumn 2012. He was also Chair of Capital Ambition, the improvement and efficiency partnership for London for four years when London councils went from sixth best performing region to best performing. In addition he was also on the Department of Health Board for four years.

Before joining Kensington and Chelsea in 2000, Derek Myers was chief executive at the London Borough of Hounslow and before that its director of social services. He holds degrees in economics and law and is a qualified social worker

He was named as third most important figure in local government in LGC's last Top 50 list.
shortdescription: The UK's first chief executive to lead two unitary local authorities at the same time has announced he is planning to step down at the end of the year.
shorttitle: The UK's first bi-borough Chief Executive to step down

headline: NEW ART INSTALLATION BRINGS 'ASPECTS OF CARNIVAL'TO PORTOBELLO ROAD
prcopy:
A new installation created by local artist Fiona Hawthorne is the latest to transform a 100-metre stretch along Portobello Road's North Wall.

The work entitled `Aspects of Carnival', will be officially unveiled by the actor Colin Salmon at a launch event at the Tabernacle, Notting Hill, on Wednesday 1 May. Images of the installation will be projected throughout the evening.

`Aspects of Carnival' comprises thirteen panels, and will remain in situ for six months, including throughout the 2013 Notting Hill Carnival.

`Aspects of Carnival' celebrates what is undoubtedly the area's most significant contribution to contemporary culture: the Notting Hill Carnival. Fiona Hawthorne's paintings tell the full story of Carnival - from early preparations, through to the heady excitement of the Carnival procession itself, to the big clean-up in the early hours.

For over 15 years Fiona Hawthorne has designed and produced a large and successful Carnival arts masquerade project for young people, giving her an insight into what takes place behind the scenes to get the show on the road. `Aspects of Carnival' captures that adventure in a vibrant mix of paint and photographs, creating an extraordinary juxtaposition of colour, character and storytelling. Moreover, it expresses how Carnival fits into the community that owns it, and captures a genuine passion for reclaiming the streets. One of the first British artists to embrace digital technology, Hawthorne here mixes contemporary painterly expression with economic lines to produce 13 works of strong integrity.

This installation is part of `the Portobello Road North Wall Project', a public art programme from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea which enables contemporary artists to showcase their talent in one of London's most vibrant creative hubs and popular tourist destinations.

The Portobello Road North Wall connects two of the most exciting markets in London: Portobello Road Market and Golborne Road Market. Artists creating work for the wall are invited to explore the social, historical and creative context of the area. Portobello Road is one of London's most distinctive and creative areas, particularly linked to fashion, independent music and the Notting Hill Carnival.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Deputy Leader of the Council said:

"It is fitting that the new Portobello Wall installation should celebrate Carnival. For almost 50 years the streets of North Kensington have become alive with the sounds and thrilling spectacle of Carnival each August Bank Holiday weekend. However, Carnival is far more than a weekend event. It has deep and resonant roots in the local community, and animates its passion throughout the year.

"Fiona Hawthorne captures both the drama and spectacle of Notting Hill Carnival, and its central significance in the lives of the local people who create it. `Aspects of Carnival' is a wonderfully fitting tribute to Carnival, and an uplifting and joyous piece of creative work which I hope everyone who visits the wall will enjoy."
shortdescription: A new installation created by local artist Fiona Hawthorne is the latest to transform a 100-metre stretch along Portobello Road's North Wall.
shorttitle: New art installation brings 'Aspects of Carnival' to Portobello Road

headline: FORCED MARRIAGE SEMINAR
prcopy:
A seminar to discuss forced marriage and `honour' based violence is being held next month.

The event, on May 9, is being organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster.

There will be a free screening of Banaz - A Love Story, a documentary by Deeyah, an award-winning activist, producer, film maker, singer and co-founder of Honour Based Violence Awareness network.

The film, which premiered at the Raindance Film Festival in London last year, documents the life of Banaz Mahmod. Banaz was killed by her uncle and father in London in 2006, after she left her violent and abusive husband, and began a relationship with a family friend.

Banaz's father Mahmod and uncle Ari were convicted of her murder in June 2007, while two other men involved in her murder became the first people to be extradited from Iraq to Britain and were jailed for life in 2010.

There will be a question and answer session on `honour' based violence and forced marriages following the screening. The panelists are Deeyah, Detective Superintendent Caroline Goode of the Metropolitan Police, who led the investigation into Banaz's death and won a Queen's Award for her efforts, along with Diana Nammi from Iranian and Kurdish Women's Rights Organisation and Sophie Wright from the Government's Joint Forced Marriage Unit (Foreign and Commonwealth Office and Home Office).

The seminar runs between 9:30am and 1pm at the Great Hall, Kensington and Chelsea Town Hall, Hornton Street, Kensington, W8 7NX.

Cllr Rock Feilding- Mellen, Cabinet Member for Civil Society said: "'Honour' based crimes and forced marriages are appalling and unacceptable. Events like this are important as they help highlight that these practices breach human rights and have no place in our society."

This event is open to front-line professionals working in the public sector, voluntary sector, police, health, housing, social care, and education in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster.

To book your place at the seminar and for any access requirements, please contact Carly Fry by emailing PEIA@lbhf.gov.uk or calling 020 8753 3430.

headline: COUNCIL EXEMPT FROM NEW PLANNING RULES
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is one of just a small number of local authorities to be granted an exemption from new planning rules to be introduced by the Government that will allow offices to change into residential property without permission from local councils.

The Council campaigned for an exemption, citing the vast differences between office and residential property values in Kensington and Chelsea and the importance of defending the need for small and medium-sized businesses to be able to remain in the borough.

Councillor Sir Merrick Cockell, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "We made a very strong case to Ministers and I am very grateful to them for accepting the merits of our case and granting us this exemption.

"This decision is the best possible news for the borough and means we are well placed to preserve a healthy mix of residential and commercial property. The reality is the high value associated with residential property in the borough would almost certainly have led to us losing important small and medium-sized commercial premises and that, once converted into homes, these would be lost forever."

Residential values far exceed office values in Kensington and Chelsea. The strong desire for residential property in the borough is reflected in values of between £750 and £2,500 per sq ft. These are increasing; there has been a 50 per cent rise in residential prices since 2009, largely as a result of inward investment from overseas.

In contrast, typical office rental values range from £400 to £500 per sq m in the high value areas of Kensington High Street and Knightsbridge to £150 to £200 sq m in parts of north Kensington.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is one of just a small number of local authorities to be granted an exemption from new planning rules to be introduced by the Government that will allow offices to change into residential property without permission from local councils.
shorttitle: Council exempt from new planning rules

headline: FACELIFT FOR HOLBEIN HOUSE
prcopy:
A £3.3m project by housing association Guinness South to refurbish Holbein House in Chelsea is now complete. Specialist housing construction company United House have been working on the two high-rise mansion blocks since February 2012, replacing windows, undertaking works to the roof as well as the smoke ventilation system.

The building's 600 replacement sash windows had to be specially made and fitted to meet planning requirements and replicate the originals. Each new window had to be carefully carried up the stairs by three or four workers, up to six flights high. All brickwork was repaired and cleaned in keeping with nearby buildings, thanks to a £50,000 grant from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Chris Wait, Head of Programme and Planning at Guinness South, said: "The contractors were faced with many challenges on this site, one of which was that no large lorries were able to access the enclosed estate. All the scaffolding had to be carried on to the site so it took a long time to prepare the building for the works. Repairing the brickwork was not a simple job either; 23 different shapes and sizes of bricks were used and some had to be specially made. Residents and shopkeepers have been very patient whilst all the work was going on. Wind, rain and freezing conditions hindered us for a few weeks but now Holbein House almost looks like it did when it was first built in the late nineteenth century."

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Housing, said: "I am very pleased to see Holbein House looking so good after these important works and want to thank all those who have worked so hard to complete the project. I am sure that the residents, who have been so patient while the work was being carried out will be very pleased with the new look Holbein House."

One Holbein House resident who has lived in the building for several years said: "The workmen have been so well-mannered. They have shown me respect and kindness all the way through this enormous project. Now the building is so much brighter and clearer; I am amazed at all the colours in the brickwork, I didn't know there were red bricks under there. I think the contractors have done a tremendous job!"

headline: COUNCILLOR NICHOLAS PAGET-BROWN IS ROYAL BOROUGH'S LEADER ELECT
prcopy:
Councillor Nicholas Paget-Brown is the Leader elect of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. Chosen by his Conservative colleagues last night (Sunday 6 May), his appointment to the top job is set to be confirmed at the Council's Annual General Meeting on 22 May.

Speaking after his election Councillor Paget-Brown paid tribute to the outgoing Leader, Sir Merrick Cockell:

"We've had 13 years of low tax, high quality services and huge investment in buildings, streets and schools. It's a record of which we are very proud.

"Although the financial clouds are darkening, our residents continue to have the highest standards and expectations for the place they live in. They want a Council which is effective, responsive and puts their interests at the heart of all it does.

"One of the Council's main ambitions should be to give everyone an opportunity to succeed. That requires a cross-departmental approach to regeneration, with an effective, integrated approach to housing, training, transport, employment and crime reduction. We must continue to work with our long-established voluntary sector to build a sense of belonging to the community.

"At a time of hugely demanding financial pressure on local government, we must continue to set one of the lowest council tax levels in the country. To deliver this, we need to manage our budgets prudently, to keep costs down, make the most of our joint working with Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster; and generate more income from our assets."

First elected to the Council in 1986, Councillor Paget-Brown served as Chief Whip of the Conservative Group from 2000 to 2011 and has been Deputy Leader since April 2011.

He has also held a number of other senior positions. On the introduction of the Cabinet system in 2001, he served as Cabinet Member for Community Safety, Regeneration and the Voluntary Sector, overseeing the introduction of Council-funded Police Community Support Officers and the creation of a model "Safer Surer" Board consisting of the Borough Commander, Council Chief Executive and other officers.

In regeneration, he was responsible for a range of capital investment projects in North Kensington, including Baseline Studios, and for maintaining strong levels of employment support and training for local residents.

As Cabinet Member for Environment, Transport and Leisure he led the award-winning Exhibition Road streetscape refurbishment and the major renovation of Albert Bridge. He also launched the Council's first ever Arts and Culture Policy and has been responsible for the ongoing renewal of the borough's parks and gardens. In 2007 he launched the Royal Borough Environmental Project which has `greened' scores of `grot-spots' in corners of the borough and supported the creation of over 300 Community Kitchen Gardens.

Away from the Council, Nicholas Paget-Brown has a background in business and worked for a small start-up company in the City which established the UK's first online research service for financial institutions. This was acquired by Reuters in 1985 and he was appointed international marketing manager for a range of Reuters' research products with global responsibility for promoting them. In 1991 he set up Knight-Ridder Information's London office. Subsequently he set up a small consultancy business which produced a corporate newsletter on energy and environmental policy and offers training and consultancy on a range of public affairs issues.

Councillor Paget-Brown was Parliamentary candidate for Don Valley (a South Yorkshire Mining seat) in 1992 and chaired Kensington and Chelsea Conservative Association between 1999 and 2001, which included the period of Alan Clark's death, the selection of Michael Portillo and the subsequent by-election.

shorttitle: Councillor Nicholas Paget-Brown is Royal Borough's leader elect

headline: THREE LONDON COUNCILS £150M APPROVE COMBINED FACILITIES MANAGEMENT CONTRACT
prcopy:
Three London councils who are redefining the way local authorities operate and deliver services have approved an outsourced facilities management contract, valued at over £150m.

Amey, one of the UK's leading public services providers, has been awarded a contract to combine the facilities management services of Westminster City Council, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham.

The contract will run for ten years and is expected to save each of the three councils over £2m a year (equivalent to more than 34 per cent saving over current costs) through operational efficiency.

Amey will deliver facilities management services across a combined estate of nearly 2,000 buildings comprising 1.3 million square feet. It will include building security and maintenance as well as catering, landscaping, environmental management, cleaning and reception services.

Transfer of Undertakings and Protection of Employment (TUPE) regulations will apply for facilities management staff across the three boroughs.

All other London boroughs and schools will have the opportunity to buy into the service as partnering authorities.

Cllr Nicholas Paget-Brown, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "By sharing facilities management across the three councils we will be able to save money, protect front line services and keep taxes low during a time of unprecedented pressure on local government finances.

"Through our Tri-borough working we are proving to residents and other local authorities that this approach works and provides even better services."

Speaking about the contract award Mel Ewell, Chief Executive of Amey, said: "We are delighted to be selected as preferred supplier for this innovative total facilities management contract. Working collaboratively with the councils will bring together service delivery expertise from the public and private sector, helping us to achieve their vision of enhanced services and greater efficiencies.

"We look forward to delivering our commitments to the three councils as well as to the local community through employment and skills development."

The new collaboration between the three councils will add to the portfolio of services they already share.

Service mobilisation will begin in June and the contract is expected to start from October this year.

Cllr Nicholas Botterill, Leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Council, said: "In these difficult economic times, we are showing categorically that by making simple common-sense reforms like this it is possible to protect and even improve front line services."

Cllr Philipa Roe, Leader of Westminster added: "Combining back-office services and management costs in this manner is also helping us to reduce council tax and it is no surprise that our three councils are in Britain's top four for having low tax."

As a result of the Tri-borough approach the three councils are are on track to save £40 million a year by 2015/16.

The savings are being achieved by sharing children's services, adult social care and library services across the three boroughs significantly reducing senior and middle management overheads.

A sovereignty guarantee signed by the three councils ensures local accountability and decision making, with each individual council responsible for their own budgets, policies and service specification.

headline: TWITTER APPEAL FOR MAGIC WAND
prcopy:
The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster, who has raised over £150,000 towards the purchase of a Sonowand for use in brain surgery at Charing Cross Hospital, is turning to London Twitter users to raise a little bit more.

A Sonowand, which helps surgeons operate more accurately by converting pre-operative MRI scans into a virtual reconstruction of the brain, costs £250,000.

Each year over 800 Londoners are diagnosed with a brain, central nervous system or intracranial tumour and sadly the prognosis is not good. Brain tumours have a very low survival rate and are responsible for more deaths in children and people under the age of 40 years than any other cancer. Astonishingly less than two per cent of cancer research funding goes into brain tumours which are the Cinderella cancer.

Cllr Buckmaster, who chose the Brain Tumour Research Campaign as his mayoral charity after a close friend was diagnosed with a brain tumour, explained: "I started the campaign to increase public awareness of the desperate need for more funding and to raise funds for research at Charing Cross Hospital and specifically to help purchase a new and revolutionary surgical tool called the Sonowand.

"You know when you hear the news that someone close to you is affected you desperately want to do something to make the whole ghastly thing go away. I could not wave a magic wand to make it that happen so that is why I have raised funds to help buy a Sonowand which will improve the surgical outcome for brain tumour patients.

"People have been incredibly generous and through various events we have raised £150,000 I am now appealing to Londoners on Twitter to help me wave the wand one more time and see if we can raise some more to help the Magic Wand appeal.

"Any donation however small will go to a very good cause to improve the surgical outcome of Londoners being treated at Charing Cross Hospital."

If you would like to make a small donation go to www.wayahead-btrc.org or email mayor@rbkc.gov.uk
