headline: BLOOMING MARVELLOUS GARDENING EVENTS
prcopy:
The popularity of gardens and garden-related activities, evidenced by the appreciation of the Chelsea Flower Show, is spreading throughout the Royal Borough with a month-long series of garden-themed community events.

The exciting programme of activities kicked off at World's End Estate, SW10 on Saturday 18 May.

Younger children enjoyed a messy art workshop, while young and old created wildflower seed bombs for planting. The Royal Borough's community gardeners Will and Lisa were on hand to offer gardening advice. While those residents that prefer relaxing out of doors rather than actually grafting and weeding sat back and enjoyed the Garden Cabaret.

Other events planned later in May and early June include a plant swap stall in Earl's Court, tour of the borough's community gardens and a Green Man Tea Party at Wornington Green. For more information go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/chelseafringe or environment@rbkc.gov.uk

The community activities are part of the Chelsea Fringe festival, which promotes a love of gardens and gardening. The Chelsea Fringe coincides and overlaps with the Royal Horticultural Society (RHS) Chelsea Flower Show but is completely independent of it and run mainly by volunteers.

In 2009 the Royal Borough started developing underused plots of land as community gardens and creating `aplotments' for residents to grow vegetables, fruit and herbs. There are now 40 community gardens with 700 residents working on their own plots.

The Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for the Environment and Council leader elect, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, said: "Gardening is one of the most popular pastimes and something that young and old can enjoy together.

"These events offer residents a chance to enjoy the community aspects of gardening and the arts, whether that is getting stuck in and planting flowers or sitting back and enjoying music and poetry."
shortdescription: The popularity of gardens and garden-related activities, evidenced by the appreciation of the Chelsea Flower Show, is spreading throughout the Royal Borough with a month-long series of garden-themed community events.
shorttitle: Blooming marvellous gardening events

headline: SPECIALIST PARENTING ADVICE FOR ADOPTIVE PARENTS
prcopy:
Three London councils, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council, and Hammersmith & Fulham Council, are set to provide a series of 16-week programmes of support and advice for adoptive parents of older children after successfully bidding for a Department of Education grant.

The Tri-borough councils and the Tavistock and Portman NHS Foundation Trust have secured a £140,000 grant to fund the AdOpt training and support programme, which is aimed at providing specialist parenting advice to adoptive parents of three to eight year-old children.

It is hoped that the programme will encourage people who are thinking about adoption to come forward to adopt older children, some of whom can have more complex needs than children who were adopted as babies. In addition to providing families with one-to-one support the scheme will provide parents with the opportunity to meet and share experiences with others who have also adopted older children.

The results of the two-year programme will be scrutinised by Department of Education officials and could influence future policies relating to the care of vulnerable children.

The three councils already work together to provide support and training for potential adopters but the new programme will mean they can increase what is currently made available to parents post-adoption for children who, though young, may have experienced trauma in their short lives.

Welcoming the grant the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Families and Children's Service, Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, said: "The AdOpt programme will allow us to provide targeted support to adoptive parents of older children who can display challenging behaviour. It could make a real difference between a placement succeeding or failing and will provide an opportunity to help parents caring for those who are most in need."

The grant is from the Department of Education's Intensive Interventions programme for looked after children and those on those on the edge of care.

Hammersmith & Fulham's Cabinet Member for Children's Service, Cllr Helen Binmore said: "No matter how wonderful being a parent is, there are times, however, when it can be incredibly challenging. This extra funding will allow us to offer more advice, guidance and practical support to adoptive parents of some of our most vulnerable children, and help families to knit together well from the start. We always need more potential adopters to share their homes and lives, and I hope that this added support and funding will make more people come forward."

Westminster Cabinet Member for Children and Young People Cllr Danny Chalkley added: " I have pledged that adoption is a top priority in Westminster, and we are determined to build upon our strong track record so that more children who have suffered abuse and neglect can benefit from the security of a permanent loving home.

headline: A VERY SPECIAL BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION
prcopy:
The Mayor and Mayoress of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea presented a lifelong resident of the borough with a telegram from Her Majesty The Queen on her 100th birthday.

Local resident Catherine Baxter celebrated her 100th birthday on Saturday 11 May.

Staff at Octavia's Miranda House in North Kensington W11 organised a celebration with all of Catherine's family and friends as well as the Mayor, Councillor Christopher Buckmaster and Mayoress, Mrs Anne Hobson who presented Catherine with a telegram of congratulations from the Queen.

Mrs Baxter was born in St Katherine's Road, now known as Wilsham Street, in 1913 and has lived in the borough her whole life. She attended St Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Primary School in Treadgold Street and married her late husband John Baxter in 1934 at St Francis of Assisi Church in Notting Hill Gate. They had 54 happy years of marriage, having four children together who went on to give them 16 grandchildren, 15 great-grandchildren and four great-great-grandchildren.

To celebrate on the day itself, the staff at Octavia's Miranda House organised a big birthday party with food and music for all of Mrs Baxter's family, friends from the local Quest Day Centre, and the residents and staff.

The Mayor said: "We are delighted to attend the celebration of the centenary year of Mrs Catherine Baxter's life to present her with the telegram from Her Majesty The Queen. It is wonderful to meet a local resident who was born and raised in the borough and still calls it home 100 years on."
Nicola McGlashen, Manager at Miranda House extra care scheme said: "It is such a privilege for all of the team at Miranda House to join in this celebration with Mrs Baxter on this special day. I hope there are many more birthdays to come."

When asked how she felt about turning 100 Mrs Baxter said: "I didn't realise I was an old lady".
shortdescription: The Mayor and Mayoress of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea presented a lifelong resident of the borough with a telegram from Her Majesty The Queen on her 100th birthday.
shorttitle: A very special birthday celebration

headline: LOCAL STREETS MARKETS CELEBRATED
prcopy:
The vibrancy and diversity of local street markets were celebrated at the launch of Love Your Local Market Fortnight (LYLM) on Wednesday 15 May at the historic Portobello and Golborne Road Market.

Minister of State at the Department of Communities and Local Government (DCLG), Mark Prisk, MP, Parliamentary Under Secretary of DCLG, Don Forster, MP, joined the Leader of the Royal Borough Cllr Nick Paget-Brown and the National Association of British Market Authorities (NAMBA) president, Geraldine Carter, for a tour of the markets where they met new market entrepreneurs, local school children and established market traders.

Portobello and Gorlborne Road Market was chosen for the launch after NAMBA named it Best Outdoor Market of the Year 2013.

As part of the fortnight street markets throughout the country offered taster stalls to people who want to try their hand at market trading.

Portobello and Golborne Market teamed up with a nearby private market, Portobello Green Fashion Market, and offered 300 pitches at just £10 a day.

Two young entrepreneurs, each of whom competed in the Council's Market Enterprise Launch Pad programme, used the fortnight to run stalls and market test their products. Medina Mukhayer sells East African food and cultural goods and Remaro Hibbert runs a positive message fashion label called `Point of View'.

Speaking before the launch of the LYLM fortnight, Council Leader elect, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, said: "This is a great opportunity to celebrate the entrepreneurial spirit of local markets and their importance to the local high street by encouraging people to shop locally.

"I am delighted that Portobello and Golborne Market has been chosen to launch Love Your Local Market Fortnight. In these challenging times it is great to see our markets continue to thrive and I wish all our traders, both new taster stallholders and established market people, every success."

headline: DAVIES MUST TEST AIRPORT CLAIMS
prcopy:
The all-party 2M Group of local authorities has warned that new proposals for extra runway capacity will fall at the first hurdle if they are not backed by scientific fact.

The campaign alliance, which includes boroughs affected by aircraft noise, has submitted its first report to Sir Howard Davies Aviation Commission which spells out how Heathrow's previous bid for a third runway was based on wholly inadequate environmental assessments.

A High Court judge subsequently ruled against the scheme.

The councils say the only way for the commission to succeed is for each proposal to be publicly scrutinised against credible, consistent benchmarks.

The group insists this process must be completely transparent if affected communities are to have any trust or confidence in the commission's recommendations.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "The overriding task for the commission must be to win the confidence of those who will pay the price for any expansion - wherever it is located. It is for these reasons we urge Sir Howard to publish the assessment methodology so this can be opened for public debate.

"Previous Heathrow schemes have fallen by the wayside because the promoters failed to spell out the true environmental, financial and human costs. Without this discipline there can be no confidence that the business case has been properly evaluated and the environmental impacts for local communities fully articulated."

In 2010, Lord Justice Carnwath ruled a third runway `untenable' and 2M says the airport is subject to the same constraints today:

 The area around Heathrow currently exceeds EU pollution limits due to aviation emissions and congestion on surrounding roads
 The additional rail infrastructure required to support additional runway capacity has not been identified
 A credible, contemporary measure for the onset of community annoyance from noise has not been established.

The councils assert that a robust assessment of Heathrow's noise, transport and air quality impacts will rule out new runways, rule out more intensive use of existing runways and highlight the need to phase out early morning flights.

The 2M Group is an all-party alliance of local authorities concerned about the environmental impact of Heathrow operations on their communities.

Members are not anti-Heathrow but work together to improve the environment and protect the quality of life for local people.

The group, which took its name from the two million residents of the original 12 authorities, now represents a combined population of five million people and was successful in 2010 in overturning plans for a third runway at the airport.

The group's priority at this stage of the review process is to make the commission fully aware of the environmental impacts that flow from any set of proposals submitted for the Heathrow site.

The group recently published research highlighting the new areas of London which could be affected by flight path noise if two new runways are built on the site.

2M also warns that more runway capacity will not guarantee better connections between London and emerging markets. In practice the airlines will use extra runway slots to fly to the most profitable routes, not untested new services to cities in China.

For example, when BA bought up BMI's runway slots they used their increased capacity to fly more services to Alicante.
shortdescription: The all-party 2M Group of local authorities has warned that new proposals for extra runway capacity will fall at the first hurdle if they are not backed by scientific fact.
shorttitle: Davies must test airport claims

headline: THE ECCENTRICITY OF ZERO
prcopy:
The latest piece of contemporary art to be unveiled in Holland Park is `The Eccentricity of Zero' by Sinta Tantra. The highly sought after spot in the Napoleon Garden has been used as a springboard for new artists for some years.

At the unveiling ceremony on Wednesday 22 May, Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, the Leader of the Council and former Cabinet Member for Leisure, was joined by the artist and Council officers.

Councillor Paget-Brown said: "The Council has been encouraging new artists with the opportunity to show their work in one of the premier sites for contemporary sculpture in London for over a decade.

"The Eccentricity of Zero will attract many visitors and I am sure it will generate a great deal of discussion. I'm delighted that Sinta agreed to have her art shown in the Napoleon Garden."

Commenting on her work, Sinta said: "The sculpture plays on the idea of the garden as a labyrinth, of lovers chasing each other, of veiled flirtations and words left unspoken. The round glass panels act like fluid screens where organic, human and architectural structures are contained, heightened and reflected. As sunlight passes through the geometric spreads of colour, nature and the viewer become incorporated into the work and act as the catalysts to enliven it."

The Napoleon Garden works are curated by the Royal British Society of Sculptors.

headline: FLOWER SHOW SUCCESS FOR TRAILFINDERS
prcopy:
The new Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams, has congratulated Trailfinders after its `Australian Garden' won the RHS Chelsea Flower Show `Best in Show' award.

In a letter to Mike Gooley, the founder of the Kensington-based travel company, the Mayor praised its garden and said: "To those of us who have seen how you have so successfully grown Trailfinders here in the Royal Borough, it is very fitting that you have enjoyed this success at Chelsea. The Chelsea Flower Show is every bit as competitive as the travel business and against such stiff opposition the Trailfinders garden did enormously well to take Best Show Garden."

Trailfinders has arranged travel for more than ten million people since being set up in Earl's Court in 1970. The company now handles about 50,000 phone enquires a week and has 24 travel centres across the UK and three in Ireland.

The company's centre of operations remains in Kensington with its head office in Abingdon Road.

The award-winning garden, created by Fleming's Nurseries of Victoria, featured native Australian plants including kangaroo paws and bottle trees. The design by Philip Johnson of Philip Johnson Landscapes, aimed to show the possibilities of sustainable landscaping within an urban setting.
shortdescription: The new Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams, has congratulated Trailfinders after its `Australian Garden' won the RHS Chelsea Flower Show `Best in Show' award.
shorttitle: Flower show success for Trailfinders

headline: CELEBRATING THE BOROUGH'S VOLUNTEERS
prcopy:
The role volunteers play in Kensington and Chelsea and across the country is being celebrated during Volunteers Week (1 to 7 June).

One borough resident, who has benefited from the care and support he received at St Mungo's, has spent the past two years working as a volunteer, helping homeless people, with West London Churches.

Loris Kamba (39) decided that volunteering would give him an opportunity to help people and also improve his chances of finding paid employment.

His efforts in the community involve working as a kitchen porter and cleaner with West London Churches, which run services for homeless people.

Because of his own experiences of homelessness, Loris can identify with the struggles the people he is now helping face. He gives three days a week of his time to his volunteering work. Speaking about what it means to him to be a volunteer, Loris said: "I enjoy serving people and being on hand to help. Volunteering is a chance to give something back to the community and it can also be great fun. The people I work with are friendly and they trust me which makes me feel good and increases my own self esteem.

"I think I am respected by those I work with who know I'm not there for the money. I really hope that the experience I have gained working as a volunteer will help me get references which will help me find full-time paid work.

"I'd like to encourage anyone out there who has time and would like to help. That would make them a good person and they'll make friends. Anyone who volunteers will find something good in it."
Cliff Dymond, St Mungo's area manager for Kensington and Chelsea, said "St Mungo's has worked in Kensington and Chelsea for 20 years, housing and supporting over 120 vulnerable men and women at any one time in a variety of accommodation settings in partnership with the borough. Our clients have experienced homelessness and difficult personal circumstances including relationship breakdown, mental health problems and drug and alcohol issues.

"We provide personalised support, including enabling clients to access volunteering, training and employment opportunities as well as addressing other issues and achieving independent living. The confidence and self-esteem that our residents get from volunteering and helping others is vital in their recovery."

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, said: "I'd like to thank all those who give up their time to help others in the borough. Their dedication, patience and expertise can, in some cases, transform people's lives."

Anyone interested in finding out more about the sort of opportunities there are to become a volunteer in Kensington and Chelsea can contact the Volunteer Centre Kensington & Chelsea, on 020 8960 3722.

Those interested in volunteering for St Mungo's can contact St Mungo's Volunteer Services, 020 7902 7973.
shortdescription: The role volunteers play in Kensington and Chelsea and across the country is being celebrated during Volunteers Week (1 to 7 June).
shorttitle: Celebrating the borough's volunteers

headline: NEW BUSES FOR CHELSEA
prcopy:
A new-look bus will be seen in Chelsea from 21 September after TfL chose the number 11 route as the second in the capital to be entirely served by the New Bus for London.

The number 11 route runs from Liverpool Street Station to Fulham Broadway - taking in the full length of the King's Road and many other tourist attractions.

Certainly cleaner and greener than its predecessors, the new diesel-electric hybrid vehicles have been shown to emit a quarter of the PM and NOx emissions of an average hybrid bus and 20 per cent less carbon dioxide.

News of TfL's decision was welcomed by Cllr Mrs Frances Taylor, Chairman of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Public Transport and Road Safety Liaison Group, who had lobbied for the new bus to come through the borough.

Cllr Mrs Frances Taylor said: "I am very pleased that the new-look number 11 is coming to the borough. The New Bus for London is very well designed and will soon be a familiar sight around Sloane Square and along the King's Road."
shortdescription: A new-look bus will be seen in Chelsea from 21 September after TfL chose the number 11 route as the second in the capital to be entirely served by the New Bus for London.
shorttitle: New buses for Chelsea

headline: TAEKWONDO SUCCESS FOR BOROUGH CLUB
prcopy:
The Taekwondo Tigers from Chelsea and Fulham enjoyed medal success in the Capital Cup London.

A team of 29 competitors, from under-11s to adults, took part, winning eight gold medals, ten silver medals and three bronze medals. The team also won the fourth place team trophy.

There were some exceptional performances especially from Shophia Javid, Jordan Ashley, and Yasmina Habibollah who all won gold medals. The Capital Cup attracted more than 600 competitors from all over the UK as well as teams from France and Holland.

Davoud Etminani, the chief instructor of the Taekwondo Tigers and former Team GB member said: "I am well happy with our team performance, we have been working very hard towards the Capital Cup. It was a competition for all age and ability groups, I think everyone involved; parents, competitors and coaches, enjoyed the weekend. This is a stepping stone for us, we are back to train hard and improve towards our future goals.

"In our club we train towards many different goals. Regardless of whether our members just simply want to keep or get fit or aim to become a future World and Olympic champion, we offer them a carefully planned program teaching self-defence, cardiovascular fitness, strength development, flexibility and Olympic-style fighting techniques. I would like to see Taekwondo Tigers producing European, World and Olympic champions in a near future. Of course we have to work very hard towards it but we have the potential to do that. I would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone involved in Capital Cup and send my special thanks to my competitors and coaching team who worked hard to make it happen."

The Taekwondo Tigers train at Chelsea Sports Centre and their coaches work with Council staff to provide instruction for children during the school holidays.

headline: COUNCIL SEEKS VIEWS ON A CROSSRAIL 2 STATION IN CHELSEA
prcopy:
The Council is asking Chelsea residents and businesses to make their views known on the idea of a Crossrail station on King's Road. This is to help the Council produce its response to a consultation by Transport for London (TfL) on its plans for a new railway line crossing London, called Crossrail 2. This would be a major new rail link connecting south-west and north-east London. TfL believes the line could help address overcrowding on several Tube and rail lines.

TfL is consulting on two different route alignments, both of which would include a line running under Chelsea and a station on King's Road. It would link Chelsea to Clapham Junction, the West End and four of central London's busiest mainline stations.

This is a long-term project in the early planning stages. If the line were to go ahead, construction would begin in the mid-2020s, and open in about 20 years' time.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "The idea of a line running under Chelsea has been around for many years. In fact, we consulted residents about it ten years ago and most thought it would be a good thing. But that was ten years ago and I want to know what local people think of the idea today. I would also urge everyone who is interested in the proposal to respond directly to TfL.

"I hope as many residents and businesses as possible take the opportunity to let us, and TfL, know what they think."

Copies of the Council's survey document have been posted to residents.

The TfL consultation will run until Friday 2 August.

Residents and businesses can find out more about Crossrail 2 at www.crossrail2.co.uk
shortdescription: The Council is asking Chelsea residents and businesses to make their views known on the idea of a Crossrail station on King's Road. This is to help the Council produce its response to a consultation by Transport for London (TfL) on its plans for a new railway line crossing London, called Crossrail 2. This would be a major new rail link connecting south-west and north-east London. TfL believes the line could help address overcrowding on several Tube and rail lines.
shorttitle: Council seeks views on a Crossrail 2 station in Chelsea

headline: LAUNCH OF BOOKS ON PRESCRIPTION SCHEME
prcopy:
The Reading Well Books on Prescription scheme, sponsored by the Reading Agency, is being rolled out across libraries in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster and Hammersmith & Fulham in June. It will allow GPs and mental health professionals to recommend over twenty different expert-endorsed self-help books to those suffering mental health problems.

To launch the scheme in the Royal Borough there will be an event on Wednesday 5 June at Brompton Library from 2pm to 4pm. The event is open to health professionals and the general public to attend with taster activities and information available.

Self-help books can help people understand and manage common conditions, including depression and anxiety. Individuals with mild to moderate mental health conditions often use self-help books as an early intervention or additional treatment.

The scheme will offer patients the opportunity to understand and manage the condition with the aid of a book as an early intervention, an alternative or additional therapy.

headline: GOING FOR GOLD
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea marked the launch of this year's entry into London in Bloom 2013 in Holland Park (Friday 31 May).

The Chairman of London in Bloom, Geoff Hyde, joined the Mayor of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams, the Leader of the Royal Borough, Councillor Nicholas Paget-Brown and the Cabinet Member for Environment and Leisure, Councillor Tim Ahern, to officially mark the borough's entry into London in Bloom.

Also attending the event were the Chairman of Brighter Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Tony Holt and a number of the London in Bloom judges, community groups, local businesses, residents and gardening groups.

Launching the event, the Mayor, said: "It is a privilege to be Mayor of the Royal Borough and be involved in something as impressive as London in Bloom".

Councillor Ahern, said: "I'm very pleased that we are maintaining our commitment to London in Bloom and delighted to now be the Cabinet Member with responsibility for parks and open spaces.

"I know everyone who lives, works and visits the borough enjoys the wonderful public and private spaces that can be seen. They combine to provide a memorable atmosphere that is part of what makes the borough such a great place to live.

"The theme of this year's in Bloom competition is `eat London'. When the judges come to look at the borough they will be able to see dozens of community kitchen gardens which we have been creating, with considerable support from local communities, in the past few years.

"I hope we can build on the Sliver Gilt award the borough received in 2012 and go for gold this year. I encourage residents who want to take part to get their trowel out and get digging."


If you want to take part in London in Bloom, but aren't sure what to plant or how to look after what you grow, ask the Plant Doctor any questions by emailing plant.doctor@rbkc.gov.uk

London in Bloom encourages communities of all sizes to make positive and lasting changes to their areas. This includes imaginative planting, cleanliness, sustainability and community effort.

headline: PUBLIC MEETING ON FUTURE OF LONDON FIRE BRIGADE
prcopy:
Royal Borough residents and businesses have until Monday 17 June to have their say on the future of the London Fire Brigade.

The London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority (LFEPA) is consulting on its Draft Fifth London Safety Plan and it is important that residents and businesses in the Royal Borough take the chance to study the proposals and let decision makers know what they think.

A public meeting about the plans will be held in the Small Hall at Kensington Town Hall, W8 on Monday 10 June between 7pm and 9pm.

The plan sets out how the fire and rescue service could be delivered over the next few years. Amongst other things, it includes plans for target times for getting to incidents and details of how savings of nearly £30m could be made. These proposals involve the closure of 12 fire stations in London, including Knightsbridge and Westminster, and the removal of 18 fire engines across the capital, with one of Chelsea Fire Station's two engines going. The proposals also include the reduction of 520 fire fighter posts.

Councillor Joanna Gardner, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Community Safety, said: "The proposals contained in the Draft Fifth London Safety Plan would see the closure of one fire station in the borough and one in nearby Westminster as well as Chelsea Fire Station losing an engine. This is clearly of concern to the Council and to the residents and businesses, not only of Kensington and Chelsea, but also of Westminster. It is very important that residents and businesses look at the proposals and make their feelings known to the London Fire and Emergency Planning Authority."

For full details of the plan proposals and to take part in an online consultation go to:
www.London-fire.gov.uk/LSP5

Alternatively, if you would like a copy of the plan and consultation document call the LFEPA on 0800 9888 569.
shortdescription: Royal Borough residents and businesses have until Monday 17 June to have their say on the future of the London Fire Brigade.
shorttitle: Public meeting on the future of London Fire Brigade

headline: MENTORS SHOW THE WAY TO EDUCATIONAL ACHIEVEMENT
prcopy:
A project, involving the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, which uses mentors to improve the overall prospects for children in the care of local authorities was celebrated at an event attended by the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson.

The event, attended by over 100 people, was hosted in London's Living Room at City Hall. The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was well represented by young people and staff involved in the `Near Peer Mentoring Project'. Glen Peache, the Royal Borough's Head of Family and Care Resources, presented the opening key note speech and talked about the positive achievements of the mentoring project.

Two young people from Kensington and Chelsea, a mentor and a mentee, talked about their experiences and achievements since joining the project. The mentor spoke about the useful work skills he has gained as well as the satisfaction of helping young people. The mentee talked about how the mentoring had helped him achieve great educational results including a B in GCSE English even though he is only 13 years old. He also spoke about becoming better able to manage his emotions and feeling more confident speaking in front of large groups of people.

The `Near Peer Mentoring Project' provides looked after children with a mentor, who is on a positive educational or employment trajectory and has also been in Council care, to support them to engage positively with education. The mentor gives practical advice and support whilst helping the looked after child to build enhanced self-belief and higher aspirations.

Seven London boroughs: the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Bexley, Lewisham, Royal Borough of Greenwich, Islington, Hackney and Croydon took part in the project, which was also supported by the Mayor of London.

In Kensington and Chelsea mentoring began in October 2010 and is clearly focused on matching looked after children with care leavers to support not only their academic, but also personal and social relationships. As well as concentrating on young people's educational attendance and performance, significant attention is given to the underlying issues behind poor attendance and performance. As well as providing bespoke educational support and tuition, the Council looks at issues such as: lack of confidence; low self-esteem; anger; conflict problems; poor behaviour; inability to make and maintain friendships, and relationships with adults and issues with authority.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "It has been clear for far too long that the educational prospects of children in local authority care lag behind those of other children. I am very pleased that we have been able to take part in this mentoring project which is already showing some really positive outcomes.

"We have tried to match our looked after children with mentors who, although older, share the same background and the same experiences. This has given our looked after children the chance to talk about things such as their future careers, what university is like, how to apply and the importance of achieving good grades."

The Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, said: "Giving young people positive role models is invaluable in helping to raise their aspirations and achieve goals. The `Near Peer Mentoring Project' has proved this perfectly, with youngsters paired with mentors not only boosting their attendance at school but also improving their grades. I'd like to thank everyone involved in the project and, in particular, the mentors, who have given their time so generously to help young people in care."
shortdescription: A project, involving the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, which uses mentors to improve the overall prospects for children in the care of local authorities was celebrated at an event attended by the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson.
shorttitle: Mentors show the way to educational achievement

headline: LONDON SEES SURGE IN USE OF CLUB DRUGS AND 'LEGAL HIGHS' - WITH MIDDLE-AGED USERS MOST AT RISK
prcopy:
Demand for treatment for so-called `legal highs' and club drugs continues to increase in London with a pioneering London clinic seeing those over 30 experiencing the greatest problems. Patients range in age from 16 to 62 years old.

The profile of users of recreational drugs contradicts the traditional stereotype of the teenage reveller. Instead, new figures from Westminster and Kensington and Chelsea councils and the Central North West London NHS Trust, paints a disturbing portrait of drug users who may be unaware of the risks of weekend drug taking.

The Club Drug Clinic, managed by Central and North West London NHS foundation Trust, has seen a steady increase in demand since opening in 2010. 60 per cent of users are older members of the LGBT (Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender) community with the remaining 40 per cent being students and clubbers.

The clinic now sees up to 40 people each month and the average age of users presenting for treatment is 30 to 35 with often several years of recreational use, becoming increasingly harmful. Doctors fear older party goers are coming to harm due to the effects of longer term use of drugs like ketamine, mephedrone, GBL and methamphetamine.

Demand for treatment has been so great that the service has opened a second clinic in central London, amongst the capital's busiest clubs and bars.

The clinic is part-funded by the councils, Westminster and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea as part of their Public Health function, and run by Central and North West London NHS Foundation Trust and based at the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital.

Dr Owen Bowden-Jones, Consultant and Founder of the Clinic, said: "We are seeing a change in the pattern of drug use, as more people start to use `legal highs' and so-called club drugs. Many users aren't stereotypical teenage revellers, but older people with jobs and responsibilities.

"Many people who take these drugs like GBL, Ketamine and Methamphetamine don't see themselves as `traditional' drug users as they're not taking Heroin or Crack Cocaine and so don't know where to turn for help when they develop problems. Newer trends have seen a huge growth in internet purchasing of `legal highs'. These drugs are often research chemicals which have been developed for their psychoactive effects but which have never been tested for safety. When we set the clinic up, we thought the primary users would be teenage clubbers, but we have seen lots of people in their 30s and members of the LGBT community. That pattern is slowly changing, partly due to work the clinic has been doing with universities.

"Our clinic is unique in offering help to people from all across the UK, who have come into central London, rather than just our own residents, which means that we get a national picture of drug use."

Cllr Rachael Robathan, Westminster Council's Cabinet Member for Public Health, said: "People making these so-called `legal highs' are continually changing their chemical make-up, with a new product coming onto the market every week. We are told that people are increasingly buying them online, rather than in a club corridor, making the behaviour seem less of a problem and more acceptable, meaning users are often reluctant to seek help.

"The continuing increase in use of these drugs is incredibly worrying as people could be buying anything. We want to make people aware of the problem and encourage users to seek the help available."

Cllr Mary Weale, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Public Health, said: "It is important that people are aware of the risk of these 'legal high' drugs. There is no room for complacency when drug use and addiction are such contributors to ill health. We must offer recovery-orientated treatment and make recreational drug users aware of the problems they face and the help that is available."

shortdescription: Demand for treatment for so-called `legal highs' and club drugs continues to increase in London with a pioneering London clinic seeing those over 30 experiencing the greatest problems. Patients range in age from 16 to 62 years old.
shorttitle: London sees surge in use of club drugs and `legal highs' middle-aged users most at risk

headline: EASY WAYS TO REPORT HELICOPTER CONCERNS
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea residents with concerns about helicopter activity in the borough are being advised to report them online or over the phone.

The reminder comes ahead of major events in the sporting calendar which can cause an increase in helicopter movements into and out of the Barclays London Heliport in Lombard Road, Battersea.

These include the British F1 Grand Prix and Royal Ascot from 18 to 22 June.

Helicopters landing at Battersea should approach from either the north-east or south-east and normally follow the middle of the river for as long as possible before turning to descend. Take-off direction depends upon the prevailing wind but should also be toward the middle of the river in the first instance.

Where, for safety reasons, helicopters fly on the north or south side of the river they should keep a minimum height of 1,000ft for all but the initial take-off or final descent.

Any resident who suspects an incident has occurred where procedures have not been followed, or who has other concerns related to the heliport, can report it at www.londonheliport.co.uk or by calling 020 7228 0181.

Resident representatives, heliport users and councillors from Wandsworth, Hammersmith & Fulham and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea make up the London Heliport Consultative Group - which exists to receive reports on helicopter movements and review complaints associated with the site.

The group has the backing of the owner of the heliport, which is responsible for about a third of helicopter activity in London.

The consultative group has produced a useful guide for residents which explains the correct procedures for helicopter approaches and take-offs.

Copies of the guide are available from the heliport or by calling Wandsworth Council on 020 8871 7524. Alternatively, you can download one from the council's website www.wandsworth.gov.uk

For more information on the work of the consultative group, visit www.wandsworth.gov.uk/heliport. This includes contact details for complaints about police or military helicopters.
shortdescription: Kensington and Chelsea residents with concerns about helicopter activity in the borough are being advised to report them online or over the phone.
shorttitle: Easy ways to report helicopter concerns

headline: WORLD FIRST: AVONDALE PARK'S FLORAL LAWN
prcopy:
The world's first grass-free lawn, made of pretty native and non-native wildflowers, colourful ornamental cultivars and some interesting non-native species, is settling in well at Avondale Park in North Kensington.

Comprising over 65 different plants the lawn provides an eye-catching and colourful patchwork of flowers and herbs to delight and intrigue park users as well as providing a source of nectar throughout its growing season which runs from March to November.

The initial reaction to the colourful lawn from local children and adults is very positive.

It is hoped that the lawn will enhance the biodiversity potential of Avondale Park and will provide bees, butterflies and other pollinators with a foraging habitat.

The project is the result of collaboration between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Lionel Smith, a PhD student at the University of Reading who came up with the idea for the lawn.

By completely replacing grass with over 65 varieties of carefully selected plants, all grown in the Council's nursery in Holland Park, it has been possible to create a highly biodiverse sward.

When the floral lawn is bedded in park users will be able to get close to it and view, smell and touch the flowers and plants. But the lawn is not designed to provide a replacement for grass as it cannot tolerate high footfall.

The new lawn requires much less maintenance than a regular grass lawn requiring only occasional mowing and very little watering.

The Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern, said: "This floral lawn is one our most innovative measures to date to enhance the biodiversity and sustainability of our local environment.

"If successful the floral lawn will improve the diversity of Avondale Park and we will look to roll it out across the borough. We have long recognised that the Royal Borough is a very attractive place for humans to live and we want to ensure that we make it very attractive for other creatures to make their homes in it, which will undoubtedly benefit all."

Lawn creator Lionel Smith said: "It has been designed to be interactive and sensory. It is a whole mix of ornamental cultivars and of British natives as well as including some foreign things.

"By being beautiful it aids the pollinators, the bees, the butterflies, the insects, diversity is at least a third greater than a standard British lawn and the number of species is much greater usually about twenty-five per cent more as well. By being beautiful it is actually being beautiful in the greatest and widest of senses."

Avondale Park is one of the borough's Sites of Importance for Nature Conservation, and was designated for its value to local biodiversity. The floral lawn is just the latest addition designed to increase biodiversity and takes its place alongside loggeries, nest boxes and seeded wildflower meadows.

The species in the lawn were grown in Holland Park nursery over the past six months by the Council's Park's Team and Quadron Services the Counci's parks maintenance contractor.

shorttitle: World first: Avondale Park's floral lawn

headline: COUNCIL SUCCESS IN FIGHT AGAINST FRAUD
prcopy:
A man who falsely claimed more than £10,000 in housing benefits was found guilty of dishonestly failing to notify the Council of a change in his circumstances at Westminster Magistrates Court last week.

Mr George Scott (65) rented a flat in Edith Grove, SW10 and claimed housing benefit whilst unemployed.

Following an anonymous tip off, investigation officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea discovered that Mr Scott had vacated his property to reside with his girlfriend in a neighbouring borough and then sublet the flat for £975 per month. Between December 2011 and June 2012 he had fraudulently obtained housing benefit of £10,661.64. During the trial it also emerged that Mr Scott failed to notify the Council that he was working and he had inherited and significant amount of money.

Hearing the case, the Justices concluded that Mr Scott had, throughout his evidence, failed to recall or lied. They stated that he contradicted his interview and he repeatedly showed that he was prepared to lie. They further stated that he was clever and capable, therefore emphatically rejecting his defence that he had suffered cognitive difficulties following a stroke which meant that he did not appreciate what he was required to notify the Council.

Mr Scott was sentenced to 24 weeks' imprisonment, suspended for two years and ordered to carry out 150 hours unpaid work. He was also ordered to repay the fraudulently obtained benefit totalling £2,891

Speaking after the hearings Cllr Warwick Lightfoot, Cabinet Member for Finance, said: "I condemn anyone who abuses the benefits system for their own gain. There are many people in genuine need and what Mr Scott did was totally unacceptable.

"I hope this case sends out a clear message that not only is the Council determined to stop people deliberately abusing the system, but also the courts take this seriously as well."
shortdescription: A man who falsely claimed more than £10,000 in housing benefits was found guilty of dishonestly failing to notify the Council of a change in his circumstances at Westminster Magistrates Court last week.
shorttitle: Council success in fight against fraud

headline: COUNCIL URGES RESIDENTS TO RESPOND TO FIRE SERVICE CONSULTATION
prcopy:
A public meeting on the future of London's Fire Brigade held at Kensington Town Hall on Monday 10 June attracted 80 residents.

They were there to hear about the London Safety Plan (LSP) which includes proposals to close Knightsbridge Fire Station, reduce the number of engines at the Chelsea station from two to one and reduce the number of firefighters in the Royal Borough by 48 from 181 to 133.

Strong opposition to these plans was expressed at the meeting. The Council is very concerned about the effects of these changes on attendance times to emergencies in the borough and will be responding that if the Fire Service is to press ahead with the closure of Knightsbridge Fire Station the Council will be seeking to keep the second engine at Chelsea Fire Station to ensure there is sufficient capacity.

Councillor Joanna Gardner, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Community Safety, said: "Clearly local people feel very strongly about these proposals and have real concerns. Residents and businesses still have time to give the Fire Service their views on the proposals by responding to the consultation before Monday the 17 June."

You can respond by filling in the questionnaire found at the following link www.london-fire.gov.uk/lsp5
If the online version isn't working you can click on the LSP consultation questionnaire to download a hard copy.

It is not necessary to reply to all the questions.

The ones most relevant to the proposals about fire station and fire fighters are numbers 21 to 25.

Questionnaires can be returned free of charge to the following address:

FREEPOST RRSK-TLGS-YLAK London Safety Plan Team, LFB, 169 Union Street, London SE1 0LL.

Alternatively you can send a letter about the proposals to the Fire Service and send it to the same address to arrive by Monday 17 June.
shortdescription: A public meeting on the future of London's Fire Brigade held at Kensington Town Hall on Monday 10 June attracted 80 residents.
shorttitle: Council urges residents to respond to fire station consultation

headline: BOROUGH'S FINANCES GIVEN AAA RATING
prcopy:
A draft set of the Council's accounts for 2012-13 was presented to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet on Thursday 13 June.

The report estimated that there would be an `underspend' of £24.3 million. Allowing for delays in spending and other matters, this represents five per cent of the Council's annual, recurrent budget.

It has not been achieved through reducing the quality of the Council's services but by Bi- and Tri-borough working, cost control and preparing for reductions in the Council's grant from central Government for several years to come.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has also maintained a healthy credit rating according to its most recent assessment by the ratings agency Standard & Poor's which awarded the borough a AAA/negative rating.

This latest rating reflects the borough's economic strength, substantial reserves and moderate debt levels and its intention to implement further cuts to its operating expenditure to match lower revenues from the Government.

Standard & Poor's report that the borough's budgetary performance has been good with strong control over budgeted costs. It also points out that the Council's ongoing cautious fiscal stance has allowed it to build up substantial reserves which provide a cushion to accommodate current and future reductions in revenue arising from reductions in Government grants.

Despite continuous cuts in its main sources of revenue over the past few years the Council has been able to avoid running a deficit owing to major efforts in reining in operating costs. The borough will continue to benefit from the Tri-borough initiative, through which it shares services with Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster and thus saving on overheads and achieving lower procurement costs.

The Council's financial management is singled out as having a positive impact on the rating it received. This demonstrates a high degree of expertise and commitment to transparency as well as continuity, fiscal discipline and well defined financial policies.

The capital programme foresees investment of £170 million from 2013-2014 onward. This programme will require £124 million of Council funding which will come mainly from the borough's own reserves and capital receipts. The programme is spread across a large number of diverse projects and includes the building of the Kensington Aldridge Academy and the Kensington Leisure Centre.

Cllr Warwick Lightfoot, Cabinet Member for Finance and Strategy, said: "This year's accounts show that once again the Council has managed to use your money wisely. Front line services have been preserved, if not enhanced, and savings have been found to match the reduction in Government grant.

"I am very pleased that having run the rule over the Council's finances and financial management Standard & Poor's has given us such a healthy rating. Clearly the decisions we have taken to share services with our neighbours and our careful stewardship of our reserves over many years has gone some way to protect vital front line services while still allowing us to make a substantial capital investment in new schools."
shortdescription: A draft set of the Council's accounts for 2012-13 was presented to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet on Thursday 13 June.
shorttitle: Borough's finances given AAA rating

headline: SCHOOL CHILDREN TAKE TO THE STREETS TO PROMOTE ROAD SAFETY
prcopy:
Some 220 children from Servite RC Primary School, Fulham Road, formed a giant walking school bus on Wednesday 12 June when they took to the streets with their road safety message `Say yes to walking! Say no to driving fast!'

Led by Cllr Mrs Frances Taylor, chairman of the Royal Borough's Public Transport and Road Safety Group, the children, accompanied by 38 staff, walked along Hollywood Road, Fawcett Street, Edith Grove and then back to school to raise awareness of the need to reduce speed limits to keep people safe. The children wore hi-vis jackets to help get the message across and ranged in age from 5 year-olds in Reception class to 11-year-olds in Year Six.

Cllr Mrs Taylor said: "It is vitally important that we do everything possible to make the environment safe for children to walk to school. Walking is the healthiest and most economical means of transport ever. I hope this event will encourage parents and carers to try walking to school if possible."

Hannah, age 10, said: "We looked more like a giant walking yellow snake than a giant walking bus. I think it was well worth it and we spread the message to drivers about slowing down near a school. Lots of drivers noticed us!"

shorttitle: School children take to the streets to promote road safety

headline: ARCHITECT AND BUILDING CONTRACTOR PLEAD GUILTY OF CAUSING DAMAGE TO GRADE II LISTED BUILDING
prcopy:
An architect and building contractor pleaded guilty at Westminster Magistrates' Court yesterday (Thursday 13 June) of causing irreversible damage to a Grade II listed townhouse in the heart of Notting Hill.

Designed by architect and artist Thomas Allom, who designed many buildings in London and worked with Sir Charles Barry on numerous projects, most notably the Houses of Parliament, 18 Kensington Park Gardens, W11 forms part of a listed terrace of properties and was an exceptional example of an elegant mid-nineteenth century townhouse.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea had granted Listed Building Consent and planning permission for alteration works to the property in January 2012. However, this consent was heavily conditioned to ensure the retention of historic features throughout the building.

Both defendants pleaded guilty to executing the unauthorised works and architect Mr Joshua Whitfield Berry was fined £3,000, plus £5,000 costs and Elston Developments Limited was fined £2,000, plus £5,000 costs.

The court heard how the works carried out in February and March 2012 were significantly over and above what had been approved and how they caused irreversible damage seriously affecting the building's architectural and historic interest.

These works effectively gutted the interior of the property and included the removal of the majority of the plasterwork from ceilings and walls; the removal of floorboards, skirting boards, dado rails and other timber features and the removal of most of the historic cornicing and some fireplaces. The end result was the complete exposure of the skeletal timber framing of the building and its internal bare brick walls on every floor level. In addition, the rear garden's balustrade wall and staircase were removed.

Councillor Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning, said:

"We are fortunate to be home to a vast number of historic and architecturally significant buildings and it is our duty to protect and preserve them so they can be enjoyed by future generations.

"Our enforcement team closely monitor building works and this case sends a strong message to architects and building contractors that planning conditions must be observed and, if breached, we will ensure that they are made to account for their actions."

In January 2013, a further Listed Building Consent was approved to carry out some structural works to be the property and to ensure, where possible, the reinstatement of historically correct features to the building. These works are currently continuing at the property.
shortdescription: An architect and building contractor were found guilty at Westminster Magistrates' Court yesterday (Thursday 13 June) of causing irreversible damage to a Grade II listed townhouse in the heart of Notting Hill.
shorttitle: Architect and building contractor plead guilty of causing damage to Grade II Listed Building

headline: SHOUT OUT FOR FLASH FASHION VOLUNTEERS
prcopy:
Portobello and Golborne Road Market is recruiting four volunteer fashion stylists for a Flash Fashion show which aims to capture and celebrate the diversity of the market and the communities it serves.

The stylists will need to create mood boards for the autumn/winter 2013 volunteer event taking place on Saturday 7 September. Mood boards should depict looks that can be assembled from clothing and accessories sourced from market stalls and local shops. The deadline for submissions is midnight, Thursday 18 July.

The market, renowned for setting new trends and being on the cutting edge of fashion, attracts hundreds of thousands of designers, stylists, editors, models and shoppers each season with its mix of high street chic and classic vintage styles.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Leisure, Cllr Tim Ahern, said: "Portobello and Golborne has a long association with fashion entrepreneurs and many of the big fashion houses visit the market regularly to get inspiration. This is a great opportunity for budding stylists to showcase their talents by capturing the unique spirit of Portobello with a mood board."

For more information on this or other Flash Fashion volunteer opportunities, or to send a completed mood board (size A4 PDF), email street.markets@rbkc.gov.uk

shortdescription: Portobello and Golborne Road Market is recruiting four volunteer fashion stylists for a Flash Fashion show which aims to capture and celebrate the diversity of the market and the communities it serves.
shorttitle: Shout out for flash fashion volunteers

headline: YOUNG KAYAKERS TAKE GOLD IN LONDON YOUTH GAMES
prcopy:
A team representing the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea regained the kayak slalom title at the Thames Water London Youth Games Regatta on Saturday 8 June. The borough had to settle for bronze last year, after winning gold in 2011, but they were back to winning ways at the London Regatta Centre.

Brothers Alexander,15, and Oliver Khlaf ,13, took senior male and junior male gold respectively. Sister Sophie, 16, was fourth in the senior female class, the quarter was completed by Lilla Shehata, 11, who was a solid seventh in the junior female class.

Each competitor had two runs over the course with the best three of the four in the team to count. Kensington and Chelsea's quickest were the three Khlafs and they just edged out Bexley into silver by two seconds. Last year's winner Tower Hamlets had to settle for bronze.

In the kayak sprint competition, there was more success for the borough as they shared overall team bronze with Ealing, Barking & Dagenham took silver with Richmond winning the overall title. There was also individual gold in the rocket class through Alexander and Oliver Khlaf, Lilla Shehata and 12-year-old Madeleine Sigey.

There were further medals for Alexander Khlaf who won silver in the male junior cirrus class, Lilla Shehetta who took bronze in the cirrus junior female finals and Sophie Klaf who won bronze in the senior female cirrus class.

Kensington and Chelsea's Team Coach Martyn Steele was pleased with the team's performance. He said: "We're all very proud because they all worked so hard throughout the year. They come training even when there's ice on the canal and they all love to paddle. So for them to actually get a reward today is great and reflects the hard work they put in all year.

"Some of the boys train up to five times a week, and put in a lot of work - they deserve everything they get for the training they do.

"Every year the standard at the London Youth Games gets better and better. It's good to see so many people getting involved because it's still a minority sport. The more people we can get involved - especially within London because of the diversity of the population - the better. To see so many people here from all backgrounds - it's amazing."

Oliver Khlaf was also delighted, he said: "I feel very happy and I feel like I deserved it because I tried really hard. I`ve been training all year for this event - it's one of the most important events of the year so I tried really hard."

He also revealed that he has big ambitions for the future, saying he hopes to follow London 2012 kayak slalom silver medallist Richard Hounslow from the London Youth Games all the way to the Olympics.

He said: "It shows that people started in London Youth Games and can then go on to achieve Olympic medals, so it's really inspiring. I definitely hope to go to bigger events and hopefully achieve an Olympic medal one day."

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Congratulations to all our kayakers for their fantastic efforts at the London Youth Games. It takes real dedication and hard work to achieve such impressive performances. I would like to thank all the coaches that work with young people and our youth sports development team for their efforts and would encourage any young people who want to give kayaking a try to contact the Council and give it a go."

Young people interested in trying kayaking should contact the Council's Canalside Activity Centre on 020 8968 4500 or the Cremorne Riverside Centre on 020 7349 9591 for more information.
shortdescription: A team representing the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea regained the kayak slalom title at the Thames Water London Youth Games Regatta on Saturday 8 June. The borough had to settle for bronze last year, after winning gold in 2011, but they were back to winning ways at the London Regatta Centre.
shorttitle: Young kayakers take gold in London Youth Games

headline: BENEFIT CHEAT SERVING EIGHT MONTHS BEHIND BARS
prcopy:
A man who falsely claimed more than £50,000 in housing and council tax benefits and income support is serving an eight month prison sentence.

Mr Raymond Daniels (56) of Copperfield House, Henry Dickens Court, London W11 was sentenced at Isleworth Crown Court Wednesday 12 June 2013, after pleading guilty to two counts of dishonesty against the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the Department for Work and Pensions.

Mr Daniels had been in receipt of housing benefit on the basis that he was not working. However, when Mr Daniels applied for a parking permit for a lorry Council officers became suspicious.

Following a joint investigation between the Council and the Department of Work and Pensions undeclared bank accounts were discovered which contained in excess of £40,000.

Even though the accounts were in his name Mr Daniels refused to admit that the money was his, and midway through a taped interview he demanded that the recorder be turned off and left the interview room throwing his rent book at the investigators.

In sentencing Judge Johnson stated the fraud was a continued serious act of dishonesty. Mr Daniels' lawyer explained that Mr Daniels was remorseful and felt shameful about his actions. He received an eight month prison sentence, to run concurrently on both charges.

The housing benefit overpayment amounted to £23,696.94, council tax £4,414.21 and income support £23,193.70 covering the period August 2007 to September 2011.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, Cabinet Member for Finance, said: "It is outrageous Mr Daniels felt that he could steal tens of thousands of pounds from the taxpayer. This prison sentence sends out a clear message to those who are trying to defraud the taxpayer and make it harder for those in genuine need.

"I congratulate our Council officers for their vigilance and can tell residents that we will work with colleagues in local and central government to prevent abuses of the system."
shortdescription: A man who falsely claimed more than £50,000 in housing and council tax benefits and income support is serving an eight month prison sentence.
shorttitle: Benefit cheat serving eight months behind bars

headline: ST LUKE'S GARDENS REOPENED
prcopy:
St Luke's Gardens were officially reopened on Friday 14 June by Lord Cadogan. He attended the ceremony with the Mayor and Mayoress of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams and his wife June; together with the Leader of the Royal Borough, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown; the Cabinet Member for Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern and a number of other Councillors, residents and Friends of St Luke's Gardens.

Cllr Ahern welcomed the official opening, saying: "I am delighted to mark an end to all the work that has gone on over the past few years. We have St Luke's Gardens returned to the beautiful park it once was. Since we refurbished the playground and courts they have been enjoyed by many residents and their children and the park is now a visual treat for all those that come to use this oasis in Chelsea."

The Mayor added: "It is wonderful to see the park looking as good as it does. This garden is a great place to enjoy the great outdoors in the heart of Chelsea. I am sure many more residents and visitors will come to love the park in the future."

St Luke's Gardens has a new games area, playground, traditional iron railings and benches and paving.

The park was originally opened by a former Countess Cadogan in the 1880s and the family has a long association with the park, neighbouring church and the area in general.

He attended the ceremony with the Mayor and Mayoress of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams and his wife June; together with the Leader of the Royal Borough, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown; the Cabinet Member for Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern and a number of other Councillors, residents and Friends of St Luke's Gardens.
