headline: MINISTERS PRAISE TRI-BOROUGH INTEGRATED CARE PILOT THAT WILL SAVE £38M PER YEAR
prcopy:
Minister of State for Health, Norman Lamb MP and Minister for Local Government, Brandon Lewis MP (Tuesday 18 June) praised the efforts of three London councils to provide better care for the elderly through an innovative integrated care pilot.

Norman Lamb MP, Care and Support Minister said: "By bringing together services from across Westminster, Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea councils, you are leading the way when it comes to integrated health and care services. I want to take this opportunity to thank you for taking this leap forward to improve people's lives. Plans, which are set to save around £38 million net per year, will integrate health and social care support to enable more people to stay independent in their own home."

Westminster Council, along with the NHS and neighbouring Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea Councils, which have led the way in local government by combining services, are one of just four areas in the country to be given special `Community Budget pilot' status by the Government to develop radical plans for public service redesign.

The integrated care model will provide targeted support to the 20 per cent of people who are currently responsible for 77 per cent of health and social care cost. They will be given help and support to be cared for in their own homes, reducing demand for more expensive institutionalised care either in a hospital setting or residential home.

Cllr Marcus Ginn, Hammersmith & Fulham Council's Cabinet Member for Community Care, said: "These innovative plans are about providing much more joined-up care so that people receive the best possible standard of services in their own home with care packages designed around their needs.

"In future we won't be asking vulnerable people to navigate their own way around the NHS which can be daunting at the best of times; they will have their own nominated person to do that for them, regardless of whether they need social care, occupational therapy or mental health care."

Cllr Mary Weale, Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Adult Social Care and Public Health, said: "By focusing on an integrated approach we will make effective early intervention to provide the support that will enable people to stay in their own home which for most people is a more attractive option than moving into residential care which is also costly for the taxpayer."

Cllr Rachael Robathan, Westminster City Council's Cabinet Member for Adults and Public Health, said: "Our pilot has shown the potential of what can be achieved when local knowledge is put at the heart of Whitehall decision making.
"We are committed to delivering our ambitious plans but we will only be successful with the continued backing of Ministers and their officials, so we are delighted to welcome ministers to view our services and discuss our plans today.

"This is about changing the way primary health and social care services are delivered, with acute or residential care becoming the last resort not the first destination."

This year, the three councils will start to implement plans that will see them work in new ways with local partners to release £38 million per year of net savings after reinvestment costs at a local level and deliver better outcomes for local people, keeping more people out of hospital for longer. This is particularly important for the 100,000 who are elderly or have complex needs and are most at risk of being admitted to hospital or a care home.
keyword4: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: Minister of State for Health, Norman Lamb MP and Minister for Local Government, Brandon Lewis MP (Tuesday 18 June)  praised the efforts of three London councils to provide better care for the elderly through an innovative integrated care pilot.
shorttitle: Ministers praise Tri-borough integrated care pilot that will save £38m per year

headline: SCHOOL ART WINNERS ON DISPLAY AT KENSINGTON CENTRAL LIBRARY
prcopy:
The creative and artistic talents of pupils from 33 schools were showcased at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's fourteenth annual Schools Art Competition and Exhibition on Tuesday 18 June, at Leighton House Museum.

A prize-giving ceremony marked the opening of the exhibition which was attended by the artists, aged from three to 18, proud parents and teachers.

The Mayoress of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Mrs June Williams, along with the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams, and Councillor Mrs Frances Taylor presented certificates and cash prizes to the children and schools whose work was selected for display. Special guest Dr Stephen Deuchar, Director of the Art Fund, was also present to congratulate the winners.

The cash prizes were generously sponsored by Flow Gallery (applied art), Park Gallery (drawing/painting) and the Friends of Leighton House Museum (Leighton Art Prize).

Twenty-six young artists received Highly Commended awards across both categories for drawing/painting and applied art.

Among the borough's schools, Sion Manning RC Girls School got the top award for applied art, with second place going to Cardinal Vaughan Memorial School, and first place in the drawing/painting category to Chelsea Academy.

The independent schools also did well, Bassett House School took second place in drawing/painting, Hill House School came third and Thomas's Kensington came third for applied art, Sussex House School was awarded the Leighton Art Prize.

Commending the youngsters and teachers for their enthusiasm and hard work the Mayor, Councillor Charles Williams, said: "The Schools Art Exhibition encourages creativity and nurtures skills that youngsters can develop. The project aims to encourage children and young people to pursue and develop their interests and talents within art - even if being an artist may not be a career choice."

The work of the competition winners will be exhibited at Kensington Central Library for a week, from Saturday 22 to Friday 28 June.

For more information about the Schools Art Competition and Exhibition and for details about entering the 2014 competition contact Culture Service Development Officer, Jennifer Kirk, on 020 7361 3844 or email Jennifer.kirk@rbkc.gov.uk

Visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/artsservice

Follow the Arts Service on Twitter @RBKCculture and like us on Facebook RBKC Culture
shortdescription: The creative and artistic talents of pupils from 33 schools were showcased at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's fourteenth annual Schools Art Competition and Exhibition on Tuesday 18 June, at Leighton House Museum.
shorttitle: School art winners on display at Kensington Central Library

headline: FLYING THE FLAG FOR ARMED FORCES DAY
prcopy:
Civic leaders and representatives of the military joined forces at Kensington Town Hall today (Monday 24 June) to raise the Armed Forces Day Flag. It will be flown throughout the week, leading up to Armed Forces Day on Saturday 29 June.

Councillor Charles Williams, Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, was joined in the flag-raising by members of the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment. Watching the ceremony were the Representative Deputy Lieutenant, Lady Arnold, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, and Mr Nicholas Holgate, Town Clerk. Also present were representatives from two of the main Service Charities, the Royal British Legion and SSAFA.

The period around Armed Forces Day gives an opportunity for the public to mark the contribution made to our country by those who serve and have served in the Armed Forces. It is also a chance to show support for the men and women who make up the Armed Forces community: from currently serving troops to Service families and from veterans to cadets.

The Royal Borough has a long standing and close relationship with the forces, having given the Freedom of the Borough to seven regiments. The Council was one of the first in London to sign the Armed Forces Covenant and has held an annual reception for the armed forces for the past 20 years.

The Mayor Councillor Williams said: "We are very proud to fly the Armed Forces flag this week as a sign of our gratitude to members of the armed forces, both past and present.

"We fly the flag for one week but our gratitude and support extend throughout the year."
shortdescription: Civic leaders and representatives of the military joined forces at Kensington Town Hall today (Monday 24 June) to raise the Armed Forces Day Flag.  It will be flown throughout the week, leading up to Armed Forces Day on Saturday 29 June.
shorttitle: Flying the flag for Armed Forces Day

headline: FIND OUT MORE ABOUT CYCLE RACE ROAD CLOSURES
prcopy:
Residents and businesses can meet organisers of August's RideLondon cycling event to discuss potential transport problems at a special drop-in event on Tuesday 16 July.

Organised by The Mayor of London and Transport for London (TfL), Prudential RideLondon will see 20,000 amateur cyclists ride their bikes through the borough on Sunday 4 August. The amateur event will be followed the same day by an elite race with approximately 150 cyclists.

Residents and visitors to the borough can expect significant transport disruption throughout the day, with major roads and bridges closed to traffic.

However, unlike last year's Olympic event, the route for Prudential RideLondon will be split, with cyclists riding through the borough before heading out of London across Hammersmith Flyover before completing a course in Surrey and returning through Chelsea.

This change of route, together with the huge number of cyclists, means that there will be enormous disruption to transport across the entire borough and much of London on Sunday 4 August.

Officials from The Mayor of London's office, TfL and the London & Surrey Cycling Partnership will be answering questions from the public at Sainsbury's on Cromwell Road on Tuesday 16 July between 4pm and 7pm.

Cllr Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "While we welcome this event, which promises to be an exciting spectacle, residents need to realise that there will be disruption to roads and public transport. Therefore it is very important that they familiarise themselves with the route and the timings so they can plan ahead.

"Driving anywhere near the route will be problematic and residents should only to use their car on Sunday 4 August if it is absolutely vital. If you need to drive, leave plenty of extra time and be prepared for significantly longer journeys."

Garrett Emmerson, Chief Operating Officer for Surface Transport at TfL, said: "Prudential RideLondon will be the largest ever mass-participation cycling event to take place in the UK. We want all participants, spectators and residents to enjoy the event weekend and all the usual attractions London has to offer. However, it is important that people become aware of the road closures, particularly on Sunday 4 August. Roads around the route will be particularly busy and we urge people to plan ahead to avoid the disrupted areas."

The amateur race will set-off from 6am in the Olympic Park before travelling through central London. The professional race will start from the same location at 1pm.

The cyclists for both events will ride through the borough after entering at Knightsbridge before heading down Brompton Road and then along along the A4 and to the border with Hammersmith & Fulham. They will re-enter the borough later in the day on a route which includes the King's Road, Cheyne Walk and Chelsea Embankment.

More information about the event, timings and the route can be found at
www.tfl.gov.uk/prudentialridelondon

You can also find information on the race organiser's website www.prudentialridelondon.co.uk

For the latest on how transport services are operating, you are advised to check before you travel at www.tfl.gov.uk and on Twitter @TfLTravelAlerts (Tube, DLR and London Overground), @TfLTrafficNews (roads) and @TfLBusAlerts (bus).
Hot on the heels of the incredibly successful Olympic cycling events, these events are part of a world class Olympic legacy festival of cycling taking place across the weekend of 3 and 4 August.
shortdescription: Residents and businesses can meet organisers of August's RideLondon cycling event to discuss potential transport problems at a special drop-in event on Tuesday 16 July.
shorttitle: Find out more about cycle race road closures

headline: GRASS FREE GARDENING
prcopy:
The world's first grass-free lawn in a public space, made entirely of flowers, was laid last month at Avondale Park, in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Made up of 65 different species of perennials the lawn will provide colour and a source of nectar throughout the growing season.

It is hoped that the lawn will enhance the biodiversity potential of Avondale Park for pollinators by providing foraging habitat for a variety of species throughout spring and summer. This is particularly important for bees and butterflies which are in significant decline and under increasing threat through loss of habitat, sources of food and pollen, and the use of pesticides.

The project is the result of collaboration between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council and Lionel Smith, a PhD student at the University of Reading who came up with the idea for the lawn.

Welcoming the development, Cllr Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Environment at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I am delighted we are at the forefront of such an exciting and innovative way of bringing biodiversity to the borough.

"I would like to congratulate Lionel Smith for his ideas in creating this lawn and also the borough's parks team for growing the species that are now doing so well in Avondale Park.

"I look forward to seeing the lawn in other parks in the borough and hopefully in other parts of the country."

Lionel Smith added: "I've been delighted by how the grass-free lawn concept has been so very well received by all the park users I have spoken to. It has been very rewarding to take cutting-edge research out of the experimental grounds and directly apply it in Avondale Park. I look forward to seeing how the lawn evolves. It certainly seems to have set many people thinking."

By completely replacing grass with a wide variety of carefully selected wildflowers of both native and non-native plant species it is possible to create a richly structured and highly biodiverse sward that is both visually and structurally attractive to people, pollinators and other invertebrates.

Once the lawn has settled, it will be able to take occasional light footfall; and young park users will be able to step on the lawn and get up close to the variety of flowers and plants used. This will provide an innovative approach to biodiversity enhancements in an urban park. However the floral lawn is not designed to provide a replacement for hardwearing turf. It provides an engaging way to bring nature to our residents' doorstep increasing their contact with nature, and is already receiving positive feedback.
shortdescription: The world's first grass-free lawn in a public space, made entirely of flowers, was laid last month at Avondale Park, in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Grass free gardening

headline: DO YOU LIKE TO BE BESIDE THE SEASIDE?
prcopy:
Once again, older residents have the opportunity to enjoy a break away from the hustle and bustle of Notting Hill Carnival, as part of a scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Now in its tenth year, 40 older people living directly on the Carnival route, who may find the exuberance of the weekend too much, have the chance to apply for a trip to the seaside.

Residents will go to the Glastonbury Hotel in Eastbourne on Saturday 24 August and will return to their homes on Tuesday 27 August, once the Council has had time to clear up and the area is quieter.

Many older people have already been in touch and there are a limited number of places available so all applications will be assessed. People who are eligible, whose health may be affected, but have not been on a trip before will be given priority.

Residents can contact the Council for more information on 020 7361 3175. The closing date to apply for a place is Friday 5 July 2013.
shortdescription: Once again, older residents have the opportunity to enjoy a break away from the hustle and bustle of Notting Hill Carnival, as part of a scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Do you like to be beside the seaside?

headline: YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS SET THEIR STALLS OUT ON PORTOBELLO MARKET
prcopy:
The Market Enterprise Launch Pad (MELP 2013) winners launch will be held on Friday 5 July at Tavistock Square between 3pm and 5.30pm and hosted by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Education Business Partnership.

The launch event celebrates the achievements of this year's three winners and gives them a chance to showcase their products to the general public.

MELP runs annually providing entrepreneurial skills development for self-employment and is aimed at 18 to 24 year olds in the borough. The programme is a competition, with winning young entrepreneurs taking the first steps towards making their dreams of self-employment into a reality. The MELP 2013 prize includes £1,000 in start-up funds, six months rent-free market stall space on Portobello Market, a business start-up support package from the Enterprise Lab and free business insurance.

The three 2013 winners are: Shani Grant, 22, who is starting a `tomboy' fashion label called `Studz UK', Remaro Hibbert, 25, owner of a positive message fashion label called `Point of View' and Medina Mukhayer, 19, who sells East African food and cultural goods.

They will be launching their businesses on Portobello and Golborne Road Markets, Acklam Village and Portobello Green Market.

There will be a brief showcase on the day to include a fashion show, Ethiopian dance and female football skills demonstration by the business owners and light refreshments will also be provided.

Shani Grant, 22, said: "Winning the competition is important to both myself and the business; as it shows that my business idea can work and is something which influential people have faith in. Studz UK is a clothing line for `tomboy' females, tailoring fit and sizing to adjust to that of the male urban look for women. There is a range of clothing, from t-shirts to binders to snapback hats. The market stall on Portobello will be a great place to showcase and sell our products"

Remaro Hibbert, 25, said: "The opportunity to be on Portobello Market for six months allows me to increase brand awareness but also allows people to get a chance to get to know the face behind the brand. I could not thank the people from MELP and the Enterprise Lab more for the guidance, confidence and encouragement they have offered me during this time."

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I wish all three young traders the very best of luck as they begin their business careers on Portobello Market.

"They did very well to impress the judges and win these coveted spots on one of the world's most famous markets. I am sure they will now go on to impress their new customers."

Follow MELP 2013's journey on Facebook: Market Enterprise Launch Pad Twitter: @RBKCMELP
shortdescription: The Market Enterprise Launch Pad (MELP 2013) winners launch will be held on Friday 5 July at Tavistock Square between 3pm and 5.30pm and hosted by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Education Business Partnership.
shorttitle: Young entrepreneurs set out their stalls on Portobello Market

headline: ENCOURAGING INNOVATION IN THE ROYAL BOROUGH
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is making up to £0.5m available to the not-for-profit sector over the next two years as part of its grants programme.

The new grants round, advertised this week, follows a successful call for applications from voluntary groups for innovative ideas last summer.

Bids for the cash have to be in by noon on Friday 26 July 2013 and to succeed, bidders will need to show how they are offering a new service or reaching a new client group.

In particular the Council will be looking for proposals that address its own priorities of tackling social isolation, supporting people into work and training, encouraging greater neighbourliness, civic participation, and self-help.

Critically important for bidders will be to convince the Council they have a business plan that can make them financially sustainable and less reliant on public-sector grants in the years ahead.

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, said: "Our community and voluntary groups are hugely important to the life of the borough. I am very pleased that, even in these straitened economic times, we are able to continue to support the vital work they do.

"This latest round of grants encourages bids from those groups whose priorities match ours. It is also very important that they are able to demonstrate how, through their business planning, they will become less reliant on public money in years to come."

For more information vist www.rbkc.gov.uk/communityfunding
or call the Community Engagement Team on
020 7598 4633 or email
communityengagement@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is making up to £0.5m available to the not-for-profit sector over the next two years as part of its grants programme.
shorttitle: Encouraging innovation in the Royal Borough

headline: HAVE YOUR SAY ON THE NORLAND NEIGHBOURHOOD PLAN
prcopy:
The Norland Neighbourhood Plan has been submitted to the Council. The plan is the culmination of many years work by the Norland Conservation Society.

The Society approached the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea in 2007 with the wish to update the Conservation Area Proposals Statement for Norland. They undertook painstaking of work to prepare the update, so when neighbourhood planning was introduced the Council suggested it should come forward as a Neighbourhood Plan for the area.

The plan demonstrates a vision by which decisions on planning applications will be determined so as to shape and direct high quality sustainable development in the area.

This will be publicised for six weeks, until 26 July 2013, alongside a number of supporting documents, before being reviewed by an examiner. During the six weeks the Council invites people to comment on the plan. These responses will be sent along with the plan to the examiner.

If you would like to make representations on the neighbourhood plan, please email your comments to neighbourhood.planning@rbkc.gov.uk or by post to: The Executive Director, Planning and Borough Development, Neighbourhood Planning, The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, The Town Hall, Hornton Street, London W8 7NX.

The opportunity to comment will close on 26 July 2013.

You may comment on any of the information submitted by Norland Neighbourhood Forum. As well as considering the plan itself, you may also want to comment on any of the supporting documents.

To see the plan go to
www.rbkc.gov.uk/norlandplan

headline: Guidelines approved to control basement development and increase the number of affordable homes
prcopy:
Planning guidelines to help control developments above and below ground and to increase the number of affordable homes were last night (Wednesday 26 June) approved by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

With economic turbulence overseas, property in Kensington and Chelsea is often seen as a safe investment for wealthy foreign investors. These buyers are able to invest huge sums of money in very large residential units. The Council proposes to restrict very large units in a scheme to 25 per cent of the overall floor space.

The Royal Borough has also seen a trend for the creation of larger properties through the amalgamation of smaller ones and estimates that this has resulted in the loss of an average of over 50 dwellings a year since 2009. These new guidelines propose to restrict this practice, except where the amalgamation is within a house, which had been previously split into flats.

Subterranean development has increased dramatically in recent years and has been the subject of concerns from residents. This has been heightened by the growth in the number of planning applications for basements from 13 planning applications in 2001, to 182 in 2010 and 307 in 2012. Basement development has given rise to issues about noise and disturbance during construction and concerns about the structural stability of nearby buildings.

Designed to introduce a sense of proportionality to basement development, highlights of these new policies include a reduction in the extent to which basements can extend into the garden, a restriction to a single storey and severe restrictions on basement developments under, or in the gardens, of listed buildings, or where a basement already exists.

At the same time the Council wants to encourage an increase in the number of affordable homes being built. It is proposing to raise the threshold where affordable housing should be built on site to 2,400 sq m. Below this threshold, developers will be required to make a financial contribution towards affordable housing. The Council believes that this is a realistic approach to encourage developers to build affordable homes as part of new developments.

Councillor Tim Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said:

"Over the past decade we've noticed a dramatic increase in the number of basement applications and at the same time a distinct pattern has also emerged of foreign investors investing huge sums of money in very large residential units.

"With some of the most expensive land values in the country it is a constant challenge for us to build affordable homes.

"Through these policies we are trying to get the right balance between residents, investors and a meaningful increase in the number of affordable homes we deliver."

These proposals will be presented to the Government's Planning Inspector in the autumn who will decide whether they are sound. If given the go-ahead, the Council hopes to introduce the new policies early next year.

shorttitle: Guidelines approved to control basement development and increase the number of affordable homes

headline: YOUNG FOOTBALLERS TAKE THEIR FIRST STEPS ON THE COACHING LADDER
prcopy:
Members of a successful youth local five-a-side league have taken their first steps on the coaching ladder after completing a Level 1 FA Coaching course.

Earl's Court Youth Club 5-Aside Power League, raised funds for the course in partnership with Chelsea Kickz project and London Youth. The course, which cost £2,700, covered key elements of practical coaching.

Of the 18 people who attended 16 successfully completed the course which is testament to both their commitment and enjoyment of it.

The idea behind the course was to help young people become qualified football coaches and develop a better idea of the sport. As well as the technical aspects of the game, they also developed other skills such as team work, communication, timekeeping, planning and delivering activities, which will strengthen their CVs.

Out of the 16 young people who successfully completed the course, 12 are in the process of applying for the Council-funded Sports Development Trainee Football Coaching Scheme, a four-month trainee coaching scheme for aspiring young football coaches.

Speaking about the impact of the course, one of the participants, Rob Labrador, said: "I gave up my half term for this and it was the best decision I made", while another, Khadar Mohamud, said: "This course has taught me to look at football in a totally different way".


Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Well done to all those who completed their FA coaching course and to those who were so generous with their sponsorship.
"Clearly the young people enjoyed the course and it is encouraging that qualifications like this can help young people find employment."

For more information about the coaching scheme please contact mohammed.jama@rbkc.gov.uk or visit
www.kccentral.rbkc.gov.uk/youthsports
shortdescription: Members of a successful youth local five-a-side league have taken their first steps on the coaching ladder after completing a Level 1 FA Coaching course.
shorttitle: Young footballers take their first steps on the coaching ladder

headline: CHILDREN SPEAK UP ABOUT THEIR RIGHTS
prcopy:
The importance of being able to play, be safe and the rights of young people were the topics given an airing by 82 children from primary schools in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham when they took part in the Children's Choice Conference at Kensington Town Hall on Friday 28 June.

On the day, the theme for discussion was `Children's Rights and Responsibilities' and included the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. The children were able to share their views with local experts and senior officers from both councils including, Andrew Christie, the Tri-borough Director for Children's Services and Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams and the Mayor of Hammersmith & Fulham, Councillor Frances Stainton opened the conference and Shaila Sheikh, Principal Participation Adviser at the Children's Commissioner for England Office, talked about the importance for children to share their views and opinions.

Speaking about what he liked during the day, Joseph (10) said: "I enjoyed the conference because I liked hearing other children's ideas", and Sami (10) supported this saying: "I think that the conference was great because children got to say their ideas and opinions."

Lorrie Knight, a teacher from Oxford Gardens Primary School in North Kensington, said: "I think that the conference is great. Children have been engaged throughout and found out new things and ideas."

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell praised the contribution of the children, saying: "This was an excellent opportunity for many senior officers from both councils, whose responsibility it is to make decisions that will affect children, to meet them and hear their ambitions and concerns first hand.

"These young residents have views and ideas that deserve to be listened to and I think everyone involved in the conference learned a lot."
shortdescription: The importance of being able to play, be safe and the rights of young people were the topics given an airing by 82 children from primary schools in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham when they took part in the Children's Choice Conference at Kensington Town Hall on Friday 28 June.
shorttitle: Children speak up about their rights

headline: YOUNG DANCERS SHOW THEIR TALENT
prcopy:
Over 200 children and young people took to the stage at the Cadogan Hall on Friday 28 June for Dance Showdown 2013, one of London's biggest youth dance events.

Dance Showdown is a chance for young people, aged between eight and 19, from schools and community groups in Kensington and Chelsea to showcase their talent in front of an 800-strong audience, including the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams and judges from the UK's dance industry.

This year's winners were:

Junior category
St Mary's winners
Pimento runner-up

Senior category
St. Charles Sixth form winners
Chelsea Academy runner-up

Community category
The Rugby Portobello Trust winners
Chois3z runner-up

The talented individual award went to Moray Hinkson

The evening also featured performances from the English National Ballet, Aaron Crosbie Irish Dance Academy and the Pineapple Performing Arts School.

Abbi Cobb, one of the winners from Funky Foot Rugby Portobello Trust, said: "The Dance Showdown was amazing; it was good that everyone got involved in supporting the other acts. I was shy to perform in front of so many people, but it went really well, very happy to have won and would love to do it again."
Speaking after the winners were announced, the Mayor, Councillor Charles Williams, said: "I have enjoyed enormously the spectacular dancing by our young people. Dance Showdown provides a wonderful stage for them to demonstrate their considerable talents to a large live audience under the watchful eye of professional dancers and I think they all rose to this daunting challenge tremendously well."
Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Congratulations to everyone who took part in Dance Showdown 2013 and especially to the winners.

"Clearly we have some very talented young dancers in the borough. Of course talent needs nurturing and I'd like to thank all the teachers, youth workers and dance coaches who have helped these young people prepare for this fantastic event."

headline: LATER THURSDAY OPENING FOR PORTOBELLO AND GOLBORNE MARKETS
prcopy:
From Thursday 4 July to Thursday 26 September, the famous Portobello and Golborne Road Markets will be open until 7pm on Thursdays, rather than the usual half day only.

The regular choice of fresh fruit and vegetables will be available, as will fabulous clothing and a range of other items. The extended hours make it easier to pick up something special for dinner and, of course, provide more bargain hunting time.

As the extended hours open up new opportunities for additional casual traders to join the markets the Council is inviting new traders, ideally with interesting products, who are able to provide their own equipment, such as tables and awnings to get in touch. At present the Council is not able to accommodate any new hot food sellers in the market.

Portobello and Golborne Road Markets are situated in the heart of Notting Hill. They are visited by thousands of tourists every week, finding inspiration in the fashion items, and other goods available on the stalls. The market is open Monday to Saturday, and runs from 8am to 7pm.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for the Environment, said: "There really is something for everyone on Portobello and Golborne Markets and now, with these extended opening hours on Thursdays, there is more time to find just what you are looking for.

"It's also good news for those who would like a casual pitch on the market. So, if you've got something to sell, get in touch with the markets office and give it a go."

For further information about opening hours and becoming a trader, please contact the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Street Trading Office on 020 7361 3001 or email street.trading@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: From Thursday 4 July to Thursday 26 September, the famous Portobello and Golborne Road Markets will be open until 7pm on Thursdays, rather than the usual half day only.
shorttitle: Later Thursday opening for Portobello and Golborne markets

headline: LANDMARK PROJECT FOR EARL'S COURT
prcopy:
A "landmark project" to redevelop 77 acres of land in Earl's Court was yesterday (Wednesday 3 July) approved by the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson.

The £8 billion scheme will result in a new urban quarter spanning the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham. It will provide some 7,500 new homes, plus new retail units and new community and cultural facilities. It is also expected to generate 36,000 construction jobs over the 20-year building period and 9,000 to 10,000 permanent jobs.

In making his decision Boris Johnson described the scheme as a "landmark project" that will "provide a massive boost not just to this part of the Capital, but to London's wider economy as well."

Based on a masterplan by architects Terry Farrell & Partners, the project was passed to the Mayor for final consent after being given the go-ahead in 2012 by both the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham.

"Redeveloping Earl's Court to provide much needed housing and other uses has been our policy for many years," said the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning, Cllr Tim Coleridge.

"On both sides of the border we hope that the granting of this planning application will make Earl's Court a more desirable place to live with less congestion and more opportunity for work, commerce and leisure."

As well as new homes, shops and community facilities the scheme includes plans for a new school, health centre, a new park and public squares. In addition it will deliver improvements to Earl's Court, West Kensington and West Brompton Tube stations plus and a wide range of other transport and streetscape enhancements.
shortdescription: A "landmark project" to redevelop 77 acres of land in Earl's Court was yesterday (Wednesday 3 July) approved by the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson.
shorttitle: Landmark project for Earl's Court

headline: Property blighting street in heart of Notting Hill repaired by Royal Borough
prcopy:
An unsightly property blighting a street in the heart of Notting Hill has been repaired by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The owner of 57A Ladbroke Road left his home in such a poor state of repair that its flaking paint and missing render had a negative impact upon the character and appearance of the Ladbroke Conservation Area.

In 2005 the Council's planning team served a notice on the owner instructing him to carry out the repair works. He ignored this notice and the Council pursued a prosecution for his failure to carry out the works. In September 2006 the courts gave the owner a conditional discharge for three years, subject to him carrying out the necessary repairs.

Despite repeated assurances to the Royal Borough that the repairs would start imminently, they failed to ever materialise. The Council has now paid for these works and has placed a charge on the land so that it will recoup its costs when the building is sold.

Councillor Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning, said:

"This individual's behaviour not only made his home look unsightly but his selfish attitude forced his neighbours to look at it every day.

"It is very rare for such situations to get so bad that the Council is forced to intervene but we will always do so if an owner fails in their duty to adequately maintain their property."

shortdescription: An unsightly property blighting a street in the heart of Notting Hill has been repaired by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

headline: FIND OUT MORE ABOUT PRUDENTIAL RIDELONDON ROAD CLOSURES IN KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA
prcopy:
Roads in Kensington and Chelsea will be closed on Sunday 4 August as 150 professional cyclists and 20,000 amateurs take part in the Prudential RideLondon 100 and Classic events. Residents and businesses can find out more about potential transport problems at a special drop-in event taking place on Tuesday 16 July at Sainsbury's on Cromwell Road between 4pm and 7pm.

The event is organised by The Mayor of London and Transport for London.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is warning residents and businesses to expect significant transport disruption throughout Sunday 4 August, with major roads and bridges closed to traffic. Parking along the route will be suspended on the day. If you usually park on an affected road, you should move your vehicle elsewhere the night before, otherwise it will be removed.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "Roads right across London and out to Surrey will be closed to allow this event to take place. Road closures on such a large scale will inevitably cause disruption. The best way to minimise any inconvenience is to plan ahead and try to avoid driving close to the route if at all possible.

"If you normally park your car on the route make sure that you don't on Sunday 4 August as it may be towed away."

The drop-in sessions will be staffed by officials from The Mayor of London's office, TfL and other organising bodies.

More information about the event and maps of the route can be found on TfL and Prudential RideLondon's websites

www.tfl.gov.uk/prudentialridelondon

www.PrudentialRideLondon.co.uk

Or follow the event on twitter @RideLondon

headline: NORLAND RESIDENTS GIVE PLANTERS NEW LEASE OF LIFE
prcopy:
Two large unsightly planters by the busy Holland Park Avenue roundabout have been given a horticultural makeover driven by the local community.

Residents, community groups, businesses and Quadron, the Council's ground maintenance contractor, came together to work with the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to transform planters previously looked after by Transport for London (TfL). An agreement with TfL means that the community has been able to transform what had previously been a neglected and drab space by a very busy road.

The first stage of brightening up the planters began in March when they were cleared and planted. Since then the community has agreed a planting plan with TfL and secured a grant from Norland City Living Local Life to buy the plants.

A big community planting day took place on Sunday 7 July when 15 local residents, with the support of the Council, transformed two large planters with a fantastic selection of new plants. The community planting day was a great way for residents to get to know each other and help improve their local environment. The residents braved the hot weather and planted well over 100 different shrubs and flowers. The hard work was appreciated by passers-by on the day who commented on a great job the local community was doing and how good the planters looked.

Norland ward Councillor, Julie Mills, said: "It is a real joy to be able to use City Living Local Life community funds to beautify this neglected area. This is the gateway to the borough. It was great fun to get stuck in with the weeding planting and watering team and in the glorious sunshine. We are all grateful to officers and residents for bringing this project to fruition.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Environment, said: "Thanks to the determination of local people and the cooperation of TfL these rather unloved planters are getting a new lease of life which will certainly brighten up the local area."

The planters will now be maintained by the local community.
shortdescription: Two large unsightly planters by the busy Holland Park Avenue roundabout have been given a horticultural makeover driven by the local community.
shorttitle: Norland residents give planters new lease of life

headline: CREMORNE RESIDENTS TAKE TEA WITH COUNCILLORS
prcopy:
Some of Cremorne's older residents enjoyed a delicious afternoon tea at Petyt Hall, Chelsea Old Church (Friday 5 July), with local Councillors while they discussed ideas about developing new activities and initiatives in their neighbourhood.

The event, which was organised by the three ward Councillors, was attended by 40 residents. A wide range of ideas were discussed, from book clubs and writing groups to a volunteer dog-walking scheme.

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, Cremorne ward Councillor and Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, said: "I was very pleased that so many Cremorne residents were able to get together and enjoy a traditional afternoon tea. It was also a great opportunity to hear what people thought would make their lives better. Some great ideas were raised and we will now look to see what we can do to turn these into reality.

"It may well be that we can support existing voluntary groups who have expertise or experience in providing the type of schemes and initiatives residents raised."

The three Cremorne Councillors who organised and attended the event were Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds, and Councillor Matthew Neal.

The tea party was supported by City Living, Local Life which is a Councillor-led initiative that enables residents and councillors to work together to find local solutions to local issues. To find out more go to www.citylivinglocallife.org.
shortdescription: Some of Cremorne's older residents enjoyed a delicious afternoon tea at Petyt Hall, Chelsea Old Church (Friday 5 July), with local Councillors while they discussed ideas about developing new activities and initiatives in their neighbourhood.

headline: WORK BEGINS ON NEW HOMES
prcopy:
Work has now begun on 112 new homes on the Silchester Estate, comprising 39 larger properties for social rent, 45 smaller properties for shared ownership and a further 28 smaller homes for sale on the open market to help pay for the work.

The homes are being built as a result of a partnership between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, who provided the land and £3 million, and Peabody which is also investing in the scheme and project managing the building programme.

A groundbreaking event was held on Friday 12 July on the site to commemorate the start of works. The event was attended by the Leader of the Royal Borough, Cllr Nicholas Paget-Brown; Deputy Leader, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen and the Cabinet Member for Planning, Cllr Tim Coleridge; together with Claire Bennie, Director of Development for Peabody and representatives of the main contractors, Mace.

Cllr Feilding-Mellen, said: "We have been working on this project for a number of years and I am delighted that we are now making our plans a reality.

"We need to have more affordable properties in the borough and this scheme is an excellent way of providing it. It is important that we have a mixture of ownership in the development as it helps us to preserve the mixed community we so value."

Claire Bennie, Peabody's Director of Development, said: "We are privileged to be building a large scheme in this central borough which we believe will provide beautifully designed homes, landscape and artwork to benefit both new and existing residents at Silchester Estate."

Warren Alexander-Pye, Project Manager for Mace, said: "We are very excited to start works on Silchester, and look forward to working alongside Peabody and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to deliver a project that reflects the quality and heritage of Peabody estates."

The work is expected to be complete in March 2015, but the first new tenants will begin moving in May 2014.
shortdescription: Work has now begun on 112 new homes on the Silchester Estate, comprising 39 larger properties for social rent, 45 smaller properties for shared ownership and a further 28 smaller homes for sale on the open market to help pay for the work.
shorttitle: Work begins on new homes

headline: CENTRAL LONDON LIBRARIES LAUNCH SUMMER READING CHALLENGE 2013
prcopy:
Children in central London are being invited to keep up a good habit of reading out of school through a national programme run through local libraries.

Libraries in Hammersmith & Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea and Westminster are inviting children, aged four to 11, to complete the Reading Agency's `Summer Reading Challenge' which tasks the youngsters with reading six books during the six-week summer break.

Launched by `Spooky Spooky House' children's author Andrew Weale at Kensington Central Library yesterday (Thursday 11 July), the challenge sets out to encourage children to keep reading regularly when the schools are closed.

During the challenge children are tasked with reading six different titles borrowed from their local library over the summer break.

They will then discuss aspects of each book, such as plot lines and their favourite character, with library staff or one of a hundred volunteers helping out with this year's challenge across the three boroughs.

The programme is flexible, allowing children to complete each book in their own time and drop in during any of the library's opening hours to record their progress as they work towards completing the challenge and receiving a medal and certificate marking their achievement.

Cllr Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Libraries, said:

"The Summer Reading Challenge is a fantastic initiative and goes from strength to strength each year.

"I'd like to encourage as many of our young people as possible to get involved and discover the pleasure that reading a good book can bring."

Cllr Greg Smith, Deputy Leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Council, said:

"We hope as many local children as possible will accept this exciting mission and enjoy a summer of reading.

"Literacy is a fundamental cornerstone of a modern society and initiatives such as this get kids to open up their minds to a world of reading."

Cllr Steve Summers, Westminster City Council's Cabinet Member for Community Services, said:

"We often hear how the literacy levels of children who don't keep up the habit of reading during the summer holidays can drop over the six-week long school break.

"This is obviously a concern for parents and teachers alike, but the Summer Reading Challenge helps to address this by encouraging young people to keep reading regularly over the holidays and familiarise themselves more with our libraries in doing so.

"The challenge is something which those who take part really enjoy year-on-year, but importantly, it provides our children with an opportunity to improve, or at least maintain their literacy levels over the summer, allowing them to progress come the new term in September, rather than play catch up."


The Tri-borough libraries launch of the Summer Reading Challenge comes ahead of the Get Reading Festival in Trafalgar Square which is being held by the Evening Standard and Mayor of London.

Five librarians from the boroughs of Hammersmith & Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea and Westminster will be on hand at the event working with colleagues from the Reading Agency in encouraging youngsters to sign up for the challenge.
shortdescription: Children in central London are being invited to keep up a good habit of reading out of school through a national programme run through local libraries.
shorttitle: Central London libraries launch Summer Reading Challenge 2013

headline: BENEFIT CHEAT WHO SUBLET HER FLAT PLEADS GUILTY
prcopy:
A woman who sublet rooms in her house whilst claiming benefits pleaded guilty to fraud at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Wednesday 10 July and was sentenced to six weeks imprisonment, suspended for 12 months and ordered to pay £500 costs.

Ms Beata Dymiter, 42, of Jones Road, Plaistow, London E13 and formerly of Markland House, Darfield Way, W10 claimed housing benefit and council tax benefit from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, but withheld details of her true income, including rental income from tenants living in her flat.

Following an anonymous tip-off, Council investigators began making enquiries and established that Ms Dymiter rented out three rooms in her property for £100, £110 and £120 per week. This income was never declared to the Council when she applied for benefit.

Between March 2011 and December 2012 Ms Dymiter was overpaid housing and council tax benefits totalling £12,565.11.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, Cabinet Member for Finance, said: "This is an example of the type of abuse we are determined to take action on. Ms Dymiter knew she was abusing the system and hiding her income in order to take more than £12,000 off the taxpayer.

"We cannot and will not stand by while people take money that is intended for people in genuine need."

In mitigation the court heard that Ms Dymiter was of previous good character and that she was a single mother who had difficulty supporting her child financially and emotionally.

The Council and Ms Dymiter have reached an agreement for her to repay the overpayment in instalments.
shortdescription: A woman who sublet rooms in her house whilst claiming benefits pleaded guilty to fraud at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Wednesday 10 July and was sentenced to six weeks imprisonment, suspended for 12 months and ordered to pay £500 costs.
shorttitle: Benefit cheat who sublet her flat pleads guilty

headline: THE RACE FOR DOGGETT'S COAT & BADGE
prcopy:
Six competitors fought fiercely for the Doggett's Coat & Badge last Friday (12 July) in a boat race that has been taking place on the River Thames each year since 1715. This year's victor was Nathaniel Brice of the Poplar, Blackwall and District Rowing Club who crossed the line in just under 25 minutes.

The race, in its 299th year, had a special visitor in HRH The Princess Royal who presented Nathaniel with a bottle of champagne.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams, greeted Her Royal Highness along with the competitors at the end of the four miles and seven furlongs course that stretches from London Bridge to Cadogan Pier in Chelsea.

This annual event passes largely unnoticed, despite the thrilling races it often provides and its impressive longevity; the Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race is a mere whippersnapper in comparison, starting in only 1829.

Thomas Doggett was an Irish actor and comedian who came to London around the year 1690. After playing many parts at Drury Lane he became its manager.

The Watermen of the Thames, who were much more numerous than they are today, were then the equivalent of the modern taxi driver. They were licensed to row passengers along and across the River Thames. No doubt Doggett relied heavily on their services. A staunch Whig, opposed to any restoration of the Stuarts, he founded the race to commemorate the first anniversary of the accession of the Hanoverian George I.

Thomas Doggett himself organised the race until his death in 1721. In his will, he instructed his executors to endow the race, which was to be managed by Mr Edward Burt of the Admiralty Office. Mr Burt was apparently unwilling to assume the burden laid upon him by Doggett and it was arranged that the executors should pay over to the Worshipful Company of Fishmongers the sum of £300 and that the Company, which added £50 to the fund, should henceforth carry out Doggett's wishes.

The Fishmongers' Company has faithfully complied with their undertaking ever since, despite the not inconsiderable rise in costs since 1721.

This year's victor was Nathaniel Brice of the Poplar, Blackwall and District Rowing Club who crossed the line in just under 25 minutes.
shorttitle: The Race for Doggett's Coat & Badge

headline: InTRANSIT Festival launches with UFO crash landing
prcopy:
A UFO crash landing in a car park in Notting Hill on Friday 19 July will officially launch this year's InTRANSIT Festival of Arts.

`Crashed' which features as part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's InTRANSIT Festival promises to take audience members on an interactive adventure of the alien unknown through private tours of the site.

`Crashed' is organised by ImmerCity, an established theatre company, which is taking two of its shows to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival later this year. It promises to captivate young and old alike.

The event takes place in Lowerwood Court, at the junction of Ladbroke Grove and Westbourne Park, from Friday 19 to Saturday 27 July at 7pm, with matinee performances on Saturday 20, Sunday 21 and Saturday 27 July at 3pm. Booking is essential at www.immer-city.com

InTRANSIT runs from Friday 19 to Saturday 27 July at venues across the borough. Highlights of the festival include an orchestra on the move through the borough's streets, the colourful history of the King's Road told through the medium of discarded chewing gum, family puzzles, tea dances and a celebration of 150 years of the Underground.

For more information about InTRANSIT and events visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/intransit

Find out the latest news via Twitter by following @RBKCculture, #InTRANSITFestival and check out the Facebook page www.facebook.com/RBKCculture for any updates.

headline: PLANNING APPLICATION SUBMITTED FOR KENSINGTON CENTRAL LIBRARY RENOVATION
prcopy:
A planning application to carry out essential repairs to the fabric of Kensington Central Library has been submitted to the Royal Borough.

Built in the 1960s the library's mechanical and electrical systems have exceeded their life expectancy and a major overhaul is now needed. The application includes plans to modernise the electrics and make it more comfortable for library users by installing a more energy-efficient heating and ventilation system. Other details include new hot and cold water services, refurbishing the lifts and installing public toilets on the lower ground floor. Essential repairs to the roof will also be carried out.

Funding of £5.8m for the project was approved by the Royal Borough last November and will ensure that the building can continue to meet the needs of the community for at least the next twenty years. The works will improve the overall use of space including creating new offices from previously underutilised space, some of which will be available to rent to the local business community.

Councillor Emma Will, Cabinet Member for Libraries, said:

"These works are essential if Kensington Central Library is to remain open for business and this cash injection demonstrates our ongoing commitment to investing in the Royal Borough's libraries."

A decision on the planning application is expected in the autumn and if granted works are expected to start in early 2014.

Due to the scale of the repairs there may be some disruption to library services. The Council is committed to keeping this to an absolute minimum and as much work as possible will take place outside library opening times. Any disruption to services will be publicised well in advance.

Visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/centralworks for the latest information and to register for e-updates.
shortdescription: A planning application to carry out essential repairs to the fabric of Kensington Central Library has been submitted to the Royal Borough.
shorttitle: Planning application submitted for Kensington Central Library renovation

headline: LIZ BRUCE FILLS TOP ADULT SOCIAL CARE JOB
prcopy:
The UK's top job in adult social services is to be filled by Liz Bruce. From early October, Liz takes over as the Executive Director of Adult Social Care for three leading London councils: the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster.

The ground-breaking, Tri-borough, shared service is currently headed by interim manager Sue Redmond and provides adult social care across central and west London. It also leads the way in moving to greater integration, not just across the three councils, but also with local health services in all three areas.

The sharing of adult care is one of the main innovations that has delivered major savings for the three councils since the tri-borough programme began in 2011. The programme is currently on target to deliver £40 million of savings per year, across all services, by 2015.

Liz takes up the Tri-borough post after four very successful years as the Strategic Director for Families, Health and Wellbeing at Manchester City Council. Her portfolio in Manchester covers all adult social care, including mental health, homelessness, domestic violence, troubled families and public health.

Liz greeted the news of her appointment by saying: "I am absolutely delighted and excited in equal measure."

Liz will oversee a joint budget of over £300 million and report to three cabinet members: Cllr Marcus Ginn in H&F; Cllr Rachael Robathan in Westminster; and Cllr Mary Weale in Kensington and Chelsea, who all welcomed the appointment.

Speaking on behalf of the three councils, Cllr Ginn said: "This is a top-flight job working for not just one, but all three, of the country's most fast moving councils. We are thrilled that Liz has agreed to join us, bringing with her an impressive background and a new injection of enthusiasm to our top management team."

Liz is an established member of the National Health Task Transition Group and has worked in education, health and local government since 1974, is a trained special education teacher, general nurse and social worker.

Liz worked in the North East, in Tyneside, for many years in areas of high social deprivation and started her career in family neighbourhood centres working across health and education.

headline: MOO-VING IN
prcopy:
Have you herd the news? Two magnificent English Longhorn cows with their calves have moved into Holland Park for the summer as a chemical- and mechanical-free way to help with the restoration of the old butterfly meadow.

The Longhorns - one of the oldest and largest of the native breeds of British cow - are renowned for their docility, strong maternal instincts and rough grazing abilities. Where other cattle turn up their noses the Longhorn digs in: nettles, diverse grasses, wild flowers and thistles - it eats them all.

Safely kept in the Wildlife Enclosure, Oak Enclosure and Arboretum by special fencing, the cows' main task will be tackling the overgrown brambles and nettles.

The introduction of cows is part of the Council's plan to improve and maintain Holland Park.

The cows follow the pigs who were previously used successfully in these enclosures.

headline: DON'T GET CAUGHT OUT BY CYCLING EVENT ON SUNDAY 4 AUGUST
prcopy:

Organised by The Mayor of London and Transport for London (TfL), Prudential RideLondon will see 20,000 amateur cyclists ride their bikes through the borough on Sunday, 4 August. The amateur event will be followed, on the same day, by an elite race with approximately 150 cyclists.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is warning residents and businesses to expect significant transport disruption throughout the day, with major roads and bridges closed to traffic. Parking along the route will be suspended on the day. If you usually park on an affected road, you should move your vehicle elsewhere the night before (Saturday 3 August), otherwise it may be removed.

Certain stretches of roads in the borough will be kept free of suspensions and obstructions such as skips whilst the race is underway. If you're moving home, having some work done or trying to arrange deliveries you may not be able to reserve space near your home or business during the RideLondon cycle race on Sunday 4 August. For more details call 020 7361 4385.

If you're planning to be away during the weekend of the event, please remember that residents with parking permits are entitled to concessionary rates in the Kensington Town Hall car park in Hornton Street. The resident rate for long-term absence is (minimum one week and a daily charge for stays of more than one week): £46.20 minimum and £6.60 per day beyond the first week. For further information please contact the car park staff directly on 020 7937 7040.

There will be a large number of road closures around the route from early morning on 4 August to make sure the route is secure and ready for the 100 mile cycling event. Local river crossings and roads closed to traffic but not pedestrians on Sunday 4 August will include:

headline: BOROUGH PRIMARY SCHOOL CHILDREN TOPS IN ENGLISH,WRITING AND MATHEMATICS
prcopy:
When it comes to the three Rs, Year Six pupils in the Royal Borough are outpacing the rest of the country according to the latest figures from the Department of Education.

The Royal Borough's provisional results at Key Stage 2 currently show that 84 per cent of children have achieved Level 4 or above in reading, writing and mathematics, the national average for 2012 was 75 per cent.

In reading 93 per cent have provisionally achieved two levels of progress from Key Stage 1 (age six to seven); the national average in 2012 was 88 per cent. In writing, 96 per cent have provisionally achieved two levels of progress (90 per cent nationally in 2012) and in mathematics 95 per cent (90 per cent nationally in 2012).

Commenting on the provisional results, Cllr Emma Will, Cabinet Member for Education and Libraries, said: "These early figures are a good indication of how effective the borough's schools are. It is gratifying that the early indications suggest that, based on national averages from 2012, Kensington and Chelsea have out-performed the national schools average for Key Stage 2. This is down to the hard work and dedication of our teachers and children. Well done."

headline: NEW SERVICE TO HELP RESIDENTS AFFECTED BY DRUG AND ALCOHOL MISUSE
prcopy:
A new treatment service for borough residents who are affected by drug and alcohol misuse was launched by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams, on Wednesday 24 July.

The KC North Hub Blenheim launched its new service which offers an integrated approach to the treatment of drug and alcohol addiction and dependency; bringing together in partnership the experience and expertise of Blenheim, Central and North West London NHS Foundation Trust (CNWL), Foundation66, and Build on Belief (BoB).

The partnership, led by the Public Health Substance Misuse and Offender Health Commissioning Team for the borough, was developed to offer a range of services delivered from under one roof which work together for the health and well-being of service users, carers, relatives and friends experiencing drug and/or alcohol-related problems.

The event launched the new purpose-built and designed service which complements a mirror service in the south of the borough, the South KC Hub at Warwick Road, SW5 hosted by CNWL. Borough residents seeking treatment can access services via either hub.

Welcoming the integrated approach the Royal Borough's Mayor, Cllr Williams, said: "For every £1 spend on drug treatment £2.50 is saved in the costs to the community. Successful drug treatment promotes and improves well-being, reduces emergency hospital admissions, cuts crime and reduces re-offending and prevents drug-related deaths and illnesses.

"Providing access to all available treatment at either hub is already proving successful. During the past April and May both hubs have achieved 90 per cent successful treatment discharges which is twice the London average of 45 per cent for the same period."

Other speakers at the event included John Jolly, Blenheim CEO, Paul Anders of Drugscope a charity that supports professionals working in drug and alcohol treatment, drug education and prevention, Tim Sampey of BoB and service users who shared their experiences of recovery.

keyword4: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: A new treatment service for borough residents who are affected by drug and alcohol misuse was launched by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams, on Wednesday 24 July.

headline: MIDDLE ROW TO BECOME AN ARK ACADEMY
prcopy:
Plans for Middle Row Primary School to convert to an academy received the final endorsement of the Royal Borough Cabinet (18 July).

The school will reopen in September as the Ark Brunel Primary Academy, one of 27 academies run by the educational charity ARK Schools.

"We are setting Middle Row on a new path and leaving its troubled recent history behind," explained Councillor Emma Will, Cabinet Member for Education and Libraries.

"Not only is it becoming an academy, it will soon have a superb new school building thanks to the Council."

The school was served with a Notice to Improve by Ofsted following an inspection in March 2012. To ensure the swiftest possible return to the expected standard, the Council initiated the removal of the governing body which was then replaced by an Interim Executive Board. The Cabinet's green light to join the ARK group of schools ensures a permanent and stable future for the school.

"We have seen some encouraging progress already with the school having been adjudged 'good' by Ofsted last month" added Councillor Will. "We hope there will be much, much more to come."

Work is currently underway on a brand new school building for Middle Row which will include a new speech and language centre. Due to open in September 2014 it will accommodate 496 pupils rather than the present 255 and will offer modern, first class facilities right across the curriculum.
shortdescription: Plans for Middle Row Primary School to convert to an academy received the final endorsement of the Royal Borough Cabinet (18 July).
shorttitle: Middle Row to become an Ark Academy

headline: GOVERNMENT GIVES GREEN LIGHT TO NEW POLICY TO PROTECT ROYAL BOROUGH'S PUBS
prcopy:
The Government has given the green light to a new planning policy which gives the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea powers to protect the borough's pubs.

Since 1980 there has been a 35 per cent decline in the number of public houses in Kensington and Chelsea, from 168 to 110 today.

With spiralling house prices this trend has accelerated in recent years and celebrated Chelsea pub the Cross Keys was closed for conversion to residential use. While planning permission for the change of use was refused by the Council, it was against this background that the Royal Borough decided to draft a policy to help keep its pubs open for business.

Now the Government's Planning Inspector has approved this planning policy giving the Royal Borough the power to stop pubs being converted to residential use where they make an important contribution to the community. Restaurants, cafés and banks also have an important part to play in local life and these will also be protected.

Another strand of this policy takes into account the positive contribution that the use of a property can make to the character of a conservation area.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said:

"Despite the economic downturn, residential land values in Kensington and Chelsea can command huge sums of money and as such they out compete any other use.

"This policy seeks to protect those uses that have lower land values, but remain of high value to the community.

"Over the past thirty years we have seen a significant reduction in the number of pubs in the borough and what we don't want is for people to lose the ability to pop into their local for a pint and a chat."


For more information and to read a copy of the Inspector's report please visit
www.rbkc.gov.uk/planningandconservation/planningpolicy.aspx
shortdescription: The Government has given the green light to a new planning policy which gives the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea powers to protect the borough's pubs.
shorttitle: Government gives green light to new policy to protect Royal Borough's pubs

headline: ADVERTISING FIRM PLEADS GUILTY TO ILLEGAL ADVERTISEMENT HOARDING
prcopy:
King Media Limited pleaded guilty on Tuesday 23 July at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court to displaying a large illuminated advertisement hoarding in the heart of South Kensington without consent.

The advertisement, on the side of 206 Brompton Road, advertised local luxurious brands and had a harmful impact on residents and the conservation area.

The advertisement was located on Crown Estate land and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea had no powers to remove the hoarding. Officers from the Royal Borough's planning department successfully lobbied the Ministry of Defence (MOD) and permission to start formal action was obtained and the advertisement and hoarding were removed earlier in the year.

King Media Limited was prosecuted by the Royal Borough under section 224 (3) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 and found guilty of three separate offences, receiving fines totalling £4,200 and costs of £6,500.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning, said:

"The hoarding was very large and caused unnecessary upset to local residents. I am very pleased that we were able to work with the MOD and get it removed. This sentence sends a strong message to other advertising firms that proper permission must be sought before hoardings are erected."
