shorttitle: Advertising firm pleads guilty to illegal advertisement hoarding

headline: FALSE CLAIM FOR BENEFITS LEADS TO FINE
prcopy:
A Bi-borough operation between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham ensured that a woman who falsely claimed more than £17,000 in benefits had her assets frozen.

Miss Kate Horgan,52, of Holland Road, Kensington, W14, claimed Housing Benefit and Job Seeker's Allowance on the basis that she did not have any significant savings. However, an investigation by council and Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) investigators discovered she had been receiving interest on capital in accounts that had not been declared for benefit purposes. Bank statements obtained for the undeclared accounts showed that her capital exceeded £44,000 between October 2009 and March 2012. Normally savings in excess of £16,000 entail a reduction in benefits payable.

A guilty plea was registered by Kate Horgan at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on 14 May. Due to the amount of the overpayment the case was then referred to Isleworth Crown Court for sentencing on 8 July. However, at the sentencing hearing Miss Horgan confirmed she had no intention of repaying the debt and would rather go to prison. Therefore, the matter was adjourned whilst a financial investigator from the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham worked to successfully freeze her bank accounts under the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002.

The matter was heard again at Isleworth Crown Court on 18 July. The Judge ordered Miss Horgan to repay the full amount of the overpayments from the frozen bank accounts or face 11 months' imprisonment. She was further ordered to pay a fine of £7,500 or face six months' imprisonment. She was also ordered to pay the full costs of the lengthy legal proceedings taken by Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea which amounted to £3,753.50.

During the period 12 October 2009 to 29 April 2012, Miss Horgan was overpaid Housing Benefit amounting to £12,033.82 and Job Seeker's Allowance amounting to £5,325.93.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Finance and Strategy, said: "This woman chose deliberately to conceal the amount of money she had saved in order to claim benefits. I am pleased that our officers, working closely with their colleagues in Hammersmith & Fulham and the DWP, were able to uncover this deception and that the court has taken such a dim view of the offence."
shortdescription: A Bi-borough operation between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham ensured that a woman who falsely claimed more than £17,000 in benefits had her assets frozen.
shorttitle: False claim for benefits leads to fine

headline: MAYOR MEETS TRINITY HOSPICE VOLUNTEERS
prcopy:
The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams, met volunteers at the Trinity Hospice Shop on Kensington Church Street (Monday 29 July) as part of his campaign to promote the hospice during his year as Mayor.

Trinity Hospice provides specialist care for adults who have life-limiting illnesses. Each year it provides assistance to over 2,000 people, 340 of whom are Royal Borough residents and of these 240 are cared for in their own homes.

Last year Trinity staff made over 1,100 individual visits to patients in Kensington and Chelsea, this included 975 nurse visits, as well as visits from the Patient and Family Support team, doctors, physiotherapists and occupational therapists.

As well as providing nursing and medical care Trinity Hospice offers practical and emotional support for patients and their families. The hospice also shares its skills with other care providers including care homes, hospitals, GPs and district nurses.

All the care is given entirely free of charge and the charity relies on support from the local community to generate the majority of its funding. In the Royal Borough, the hospice has five shops to supplement donations (one in King's Road, two in Kensington Church Street, one in Bute Street and one in Notting Hill Gate).

Cllr Williams said: "Trinity Hospice has been caring for the people of Kensington and Chelsea and Central and south-west London for over 120 years. At a very emotional and critical time in a person's life Trinity Hospice is there to provide care, support and friendship, either at the hospice in Clapham or in their own home.

"Trinity shops are a vital source of income for the charity and I want to encourage people to support them either by shopping in them or becoming a volunteer. All profits raised in the shops go directly to the charity which costs nearly £10 million a year to run. The Government can only provide 30 per cent of the funding so the remaining £7 million must be raised from the public by donations or their support of the shops."

Sally Bateson, Trinity Hospice's Director of Fundraising and Communications, said: "We are delighted to have the support of the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea this year. We are very much looking forward to working with him and his team to raise both funds and awareness in the Royal Borough over the coming months. The support of local residents is so important in helping us continue to provide our vital end-of-life care services to over 300 people in the borough this year.

For information about supporting Trinity or to get information on any of the services it offers go to www.trinityhospice.org.uk or call 020 7787 1000.

For more information about the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and his Trinity Hospice Campaign go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/mayor
shortdescription: The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams, met volunteers at the Trinity Hospice Shop on Kensington Church Street (Monday 29 July) as part of his campaign to promote the hospice during his year as Mayor.
shorttitle: Mayor meets Trinity Hospice volunteers

headline: BE PREPARED FOR TRANSPORT DISRUPTION ON SUNDAY 4 AUGUST
prcopy:
Residents and businesses should expect significant transport disruption on Sunday 4 August when the Prudential RideLondon cycling event passes through the borough.

Organised by The Mayor of London and Transport for London (TfL), Prudential RideLondon will see 20,000 amateur cyclists ride through the borough on Sunday 4 August. The amateur event will be followed, on the same day, by an elite race with approximately 150 cyclists.

Roads and bridges along the route of the race will be closed to traffic from 5am on Sunday 4 August and are estimated to reopen between 2.30pm and 7.15pm depending on where they are on the route.

Parking along the route will be suspended on the day. If you usually park on an affected road, you should move your vehicle elsewhere the night before (Saturday 3 August), otherwise it may be removed.

There will be a large number of road closures around the route from early morning on Sunday 4 August to make sure the route is secure and ready for the 100-mile event. Local river crossings and roads closed to traffic, but not pedestrians, on Sunday 4 August will include:

 A4 (westbound closure only between Warwick Road and Hogarth roundabout) - closed from 5am to approximately 2.30pm
 A4 (closed in both directions between Hyde Park Corner and Warwick Road) - closed from 5am to approximately 2.30pm
 Battersea Bridge - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Albert Bridge- closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 King's Road (between Gunter Grove and Putney Bridge) - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Ashburnham Road - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Cremorne Road - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Cheyne Walk - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Chelsea Embankment - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Chelsea Bridge - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Chiswick Bridge - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Putney Bridge - closed from 5am to approximately 7.15pm
 Grosvenor Road - closed from 5am to approximately 7.30pm
 Millbank - closed from 5am to approximately 7.30pm
 Vauxhall Bridge - closed from 5am to approximately 7.30pm
 Lambeth Bridge - closed from 5am to approximately 7.30pm
 Westminster Bridge - closed from 5am to approximately 7.30pm


Full details of road closures are available at www.tfl.gov.uk/prudentialridelondon Drivers are urged to plan ahead or to consider re-timing their journey to avoid disruption, particularly if people are planning to travel to or from airports, or to a special event. For information about a specific road closure call TfL customer services on 0343 222 1234.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "Roads right across London and out to Surrey will be closed to allow this event to take place. Road closures on such a large scale will inevitably cause disruption. The best way to minimise any inconvenience is to plan ahead and try to avoid driving close to the route if at all possible.

"If you normally park your car on the route make sure that you don't on Sunday 4 August as it may be towed away."

headline: SUMMER ACTIVITIES AT HOLLAND PARK ECOLOGY CENTRE

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH INVESTS IN VOLUNTARY ORGANISATIONS
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is opening its yearly funding opportunity to local voluntary and community groups, as part of its Corporate Services Grants programme.

Over £2m is available to support priorities that demonstrate the Council's commitment to voluntary organisations and their role in improving life opportunities for residents.

The new grants round for funding in 2014-15 follows a call for applications from voluntary groups for specific, innovative projects last month.

The Council is looking for proposals that address its main priorities in the grants scheme which are: providing information and advice services to residents; support to smaller voluntary organisations and providing community engagement opportunities.

In addition, the Council is advertising Adult Social Care and Carers' services grants which will support services that help older people to stay active and involved in their community. Carers' services grants are available for community-based support to informal unpaid adult carers, aged 18 and over, to continue in their caring role for an adult resident of the Royal Borough.

Bids for the cash have to be in by noon on Friday 6 September 2013 and to succeed bidders will, amongst other things, need to be a voluntary, community or social enterprise organisation, and be based in Kensington and Chelsea or have a demonstrable local connection.

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement said: "I am very pleased that, despite great pressures on the Council's finances ,we are able to make £2m available to support the work of local voluntary and community groups.

"The continuing efforts of those that work in the community and voluntary sector bring great benefit to many people of all backgrounds in the borough. I would encourage those that run these services to look carefully at our priorities and I look forward to the Council being able to provide important funding to assist them in the coming year."

A drop-in session for organisations to discuss the funding and how to apply has been organised for Wednesday 21 August, 11am to 4pm at Kensington Town Hall, Committee Room 2. Organisations that wish to attend are asked to email communityengagement@rbkc.gov.uk to book a time to meet with officers.


For more information, including the criteria for the fund and how to apply, visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/communityfunding or call the Community Engagement Team on 020 7598 4633 or email
communityengagement@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is opening its yearly funding opportunity to local voluntary and community groups, as part of its Corporate Services Grants programme.
shorttitle: Royal Borough invests in voluntary organisations

headline: NEW INITIATIVE LOOKS AT WAYS OF SUPPORTING CHILDREN FROM TROUBLED BACKGROUNDS
prcopy:
Three central London boroughs have been chosen to take part in a new initiative to find out the best ways of giving children from troubled backgrounds the social and emotional skills they need to thrive.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council and Hammersmith & Fulham Council have been identified by the Early Intervention Foundation (EIF) to join 19 places up and down the country to focus on how children and families can be supported before problems occur.

Over the next 18 months councils will share knowledge with Police and Crime Commissioners, Clinical Commissioning Groups and Directors of Public Health to build up a picture of what intervention programmes have the most impact, thereby determining where money can most effectively be spent.

Andrew Christie, Tri-borough Executive Director of Children's Services, said:

"Our three boroughs are committed to giving our children the very best start in life and supporting families before problems arise is the best way of achieving this.

"We know that early intervention is more cost-effective and most importantly improves the outcomes for children at risk."

EIF CEO, Carey Oppenheim, said; "The EIF believes that addressing the root causes of social problems, rather than trying to fix their after-effects, is better not only for individual children but for our society as a whole. Underpinned by robust evidence our mission is to change to a predominant culture from costly late reaction to effective early intervention. This first wave of 20 pioneering places will ground that mission in real life, giving us invaluable working examples of success."

shortdescription: Three central London boroughs have been chosen to take part in a new initiative to find out the best ways of giving children from troubled backgrounds the social and emotional skills they need to thrive.
shorttitle: New initiative looks at ways of supporting children from troubled backgrounds

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH SCHOOLS CELEBRATE A LEVEL SUCCESS
prcopy:
Students from schools in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are celebrating excellent A level results today (Thursday 15 August). Overall averages for the Royal Borough were well above the national average with 48 per cent gaining A* and A grades (national 26 per cent), 75 per cent A* to B (national 53 per cent) and 92 per cent A* to C (national 77 per cent).

Holland Park School students, who recently moved into their magnificent new building, have recorded the best set of results in the school's history.

Passes at grades A* to B were 71 per cent, up from 61 per cent in 2012, well above the national average of 53 per cent.

Passes at A* and A were 37 per cent, up from 28 per cent in 2012. The national average is 26 per cent.

94 per cent of students achieved grades A* to C which was also above the national average of 77 percent.

Colin Hall, Head of Holland Park School, said: "We are delighted to have achieved our highest ever A level results, particularly in a national context of more difficult examinations and grade deflation."

There were some stunning individual performances from star students at the school. Hibba Mazhary gained A*s in English, French, Geography and Mathematics, thus securing her place at Oxford University. Commenting on her results Hibba, said: "I'm so pleased. I can hardly believe I'll be starting at Oxford this autumn. Thank you for all the inspiration; from my parents, from my teachers and, most of all, from my school."

And it was an historic day for the Chelsea Academy which celebrated its first ever set of A level results. Chelsea Academy is the first new secondary school built in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea for fifty years. It opened in September 2009 in temporary accommodation before moving into its award-winning new building on Lots Road a year later. Its sixth form opened in 2011.

Passes at A* to C were 79 per cent compared with the national average of 77 per cent.

Amongst many individual successes was the Academy's first Oxbridge place secured by Kim Engel who achieved an A* in Government and Politics, History and Mathematics and is going on to study Politics, Philosophy and Economics at Hertford College, Oxford.

Other fine performances came from:

Charlotte Baylon who achieved an A* in Mathematics, and A grades in Chemistry and Psychology, and is going on to study Mathematics at Nottingham University.

Matthew Gela who achieved an A grade in Chemistry, Economics and Mathematics, and an A* in Further Mathematics and a merit Advanced Extension Award for Mathematics, is going on to study Mathematics at Imperial College London.

Chelsea Academy Principal, Andy Yarrow, said: "We are absolutely delighted with this first set of A level results. A huge amount of hard work on the part of students and staff over the past two years has paid off. When deciding to open the Sixth Form before our own students had reached Year 12 age, we knew that we were taking a chance. However, this has proven to be a step well worth taking and bodes well for the future as the Sixth Form continues to grow. My congratulations and thanks go to all those who have played a part in this success."

Cardinal Vaughan Memorial School also celebrated another set of outstanding A level results.

Passes at grades A* to B were 87 per cent, up from 83 per cent in 2012 and well above the national average of 53 per cent.

The percentage of pupils getting grades A* to C is 97 per cent, as in 2012 and above this year's national average of 77 per cent.

Passes at A* and A were 62 per cent up from 52 per cent. The national average is 26 per cent.
Head Teacher Paul Stubbings, said: "We went up by ten per cent from a very high baseline in a year when the national proportion at A* and A went down.

"I'm delighted with these outstanding results because they are the best possible reward for all the hard work of staff and pupils at the Vaughan."
Some of the highest achieving students include:
Samson Frezgi, who got an A* in Mathematics, and two As in Economics and History. He will be going on to study Economics at the London School of Economics.
Olivia Phelan achieved four A grades in English, History, French and Mathematics securing a place at Oxford University to study Politics, Philosophy and Economics.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "Congratulations to all the students and staff at Holland Park School, Chelsea Academy and the Cardinal Vaughan Memorial School on such a fantastic performance. This really is a tribute to the hard work and commitment of staff and students.

"I am particularly pleased to see the first set of pupils to take A levels at the Chelsea Academy setting a high standard for the future. I am also delighted that the students at Holland Park School, in their first year in their new surroundings, have achieved such magnificent results.

"This year's A level results show just why we are so proud of our schools in Kensington and Chelsea."
shortdescription: Students from schools in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are celebrating excellent A level results today (Thursday 15 August).  Overall averages for the Royal Borough were well above the national average with 48 per cent gaining A* and A grades (national 26 per cent), 75 per cent A* to B (national 53 per cent) and 92 per cent A* to C (national 77 per cent).

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH SCHOOLS AND PUPILS CELEBRATE GCSE SUCCESS
prcopy:
Pupils from Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea schools are celebrating GCSE success after the exam results were announced today (Thursday 22 August).

Results have bucked the national trend with 80 per cent of pupils achieving five A* to C grades, including English and mathematics, across the borough for the second year running.

At Holland Park School 87 per cent of students gained the all important five A* to C grades including English and mathematics.

The school is particularly proud of its English Baccalaureate figure which has risen from 24 per cent to 43 per cent this year. This is the proportion of students who have gained the combination of English, mathematics, double science, a language and a humanities subject at GCSE.

This year, 38 per cent of Holland Park students achieved A* or A, up from 32 per cent last year and well above the 2013 national average of 21 per cent.

Colin Hall, Head of Holland Park School, said of the results: "We are proud of both the students and teachers who have worked so hard to produce these outstanding grades. Our fast-rising English Baccalaureate and A* and A figures show a school that is committed to serious, academic study and can equip students with the qualifications and grades they need to compete in today's increasingly competitive world."

In a field of excellent results the performances of Omar Sabbagh and Noah Tucker stood out with both boys gaining 11 A* grades.
Cardinal Vaughan Memorial School enjoyed another fine year with 91 per cent of pupils achieving five or more GCSEs graded A* to C, including English and mathematics, up from 88 per cent in 2012.

Commenting on the pupils' achievements, Paul Stubbings, Head teacher at Cardinal Vaughan Memorial School, said "I'm delighted with these outstanding results because they are the best possible reward for all the hard work of staff and pupils at the Vaughan. Teachers and students work together very well: they expect a lot from each other and deliver the goods. I congratulate them all."

Kit Stanford, 16, who attained eight grade A* and four As, said: "I was extremely pleased with the grades I attained and thank my teachers for all their help."

Thomas King, who achieved 12 A* grades, said: "I'm really glad that all the hard work and revision I've done has paid off and am looking forward to starting A levels."

There was also good news at St Thomas More Language College where 74 per cent of pupils gained five or more A* to C, including English and mathematics, up from 70 per cent in 2012.

Dr Trevor Papworth, Head of Thomas More Language College, congratulated the pupils saying: "St Thomas More Language College is delighted to be celebrating another year of continued success, which reflects the hard work and commitment of our students, their families and our dedicated staff."

And Sion Manning school also saw improved performance with 72 per cent of pupils gaining five or more A* to C grades, including English and mathematics, up from 66 per cent in 2012.

There was also success for all the pupils taught in the borough's Pupil Referral Unit. They all gained at least one qualification.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "These excellent results are a reward for many hours of hard work by pupils and teachers in all of our schools and I congratulate everyone concerned. I am particularly pleased to see so many of our young people passing English and mathematics.

"Results like this show why we are right to be so proud of our schools."
shortdescription: Pupils from Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea schools are celebrating GCSE success after the exam results were announced today (Thursday 22 August).
shorttitle: Royal Borough pupils celebrate GCSE success

headline: MARKETS CELEBRATE ENGLISH APPLES
prcopy:
Portobello Road, famous for its fashion, antiques and atmosphere, is set to celebrate English apples at a special cooking demonstration on Friday 18 October.

Guest chef Oliver Rowe, from BBC's Urban Chef series, will join forces with food entrepreneur Clippy McKenna to create a selection of mouth-watering dishes using seasonal traditional English apples - including some from the Brogdale Collections in Kent - which will be on sale at nearby stalls.

This is the fifth year that the Portobello and Golborne Road Markets have promoted English apples. It is part of an ongoing campaign to promote the markets' fruit and vegetable stalls. This includes a Road Food demonstration on the third Friday of each month and Saturday sample tastings at select stalls.

While English apples are flavour of the month during October, November will have a very definite Middle Eastern and North African theme to coincide with the Royal Borough's Nour festival of the arts and culture.

Cllr Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for the Environment, said: "There is a great variety of fruit and vegetables available at Portobello and Golborne Markets and the Road Food demonstrations are an innovative way to promote seasonal food such as English apples. I want to encourage local residents to visit the markets often for food shopping and for inspiration. The value for money, freshness and quality of ingredients on offer is excellent."

Road Food demonstrations take place on the third Friday of each month at a stall beside the Office shoe shop, 217 Portobello Road. If you have a suggestion for a theme email the Royal Borough's Markets Office, street.trading@rbkc.gov.uk.

Saturday sample tastings are prepared by volunteer teams from local community organisations and catering colleges. The Markets Office is looking for groups interested in handing out recipe sheets and creating tasty sample dishes from ingredients grown in nearby community kitchen gardens and supplemented by fruit and vegetables bought from the markets and local shops.

headline: BIGGEST CLEAN-UP IN THE CAPITAL
prcopy:
An estimated 225 tonnes of rubbish were cleared from the roads of Notting Hill following this year's Carnival.

The Council's contractors, SITA UK, had more than 200 people working into the early hours of Monday and Tuesday in an operation involving more than 30 refuse trucks, mechanical sweepers and transit vans. The team also employed a large motorway vehicle to wash down the roads. The clean-up finished at 3am on Tuesday 27 August.

Commenting on the huge task Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environment and Leisure, Councillor Tim Ahern, said: "This was another great year for Notting Hill Carnival, with hundreds of thousands of visitors. We hope that they all enjoyed themselves, but the event certainly creates an enormous amount of waste.

"Our contractor, SITA UK, and Council officers deal with the logistical challenge of clearing the streets of one of Europe's biggest street parties with consummate professionalism. I would like to thank them for all their hard work and I am sure residents are happy that when they get up for work on Tuesday morning their streets have been returned to normal, ensuring minimum disruption."

SITA UK's Contract General Manager, Gary O'Hagan, added: I would like to thank all our staff for the amazing effort they put into making this year's Carnival clear-up a real success. The clean-up operation takes meticulous planning and could not be achieved without the professionalism and dedication of our workforce."
shortdescription: An estimated 225 tonnes of rubbish were cleared from the roads of Notting Hill following this year's Carnival.
shorttitle: Biggest clean-up in the capital

headline: A CELEBRATION OF SCIENCE
prcopy:
Science will take centre stage this September when the Council joins with the Natural History Museum, Imperial College and other major institutions in A Celebration of Science.

The festival, from Monday 23 to Saturday 28 September, will include a host of inspiring and entertaining talks on: Darwinian evolution, human evolution and the Neanderthals, mathematical biology and the future of the earth in a billion years time as the sun heats up.

There will also be a celebration of the life of Sir Hans Sloane, a half-day conference debating the two cultures and legacy of CP Snow, and a science policy conference on Margaret Thatcher, Harold Wilson, and the contemporary challenges in British science.

Aimed at all age groups, other highlights include: TEDxAlbertopolis which will explore how art and science fit together in the modern world, Science Uncovered which will give exclusive behind-the-scenes access to the Natural History Museum's science and specimens, and a special science day for Year 6 students.


Speakers include:

 Professor the Lord May of Oxford, O.M., A.C., Kt., F.R.S. (Royal Society Research Professor, Department of Zoology, Oxford University, and Imperial College, London, 1988-2002, now Emeritus; Fellow of Merton College, Oxford, 1988-2001, now Emeritus; President, Royal Society, 2000-05; formerly Chief Scientific Adviser to H.M. Government)

 Professor Chris Stringer, Ph.D., D.Sc.. F.R.S. (Research Leader in Human Origins, Natural History Museum)

 Professor George Steiner, M.A., D.Phil., F.B.A., F.R.S.L. (Churchill College Cambridge Emeritus Professor of English and Comparative Literature University of Geneva, Philosopher, literary critic and polymath)

 Sir Crispin Tickell, G.C.M.G., K.C.V.O. (HM Diplomatic Service, ret'd. Hon. Fellow and former Warden of Green College, Oxford)

 And Baroness Warnock, D.B.E., F.B.A. (Former Mistress of Girton College Cambridge, Chair of Committee of Inquiry into Human Fertilisation and Embryology, philosopher and public intellectual).

Cllr Warwick Lightfoot, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's lead on the festival, said: "This part of west London has one of the greatest concentrations of scientific research and scholarship anywhere in the world; Imperial College, the Natural History Museum, the Science Museum along with the clinical medical research at the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, the Brompton Hospital and the Royal Marsden Hospital, and the specialist science institutions such as the 1851 Commission, British Science Association and the Chelsea Physic Garden combine to make a hugely important scientific community.

"This series of debates and discussions will prove interesting and entertaining, as well as a springboard to inspire a new generation to take an interest in science."

For the programme and further information visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/celebrationofscience
shortdescription: Science will take centre stage this September when the Council joins with the Natural History Museum, Imperial College and other major institutions in A Celebration of Science.
shorttitle: A Celebration of Science

headline: MARKETS SET TO BECOME A CATWALK
prcopy:
A taste of London Fashion week will come to Portobello & Golborne Road Markets on Saturday 7 September when a series of Flash Fashion shows portraying four very distinctive looks; `Parisian Chic', `Denim Grunge', `Call of the Wild' and `Scottish Heritage', are staged on the North Kensington streets.

Inspired by the slogan `Make the Street Your Catwalk', four groups of models will strut their way around Portobello and Golborne Roads. Each group will model a look for a series of Flash Fashion moments starting from 11am. The Flash Fashion finale will be a 400m catwalk from Tavistock Road to Colville Terrace starting at 3:15pm. Designers like Paul Smith and Vivienne Westwood use the markets as a source of inspiration, and Peter Simon (founder of Monsoon) started his retail career trading on the market.

This is the third Flash Fashion commission by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, and the Portobello and Golborne Management Committee. The event is part of an ongoing campaign to promote the diversity and creativity of the markets. It is produced by volunteers whose enthusiasm for the local markets and community are the heart and soul of the Flash Fashion ethos.

There will also be an exhibition of the `Portobello & Golborne LOOK Photo Challenge' finalists in Portobello Square, Tavistock Road W11 on Flash Fashion Saturday. Shoppers and visitors will have a chance to vote for their favourite photograph until 2.30pm, with the winner announced at 3pm.

Cllr Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for the Environment, said: "The markets have very colourful and diverse traditions, and the quality and diversity of goods on offer, coupled with the great atmosphere, continually attract shoppers and visitors".

"I want to congratulate all our budding designers for the eclectic looks they have put together using the markets as their inspiration".

headline: HAVE YOUR SAY ON THE FUTURE OF NOTTING HILL GATE
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is looking at ways of rejuvenating Notting Hill Gate and wants you to have your say.

Between Tuesday 10 and Thursday 19 September there are opportunities to drop into an exhibition or join a workshop to share your ideas for the area's future at Astley House, 3rd Floor, 33 Notting Hill Gate, W11 3JQ (entrance next to Barclays bank).

Topics under discussion include strengthening the identity of the town centre, improving the streets and public spaces and enhancing the buildings and architecture.

The Council is preparing a development brief for Notting Hill Gate that will be used to assess planning applications and this is your chance to say what it should include.

headline: COUNCIL REPORTS TO RESIDENTS
prcopy:
Council Tax payers in the Royal Borough can now read the annual report which documents how their money has been spent over the last year.

The Council's commitment to provide high quality services in spite of reductions in Government grants is at the core of the report. With savings, many achieved through the shared services with our neighbouring boroughs, Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster, the Council has managed to keep council tax low and service quality high. It is also investing in new school buildings and a state-of-the-art leisure centre in North Kensington.

A London-wide survey corroborates this picture: 86 per cent of residents said the Council is doing a good job; a two per cent increase on 2012.

Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, Leader of the Council, said: "Against a background of municipal austerity this report shows how the Council continually seeks to balance its books and provide excellent services for residents. We have also funded an ambitious capital programme which has delivered a new Holland Park School and is building a new secondary academy in north Kensington.

"As a responsible Council we are protecting the vulnerable, providing opportunities for residents to make the most of their lives, contributing much to the quality of life in the borough and still setting one of the lowest Council Taxes in England."

To view the report online visit: http://www.rbkc.gov.uk/reporttotaxpayers
shortdescription: Council tax-payers in the Royal Borough can now read the annual report which documents how their money has been spent over the last year.
shorttitle: Council reports to residents

headline: APPEALING NEW WAY TO DEAL WITH THE COUNCIL
prcopy:
Residents in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea can now keep in touch with local services using the free `RBKC local services' app on the go.

The new app allows residents to access services at times and in a manner which best suits them. Its aim is to make it convenient and straightforward for people to report problems, check progress on issues and look up information on the move.

Issues like broken pavements, graffiti, abandoned vehicles, dumped rubbish, fraud and broken parking meters are just some of the things that can be reported and automatically directed to the appropriate member of staff using the new app.

The app can be used anonymously or users can register. Registered users will automatically receive updates, information and feedback on what is happening.

The app also allows residents to look up key news in their area and search for events, news, shopping and things to do.

The free RBKC Local Services app is available for Android, Blackberry and Apple operating systems - just visit the app store on your device and search for `rbkc local services' to get started.

Cllr Joanna Gardner, Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services, said: "I am delighted we are able to offer this new service to residents of the Royal Borough. People have so many demands on their time these days that anything that offers a quicker service is to be welcomed."

"As the app is in real-time it also means that our officers will be able to deal with problems far quicker than was the case previously."
shortdescription: Residents in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea can now keep in touch with local services using the free `RBKC local services' app on the go.
shorttitle: Appealing new way to deal with the Council

headline: CAFE COUGHS UP FOR SMOKE OFFENCES
prcopy:
In spite of several warnings a west Kensington café manager was fined a total of £2,400 for failing to stop customers smoking on his premises. Mr Alix Shad was found guilty under the Health Act 2006, by a lay bench at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on 10 September 2013.

Mr Shad co-managed the Shisha Café, 5 Russell Gardens, W14 and was charged with three offences between December 2012 and February 2013. The café had been warned as early as May 2012 that its shelter for smoking did not comply with legislation*. The first offence involved five people smoking inside the café. The second offence followed a complaint from a member of the public when about 20 people were smoking shisha pipes inside the illegal shelter and the main building. On the third occasion 20 or 30 people were witnessed doing the same.

The main manager of the café, Mr Farid Ejlali, had previously been fined £600 for two of the same breaches at Hammersmith Magistrates' court on 13 August 2013 after pleading guilty by post. He was ordered to pay £950 costs and a £30 victim surcharge.

Cllr Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health said: "It is regrettable that we have to take action against local traders when we would much rather help them to comply with the law. But Mr Shad and Mr Ejlali disregarded the information and warnings from our environmental health officers and continued to flout the legislation. When people ignore their legal responsibilities they will be made to pay and, in this case, both men have been taught a salutary lesson."

Mr Shad received an £800 fine for each of the three breaches. He also must pay £950 costs and an £80 victim surcharge. The case was proved in his absence.

* Where a shelter is provided for customers to smoke at least 50 per cent of the perimeter wall(s) must be open to the air. Failure to prevent a person smoking in smoke-free areas is an offence under section 8(4) Health Act 2006.
shortdescription: In spite of several warnings a west Kensington café manager was fined a total of £2,400 for failing to stop customers smoking on his premises. Mr Alix Shad was found guilty under the Health Act 2006, by a lay bench at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on 10 September 2013.
shorttitle: Cafe coughs up for smoke offences

headline: ROOFTOP REMODEL IS OUT OF CHARACTER
prcopy:
A Notting Hill resident who had installed fencing and other fixed wooden structures on his roof, was fined £1,000 after pleading guilty at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Tuesday 10 September 2013.

Federico Biroli of 23 Queensdale Road, W11 failed to comply with an Enforcement Notice served by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea on 6 March 2012. Following complaints about the structures on his roof the Council investigated and served a notice on Mr Biroli for contravening section 179 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990. The Victorian house is in the Norland Conservation Area.

The enforcement notice gave Mr Biroli three months from 1 May 2012 to remedy the situation. Although he did remove some of the items from the front parapet, the majority of the notice was ignored. Four more site visits and three letters later the work had still not been completed.

Because Mr Biroli's roof additions were considered intrusive and alien to the character of the Norland Conservation Area the Council served an Enforcement Notice. The fact that he largely ignored the notice, in spite of regular reminders and clear instructions on what he had to do, led to the lay bench fining him £1,000 with £2,025 costs and a £100 victim surcharge.
shortdescription: A Notting Hill resident who had installed fencing and other fixed wooden structures on his roof, was fined £1,000 after pleading guilty at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court yesterday, 10 September 2013.
shorttitle: Rooftop remodel is out of character

headline: A CELEBRATION OF SCIENCE - DEBATING C.P. SNOW'S LEGACY
prcopy:
Join six of the leading luminaries from the worlds of science and the arts for a half day conference debating the Two Cultures and the legacy of English chemist, C.P. Snow at Kensington Town Hall.

In 1959 Snow delivered an influential Rede Lecture called The Two Cultures which provoked widespread and heated debate at the time. Subsequently published as The Two Cultures and the Scientific Revolution, the lecture argued that the breakdown of communication between the "two cultures" of modern society - the sciences and the humanities - was a major hindrance to solving the world's problems. In particular, Snow argued that the quality of education in the world is on the decline.

Snow's Rede Lectures specifically condemned the British educational system, as having since the Victorian period over-rewarded the humanities (especially Latin and Greek) at the expense of scientific education. He believed that in practice this deprived British elites (in politics, administration, and industry) of adequate preparation for managing the modern scientific world. By contrast, Snow said, German and American schools sought to prepare their citizens equally in the sciences and humanities, and better scientific teaching enabled those countries' rulers to compete more effectively in a scientific age.

The Two Cultures will be revisited and Snow's legacy debated by Lord May FRS, Professor George Steiner, Professor Frank James, Baroness Warnock, Professor Martin Roth, Director V&A and Paul Thompson, Rector RCA.

The conference, which is free to attend, takes place in Committee Room 1 of Kensington Town Hall, Hornton Street, W8 7NX, between 3pm and 7pm, on Wednesday 25 September and is part of a Celebration of Science, a week of thought provoking, inspiring and entertaining talks on the world of science organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, the Natural History Museum, Imperial College, the Royal College of Art and other major institutions.

For more information on Celebration of Science visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/celebrationofscience
shortdescription: Join six of the leading luminaries from the worlds of science and the arts for a half day conference debating the Two Cultures and the legacy of English chemist, C.P. Snow at Kensington Town Hall.
shorttitle: A celebration of science - debating C.P. Snow's legacy

headline: THINKING ABOUT ADOPTION, COME TO OUR OPEN DAY
prcopy:
Could you offer a child a loving home? The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is appealing for single parents, couples and families to learn more about adoption - with the promise of local authority support throughout the process

Every year new adopters are needed to come forward and give children a safe and loving home.

Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "If anyone has thought about adopting I want encourage them to come to one of our open evenings.

"We are always on the look out for people to come forward and find out what is involved. Adoption is a lifetime commitment but it is one of the most rewarding things you can do. Every year our team places children in loving homes but there are still more children seeking a family and we need potential adopters to contact us."

Regular information events are being held at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham, Westminster City Council with the next one 19 September at Westminster City Hall.

Children in the council's care come from diverse backgrounds and so do adopters. You can adopt if you are single, married or in a relationship, including a civil partnership or same-sex relationship, and are at least 21 years old.

A successful example of adoption is Yvette and Paul*, who adopted three-year-old Charles* two years ago.

Yvette said: "We are the very proud parents of Charles, the most wonderfully engaging and lively three-year-old boy you could imagine. Our lives have been transformed in the most exciting way possible since he came to us over two years ago. He loves running around, chatting, train sets, stories and exploring anything that can be explored!

"Our lives have been transformed in the most exciting way possible since he came to us over two years ago. He loves running around, chatting, train-sets, stories and exploring anything that can be explored," Yvette said.

"We had known from the outset of our relationship that we would want a family and we also knew that our ages were such that this would be most likely to occur through adoption. Although the adoption process sounded daunting, we were always very comfortable - indeed, excited - about the idea of adopting a child."

Paul added: "As we expected, the process was emotionally tiring but we received great support from the council and, in particular, our excellent social worker. The result could not have been more fantastic and we are just so happy to be the parents to such a wonderful little boy."

headline: TMO TOUR OF FIRST NEW COUNCIL HOMES IN DECADES
prcopy:
Three brand new Council homes at World's End Estate have been completed as part of the collaborative Hidden Homes programme in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Space is at a premium in the Royal Borough, so the Council and the TMO have been working closely together to redevelop underused spaces on existing Council estates. An unused office space at Greaves Tower, World's End Estate, is the first in the programme to be completed, having been turned into three separate two-bedroom units.

A small group, including Councillor Feilding-Mellen, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Housing, Property and Regeneration, RBKC Director of Housing Laura Johnson, Chair of the TMO Board, Fay Edwards and Residents' Association Chair, John Rendall, joined TMO Chief Executive Robert Black for a tour of the new homes on Friday morning (13 September 2013).

Mr Black said: "A key consideration for the programme is adding to our stock of accessible housing for people with mobility problems. All the new homes are built to `Lifetime Homes' specifications and we are really proud that they have been delivered to a very high standard."

The Royal Borough's Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Housing, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellensaid: "I am really pleased to see this old office space brought back into use as housing for local people. We have great need for more affordable homes for people who live and work in the borough, and so this and other developments we have coming up over the next few months will help to deliver the Council's aspiration of providing lower cost homes for those in housing need."

The three homes have applicants ready to move in as soon the keys are made available. Two applicants are from the Homeless Persons Register and one is a TMO tenant who is transferring on medical grounds.

Transferring TMO tenant Mercedes Morris, who has mobility difficulties and uses a walking aid, says she is thrilled with her more accessible new home.

"I'm currently on the fourth floor and I rely on family to do a lot of my shopping and errands. Moving into my new home will give me so much more independence" she said.

"I'll be able to do my own shopping now and I can reach everything in the kitchen. It will make such a difference."

Also, under development at Holmfield House, north Kensington, are three three-bedroom homes which are due for completion in November 2013.

`Lifetime Homes' is a set of principles developed by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation that has been adopted into current building regulations. They focus on enhanced accessibility and design features that make the home flexible enough to meet whatever comes along in life, for example disability. The goal is for properties to always be able to meet the needs of inhabitants.

shorttitle: TMO tour of first new Council homes in decades

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH SCIENCE WEEK WILL TACKLE THE BIG ISSUES
prcopy:
With public alarm rising about the threat to health posed by antibiotic resistance, one of the leading scientists in the field is coming to the Royal Borough to share his expertise.

Dr David Ogbolu will join several luminaries from the world of science to discuss "the past, present and future of the Earth and its people."

The free event takes place at the Isaac Newton Centre, 108a Lancaster Road, W11 1QS on Saturday 28 September between 11am and 7pm.

A Ph.D. in Medical Microbiology, Dr Ogbolu is also the holder of a prestigious Royal Society Newton International Fellowship, awarded to the best young scientists from around the world to enable them to pursue cutting-edge research in the UK.

A number of medical organisations, including the World Health Organisation, have warned that overuse of antibiotics threatens a public health crisis. And recently, the USA's Centre for Disease Control linked tens of thousands of deaths each year to the growth of drug resistance.

As well as looking at the growing antibiotics crisis, the day-long event will also explore several other topics. Highlights will include the Natural History Museum's Dr Chris Stringer discussing the fate of Neanderthal man and Dr Michael Tildesley who will look at the biology and epidemiology of Avian flu and Foot and Mouth.

It's all part of the Royal Borough's Celebration of Science, a packed week of debate, discussion and lectures on the world of science. For the full programme visit: www.rbkc.gov.uk/celebrationofscience
shortdescription: With public alarm rising about the threat to health posed by antibiotic resistance, one of the leading scientists in the field is coming to the Royal Borough to share his expertise.
shorttitle: Royal Borough science week will tackle the big issues

headline: THE NEW ECOLOGY CENTRE
prcopy:
Home to animals such as Theo the royal python, two leopard geckos and a number of tiger hissing cockroaches, the new Ecology Centre in Holland Park will help children and adults learn more about their environment.

This follows its official opening yesterday (Thursday 19 September) by Cllr Daniel Moylan - Chairman of local charity Kensington and Chelsea Environmental Ltd (KCEL).

Designed with the environment in mind, the building is made from sustainably-sourced wood and features an insulating earth wall to heat and cool the centre through the seasons.

As the former centre proved popular with local schools, this new building contains a selection of assessable teaching rooms, a garden, and is also now the purpose-built base for the Ecology Service.

The Council's Cabinet Member for Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern, said: "This new building provides a great opportunity for the Ecology Service to expand and develop its high-quality environmental education sessions. I must also thank KCEL which donated a considerable sum towards the build."

Cllr Daniel Moylan said: "I would like to thank everyone involved in this project to build what is a fine new ecology centre in Holland Park.

"The Council has a long history of delivering excellent ecology education and I hope that this building will serve as a great platform for the service to flourish.

"Kensington and Chelsea Environmental Limited has distributed over £1.5 million in grants over fourteen years to support local environmental projects. This is our biggest project and, sadly, our last, as our funding has now run out. We hope it will be a lasting legacy from the charity to the people of the Royal Borough."

The centre is open to the public from the end of September and will offer a holiday activity programme for five- to 12-year-olds and an adult events programme. Upcoming events include a bat walk and nature photography workshops.
shortdescription: Home to animals such as Theo the royal python, two leopard geckos and a number of tiger hissing cockroaches, the new Ecology Centre in Holland Park will help children and adults learn more about their environment.
shorttitle: The new Ecology Centre

headline: FIRST CLASS SHAPE FOR CHELSEA SPORTS CENTRE
prcopy:
The Chelsea Sports Centre gym is to get a £1.35 million upgrade, the Royal Borough's Cabinet agreed last night (Thursday 19 September 2013).

The move comes in response to users of the current facilities, 80 per cent of whom are local people. In surveys they expressed the wish for more space and more equipment and that is just what they are going to get.

Amongst the proposals approved by Cabinet are the installation of a mezzanine floor in the underused sports hall to greatly extend gym floor space; the creation of a new studio space beneath; and a major upgrade for the changing rooms.

The work will be overseen by the Royal Borough's leisure contractor, Greenwich Leisure Limited, and should complete in spring 2014.

"We want our residents to have more years of good health and one of the keys to that is exercise," said Cabinet Member for Leisure, Cllr Tim Ahern.

"Getting more people to work out is precisely why we have ordered this refit and it also why we are building a brand new centre in North Kensington which we intend to be the very best in the Capital."
shortdescription: The Chelsea Sports Centre gym is to get a £1.35 million upgrade, the Royal Borough's Cabinet agreed last night (Thursday19 September 2013).
shorttitle: First class shape for Chelsea Sports Centre

headline: TESCO PLC FINED FOR CONSTRUCTION NOISE
prcopy:
Tesco PLC was found guilty on Friday 20 September of two charges under Section 60 of the Control of Pollution Act at Westminster Magistrates' Court and fined £5,000 and ordered to pay the Council's costs of £8,000.

The case was brought by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea after a number of complaints from residents in the flats above the Cromwell Road Tesco about noise from building works outside permitted hours during a large refurbishment of the store.

Noise came from a compressor which was being used to power a jet washer and also from construction work inside the store while trading was taking place.

Despite the Council's Noise and Nuisance team working closely with Tesco and the contractors, Longcross Construction Limited, the noise persisted. Tesco and its contractors were fully aware of the disturbance to these residents and ignored warnings from Council officers. Therefore, prosecution action against the contractors and Tesco began.

Longcross Construction Limited, pleaded guilty to the charges at an earlier hearing.

The court heard that there had been no other convictions related to work on the site.

Councillor Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "Residents shouldn't have to put up with persistent noise outside the permitted hours.

"Officers had issued a number of warnings to Tesco but unfortunately these were not heeded leaving us with no alternative but to prosecute through the courts.

"I am very pleased that this matter has now been resolved."
shortdescription: Tesco PLC was found guilty on Friday 20 September of two charges under Section 60 of the Control of Pollution Act at Westminster Magistrates' Court and fined £5,000 and ordered to pay the Council's costs of £8,000.
shorttitle: Tesco PLC fined for construction noise

headline: COUNCIL BACKS POLICE PLANS TO TACKLE AGGRESSIVE BEGGING IN KNIGHTSBRIDGE
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea has given its legal consent to the creation of a 'Group Dispersal Zone' (GDZ) in Knightsbridge. The zone, which covers Harrods and surrounding streets, will enable police to deal more effectively with organised begging which has become a growing problem in the area in recent weeks and is expected to rise further in the run up to Christmas.

Created under the Anti-Social Behaviour Act 2003, dispersal zones enable police to order groups of two or more to leave a defined area if they believe them to be causing distress, alarm or harassment. Once dispersed, it is a criminal offence to re-enter a zone within 24 hours.

"This is organised begging, which can be aggressive and frightening," explained Cllr Joanna Gardner, Cabinet Member for Community Safety.

"The police are right to tackle it and we won't hesitate to support them with similar measures elsewhere if required."

This is not the first time there has been a dispersal zone in the Knightsbridge area. Previous GPZs have led to over 700 orders to disperse and nine ASBOs. A GPZ lapses after a maximum of six months and fresh evidence is then required.
shortdescription: Kensington and Chelsea has given its legal consent to the creation of a 'Group Dispersal Zone' (GDZ) in Knightsbridge.  The zone, which covers Harrods and surrounding streets, will enable police to deal more effectively with organised begging which has become a growing problem in the area in recent weeks and is expected to rise further in the run up to Christmas.
shorttitle: Council backs police plans to tackle aggressive begging in Knightsbridge

headline: PERSISTENT BEGGARS ARRESTED IN LOCAL OPERATION
prcopy:
Two persistent beggars were arrested during a joint operation between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the police to tackle antisocial behaviour. The arrests took place on Gloucester Road and on Kensington High Street.

The Council and police set up a joint team, the Street Population Service (SPS), to tackle antisocial behaviour on street. Its experience with beggars shows that 98 per cent are misusing either drugs or alcohol and much of the money they receive will go to fund these.

Both the Council and police recommend that the best way people can help vulnerable people on the streets is to give money to one of the established charities which help them, rather than to individuals on the street as this encourages them.

Begging is a crime and there are a number of ways to deal with it, ranging from warnings to arrests and the SPS look at individual circumstances and use a variety ways to catch beggars, including CCTV and reports from the public.
shortdescription: Two persistent beggars were arrested during a joint operation between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the police to tackle antisocial behaviour.  The arrests took place on Gloucester Road and on Kensington High Street.
shorttitle: Persistent beggars arrested in local operation

headline: WINNING DESIGN
prcopy:
The design for a new private housing development commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was a Project Award winner at the Housing Design Award ceremony.

The plans are part of a larger scheme to build a new Middle Row Primary School in North Kensington and the housing is intended to help meet the cost of the new school.

Demand for school places in the Royal Borough is growing and the new school, due in September 2014, will provide more places and more flexible teaching options, including a nursery and specialist speech and language centre.

Planning permission has been granted for 39 private homes and two commercial units, designed by Penoyre & Prasad, on land adjoining the new school.

Councillor Emma Will, Cabinet Member for Education, said: "From the outset we wanted the redevelopment of Middle Row School to be of a high quality, and this goes for the private homes next to the school as well. Work is well underway on the school and it is pleasing to see the designs of buildings the children will see every day have been recognised with this award."

Awards are given to projects of great potential where the scheme has detailed planning permission but is not yet finished and occupied; and for completed schemes of outstanding merit. Judges consider many aspects, including the relationship to surroundings and neighbourhood, response to site constraints and opportunities, external appearance and internal planning, sustainability in construction finishes and detailing and workmanship.
shortdescription: The design for a new private housing development commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was a Project Award winner at the Housing Design Award ceremony.
shorttitle: Winning design

headline: STREET SCIENCE
prcopy:
As part of the Council's Celebration of Science week, the Royal Borough's Mayor and Mayoress, Cllr and Mrs June Williams, met researchers from Imperial College London for a special dose of science - courtesy of a customised tricycle; the college's new mobile classroom.

Staffed for the past week by a host of scientists, Imperial's Public Engagement Tricycle is the college's new vehicle for introducing people to their research and pedalling the wonderful world of science.

The Mayor said: "Since Monday residents and passersby have been able to marvel at superconductors, taste liquid nitrogen ice cream and watch elephant toothpaste exploding.

"It was an engaging way to learn more about science and a great way to spend a lunch hour."

Interested in science? Come to the last few events of a Celebration of Science. See the events programme here www.rbkc.gov.uk/celebrationofscience
