headline: NOUR FESTIVAL HIGHLIGHTS MIDDLE EASTERN AND NORTH AFRICAN ARTS
prcopy:
Nour Festival of Arts, an annual showcase of contemporary arts and culture from across the Middle East and North Africa is taking place during October and November at venues across the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The Festival welcomes established artists and emerging talent to some of the foremost cultural institutions in London, creating a diverse programme that encompasses current affairs, cuisine, contemporary visual arts, film, music, poetry and performance.

A highlight includes the partnership with the Museum of Islamic Art, Doha (MIA) which brings to London the exhibition Ferozkoh: Tradition and Continuity in Afghan Art. Ferozkoh pairs priceless historic objects from MIA's collection with modern-day interpretations by craftspeople from Afghanistan.

Cllr Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Arts, said: "We created the Nour Festival in 2010 in the belief that everyone in the Royal Borough should have the opportunity to experience world-class arts and culture. The significant growth of the festival highlights a wider audience, across London and beyond, interested in exploring an often unseen side of the Middle East and North Africa - its contemporary culture and artistic expression.

"Nour inevitably challenges preconceptions and confounds expectations. This year's festival is no different. Audiences can join us on a journey through the region, enjoy a variety of artistic forms, encounter unexpected voices, and engage with issues as diverse as identity, personal health or individual rights.

"Looking ahead to 2014 and beyond, we believe the Nour Festival will continue to thrive and prosper, with the introduction of even more partners - local, national and international alike. Global interest in Nour continues to grow, as does the appreciation of its large and varied audiences."
shortdescription: Nour Festival of Arts, an annual showcase of contemporary arts and culture from across the Middle East and North Africa is taking place during October and November at venues across the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Nour Festival highlights Middle Eastern and North African arts

headline: HOLGATE TAKES THE HELM
prcopy:
Nicholas Holgate has been appointed as the interim joint chief executive of Hammersmith & Fulham and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Currently Town Clerk and Executive Director of Finance at the Royal Borough, Holgate will take up the Bi-borough reins in November and is expected to remain in post for an extended period.

Since joining Kensington and Chelsea, Nicholas' responsibilities have grown steadily. As well as finance he is today in overall charge of property, including housing and planning; IT and communications.

In addition he has contributed to the design of groundbreaking service-sharing arrangements between the Tri-borough partners: Hammersmith & Fulham, Westminster and Kensington and Chelsea. These arrangements are on track to save the three boroughs £43 million a year by 2015-16, money that would otherwise have had to be found through service reductions.

A graduate of Trinity College, Cambridge, Nicholas Holgate is a comparative newcomer to local government, only joining in 2008. Before that he was a civil servant who held a number of senior posts at HM Treasury before becoming Chief Operating Officer at the Department for Culture, Media and Sport.

"There is never a right time to lose someone like Derek Myers," said the Leader of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr. Nick Paget-Brown. "But it does show a rare strength in depth to be able to call on the skill and experience of Nicholas Holgate to take the helm."

Cllr Nicholas Botterill, Leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Council, said: "Derek Myers is a very tough act to follow and, while we are sad to see him go, we know that Nicholas Holgate is also excellent and inspirational, and will lead from the front with real strength. We look forward to him taking up the role very soon."
shortdescription: Nicholas Holgate has been appointed as the interim joint chief executive of Hammersmith & Fulham and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Holgate takes the helm

headline: BOROUGH BLOSSOMS IN AWARDS
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea scooped a clutch of awards at this year's `London in Bloom' awards held at Richmond Park last week, Wednesday 18 September.

The Royal Borough scored a hat-trick as it gained the prestigious Gold in the City category for the third year running.

Holland Park, Little Wormwood Scrubs, Cremorne and Kensington Memorial Park all secured Gold awards again, as did Gunnersbury Cemetery which not only got Gold but won Cemetery of the Year for the second year running.

There was further good news as Westfield Park improved on its performance last year to secure Gold and Avondale Park also gained Gold.

As well as these results the Emslie Hornimans Pleasance secured a Silver Gilt award and the borough got third place in the Floral Display category.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Leisure, said: "I am delighted that the London in Bloom judges were able to give the borough such recognition. I would like to thank residents and Council officers for their hard work and the pride they show in how the borough looks, this is a great result for all of them.

"We thought that last year was a great year for the borough, but we have managed to better it this year.

"Since last year we have continued to build on our commitment to parks and the open spaces in the borough, indeed Avondale Park has the first grass free lawn in a public space in Europe and we hope will prove a template for others. Residents and visitors can rest assured that we are committed to continuing the excellent work these awards recognise and I hope more people will enjoy all the Royal Borough has to offer in the coming year."

The Council works closely with many groups throughout the year to ensure the borough is always at its best, among these are the Brighter Kensington and Chelsea Scheme, Kensington Gardeners Club and Chelsea Gardens Guild.

There were also 13 awards in the community competition `It's your neighbourhood' which is the first year the Royal Borough has entered. Many of the winning entries have only been set up in the last year and have only recently got garden clubs.
shortdescription: Kensington and Chelsea scooped a clutch of awards at this year's `London in Bloom' awards held at Richmond Park last week, Wednesday 18 September.
shorttitle: Borough blossoms in Awards

headline: BOUNDARY COMMISSION PUBLISHES PROPOSALS FOR ROYAL BOROUGH
prcopy:
Final recommendations for new electoral arrangements for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have been published by the independent Local Government Boundary Commission for England.

The recommendations follow a twelve-week public consultation on its draft proposals and draws new boundaries for each Council ward across the borough.

The Commission's final recommendations propose that Kensington and Chelsea should be represented by 50 Councillors in the future, four fewer than now. Those Councillors would represent 14 three-member wards and four two-member wards in the borough.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "I thank the Boundary Commission for its recommendations and for listening so carefully to local representations from both the Council and residents."

Max Caller, Chair of the Commission, said, "We are extremely grateful to the people of Kensington and Chelsea who took the time and effort to send us their views. The Commission considered every piece of evidence it received before finalising these recommendations.

"Across the borough we have sought to balance the views expressed to us by local people with the criteria we must apply when we are deciding on new electoral arrangements. As such, we believe these recommendations deliver electoral equality for voters as well as reflecting the identities of communities across Kensington and Chelsea."

In response to the views submitted during the consultation, the Commission proposes some changes to the draft recommendations it put forward in March.

The proposals are that the museums and streets to the north of Cromwell Road should be part of the Hans Town ward rather than Queen's Gate as originally suggested in the draft plans. In addition, the whole of Onslow Square will be included within Courtfield ward instead of being divided between wards. Finally, and in response to submissions made to it, the Commission proposes that part of St Charles ward should be called St Helen's and that Hans Town ward should be called Brompton and Hans Town in recognition of the strong evidence of community identity for the Brompton area.

The new arrangements must now be implemented by Parliament. A draft order - the legal document which brings into force the recommendations - will be laid before Parliament in the next few months. The draft order provides for the new electoral arrangements to come into force at the council elections in 2014.
shortdescription: Final recommendations for new electoral arrangements for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have been published by the independent Local Government Boundary Commission for England.
shorttitle: Boundary Commission publishes proposals for Royal Borough

headline: COMBINING SERVICES SAVING MORE MONEY THAN EVER ENVISAGED
prcopy:
Combining management costs and services at three flagship councils is saving more money than ever envisaged.

The 'Tri-Borough' councils of Hammersmith & Fulham, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Westminster City Council, are on track to save £43 million a year by 2015/16, it was revealed at a meeting of Hammersmith & Fulham Overview and Scrutiny Board on Tuesday, September 24. This figure exceeds the original estimate of £40 million.

The three councils are sharing £300 million of services, cutting management costs in these areas by half.

Savings made from the ground-breaking alliance have helped the three local authorities to keep their council tax amongst the lowest in the country. WCC has the second lowest average council tax in Britain, H&F is third and the Royal Borough is fourth.

Leader of the Royal Borough, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown said: "Tri-borough working is helping protect front line services by reducing spending. But we must continue to look at ways to bring costs down and ensure we get value for money. We will do this by looking at opportunities to procure services jointly and by benchmarking the services we provide against other providers to ensure there is no wastage or spending incurred that we are not aware of."

Hammersmith & Fulham Council Leader, Cllr Nicholas Botterill said: "We always knew that combining services was a common-sense move as we looked to safeguard vital services. These latest saving figures show, without shadow of a doubt, that our bold decision to work together back in 2011 has been fully vindicated.

"Inevitably, the journey has been complicated at times but we are on track to save taxpayers more money than we ever imagined while protecting and even improving front line services. This is not the end of the story and we are exploring all areas of the council to look at future opportunities."

Cllr Philippa Roe, leader of Westminster City Council, said: "Our Tri-borough collaboration has proven itself a highly effective way of delivering excellent services while keeping costs down, and stripping out unnecessary duplication. This approach is further underlined by the fact we are saving £3 million more than originally envisaged.

"We will continue to look for further savings and areas to cooperate on to ensure that taxpayers' money works as hard as possible, and that we keep providing those front line services we know people really value."

The three councils have achieved the savings by sharing children's services (saving £2.68 million a year by 2015/16), adult social care (saving £3.2 million) and library services (saving £146,000) across the three boroughs significantly reducing senior and middle management overheads.

Environment, leisure and residents services, together with transport and technical services are combined on a bi-borough basis between Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham. This is on course to save £4.2million by 2015/16. The two authorities already share a chief executive, a single legal department and a single human resources team.

The additional £3 million is as a result of greater than expected savings that have been found predominantly as a result of sharing more staff than first envisaged, sharing back office functions, procurement and aligning major contracts where possible.


With many councils across the country cutting front line services as a result of the national debt crisis, residents in Hammersmith & Fulham, Kensington and Chelsea and Westminster are noticing improved services as a result of this new way of working. Improvements include:

 The one library card policy, giving residents, workers and students unprecedented access to more than one million library books and a range of specialist collections.

 Shared foster placements across the three boroughs, helping to find looked after children a loving home faster.

 The length of care proceedings has been halved from 52 to 26 weeks and reduced legal costs significantly.

The three councils have also shown, through their `whole-place' Community Budget pilot, that within five years they could, with the co-operation of central government departments, create annual savings of about £80 million across local public services in the area. If fully implemented, the plans developed through the recent pilot would help drive growth, reduce dependency, build homes, create jobs, lengthen lives and rehabilitate criminals, according to the councils.

In February 2013, the councils signed up to a contract with BT that will save local taxpayers more than £6 million over the next eight years. The managed service contract will enable the councils and BT to radically redesign the councils' human resources and finance services.

A Tri-borough approach has also now been adopted for the three councils' new public health function. A shared public health function, led by a single director of public health is now looking to push innovation in the design of health and prevention services across the three boroughs.

In October, a Tri-borough facilities management contract will be implemented with Amey. The contract will run for ten years and is expected to save each of the three councils over £2 million a year (equivalent to more than a 34 per cent saving over current costs) through operational efficiency.

A sovereignty guarantee signed by the three councils ensures local accountability and decision making, with each of the three councils remaining responsible for their own budgets, policies and service specification.
keyword3: Leader of the Royal Borough, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown
shortdescription: Combining management costs and services at three flagship councils is saving more money than ever envisaged.
shorttitle: Combining services saving more money than ever envisaged

headline: BOROUGH'S CROP OF KITCHEN GARDENS GROWS
prcopy:
The sunflowers were resplendent, the courgettes abundant, the tomatoes plentiful and the Henry Dickens Court gardeners simply proud as the Deputy Mayor of the Royal Borough, Cllr Sam Mackover, formerly declared the community kitchen garden open on Saturday 28 September.

North Kensington's Henry Dickens Court community garden is the latest kitchen garden to be developed on one of the borough's underused scraps of land. This time a bare patch of ground to the side of the flats was turned into a garden with 21 plots with the gardeners comprising a mixture of private homeowners and tenants from the flats.

Each year the Council adds between five and ten new gardens to the borough's crop of community gardens, currently numbering 42. It works with social landlords and local organisations to identify neglected areas which can be transformed into a horticulturist's delight.

Blossoming alongside are neighbourhood communities where residents get to know one another as they swap tips, vegetables and recipes, with young and old alike delighting in the joy of gathering and cooking their home grown produce.

Ask Natalie Blake whose small crop of garden peas was barely enough for one portion but this drawback paled into insignificance compared with Natalie's family's pleasure as they savoured the sweet taste of just-picked and popped garden peas.

"This is my first garden and I'm really happy with what I've grown. It has really encouraged my children to eat things that are home produced," said Natalie as she surveyed her plot with herbs, parsley, thyme, cucumber, courgettes and tomatoes. "It is a lot of work, weeding and watering but the gardening club gave loads of support and advice and I can email the community gardeners with any queries."

Of all the vegetables that she grew over the summer her favourite are cucumbers which she explained were "just so tasty and lovely". Next year she plans to grow a pizza topping garden as her two boys love pizza.

Commenting on the latest community kitchen garden Cllr Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for the Environment, said: "The Henry Dickens Court gardeners have done a fantastic job. The area was just prepared in May and in a few short months they've transformed it into a cornucopia of fresh produce.

"There are so many benefits to these kitchen gardens from the exercise of physically gardening to health benefits of cooking home-grown produce to community benefits of neighbours getting to know each other as they chat with their fellow gardeners. If anyone knows of an area which might have the potential to be transformed into a community garden I hope they will send their suggestion to the Environment Team."

For more information on the community kitchen garden project email environment@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: The sunflowers were resplendent, the courgettes abundant, the tomatoes plentiful and the Henry Dickens Court gardeners simply proud as the Deputy Mayor of the Royal Borough,  Cllr Sam Mackover, formerly declared the community kitchen garden open on Saturday 28 September.
shorttitle: Borough's crop of kitchen garden grows

headline: WORK TO STRENGTHEN HAMMERSMITH FLYOVER BEGINS ON 28 OCTOBER
prcopy:
TfL is writing to residents to advise them of its plans for forthcoming works involving night-time closures and weekend working on Hammersmith Flyover from Monday 28 October. The work, which will take up to 18 months, will be undertaken by Costain.

It is the second and final phase of strengthening of the flyover following the first phase which was completed last year. The flyover will not be closed during peak times.

In December 2011 TfL found that steel cables on a number of the flyover's 16 spans had deteriorated significantly, due to corrosion caused by water seeping into the structure. This led to its temporary closure just before Christmas and subsequent urgent strengthening work on the worst affected spans allowing the flyover to fully reopen to traffic in May 2012.

Work is now required to complete the strengthening of the remaining spans and undertake essential planned maintenance to ensure that the structure remains safe and usable for years to come.

The work will involve the installation of additional structural cables to strengthen the spans, replacing the bridge bearings and the drainage system, waterproofing and resurfacing the deck to stop future internal corrosion and strengthening the walls at either end of the flyover.
Works will begin with the installation of scaffolding and hoarding around the structure to allow work inside and below the flyover. No traffic restrictions will be in place on the flyover during this time, but overnight closures on the roads below will be required to facilitate the works.

All night-time closures will be between 10.30pm and 5am.

From January to June 2014 the central reservation and drainage will be upgraded, which will require the temporary reduction of the width of all lanes on the flyover. Larger vehicles will be required to use specific lanes. During this period it will be necessary to close the flyover in one direction every few nights to allow materials to be safely delivered and collected from the flyover deck.

It will be necessary to carry out a limited number of weekend closures in one direction between June and September 2014 and TfL plans to do the majority of these during the summer school holiday to minimise disruption.

The weekend closures (Friday evening to Monday morning in one direction only) will be required to carry out concrete repairs, replace the waterproofing and resurface the flyover deck. TfL will ensure that the date and time of these closures and diversion routes are widely advertised ahead of the works. Night time closures will then again be required between September and December 2014 to carry out strengthening of the walls at either end of the flyover and replacement of the expansion joints on the top of the flyover.

TfL is running an Information Centre showing details of the Hammersmith Flyover's construction, its history and the planned strengthening and refurbishment works. This will take place on
 Friday 4 October ¬- 10am until 8pm
 Saturday 5 October - 10am until 4pm

at St Paul's Church, Queen Caroline Street, London W6 9PJ.

TfL, Costain and its designers, Ramboll-Parsons Brinckerhoffs, will be available to listen to your comments and answer any questions about the works that you may have.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Transportation, said: "Clearly any major work on the Hammersmith Flyover will have a major impact on local traffic. I would urge residents and businesses to familiarise themselves with what is happening and the timetable so they can plan ahead to minimise disruption."
shortdescription: TfL is writing to residents to advise them of its plans for forthcoming works involving night-time closures and weekend working on Hammersmith Flyover from Monday 28 October. The work, which will take up to 18 months, will be undertaken by Costain.
shorttitle: Work to strengthen Hammersmith Flyover begins on 28 October

headline: ADMISSIONS NOW OPEN FOR THE EARL'S COURT FREE SCHOOL PRIMARY
prcopy:
A new primary school to be built on the site of the new Earl's Court development and sponsored by the charitable trust behind the West London Free School (WLFS) is now taking applications for September 2014.

While the school's permanent home will be in Earl's Court it will initially be based in a temporary site on Banim Street, located in Hammersmith & Fulham.

Because the school will open in Hammersmith but eventually relocate to Earl's Court, children will be admitted according to their proximity to two separate geographical points rather than just one: the school's temporary home on Banim Street and the Earl's Court Underground Station. The 30 places will be split equally between the two.

The school will open with one Reception class of 30 pupils in 2014 and continue to admit 30 children each year until July 2020. At that point, it will relocate to its permanent home in Earl's Court and become a two-form entry school, admitting 60 children in Reception and an additional 30 children in each year group. In this way, it will be able to accommodate the demand for primary school places for children of various ages from families living in the new Earl's Court development.

Councillor Jonathon Read, the Royal Borough's Lead Member for Family and Children's Services and ward Councillor for Earl's Court, said:

"We welcome this new school, which highlights the positive aspects of the redevelopment of Earl's Court. It will provide parents with even more choice about where to send their children."

Toby Young, Chairman of the WLFS Academy Trust, said:

"Our schools offer children a classical liberal education, regardless of background or ability. That is, a traditional, knowledge-based curriculum, complemented by plenty of music, art, drama and competitive sport. So far, this has proved extremely popular with parents in Hammersmith and I'm delighted to be able to extend this offer to the residents of Earl's Court."

The Earl's Court Free School is part of pan-London coordination. If you are interested in applying you can do so by visiting www.eadmissions.org.uk

For more information on the school visit www.wlfs.org
shortdescription: A new primary school to be built on the site of the new Earl's Court development and sponsored by the charitable trust behind the West London Free School (WLFS) is now taking applications for September 2014.
shorttitle: Admissions now open for the Earl's Court Free School Primary

headline: EPIC LEARNING GIVEN DfE THUMBS UP
prcopy:
The Department for Education (DfE) has recognised the work done at the School Engagement Programme to help re-engage pupils at risk of dropping out of mainstream education by registering the centre as an independent school, renamed Epic Learning.

Pupils who attend Epic Learning, based at Golborne Youth and Community Centre, are aged between 13 and 18. They follow a curriculum which balances core academic subjects, personal development qualifications in team and employability skills as well as work experience.

New DfE rules mean that this alternative education provision can continue to be provided and allow Epic Learning to be registered as a school independent of the Council. This is a recognition of the quality of teaching and support the pupils receive.

The pupils are referred by schools in the borough or are Royal Borough residents attending schools in other boroughs.

Cllr Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "We know that there will always be some children and young people who, for many reasons, find it difficult to thrive in their schools. That is why it is so important to be able to work with them in a different environment to make sure that they get another chance to learn.

"I am very pleased that the DfE has recognised that the work we do at the School Engagement Programme is of such a high standard that it can be officially recognised as an independent school."
shortdescription: The Department for Education (DfE) has recognised the work done at the School Engagement Programme to help re-engage pupils at risk of dropping out of mainstream education by registering the centre as an independent school, renamed Epic Learning.
shorttitle: Epic Learning given DfE thumbs up

headline: HALF-TERM FUN AT NEW ECOLOGY CENTRE
prcopy:
There is a variety of half-term fun activities to keep youngsters intrigued, amused and informed at Holland Park's new Ecology Centre during the week of Monday 28 October to Friday 1 November.

The popular events, which are open to children aged five to ten years, include investigating the park's creepy crawlies, finding out how to make a hibernating hedgehog happy, planting spring bulbs and building a beetle hotel.

The cost for Royal Borough residents is £4.10 per session and £5.20 for non-residents. All children under eight years must be accompanied by an adult. Booking is essential, phone 020 7938 8186 or email ecology.centre@rbkc.gov.uk

The new Holland Park Ecology Centre is now located next to the Adventure Playground by Abbotsbury Road car park, post code W8 6UL.

headline: FANFARE GREETS NEW COLVILLE SCHOOL FACILITIES
prcopy:
The newly refurbished Colville School building was opened today (Thursday 3 October), to the sound of a trumpet fanfare, by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams, who was accompanied by the Mayoress, Mrs June Williams.

The Victorian building has just received a £450,000 renovation paid for by the Council and the school. The new facilities include two new reception classes, a special music centre and rooms for a breakfast club and play centre. This new arrangement has freed up room in the main building, providing space for a second music room and further specialist teaching of art. Colville School is recognised as a high-achieving music specialist school.

Commenting on the refurbishment, the Mayor said: "I was delighted to be invited by the staff and pupils of Colville School to open their impressive new facilities which I am sure will be enjoyed by many generations of Colville pupils.

"Clearly from what I have heard today Colville is a place where musical and artistic talent can really shine."

As the Mayor cut the ribbon to officially declare the renovation work complete and open the school's trumpet-playing pupils played a fanfare which they had composed for the occasion. A special assembly to celebrate the event included samba drumming and a steel band.

A party, including the Mayor, local Councillors and officers from the Council's Education Department, were given a tour of the building and heard from pupils and parents what they thought of the school.

Tanjib, aged nine, said: "The new rooms are astonishing, they're great rooms to learn and have fun."

Nahza Grain, a parent, said: "We are amazed by Colville, it just keeps changing for the better."

Jagdeep Birdi, Headteacher of Colville Primary School, said: "Our transformed school is a gem in the heart of Notting Hill."
shortdescription: The newly refurbished Colville School building was opened today (Thursday 3 October), to the sound of a trumpet fanfare, by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Charles Williams, who was accompanied by the Mayoress, Mrs June Williams.
shorttitle: Fanfare greets new Colville School facilities

headline: MAYOR SUPPORTS POPPY APPEAL
prcopy:
Keen volunteers joined stalwart supporters of the Royal British Legion Poppy Appeal yesterday evening (Thursday 3 October) at a special mayoral reception at Kensington Town Hall.

The charity, which supports current and former members of the armed services and their families, needs to strengthen its ranks in the Royal Borough and has worked with the Mayor, Cllr Charles Williams, to help bring some new and current volunteers together.

Commenting on the evening, the Mayor said: "It was wonderful to see so many people willing to devote their time to support the Poppy Appeal. There is still time to sign up for this year's effort, so do contact the charity if you can spare some time."

Rear Admiral Richard Burn, Chairman of Chelsea and Kensington branch of the charity and Poppy Appeal Organiser for Chelsea, said: "Being a poppy person is not only fun, it is really worthwhile and rewarding. Come and join us, we need your help."

This year's appeal will run from Saturday 26 October to Monday 11 November.

To find out more: Chelsea area, contact Richard Burn on 020 7376 4031 or burn72@btinternet.com and for Kensington, contact Tim Connolly on 07766 752062 or tpaulconnolly1@gmail.com
shortdescription: Keen volunteers joined stalwart supporters of the Royal British Legion Poppy Appeal yesterday evening (Thursday 3 October) at a special mayoral reception at Kensington Town Hall.

headline: POLICE AND COUNCIL MOVE TO HELP TENANTS IN DISTRESS
prcopy:
A rash of antisocial behaviour at a block of flats in Earl's Court has been brought under control, thanks to the Royal Borough's Community Safety Team.

With security at the block badly compromised, so that non-residents were able to enter the basement and common areas at will, legitimate tenants had been suffering a range of antisocial behaviours that had led to a dozen or more complaints.

Intruders were leaving takeaway cartons and other rubbish strewn around the property, heavy doors were being slammed day and night with the noise reverberating throughout the building, and rough sleepers, drug takers and prostitutes were gaining access to the basement.

However help was on hand in the form of the Kensington and Chelsea Community Safety Team, a joint police and Council team established to help reduce crime and antisocial behaviour.

A range of `target hardening' measures were soon prescribed to keep the noise down and intruders out. These included tough new locks, noise-deadening door and wall furniture and mesh grilles to prevent glass breakage.

In addition the team also installed a CCTV system so that any future intruders or offenders can be identified and actions taken.

"The quality of life at this block had taken a very serious dive," said the Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services, Cllr Joanna Gardner. "We stepped in because something had to be done and hopefully the tenants will now be seeing a marked improvement."

As well as installing all the measures the Community Safety Team is meeting 75 per cent of the cost with the registered social landlord paying the rest.

Members of the public can contact the Community Safety Team by calling 020 7795 6660 or email commsafe@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: A rash of antisocial behaviour at a block of flats in Earl's Court has been brought under control, thanks to the Royal Borough's Community Safety Team.
shorttitle: Police and Council move to help tenants in distress

headline: RECYCLING TO BECOME CLEARER IN KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA
prcopy:
Residents' recycling bags will be going clear in the autumn in a bid to tackle bad recycling and reduce contamination costs.

The change, from orange to clear recycling bags, is to help residents recycle responsibly and prevent people from putting the wrong items out for recycling. This includes things such as food, dirty packaging, plastic wrappers, shredded paper, polystyrene, tissues and textiles. Clear sacks will encourage people to recycle correctly and allow the contractor's recycling collectors to spot incorrect items in the sacks.

The Council has to pay seven times as much for a contaminated load of recycling than for clean and dry recycling. If the contamination spreads then the whole load is rejected at the sorting facility. In addition, the wrong types of materials can also damage the machinery and further contaminate clean recycling.

Cabinet Member for Environment, Environmental Health and Leisure, Councillor Tim Ahern, said: "It costs the Council more to dispose of rubbish than it does to recycle and the Council is charged for contamination of recycling. The new clear recycling bags will not only make it easier for collectors to spot contamination in recycling bags, but residents and businesses will also be able to see and remove any non-recyclable items from their bags".

There will be no other changes to the recycling service, residents will continue to get a pack of recycling bags every three months and orange recycling bags will continue to be collected until supplies in households and Council offices have run out.

For residents living in flats that use orange-lidded recycling banks there will be no change.
Recycling bags are for recycling only. They must not be used in place of black bags for general rubbish.
For more information about clear bags and recycling visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/recycling contact Streetline on 020 7361 3001 or email streetline@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Residents' recycling bags will be going clear in the autumn in a bid to tackle bad recycling and reduce contamination costs.
shorttitle: Recycling to become clearer in Kensington and Chelsea

headline: A LOOK BACK AT CELEBRATION OF SCIENCE WEEK
prcopy:
A week-long Celebration of Science, which drew on the strong local science base and the rich legacy of scientific research and scholarship in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, has been an outstanding success.

The event was organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and supported by local institutions such as Imperial College London, the Natural History Museum and the Royal College of Art. It brought together some of the most distinguished names in modern British science and some of the best public presenters of science in the country. Scientists of the future also played their part with several talented young scientists from Imperial College lending their knowledge and expertise.

A series of distinguished speakers included Lord May FRS (Oxford University and a former President of the Royal Society), Professor George Steiner FBA, Sir Roy Anderson FRS (Imperial College), Professor Frank James (of the Royal Institution), Professor Terence Kealey (Vice-Chancellor of Buckingham University), Lord Taverne (former Chairman of Sense about Science) and Professor Chris Stringer FRS (Natural History Museum).

The week confirmed a wide and healthy interest in scientific matters and all the events attracted enthusiastic audiences of all ages. Events during the week linked into TEDxAlbertopolis at the Royal Albert Hall and to the Science Uncovered evening at the Natural History Museum. A specially commissioned day at the Natural History Museum attracted 450 Year 6 children from local schools, where the matters covered linked directly to their current school work.

The Celebration of Science examined some of the serious and interesting contemporary scientific issues. These included a presentation by Mike Tildesley, a mathematician who models the spread of diseases such as avian flu and foot and mouth Disease, exploring probability and the range of uncertainty involved in assessing the course of an epidemic. Dr David Ogbolu, the Royal Society Newton International Research Fellow, a microbiologist, explored the science of diseases that are resistant to antibiotics. This complemented the speech made by the Chief Medical Officer Dame Sally Davies at the TEDxAlbertopolis event where she expressed her serious concern about this development.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, Cabinet Member for Finance and Strategy, who had responsibility for organising Celebration of Science, said: "I am delighted that so many people were able to come along and enjoy, learn and be stimulated by the fascinating range of science events that we put on. There was something for everyone. An exploration of the life of Sir Hans Sloane, the continuing debate about the two cultures, modern British science policy and the scope and efficiency of British science, as well as a rigorous examination of a wide range of science from mathematical biology to the astrophysics of the origins the Earth and how life will evolve over the next billion years. Clearly, there is a very rich scientific heritage here in Kensington and Chelsea and, judging from the reaction of some of the younger people who attended, we are well placed to build on this.

"I'd particularly like to thank all our speakers for their quality contributions and making complex things so understandable and interesting and to thank all the great institutions that helped to make this event possible."
shortdescription: A week-long Celebration of Science, which drew on the strong local science base and the rich legacy of scientific research and scholarship in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, has been an outstanding success.
shorttitle: A look back at Celebration of Science week

headline: PORTOBELLO MARKET EXTENDS TRADING HOURS FOR CHRISTMAS SHOPPERS
prcopy:

Traditionally Thursday has been a half-day trading until 1pm only. By extending the day from 8am to 7pm the Markets Office is aiming to attract more stallholders, including antique traders building on their regular weekend trade.

On Friday 18 October the Portobello and Golborne Markets will celebrate English apples when chef Oliver Rowe and food entrepreneur Clippy McKenna rustle up a variety of tasty dishes using English apples bought at the market stalls. The event is to help promote English Apple Day.

The third Friday of each month sees regular `Road Food' cooking demonstrations which promote food that can be produced using ingredients sourced from the markets or local shops.

The stall is located opposite the Office shoe shop, 217 Portobello Road.

Anyone interested in trading at the market or making a suggestion for the Road Food demonstrations should email the Street Trading Office at street.markets@rbkc.gov.uk

headline: ROYAL BOROUGH'S FREEMEN OPEN THE FREEMAN SUITE
prcopy:
The former Council Leader Baroness Hanham and fellow Royal Borough Freeman Sir Michael Craig-Cooper jointly opened Kensington Town Hall's Freeman Suite, a new suite of meeting rooms and staff entrance on Monday 7 October. Both Baroness Hanham and Sir Michael Craig-Cooper are Freemen of the Royal Borough and have had meeting rooms named after them as had the former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher who was made a Freeman in 1979.

Since 2010 the 33-year-old building has been undergoing a substantial refurbishment programme, to allow the replacement of heating and electrical systems which had reached the end of their economical life, and to increase the office capacity of the building so it can accommodate more staff in order to free outlying office buildings some of which can now be let commercially.

The work will allow the Council to lower its property costs, overheads, carbon foot print and deliver ongoing savings of over £2.56 million per year.

The refurbished basement has 10 meeting rooms which are equipped with the latest IT facilities and are capable of accommodating between them 10 and 44 people. In addition to meeting rooms it features a reception and waiting area, café with extensive seating, staff showers, toilets, quiet room, print and post room, and first aid room.

The Freeman Suite name is in recognition of the significant contribution Nicholas Freeman made to life in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea during his service as Leader of the Council from 1977 to 1989. On standing down in May of 1989 he was promptly elected as Mayor, a capacity in which he served until his death in November of that year.

The Freedom of the Borough is the highest honour which the Council can bestow. It recognises a significant contribution to public life. Seven honorary Freemen of the current Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have had rooms named after them.

headline: HOUSING BENEFIT FRAUDSTER £8,000 OUT OF POCKET
prcopy:
A man who falsely claimed more than £4,000 in Housing Benefit was found guilty of fraud at Isleworth Crown Court last week (Thursday 10 October).

Mr Manolis Nikolantos, of Harrington Road, London SW7, failed to notify the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea that he moved out of the property in December 2010. Despite no longer being resident, he continued to allow benefit payments to be paid into his bank account until July 2011. The Council only became aware that Mr Nikolantos had moved after his benefit entitlement letters were returned to the authority marked `gone away'.

In court Mr Nikolantos claimed that, despite evidence to the contrary, he did notify the Council of his change of address. In mitigation the court was asked to take into account Mr Nikolantos' previous good character and that had he been honest about leaving he may well have been entitled to some housing benefit.

Mr Nikolantos was sentenced to a 12 month community order with a requirement to do 180 hours unpaid work. He was ordered to pay full compensation of £4087.26 to the Council within six months, and was also ordered to pay a contribution to the prosecution costs of a further £4,000.
shortdescription: A man who falsely claimed more than £4,000 in Housing Benefit was found guilty of fraud at Isleworth Crown Court last week (Thursday 10 October).
shorttitle: Housing Benefit fraudster £8,000 out of pocket

headline: A NEW GUIDE
prcopy:
To help guide visually-impaired users along one of London's busiest streets, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea yesterday (Wednesday 23 October) unveiled a tactile map of Exhibition Road.

Displaying a three dimensional representation of South Kensington Station to Hyde Park, the map is made of robust zinc and features colour-coding, raised letters, symbols and Braille.

Located in Thurloe Street, just outside South Kensington Station - a station where over 32 million journeys start or finish each year - it's the product of extensive work with specialist tactile design team Topografik, Guide Dogs for the Blind and various consultation groups.

The Council's Cabinet Member for Transport, Cllr Timothy Coleridge, said: "This new map will help visually-impaired users, including those with guide dogs, and other visitors who may appreciate the clarity, such as young children and non-English speakers, to find their way down this striking new space. A home to some of Britain's most important cultural and educational institutions."

Helen Aluko-olokun, Policy Business Partner at Guide Dogs, said: "This map is a very good example of where the local authority has demonstrated best practice in an environment which is challenging for many blind and partially sighted people. We hope that other local authorities follow this example."
shortdescription: To help guide visually-impaired users along one of London's busiest streets, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea yesterday (Wednesday 23 October) unveiled a tactile map of Exhibition Road.
shorttitle: A new guide

headline: TACKLING SUPERCAR AND PEDICAB NUISANCE
prcopy:
Drivers of some of the most expensive cars on the road were the target of a joint police and Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea operation to tackle nuisance caused by revving engines.

In recent years drivers of high performance `supercars' have been attracted to roads in the Brompton area, particularly Brompton Road, Sloane Street, Hans Road, Beauchamp Place, Basil Street and Walton Street.

The makes of cars spotted in the area included a £1.2m Lamborghini Reventon and a £2m Bugatti Veyron.

While the cars are spectacular to look at, the noise of engines being constantly revved or left idling late into the night has caused a nuisance to local residents.

This August, Council enforcement officers joined with the police in a two-week operation to gauge the scale of the problem and to take action, where appropriate, to put a stop to noisy engines. During this time 231 high performance cars were counted in the area with 30 visiting each night.

In the first instance 45 letters urging drivers to have consideration for local residents were handed to those witnessed leaving their engines idling. Verbal warnings were given to 13 drivers, all of which immediately complied with a request to switch off their engines.

Six cars were found without insurance and were towed away. Some were also towed as the tinted glass was too dark and therefore illegal to drive.

It is not only powerful supercars that are causing problems in the area. At the other end of the horsepower spectrum action was taken against the operators of pedicabs, a rickshaw-like bike, providing a taxi service. In the two-week operation 173 pedicabs were counted in the area and 30 were spotted each night. The bikes often blast out loud music from stereos controlled by passengers' smart phones and also cause an obstruction by mounting pavements, particularly on Beauchamp Place.

Councillor Joanna Gardner, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services, said: "We are going to keep a close eye on the behaviour of drivers of these powerful cars and the operators of pedicabs. We have an ongoing commitment, with our partners the police, to reduce the nuisance caused by this antisocial behaviour."
shortdescription: Drivers of some of the most expensive cars on the road were the target of a joint police and Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea operation to tackle nuisance caused by revving engines.
shorttitle: Tacking supercar and pedicab nuisance

headline: BISHOP JOINS KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA'S CREDIT UNION
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea's credit union enrolled a high profile member on Wednesday 16 October when the Bishop of Kensington, Rt Rev'd Paul Williams, visited the pop-up branch at Dalgarno Community Centre, North Kensington to join, as part of a church-wide celebration of International Credit Union Day.

Your Credit Union already has 200 members since it started operating earlier this year, some are residents who live in the borough and others people who work in it.

Backed by the Council, social housing landlords and voluntary organisations, its aim is to improve the financial services available to people who live and work in the area, particularly those marginalised from affordable banking services and struggling with their household finances.

Bishop Paul said: "I am very pleased to be joining Your Credit Union as it establishes a real lending alternative that is local, and relational in communities like Dalgarno. Faith in Christ compels us to care for those in need not just with our words but also practical action. I would encourage people across the borough to support this excellent initiative.''

Your Credit Union chairman and local Councillor, Cllr Jonathon Read said: "We're delighted that Bishop Paul has opened an account with Your Credit Union, Kensington and Chelsea. It might surprise people to know that the borough is not uniformly affluent, but rather there are significant pockets of deprivation where people are on restricted incomes. These residents will now have access to affordable finance, a credit union account, and advice on how to manage their finances.

"It will also provide our better-off residents with the opportunity to invest their money in a venture that will benefit their local community as well as giving them a financial return."

A feasibility study carried out by the Octavia Foundation in 2009 identified over 24,000 financially excluded residents in the Royal Borough, each paying a `poverty premium' of up to £1,000 each year through higher cost of borrowing, higher bills, additional charges and lack of access to cheaper deals.

By providing affordable options for people to responsibly borrow small levels of money, it was estimated, in the 2009 report, that Your Credit Union would see around two thirds of all loans, or approximately £3.5million, expected to be loaned to financially excluded individuals over the first five years, keeping an estimated £1.8 million within the community.

Local priest at St Francis Church, Rev'd Azariah France-Williams, added: "As a church leader I am delighted to endorse our local Credit Union. We all deserve to be treated with respect and dignity and affordable loans are a way to ensure a vital community where people's well-being is valued and their ambitions are supported."

The Church of England is marking International Credit Union Day across 30 Dioceses, with over 40 Bishops involved in celebrating the work of more than 50 credit unions serving communities across the country.

headline: YOUTH PARLIAMENT MEMBERS SPEAK AT COUNCIL MEETING
prcopy:
The borough's two Youth Parliament Members addressed a packed Council Chamber on Wednesday 16 October on the benefits of getting young people involved in local life and democracy.

Amrit Tamana and Adrianna Franklin were elected by pupils from borough schools and youth clubs and officially represent the borough on both the local and national stage.

High on the agenda was how young people can work with Councillors to make sure their views are taken into account when planning and delivering services.

A simple `how to' guide was launched at the meeting which will show how Councillors can make best use of youth participation to inform their City Living, Local Life initiatives. The guide has been produced by the Council assisted by a local young person volunteering to help produce it.

There was a lively debate and discussion on the night. Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, said: "We were very pleased to welcome our Youth Parliament Members into the Council Chamber and were impressed by the quality of their presentation and their contribution to the debate.

"We have a good track record of listening to young people here in Kensington and Chelsea, which has helped us shape and provide services that can really make a difference."

Adrianna Franklin, Deputy Member of Youth Parliament for Kensington and Chelsea, said: "We were pleased to be given the opportunity to speak to the Councillors about some of our work and the work of the Youth Forum and to be able to pass on some of the views of young people today. What we wanted to show was that young people also have an opinion about the issues that affect their community and would like to be involved more in the decisions that are made at local and ward level."

headline: BOOK NOW FOR NOVEMBER'S HISTORY FESTIVAL
prcopy:
This November some of the country's leading historians and authors are taking part in the London History Festival, organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

In association with `History Today' magazine, Endeavour Press and Waterstones festival-goers can listen to lectures and discussions from leading authors and historians including Max Hastings, Lady Antonia Fraser, Dan Snow and Charles Moore.

Diverse and thought-provoking topics will be covered including: the life and career of Margaret Thatcher, the origins and campaigns of the First World War and the monarchs and strongholds of medieval England.

"We are delighted to be hosting the London History Festival for the fifth year in a row.

headline: GCSE SUCCESS RANKS BOROUGH SCHOOLS SECOND IN THE COUNTRY
prcopy:
Pupils at schools in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have achieved the second best GCSE performance in the country, according to figures released by the Department for Education yesterday Thursday 17 October).

In total 80 per cent of pupils in the borough's schools achieved five or more A* to C GCSEs (including English and mathematics), placing the borough second in the national table behind the Isles of Scilly. The national average for maintained schools was 59 per cent and the average for inner London was 62 per cent.

There was more good news for the progress borough pupils make from Key Stage 2 to Key Stage 4 in English where they were placed top of the national league table. They were placed fourth in the country for their progress from Key Stage 2 to Key Stage 4 in mathematics.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "I am very proud of the standard of education the borough's schools provide. Our position in these national tables reflects a tremendous amount of hard work by teachers and pupils and will give parents confidence that an education in a Royal Borough school is one of high quality. "

headline: GIFT BOXES HELP RAISE AWARENESS OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING IN THE CAPITAL
prcopy:
From Friday 18 October to Sunday 20 October a giant walk-in gift box will be placed at the north end of Carnaby Street to help raise awareness of human trafficking in the capital.

The gift box is an innovative way of highlighting the fact that many trafficked victims are often persuaded to leave their homes and families under the pretence of a better life. It is only when they arrive at their destination that the true horror of what awaits them becomes apparent.

Members of the public are invited to walk into the gift box and read first-hand accounts from victims as part of the European Communities Against Trafficking (ECAT) Project. Launched in February by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, ECAT is a two-year European Commission funded programme to identify and support victims of trafficking in this borough and Westminster.

The Royal Borough is the lead organisation for the initiative and is working with the Metropolitan Police's specialist anti-trafficking unit and partner agencies Rahab UK, STOP THE TRAFFIK UK, Borgorete in Italy and Caritas in Lithuania. These specialists are raising awareness in communities and amongst professionals and equipping vulnerable groups with skills for resisting traffickers. They also providing victim support services to increase safety and prevent re-trafficking of victims.

In the past six months, almost 100 vulnerable people in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the City of Westminster have been identified and approximately ten victims of trafficking have been helped to escape as a result of the ECAT project. Additionally, ten traffickers have been arrested and over £100,000 of assets have been seized by the police.

Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, Leader of the Royal Borough, said:

"Too often this heinous crime goes undetected in large cities and this event is designed to help raise awareness of the issue amongst ordinary people.

"Human trafficking is a complex issue and resources need to be given to those organisations both at home and abroad that have a successful track record in helping to stamp out this terrible practice."

For more information on the project visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/againsthumantrafficking and @ECATrafficking
shortdescription: From Friday 18 October to Sunday 20 October a giant walk-in gift box will be placed at the north end of Carnaby Street to help raise awareness of human trafficking in the capital.
shorttitle: Gift boxes help raise awareness of human trafficking in the capital

headline: CAFE NOVA'S RECIPE FOR SUCCESS
prcopy:
Delicious family recipes from around the world are top of the menu at Portobello's first social enterprise eatery run by cooks and staff from North Kensington's diverse community.

Café Nova, on Thorpe Close, opened its doors in May 2012 as a social enterprise that seeks to support local people to develop skills for employment. The café has been helped along the way with a grant of £43,000 from the Council's Corporate Services innovative projects fund.

The staff serve freshly made dishes from a different world region each day while working to develop their skills and expertise.

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, who is visiting local groups which have benefited from innovative projects funding this month said: "Café Nova is a community enterprise where local people can transform their skills into work opportunities.

"I'm delighted to have seen first-hand how, with the Council's support, 50 local people have volunteered at Café Nova and as a result of what they learnt have now gone into paid employment or are setting up their own catering businesses. It is also great to see this space being used more by local people and community groups."

NOVA is a registered charity whose mission is to help committed and motivated people to develop and fulfil their skills, confidence and employment potential; bringing about real and lasting change in people's lives by addressing each and every person as an individual and seeking out ways to best support that person to reach their goals.

To find out more about the NOVA visit www.novanew.org.uk
For more information on the Council's support to the voluntary sector visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/communityfunding

headline: CAROLS TO INSPIRE FESTIVE CHEER
prcopy:
The Royal Borough's Opera Holland Park is taking to the streets of London this Christmas for the fifth year as part of its Inspire project. Singers will visit care homes, shopping areas and museums to bring festive music to people in central London.

The opera's singers will be performing at the annual Motcomb Street Christmas party in Belgravia on Wednesday 4 December between 6pm and 8.30pm.

They will follow this up with a full day of performances on Thursday 12 December. Starting at the main entrance to the V&A from 1pm to 1.30pm, where the public will be able to enjoy the carols and are encouraged to join in as well. From there the singers will be moving on to Cecil Court, off Charing Cross Road, to perform carols under gaslight from 5pm to 6pm.

Cllr Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Arts, welcomed the community effort, saying: "The wonderful singers from Opera Holland Park will spread festive cheer across central London.

"I would encourage anyone in or near Belgravia, the V&A or Cecil Court to take a little time out of their day and come and listen to some wonderful singing."

During December Opera Holland Park will also be performing a number of private events in care homes across the Royal Borough.

The Inspire project aims to encourage all members of the community to experience, discover and actively participate in opera and classical music, developing their taste and knowledge and bringing the art form to as wide an audience as possible.
shortdescription: The Royal Borough's Opera Holland Park is taking to the streets of London this Christmas for the fifth year as part of its Inspire project.  Singers will visit care homes, shopping areas and museums to bring festive music to people in central London.
shorttitle: Carols to inspire festive cheer

headline: OPENING UP ONE-WAY STREETS FOR TWO-WAY CYCLING WINS NATIONAL AWARD
prcopy:
Pioneering work by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to allow two-way cycling on one-way streets was recognised recently with the Council winning a prestigious National Transport Award in the Achievements in Cycling category.

The award recognised the work done by the Council to persuade the Department for Transport (DfT) to allow new, more intuitively understandable signs indicating that cyclists could ride in both directions on designated one-way streets. Previously, councils were required to use the `flying motorbike' sign that prohibits motor vehicles, but which few road users understood. By making appropriate one-way streets accessible to cyclists the Council aims to provide routes on quieter back streets where first-time or nervous cyclists will feel more comfortable riding.

Opening up more one-way streets to two-way cycling is a cheap and efficient way to promote cycling. The scheme was piloted in the Royal Borough, but several other boroughs have taken advantage of the new flexibilities agreed by the DfT. The Council is now planning the next set of one-way roads that could be converted to two-way operation for cycling, and will be consulting local residents shortly.

Councillor Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "There are many one-way streets in the borough, and across London, that could be used safely for two-way cycling.

"These are quieter roads which could really help the less experienced cyclist to get around. It's a practical idea which requires no high-cost engineering solution.

"I am very pleased that our work to persuade the DfT has been recognised with this award."
shortdescription: Pioneering work by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to allow two-way cycling on one-way streets was recognised recently with the Council winning a prestigious National Transport Award in the Achievements in Cycling category.
shorttitle: Opening up one-way streets for two-way cycling wins national award

headline: YOUNG PEOPLE'S QUESTION TIME
prcopy:
The Kensington and Chelsea Youth Forum held a Young People's Question Time (Friday 18 October) as part of Local Democracy Week. The event was organised by the borough's Members of Youth Parliament and youth representatives and was attended by 45 young people from different youth groups across the borough.

The panel consisted of Amrit Tamana, Member of Youth Parliament for Kensington and Chelsea, Brendan O'Keefe, Head of Services to Young People, Chief Inspector Billy Bowen-Long of the Kensington Police, Nadia Bellot, Youth Worker, and Brendon Read, a young entrepreneur.

Topics discussed included plans for the future of the youth service as it becomes a social enterprise and employee-led mutual, how relations with young people in the community can be improved, and how to encourage more young people to use youth services.

Youth Forum member Kirsty Fraser, who co-hosted the event, said: "It was amazing to see so many young people so engaged and passionate about the issues that affect them. Young people really challenged the decision-makers with their questions which created a stimulating debate".

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "It is very important young people recognise they have a voice in how the services they use are delivered. Events like this really do have an influence on the Council and can influence what we do and how we do it."
shortdescription: The Kensington and Chelsea Youth Forum held a Young People's Question Time (Friday 18 October) as part of Local Democracy Week. The event was organised by the borough's Members of Youth Parliament and youth representatives and was attended by 45 young people from different youth groups across the borough.
shorttitle: Young people's question time

headline: DEVELOPERS ATTEMPT TO DERAIL ROYAL BOROUGH'S BASEMENT PROPOSALS
prcopy:
The capital's biggest basement developers are attempting to derail the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's plans to control development below ground.

Following the Council's latest round of consultation on the proposals last month, a number of basement developers are aggressively opposing the plans, claiming that there is not enough evidence to support tighter controls.

Residents, on the other hand, are overwhelmingly supportive of the new policies which are designed to set limits on the scale of basement development. Highlights include a reduction in the extent to which basements can extend into the garden, a restriction to a single storey and severe restrictions on basement developments under, or in the gardens, of listed buildings, or where a basement already exists.

Before the new policies can be introduced by the Council, they need to be examined by the Government's Planning Inspector who will decide whether they are sound. The Council is gathering extra evidence to oppose the developers' claims and this means that the examination will take place later in 2014 than originally expected. Further details on the timetable will be announced in due course.

Councillor Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said:

"Basements are a very lucrative business for developers and our plans have clearly struck a nerve.

"Residents have told us that we have got it right and council officers are gathering the evidence we need to make our case watertight.

"Over the past decade we've noticed a dramatic increase in the number of basement applications and now is the time to ensure measures are brought in to introduce a sense of proportionality to basement development."
keyword3: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: The capital's biggest basement developers are attempting to derail the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's plans to control development below ground.
shorttitle: Developers attempt to derail Royal Borough's basement proposals

headline: £100,000 GRANT OFFERS YOUNG PEOPLE A BRIDGE TO EMPLOYMENT
prcopy:
A scheme to help 74 young people into employment has been launched in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Funded by a £100,000 grant from the City of London Corporation's charity City Bridge Trust, the project is enabling the Council to work with three key partners, Clement James, Youth Action Alliance and Spearhead.

Together the three organisations will work with 74 young people from Kensington and Chelsea, aged between 16 and 24 and not in employment, education or training (NEET), to offer them practical help and support to find work. The project will run for 12months. Current figures suggest that the number of young people aged 16 to 19 who fall into this category in the borough is 157.

The Clement James Centre will work with the young people to help them prepare CVs and develop employment skills with practice interviews, courses and workshops around timekeeping, communication, presentation and other employability skills. They will also have a day within a business to develop these skills in a real life setting.

Youth Action Alliance will provide mentors and hands-on experience of working in an office environment in their own specialist training centre. This will give young people, with little or no previous experience of what it is like to work in an office, a chance to try their hand at the tasks that any young job starter would expect to do.

Direct work with young recruits and their employers will be undertaken by Spearhead. This will involve placing new recruits and providing advice and support to managers on how to get the best out of any new young member of staff.

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: "Thanks to this very generous funding from City Bridge Trust we will be able to help offer young residents a chance to develop the sort of skills they will need to find employment.

"By drawing on the experience of our three partners we can, hopefully, make a real difference to the job prospects of these young people."

For more information about the project contact Mark Ward, the Royal Borough's Employment Initiatives Officer at Mark.Ward@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: A scheme to help 74 young people into employment has been launched in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: £100,000 grant offers young people a bridge to employment

headline: GOLBORNE ROAD BRIDGE GETS MAKEOVER
prcopy:
North Kensington's Golborne Road bridge has been given a makeover, transforming it from a tired-looking iron railway bridge into an attractive local landmark, using a design chosen by local people.

Network Rail, owners of the bridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and local designers Urban Eye and Brownbaby worked jointly on the project after local residents flagged up that the 100-year-old plus bridge was in need of some `tender loving care.'

The work included cleaning repainting and repairing the bridge as well as installing new lighting and new security grilles.

Over 350 local people and businesses responded to a consultation and offered opinions on four designs for the bridge. The most popular design is a mixture of colourful geometric patterns.

The bridge crosses the Great Western Railway, which was created to provide a train line from Paddington to Bristol. Today the bridge serves as an important link from Portobello and Golborne Markets to Trellick Tower and beyond.

To mark the refurbishment the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams, switched on the new lights at a ceremony on Monday 28 October.

Commenting on the refurbished bridge the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern said: "Golborne Road Bridge is an important local landmark I would like to congratulate everyone who contributed to its makeover. The eye-catching design, which looks great both during the day and night, is fitting for a bridge that provides a link to the thriving markets of Portobello and Golborne."

Miles Watson from Urban Eye added: "We are delighted by the outcome and hope that the partnership model we initiated on this project might be effectively replicated on bridges in other London boroughs."
keyword2: Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern
keyword3: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: North Kensington's Golborne Road bridge has been given a makeover, transforming it from a tired-looking iron railway bridge into an attractive local landmark, using a design chosen by local people.
shorttitle: Golborne Road bridge gets makeover

headline: BUYING A USED CAR? CHECK IT, DON'T REGRET IT!
prcopy:
This year's National Consumer Week (4 to 10 November) is focusing on used cars and how to buy them wisely. The theme of the week is `Check it, don't regret it!'

Trading standards officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham want to make sure that residents who buy a used car can be confident that they are buying a car that is roadworthy, safe to drive, and has no outstanding finance issues.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "You don't buy a car every day and when you do you want to make sure that you are getting something that is safe, value for money and legally yours. One way to reduce any risk is to follow sound advice from respected motoring organisations before you part with your cash."

During the week, trading standards officers will be working closely with the Citizens Advice Bureau, giving advice on how to avoid some of the pitfalls associated with buying a used car. You can speak to a trading standards officer at one of the following sessions:
Monday 4 November from 10am to 1pm. Avonmore library, 7 North End Crescent London W14

Tuesday 5 November from 10am to 3pm at the junction of Portobello Road and Westbourne Park Road opposite Subway London W11

Wednesday 6 November from 10am to 4pm Hammersmith Town Hall Market King Street London W6

Thursday 7 November from 10am to 1pm Westway Information Centre, 140 Ladbroke Grove W10

The advice from the Trading Standards Institute and Citizens Advice Bureau is:

? Check MOT certificate - indicates if car is roadworthy

? Check service history - shows if car has been maintained

? Check V5 registration document - shows if car is stolen

? Check if car is a write off - helps you know what you are buying

? Check finance history - ensures car doesn't have an outstanding hire purchase agreement

? Test drive and walk around check - for signs the car isn't what it seems

? Get engineer's check - shows condition of car and any hidden dangers

? Check price value guide - indicates reasonable price to pay

? Check car is not recalled - shows if car was recalled for safety reasons by manufacturer


You can do many of these checks yourself, or there are companies that offer data checks.

For more detailed information and advice on how to make these checks, go to www.adviceguide.org.uk/usedcars or visit your local Citizens Advice Bureau.
shortdescription: This year's National Consumer Week (4 to 10 November) is focusing on used cars and how to buy them wisely. The theme of the week is `Check it, don't regret it!'
shorttitle: Buying a used car? Check it, don't regret it.

headline: GET INVOLVED IN FURNITURE RESTORATION WITH GOLDFINGER
prcopy:
Goldfinger Factory is a new innovative social business in Golborne. The furniture upcycling project has taken over two shop units at the base of Trellick Tower and plans are afoot to open a showroom and workshop soon.

The project plans to restore mid-century furniture, sell it and plough the profits back into the enterprise. The investment will be used to offer cheap furniture to people on low incomes.

The shop also hosts `Redemption', an alcohol-free bar, restaurant and café which is now open for business. Downstairs, is being used as the furniture restoring and making workshop.

Oliver Waddington-Ball, founder of the project, says: "We plan to run courses for people on how they can mend, restore and build furniture using raw materials that are free or cost next to nothing. So, as well as selling cheap, quality furniture, we'll also offer opportunities to learn new skills that can help people into work. We're also available to help local groups kit out their premises.

"We're very keen to work with local people and organisations. We're looking for volunteers to help in the workshop and we want partners to run training projects in furniture restoration and building. We have the premises, the tools and the expertise - now we want local people. I'll be delighted to hear from anyone who wants to get involved with our project."

Goldfinger Factory has been helped along the way by a grant from the Royal Borough's innovation fund. A total of £150,000 has been awarded to the social enterprise over the next three years. Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, said: "I am very pleased that the support we have been able to give to the Goldfinger Factory is enabling these exciting developments. I'd urge anyone who wants to learn about furniture restoration, or find out more about what Goldfinger has to offer, to get in touch with Oliver."

Redemption is open from 4pm to 10pm Wednesday, Thursday and Friday; 11am to 10pm on Saturday; and 11am to 5pm on Sunday. For further information email goldfingerfactory@gmail.com
shortdescription: Goldfinger Factory is a new innovative social business in Golborne. The furniture upcycling project has taken over two shop units at the base of Trellick Tower and plans are afoot to open a showroom and workshop soon.
shorttitle: Get involved with furniture restoration with Goldfinger

headline: COUNCIL FUNDS URBAN HELP
prcopy:
Thanks to the Council's innovative project grant two local organisations have joined forces to provide a new service to residents. The HELP Counselling Centre and Urban Bliss have created `Urban HELP' to offer a combination of affordable counselling with complementary therapies.

Based at the Golborne end of Portobello Road, the project represents a collaboration between a charity and local business and offers residents a new opportunity to access high quality, affordable counselling.

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, visited the organisation and met Mary Ziemer, charity director and trustee, Sarah Young. Speaking about his visit he said: "The pooled experience and expertise of these two organisations means that counselling is available, as well as some complementary therapies, at affordable prices to residents. I am very pleased we have been able to assist with the funding of such a worthwhile project."

One service user said: "The counselling made an enormous difference in getting me through a very difficult time. I also learned a lot about myself in the process."

headline: PRIZE PUMPKIN GETS MAYOR'S APPROVAL
prcopy:
The borough's community gardeners put aside their secateurs and spades and took up cutters and scalpels as they helped young residents carve pumpkins at an "Amazing Pumpkin" competition held on Halloween night, Thursday 31 October, at the Henry Dickens Community Kitchen Garden, W11.

The Royal Borough's Mayor, Cllr Charles Williams was on hand to judge the pumpkins and, after careful consideration, declared Irene Lyford the winner.

North Kensington's Henry Dickens Court community garden is the latest kitchen garden to be developed on one of the borough's underused scraps of land and made available to residents to grow their own vegetables and herbs.

There are now over 400 community kitchen plots throughout the borough, from St Charles Community Centre in the north of the borough to World's End Community Garden on the banks of the Thames in the south.

Over 700 residents have become gardeners and are supported by two part-time community gardeners, Lisa Wilkinson and Will Gould, who provide advice and run seasonal gardening workshops.

In addition to helping carve pumpkins at Henry Dickens Court on Thursday Lisa and Will ran a similar event at Wiltshire Close Estate, se a short walk from Sloane Square, the previous Saturday (26 October) for local youngsters and to publicise the community gardens to residents. As a result of Saturday's event another resident signed up for a plot.

The Community Kitchen Garden schemes helped the Council secure Gold in the London in Bloom competition in 2013.
