headline: RESIDENTS GET RECYCLING ADVICE
prcopy:
Around 10,000 residents in Kensington and Chelsea will be advised about their recycling habits as part of a door knocking campaign to help people recycle responsibly and reduce contamination.

During November teams of recycling advisers will be visiting residents who receive kerbside collections in areas around Earl's Court, Gloucester Road and South Kensington, where a larger number of `contaminated' recycling bags have been found.

Contaminated bags and recycling banks are those that have waste in them that shouldn't be there - typically textiles, food waste (including residue from food containers), nappies, toys and electrical items.

The focus will be on helping to educate residents in what can and cannot be recycled, what constitutes `contamination', why it is such a problem for recycling quality and also the cost implications for the Council and the taxpayer.

Contamination is forecast to cost the Council an additional £400,000 this year and dealing with contaminated recycling costs seven times as much as clean recycling.

This work is being done in conjunction with the new clear recycling bags initiative which is being rolled out across the borough.

The only things that should be put in recycling bags or banks are clean and dry:

 paper and card/cardboard (excluding shredded paper)
 glass bottles and jars
 plastic bottles, pots tubs and trays
 cans, tins and empty aerosols
 food/drinks cartons (e.g. Tetra Pak)

Food residue should be rinsed off before recycling the containers and all lids should be removed.
Free textile collections are available from the charity TRAID (Call TRAID on 020 8733 2580 (select option 1) or go to the Council website to book a collection). Most plastic films and carrier bags can now be recycled at local supermarkets, and the public can recycle electrical items at the Civic Amenity Site, Smugglers Way, Wandsworth, SW18 1JS.

The Council does not operate a collection for food waste or provide subsidised composters or wormeries, although the recycling team can provide help and advice to any resident on these matters.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environment, Environmental Health and Leisure, Councillor Tim Ahern said: "Recycling contamination is a big problem. In recent months this has gone up, usually because people don't understand what goes in their bag or bank but, in a small minority of cases, because people don't care or realise how much it costs to the Council and taxpayers.

"The current rate of contamination in recycling bags will cost the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea around £400,000 this year."

If you would like to find out more about the campaign or speak to someone about recycling in the borough call Streetline 020 7361 3001 or email Streetline@rbkc.gov.uk

For more information about what can and cannot be recycled visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/recycling
shortdescription: Around 10,000 residents in Kensington and Chelsea will be advised about their recycling habits as part of a door knocking campaign to help people recycle responsibly and reduce contamination.
shorttitle: Residents get recycling advice

headline: CONSIDER ADOPTION DURING NATIONAL ADOPTION WEEK
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council and the London Borough of Hammersmith and Fulham are appealing for single parents, couples and families to consider adoption and learn more about the process during National Adoption Week 4 to 10 November 2013.

Children in council care come from diverse backgrounds and so do adopters. Potential adopters can be single, married or in a relationship, including a civil partnership or same-sex relationship, and must be at least 21-years-old.
There is an adoption open evening tonight (Thursday 7 November) from 6pm to 8pm at Westminster City Hall, 64 Victoria Street, SW1E 6QP, in Committee Rooms 5, 6, and 7.

If you miss tonight's open evening there will be another on Thursday 28 November 2013 from 6pm to 8pm at Kensington Town Hall, Hornton Street, W8 7NX, in Committee Rooms 3 and 4.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, Cllr Elizabeth Campbell, said: "We are always looking for people to come forward and find out what is involved with adoption. If anyone has thought about adopting I want encourage them to come to one of our open evenings.

"It is a lifetime commitment but it is one of the most rewarding things you can do. Every year our team places children in loving homes but there are still more children seeking a family and we need potential adopters to contact us."

Westminster City Council, the London Borough of Hammersmith and Fulham and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea recognise that all of the parties involved may need some support at different stages in the adoption journey, and an adoption support team is available to work with adoptive families.

headline: MAGIC WAND APPEAL SECURES SONOWAND SCANNER TO HELP BRAIN CANCER PATIENTS
prcopy:
The first of two new high-tech ultrasound scanners which enable more accurate brain surgery has been installed at Charing Cross Hospital's neurosurgery centre, marking a significant step forward for brain cancer treatment in London.

Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust, which runs Charing Cross Hospital, was able to purchase the equipment, costing £250,000 each, thanks to a fundraising drive by the charity Brain Tumour Research Campaign (BTRC) spearheaded by the former mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster.

Charing Cross Hospital is the first centre in the UK to have the latest model of the ground-breaking SonoWand mobile imaging equipment and is one of only two centres in the country to have an older model which has been in use since 2008. A second machine will be delivered to the hospital later this year.

Councillor Christopher Buckmaster started his Magic Wand Appeal after a close friend was diagnosed with a brain tumour, he said: "This is marvellous news and a fitting end to the campaign which began to increase public awareness of the desperate need for more funding for brain cancer treatment and to raise funds for research at Charing Cross Hospital and the purchase of the new machines. I am so proud of everyone's efforts."

The new equipment, called SonoWand Invite, helps surgeons operate more accurately, safely and quickly by converting pre-operative MRI scans into a virtual 3D reconstruction of the brain. During the procedure surgeons are able to see rapidly updated images of the brain and brain movement (shift) in real time so that they can remove as much of a tumour as possible without damaging healthy tissue. This is done by utilising integrated finely tuned and calibrated ultrasound that creates 3D images of the brain and blood vessels with high resolution that can be merged with the MRI.

This marks significant progress in the battle against brain cancer which causes more deaths in children and people under 40 every year than any other cancer. More than 800 Londoners are diagnosed with a brain, central nervous system or intracranial tumour every year while less than one per cent of cancer research funding goes to brain tumours.

Mr Kevin O'Neill, consultant neurosurgeon at Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust and co-founder of the charity BTRC, said: "Accurately locating a tumour and safely removing it without damage to normal brain tissue and blood vessels is a real challenge for surgeons. The SonoWand makes surgery safer, more accurate and more of the tumour is removed so that what's left responds better to other treatments such as chemotherapy and radiotherapy. The new model is a major advance from the prototype and provides a platform to combine robotics and other technologies being developed at Charing Cross Hospital and Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust.

"This is great news for brain tumour patients in London and for our team here at Charing Cross Hospital. Early studies using this technology are showing that patient survival and outcomes are better. The new equipment could revolutionise brain surgery, translating into patients living longer and therefore having the opportunity to benefit from our further research."

Sandra Stankovic, who lives in Ealing, was operated on by Mr O'Neill using the older model of the SonoWand in July for a rare type of cancerous brain tumour. Using the SonoWand meant the tumour was removed and blood vessels supplying the tumour were destroyed without damage to nearby vessels supplying healthy tissue.

Sandra is still in treatment to prevent the tumour from recurring although her last scan, a month ago, was clear. Sandra, a mother of two children, Leo aged seven and Lily aged five, and founder of an IT company, said: "Using the SonoWand combined with Mr O'Neill's exceptional skills meant the tumour was successfully removed and I am doing really well. The SonoWand meant the surgeon was not operating `blind' on my brain and he could see the blood vessels in real time and navigate through them."

Sandra has also been treated with anti-cancer drugs (chemotherapy) at Charing Cross Hospital since the tumour was first diagnosed seven years ago. She added:
"I can't stress enough how amazing my care is at Charing Cross Hospital - my surgeon Mr O'Neill, my oncologist Dr Mark Glaser and the two oncology nurses, Shaun O'Gara and Theresa Sage - are all brilliant and I feel very safe in their hands. Now with the new SonoWand equipment, I believe the treatment will be even better."

The Trust was able to purchase the new machines, which each cost £250,000, thanks to the charity fund-raising campaign by the BTRC, Cllr Buckmaster's Magic Wand Appeal and private donors in partnership with Imperial College Healthcare NHS Trust.

BTRC co-founder Wendy Fulcher said: "One of our main aims has been to establish Charing Cross Hospital as an international centre of excellence for neuro-oncology and the new equipment marks a major step towards achieving this aim."

Alexandra Dixon, one of Mr O'Neill's former patients, said: "It is such exciting news that Charing Cross Hospital has the latest model. The machine provides excellent imaging in real time during surgery - and I was lucky enough to be the first patient in London to benefit from it. Patients and doctors will be thrilled to have these brand new latest versions of the equipment."
shortdescription: The first of two new high-tech ultrasound scanners which enable more accurate brain surgery has been installed at Charing Cross Hospital's neurosurgery centre, marking a significant step forward for brain cancer treatment in London, thanks to a fundraising drive by the Brain Tumour Research Campaign spearheaded by the former Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Christopher Buckmaster.
shorttitle: Magic Wand Appeal secures SonoWand scanner to help brain cancer patients

headline: BEST BAR NONE AWARDS 2013
prcopy:
Janet's Bar on Old Brompton Road, in South Kensington, scooped the coveted Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Best Bar None `Overall Winner' for 2013 at last night's (Wednesday 13 November) sixth annual awards ceremony at a packed Royal Garden Hotel, Kensington.

Beating off stiff competition to the overall title, in what is now one of the largest Best Bar None competitions in the country, it was also named `Best Bar'. Janet's Bar has been a strong contender in Best Bar None since the scheme began in 2008, and this is the second time it has been recognised as overall winner.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Environment, said: "I am delighted that this year we have seen even more businesses enter the Best Bar None competition in the Royal Borough, making it the largest in London.

"I would like to congratulate all the venues that have been recognised at the awards and in particular Janet's Bar which has been such a great supporter of Best Bar None and a worthy winner.

"It is good to hear we are now the largest Best Bar None in London and I hope we are able to build on this in the coming years. Accreditation through Best Bar None shows a commitment to high standards that appeals to residents and patrons of all the establishments involved."

Celebrating her win, Janet Evans said: "I am very excited to receive this award. It is wonderful! We are constantly working to improve the quality of service and experience we give our customers. This award shows us that we are getting it right and we are grateful for the recognition."

Also at the awards was Guy Dodwell, Senior Sales Director for Diageo UK, who added: "It's great to see such diversity in the industry, working together for the same objective."

A further 53 pubs, bars and clubs across the borough gained membership of the scheme, with the category winners as follows:

Runner up - O'Neills, Earl's Court Road

Bar Category

Best Bar None in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is sponsored by Diageo GB and the Royal Garden Hotel with support from various partner agencies.

headline: COMMUNITY THANKED FOR THEIR BLOOMING EFFORTS
prcopy:
Residents, businesses and voluntary organisations that helped make the Royal Borough a blooming good place to work, live and visit were thanked at a special celebration at Kensington Town Hall on Tuesday 12 November.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough, Cllr Charles Williams, and the Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern praised the huge effort by all involved in making the borough greener and cleaner as evidenced by the large number of awards won during 2013.

This included 11 for the `London in Bloom' scheme, nine of which were gold awards and 14 for the Royal Horticultural Society's `It's Your Neighbourhood' campaign - the most won by any London borough.

Thanking the residents, business people, schools and community groups for their work, the Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern, said: "This is a fantastic effort for `Team Royal Borough'. It is community efforts that makes Kensington and Chelsea such a green and beautiful borough in which to live and has helped the Council achieve gold in the In Bloom awards."

The In Bloom judges were particularly impressed with the borough's `fantastic' parks and open spaces and the Council's maintenance contractor Quadron, parks staff and the community organisation Friends of Holland Park received special mention.

The winners of the In Your Neighbourhood awards each received certificates and a figure of a small hero garden gnome as evidence of their work to green their immediate local environment - whether it was their street or a small patch of communal land needing a revamp.

headline: RESIDENTS GET OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN OF NEW DEVELOPMENTS AT ROYAL MARSDEN
prcopy:
Residents of Kensington and Chelsea, and Sutton, will have the opportunity to speak with senior management of The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust at a public meeting on Tuesday 26 November at Kensington Town Hall.

Both recent and upcoming developments at the world-leading cancer centre will be discussed; along with current NHS issues including the growing number of patients and patient experience. The audience will also be able to raise any questions or concerns they may have.

The Royal Marsden is leading cancer centre specialising in cancer diagnosis, treatment, research and education. As the Trust has sites on Fulham Road, Chelsea and in Sutton, Surrey, the meeting is a joint venture between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the London Borough of Sutton.

Chaired by Councillor Robert Freeman from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Councillor Mary Burstow from the London Borough of Sutton, the meeting will be the first in a series hosted by the Royal Borough's Adult Social Care and Health Scrutiny Committee.

Royal Marsden chief executive, Cally Palmer CBE, medical director Professor Martin Gore and chief nurse Dr Shelley Dolan will speak and give an update on issues including increasing patient numbers, quality and performance monitoring information and the National Cancer Patient Experience Survey. The panel will then take questions.

Members of the public and local community groups are invited to attend the meeting which starts at 7pm. Booking is not required. Questions can be submitted in advance to scrutiny@rbkc.gov.uk or taken on the night.

Available on webcast go to http://www.rbkc.public-i.tv/core/

headline: £452m Earl's Court regeneration package agreed
prcopy:
Another major milestone in the £8billion redevelopment of Earl's Court was reached today with agreement between London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Transport for London (TFL) and scheme developer EC Properties LP on a £452million package of benefits for the area.

As part of the Section 106 agreement EC Properties LP has agreed that as the approved scheme is developed a new primary school, leisure centre and health facilities will be built as well as community and cultural spaces. Thirty seven acres of green open space will be provided, including a new five acre park and there will also be significant improvements to the transport infrastructure including increased capacity at Earl's Court, West Kensington and West Brompton Underground stations.

Cllr Nicholas Botterill, Leader of Hammersmith and Fulham Council said: "The redevelopment of Earl's Court and West Kensington will usher in a new era of prosperity and opportunity on a scale that has never been seen before in west London.

"We have said, from the very outset, that we would only include the estates if people living on them substantially benefit from redevelopment, followed by the wider area.

"This agreement can leave estate residents in no doubt that they will be the major beneficiaries of the scheme, not only gaining brand new homes, but also reaping the rewards of the huge raft of community improvements."

Cllr Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Planning, said: "We have been involved in discussions over many years about the redevelopment of Earl's Court and it is good news that the developers have agreed to this very significant contribution to the area. It will bring great benefits to all the residents, current and future.

"The community facilities will make this a great place to live and I am sure will be welcomed by everyone. A new primary school will be a boon to local parents and the leisure centre will make it easier for people to get to sports facilities."

Gary Yardley, Investment Director at Capital & Counties Properties PLC, the parent company of EC Properties LP, said: "The conclusion of these negotiations adds further momentum to the Earl's Court project and we are pleased to have agreed this package of benefits for the local community. The value of this contribution represents the scale of the project and brings to life the very real benefits that this development will bring to west London. We look forward to working with the local community to deliver the Earl's Court Masterplan which will create 7,500 new homes and 12,000 new jobs."

Details of the regeneration package include:

 Up to 7,500 new homes of which 1,500 are affordable and replacement homes - £315million
 Improvements to streets and public realm and the creation of 37 acres of green space, including garden squares, communal gardens and a new five acre park - £35million
 Improvements to local amenities as well as a new primary school, community centre, leisure centre, health centre, cultural space and money towards a cultural fund for the area. - £41.4 million
 Up to 10,000 permanent jobs are expected to be created and there will be £8million worth of employment and skills training in the local area
 There will also be significant transport improvements. £38.2 million will be spent on improving the Tube stations in the area. £5.5 million will be spent of new and improved bus lanes, bus stops and service improvements and new and £3.1 million will be spent on new and improved cycle lanes, three new cycle hire hubs plus over 11,000 cycle parking spaces.

The redevelopment of Earl's Court will provide new homes for people living on West Kensington and Gibbs Green estates, which is part of the 77 acre site, with the first residents expected to move into new homes by 2018.
shortdescription: Another major milestone in the £8billion redevelopment of Earl's Court was reached today with agreement between London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Transport for London (TFL) and scheme developer EC Properties LP on a £452million package of benefits for the area.
shorttitle: £452m Earl's Court regeneration package agreed

headline: EARL'S COURT FREE SCHOOL CONSULTATION OPENS
prcopy:
Parents, teachers and community groups in the Royal Borough are being asked what they think about proposals to open a primary free school in Earl's Court.

The consultation is open until 5pm on Friday 3 January 2014. You can fill in a questionnaire online at www.wlfs-earlscourt.org/consultation or you can fill in a paper copy using one of the consultation leaflets that are being distributed across the borough.

The West London Free School Charitable Trust (WLFS Charitable Trust) has been given the green light by the Department for Education to open a third school in September next year. That school will be called Earl's Court Free School Primary, though it will initially be based in Cambridge Grove in Hammersmith, the current home of sister school, West London Free School Primary. The trust also has a secondary school in Hammersmith, which opened in 2011.

Subject to planning approval and consultation, the new primary school will move to Earl's Court, as part of the regeneration and redevelopment of the area. This however will not be until 2020 when the multi-million pound redevelopment of Earl's Court is complete.

Thirty children each year will be accepted to the reception class until the school relocates to Earl's Court, when the entry numbers would double to 60 children a year. The school will provide children with a classical liberal education, focusing on a core of academic subjects complemented by art, music, drama and competitive sport.

Toby Young, chairman of WLFS Charitable Trust, says: "I helped set up the West London Free School because I believe that all children should have access to a classical liberal education, regardless of background or ability. That approach has proved so popular with local parents that my group is now opening a third school and our aim is to open a new one every year for as long as there is demand for this type of school from parents."

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Education, said:

"This new primary school is just one the many positive aspects of the redevelopment of Earl's Court.

"Demand for primary school places in the area is set to grow and it helps to give local parents even more choice on where to educate their children."

Councillor Georgie Cooney, Hammersmith & Fulham Council's Cabinet Member for Education, says: "We welcome the suggestion for another free school and continue to offer our support to parents wanting to set up schools or those who opt to send their children to these new schools.

"With new housing and development coming to Earl's Court, there will also be a growing population and greater demand for places in the area in the future. A new school will help address this issue while offering local parents more choice for their children's education."

An open event will be held at West London Free School Primary (the proposed temporary site for the school) at Cambridge Grove, Hammersmith, W6 0LB, on Wednesday December 11. There will be two sessions from 6pm to 7pm and 7.30pm to 8.30pm.

For more information on the proposals email consultation@wlfs.org
keyword3: West London Free School Charitable Trust
shortdescription: Parents, teachers and community groups in the Royal Borough are being asked what they think about proposals to open a primary free school in Earl's Court.
shorttitle: Earl's Court Free School Consultation opens

headline: New opportunity for independent living
prcopy:
Residents, their families and staff joined the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and councillors to mark the official opening of Piper House yesterday (Thursday 21 November) following £1.65m of investment.

Over the past two years Piper House has been transformed into 12 flats for people with learning disabilities and complex needs so they can live independently in their local community.

The Mayor, Cllr Charles Williams, said: "I am delighted to be opening Piper House today. I have spoken to many of the residents and their families, who are all genuinely happy to be here and having looking around for myself I am very impressed with the facilities offered."

Cllr Fiona Buxton, the former Cabinet Member for Adult Social Care who approved the start of works, added: "It is good news for everyone that we are able to offer people with complex needs the chance of independent living within the borough. This means they do not lose contact with family and friends by having to move away, as well as allowing them to have the best standard of living and chances possible.

"When you consider that for many of the younger residents this will be their first time living away from their families and carers you will appreciate just how important it was for us to upgrade these facilities and give them a place to live that everyone associated with Piper House can be proud of."

The work has seen Piper House converted from three, six-bed flats for people with learning disabilities, but lacking full access, into 12 flats, ten of which can be used by wheelchair users.

It follows the decision by the Council in 2008 to develop more local services for people with complex needs. This involved extensive consultations with the existing residents, their families, the staff and others and the result of this was the final design of Piper House.

To find out more about Piper House and what residents think of it go to http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J_nOohFivLU&feature=youtu.be
shortdescription: Residents, their families and staff joined the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and councillors to mark the official opening of Piper House yesterday (Thursday 21 November) following £1.65m of investment.
shorttitle: New opportunity for independent living

headline: SWEEPING REFORMS TO NEW TENANCIES IN KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA
prcopy:
People with genuine local connections and armed forces personnel will receive greater priority for council housing as part of a package of sweeping reforms to new tenancies in Kensington and Chelsea.

The reforms, agreed by the Council's Cabinet last night (21 November 2013),following six months of public consultation and scrutiny, include measures that will transform not only who can get a Council home, but also on what terms.

Amongst the measures is an end to lifetime tenancies. New tenants are already issued with 12 month introductory tenancies. But from 6 January 2014 a tenant who completes such a tenancy without breaching its terms will then be eligible for either a two or, more typically five-year tenancy.

There would typically be a presumption to renew; however, tenancies would not be renewed if at the end of their term:

 there has been a serious breach of the tenancy agreement including rent arrears or antisocial behaviour
 the tenant or tenant's partner has acquired a legal interest in another property suitable for occupation
 household income has grown to more than £50,000 for one and two-bed flats and £65,000 for larger properties
 savings and investments, other than for pension purposes, exceed £25,000.
.
In addition, if the property has become too large for the household's needs, a new tenancy would only be offered on a smaller property, so that families trapped in overcrowded accommodation have a better chance of being allocated a home that meets their needs.

As well as amending the terms of tenancies, the Council is also altering the rules on which households qualify for Council and Housing Association homes in the first place. From 17 February 2014 people who have not been in the borough for at least three years will generally be disqualified. Extra points will be awarded to households where at least one member is in paid work for 16 hours a week or more. Serving and former members of the armed forces and bereaved partners of forces personnel also attract extra points. Households with high incomes and significant savings will no longer be eligible for social-rented properties*, but will instead be able to access intermediate housing options, such as shared ownership or discount market rented properties.

"Our social housing is a scarce and precious resource," said Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, the Council's Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Housing. "We have an absolute duty to make sure that it goes to the right people. For us that means those in the greatest need, those with real roots in our borough, those who work and are good neighbours, and those who have served our country. Therefore, we are adjusting our policies accordingly."

As a corollary of the reforms, the Council intends to remove from its housing register those households with no realistic prospect of ever getting a Council or Housing Association home. Last year the Council let 470 properties but it has nearly 9,000 households on its housing register, nearly 6,500 of which are neither homeless, overcrowded or in pressing medical need.

"People are currently able to join our housing register that in fact have very low priority", explained Cllr Feilding-Mellen.

"It is better to offer them realistic housing advice about where they can find actual accommodation than to leave them languishing on a list for homes which will simply never become available because quite properly the homeless, the ill and the chronically overcrowded will always be ahead in the queue."

These new tenancy policies form part of a wider set of planning and housing policy reforms intended to increase the supply of new housing of all tenures across the borough, but with a special focus on more housing for those who are ineligble for social housing but unable to afford private housing in the borough. Cllr Feilding-Mellen concluded, "In order to protect and preserve our mixed community, we need to make sure there are more homes available for those hard-working households and families in the middle of the income spectrum, and so we will be looking at every opportunity to deliver more intermediate and mid-market housing here in Kensington and Chelsea".
shortdescription: People with genuine local connections and armed forces personnel will receive greater priority for council housing as part of a package of sweeping reforms to new tenancies in Kensington and Chelsea.
shorttitle: Sweeping reforms to new tenancies in Kensington and Chelsea

headline: LIFE COACHING IN ST CHARLES WARD
prcopy:
Life coaching is being increasingly explored as a way of tackling issues such as worklessness, loss of confidence, disengagement and family problems. It involves looking at each individual's needs and allowing them to set out what they want to achieve. Coaches then provide tailored support to each individual and connect them up to existing services and activities.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's City Living, Local Life is currently in its second year of funding a life coaching project in St Charles Ward, and reports from Dalgarno Way are pretty positive. Tara Kennedy, Project Development Manager at the Dalgarno Centre said the project "has exceeded our expectations in the success and change it has brought to those receiving coaching."

Life coaching in St. Charles is being provided by the Clement James Centre. Eight St Charles Ward residents initially attended an induction at the centre in March 2013 and then received six sessions of one-hour coaching. Since then eight more people have benefited from the project.

So far there have been positive results for those who have received life coaching including career changes, signing up for leadership courses and gaining new employment. One person has even started up her own business as a life coach and is offering her services for free to other residents who feel they may benefit from it.

The project is being funded for two years and 32 residents will have received coaching by the end. In addition to the coaching, the programme offers the opportunity for the coaches, and other local residents, to attend a two-day accredited life coaching course each year.

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, said: "I am very pleased to hear that this life coaching project is making a positive difference to people's lives."

Councillor Pat Healy, a St Charles ward Councillor said: "I am delighted that the life coaching project has proved such a success, not just in helping the St Charles residents who have been through the process to begin to fulfil their own potential. But as we hoped, some of them are already giving back by using their experience to life coach others who might otherwise have fallen by the wayside."

For more information, please contact Tara Kennedy at tara@dalgarnotrust.org.uk

It involves looking at each individual's needs and allowing them to set out what they want to achieve. Coaches then provide tailored support to each individual and connect them up to existing services and activities.
shorttitle: Life coaching in St Charles ward

headline: COLVILLE PUPILS FIND FUN IN MACBETH
prcopy:
Pupils from Colville Primary School got to grips with one of Shakespeare's most famous plays when they took on the daunting challenge of performing Macbeth at the Waterman's Theatre, Brentford, on 20 November, as part of the UK-wide Shakespeare Schools Festival

The year five pupils worked as a strong ensemble cast and used percussion and physical performance to create the moon and landscape of this famous tragedy.

Olivia Carruthers, who directed the performance, said: "It has been a pleasure working with these very enthusiastic and talented young people. I was amazed at how quickly and easily they learned their lines and showed a real understanding of Shakespeare's difficult language. They have worked incredibly hard and have given me one hundred percent commitment to making this a very special experience for all of us. I am so proud of what they have achieved in such a limited time and I, for one, will miss our rehearsal time together when this is all over."

Jannate, who plays Lennox, said: "I didn't know any Shakespeare and when they said there was going to be a play of Macbeth I wanted to participate. Being in the play has given me a lot of confidence. And Shakespeare is actually fun!"

Jagdeep Birdi, Headmaster of Colville School, said: "The year five cast delivered their lines like seasoned actors. The Bard himself would have been proud."
shortdescription: Pupils from Colville Primary School got to grips with one of Shakespeare's most famous plays when they took on the daunting challenge of performing Macbeth at the Waterman's Theatre, Brentford, on 20 November, as part of the UK-wide Shakespeare Schools Festival
shorttitle: Colville pupils find fund in Macbeth

headline: CHILDREN TAKE OVER THEIR PLAY CENTRES
prcopy:
Over 40 children from primary schools across the borough seized a chance to run their play centres as part of Takeover Day, a national scheme to give youngsters a chance use their own skills and enthusiasm to shape the way their services are run.

The children got involved in all the daily activities including planning meetings, taking registration and organising activities for younger children. They also helped prepare and serve tea and were involved in debriefing meetings to look at how the day had gone.

As a reward for their efforts children who took part in Takeover Day were invited to the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's parlour on Friday 22 November to receive special certificates. While there, they also took part in a workshop delivered by members of the borough's Children's Forum, aimed at tackling bullying.

Olivia (9) said: "Takeover Day is, in my opinion, an amazing experience." Elias (10) said: "It helped me to learn how adults cope with us on a daily basis." and Kyle (10) said: "I got involved because I wanted to see how it is being a play worker."

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "Takeover Day always gives the officers who work closely with children something to think about. We learn a good deal from watching how the children would go about running things for a day while the children get a chance to develop their own skills.

"This year, as well as taking over their play centres, there was an opportunity for the children to reflect on the very important issue of bullying, how to recognise it and how to stop it should it arise."

Takeover Day, which this year falls within Anti-Bullying Week, is promoted by the Children's Commissioner for England and delivered by Children's Participation Team for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.
shortdescription: Over 40 children from primary schools across the borough seized a chance to run their play centres as part of Takeover Day, a national scheme to give youngsters a chance use their own skills and enthusiasm to shape the way their services are run.
shorttitle: Children take over their play centres

headline: You asked Nick
prcopy:
More than 50 residents were at the St Cuthbert's Centre in Earl's Court on Tuesday night (26 November) to put questions to the Leader of the Council, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown.

Amongst the issues raised were pavement cycling, illegal dumping, air quality and developments in garden squares. But the evening was dominated by questions about the forthcoming redevelopment of Earl's Court with residents expressing anxiety about noise, traffic, lorry movements, the loss of the Exhibition Centre and other aspects of the scheme.

A number of senior cabinet members and councillors were there to support the Leader and help answer the questions. Officers from the Council and the police were also on hand with advice and guidance at a selection of information stands.

This was the second Ask Nick event. A third is planned for Chelsea in the new year.
shortdescription: More than 50 residents were at the St Cuthbert's Centre in Earl's Court on Tuesday night (26 November) to put questions to the Leader of the Council, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown.

headline: NEW PROVIDER FOR YOUNG CARERS
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council and Hammersmith & Fulham are now using Spurgeons, a charity with decades of experience working with children, to provide support and advice to their young carers.

There will be no change to how young carers are referred to the service, but the long-term mentors for the carers will now be provided by Spurgeons. The aim is to allow the councils to improve the service offered to young carers and build a more flexible and tailored service.

Currently the Royal Borough is working with 105 young carers, children who are caring for a sick relative; parent, grandparent or sibling. Part of the new arrangement with Spurgeons will be to look at ways to encourage more children to make use of the help available and, also, to be willing to described themselves as carers.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "I am delighted we are now working with Spurgeons to support our young carers.

"It is a great challenge for anyone to have to care for a sick relative, even more so if you yourself are a child and we want to help them as much as possible. The new contract with Spurgeons gives us an opportunity to develop the services we offer, to meet the needs of the individual carers. I know that Council officers and Spurgeons are currently speaking with young carers to find out what they need.

"I want to encourage any young person who is looking after someone to contact us. There is a lot of help and support we can offer and it is important to know that you are not alone."

If you are a young carer, or know someone who is, and would like to find out more please contact Spurgeons on triboroughyoungcarers@spurgeons.org
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council and Hammersmith & Fulham are now using Spurgeons, a charity with decades of experience working with children, to provide support and advice to their young carers.
shorttitle: New provider for young carers

headline: CONSULTING ON A PLANNING BRIEF FOR ROYAL BROMPTON HOSPITAL
prcopy:
The Royal Brompton Hospital and Harefield NHS Trust is a world class centre for heart and lung treatment. Since its establishment it has grown considerably and occupies many sites in Chelsea. Its extended campus now includes outdated buildings or accommodation, which are no longer needed for modern medical care.

A planning brief is being prepared by The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea that will be used to assess any planning applications that come forward. It has organised a public consultation exhibition and workshops to give local people a chance to have their say on what options and issues are most important to consider for any proposed changes.

From Monday 25 November to Monday 9 December 2013 there will be an opportunity to visit the exhibition, share ideas or join a workshop to look at the area in more detail. The exhibition takes place at Chelsea Library, Chelsea Old Town Hall, King's Road, SW3 from Monday to Saturday between 9.30am and 5pm.

Open workshops will run on:

Monday 2 December - Chelsea Old Town Hall, King's Road, SW3, between 10am and noon.

Wednesday 4 December - Chelsea Old Town Hall, King's Road, SW3, between 6pm and 8pm.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: "The Royal Brompton Hospital occupies a number of sites in Chelsea. If a planning application comes forward to consolidate the hospital on one particular site we want to make sure we have gauged local opinion about how this might be done.

"I hope as many residents and businesses as possible take the time to come along to the exhibition or workshops or take a look at our website and let us have your thoughts online."

For more information go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/royalbromptonhospital by Monday 9 December 2013
shortdescription: The Royal Brompton Hospital and Harefield NHS Trust is a world class centre for heart and lung treatment.  Since its establishment it has grown considerably and occupies many sites in Chelsea.  Its extended campus now includes outdated buildings or accommodation, which are no longer needed for modern medical care.
shorttitle: Consulting on a planning brief for Royal Brompton Hospital

headline: RESIDENTS CAN REPORT HELICOPTER CONCERNS
prcopy:
Residents with concerns about helicopter activity and related noise are being reminded they can easily report them online or over the phone.

The Barclays London Heliport in Lombard Road, Battersea, is responsible for about a third of helicopter activity in London - and all pilots must adhere to established procedures when approaching and departing the site.

Helicopters landing at Battersea should approach from either the north-east or south-east and normally follow the middle of the river for as long as possible before turning to descend. Take-off direction depends upon the prevailing wind but should also be towards the middle of the river in the first instance.

Where, for safety reasons, helicopters fly on the north or south side of the river they should keep a minimum height of 1,000 feet for all but the initial take-off or final descent.

Any resident who suspects an incident has occurred where procedures have not been followed, or who has other concerns related to the heliport such as noise nuisance, can report it online at www.londonheliport.co.uk or by calling 020 7228 0181.

Resident representatives, heliport users and councillors from Wandsworth, Hammersmith & Fulham and Kensington and Chelsea councils make up the London Heliport Consultative Group - which exists to receive reports on helicopter movements and review complaints associated with the site.

The group, which has the backing of the owner of the heliport, has produced a useful guide for residents, which explains the correct procedures for helicopter approaches and take-offs.

Copies of the guide are available from the heliport or by calling Wandsworth Council on 020 8871 7524.

For more information on the work of the consultative group, visit www.wandsworth.gov.uk/heliport This includes contact details for complaints about police or military helicopters.

Residents can also view agendas and minutes of meetings held by the consultative group by clicking on the link above.
shortdescription: Residents with concerns about helicopter activity and related noise are being reminded they can easily report them online or over the phone.
shorttitle: Residents can report helicopter concerns

headline: VOTE PORTOBELLO MARKET BRITAIN'S FAVOURITE MARKET
prcopy:
If you enjoy shopping at Portobello and Golborne Markets and think they are worth shouting about go online and vote them Britain's Favourite Market by going to www.nabma.com/vote

NABMA (the National Association of British Market Authorities) has launched its hunt for Britain's Favourite Market and the winner will be the one that secures the most online votes.

Stallholders from Portobello and Golborne Markets and the Council's Street Trading Office are appealing to residents and visitors to the markets to make sure they cast their vote.

Last year NABMA selected Portobello and Golborne Markets as the best outdoor market in the country. Both markets attract millions of visitors every year drawn by their eclectic mix of everything from antiques and art to fashion, accessories, gifts and high quality fresh food, from a mix of new and existing traders.

Urging shoppers, residents and stallholders to vote them Britain's Favourite Market the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for the Environment Cllr Tim Ahern said: "Portobello is world renowned as a unique market but we would like it to be awarded the title Britain's Favourite Market. I hope as many people as possible will go to www.nabma.com/vote and vote for it.

"If they need reminding of how great it is they should check it out while doing their Christmas shopping. There is something to suit every taste and pocket, whether it is buying ingredients for Christmas dinner or gifts for your loved ones."
shortdescription: If you enjoy shopping at Portobello and Golborne Markets and think they are worth shouting about go online and vote them Britain's Favourite Market by going to www.nabma.com/vote
shorttitle: Vote Portobello Market Britain's Favourite Market

headline: LONDON'S FIRST NEIGHBOURHOOD PLAN PASSES REFERENDUM
prcopy:
Over 400 residents living in Norland ward, Kensington, yesterday (Thursday 5 December) said yes in the first neighbourhood planning referendum in London. It asked local people whether the Council should consider the Norland Neighbourhood Area Plan when deciding planning applications.

It is conservation-led, and aims to shape high quality sustainable development in the area, providing policies on residential alterations as well as preserving the area's heritage in the face of increasing development pressure.

Residents of the Norland Conservation Area, which is mainly the southern half of the ward were asked:

Do you want The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to use the neighbourhood plan for the Norland Neighbourhood Area to help it decide planning applications in the neighbourhood area?

A total of 582 votes were cast (a turnout of 26 per cent) with 429 in favour and 152 against and one spoiled ballot paper.

The referendum came about as a result of the Norland Conservation Society using powers given to communities under the Government's Localism agenda. It is the culmination of many years work by the Norland Conservation Society.

To see the plan go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/norlandplan
shortdescription: Over 400 residents living in Norland ward, Kensington, yesterday (Thursday 5 December) said yes in the first neighbourhood planning referendum in London.  It asked local people whether the Council should consider the Norland Neighbourhood Area Plan when deciding planning applications.
shorttitle: London's first Neighbourhood Plan Passes Referendum

headline: COLVILLE PRIMARY SCHOOL CELEBRATES RECENT OFSTED INSPECTION
prcopy:
Pupils and staff at Colville Primary School are celebrating after education watchdog, Ofsted, recognised it as a good school.

Last month Ofsted inspected the school and praised the strong leadership of the headteacher and governors for creating a dedicated and enthusiastic team. Ofsted found Colville to be a `warm and welcoming school' and the school's achievement in mathematics and reading was praised.

Colville is one of the top schools for reading in the Royal Borough and a total of 82 per cent of children achieved Level 5 compared to the national average of 45 per cent.

The Victorian building recently underwent a £450,000 renovation paid for by the Council and the school. The new facilities include two new reception classes, a special music centre and rooms for a breakfast club and play centre. This new arrangement has freed up room in the main building, providing space for a second music room and further specialist teaching of art. Colville School is recognised as a high-achieving music specialist school.

Headteacher, Mr Jagdeep Birdi, attributed the school's success to the fact that:

"Our children benefit hugely from small class sizes right across the school and we deliver a very broad curriculum, which includes specialised teachers for art and music.

"This is simply the beginning. It is a hugely positive foundation on which to build. And with the talent, dedication and enthusiasm of staff, governors and pupils, the only way is up".

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Education, said:

"This is a great result for Colville and I am delighted for the teachers and children. I am sure the school will continue to go from strength to strength."
shortdescription: Pupils and staff at Colville Primary School are celebrating after education watchdog, Ofsted, recognised it as a good school.
shorttitle: Colville Primary School celebrates Ofsted inspection

headline: FIRST NEWLY BUILT COUNCIL HOMES IN A GENERATION
prcopy:
Three newly built Council homes were opened in the Royal Borough for the first time since the 1980s last Friday(6 December) at Holmefield House, North Kensington.

The three, three-bedroom flats are fully accessible and are built on disused space below the first floor flats.

Welcoming the opening, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Housing, said: "We all know there is tremendous demand for housing in London and I am delighted that were are able to open our first brand new Council homes for over 20 years today. It is part of a wider strategy to convert underutilised spaces into new housing for those in need.

"I know these flats are in great demand and we have plans to utilise as much disused space as we can for more homes. The new flats at Holmefield House come hot on the heels of three flats we converted back from offices on World's End Estate. We are now planning to convert the soon to be vacated Whistler Walk Children's Home into four more flats."

Robert Black, Chief Executive of the Kensington and Chelsea TMO said "The new homes are fully accessible, which is important as older Council housing is not able to offer the accessibility to disabled residents that we would want.

We are closely working with the Council and are looking at further opportunities to increase the number of accessible homes in the borough".

The Council's Hidden Homes Initiative aims to increase the number of Council homes in the borough. It has already returned three flats on the World's End Estate which had been used as office space for many years. The next development is the conversion of Whistler Walk Children's Home into four flats once the home moves early in 2014.
shortdescription: Three newly built Council homes were opened in the Royal Borough for the first time since the 1980s last Friday(6 December) at Holmefield House, North Kensington.
shorttitle: First newly built Council homes in a generation

headline: WHITE RIBBON WEEK
prcopy:
Nearly 300 residents and staff of the Royal Borough showed their support for White Ribbon Week by pledging to never commit, condone or remain silent about violence against women (Monday 25 to Friday 29 November).

The campaign was launched on Monday 25 November as part of the international elimination of violence against women day which aims to raise awareness of abuse. Men in particular were asked to wear a white ribbon as a personal pledge, although everyone was welcome to show their support. The borough saw Council staff, the police, PCSOs and staff at St Charles Hospital all give their support to the cause.

Amongst those giving their support were the Leader of the Royal Borough, Cllr Nicholas Paget-Brown, the Mayor Cllr Charles Williams and the Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services, Cllr Joanna Gardner.

Cllr Gardner said: "I am delighted with the support we garnered for the White Ribbon campaign. We have a close relationship with the police and support organisations and we hope to build on this and give people in need as much help as possible.

"Domestic abuse is an issue we can all do something about, not just by reporting it if we see it, but knowing the signs of domestic violence and where help is available if it is needed."

This is the first time the Royal Borough has joined in the White Ribbon campaign. To find out more go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/whiteribboncampaign

headline: RUBBISH AND RECYCLING COLLECTIONS OVER THE FESTIVE SEASON
prcopy:
There will be no rubbish, recycling or garden waste collections on Christmas Day, Boxing Day or New Year's Day.

Anyone who normally has rubbish and recycling collections on Monday and Thursday will only receive a Monday collection during the Christmas week.

Normal service will resume on Thursday 2 January 2014.

During the Christmas and New Year period the amount of rubbish produced per person in the Royal Borough increases. A lot of this rubbish can be recycled.

There are a number of ways residents can recycle waste whilst saving taxpayers' money and looking after the environment:

 put old cards and wrapping paper into your recycling bag or recycling bank. Don't forget to include any old newspapers, magazines or junk mail
 glass bottles, jars and tins can easily be recycled. Rinse clean any glass bottle or jar, drinks can or food tin and place it in the recycling bag or recycling bank
 recycle plastic bottles, pots, tubs and trays - e.g. water, shampoo, bubble bath, milk, bleach, detergent, washing-up liquid bottles, yoghurt pots and ready meal trays. Please remove the lids, rinse clean and place into your recycling bag or recycling bank
 empty aerosol cans, without the lids, can also be recycled in recycling bags and banks.

As much as £400,000 a year is wasted dealing with contaminated recycling at a cost to the Council and council tax payers.

Last year residents recycled over 81 tonnes of Christmas trees for composting, so this year the Council is running the Christmas tree composting scheme again.

From Thursday 2 to Wednesday 15 January 2014 the Council will collect Christmas trees to be shredded and turned into compost.

Christmas tree collection dates are different to those for normal rubbish. You can find out your tree collection days at www.rbkc.gov.uk/christmastrees or telephone Streetline on 020 7361 3001. Alternatively, residents can deliver their Christmas trees to the following collection points between Thursday 2 January and Wednesday 15 January 2014.

For details of drop off points, visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/christmastrees
shortdescription: There will be no rubbish, recycling or garden waste collections on Christmas Day, Boxing Day or New Year's Day.
shorttitle: Rubbish and recycling collections over the festive season

headline: ST THOMAS MORE IS OUTSTANDING SAY OFSTED INSPECTORS
prcopy:
Staff and students at St Thomas More Language College in Chelsea are preparing for the Christmas holidays on a high after celebrating their recent Ofsted inspection which judged the school to be to be `Outstanding'.

The government inspectors awarded the outstanding rating, the highest possible, in all four categories of their inspection: the achievement of pupils, the quality of teaching, the behaviour and safety of the pupils, and leadership and management.

Head teacher, Doctor Trevor Papworth, said: "We are clearly delighted with the outcome and feel the judgement echoes living out our motto `Serving God, Striving for Excellence'. We have made rapid progress since our last `good' judgement in 2009 and this is a recognition to the staff, students and their families for their amazing hard work and dedication to being the best they can possibly be - particularly when being judged against the much more challenging 2013 Ofsted framework."

The report is full of praise for the college with inspectors summarising "As a result of outstanding teaching all groups of students make rapid and sustained progress" and "Behaviour in lessons and around the college shows that students have an extremely mature attitude to each other and to their teachers and this results in a strong family atmosphere and values."

This latter statement is particularly welcomed by Dr Papworth given that students have always described the school as `a family'. Inspectors were also very impressed with the wide range of opportunities available to students outside the main curriculum and how these additional learning opportunities are a real strength of the college.

Mary Alves, Head Girl of the school, said: "Being in an outstanding school makes me feel amazing. It rewards all the hard work students and staff have made. We all excel as a community and we always knew we were outstanding but it's great to be told!"
shortdescription: Staff and students at St Thomas More Language College in Chelsea are preparing for the Christmas holidays on a high after celebrating their recent Ofsted inspection which judged the school to be to be `Outstanding'.
shorttitle: St Thomas More is outstanding say Ofsted inspectors

headline: CHAIN REACTION
prcopy:
The Mayor of London's Cycle Hire Scheme will be available to even more residents and visitors to the borough following the opening of 24 new docking stations in December and early January.

Council officers have been working with TfL over the past year to find suitable locations for the stations.

The borough already has a good supply of cycles based at more than 60 docking stations, and this latest expansion will extend the coverage of the scheme from the river all the way to the Westway, giving residents and visitors the freedom to make even more trips by bike.

TfL is also opening new docking stations in the neighbouring boroughs of Hammersmith & Fulham and Wandsworth, meaning even more locations will be accessible using one of the popular `Boris bikes' hired from Kensington and Chelsea.

headline: COUNCIL MAINTAINS FUNDING LEVELS FOR COMMUNITY AND VOLUNTARY GROUPS
prcopy:
All the community and voluntary organisations that were funded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Corporate Grants Programme in 2013-14 will once again be funded in 2014-15.

Despite pressure on the Council's own finances all the grants have been maintained or increased and no organisation will experience a cut to its grant.

There is also good news for the organisations that bid for support from the Council's Innovative Project scheme. Eight new third sector projects will be supported over the next two years totalling £557,000. An additional £200,000 has been made available for innovation from 2014-15 which has allowed the Council to support these projects.

Six out of the eight projects are led by local organisations that are well established in the borough including: Age UK, St Clement James Centre and the Octavia Foundation.

The projects that are being supported will tackle isolation in older men; engage businesses in supporting unemployed people through work experience; establish a mobile crèche as a social enterprise which will provide work and training opportunities, and establish a new social enterprise that supports older women to make and sell goods.

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, said: "The voluntary sector plays an enormous role in life in the borough. It provides important services for residents which help support the Council to deliver its priorities. I am delighted that we have been able to maintain our level of funding and make more money available for innovative projects."
shortdescription: All the community and voluntary organisations that were funded by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Corporate Grants Programme in 2013-14 will once again be funded in 2014-15.
shorttitle: Council maintains funding levels for community and voluntary groups

headline: CONTRACTOR APPOINTED TO CARRY OUT KENSINGTON CENTRAL LIBRARY REPAIRS
prcopy:
ITC Concepts Limited has been appointed by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to carry out essential repairs to the fabric of Kensington Central Library.

Built in the 1960s, the library's mechanical and electrical systems have exceeded their life expectancy and a major overhaul is now required. ITC Concepts Limited will be the main contractor and will oversee the works which include modernising the electrics and making it more comfortable for library users by installing a more energy-efficient heating and ventilation system. Other details include new hot and cold water services, refurbishing the lifts and installing public toilets on the lower ground floor. Essential repairs to the roof will also be carried out.

Funding of £5.8m for the project was approved by the Royal Borough back in November 2012 and will ensure that the building can continue to meet the needs of the community for at least the next twenty years. The works will improve the overall use of space including creating new offices from previously underutilised areas, some of which will be available for the local business community to rent.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Libraries, said:

"These renovation works are essential if Kensington Central Library is to continue to meet the needs of the community for decades to come and is part of our ongoing commitment to the borough's libraries."

Preliminary building work began in November 2013 in non-public areas of the library. Between December 2013 and February 2014 access to the Biography Collection and music scores in the basement will be temporarily suspended and a small amount of some Local Studies material will also be unavailable. The main renovation work is expected to start in January 2014 and last for 12 months. All the current books in the library will continue to be available for the public.

Due to the scale of the repairs there will be some disruption to library services.
The Council will aim to minimise this, however there may be changes to services and noise. Any disruption will be publicised well in advance.

Please ask a member of staff or email libraries@rbkc.gov.uk for further details. To find out more and register for e-updates visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/centralworks
or keep a look out for information displayed in the library.
keyword5: new hot and cold water systems

shorttitle: Contractor appointed to carry out Kensington Central Library repairs

headline: MAYOR'S CHARITY CAROLS
prcopy:
Nearly 300 people joined the Mayor of the Royal Borough, Cllr Charles Williams, together with celebrity speakers, at Monday's Christmas carol concert that raised money for Trinity Hospice.

Held in the beautiful St Mary Abbots Church, Kensington, guests were treated to songs from Cardinal Vaughan Memorial School's Schola Cantorum; a bible reading from former Council leader Baroness Hanham; and Christmas readings from actress Dame Diana Rigg and news reader Huw Edwards.

headline: VIRGIN ACTIVE FINED £100,000
prcopy:
Virgin Active was fined £100,000 yesterday (Thursday 19 December) at Southwark Crown Court and ordered to pay costs of £31,741.36. It had previously pleaded guilty to one offence under the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 and to another offence under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974 at Hammersmith Magistrates Court on 15 October. The offences were found following an investigation by Environmental Health Officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea into the death of a woman swimming at a Virgin Active Club at 17a Old Court Place, Kensington, London W8.

The court heard how on 3 December 2011 Miss Elsa Carneau (25) drowned whilst swimming in the pool at the club.

Miss Carneau was not a club member but had previously used the facilities as a guest of a club member. On the day of the incident, Elsa Carneau was allowed to enter the club unaccompanied, despite this being against the club's rules, where she swam lengths. The swimming pool was not required to have lifeguards but was monitored by CCTV and physical poolside checks. However, the single CCTV camera, which was located at one end of the pool, failed to provide a clear view of the whole pool and did not cover the end of the pool where Elsa Carneau got into difficulty.

After some time, the other swimmers became concerned that she was underwater and not moving. Finding her unconscious, Elsa Carneau was lifted out of the pool but, sadly, attempts to resuscitate at poolside were unsuccessful.

The accident was investigated by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and serious shortcomings in the management of health and safety risks relating to swimming activities at the club were uncovered.

Officers found that there had been a failure to undertake a suitable and sufficient risk assessment of the swimming pool. They discovered a failing to make proper arrangements for the effective planning, organisation, control and monitoring of the preventative and protective measures identified in Virgin Active's documentation and a failure to conduct the operation of the swimming pool in such a way as to ensure, so far as was reasonably practicable, that people were not exposed to risks whilst using the swimming pool. The investigation also revealed that the required checks of the CCTV and physical checks of the poolside were not carried out on the day of the incident. The CCTV checks were routinely not completed a month prior to the incident and the poolside checks were not carried out as per Virgin Active's procedure.

Summing up His Honour Judge McCreath, Hon. Recorder of Westminster, highlighted that there was foreseeable risk and a serious breach of Virgin Active's duty and that there was evidence of inadequate supervision on the day.

He also highlighted that the CCTV was defective in two significant ways in that it did not cover the whole pool and that the pictures to front of house lacked clarity.

He also acknowledged that it was impossible to demonstrate corporate faults of Virgin Active causing this death and that strong arrangements and corporate structures were in place and that the company generally had a good safety record.

Cllr Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "This was a very sad case for officers to investigate. What they found was a failure to have proper procedures and risk assessments in place to ensure safe monitoring of the pool."

The offences were found following an investigation by Environmental Health Officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea into the death of a woman swimming at a Virgin Active Club at 17a Old Court Place, Kensington, London W8.

headline: LIBRARY EVENTS TO INSPIRE AND DELIGHT
prcopy:
The Royal Borough's libraries are offering free events during January to inspire and inform members.

On Tuesday 14 January at North Kensington Library, Charlotte Read will explain how she turned her daily Facebook status posts into a self-published book of thoughts which has developed into a full-time profitable business. She now sells the book, related prints and greeting cards in gift shops around the UK, online and at her thriving Portobello Road market stall.

Join her for an evening where she talks about her experience of self-publishing, how to get your book noticed and how to go about distributing it when there's no one to do it but yourself.

headline: PARKS POLICE TO WEAR LAPEL CAMERAS
prcopy:
Dogs defecating and fighting, litterbugs, drunks and other antisocial behaviour could soon be significantly reduced in parks across the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith and Fulham after parks police officers were issued with lapel cameras.

The councils say the move, which will enable officers to capture court ready evidence at the touch of a button, will help cut crime and antisocial behaviour in 23 parks and open spaces and speed up prosecutions.

The cameras are able to capture high quality footage at night and all videos will show the date and time. It is hoped this will speed up the time it takes to prepare court cases as well as making it more likely the offenders will plead guilty.

Cllr Tim Ahern, Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Cabinet Member for Environment, said: "We are rightly proud of our parks and have always strived to make them both welcoming and an oasis of calm in a very busy city. Our parks police combat antisocial behaviour whenever they see it. This initiative is a great way to help them to deal effectively with the problem and ensure it is easier to take action against offenders."

Cllr Greg Smith, Hammersmith and Fulham Council Deputy Leader, added: "A picture is worth a thousand words and video footage is much more effective in securing convictions than verbal accounts, which can be challenged. Dog poo, littering and other forms of antisocial behaviour could soon be a thing of the past in our parks. My message to anyone thinking of causing a problem in our parks is: smile - you're on camera and we will see you in court."
shortdescription: Dogs defecating and fighting, litterbugs, drunks and other antisocial behaviour could soon be significantly reduced in parks across the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith and Fulham after parks police officers were issued with lapel cameras.
shorttitle: Parks police to wear lapel cameras

headline: CROSSRAIL ROADSHOW INVITATION - SEWER WORKS IN TAVISTOCK ROAD
prcopy:
The surface tracks for Crossrail at Westbourne Park will be laid above the Green Lane Sewer, which runs parallel and to the west of the Great Western Road. The existing sewer is in a shallow position and occupies space needed for the new tracks along the Great Western main line.

This means the sewer must be replaced with a deeper one between Great Western Road and Tavistock Road, passing beneath the Great Western main line and Hammersmith & City line, and then west under Tavistock Road to Basing Street.

Crossrail is inviting residents to an information roadshow on Friday 17 and Saturday 18 January. Its exhibition caravan will be positioned in Tavistock Crescent at the junction with Great Western Road near to the Metropolitan pub. It will be open from 10am to 7pm on Friday 17 January and 10am to 4pm on Saturday 18 January. Community liaison staff and engineers will be on hand to explain the works and answer questions.

Work starts on utilities diversion in Tavistock Road in January/February 2014 and work on the replacement sewer begins in March 2014 and will last for approximately nine months.

For more information contact the Crossrail helpdesk on 0345 602 3813.
