headline: £25M EXTRA FOR INVESTMENT IN COUNCIL HOMES
prcopy:
The money available to repair and improve council homes is expected to soar by £25m over the next five years, thanks to a series of measures contained in the housing budget discussed last night (Wednesday 16 January) at the Tenant Consultative Committee

In 2012 councils became subject to a new self-financing regime in which they support and maintain their housing stock purely from their own rental income and other resources. In Kensington and Chelsea, that greater freedom and autonomy is having a positive budgetary effect.

Crucially, increases in rental income are no longer handed to central Government's redistributive housing subsidy system but are instead retained locally.

Since 2002 council rents have been calculated using a complex national formula. For each property, a target rent is set and the expectation is that over time the rent charged moves towards the target rent. However, the rate at which they can do so has been severely limited.

Currently just one per cent of the Council's housing stock has reached the target rent indicated by the national formula. Using the greater freedoms under the new finance regime, the Council is accelerating the pace of convergence so that all rents reach target by 2018-19.

In 2014-15 rents will therefore increase by an average of 6.26 per cent, which is just one per cent more than would have been the case under the old regime. Even so, that additional increase will generate an extra £7 million over five years while the average Council rent in Kensington and Chelsea will still be just £118.29 per week, which is just a fraction of the market rate.

But it's not all about rent. The end of the annual uncertainty over the level of subsidy enables stable financial and business planning. Against that background, a range of savings and initiatives are being realised. For example, the Kensington and Chelsea Tenant Management Organisation (KCTMO) performance has increased markedly across a range of measures but its management fees have not, empty flats are being let quickly and efficiently to maintain rental income and KCTMO is also beginning to better exploit the potential of community centres and estate parking to support investment in people's homes.

"It's no secret that we are in an age of austerity," said the Deputy Leader of the Council, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, "so it's excellent news that we'll be able to invest £60m - that's an additional £25m than previously planned - in our estate over the next five years. All of that extra money will be coming back to our tenants in the form of better repairs, maintenance and other services, and we'll be doing that at the same time as putting protections in place to ensure no tenants suffer excessive rent increases."
shortdescription: The money available to repair and improve council homes is expected to soar by £25m over the next five years, thanks to a series of measures contained in the housing budget  discussed last night (Wednesday 16 January) at the Tenant Consultative Committee
shorttitle: £25m extra for investment in Council homes

headline: THE FEELING'S MUTUAL - EXCITING TIMES FOR ROYAL BOROUGH'S YOUTH SERVICE
prcopy:
Kensington and Chelsea's nationally respected youth service department has this month become an independent Public Service Mutual (PSM).

Epic CIC*, as the new organisation will be known, is the first youth service department in the country to be freed from local authority control. As an independent body the service is now a PSM with its 152 staff owning shares in the company and having a say in its management. Its new mutual status will also enable Epic to market itself to other organisations.

Although legally separated, it will continue to provide the Royal Borough with first-class services and has signed a five year contract to do so.

Epic currently operates four youth centres and is working out of several sites run by the voluntary sector, as well as directly with the community. Amongst other roles, it provides guidance and support for 13 to 19-year-olds and particularly those in difficulty. That guidance and support takes many forms including intensive one-to-one work, arts, sport, health, education and experiencing the great outdoors.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said:

"Councils up and down the country have had to make very difficult decisions, resulting from a growing need for high quality support for young people combined with reduced public expenditure.

"To ensure that our nationally recognised youth service does not suffer, we decided to pursue a different approach so that Epic CIC can grow and share its skills and experience with other organisations."

Francis Maude MP, Minister for the Cabinet Office said:

"This Government is committed to improving the UK's public services and confronting the combined challenge of reduced public expenditure, rising customer demand, and increased service complexity.

"Hard working taxpayers expect nothing less, and to meet these challenges we need to break down the old binary choice between in-house and outsourced delivery and establish more innovative models for delivering services.

"That's why we are supporting new mutuals and I hope that Epic CIC can inspire staff in other youth services by demonstrating that increased autonomy and freedom can achieve great results."

Brendan O'Keefe, who heads up Epic CIC, said:

"It's been a long journey to get to this point and we have taken the time to ensure that everything is in place so that we can successfully stand on our own two feet from day one.

"Epic's staff are very excited about what 2014 will bring and we look forward to going from strength-to-strength with the support of the Royal Borough."

Back in July 2012 the Royal Borough's Cabinet agreed that the employees of the Youth Service will leave the Council and become an independent body. For many months the Royal Borough has been supporting and advising the service employees as it finalises its business plan and puts the necessary operational structures in place.

As well as continuing to provide services to Kensington and Chelsea, the PSM will market itself to other bodies, something it is already doing with some success. It has already secured contracts with a London health commissioning body and a number of schools.
shortdescription: Kensington and Chelsea's nationally respected youth service department has this month become an independent Public Service Mutual (PSM).
shorttitle: The feeling's mutual - exciting times for Royal Borough's Youth Service

headline: PLANNING PERMISSION FOR TWO MAJOR COUNCIL SITES
prcopy:
An unattractive and underused municipal car park in Young Street, Kensington, is to be replaced by a twenty-first century mansion block, the Council's Major Planning Development Committee agreed last night (21 January 2014).

Of the 53 market homes in the new block, approximately 17 will be for sale, with the remainder for private rent. The income will be shared between the Council and its development partner, Grainger.

Standing at the northern entrance to historic Kensington Square, the car park at 19-27 Young Street is something of an eyesore. The new development is an opportunity to dramatically improve the approach to the square, which is not only one of the oldest in London, but also one of the most desirable.

Built to an exacting specification, the mansion block will complement the square's dominant architectural styles and materials. The expectation is that it will also yield a significant new income stream to support Council services.

"This is a dated and ugly car park, which we can easily do without," said the Council's Cabinet Member for Housing, Property and Regeneration, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen. "Replacing it will be a fine building, far more appropriate to this important location. And if that wasn't justification enough, there will also be rental income and some badly needed affordable four-bedroom houses provided offsite at Hortensia Road."

Also before the committee last night was the related development of land on Hortensia Road. Again this is a partnership development between the Council and Grainger.

The committee granted permission for the land to be developed to provide 31 new homes comprising 19 one- and two-bedroom flats for market rent and five one-and two- bedroom flats for intermediate rent*. In addition, there will be seven new Council homes, one of them a two-bed flat, the other six, four-bedroom houses which are in very short supply for social housing tenants. Included in the development will be a commercial unit at ground floor level.

"We are delivering the new housing that London so desperately needs," added Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, "built to a high quality specification and designed in a way that is sensitive to nearby listed buildings. We are convinced this is the best achievable future for our sites."
shortdescription: An unattractive and underused municipal car park in Young Street, Kensington, is to be replaced by a twenty-first century mansion block, the Council's Major Planning Development Committee agreed last night (21 January 2014).
shorttitle: Planning permission for two major Council sites

headline: National Voter Registration Day
prcopy:
The Council is encouraging young people to make sure they register to vote if they haven't already done so. National Voter Registration Day is on Wednesday 5 February and this year, if you are on the electoral register, you can have a say not only in who runs the Council but who represents you in the European Parliament.

It is also an opportunity for people to encourage friends who are not on the electoral register to make sure they have the chance to have their say.

To register contact Electoral Services at elect@rbkc.gov.uk or call 020 7361 3444. You can also find more information about what happens in the Royal Borough at www.rbkc.gov.uk/councilanddemocracy/

Find out more about National Voter Registration Day at Bite the Ballot, www.bitetheballot.co.uk or on Twitter @bitetheballot or on Facebook www.facebook.com/bitetheballot

National Voter Registration Day is on Wednesday 5 February and this year, if you are on the electoral register, you can have a say not only in who runs the Council but who represents you in the European Parliament.

headline: A BIG THANKS
prcopy:
As a pat on the back for time invested volunteering in borough schools, a group of school governors gathered for a special Mayoral thank you, last Thursday (23 January), at Kensington Town Hall.

Forming part of one of the largest volunteer groups in the country, governors are key players in the life of a school.

From fundraising to strategic advice, to balancing resources and appointing the head, a governor is an essential source of school support.

Greeted by the Mayor, Cllr Charles Williams, and the Council's Cabinet Member for Education, Cllr Emma Will, the governors got the chance to network with their peers and enjoyed a selection of tasty refreshments as a well deserved thank you.

The Mayor said: "Governors who give freely of their time and expertise to schools have played an important part in helping the Royal Borough's schools to achieve outstanding results. I am delighted I was able to express my appreciation by holding this thank you party."

The event was the first in a series which looks to recognise the work of people who add to the life of the borough.

To find out more about becoming a school governor in a Royal Borough school call School Governance Support on 020 7598 4781.
shortdescription: As a pat on the back for time invested volunteering in borough schools, a group of school governors gathered for a special Mayoral thank you , last Thursday (23 January), at Kensington Town Hall.
shorttitle: A big thanks

headline: A VALUABLE FORCE
prcopy:
Police volunteers who work in the Royal Borough were recognised at a special reception last night (Thursday 30 January) at Kensington Town Hall.

From working with police cadets or serving as a Special Constables, to offering advice on Notting Hill Carnival, police volunteers are a valuable force and help make the borough a better place.

The volunteers met the Mayor, Cllr Charles Williams, along with the Council's Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services, Cllr Hon Joanna Gardner and Chief inspector Gareth Davies.

Commenting after the event, the Mayor said: "I was delighted to be able to thank those who help the police in a voluntary capacity in many different ways. I hope that more people will come forward to support the Metropolitan Police as volunteers."

The event was the second in a series which looks to recognise the work of people who add to the life of the borough.

To find out about volunteering with the borough's police, contact Andy Williams on 020 8246 0624 or Andy.M.Williams@ met.police.uk
shortdescription: Police volunteers who work in the Royal Borough were recognised at a special reception last night (Thursday 30 January) at Kensington Town Hall.
shorttitle: A valuable force

headline: RECYCLED CHRISTMAS TREES TO BE PLANTED IN KITCHEN GARDENS
prcopy:
Royal Borough residents recycled 97 tonnes of Christmas trees during two weeks from 2 January to 15 January, an increase of over 16 tonnes on the previous year. The majority of the trees will be shredded and used in compost for landscaping projects but 30 trees, which were found rooted in pots, were rescued from the recycling by the Council's contractor SITA and have been passed on to the Council's community kitchen gardens team. The team believe that 20 of the trees could live if planted in the borough's kitchen gardens.

The number of Christmas trees recycled has grown steadily each year since the scheme was introduced seven years ago as part of a drive to stop biodegradable material going to landfill. In 2008, 52 tonnes were recycled this has increased over the years by 45 tonnes.

Pine trees on their own do not make ideal compost as they are quiet acidic, so the trees are sent to be blended with other materials by a specialist composting contractor.

Cllr Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for the Environment, said: "Recycling Christmas trees is an environmentally friendly way to end the festive period. It also saves the council money as it costs less per tonne to send trees for composting rather than sending them for disposal as general waste."

headline: MAYOR OF LONDON FUNDS CYCLE PARKING AND TRAINING IN KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA
prcopy:
There will be more money available for cycle training and bike parking in Kensington and Chelsea following the Mayor of London's decision to allocate £629,000 over the next three years from his Vision for Cycling fund.

As a result of the funding 1,500 new on-street cycle parking places will be created in the borough, along with a further 1,500 off-street parking spaces to make it easier for residents in flats to keep their bikes secure. A cycle parking occupancy survey for the whole borough will be carried out to identify new locations where there is demand for more cycle parking.

If you would like to suggest a location for cycle parking contact cycling@rbkc.gov.uk

There will also be even more opportunities for anyone who lives, works or studies in the borough to access cycle training. The Council aims to provide cycle training for 800 adults and over 1,500 children over the next three years.

Special training will also be provided for drivers of large lorries in an attempt to highlight to them the dangers cyclists face when in close proximity to their vehicles.

Councillor Tim Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "I am very pleased that the Mayor of London has provided this funding for the next three years. It enables us to make even more cycle parking available and also to run important cycle safety training."

To book a two hour training session, or to find out more, visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/cycletraining
shortdescription: There will be more money available for cycle training and bike parking in Kensington and Chelsea following the Mayor of London's decision to allocate £629,000 over the next three years from his Vision for Cycling fund.
shorttitle: Mayor of London funds cycle parking and training in Kensington and Chelsea

headline: PUPILS ON FREE SCHOOL MEALS IN KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA GET BEST GCSE RESULTS
prcopy:
Pupils who receive free school meals in Kensington and Chelsea do better in their GCSE exams than pupils who receive free meals in any other local authority in the country according to figures published by the think tank Demos.

The attainment gap, as it is known, measures the contrasting performance in GCSE exam results between children on free school meals and those whose parents are considered able to afford to pay for a school lunch. The figures are based on pupils who achieved five or more GCSEs at grades A* to C, including English and mathematics.

In Kensington and Chelsea the attainment gap is four per cent while nationally the gap is 27 per cent.
Commenting on these figures, Cllr Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "We have known for some time that children in Kensington and Chelsea, who receive free school meals, perform very well in their GCSEs.

"I am very pleased that young people in our borough achieve such good results, in particular those who face disadvantage or additional challenges. I believe that high- quality teaching in extremely well-led schools will always deliver the best results for children and young people, whatever their background."

In Kensington and Chelsea an impressive 77 per cent of children on free school meals achieved five or more GCSEs including English and mathematics, while 81 per cent of children in the borough who did not receive free school meals hit this target.

Nationally only 38 per cent of pupils receiving free school meals passed five or more GCSEs including English and mathematics while the national pass rate for those not receiving free school meals was 65 per cent.
shortdescription: Pupils who receive free school meals in Kensington and Chelsea do better in their GCSE exams than pupils who receive free meals in any other local authority in the country according to figures published by the think tank Demos.
shorttitle: Pupils on free school meals in Kensington and Chelsea get best GCSE results

headline: TABLE TENNIS SUCCESS FOR BOROUGH SCHOOLS
prcopy:
Young table tennis players in Kensington and Chelsea won yet more medals at this year's English Schools London Table Tennis Championships held at the impressive facilities of the University of East London.

The girls from Fox Primary took gold for the third successive year with brilliant performances from Arriana, Rose, Isabella, Laura and Eva.

The boys, led by Benji and ably supported by Marco, Elliot, Saul and Oscar took the silver medal after narrowly losing out to last year's national silver medallists in a thrilling final.

In the Under-13 section, the girls from Chelsea Academy excelled themselves by dispatching three other schools and bravely losing to a very strong Burlington Danes team in the final. All three teams will now represent their school and borough in the South of England regional finals in February.

The success of the three Kensington and Chelsea teams owes a lot to the very popular Centre of Excellence sessions held at the Chelsea Academy every Friday evening between 5pm and 8pm, where new players are always welcome. Special thanks go to Hewley Griffith, Charleigh Kirby and Marcia Ma for their expert coaching.

Councillor Emma Will, Cabinet Member for Education, said: "Congratulations to all of those who took part and did so well. We clearly have a real pool of table tennis talent in the borough's schools which is being nurtured by willing coaches and teachers."

Although Fox Primary has dominated primary school table tennis in the borough over the past five years, two schools, Bousfield and Ashburnham, have come on board to challenge the Fox supremacy. Regular table tennis sessions are also taking place at Holland Park School and the St Thomas More Language College.

For those that are really keen to pursue their table tennis dreams, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Centre of Excellence at Chelsea Academy has a direct link to the highly successful London Table Tennis Academy, where former Fox student Kidi is busy developing his England career.
shortdescription: Young table tennis players in Kensington and Chelsea won yet more medals at this year's English Schools London Table Tennis Championships held at the impressive facilities of the University of East London.
shorttitle: Table tennis success for borough schools

headline: NEW COMMUNITY SPORTS CLUB FOR YOUNG PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES
prcopy:
Young disabled people from Kensington and Chelsea aged between 11and 25 can get involved in a wide range of sports at the new Community Club based at Sion Manning Girls School in North Kensington.

On offer at the club are a choice of mainstream as well as paralympic sports including boccia, goalball, football, judo, racquet sports, athletics, fencing and much more.

The club is open every Saturday during term time for two hours of activities. And for those young people who want to compete and test their skills there will be regular tournaments with other clubs across London.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said: "This is a fantastic opportunity for young people with a disability to either keep taking part in a sport or to give something new a try."

The first session takes place on Saturday 8 February from 11am to 1pm and costs £2 to attend. If you are interested just come along to see what is on offer and talk to the coaches. There is no need to book.

For more information contact Alan Whetherly on 020 7021 0973 or email alan@disabilitysportscoach.co.uk

prcopy:

That guidance and support takes many forms including intensive one-to-one work, arts, sport, health, education and experiencing the great outdoors.

Nick Hurd MP, Minister for Civil Society, said:

"The entire public sector faces the challenges of reduced expenditure and rising customer demand. To meet these challenges, the Government is transforming the way services are delivered by creating an alternative to the old choice of in-house and outsourced delivery.

"We are supporting public service mutuals because we know that letting entrepreneurial front-line staff take ownership of their services results in greater innovation, efficiency, and improved outcomes for young people and communities.

"I wish Epic CIC success for the future and I hope they can inspire staff in other youth services to follow their lead and reap the benefits."

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, said:

Brendan O'Keefe, who heads up Epic CIC, said:

"Epic's staff are very excited about what 2014 will bring and we look forward to going from strength-to-strength with the support of the Royal Borough.

We are enormously grateful to our friends and colleagues in the Cabinet Office Mutuals Support Programme for their support and guidance during the creation of Epic. I am also delighted to have been named as a Cabinet Office Mutuals Ambassador, and will happily work with the Cabinet Office team to encourage the growth of new mutuals in the youth sector."

headline: SUPPORT CHARITY NOT CRIME
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is backing a pan-London Home Office campaign, Support Charity Not Crime, to make sure people are not duped into giving criminal or terrorist organisations money when they donate to charity.

Last year two high-profile prosecutions of individuals, who used bogus charitable collections to support terrorism, highlighted the need to make sure your money is going to reputable organisations.

In February 2013 Irfan Naseer, Irfan Khalid and Ashik Ali were found guilty of 12 counts of preparing for acts of terrorism. They had financed their plot using monies raised in the name of Muslim Aid. In August 2012 Mohammed and Shafiq Ali were sentenced to three years at the Old Bailey for undertaking charity street collections for a non-specific charity and then sending the money to Somalia for terrorist training and fighting.

In London fundraisers require a licence from the police to collect in a public place and people are being encouraged to check that collectors have this. Collectors should always be willing to show you their permit.

On private property a licence is not required but the collector must have the owner's permission. If you are thinking of putting money into a collection box in a shop, club or any other private place there are steps you can take to make sure the organisation you are donating to is legitimate.

Do check the charity's name and registration number on the side of the box, bucket or collecting tin. This can be verified at the Charity Commission's website www.charitycommission.gov.uk

If in doubt ask the collector for more information - genuine fundraisers should always be happy to answer questions and explain more about the charity. Legitimate fundraising materials should always feature the charity's name, registered name and a landline contact number. The public should be wary of those that list only a mobile phone number.

If you suspect a collection or appeal is not legitimate you can report it to Action Fraud on 0300 123 2040 or inform the Charity Commission.

Most collections and appeals are legitimate but some are scams and in some instances donations find their way into the hands of organised criminals and terrorists.

Cllr Joanna Gardner, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services, said: People need to be confident that the money they give to charity is going to good causes and not to support criminal gangs or terrorists.

"The best way to do this is to check that the person collecting on the street is displaying a proper permit issued by the police before handing over money or Direct Debit details. If you are in a shop or club and are thinking of putting money into a collecting box take a moment to check the name and registration number and if you are unsure look these up on the Charity Commission's website.

"If you have any doubts don't give."

-ENDS-

Notes to Editors

The Charity Commission
notestextcopy:
Metropolitan Police and London Councils are all backing this campaign.
The Bi-borough Prevent Team is leading on this campaign locally. Prevent is part of the Government's Counter Terrorism strategy which is called Contest. Prevent aims to stop people becoming terrorists or supporting terrorism.

"

headline: FREE ACTIVITIES FOR DADS AND YOUNGSTERS
prcopy:
The borough's children's centres run free activities and courses to encourage fathers to enjoy quality time with their young children.

Chelsea Sports Centre, Chelsea Manor Street, SW3 is offering free swimming on Sundays between 1pm and 3pm for fathers and male carers of children aged under eight years. Vouchers for the free swim are available from the borough's children's centres, call 020 7598 4775.

On Saturday 8 and 15 February a special `Dad Power' course will be held at Chelsea Open Air Children's Centre, SW3, offering advice and tips on child development to help improve the parenting skills for fathers and male carers of children under five years. The course will cover a number of topics including understanding children's behaviour, setting boundaries as well as developing strategies to change unwanted behaviour. To book a place call Chelsea Open Air call 020 7352 8374.

headline: A CHANCE TO QUESTION MANAGERS FRO THE CHELSEA AND WESTMINSTER HOSPITAL
prcopy:
Residents and community groups will have an opportunity to question the senior management of Chelsea and Westminster Hospital NHS Foundation Trust at a public meeting on Monday 24 February at 6.30pm in Kensington Town Hall.

Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, which has one main site on Fulham Road and four sexual health clinics across London, provides a range of inpatient, day care and outpatient services including A&E and maternity. In addition to this, it offers a range of specialist services including paediatric and neonatal surgery in the new Chelsea Children's Hospital, the most extensive HIV and sexual health service in Europe, high risk maternity care, the regional burns unit for London and bariatric (weight loss) surgery.

The meeting, which has been organised by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, is the second in a series being held for each of the major trusts providing healthcare in the borough.

Councillor Robert Freeman, Chairman of the Adult Social Care and Health Scrutiny Committee, said: "This is an opportunity for residents to hear what is happening at Chelsea and Westminster, find out about the Trust's expansion plans and raise any concerns that they may have."

The Trust's Chief Executive, Tony Bell, and Executive Director of Nursing and Quality, Elizabeth McManus, are among the confirmed speakers. They will give an update on developments at Chelsea and Westminster Hospital, including plans for the Trust to become a major hospital as part of the `Shaping a healthier future' programme to reorganise the NHS in North West London. The hospital representatives will then take questions from the public.

Members of the public and local community groups are invited to attend the meeting (booking is not required) and questions can be emailed in advance to scrutiny@rbkc.gov.uk or taken on the night. Questions submitted in advance will be asked first.

For more information, contact Gareth Ebenezer, Clerk to the Adult Social Care and Health Scrutiny Committee, on 020 7361 2947.
shortdescription: Residents and community groups will have an opportunity to question the senior management of Chelsea and Westminster Hospital NHS Foundation Trust at a public meeting on Monday 24 February at 6.30pm in Kensington Town Hall.
shorttitle: A chance to question managers from the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital

headline: LANDLORD FINED FOR BREACHING HOUSING STANDARDS
prcopy:
The owners of a poorly maintained House in Multiple Occupation have been fined £8,300 and ordered to pay Council costs of £4,790 after they pleaded guilty to 26 breaches of the Management of Houses in Multiple Occupation (England) Regulations 2006 and a Section 72 Offence under the Housing Act 2004 at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Tuesday 4 February.

The Bangladesh Centre, 24 Pembridge Gardens W2, was prosecuted by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea after a routine inspection by officers from Environmental Health who found that measures to ensure the safety of the house's 24 residents were not in place. They were also concerned about the condition of the accommodation, which was poorly maintained, and the lack of fire precautions and cooking and washing facilities.

The conditions witnessed were so poor the Council took immediate enforcement action.

The court heard from the owners that they required more time to comply with the legal notices and that their legal team required more time to prepare. After several adjournments the case was heard.

Commenting on the sentence, Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Housing, said: "This property was not in a fit and proper state to provide safe accommodation for its residents so it was right that we took this action. I am very pleased that the court has handed down this punishment. We will always be vigilant to make sure that landlords meet their legal obligations."
shortdescription: The owners of a poorly maintained House in Multiple Occupation have been fined £8,300 and ordered to pay Council costs of £4,790 after they pleaded guilty to 26 breaches of the Management of Houses in Multiple Occupation (England) Regulations 2006 and a Section 72 Offence under the Housing Act 2004 at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Tuesday 4 February.
shorttitle: Landlord fined for breaching housing standards

headline: ARTISTS CALLED TO BE AT THE HEART OF NORTH KENSINGTON
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is calling for artists to submit their ideas for this year's Portobello Road Wall Arts Project.

The theme for the wall, which links Portobello and Golborne markets in North Kensington, is `Heart of the Community'.

Proposals should be submitted to the Council by noon, Friday 14 March 2014.

The successful work will be installed for at least six months and is expected to be unveiled before the end of July.

Councillor Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Arts, said: "This is the eighth year we have looked for an artist to make their mark in Portobello.

"This very exciting part of the borough is visited by millions of people each year. It is also a place with a real sense of community and this is reflected in the theme of this year's commission.

"I look forward to seeing lots of exciting and original proposals."

The current installation by local artist Fiona Hawthorne `Aspects of Carnival' depicts the full story of Notting Hill Carnival from early preparations through to the Carnival processions and the big clean-up afterwards.

For the full brief and guidelines visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/portobelloroadartsproject
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is calling for artists to submit their ideas for this year's Portobello Road Wall Arts Project.
shorttitle: Artists called to be at the heart of North Kensington

headline: ASK NICK AT THE CHELSEA THEATRE
prcopy:
The Chelsea Theatre was packed to the rafters last Tuesday (11 February) for Ask Nick 3, the latest in a series of opportunities for residents to put questions to the Leader of the Council and other cabinet members about the most pressing local issues.

Over 130 people turned up to the venue in SW10. Amongst the many issues raised by the audience were street cleansing, basement development and the Royal Borough's housing market. But by far the biggest issue of the night was the future use of the Isaac Newton site in Lancaster Road in W11.

"These meetings are always interesting," said the Council Leader, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, "but not always cosy."

"We are making major decisions with big impacts on the lives of our residents so it is absolutely right that people have the chance to have their say and put questions to us and we are going to continue to make sure they can do just that."

More Ask Nick events will be announced in the near future. Look out for details at www.rbkc.gov.uk/asknick
shortdescription: The Chelsea Theatre was packed to the rafters last Tuesday (11 February) for Ask Nick 3, the latest in a series of opportunities for residents to put questions to the Leader of the Council and other cabinet members about the most pressing local issues.
shorttitle: Ask Nick at the Chelsea Theatre

headline: Fashion history is the latest buzz at Colville Primary School
prcopy:
Colville Primary School combined history with fashion to put on an amazing fashion show (13 Feb).

The show spanned the fashion statements made by prehistoric man right through to modern day styles.
Children even put on their interpretation of `Futuristic Fashions'.

Headteacher, Jagdeep Birdi said, "Preparing for the show created such excitement - from nursery right through to our Year 6. The hum of excitement was almost palpable".

Agape, from Year 3, said, "It was an amazing experience which really made learning about the Romans come to life".

Joyce Tackie, Colville's art teacher, who co-ordinated the event, said, "Our planning included the design of costumes as well as marketing the end product. I am delighted that so many staff and parents helped us with the preparations and that over 250 parents attended two shows".
shortdescription: Colville Primary School combined history with fashion to put on an amazing fashion show (13 Feb).
shorttitle: Fashion history is the latest buzz at Colville Primary School

headline: PLANNING FOR THE FUTURE OF DEMENTIA CARE SERVICES
prcopy:
Vital services for people with dementia are to be relocated to more flexible premises at St Charles Centre in North Kensington in order to meet demand and improve the range of services on offer.

Currently based at the Miranda Barry Centre in Ellesmere House, SW10, the current premises do not offer the flexibility required to meet the predicted increase in the number of people who will be living with dementia in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. This means action must be taken now to ensure residents have access to the most suitable services to enable them and their carers to remain healthy in the community, reduce hospital admissions and the need for costly long-term residential care.

Cabinet agreed last night (Monday 24 February) to enter into a lease agreement with Central North West London NHS Trust (CNWL) to provide dementia services from the ground floor of Chamberlain House at the St Charles Centre for Health and Wellbeing in North Kensington.

At present, day services for older people with dementia are delivered from the Miranda Barry Centre in Ellesmere House. It is acknowledged as a well-managed and popular centre offering a range of activities ranging from arts and crafts to movement sessions. However, its location and layout means what can be done in years to come will be restricted necessitating the need to look for a more suitable building which can accommodate a range of integrated health and social care services for people with dementia, their families and carers.

The way day services will be delivered in the future will need to change and move to a hub model. This will provide a range of centre-based and non-centre support including provision of information and advice, person-centred support planning, flexible transport throughout the day, flexible opening hours and a cafe-style approach to nutritious meals.

While it will not be possible for the Miranda Barry Centre to meet these requirements they can be met at Chamberlain House. The former day hospital is ideally suited to providing day services to older people and offers the space, layout, security and accessibility required of a specialist dementia resource centre. Furthermore, CNWL's Community Mental Health Team is based on the St Charles site, so it is anticipated that moving to this site will lead to improved links between statutory health and social care services.

Age UK Kensington & Chelsea has already expressed an interest in using the proposed dementia resource centre as an additional venue for its Memory Cafe sessions as well as carers' support groups and a range of stimulating activities. The centre would create a one-stop service enabling people with dementia and their carers to access sources of practical help and advice.

A full refurbishment of the ground floor of Chamberlain House is planned and it is anticipated that the new facilities would be ready to open in May 2014.

Councillor Mary Weale, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Adult Social Care and Public Health, said: "Dementia is a debilitating condition and unfortunately the number of people who will be affected by it in the borough in years to come is set to rise.

"This means we have to plan ahead to make sure we are offering the best day services we can and integrating this with the health service and the voluntary sector.

"The reality is that we will not be able to meet the challenges ahead of us from the Miranda Barry Centre, excellent though its services have been.

"What we will do however is to take the expertise we have built up and improve on it at Chamberlain House."
shortdescription: Vital services for people with dementia are to be relocated to more flexible premises at St Charles Centre in North Kensington in order to meet demand and improve the range of services on offer.
shorttitle: Planning for the future of dementia care services

headline: CELEBRATING GOLD
prcopy:
The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea recognised the efforts of local people to improve their community and neighbourhood last night (Wednesday 19 February) when he welcomed over 115 residents to the Community Engagement Reception in the Mayor's Parlour at Kensington Town Hall.

The highlight of the evening was the presentation of three Gold Standard Awards to tenants' and residents' associations that have shown the highest standards in representing their communities:

Whitchurch House Residents' Association represents 44 residents at Whitchurch and Blechynden House, with an average age between 55 and 95 years. It supports residents to arrange trips, tea parties and an annual Christmas party as well as publishing a regular newsletter.

Silchester Estate Residents' Association has worked to tackle issues such as overcrowding, isolation and antisocial behaviour. It also organises a very popular summer event on the estate which is eagerly anticipated and attended by more than 200 residents.

Nevern Square Conservation Area Residents' Association has run a series of events to foster a sense of community and belonging to help tackle problems such as social isolation. It has also conducted a wide survey to find out the views of people who lived within the Nevern Square Conservation Area including what they like and dislike about the area, views on policing, drugs, crime, traffic and local planning issues.

All three associations received a one-off grant of £500.

The evening provided an excellent opportunity to share good news stories and appreciation to those residents and community groups which have supported or benefited from the Council's City Living, Local Life (CLLL) initiative. The programme aims to encourage and help residents work with their local ward Councillors to develop practical projects on local issues or ideas.

The initiative, now in its second year, allocates up to £20,000 each year to each ward to support Councillors' work with a range of partners including residents, voluntary and community organisations and local businesses to make life better for residents.

Over 141 initiatives are working towards:

 improving employability and people's life chances
 tackling isolation amongst older people in the community
 improving the street scene and local environment
 increasing access to cultural opportunities and encouraging a sense of local identity
 promoting volunteering and community participation

Councillor Gerard Hargreaves, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement, said: "I am delighted that we were able to recognise the efforts of those resident and tenant associations that work so hard to make their community a better place to live in.

"We can see just what a difference this type of local initiative can have on the ground and that's why our City Living Local Life programme will continue to support community-based work at a ward level. It's also why I am so pleased that we have been able to maintain levels of Council funding to community and voluntary groups whose work makes this borough such a wonderful place to live.

"I would like to thank the Mayor for hosting this reception and I know his hospitality was greatly appreciated by all who attended."

Speaking about the evening, the Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, said: "My congratulations to tonight's Gold Standard Award winners. I know just what a difference well organised and supported residents' and tenants' associations can make to the quality of life in an area and we can learn a lot by working closely with them to nip problems in the bud or help them improve their local environment."

The Annual Report of 2013 provides a snapshot of the activity undertaken by Councillors at ward level. To read the report go to www.citylivinglocallife.org
shortdescription: The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea recognised the efforts of local people to improve their community and neighbourhood last night (Wednesday 19 February) when he welcomed over 115 residents to the Community Engagement Reception in the Mayor's Parlour at Kensington Town Hall.
shorttitle: Celebrating Gold

headline: INTRANSIT STREET ART FESTIVAL RETURNS
prcopy:
Art will be taking to the streets again this summer when Kensington and Chelsea's InTRANSIT festival returns bigger and better than ever before from 18 to 27 July.

The theme for this year's InTRANSIT is `How good it is to dwell in unity' which is the English translation of the motto of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

A full brief and call for submissions from artists will be published towards the end of February. Check www.rbkc.gov.uk/artsservice for more details.

Now in its eighth year, InTRANSIT explores and celebrates the physical spaces and architecture of the borough through art and performance.

This year the Council has commissioned design and production team O' Neill Ross to curate the festival. Their experience includes production and design of Secret Cinema (2010 to 2013) as well as site-specific projects with The London Contemporary Orchestra and Silent Opera.

Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, Transport and Arts, Councillor Timothy Coleridge said: "The InTRANSIT festival continues to go from strength to strength. This year we are pleased to announce the return of design and production team O'Neill Ross as guest curators of the festival. InTRANSIT offers unforgettable experiences - and plenty of fun too. The wide-ranging programme presents immersive performance, dance and street theatre giving residents and visitors alike the opportunity to discover the unfamiliar in familiar places across Kensington and Chelsea."

If you are an artist, producer or potential sponsor and would like to be involved in this year's InTRANSIT Festival, please contact the Arts Service, email arts@rbkc.gov.uk

Follow the Arts Service and InTRANSIT Festival latest news and opportunities on Twitter @RBKCculture and Facebook InTRANSIT Festival.
shortdescription: Art will be taking to the streets again this summer when Kensington and Chelsea's InTRANSIT festival returns bigger and better than ever before from 18 to 27 July.
shorttitle: InTRANSIT street festival returns

headline: ROLL UP FOR A £10 MARKET STALL
prcopy:
Aspiring entrepreneurs who want to market test an idea can do so on the world famous Portobello Market during `Love Your Local Market' fortnight which runs from 14 May to 28 May.

Some 300 market pitches are available in the borough's markets, Portobello Road, Golborne Road, and Portobello Green Vintage Market, to first-time traders. Stalls cost just £10 a day, with prizes awarded each week for the best new stall.

The theme this year is `youth in all its dimensions' and the hope is to attract new traders and customers and invigorate the markets with youthful energy.

The Street Trading Office is also seeking proposals from community groups, charities, schools and colleges wishing to organise youth-themed markets on Friday 16 and Friday 23 May.

Last year a similar event attracted scores of have-a-go traders who sold a range of products including: men's and women's fashion, homemade cosmetics, children's clothes, gourmet cookies and sauces and marinades.

Cllr Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member with responsibility for the markets, said: "We are very pleased to be able to give young people, and those young at heart, an opportunity to try their hand at trading on our markets which attract visitors from all over the world. What better place to have a stall and market test an idea? I hope that many people avail themselves of the opportunity to take a pitch."

For more information and to register your interest in a market stall email marketevents@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Aspiring entrepreneurs who want to market test an idea can do so on the world famous Portobello Market during `Love Your Local Market' fortnight which runs from 14 May to 28 May.
shorttitle: Roll up for a £10 market stall

headline: COUNCIL PAYS FOR 41 NEW POLICE OFFICERS
prcopy:
An extra 41 police officers will be on the streets of Kensington and Chelsea next year and they will be focussing solely on those issues of greatest concern to residents.

The Kensington and Chelsea Community Policing Team, as the unit will be known, is being formed thanks to an annual £1.4 million investment by the Council.

Comprising 36 constables, four sergeants and an inspector, it will be tasked by a joint police and Council management team led by a senior council officer.

As well as providing high visibility patrols and dealing with antisocial behaviour, licensing and crime prevention, it will also tackle longstanding resident concerns like graffiti, vice cards, begging, dog fouling, litter, and illegal street trading.

In previous years, the Royal Borough has supported the police with additional PCSOs and there are currently 58 paid for by the Council. As part of a wide ranging package of measures, the Metropolitan Police Service (MPS) has frozen PCSO recruitment. With PCSOs leaving the service through natural wastage or becoming constables, the number available across London and to Kensington and Chelsea has been declining.

At the same time the MPS has, for the first time, extended to Kensington and Chelsea a scheme enabling councils to buy police officers who have a more extensive range of powers than PCSOs.

The real cost of a police constable is £65,000 a year but the Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime (MOPAC) is currently offering a buy one get one free. In other words, it will cost £32,500 a year to acquire the services of a constable, which is roughly equivalent to the price of buying a PCSO.

With PCSO numbers in decline, the Council believes it can achieve a bigger impact on crime and fear of crime by reinvesting in police constables who have a much greater range of powers than PCSOs.

"Financially speaking these are difficult times, but, as a Conservative Council, we are committed to investing in security for our residents and, with this switch from PCSOs to PCs, achieving a higher return on our money," said Cllr Joanna Gardner, Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services. "The new team will be able to respond to some of those local issues which aren't usually a priority for police, but do concern our residents and affect their lives.

"These officers will operate as part of a Council tasked team on problems which are important to our residents and businesses alike. As they have a full range of powers, including arrest, they will be able to operate across a much broader range of policing challenges.

"All the evidence says that our investment in PCSOs has been a success, particularly when it comes to providing a visible policing presence, but PCSO numbers are going into decline and we now have an opportunity to reinvest in full police officers and a different way of working."

The first members of the New Kensington and Chelsea Community Policing Team will be on the streets of Kensington and Chelsea by late summer 2014.
shortdescription: An extra 41 police officers will be on the streets of Kensington and Chelsea next year and they will be focussing solely on those issues of greatest concern to residents.
shorttitle: Council pays for 41 new police officers

headline: AVONDALE PARK AND ST ANNE'S NURSERY: CONSULTATION ON PROPOSAL FOR JOINT GOVERNING BODY
prcopy:
A public consultation has begun on the proposal for the governing bodies of Avondale Park Primary School and St Anne's Nursery School to join together in a federation.

A federation is where two schools remain separate in law but are managed together by a single governing body and unified leadership team.

The existing boards of governors believe this step would be in the interest of both schools and the communities they serve.

Avondale Park and St Anne's Nursery School are rated respectively as good and outstanding by Ofsted.

The consultation begins on Tuesday 25 February and closes on Tuesday 25 March.

Teaching staff at both schools will have their own meetings and a public meeting will take place at the Isaac Newton Centre, 108 Lancaster Road, W11 between 4pm and 5.30pm on Tuesday 11 March.

Any new governing body would assume control of both schools at the start of autumn term.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "These are both excellent schools that serve their communities well. Both boards of governors believe strongly that the best way to maintain their high standards is to join together in a federation.

"It is important that local people can have their say and I would encourage as many people as possible to look at what is being proposed and to have their say."

The consultation document and response slip can be downloaded at:
www.avondalepark.rbkc.sch.uk
www.st-annes-school.org

You can also respond with your comments by writing or
emailing to these addresses:

headline: TAX FREEZE AND CASHBACK FOR KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA RESIDENTS
prcopy:
Royal Borough council taxpayers will have their council tax frozen for the fifth year in a row, following a Kensington and Chelsea Cabinet decision last night (Monday 24 February). And in addition they will receive a one-off £100 rebate, thanks to an overachieving efficiency drive.

Equivalent to a nine per cent reduction at band D (six per cent at band G), the efficiency dividend will cost about £7.5 million. *

It's been made possible thanks to the success of the Council's extensive cost reduction programme. From 2010 Kensington and Chelsea committed to a demanding programme of savings, more than matching a loss of grants to the Council from central Government as Ministers sought to reduce the public sector deficit.

The Royal Borough's challenge has been to plug that financial gap without damaging its high-quality services.** It has met that challenge by helping to pioneer the most radical service sharing arrangement in Britain.*** In addition it has been transforming the way it manages its valuable property estate and improving efficiency in many other ways.

So successful has that cost reduction programme been that it has exceeded its savings targets for 2013-14, thereby producing a surplus. But with austerity likely to be prolonged well beyond 2014, that one-off surplus can't be ploughed back into services on any sustainable basis. The Cabinet has therefore decided to hand the money back to its taxpayers as a one-off efficiency dividend.

"Although at times it has been painful and difficult," said Council Leader, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown, "we have done a good job of bringing down costs while protecting our high-quality services.

"As a result we now find ourselves with a little left in the tank. In deciding what to do with it, we think it is wrong to discount from our calculations those whose money this was in the first place.

"Services require annual recurrent spending. As this is a one-off surplus the right place for it is with our residents."

Thanks to the cashback and the continuing freeze in council tax - which began in 2010/11 - residents in bands E to H will be paying less council tax in 2014-15 than they were in 2001 when allowance is made for inflation. Residents in bands A to D will be paying less than in 2000.****

As well as setting the council tax and ordering the dividend, the Cabinet last night agreed full revenue and capital budgets for 2014-15. Both can be read online at www.rbkc.gov.uk

The savings and efficiencies described in the revenue budget will enable the Council to avoid any significant service reduction compared with 2013-14.

Despite the continuing financial pressures, strong reserves carefully built up over many years will allow the Council to continue to be ambitious for the Royal Borough. For example, work is well underway on the new £57.8 million academy and leisure centre for North Kensington, two thirds of which will be met directly from the Council's own coffers. A new Middle Row primary school and a new children's home at East Row are also under construction.

"We have so far managed to find our way through these difficult times while maintaining excellent local services," added Cllr Nick Paget-Brown.

"We are very proud of that and equally proud that we are still able to pursue our ambitions to regenerate our borough."
shortdescription: Royal Borough council taxpayers will have their council tax frozen for the fifth year in a row, following a Kensington and Chelsea Cabinet decision last night (Monday 24 February).  And in addition they will receive a one-off £100 rebate, thanks to an overachieving efficiency drive.
shorttitle: Tax freeze and cashback for Kensington and Chelsea residents

headline: GO-AHEAD GIVEN FOR KENSINGTON FREE SCHOOL PRIMARY ON WARWICK ROAD
prcopy:
The sponsor for the new Warwick Road academy will be the West London Free School Academy Trust after the Department for Education (DfE) gave the go-ahead for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to work with the education charity. The new school will be called the Kensington Free School Primary.

With rising numbers of children in the borough needing a primary school place, and a large residential development planned for the area, this decision is good news for parents.

When built, the new primary school will offer 30 reception places a year and have a total of 210 pupils aged from four to 11. In addition there will also be the provision for a part-time nursery. The school is expected to open in September 2016.

The West London Free School Secondary for girls and boys aged 11 to 18 in Hammersmith was co-founded by Toby Young and opened in 2011. It was the first free school to sign a funding agreement with the Secretary of State for Education, Michael Gove. This was followed by the opening of the Trust's second school, the West London Free School Primary, also in Hammersmith, in September 2013. Both schools are hugely oversubscribed and it is expected that the new Kensington Free School Primary will be very popular with parents.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "I am very pleased that the DfE has agreed that we can work with the West London Free School Academy Trust to deliver a brand new primary school on Warwick Road.

"We are very proud of our schools and strive for the highest standards. The West London Free School has a very strong academic ethos and is already a very popular school in Hammersmith and Fulham. I have no doubt the new school will do extremely well here in Kensington and Chelsea."

The developer Berkley Homes is building the new school to provide first-class facilities, which will also be made available to the local community. The designs for the new school are currently in the planning stages.
shortdescription: The sponsor for the new Warwick Road academy will be the West London Free School Academy Trust after the Department for Education (DfE) gave the go-ahead for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to work with the education charity. The new school will be called the Kensington Free School Primary.
shorttitle: Go-ahead given for Kensington Free School Primary on Warwick Road

headline: HISTORY IN THE MAKING AT COMMONWEALTH FLAG RAISING CEREMONY
prcopy:
The Royal Borough will join hundreds of other local authorities, civic dignitaries, community groups and charities in marking Commonwealth Day on Monday 10 March when it raises the Commonwealth flag at 9.30 am at Kensington Town Hall.

This will be the largest, single, raising of the Commonwealth flag in the history of the Commonwealth.

The Right Hon Sir Malcolm Rifkind, MP for Kensington, will join the Royal Borough's Mayor Cllr Charles Williams; councillors; and Lord Howell, Chairman of the Council of Commonwealth Societies, President of the Royal Commonwealth Society and the Commonwealth Youth Choir.

This ceremony will allow local residents and community organisations to join with others nationwide in a public expression of commitment to the Commonwealth and show their appreciation for its values.

A specially written Commonwealth Affirmation will be read at the ceremony.

Cllr Williams said: "I hope as many people as possible will come and take part in the Commonwealth flag raising ceremony and join with others in expressing our appreciation of the Commonwealth values and the opportunities it offers to help create inclusive and equitable societies."

Anyone wishing to take part in the ceremony should gather in the courtyard outside Central Library at Kensington Town Hall for 9.30am
shortdescription: The Royal Borough will join hundreds of other local authorities, civic dignitaries, community groups and charities in marking Commonwealth Day on Monday 10 March when it raises the Commonwealth flag at 9.30 am at Kensington Town Hall.
shorttitle: History in the making at Commonwealth flag raising ceremony

headline: ASBO SERVED ON ANTISOCIAL NEIGHBOUR
prcopy:
A woman who was convicted of harassment and public order offences at Hammersmith Magistrates Court in November 2013 has been issued with a post-conviction Antisocial Behaviour Order (ASBO) following action by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the Crown Prosecution Service. She was also sentenced to four months in prison suspended for 12 months and ordered to pay £6,750 costs to the Council.

The Court heard how Deidre Berry (59) had subjected her neighbours, a young married couple, to a tirade of abuse, insults and harassment since June 2013.

The ASBO, which was granted on Friday 28 February at Hammersmith Magistrates Court and lasts for five years, prohibits Berry of Iverna Gardens W8 from the following behaviour at her address:

Banging pots and pans or other objects inside or outside her property in such a manner so as to cause harassment, alarm or distress to residents of, or visitors to, any neighbouring properties within a 100-metre radius of her address and to include any pets of such neighbouring properties

Shouting, swearing, screaming or any other loud sound coming from inside or outside her property so as to cause harassment, alarm or distress to residents of, or visitors to, neighbouring properties within a 100-metre radius of her property and to include any pets of such neighbouring properties

Using threatening, intimidating, insulting or abusive words or behaviour inside or outside her property so as to cause harassment, alarm or distress to residents of or visitors to any neighbouring properties within a 100-metre radius of her property.

The order also prohibits her from:

Using threatening, intimidating, insulting or abusive words or behaviour when communicating with any emergency services. Such communication could be by email, telephone, personal attendance but not limited to these modes only and emergency services includes any police contact, fire service, hospital, doctors or any other service concerned safety

Impeding traffic - whether by any means including lying down or sitting or standing in any part of any road

Contacting directly or indirectly any neighbours or people who have been witnesses against her in any court proceedings

Making phone calls to 101 or 999 or any other police neighbourhood team or other police phone number or any other emergency service number whether speaking with anyone or just hanging up unless other than in a genuine emergency which would be confirmed by any emergency service attending.

In granting the order the court recognised that Deidre Berry had acted in an antisocial manner which caused, or was likely to cause, harassment, alarm or distress to one or more persons not of the same household as herself and there was an urgent need to protect the community from further antisocial acts and that immediate action was required to stop further antisocial behaviour.

The court heard that Ms Berry believed that her neighbours had harassed her and that the police and courts were against her.

A Council spokesman said: "We have worked with the Crown Prosecution Service to obtain this Antisocial Behaviour Order from the court because residents were experiencing real distress as a result of Deidre Berry's behaviour.

"We will not hesitate to take similar action against others who might damage the quality of life of their neighbours."
shortdescription: A woman who was convicted of harassment and public order offences at Hammersmith Magistrates Court in November 2013 has been issued with a post-conviction Antisocial Behaviour Order (ASBO) following action by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the Crown Prosecution Service.  She was also sentenced to four months in prison suspended for 12 months and ordered to pay £6,750 costs to the Council.
shorttitle: ASBO served on antisocial neighbour

headline: Operation Shelley
prcopy:
Operation Shelley 4, the fourth in a series of joint initiatives between the Royal Borough, police and local partners, was launched on Monday 3 March at Kensington Police Station.

The aim of Operation Shelley 4 is to target a number of different crimes and antisocial behaviour which affect local residents. Officers from the Council and police have joint plans to tackle human trafficking, noise and nuisance and environmental health breaches amongst others.

Following the launch, police and Council officers were out targeting prostitute cards in phone boxes resulting in the removal of over 2,000 cards and the arrest of one man.

Officers spotted a number of people dropping litter on the street and these people were asked to put their rubbish in the bin and advised about the issues of littering and the powers the police and Council have to impose penalties.

Cllr Joanna Gardner, Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services, said: "This, the fourth Operation Shelley, provides an invaluable platform for the police, Council and other partners to coordinate enforcement efforts so as to tackle crime and community safety issues of most concern to residents and businesses.

"I am delighted that the partnership's coordinated efforts are going from strength to strength as illustrated by the breadth of activities to tackle issues including drivers with no insurance and vehicles with no MOTs; aggressive begging and prostitute cards in phone boxes. Officers across the partnership will also be active in the community providing advice and guidance on cycling safety and how to avoid becoming a victim of crime."

During the rest of the week Operation Shelley will see further litter patrols, cycle safety advice, offering advice on controlling dogs, emission testing of cars and graffiti removal.
shortdescription: Operation Shelley 4, the fourth in a series of joint initiatives between the Royal Borough, police and local partners, was launched on Monday 3 March at Kensington Police Station.
shorttitle: Operation Shelley

headline: AWARD-WINNING CHILDREN'S AUTHOR HELPS ROYAL BOROUGH CELEBRATE WORLD BOOK DAY
prcopy:
Award-winning children's author, Sarwat Chadda read and talked to children at Kensington Central Library on Thursday 6 March as part of the Royal Borough's celebrations for World Book Day.

Sarwat is the author of the Ash Mistry series which entertains children across the world with its action-packed plots. He spoke about his books and the challenges of being an author. The highly entertaining day also saw children write their own short story about a superhero before taking to the stage to act out the character.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Libraries, said:

"We were very pleased to support World Book Day and to have an opportunity to spread the joy of reading to so many of our primary school children.

"It was a wonderful day and a great opportunity for our library service to showcase the wealth of resources they have on offer. Children left inspired to read, as well as join and use the Royal Borough's libraries."

Due to the popularity of the event the Council had to hold two sessions one in the morning and the other in the afternoon. Five primary schools sent over 300 children aged eight to 11.

Each child who came to the event received a free signed copy of the first book in the Ash Mistry series along with a library membership pack.
shortdescription: Award-winning children's author, Sarwat Chadda read and talked to children at Kensington Central Library on Thursday 6 March as part of the Royal Borough's celebrations for World Book Day.
shorttitle: Award-winning children's author helps Royal Borough celebrate World Book Day

headline: HELPING WOMEN REOFFENDERS BREAK THE CYCLE
prcopy:
Marking International Women's Day, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and City of Westminster councils are highlighting the work of a project helping reoffenders to break the cycle and build a new life.

Launched in January, ADVANCE Minerva is a service specifically for female short-sentenced prisoners and begins when women are in prison, supporting them through the gates and beyond. It aims to reduce reoffending by women by ten per cent over two years.

Councillor Joanna Gardner, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Community Safety, IT and Corporate Services, said: "International Women's Day is an ideal opportunity to highlight the issues of female reoffenders and what can be done to offer them support. The evidence is that ADVANCE Minerva is effective and therefore we will continue to offer help to women as they prepare to leave prison and re-enter society."

Westminster City Council Cabinet Member for Community Protection, Councillor Nickie Aiken, said: "ADVANCE Minerva sets out to reduce reoffending among women through support and advocacy, addressing women's complex needs. There is a focus on building basic life skills - helping women to become less dependent on benefits or criminal behaviour, relying instead on their skills and employment. In short, women are given both the opportunity and support to make positive changes in their lives."

Nationally, it has been recognised that short-sentenced prisoners are disproportionately likely to reoffend. They have a significant impact on local communities, committing offences that are highly visible to our residents, such as theft, motoring offences and burglary. The Royal Borough and Westminster have been working with other boroughs to design services to support and rehabilitate short-sentenced prisoners from prison into the community, funded with support by the Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime and the Tri-borough Public Health department.

Proportionately more women than men are sentenced to short prison sentences: 59 per cent of women offenders receive sentences of under six-months but even these sentences have far-reaching social and financial implications. Across the country, it is estimated that more than 17,240 children were separated from their mothers in 2010 by imprisonment.

The Government's `Transforming Rehabilitation' agenda will mean that management of offenders will be extended to short-sentenced prisoners. The Tri-borough councils are supportive of the Government's shift to provide targeted rehabilitation to a cohort that has long been overlooked and who have a reoffending rate of over 50 per cent. Transforming Rehabilitation will see Community Rehabilitation Companies manage short-sentenced prisoners, on a payment-by-results basis.
shortdescription: Marking International Women's Day, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and City of Westminster councils are highlighting the work of a project helping reoffenders to break the cycle and build a new life.
shorttitle: Helping women reoffenders break the cycle

headline: GARDENERS WEAVE LIVING WILLOW TO GROW BENCH
prcopy:
The Mayor of the Royal Borough, Cllr Charles Williams, lent a hand to the community gardeners on Saturday 8 March when he joined them in weaving living willow which will eventually grow into a garden bench. The willow fuses as it grows and will form a seat capable of taking the weight of adults.

Community gardeners Will Gould and Lisa Wilkinson were at the St Charles Health and Wellbeing Centre Open Day to provide advice and support to the residents who have plots in the centre's kitchen gardens and at other locations throughout the borough.

Open Age ran a herb smelling quiz during which a variety of herbs were hidden in cups that contestants had to identify by smell. Visitors and children also had an opportunity to plant herbs such as basil, parsley and thyme in containers and take them home to grow on their windowsills.

Since 2009 the Council has been working with partners to turn unused areas into community kitchen gardens for residents to use. To date there have been 42 kitchen gardens created. They stretch from the north of the borough at the St Charles Centre to Cremorne Gardens in the south and approximately 1,000 residents have got involved and now grow a selection of herbs and vegetables to augment their shop bought produce.

To find out more information about the community kitchen gardens email environment@rbkc.gov.uk
