The willow fuses as it grows and will form a seat capable of taking the weight of adults.
shorttitle: Gardeners weave living willow to grow bench

headline: MARKING COMMONWEALTH DAY
prcopy:
Children from the Commonwealth Choir joined Kensington MP, the Rt. Hon. Sir Malcolm Rifkind and the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams at Kensington Town Hall on Monday 10 March for a special ceremony to raise the Commonwealth flag and mark Commonwealth Day.

To the strains of the Commonwealth Anthem, the flag was raised by troopers from the Household Cavalry Mounted Regiment. They were watched by a large audience which included The Rt. Hon. the Lord Howell of Guildford, P.C., - Chairman, Council of Commonwealth Societies and President of the Royal Commonwealth Society, Councillor Victoria Borwick - Deputy Mayor of London and Carl Wright - Secretary-General of the Commonwealth Local Government Forum.
The Rt. Hon. Sir Malcolm Rifkind read the Commonwealth Affirmation to mark the occasion. As well as being the Member of Parliament for Kensington, Sir Malcolm is a former Foreign Secretary and member of the Commonwealth Eminent Persons' Group.

A message from The Queen was read by Lady (Elizabeth) Arnold, D.L., Representative Deputy Lieutenant for Kensington and Chelsea.

Speaking after the ceremony The Mayor said: "The Commonwealth is an unique family of nations. I am delighted that we could show the value we place on our links within the Commonwealth by joining with other local authorities and community organisations throughout the country to raise the Commonwealth Flag and mark this day."
shortdescription: Children from the Commonwealth Choir joined Kensington MP, the Rt. Hon. Sir Malcolm Rifkind and the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Charles Williams at Kensington Town Hall on Monday 10 March for a special ceremony to raise the Commonwealth flag and mark Commonwealth Day.
shorttitle: Marking Commonwealth Day

headline: NEW-LOOK NORLAND ROAD
prcopy:
Following an extensive facelift, a now traffic-free and smarter space in North Kensington is set to be formally opened on Saturday 29 March by the Mayors of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham.

As an important pedestrian route to nearby Westfield shopping centre, bus, Tube and rail stops, Norland Road is now more appealing, brighter and safer for pedestrians following the introduction of new street lighting, new high-quality stone paving and additional trees.

The refurbishment, funded by the Royal Borough and Transport for London, follows complaints about vehicle noise and damage to the paved area which was not built to take traffic.

The event is free, open to all and runs from 10am to 1pm.

Along with a host of other activities, residents can get tips from local community gardeners; give their bike a health check courtesy of experts from Dr Bike and learn about road safety via a special crash simulator.

There's no need to book - just turn up and get involved.
shortdescription: Following an extensive facelift, a now traffic-free and smarter space in North Kensington is set to be formally opened on Saturday 29 March by the Mayors of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham.
shorttitle: New-look Norland Road

headline: ADVERTISING FIRM PLEADS GUILTY TO UNAUTHORISED TELEPHONE KIOSK ADVERTISING
prcopy:
Arqiva Wifi Ltd pleaded guilty on Tuesday 11 March at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court to displaying unauthorised advertising on the side of a telephone kiosk in the heart of Chelsea and were ordered to pay fines and costs totalling £1,507.

In October 2012 the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea sent letters to Arqiva Wifi Ltd, along with other companies who own telephone kiosks in the borough, warning them that the Council's consent must be obtained before advertising in a Conservation Area.

Despite reminders in September and October 2013 Planning Enforcement Officers noticed that Arqiva Wifi Ltd continued to display advertisements from the National Theatre and Natural History Museum on a kiosk in Sloane Square.

Arqiva Wifi Ltd were prosecuted by the Royal Borough under section 224 (3) of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 and pleaded guilty to five separate offences and fined £1,000, ordered to pay a victims surcharge of £20 and full costs totalling £487.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning, said:

"Protecting the integrity of our Conservation Areas is something that the Royal Borough takes very seriously.

"Advertising companies need to realise that our Planning Enforcement Officers are vigilant and will check whether advertisements comply with the law and if warnings are ignored the Council will prosecute."

In mitigation Arqiva Wifi Ltd blamed Clear Channel in their explanation to the court.
keyword3: Royal borough of kensington and chelsea
shortdescription: Arqiva Wifi Ltd pleaded guilty on Tuesday 11 March at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court to displaying unauthorised advertising on the side of a telephone kiosk in the heart of Chelsea and were ordered to pay fines and costs totalling £1,507.
shorttitle: Advertising firm pleads guilty to unauthorised telephone kiosk advertising

headline: SIR MERRICK'S CONTRIBUTION TO LOCAL GOVERNMENT RECOGNISED
prcopy:
Sir Merrick Cockell has won the Judges' Special Award for Contribution to Local Government in the 2014 LGiU* and CCLA* Achievement Awards.

Leader of the Royal Borough for 13 years, from 2000 to 2013, Sir Merrick was also leader of London Councils from 2006 to 2010 and since 2011 has represented the whole of local government as the Chairman of the Local Government Association.

As Leader, Sir Merrick personally led the long campaign for a new secondary school in Chelsea that, in 2010, delivered the Chelsea Academy which won the Public Building of the Year Award 2011 and is rated as "outstanding" by Ofsted.

He was also closely involved in the project to rebuild Holland Park School which, from the outset, was built to match the very best in the country.

Amongst a number of other public realm projects, Sir Merrick led the team responsible for the multi-award winning Exhibition Road streetscape scheme.

In more recent years he helped to design the Royal Borough's response to the financial crisis and the consequent dramatic falls in Government funding. A key element of that response is the influential `Tri-borough initiative', a radical back office and service sharing arrangement with Westminster and Hammersmith & Fulham that will yield at least £10 million worth of savings to the Council by 2015.

*(Local Government information Unit and Churches Charities and Local Authorities)
shortdescription: Sir Merrick Cockell has won the Judges' Special Award for Contribution to Local Government in the 2014 LGiU* and CCLA* Achievement Awards.
shorttitle: Sir Merrick's contribution to local government recognised

headline: WORK TO BEGIN ON SEWER IN NORTH KENSINGTON
prcopy:
Work to increase the depth of a sewer in North Kensington to enable surface tracks for Crossrail to be laid begins on Wednesday 19 March.

The surface tracks for Crossrail at Westbourne Park will be laid above the Green Lane Sewer, which runs parallel and to the west of the Great Western Road. The existing sewer is in a shallow position and occupies space needed for the new tracks along the Great Western main line.

This means the sewer must be replaced with a deeper one between Great Western Road and Tavistock Road, passing beneath the Great Western main line and Hammersmith & City line, and then west under Tavistock Road to Basing Street.

This will involve two of the three work sites in Tavistock Road (Basing Street and St Luke's Road) having excavations for utility diversion works. A short while later work at the site at The Metropolitan pub will also commence. Immediately after utility diversions have been completed work will start on the main shafts to be used for the sewer construction.

For more information contact the Crossrail helpdesk on 0345 602 3813.
shortdescription: Work to increase the depth of a sewer in North Kensington to enable surface tracks for Crossrail to be laid begins on Wednesday 19 March.
shorttitle: Work to begin on sewer in North Kensington

headline: GET HOME SAFELY: IF YOU CAN'T WALK STRAIGHT, THINK STRAIGHT
prcopy:
Get Home Safely is the message to clubbers and late night revellers in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea

A campaign to promote road safety has been launched after statistics for killed and seriously injured (KSI*) pedestrians showed a higher number of night-time casualties occurred in the borough than other central London authorities.

Called Get Home Safely, it is in response to figures from 2010 to 2013 that show that over a quarter of pedestrian KSI* casualties occur between 11pm and 3am, the majority of these are on Friday or Saturday nights. A high number of the casualties were impaired by alcohol and over half were aged between 20 and 29 years.

The slogans `If you can't walk straight, think straight!', `Don't become an easy target' are used with the strapline `Get a bus, Get a cab, Get home safely' on images that mimic the design of road traffic signs.

One aimed at motorists warns: 'mind you don't knock them down when they've knocked a few back', 'watch out for pedestrians on the road between 11pm and 3am'.

Councillor Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Transport said: "we want people to come and enjoy the multitude of excellent night time attractions in the Royal Borough but we ask that they take extra care on their journey home. We are also asking people driving through the borough late at night to be alert for pedestrians even if the roads are otherwise quiet."

The hard-hitting campaign will be featured on back of buses and at Tube stations that are most commonly used by people on a night out.

To launch the campaign the Council is offering people the opportunity to show their support by wearing a Get Home Safely t-shirt. The first 50 people to tweet `#roadhug' to @rbkc will win a Get Home Safely t-shirt. All entrants will also have the chance to win one of three Tastecard annual memberships, A tastecard membership gives 50 per cent off the total food bill, or 2 meals for the price of 1 at participating restaurants.
keyword2: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: Get Home Safely is the message to clubbers and late night revellers in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shorttitle: Get Home Safely - if you can't walk straight, think straight

headline: FIRST WORLD WAR NOVEL CHOSEN FOR THIS YEAR'S CITYREAD LONDON
prcopy:
The title for this year's Cityread London is the bestselling and critically acclaimed First World War novel 'My Dear, I Wanted to Tell You' by Louisa Young, selected to mark the centenary of the outbreak of war through literature.

Cityread London is a month-long celebration of literature with related events, workshops and screenings across the Capital. This initiative is designed to promote reading for pleasure, engage new library users and encourage people to explore and celebrate their city's history. Cityread London chooses a book and invites the whole Capital to get reading.

This year will also see, for the first time, a children's book celebrated with a programme of activities around Michael Morpurgo's bestseller Private Peaceful.

Events will be held throughout April in the Royal Borough's libraries and as well as opportunities to borrow 'My Dear, I Wanted to Tell You' and 'Private Peaceful', there will be events for children, families, young people and adults.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Libraries, said:

"We are proud to be supporting Cityread London for the third year in a row and this year's title is very apt as we mark the centenary of the First World War.

"I'd like to urge residents to come and check out the fantastic range of events on offer in our libraries."

Highlights include creative writing workshops, craft sessions and storytelling events. For more information visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/cityread or drop into your local library.

headline: THE CYCLISTS ARE COMING
prcopy:
Residents and businesses are being warned to expect severe traffic and public transport disruption on Sunday 10 August following the announcement by Prudential RideLondon of the route for two major cycling events - the RideLondon-Surrey 100 and the RideLondon-Surrey Classic.

Developed by the Mayor of London and his agencies, Prudential RideLondon is a world-class festival of cycling taking place over the weekend of Saturday 9 and Sunday 10 August 2014.

Both events on Sunday 10 August will follow a 100-mile route which starts in east London and heads out to Surrey before returning for an exciting finish on The Mall.

The RideLondon-Surrey 100 event will attract some 24,000 amateur riders, many of whom will be raising money for good causes. The Classic is a race for 150 professional riders.

The route enters the borough in Knightsbridge and travels along the route of the A4 before entering Hammersmith and Fulham. Cyclists will then come back into the borough via King's Road, Ashburnham Road, Cremorne Road, Cheyne Walk and Chelsea Embankment before an exciting finish on The Mall.

Closing 100 miles of roads and bridges inevitably has a major impact on traffic, public transport and parking. It is not just the roads that the cyclists ride along that will be affected. Many other local roads will be closed to traffic from the early hours of Sunday 10 August to allow the event to pass safely through the borough.

TfL and Prudential RideLondon will be publicising more details of the route, road closures, impact on public transport and where to get further information on their websites. A map of the route is available at www.prudentialridelondon.co.uk

Councillor Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Transport, said: "Our experience from last year's event suggests that major disruption is inevitable. There will be local parking restrictions and road closures.

"I do urge residents and businesses to get this date into their diary to make sure they are not caught out when the cyclists arrive on Sunday 10 August.

"Of course both the amateur event, which will raise an enormous amount of money for good causes, and the professional race, will be exciting spectacles. However, you simply cannot have an event of this scale without it having an enormous impact on our roads.

"The best way to minimise inconvenience and disruption to your plans is to be aware of the date and plan ahead."

More information about Prudential RideLondon and details of the final route can be found on the organiser's website www.prudentialridelondon.co.uk
shortdescription: Residents and businesses are being warned to expect severe traffic and public transport disruption on Sunday 10 August following the announcement by Prudential RideLondon of the route for two major cycling events - the RideLondon-Surrey 100 and the RideLondon-Surrey Classic.
shorttitle: The cyclists are coming

headline: COMMANDER WELCOMES CADETS
prcopy:
Top brass from the Metropolitan Police and the Royal Borough marked the launch of Kensington and Chelsea's first branch of the Junior Volunteer Police Cadets (JVPC), at a recent event held at St Charles Primary School.

Aimed at ten to 13-year-olds, the JVPC offers children the chance to develop their leadership and problem solving skills and to learn to work as a team. As well as having a great deal of fun with games and outdoor activities, the cadets will learn first aid, personal safety and good citizenship.

Thanks to support from St Charles Primary School, local demand for the cadet programme has been strong, with more than 30 youngsters signing up.

"The Junior Cadets is a lot of fun," said Commander Simon Bray of the Metropolitan Police, "but we also want to get young people looking out for themselves and for each other.

"Longer term it would be lovely if we could also get some of the juniors to eventually sign up for the senior cadets and to start thinking about a career in the police."

Guests at the launch saw the cadets performing drill exercises and reciting the phonetic alphabet and police caution.

To find out more about the Junior Volunteer Police Cadets, contact PC Jayne Richardson by email at Jayne.S.Richardson-Griffith@met.pnn.police.uk

"I was extremely pleased with the level of interest by the pupils at St Charles," said Jayne. "Thanks to the support we have had from St Charles and from parents, we are running two cadets units on a Monday and Tuesday after school."
shortdescription: Top brass from the Metropolitan Police and the Royal Borough marked the launch of Kensington and Chelsea's first branch of the Junior Volunteer Police Cadets (JVPC), at a recent event held at St Charles Primary School.
shorttitle: Commander welcomes cadets

headline: MAYOR COLLECTS SUPPORT FOR TRINITY HOSPICE
prcopy:
The Royal Borough's Mayor, Cllr Charles Williams was out on the streets of Kensington and Chelsea on Saturday 22 March to raise funds for Trinity Hospice and promote the charity's work. Volunteers joined Cllr Williams at collection points on Kensington High Street and King's Road.

Cllr Williams said: "Trinity Hospice has been caring for the people of Kensington and Chelsea and central and south-west London for over 120 years. At a very emotional and critical time in a person's life Trinity Hospice is there to provide care, support and friendship, either at the hospice in Clapham or in their own home. All the care is given entirely free of charge."

Trinity Hospice provides specialist care for adults who have life-limiting illnesses. Each year it provides assistance to over 2,000 people, 340 of whom are Royal Borough residents and of these 240 are cared for in their own homes.

Last year Trinity staff made over 1,100 individual visits to patients in Kensington and Chelsea, this included 975 nurse visits, as well as visits from the Patient and Family Support Team, doctors, physiotherapists and occupational therapists.

The charity relies on support from the local community to generate the majority of its funding.

If you would like to contribute to the Mayor's charity email mayor@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: The Royal Borough's Mayor, Cllr Charles Williams, will be out on the streets of Kensington and Chelsea tomorrow Saturday 22 March to raise funds for Trinity Hospice and promote the charity's work.  Volunteers will join Cllr Williams at collection points on Kensington High Street and King's Road.
shorttitle: Mayor collects support for Trinity Hospice

headline: EXTENDED HOURS FOR NOISE AND NUISANCE SERVICE
prcopy:
From Tuesday 1 April 2014 the teams dedicated to dealing with noise and nuisance complaints in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham Council will be merging to form one bi-borough service.

As a result of this residents in Kensington and Chelsea will now be able to contact officers up until 3am from Monday to Wednesday and 5am from Thursday to Sunday. There will also be more officers on duty in the borough at weekends.

Councillor Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "Noisy parties or inconsiderate neighbours can cause real annoyance and distress so I am very pleased that we have been able to extend the time the noise and nuisance service can be contacted and to have more staff available on the weekends at no additional cost to residents."

If you need to contact the Royal Borough's Noise and Nuisance service please call 020 7361 3002.
shortdescription: From Tuesday 1 April 2014 the teams dedicated to dealing with noise and nuisance complaints in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Hammersmith & Fulham Council will be merging to form one bi-borough service.
shorttitle: Extended hours for Noise and Nuisance service

headline: GIFT BOX RAISES AWARENESS OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING IN THE CAPITAL
prcopy:
From Tuesday 1 April to Thursday 3 April a walk-in GIFT box will be placed in the forecourt of Kensington Town Hall to help raise awareness of human trafficking in the Capital.

The GIFT box is a unique project launched by STOP THE TRAFFIK and the United Nations Global Initiative at the London 2012 Olympics. It is an innovative way of highlighting the fact that many trafficked victims are often persuaded to leave their homes and families under the pretence of a better life. It is only when they arrive at their destination that the true horror of what awaits them becomes apparent.

Members of the public are invited to walk into the GIFT box and read first-hand accounts from victims as part of the European Communities Against Trafficking (ECAT) Project. Launched in 2013 by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, ECAT is a two-year European Commission funded programme to identify and support victims of trafficking in this borough and Westminster.

The GIFT box will be staffed by volunteers from STOP THE TRAFFIK and professionals working on the ECAT project who will be on hand to answer questions and concerns about trafficking and hand out leaflets about the project.

Residents will also have the opportunity to safely disclose any concerns about trafficking - almost 70 reports were made during the Olympics initiative. These would be fed directly into the victim support and enforcement arm of the project and acted on, where possible.

For more information visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/ecat or www.stopthetraffik.org
shortdescription: From Tuesday 1 April to Thursday 3 April a walk-in GIFT box will be placed in the forecourt of Kensington Town Hall to help raise awareness of human trafficking in the Capital.
shorttitle: GIFT box raises awareness of human trafficking in the Capital

headline: FREE FITNESS CLASSES IF YOU BRING A BUDDY
prcopy:
Are you interested in getting fit but daunted at the prospect of going to a class or activity on your own? Well, help is at hand thanks to `Bring a buddy week' which runs from Monday 7 April to Friday 11 April.

The Royal Borough's Sports Development Team is inviting residents to take part in a range of activities, including health walks, gym works, dancing and keep fit sessions, for one week only. All activities are free but you must bring a friend to join in.

headline: GRENFELL TOWER REFURBISHMENT CONTRACT AGREED
prcopy:
A major milestone in the £10m refurbishment of the Royal Borough's Grenfell Tower in North Kensington has been reached with the appointment of the construction company Rydon to carry out the work.

Funded by the Royal Borough as part of the wider £57m regeneration of the area which will see it transformed by 2016, the contract has been awarded by Kensington & Chelsea TMO (KCTMO), which manages the block on behalf of the Council.

The large scale works will include an upgrade of the cladding to the exterior of the building, new windows and a totally new heating system. All of this will greatly enhance the energy efficiency of the tower.

Seven much needed new homes will also be created from unused spaces. In addition there will be new facilities for the nursery and the Dale Boxing Club.

Rydon was appointed under strict OJEU (Official Journal of the European Journal) guidelines. KCTMO required a contractor that could demonstrate outstanding resident engagement in similar tower block refurbishments.

Fay Edwards, Chair of KCTMO, which manages the tower on behalf of the borough, said: "I'm delighted that we have been successful in appointing Rydon. I sat on the tender panel and was involved in the interview process. Residents of the tower have long had to put up with a sub-standard heating system and poor insulation and this has affected the quality of their lives. The new heating system will mean they can adjust the heating to their own needs for the first time."
shortdescription: A major milestone in the £10m refurbishment of the Royal Borough's Grenfell Tower in North Kensington has been reached with the appointment of the construction company Rydon to carry out the work.
shorttitle: Grenfell Tower refurbishment contract agreed

headline: Best Bar None gears up for 2014
prcopy:
Bars, pubs and clubs in Kensington and Chelsea have another chance to join the prestigious Best Bar None (BBN) scheme which is entering its seventh year in the Royal Borough. The scheme recognises licensees who demonstrate excellent management standards.

BBN encourages bar owners and managers to ensure their pubs and clubs are crime-free and that their customers do not disturb their neighbours. In 2013 Janet's Bar, a long standing bar situated on Old Brompton Road, South Kensington, was the overall winner; it has been a member of the Best Bar None scheme since it began.

The scheme currently has 53 pubs, bars and clubs across the borough; it continues to be one of the largest schemes in the country and is supported by Diageo Great Britain and the Royal Garden Hotel with support from various partner agencies.

Landlords and managers of all the borough's pubs, bars and clubs will be able to submit applications for this year's membership between 7 April and 7 June, with the awards presentation in November 2014.

To get an application form and for more information go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/bestbarnone or email bestbarnone@rbkc.gov.uk

shorttitle: Best Bar None gears up for 2014

headline: HOSTEL FINED £39,000 FOR BREACH OF ASBESTOS REGULATIONS
prcopy:
A company that failed to comply with health and safety regulations regarding the removal of asbestos from a hostel it owned in Queensbury Place, SW7, was fined £39,000 (Monday 7 April) at Isleworth Crown Court and ordered to pay the Council's costs of £12,299.75 and a victim surcharge of £120.

The company, Drewhaven Limited, had pleaded guilty at an earlier hearing to one charge under Regulation 4 of Control of Asbestos Regulations 2006 and one charge under Section 2 (1) of the Health and Safety at Work Act 1974 etc. and a further charge under Section 3 (1) of the same Act.

The Court heard that the hostel was visited in 2010 by an Environmental Health Officer (EHO) from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea who judged it to be in poor condition with no health and safety systems in place and lacking an asbestos survey.

A list of works and an enforcement notice was issued to the owners which included the instruction to commission an asbestos survey of the property. A survey was carried out which identified materials which contained asbestos and gave some guidance on how to manage them safely.

The hostel was inspected again, 18 months later, in the run-up to the 2012 Olympic Games in an attempt to ensure low-performing hotels were meeting health and safety standards. The inspecting EHO asked about the asbestos containing materials and was told that they had been removed. When he requested to see the paperwork he was told that there was none available.

A subsequent inspection revealed that fireplace panels, which had contained asbestos, had been removed by an unlicensed contractor without the proper controls to ensure the safety of the contractor, guests and employees put in place.

Officers from the Council's Environmental Health department found evidence of asbestos containing debris and dust in six rooms. Immediate notices were served on the owners prohibiting the use of the rooms until they could be decontaminated by a licensed contractor. This was acted upon by Drewhaven Limited and once the work was completed permission was given for the rooms to be used again.

An investigation was then launched by the Council to determine who was responsible for the breaches of the regulations.

The court heard that Drewhaven Ltd had attended interviews at the Council's Environmental Health department voluntarily and had pleaded guilty at the earliest opportunity. However, Judge Zoe Smith pointed out that there had been a high degree of negligence which meant guests were put at significant risk for eight weeks.



End
shortdescription: A company that failed to comply with health and safety regulations regarding the removal of asbestos from a hostel it owned in Queensbury Place, SW7, was fined  £39,000 (Monday 7 April) at Isleworth Crown Court and ordered to pay the Council's costs of £12,299.75 and a victim surcharge of £120.
shorttitle: Hostel fined £39,000 for breach of asbestos regulations

headline: RUBBISH COLLECTIONS OVER EASTER BANK HOLIDAY
prcopy:

headline: FRAUDSTER SENT TO PRISON
prcopy:
A woman who falsely claimed more than £26,000 in housing and council tax benefits from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was sentenced to six months in prison at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Friday 11 April 2014.

Miss Taibo Djalo-Seidi, 33, of Cambridge Gardens W10, made a claim for benefits from May 2010 to June 2013 on the basis that she was engaged in part-time work. However, following a National Fraud Initiative referral, Council investigation officers established that she had failed to declare that she was employed in a nursery by the London Borough of Camden on a full-time basis since 2007; making her claim false from the outset.

Miss Djalo-Seidi pleaded guilty to four charges of benefit fraud under s111A of the Social Security Administration Act 1992 and three counts of benefit fraud under s3 of the Fraud Act 2066. In mitigation she stated that the extra money had been sent to her sick family in Africa. She was sentenced to six months in prison for each charge, to run concurrently and after three months she will be released on licence for the remaining three months of her sentence. A custodial sentence was given as a result of her receiving a caution for the same type of offence two years earlier.

In sentencing Djalo-Seidi the bench stated: "We have looked at these offences .... and have decided that they are so serious only custody is appropriate. Had you not cooperated it would have been nine months in total......our reasons are that you had a caution for a similar offence and two years later you systematically and fraudulently claimed for benefits. There was premeditation and planning and we feel you have abused a system to support people in genuine need."

From May 2010 to June 2013 Taibo Djalo-Seidi was overpaid housing benefit of £26,152.52 and council tax benefit of £205.69.
shortdescription: A woman who falsely claimed more than £26,000 in housing and council tax benefits from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was sentenced to six months in prison at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Friday 11 April 2014.
shorttitle: Fraudster sent to prison

headline: FIGHTING SCAMS
prcopy:
As part of Scams Awareness Month, during May the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council is warning residents to be vigilant and avoid becoming a victim of crime.

Fraud offences in England and Wales rose by 25 per cent in 2013, compared to the previous year, with 207,252 cases reported to Action Fraud. But nationally the Citizens Advice Bureau has calculated up to four million people could be scammed each year as many scams go unreported.

People are just as likely to be conned over the phone and via text messages as they are through emails and websites. New analysis reveals:
 over a third of scams (34 per cent) were over the phone
 almost a quarter of scams (24 per cent) were through visits to a website
 16 per cent were letter or fax scams
 one in ten scams (ten per cent) is via emails

The Royal Borough's Trading Standards team is also warning people to watch out for unsecure websites that ask for financial details, as well as realising that scammers use the phone and email to carry out fraud, and can turn up on your doorstep.

Top tips for dealing with scams
1. If it sounds too good to be true it probably is.
2. Never give out your bank details or send money unless you are certain you can trust the person contacting you.
3. Contacted out of the blue? Be suspicious.
4. Your bank and the police will never collect your bank card, ask for your PIN or come to your home.
5. Make sure the website's secure, if you are buying online - check for the padlock or 'https' next to the web address
6. It you haven't bought a ticket, you can't win it.
7. You shouldn't have to pay anything to get a prize.
8. Pressure to make a decision straight away? Take your time and just say: "No thank you".
9. Walk away from job ads that ask for money in advance.
10. Computer firms do not make unsolicited phone calls to help you fix your computer.
11. Don't suffer in silence - tell others about scams.

What to do if you have been scammed

 Report it to Action Fraud on 0300 1232040 to help stop it happening to others
 Get advice and report scams to Trading Standards through the Citizens Advice consumer service on 08454 040506 or online advice at http://www.adviceguide.org.uk/
shortdescription: As part of Scams Awareness Month, during May the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea Council is warning residents to be vigilant and avoid becoming a victim of crime.
shorttitle: Fighting scams

headline: DON'T BE A VICTIM OF PHONE SCAMS OR HARD SELLING
prcopy:
Local trading standards officers are urging residents not to be pressurised into buying goods or services as a result unsolicited phone calls. Figures from the Citizens Advice Bureau show that 34 per cent of recorded scams take place over the phone.

If you receive an unexpected phone call, don't be pressurised into agreeing to purchase anything there and then. Tell the caller you are not interested and take the time to do some research and speak to friends and family before making a decision.

This is just what a Royal Borough resident did recently when called by a company using scare tactics. The company told her that police in the area no longer have to attend calls regarding burglaries, this is untrue, police will continue to respond to any calls of criminal activity. They encouraged her to arrange an appointment at her home with a representative from the company to see a demonstration of how the company's `direct police call system' works. On this occasion the resident did the right thing and took the caller's name and details and reported it to the Council; Trading Standards officers are now looking into the matter

Often, the aim of these telephone calls is to gain access to your home, and use hard sell tactics to encourage you to buy unwanted goods or services.

Remember you can say no, and if you do agree to anything over the telephone or at home then you have cancellation rights if you change your mind.

For further advice about your rights, or to report hard sell or scare tactics contact Citizens Advice Consumer Service on 08454 040506 or visit www.adviceguide.org.uk

May is Scams Awareness Month, visit www.citizensadvice.org.uk/sam14 to check how scam aware you are. All scams can also be reported to Action Fraud on 0300 1232040 and at www.actionfraud.police.uk
shortdescription: Local trading standards officers are urging residents not to be pressurised into buying goods or services as a result unsolicited phone calls. Figures from the Citizens Advice Bureau show that 34 per cent of recorded scams take place over the phone.
shorttitle: Don't be a victim of phone scams or hard selling

headline: CHILDREN URGED TO TAKE SUMMER READING CHALLENGE
prcopy:
The summer break from school is a great chance to settle down with a good book. Children can experience this by joining in with the Summer Reading Challenge at their local library.

The Summer Reading Challenge will take place in July and August. It is the biggest national reading initiative and is run by nearly every public library in the UK. The challenge is for children aged four to 11 and is simple: read six or more library books over the summer.

Taking part in the Summer Reading Challenge helps prevent the `summer reading dip' - when children without reading opportunities at home over the long summer break from school can lose confidence in their reading.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education and Libraries, said: "The importance of encouraging children and young people to read cannot be underestimated. Our libraries do a wonderful job to support the reading habit and the Summer Reading Challenge is just another example of this.

"I hope as many of our younger readers come into their library and sign up for a summer of reading."

If you would like your child to take part in the Summer Reading Challenge please ask a member of staff in your local Kensington and Chelsea library.

Taking part will be scores of young people from the police cadets, sea cadets and the army cadet force.

Families will be warmly welcomed to come along and experience for themselves the thrills and spills of cadet life.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea will be on hand to award medals and trophies to the survivors!

But YOU Day won't all be about the uniformed services; there will be also be lots of other volunteering opportunities thanks to the presence of Team London and Kensington and Chelsea's Volunteer Centre.

Lady Elizabeth Arnold, the Representative Deputy Lieutenant for the Royal Borough and Chair of the YOU committee said: "We all want to see our young people having fun, getting fit, making friends and learning new skills. There are few better ways of ticking all those boxes than signing up for a cadet force.

"So I'm hoping YOU 2014 will attract new cadets and also more of the wonderful volunteers who make cadet life possible."

The day begins at 10.30am and runs to 3.30pm, on the Sports Field in Holland Park. For more information please contact the Council Community Engagement Team on 020 7598 4633 or email Communityengagement@rbkc.gov.uk

headline: COUNCILLORS' FUNDING HELPS TURN THE TABLES
prcopy:
Worn out and wobbly tables in a popular social club at the foot of Treverton Tower have been given a new lease of life by Goldfinger Factory, a local company which specialises in renovating unwanted furniture, thanks to financial support from local ward Councillors.

The club room is used for twice weekly bingo sessions for elderly people from the estate, the Dalgarno ward Councillors' surgeries and children's parties. Over time its tables have become worn and rickety, making them unsuitable to use.

Peter Doyle, Chairman of the Balfour of Burleigh Residents Association, said: "The tables in the clubroom had become wobbly after years of use and did not feel safe. Goldfinger said they could keep the table tops and replace the legs with safer and stronger ones.

"The safer tables mean the clubroom can be used for more community functions.

"Goldfinger is a local company that we were keen to work alongside, and for them to offer their expertise for this community resource. We hope that local residents might also wish to get involved in future projects and learn worthwhile skills in upcycling."

Through City Living, Local Life, the Dalgarno ward Councillors funded this project to ensure the club room could continue to be used by the local community. Councillor Pat Healy said: "This was not just a case of repairing some tables in a popular community facility. It was an opportunity to use the particular skills of Goldfinger Factory, a local organisation, to make sure the club room's tables were up to the job for many years to come."

Oliver Waddington-Ball, of Goldfinger Factory, said: "A crucial part of Goldfinger Factory's ethos is to serve, support and work alongside the local community. Through City Living, Local Life, we have been given an opportunity to offer our expertise to a small, but significant project, and look forward to future community collaborations"

The Goldfinger Factory sells designed and restored products at the foot of Trellick Tower and provides building services to the community, commercial and residential sectors. In the process of providing its goods and services it teaches local people a number of furniture restoration skills.
shortdescription: Worn out and wobbly tables in a popular social club at the foot of Treverton Tower have been given a new lease of life by Goldfinger Factory, a local company which specialises in renovating unwanted furniture, thanks to financial support from local ward Councillors.
shorttitle: Councillors' funding helps turn the tables

headline: ILLICIT TOBACCO AND SPIRITS SEIZED
prcopy:
Illicit shisha tobacco, duty-free cigarettes and spirits with counterfeit duty-paid stamps were seized in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea on 20 May as part of Operation Wagtail, a joint operation involving trading standards officers and Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC).

Officers discovered 17.5kg of illicit shisha tobacco in a shop in Kensington. As the product contains tobacco it should carry all the relevant health warnings to be sold legally, but these were not present. A search of the same shop also revealed 900 duty-free cigarettes for sale.

A visit to a shop in the north of the borough resulted in officers from HMRC discovering a huge quantity of non-duty paid spirits which had counterfeit duty paid stamps. Such was the quantity seized that officers had to work late into the night to register it all and order a truck to take it all away.

Operation Wagtail involved officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster working across the three boroughs alongside HMRC.

Councillor Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "Shopkeepers are responsible for what they sell. They must ensure when they sell tobacco and spirits that the proper health warnings are in place and duty paid. Where we find evidence of any illegal sales we will seize the goods and consider appropriate legal action."

If you have any information relating to illicit tobacco or alcohol on sale in the borough you can report it to trading standards by calling the Environmental Health line on 020 7361 3002 or email trading.standards@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Illicit shisha tobacco, duty-free cigarettes and spirits with counterfeit duty-paid stamps were seized in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea on 20 May as part of Operation Wagtail, a joint operation involving trading standards officers and Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC).
shorttitle: Illicit tobacco and spirits seized

The Mayor's Awards formally acknowledge the positive difference made by those who live or work in the Royal Borough. The award is given to people who make an outstanding contribution to their local community and add significantly to the quality of life of those around them.

Cllr Williams said: "I'm delighted to be able to recognise, on behalf of the Royal Borough, the outstanding contribution these six people have made to communities in our borough. Their work, often voluntary, has gone a long way to improving others' lives in their local neighbourhoods. These awards give the Council a chance to say thank you and recognise their hard work and efforts."

The award winners are:

Moya Denman for her work with the elderly through East Chelsea Community Contact, Sixty Plus, Age Concern, New Horizons and Age UK K&C.

Stephen Duckworth for his work with the voluntary sector in North Kensington.

Ian Henderson for his work for the residents of the Sutton Estate.

Abdallahi Nur for his work with the Baraka Youth Club.

Jennifer Ware for her work in the interests of the Earl's Court community over many decades.

The people nominated do not have to live in the Royal Borough - they might work here, maybe they visit to do voluntary work, or perhaps they lived here previously and can be nominated for the contribution they made at that time.

headline: SUCCESS FOR BOROUGH'S YOUNG KAYAKERS

This was one of a number of fine performances on the water by the borough's kayak team at the London Regatta Centre in east London on 31 May.

A great effort in the sprint team event ended with the borough's kayakers clinching second place - an improvement on last year's third spot.

There was success too in the individual slalom events with Oliver Khlaf taking first place in the junior male event and his brother Alexander Khlaf winning the senior male. Sophie Khlaf made it a good day for the family when she came third in the senior female slalom. Holly Moorhead was placed third in the junior female event.

The individual sprinters had a good day as well. Alexander Khlaf won the senior male sprint and Oliver Khlaf was second in the juniors. Sophie Khlaf was second in the senior female section.

If you live or go to school or college in the borough you can give kayaking and canoeing a try at the Canalside Centre which runs a range of outdoor sporting activities on Tuesdays and Thursdays between 4.30pm and 7.30pm, and on Saturdays between 11am and 1pm and 2pm to 4pm for young people aged nine to 19.

These popular sessions run throughout the year and are suitable for beginners right through to elite kayakers.

To find out more about what's on offer at the Canalside Centre go to www.canalsidecentre.org.uk or call 020 8968 4500.
shortdescription: Young kayakers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea won the kayak slalom event at the London Youth Games for the second year running.
shorttitle: Success for borough's young kayakers

headline: OFSTED PRAISES BOROUGH'S ADULT AND COMMUNITY LEARNING SERVICE
prcopy:
The Royal Borough's Adult and Community Learning service has been rated as `good' by Ofsted following a recent inspection which found it met a broad range of community needs and helped many vulnerable students.

Inspectors judged the service good because of the progress learners make and the valuable skills and knowledge gained during their courses. In addition the inspectors found that learners were highly motivated to progress to further study or employment.

The Council was praised by Ofsted for having a good overview of the service and was effective in planning and improving it.

The inspection looked closely at the visual arts delivered by Kensington and Chelsea College and foundation English and mathematics delivered by community organisations.***

When the service was last inspected in June 2012 it was judged to be satisfactory.

Cllr Emma Will, the Council's Cabinet Member for Education and Libraries, said: "The report reflects a very encouraging improvement in the service's performance. I want to congratulate all the staff and learners for their hard work both in the lead up to and during the week of the inspection. It is clear that our services to adult learners are of a high quality but we can and will strive to improve them further."

Mark Brickley, Principal for Kensington and Chelsea College, said: "We take great pride in providing students, whatever their age, social background, or previous experience, with excellent learning opportunities and it is gratifying that this Ofsted report shows that we are delivering."

headline: EXPECT BUSY ROADS WHEN THE TOUR DE FRANCE COMES TO LONDON
prcopy:
The 2014 Tour de France is coming to London in July. Stage 3 of the event on Monday 7 July will run from Cambridge to central London.

The roads that comprise the Stage 3 route will be closed on Monday 7 July from 10am. TfL hope to reopen the roads as quickly as possible but the closure is expected to last most of the day. It is anticipated that all roads will be reopened by 6pm, provided that it is safe to do so.

Although the race route does not enter the borough, roads in central London will be extremely busy and displaced traffic may have an impact on roads in Kensington and Chelsea.

TfL is advising drivers to avoid central London if at all possible. If people have to drive, they should:

- check how their route may be affected
- consider travelling at different times
- allow more time to complete their journey.

Tube and rail will be the best way to get around the affected areas of London, with the vast majority of services in central London running as normal. However, the Circle and District lines are expected to be extremely busy.

For more information on the route and how roads and transport will be affected go to TfL's Tour website tfl.gov.uk/tourdefrance

Official Tour de France Fan Parks will be located at Green Park, Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park and Trafalgar Square, where the whole of Stage 3 will be broadcast live on giant screens. You can find out more at www.tourdefrancefanpark.co.uk
shortdescription: The 2014 Tour de France is coming to London in July. Stage 3 of the event on Monday 7 July will run from Cambridge to central London.
shorttitle: Expect busy roads when the Tour de France comes to London

headline: COUNCIL LEADER JOINS BOROUGH'S CREDIT UNION
prcopy:
Council Leader Cllr Nick Paget-Brown gave the borough's credit union, YourCU, the stamp of approval on Monday 2 June when he joined.

Cllr Paget-Brown is the latest in a number of community leaders and politicians to show their support for YourCU Kensington and Chelsea.

The credit union, which started with help from various local housing associations and the Council, has now lent over £250,000 to residents and that figure is growing fast month on month.

Speaking after joining Cllr Paget-Brown said: "With the rise of payday and money shop lending the need and demand for affordable credit is growing. Credit unions, such as YourCU, can help those that may not be able to access mainstream high street finance or even have a bank account. I would ask all residents to consider joining the credit union whether they wish to borrow or save."

There are an estimated 24,500 `financially excluded' households in the Royal Borough, each paying a `poverty premium' of up to £1,000 a year through high borrowing costs, additional charges and lack of access to cheaper deals.

YourCU CEO William Rhodes said: "We are delighted that Cllr Paget-Brown has joined, we know there is a huge amount of good will out there and we'd love more people to come on board and invest in it for the social good and at an interest rate that tops many high street banks."

At its AGM in April YourCU voted to increase its catchment area and is now open to savers and borrowers from Hammersmith in the west, to Wandsworth in the south and Canary Wharf in the east.
For more information go to www yourcu.co.uk or email info@yourcu.co.uk or call 020 7605 6341.
shortdescription: Council Leader Cllr Nick Paget-Brown gave the borough's credit union, YourCU, the stamp of approval on Monday 2 June when he joined.
shorttitle: Council Leader joins borough's credit union

headline: COUNCIL ISSUES LEGAL NOTICE TO STOP UNAUTHORISED WORK
prcopy:
The owner of a property in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, who has allowed work on a Grade II listed building to go ahead without proper planning permission and listed building consent, has been served with a Temporary Stop Notice by Council planners.

The property, at 186 Holland Park Avenue, is Grade II listed and the first building both pedestrians and drivers see when entering the Royal Borough from Shepherds Bush. Its poor condition has attracted many complaints.

A number of warnings have been issued to the owner, but these have not been heeded and work has continued. The Temporary Stop Notice restricts the owner, or his builders, from carrying out works that have not been approved by the Royal Borough. To continue to work on the building will be a criminal offence with a maximum penalty of £20,000 in a magistrate's court and unlimited legal action if heard in a crown court.

The notice, which expires on Friday 4 July, enables the Council's planning enforcement officers to consider the next steps in protecting the Grade II listed building.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: "We simply cannot allow unauthorised work on listed buildings in the borough. Our warnings have gone unheeded so therefore we have issued this legal notice to prevent further work.

"Officers will always investigate any complaints and, when required, use all the powers at their disposal, including court action, to make sure the planning process is properly respected."
shortdescription: The owner of a property in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, who has allowed work on a Grade II listed building to go ahead without proper planning permission and listed building consent, has been served with a Temporary Stop Notice by Council planners.
shorttitle: Council issues legal notice to stop unauthorised work

headline: KENSAL LIBRARY CELEBRATES 50th BIRTHDAY IN STYLE
prcopy:
Kensal Library celebrated its 50th birthday in style on Friday 6 June with live music, face painting, craft sessions and, thanks to Gail's Artisan Bakery, a special birthday cake.

The building first opened to the public on Saturday 6 June 1964 and was officially opened on Wednesday 7 December 1964 by the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington, Cllr Mrs John Walford JP.

Since then the library, which attracts nearly 2,000 visitors a month, has undergone numerous renovations -the most recent of which was the introduction of self-service technology.

Thanks to a new system upgrade, Royal Borough residents can borrow, reserve, renew and return books, DVDs and CDs in any of the 23 libraries across Kensington and Chelsea, Hammersmith & Fulham and Westminster.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Libraries, said:

"It was a marvellous afternoon and Kensal Library's half-century of service to the North Kensington community was marked in a really special way.

"Exciting times are ahead for our library users with the introduction of one library card. Those who live, work or study in the Royal Borough, Westminster or Hammersmith & Fulham, can now access more than one million books and a range of specialist collections."

headline: TfL consults on latest Crossrail 2 options - a station for Chelsea
prcopy:
As TfL launches the last phase of its consultation on the route for Crossrail 2, the Council is urging local residents to help make sure the line stops at Chelsea.

Over the next six weeks, TfL will be consulting on three options: one with a station at Dovehouse Street, another with a station further west at Cremorne, and one that bypasses the borough altogether.

"After so many years of campaigning for Crossrail 2 it would be a disaster if we were to fall at the final hurdle," said Cllr Tim Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Transport.

"West Chelsea is poorly served by public transport. Our streets are congested and our air quality is poor. A Crossrail station would make a massive difference so it's worrying at this late stage to see an option there that bypasses Chelsea altogether. We urge as many residents as possible to get involved in the consultation and demand our station."

The Council has long supported the idea of a new rail line connecting south-west and north-east London and last year it checked to make sure that the people of Chelsea agreed.

About 3,000 Chelsea residents and businesses replied to the Council's survey, with around 70 per cent expressing support for the new line and a station in Chelsea.

There was more support than opposition right across the survey area, although support was particularly high to the west. And while there was strong support for a station at the Chelsea Fire Station site on Dovehouse Street, opinion was divided almost equally between those who felt this was the best location and those who thought it might be better placed further west.

The Council itself accepts that more residents would benefit if the western option were chosen but believes either of the King's Road options would bring very significant benefits.

Crossrail 2 would relieve pressure on major London stations such as Euston, Victoria and Clapham Junction and ease congestion on very busy Tube lines. In some cases, journey times could be more than halved.

The line would pass deep under Chelsea and a station on the King's Road would, among other things, link residents to Clapham Junction, the West End and four of London's busiest mainline stations.

The idea for Crossrail 2 - formerly called the Chelsea- Hackney Line - has been around for many decades, with the Chelsea Fire Station having long been earmarked as a potential site for the station.

Parts of Chelsea remain poorly served by public transport and the Council believes the line would:

 dramatically improve local transport options

 relieve local and city-wide congestion

 ease pressure on the transport network

 improve air quality

 dramatically improve journey times

 help the hard-pressed retail sector


As part of the consultation TfL will be running the following drop-in sessions:

Chelsea Theatre Studio 2, 7 World's End Place, King's Road, London, SW10 0DR
Friday 20 June, 10am to 4pm
Friday 27 June, 2pm to 8pm

Chelsea Old Town Hall Small Hall, King's Road, London, SW3 5EE
Friday 11 July, 2pm to 8pm
Saturday 12 July, 10am to 4pm

Residents can also participate online at www.crossrail2.co.uk
shortdescription: As TfL launches the last phase of its consultation on the route for Crossrail 2, the Council is urging local residents to help make sure the line stops at Chelsea.
shorttitle: TfL consults on latest Crossrail 2 options - a station for Chelsea

headline: NEW MAYOR FOR THE ROYAL BOROUGH
prcopy:
Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds has been elected to serve as Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea for 2014/15.

Born in Castlemartyr, County Cork, in the Republic of Ireland, Maighread Condon-Simmonds was educated at a convent school before moving to South Devon when she was 18 where she trained as a nurse at Torbay Hospital. Three years later she came to London and did her psychiatric nurses' training at the Maudsley Hospital.

As well as a career in nursing Maighread Condon-Simmonds has worked for Pan Am
and Pilgrim Airlines at Kennedy Airport where she undertook flying lessons in de Havilland Twin Otter aeroplanes.

Commenting on her election Maighread Condon-Simmonds, said: "It is a great honour to have been elected as Mayor and I look forward to a demanding and hopefully rewarding year as I undertake my new civic duties.

"I have adopted SANE as my Mayoral charity. More and more lives are affected by mental illness, yet all too often people pass over it through embarrassment. SANE works to improve the quality of life for anyone affected by mental illness and I will do all I can to help them both in raising funds and awareness."

In 2002 Cllr Condon-Simmonds was elected to the Council and since that time has served as a Councillor for the Cremorne Ward. She has sat on the Planning, Public Realm, Administration, Adult Social Care and Family and Children's Services Overview and Scrutiny committees. She is a governor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Primary School and board member of the Kensington and Chelsea Tenant Management Organisation. Maighread combines her work on the Council with nursing people in their own homes.

Maighread Condon-Simmonds has a wide variety of interests. She is a keen reader, listener of Jazz music, swimmer, cyclist, hill walker and skier, as well as being a great lover of sport; rugby being her favourite.

The new Mayor has appointed her son, Timothy J.K. Simmonds as her consort.

Councillor Robert Atkinson, a former Leader of the Council's Labour Group serves as Deputy Mayor. He has been a borough Councillor since May 1988. Robert has lived in Kensington and Chelsea for 32 years, but was born in rural Lancashire.

He is married to Maria Elena Arana (an International Development specialist). Together they have three grown up children.

Robert has an M.A. from Johns Hopkins in International Relations and Economics and a BA in History and Politics from Leeds. He did a stage with the European Commission in Brussels and was a Research Fellow at Kingston University before spending 23 years working for an International Education Company with offices in Queen's Gate.

He currently manages the office of a Member of Parliament. Robert is a trustee of Campden Charities and a governor of Servite School, Fulham Road. He is a former director of the Kensington and Chelsea Primary Care Trust and in the past 26 years has served on the governing bodies of seven schools and colleges within the borough.

Robert's interests include transport, education, Church architecture and Latin America.

Father Pat Ryall from the Servite Church in Fulham Road has agreed to serve as Mayor's Chaplain.

shortdescription: Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds has been elected to serve as Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea for 2014/15.
shorttitle: New Mayor for the Royal Borough

headline: BASEMENT DEVELOPER WARNED FOLLOWING RESIDENTS' COMPLAINTS
prcopy:
Planners for the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have ordered work on a basement development to stop unless the developer, Cranbrook Basements Ltd, sticks to a construction traffic management plan following residents' complaints that construction vehicles were not keeping to agreed routes.

Planning permission had been granted for a basement development at 57 Bury Walk, SW3, subject to a condition that disturbance to residents by construction traffic would be minimised following a Construction Traffic Management Plan (CTMP).

At the beginning of May the Council received complaints from members of the public about traffic associated with work on this property. Planners investigated and found that the transportation of materials from the site were not in line with the planning condition and warned the developer that legal action would be taken if they continued to breach the CTMP. This warning was not heeded so the Royal Borough's Planning Enforcement Team issued a Breach of Condition notice on 23 May 2014. This notice gives the developer 28 days to comply with the CTMP, after which any breach would be a criminal offence.

Despite this, the developer continued to breach the CTMP leading to the Council issuing a Temporary Stop Notice to the developer and owner of the property on 11 June. This means that, although works can continue, any further breaches of the CTMP will be a criminal offence with a maximum penalty of £20,000 in a magistrates court and unlimited if heard in a crown court.

Cllr Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: "Conditions were placed on the traffic movements when planning permission was granted for this development. Cleary, the developer has chosen time and again to ignore these which has led to our decision to use both legal instruments to prevent the developers from disrupting the rest of the neighbourhood."

Construction traffic in residential areas, particularly from basement developments, can have a big impact on the lives of neighbouring residents if developers ignore their planning conditions. The Royal Borough will not tolerate violations of planning law that have a significant impact on neighbouring properties and is prepared to use all legal powers at its disposal.
shortdescription: Council planners have ordered work on a basement development to stop unless the developer sticks to a construction traffic management plan following residents' complaints that construction vehicles were not keeping to agreed routes.
shorttitle: Basement developer warned following residents' complaints

headline: INTRANSIT BRINGS ART TO THE BOROUGH
prcopy:

headline: YOUNG ARTISTS WOW JUDGES WITH REMARKABLE WORK
prcopy:
A remarkable large scale pencil drawing reminiscent of Lord Leighton's work `Flaming June' and a vivid acrylic painting depicting an abstract teddy bear were just two of the subjects that wowed the judges at the 15th Annual Kensington and Chelsea Schools Art Competition.

Thirty-two schools entered the competition with pupils from both the state and independent sector featuring among the winners. They were presented with their awards by the Royal Borough's Mayor, Cllr Maighread Condon-Simmonds, at a ceremony at Leighton House Museum yesterday Tuesday 17 June.

The Leighton Art Prize was won by eighteen-year-old Caroline Cheung from Ashbourne Sixth Form College whose work `Exhausted' was praised by the judges as a "particularly dynamic piece of work, in which academic traditions underpin a highly personal interpretation of the female figure."

The winners in the Drawing/Painting category were: seven-year-old Leah Noirot, Falkner House School, who was awarded first prize for her drawing of `The Old Teddy'; seventeen- year -old Eva Apodiacos, Queen's Gate Secondary School was awarded second prize for 'Under the Skin' and; fifteen-year-old Sarah Bagheri Holland Park School, received third prize for her work `Untitled'.

Students from Sion-Manning School dominated the applied art category with sixteen-year-old Sunlight Johnson taking the first prize for her work `Trampolining' and Isiuwa Igbinomwanhia, also aged sixteen, receiving second prize for her work 'Force of Nature'. Nine-year-old Maria Parsnejad, Hill House International Junior School, received a third prize for her painting of `My mum, me and my sisters'.

A new category this year was the Photography/Digital Art category and was won by Paris Beyk, aged seventeen, from David Game College for her work `Reflection of my Reality 1'

Praising the winners the Mayor said: "I want to congratulate all the young people and their teachers on their creativity and hard work in preparing for and entering this competition. The Royal Borough has a long history of supporting artists and I hope that some of those who took part in the competition will be encouraged to develop their artistic talents further.

"Their work is just fantastic I also hope that many residents will take the opportunity to visit the exhibition and see for themselves the talent that is developing and being nurtured in our schools."

Prize winner Eva Apodiacos is set to study an art foundation course next year at the City & Guilds of London Art School and said the award was a great confidence booster: "I am so pleased to have my work on show in the Gallery at Leighton House Museum, and am very excited to have won a prize. It's great to have my work recognised, especially as I am heading off to start an art foundation course."

Eva also received a special award which entitles her to a bespoke tour of the Art School and a session in their print room over the Summer.

Local businesses that would like to display winning entries in their premises can do so through the Schools Art Loan programme, a new scheme which the Council has launched.

Senior curator at Leighton House Museum, Daniel Robbins, described the standard of entry asparticularly high. "Frederic Leighton put great store by figure drawing and the drawing of draperies and so it was particularly fitting that this year's Leighton Prize should be awarded to a student who showed such aptitude in these areas," he said.

"Later this year, 50 paintings by Leighton and his contemporaries will be exhibited at Leighton House, the only UK venue for a touring exhibition of the Pérez Simón collection from Mexico. The exhibition entitled `A Victorian Obsession' will surely encourage school children and students alike with new inspiration to pursue their interests and develop their creativity."

The competition prizes are sponsored by The Park Gallery, Flow Gallery, Friends of Leighton House Museum, and City and Guilds of London Art School.

For more information go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/leightonhousemuseum
shortdescription: A remarkable large scale pencil drawing reminiscent of Lord Leighton's work `Flaming June' and a vivid acrylic painting depicting an abstract teddy bear were just two of the subjects that wowed the judges at the 15th Annual Kensington and Chelsea Schools Art Competition.
shorttitle: Young artists wow judges with remarkable work
