headline: PLANNERS SERVE SECOND NOTICE ON LISTED BUILDING
prcopy:
The owner of a property in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has been served with a second legal notice by Council planners in a matter of weeks due to the Council's concern about the condition and appearance of the property dragging down the rest of the neighbourhood.

The property, at 186 Holland Park Avenue, is Grade II listed and the first building both pedestrians and drivers see when entering the Royal Borough from Shepherd's Bush. Its poor condition has attracted many complaints.

Works were being carried out on the building without proper planning permission and listed building consent and, on 6 June 2013, a Temporary Stop Notice was served on the owner by Council planners to prevent the unauthorised works continuing.

On the 16 June 2013 a second legal notice was served by the Council's planning enforcement team on the property owner requiring that the condition and appearance of the property is improved. The owner has a right to appeal the notice in the magistrates' courts but, if no appeal is forthcoming, the owner must carry out the improvement works to the property by 18 September 2014.

The works are requested by the Council and considered by planning officers to be necessary to stop the property being an eyesore. If the notice is not complied with then the Council can enter the property and carry out the necessary works. Furthermore the Council can charge the owner for the costs in carrying out the works and prosecute the owner in the magistrates' court.

The Council is committed to tackling properties which are poorly maintained and have become a blight on the rest of the neighbourhood, particularly properties which are listed buildings and situated within Conservation Areas.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Council's Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: "Sadly, we have had to serve another notice to try and both prevent unauthorised work on this property and to make sure that the work that is required is done properly and meets the requirements of this important and historic building."
shortdescription: The owner of a property in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has been served with a second legal notice by Council planners in a matter of weeks due to the Council's concern about the condition and appearance of the property dragging down the rest of the neighbourhood.
shorttitle: Planners serve second notice on listed building

headline: FUNDING APPROVED FOR WHISTLER WALK HIDDEN HOMES
prcopy:
On Thursday 19 June the Royal Borough's Cabinet approved funding to convert the redundant children's home at Whistler Walk into seven new social housing homes.

A total of £743,000 has been allocated to the scheme and the Kensington and Chelsea Tenant Management Organisation (KCTMO) will oversee the works. The scheme will provide seven new homes (one one-bed, four two-bed and two three-bed) all built to Lifetime Homes Standards.

The former Whistler Walk Children's Home was based on the World's End Estate and has been relocated to Olive House on East Row (named in memory of former Councillor the late The Rt Hon The Baroness Shireen Olive Ritchie).

The creation of seven new homes at Whistler Walk is part of the Council's longstanding strategy of releasing hidden homes in the Royal Borough. An unused office space at Greaves Tower, World's End Estate, was the first in the programme to be completed, having been turned into three separate two-bedroom units. Unused space on the lower floors of Grenfell Tower will be converted to make between seven and nine new affordable homes.

A number of redundant basement areas in Elm Park Gardens have been converted over the past few years. The resulting properties are a mixture of flats for social rent, affordable rented housing and properties for sale. The properties which have been sold to date have raised in the region of £8m which is being used to carry out much needed repairs and improvements to the Council's housing stock.

Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Housing, said:

"Space is at a premium in the Royal Borough, so the Council and the KCTMO have been working closely together to redevelop redundant Council property or underused spaces on existing Council estates to create new affordable homes for local people.

"Our 'Hidden Homes' strategy is already proving to be successful, with a total of six new homes delivered last year, and with at least double that in the pipeline for the next year or so."
shortdescription: On Thursday 19 June the Royal Borough's Cabinet approved funding to convert the redundant children's home at Whistler Walk into seven new social housing homes.
shorttitle: Funding approved for Whistler Walk Hidden Homes

headline: NEW CHILDREN'S HOME OPENED IN ROYAL BOROUGH
prcopy:
A £2.6m children's home was officially opened today (Tuesday 24 June) by the Leader of the Council, Councillor Nick Paget-Brown.

Olive House replaces the old 1970s home based in Whistler Walk, World's End Estate which, although very well run, was no longer suitable as a children's home. The new building is named after a former Councillor, Shireen Olive Ritchie, who was a driving force behind the home in her role as Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Services, which she held for many years prior to her death in 2012.

The home can house up to nine children and provides greatly improved internal and external space for social and recreational use. It is split into five rooms for children who are long-term residents and four `flats' which give those 18 and 19-year-olds about to leave the home experience of what living on their own will be like.

At the opening ceremony Councillor Paget-Brown said: "It is a great honour to be here today opening Olive House. It is a fitting tribute to Shireen Ritchie, who worked tirelessly on behalf of children and young people and was greatly respected by her colleagues and Council officers who met her.

"I am sure the children here are as impressed as I am by the quality of the house and by all the facilitites it has to offer. I wish them and the staff the best for the future."

One of the main challenges was to give Olive House a `homely feel' and steer clear of the traditional look and feel of an old, institutionalised children's home.
shortdescription: A £2.6m children's home was officially opened today (Tuesday 24 June) by the Leader of the Council, Councillor Nick Paget-Brown.
shorttitle: New children's home opened in Royal Borough

headline: BUTTERFLY AND MOTH MORNING IN HOLLAND PARK
prcopy:
Discover how to identify the different species of butterflies and moths that make their home in Holland Park at a free talk, `Butterfly and Moth Morning', organised by the Ecology Centre on Saturday 12 July.

Lepidopterist Tim Freed will lead a guided walk which starts at 10am. Booking for the event, which is sponsored by Friends of Holland Park, is essential. To reserve a place email ecology.centre@rbkc.gov.uk and meet at Holland Park Ecology Centre.
shortdescription: Discover how to identify the different species of butterflies and moths that make their home in Holland Park at a free talk, `Butterfly and Moth Morning', organised by the Ecology Centre on Saturday 12 July.
shorttitle: Butterfly and moth morning in Holland Park

headline: MAYOR CELEBRATES SCIENCE WITH SCHOOL PUPILS
prcopy:
It certainly was rocket science at Holland Park School when it hosted the Borough Schools Science Fair, attended by students from St Thomas More Language College and The Chelsea Academy.

The science fair, involved 180 students aged 11 to 13, was part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Celebration of Science. The students took part in rocket science, robotics, astrophysics and corrosive chemical workshops. Students were delighted by the hands-on practical nature of the day. They programmed their own robots to complete a maze and even hunted for meteorites in the school grounds.

Talking about the challenges on the day, Dylan Acri, a Year 7 student at Holland Park School, said: "I took part in the robotics workshop, which was amazing. We saw how real-life robots are made and then used laptops to programme our own robots to go through a maze. I had tried some computer programming before but this was different because you could see the robot move instantly."

The event was attended by the Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds, who said: "I had a fabulous time at the science fair and was hugely impressed by what I saw. We have some dedicated science teachers and very enthusiastic students."
shortdescription: It certainly was rocket science at Holland Park School when it hosted the Borough Schools Science Fair, attended by students from St Thomas More Language College and The Chelsea Academy.
shorttitle: Mayor celebrates science with school pupils

headline: LATIMER ALTERNATIVE PROVISION ACADEMY PRAISED BY DEPUTY PM
prcopy:
The Latimer Alternative Provision Academy in North Kensington was recognised at an awards ceremony in London hosted by the Deputy Prime Minister, Nick Clegg MP, for schools from every region to celebrate the excellent work done to help children from disadvantaged backgrounds catch up with their peers.

Selected as a joint runner-up in the National Pupil Premium Award for Special Schools along with the Bridge Alternative Provision Academy in neighbouring Hammersmith, Latimer was praised by the judges for going beyond the usual support. The judges were impressed by its use of remote learning and extra-curricular activities for different children.

Speaking at the event on Wednesday 25 June, Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg said: "The fantastic work of Latimer Academy shows how the Pupil Premium is working. They've used the funding to give students healthy breakfasts each morning and an outdoor gym to help them keep fit and stay focused in class. Students have held an exhibition of their art and writing at a commercial gallery to motivate them in their studies."

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Education, said: "I am very pleased to see the hard work of staff and students at the Latimer Alternative Provision Academy recognised by the Deputy Prime Minister.

"This is a school that provides education for pupils often with complex needs and clearly does it very well."
shortdescription: The Latimer Alternative Provision Academy in North Kensington was recognised at an awards ceremony in London hosted by the Deputy Prime Minister, Nick Clegg MP, for schools from every region to celebrate the excellent work done to help children from disadvantaged backgrounds catch up with their peers.
shorttitle: Latimer Alternative Provision Academy praised by Deputy PM

headline: HEALTHY EATING AWARD FOR HOLLAND PARK CAFE
prcopy:
A café that changed its menu to include more fruit and vegetables and reduced fat, salt and sugar has been recognised for its commitment to healthier eating.

The Holland Park Café, in Kensington's Holland Park, was recently awarded the Healthier Catering Commitment (HCC) by Central London Community Healthcare NHS Trust and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea. This follows work by the café's manager and staff with local NHS dietitians and Environmental Health Officers, designed to give more choice to customers and help them make better choices about what to choose from the menu.

Café manager, Ade Phillips, said: "The commitment was easy to implement and customers appreciate having healthier choices". Ade has also noticed customers are requesting more salads and healthier spreads on sandwiches.

The HCC is running across London. To achieve it, food businesses need to meet at least eight of 24 criteria to improve the nutrition of their food.

Ali Ginn, the programme dietitian, said: "Cafés and fast food restaurants appreciate the scheme as they can give better choices to their customers and changes do not usually cost anything. There are lots of fast food outlets with the award. But it's great to see a park café making changes, complementing the healthy lifestyle parks promote."

Councillor Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: "Congratulations to Holland Park Café on this award. Customers appreciate a good choice and the healthier those choices can be, the better.

"I am very pleased the borough's Environmental Health Officers have been able to work so closely with their NHS colleagues and the café staff to achieve this recognition."

For more information on the commitment visit

http://www.cieh.org/healthier-catering-commitment.html

For local information or to sign up, contact Central London Community Healthcare dietetics team on 020 7313 3024.
shortdescription: A café that changed its menu to include more fruit and vegetables and reduced fat, salt and sugar has been recognised for its commitment to healthier eating.
shorttitle: Healthy eating award for Holland Park Cafe

headline: FALSE IDENTITY USED IN BENEFIT FRAUD
prcopy:
A woman who falsely claimed nearly £50,000 in Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was sentenced at Isleworth Crown Court on Wednesday 25 June 2014 to 24 weeks imprisonment suspended for 12 months. She was also sentenced to 12 months supervision and 16 sessions of structured supervision for women.

Ms Mary Mendy, aged 50, of Grenfell Tower, Lancaster West Estate, W11, claimed Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit on the basis that she was working part-time. However, following an investigation by the Council's Corporate Investigation Group, it was discovered she had created a false identity - Mary Abel Thomas - and under this name had a second job which she had failed to declare for benefit purposes.

Mendy had earlier pleaded guilty on 28 May 2014, at Isleworth Crown court to six counts of failing to declare her true circumstances when she had a legal duty to do so, contrary to the Fraud Act 2006.

The court heard Ms Mendy's mitigation that her husband was sometimes violent to her and had forced her to open an account in the name of Mary Thomas and insisted she did not inform the Council of her change in circumstances. She maintained he controlled the finances and ran the account. However, His Honour Judge Dugdale said it was apparent that although there was a degree of coercion there was another route for her to take and she had plenty of opportunity to take herself out of the situation.

During the period 1 April 2004 to 21 July 2013 Mary Mendy was overpaid Housing Benefit totalling £45,631.06 and Council Tax Benefit amounting to £3,874.80.
shortdescription: A woman who falsely claimed nearly £50,000 in Housing Benefit and Council Tax Benefit from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was sentenced at Isleworth Crown Court on Wednesday 25 June 2014 to 24 weeks imprisonment suspended for 12 months. She was also sentenced to 12 months supervision and 16 sessions of structured supervision for women.
shorttitle: False identity used in benefit fraud

headline: KENSINGTON GARDENER PLANTS TRIBUTE TO WORLD WAR I FALLEN
prcopy:
A garden planted to depict the historic Menin Gate will be open to the public on Sunday 6 and 27 July as part of the National Garden Scheme.

The garden at 57 St Quintin Avenue, W10 belongs to local resident Harvey Groffman who spent 42 years as a gardener at Kew Gardens. The planting commemorates the outbreak of World War I by creating a floral bedding display that evokes the Menin Gate flanked and fronted with poppies.

The Menin Gate Memorial is the largest of five memorials commemorating the missing of the Ypres Salient and sits astride the road along which many troops passed on their way to the front.

Since 1928, the Last Post has been sounded under the Menin Gate every evening at 8pm.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds, said: "There will be many commemorations to mark the centenary of the outbreak of World War I. I think it is very fitting that Mr Groffman has used the Menin Gate to inspire his planting."

Admission costs £3 for adults and is free for children. Viewing at other dates can be arranged by calling Mr Groffman on 020 8969 8292.
shortdescription: A garden planted to depict the historic Menin Gate will be open to the public on Sunday 6 and 27 July as part of the National Garden Scheme.
shorttitle: Kensington gardener plants tribute to World War I fallen

headline: FOOD ALLERGY AWARENESS COURSES FOR BUSINESSES
prcopy:
All food businesses in the Royal Borough will be required to give their customers comprehensive information about their products' ingredients, so customers with food allergies can identify the food they need to avoid, when the Food Information for Consumer Regulations comes into force on Saturday 13 December 2014.

To help food businesses inform their customers the Council's Public Health Training Service has developed a series of courses including: an in-house `Allergy Awareness' course aimed at food suppliers and a `Food Allergen Management' course for managers and supervisors.

Businesses will risk prosecution if they do not get their allergy information right and could be taken to court by a customer who suffers an allergic reaction to a food.

For restaurants, cafes, supermarkets, hotels, schools colleges, care homes and such like information about allergens must be displayed on a board or staff must be able to explain it clearly. For packaged food suppliers allergens must be highlighted in the ingredients lists in bold or italics.

For more information about the courses go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/publichealthtraining or call 020 7361 3002.
shortdescription: All food businesses in the Royal Borough will be required to give their customers comprehensive information about their products' ingredients, so customers with food allergies can identify the food they need to avoid, when the Food Information for Consumer Regulations comes into force on Saturday 13 December 2014.
shorttitle: Food allergy awareness courses for businesses

headline: DEVELOPER FAILED TO PROVIDE SUFFICIENT FUNDING FOR AFFORDABLE HOUSING - PLANNING INSPECTORATE
prcopy:
A decision by the Council to refuse planning permission for a cinema, shop and 11 flats on King's Road, Chelsea because the developer failed to provide sufficient funding for affordable housing was upheld by The Planning Inspectorate.

At a public inquiry last April Planning Inspector Jessica Graham was asked to consider whether the scheme, at 279 King's Road, made sufficient financial contribution towards affordable housing.

Representatives for Ilona House Securities Ltd told the hearing that a Section.106 undertaking included an obligation to pay a contribution of up to £200,000. However, the Council argued that the development could provide a surplus of over £1 million towards the provision of social housing.

Dismissing the appeal Ms Graham found that payment of £200,000 would fall a long way short of the "maximum reasonable amount" that could be contributed toward affordable housing.

The Inspector agreed with the Council that some of the key assumptions in the developer's financial viability statement were wrongly balanced in its favour to reduce the funding available for affordable housing, including interest rates, necessary profit, contingency costs and land valuation. She said: "there remains an identified surplus of over £1 million, which could contribute toward the provision of affordable housing in the borough. I regard this figure as more indicative of the maximum reasonable amount."

Welcoming the decision the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, Cllr Timothy Coleridge, said: "This decision supports the Council's rigorous approach. Developers should be clear that we will leave no stone unturned to make sure we get as much affordable housing as we can as part of new developments."
shortdescription: A decision by the Council to refuse planning permission for a cinema, shop and 11 flats on King's Road, Chelsea because the developer failed to provide sufficient funding for affordable housing was upheld by The Planning Inspectorate.
shorttitle: Developer failed to provide sufficient funding for affordable housing - Planning Inspectorate

headline: FINE AND CONFISCATION ORDER FOR HOLLAND PARK HOMEOWNER
prcopy:
A man who extended his house at 104 Portland Road in Holland Park, Kensington, without planning permission has been fined £15,000 at Isleworth Crown Court today (Monday 7 July), and had £25,350 confiscated under the Proceeds of Crime Act.

Mr Mayur Naturbhai Patel (54) was also ordered to pay the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's costs of £3,580. He faces 15 months in prison if he fails to pay the confiscation order in three months.

On 10 June Mr Mayur Naturbhai Patel pleaded guilty to breaching the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 after he made major rooftop alterations to his Portland Road property without planning permission and did not comply with a Council enforcement notice requiring them to be removed.

Sentencing was referred to Isleworth Crown Court as it has the power to deal with a proceeds of crime action instigated by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea which wanted to prevent Mr Patel profiting financially from the additional floor space created by his illegal development.

At his original hearing on 10 June, magistrates heard how Mr Patel, currently of Academy Place, Isleworth, failed to comply with a planning enforcement notice served by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea in November 2012.

Enforcement officers issued the notice following complaints that major work was underway at 104 Portland Road in W11. On inspection they discovered that the roof had been altered and that a large roof extension and a rear roof had been constructed, all of which is unauthorised development harming the appearance of the Norland Conservation Area in which Portland Road stands.

Despite the four months allowed under the notice to restore the property, and a number of reminders, most of the work required remains outstanding to this day, but still needs to be undertaken to avoid potential further action by the Council.

In his defence Mr Patel claimed to have received verbal confirmation from his architect and a planning officer that the alterations would be acceptable. Mr Patel has no previous convictions.

In his closing remarks His Honour Judge Phillip Matthews said he did not ascribe shady motives when imposing the financial penalty, but thought Mr Patel had acted with the "utmost stupidity" and that it was no mitigation to say he relied on the advice of architects.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: "I am very pleased that the court has made this ruling. We were determined that Mr Patel should not gain financially from his illegal development."
shortdescription: A man who extended his house at 104 Portland Road in Holland Park, Kensington, without planning permission has been fined £15,000 at Isleworth Crown Court today (Monday 7 July), and had £25,350 confiscated under the Proceeds of Crime Act.
shorttitle: Fine and confiscation order for Holland Park homeowner

headline: DID YOU KNOW THE LATE GEORGE DORRELL VC MBE?
prcopy:
The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea would like to contact the friends and family of the late George Dorrell VC MBE so they can share in a ceremony on Monday 1 September 2014 to commemorate the award of his Victoria Cross.

The event, to be held in Kensington, London, is part of a nationwide campaign to honour Victoria Cross recipients from the First World War by laying commemorative paving stones in their birthplace on the centenary of the award.

According to Mr Dorrell's birth certificate he was born in Chelsea, London, on 7 July 1880 and died in 1971 in Stoke D'Abernon, Elmbridge, Surrey, aged 90. He was survived by a sister, a son, two daughters and eight grandchildren.

Mr Dorrell was awarded the Victoria Cross on 1 September 1914 at the battle of Nerys, France.

If you knew the late George Dorrell, please contact Shirley Long at the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea on 020 7361 3238 or shirley.long@rbkc.gov.uk
keyword3: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea
shortdescription: The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea would like to contact the friends and family of the late George Dorrell VC MBE so they can share in a ceremony on Monday 1 September 2014 to commemorate the award of his Victoria Cross.
shorttitle: Did you know the late George Dorrell VC MBE?

headline: HELPING THOSE WITH DEMENTIA
prcopy:
Residents and businesses are being invited to find out more about dementia and how they can help those who suffer from the condition at an event at Chelsea Old Town Hall on Tuesday 15 July.

Starting at 9.30am, the free event will give attendees the chance to hear about the condition, participate in interactive activities and share ideas for making the borough more dementia-friendly.

Run by Age UK Kensington & Chelsea, the event will mark the public launch of the Dementia Action Alliance - a network of over 1,200 organisations who work to improve the lives of dementia sufferers, their carers and families.

The Royal Borough's Mayor, Cllr Maighread Condon-Simmonds, will open the event and Dr James Warner, a consultant psychiatrist and clinical director for older people's Mental Health services at Central North West London NHS Trust, will deliver the keynote speech.

To register, contact Holly Corlett at Age UK Kensington & Chelsea on 020 8960 8137 or at hcorlett@aukc.org.uk
shortdescription: Residents and businesses are being invited to find out more about dementia and how they can help those who suffer from the condition at an event at Chelsea Old Town Hall on Tuesday 15 July.
shorttitle: Helping those with dementia

headline: CONSTRUCTION COMPANY FINED FOR NOISY WEEKEND WORK
prcopy:
A construction company that breached a notice served by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, which formalised the hours it could undertake noisy work during the redevelopment of the Wornington Green estate in North Kensington, was fined on two counts yesterday (8 July) at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court.

Ardmore Construction Limited are the contractors undertaking the redevelopment of Wornington Green. On 5 August 2013 the company was served with a section 60 notice under the Control of Pollution Act 1974. This notice formalised the permitted hours for noisy works audible at the site boundary.

The court heard about two breaches of this notice relating to offences which occurred on Sunday 8 December 2013 at 11.59am, and Saturday 22 February 2014 at 1.30pm. No one attended the hearing for Ardmore Construction Limited, and Deputy District Judge Lyons found the case proved. For the first count Ardmore received a fine of £1,000; for the second count a further fine of £1,000. Costs were awarded of £641.87 plus a victim surcharge of £200. In fining the company Judge Lyons said that she had taken account of the fact it had already been cautioned for its conduct.

Previously Ardmore Construction Limited had been formally cautioned by the Council for breaches of the same notice for offences that occurred on Saturday 31 August 2013 at 5pm, and the following day on Sunday 1 September 2013 at 10.17am.
shortdescription: A construction company that breached a notice served by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, which formalised the hours it could undertake noisy work during the redevelopment of the Wornington Green estate in North Kensington, was fined on two counts yesterday (8 July) at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court.
shorttitle: Construction company fined for noisy weekend work

headline: BE INSPIRED BY SCIENCE
prcopy:
Science will be in the spotlight this October when the Council joins with the Natural History Museum and Imperial College to produce its second annual science festival.

Taking place from Friday 3 to Saturday 18 October, a Celebration of Science will feature talks on chemistry, materials science and particle physics, as well as air quality, Islamic mathematics, food science and public health. There is also fun to be had learning about ecology and sports science in the borough's parks.

Festival highlights include talks on: sea power and the role and purpose of the nuclear deterrent; the eighteenth century bureaucrat Sir Hans Sloane; how new technology has transformed recent warfare in Iraq and Afghanistan, and public health and smoking in the First World War.

Speakers include:

 Dr Arthur MacGregor, formerly Director of the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford and author of the Oxford Electronic Dictionary of National Biography article on the life of Sir Hans Sloane.

 Professor Mike Kelly FRS, Prince Philip Professor of Engineering, University of Cambridge.

 Professor John Loughhead, Imperial College, Director of the UK Energy Research Centre (UK ERC).

 Professor Andy Sterling of Sussex University.

 Professor Robin Wilson, formerly Professor of Pure Mathematics at the Open University and President of the Mathematical History Society.

 Professor Nicholas Bosanquet, Imperial College.

 Sir Hew Strachan FBA, Chichele Professor of the History of War, All Souls College Oxford.

 Air Vice Marshall Peter Dye, Director of the RAF Museum.

 Admiral Lord West, the former First Sea Lord and Labour Security Minister.

Cllr Warwick Lightfoot, the Council's lead on the festival, said: "Following the success of last year's science festival, we've been fortunate enough to secure a host of impressive and distinguished speakers to delight and challenge audiences about the captivating world of science.

"It is a wide an interesting programme which I hope will appeal to all. I encourage everyone to see what's on and take time out to be inspired by science."

For the full programme of events, visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/celebrationofscience
shortdescription: Science will be in the spotlight this October when the Council joins with the Natural History Museum and Imperial College to produce its second annual science festival.
shorttitle: Be inspired by science

headline: NEW GYM FOR CHELSEA SPORTS CENTRE
prcopy:
Visitors to Chelsea Sports Centre on Chelsea Manor Street, SW3, can now benefit from a new state-of-the-art gym following a £1.36m refurbishment by the Council.

The centre now has a larger gym, new group exercise studio, new changing rooms and fast-track access via a refurbished reception.

On top of that there are now over 70 brand new gym machines, ranging from treadmills to cross trainers and bikes to rowing machines.

Cllr Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Leisure, said: "Along with a variety of weekly group exercise classes and two indoor heated swimming pools, the gym's new facilities transform the centre into a first-class place for residents to keep fit."

To use the sports centre you need to be a member. Signing up is easy; either pop in and register at the centre's reception, or sign up online at www.better.org.uk/chelsea where you can also find a full timetable.
shortdescription: Visitors to Chelsea Sports Centre on Chelsea Manor Street, SW3, can now benefit from a new state-of-the-art gym following a £1.36m refurbishment by the Council.
shorttitle: New gym for Chelsea Sports Centre

headline: COWS START CONSERVATION GRAZING TO RESTORE HOLLAND PARK MEADOWS
prcopy:
Two Longhorn cows, five-year-old Jelly and three-year-old Lulu, along with their calves are leaving their Hertfordshire farm and heading for the bright lights of London for a spot of grazing in fashionable Holland Park.

The cows are being brought in as part of a conservation-grazing project by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea to restore two woodland meadow areas, which had become overgrown with weeds.

Jelly and Lulu will be in the park for up to three weeks to help restore the park's diverse woodland meadows by chomping their way through plants, such as nettles, which are dominating the meadow area. It is the second year that cows are being used in this way. Last year two other cows from the same herd spent six weeks in the park and previously pigs were used during the summer months to graze the area.

Longhorns are one of the oldest and largest of the British native breeds and are renowned for their docility, strong maternal instincts and rough grazing abilities. Where other cattle would turn up their noses the Longhorn digs in: nettles, diverse grasses, wild flowers and thistles, it eats them all.

Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern, said: "We are delighted to welcome Jelly and Lulu to Holland Park where they will go straight to work grazing in the conservation area. The cows did great work in record time last year and we are expecting a similar performance this year. It is all part of the work the Ecology Service does to enhance biodiversity in the borough."

The Longhorns will arrive in Holland Park on Monday 14 July and will remain for three weeks. Originally used as oxen to plough the land the Longhorn rose to fame as a superior beef animal in the 1700s but in the early 1900s the breed fell out of favour.

The modern rise of the Longhorns is attributed to a change in farming methods with some farmers preferring a less intensive rearing and grazing system in which the slow maturing and more maternal breeds rule supreme.

If anyone would like to find out more about the use of cattle in conservation grazing there is a talk on 23 July 2014 at 6.30pm meet by Lord Holland's statue. For more information email ecology.centre@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Two Longhorn cows, five-year-old Jelly and three-year-old Lulu, along with their calves are leaving their Hertfordshire farm and heading for the bright lights of London for a spot of grazing in fashionable Holland Park.
shorttitle: Cows start conservation grazing to restore Holland Park meadows

headline: BENEFIT FRAUDSTER SENTENCED TO 200 HOURS COMMUNITY SERVICE
prcopy:
A woman who falsely claimed £21,000 in Housing and Council Tax benefits from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was sentenced at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Tuesday 8 July to 200 hours community service and ordered to pay £360 in costs.

Ms Oulichki had earlier pleaded guilty on 10 June, at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court to four counts of failing to declare her true circumstances when she had a legal duty to do so, contrary to the Fraud Act 2006.

Fifty-four year old Aicha Oulichki, of Pikemans Court, West Cromwell Road, had claimed Housing and Council Tax benefits for herself and her husband, Mr Abdullah Kdadri, based solely on her part-time earnings.

However, following investigation by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Corporate Investigation Group it was discovered that Mr Kdadri was working as a foreign language teacher. Furthermore, Mrs Oulichki had failed to declare a bank account in Mr Kdadri's name that held £17,000 in savings. It was into this account that his wages were paid.

During her sentencing Mrs Oulichki blamed her failure to declare her true circumstances on the fact that she lost her father in 2008. Deputy District Judge Lyons stated that a number of people suffer bereavements but do not go on to commit fraud. She warned Mrs Oulichki that had it not been for her early guilty plea a suspended sentence of imprisonment would have been imposed.

During the period 22 September 2008 to 18 November 2012 Miss Oulichki was overpaid Housing Benefit of £17,308.71 and Council Tax Benefit of £4,111.42.
shortdescription: A woman who falsely claimed £21,000 in Housing and Council Tax benefits from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea was sentenced at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court on Tuesday  8 July to 200 hours community service and ordered to pay £360 in costs.
shorttitle: Benefit fraudster sentenced to 200 hours community service

headline: Housing Minister visits Silchester housing development
prcopy:
New homes in North Kensington, that are being built as a result of a partnership between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Peabody, were visited by the Housing Minister as the Government announced new `Growth Deals' to deliver funding for regional infrastructure and housing projects.

Housing Minister, Kris Hopkins MP, visited the Council's Silchester Estate earlier this week (Monday 7 July) to see the progress on 112 new homes.

Due to be completed in November 2015, the Silchester development, near Latimer Road Station, will provide 45 larger properties for social rent, 39 shared ownership, and a further 28 homes for sale on the open market, to help pay for the work. There will also be a new shop, community facilities and landscaped gardens.

The Council has provided the land and £3 million with Peabody also investing in the scheme and project managing the building programme.

Representatives from Peabody, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, including the Deputy Leader of the Council, Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, and main contractor Mace, joined the Minister on a tour of the site.

Councillor Feilding-Mellen said: "I would like to thank Kris Hopkins for coming to see our Silchester development. It is a great example of good design increasing the density of an inner-city site to deliver more homes for both the public and private sector. I am very pleased our work with Peabody will provide these much-needed new homes for local people.

"The Royal Borough and other councils across London need to find more such opportunities to increase the supply of new housing on their own landholdings - especially on those sites that are under-used and have lower than average densities. I am sure the Government's new `Growth Deal' will play its part in enabling more such developments to be delivered."

Jeremy Stibbe, Executive Director of Development and Sales at Peabody said: "We welcome the recognition that housing has received as part of critical infrastructure to support growth, and the latest funding boost to help councils to build more affordable homes in their area. We're delighted to be working with the Royal Borough to deliver significant numbers of affordable homes in North Kensington. Silchester is a great example of how we're using our capacity to help local authorities to deliver more housing across all tenures, jobs and community investment."
shortdescription: New homes in North Kensington, that are being built as a result of a partnership between the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and Peabody, were visited by the Housing Minister as the Government announced new `Growth Deals' to deliver funding for regional infrastructure and housing projects.
shorttitle: Housing Minister visits Silchester housing development

headline: CADETS DEMONSTRATE THEIR SKILLS IN HOLLAND PARK
prcopy:
Holland Park was transformed into a dynamic parade ground on Saturday 5 July when over 100 local police, army, sea and air cadets took part in a series of activities designed to showcase the challenges undertaken by these uniformed youth services.

Over 500 members of the public turned out to see the air cadets' marching band display and a full-on riot control demonstration by the police cadets.

Anyone present was able to try their hand at the challenging spider wall and army assault course. The Boys Brigade, showed just how it should be done when its representatives won the time trial. The winning team's efforts were rewarded when the Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, who was present on the day, awarded prizes.

Commenting on the day, the Mayor, Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds, said: "I was very impressed by the discipline and skills of the cadets from across the services. They obviously had a real sense of pride in their uniform and it was clear they were having fun on the day.

"I would certainly encourage any young person to give the cadets a try. I would like to thank all those who work with the cadets for their time and dedication. It really does show."
shortdescription: Holland Park was transformed into a dynamic parade ground on Saturday 5 July when over 100 local police, army, sea and air cadets took part in a series of activities designed to showcase the challenges undertaken by these uniformed youth services.
shorttitle: cadets demonstrate their skills in Holland Park

headline: MAJOR ROAD CLOSURES FOR AUGUST CYCLE EVENT
prcopy:
Residents and businesses should expect severe traffic and public transport disruption on Sunday 10 August when amateur and professional cyclists ride though the borough as part of the Prudential RideLondon event.

Developed by the Mayor of London and his agencies, Prudential RideLondon is a world-class festival of cycling taking place over the weekend of Saturday 9 and Sunday 10 August 2014.

Many other local roads will be closed to traffic from the early hours of Sunday 10 August to allow the event to pass safely through the borough. headline: PLANNING ENFORCEMENT SENDS A MESSAGE
prcopy:
A dozen properties in Kensington and Chelsea felt the force of the Royal Borough's planning enforcement team during June.

The owners of a house at Douro Place W8 were served with an enforcement notice in connection with an unauthorised rooflight. The owners of 62 Portobello Road W11 received a similar notice for an unauthorised wall and railings. The owner of 27 Langton Street, SW10 was served with an enforcement notice in relation to an unauthorised roof terrace. And an enforcement notice was also served on the owners of Petersham House, SW7 because of an unauthorised extract flue.

Meanwhile, the owner of 186 Holland Park Avenue W11 was hit with a notice ordering unauthorised work to stop on the listed building and then a further notice requiring repair and redecoration. The owner of a house on Holland Park W11 was also served with a Section 215 notice requiring repair and redecoration.

Most notably, the owner of 104 Portland Road found himself in court for failing to comply with an enforcement notice in relation to an unauthorised roof terrace. He was fined £15,000 at Isleworth Crown Court and had £25,350 confiscated under the Proceeds of Crime Act. In addition, he was ordered to pay the Council's costs of £3,580 and will face 15 months in prison if he fails to pay the confiscation order within three months.

"Owners and developers must respect planning law and they must respect their neighbours," said Cllr Tim Coleridge, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Planning, "there is nothing optional about it, as a number of people in Kensington and Chelsea have recently found out."
shortdescription: A dozen properties in Kensington and Chelsea felt the force of the Royal Borough's planning enforcement team during June.
shorttitle: Planning enforcement sends a message

headline: TWO LEGAL NOTICES SERVED AFTER COMPLAINTS ABOUT BASEMENT DEVELOPMENT
prcopy:
Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea planners have ordered work on a basement development to stop unless the developer, W11 Construction Ltd and the owner Blue Arrow Ltd, stick to a construction traffic management plan following residents' complaints that construction vehicles were not keeping to agreed routes.

Planning permission had been granted for a two-storey basement development at 3 Campden Hill Place, W11, subject to a condition that disturbance to residents by construction traffic would be minimised following a Construction Traffic Management Plan (CTMP).

At the beginning of May the Council received complaints from members of the public about traffic associated with work on this property. Planners warned the developer that legal action would be taken if they continued to breach the CTMP. This warning was not heeded so the Council's Planning Enforcement Team issued both a Breach of Condition Notice and a Temporary Stop Notice on both companies on the 16 July 2014. The effect of both notices means any future breaches of the CTMP by the developers will be a criminal offence. Each breach could lead to a maximum penalty of £20,000 in a magistrates court and unlimited if heard in a crown court.

Cllr Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: "Conditions were placed on the traffic movements when planning permission was granted for this development to prevent the developers from disrupting the rest of the neighbourhood. We will not tolerate developers ignoring planning conditions when it affects the everyday lives of our residents and the issuing of both notices in the same day is testament to our strict stance."

Construction traffic in residential areas, particularly from basement developments, can have a big impact on the lives of neighbouring residents if developers ignore their planning conditions. The Royal Borough will use all legal powers at its disposal to ensure planning conditions are followed.
shortdescription: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea planners have ordered work on a basement development to stop unless the developer, W11 Construction Ltd and the owner Blue Arrow Ltd, stick to a construction traffic management plan following residents' complaints that construction vehicles were not keeping to agreed routes.
shorttitle: Two legal notices served after complaints about basement development

headline: PROTECTING KENSINGTON AND CHELSEA'S PLAY SERVICES
prcopy:
Last night (Thursday 17 July) Cabinet agreed a strategy to protect play services in the Royal Borough and place them on a sustainable financial footing for the future.

The plans would see responsibility for delivering after school and holiday childcare transferred from the Council to primary schools or third sector providers from April 2015. The proposals would also result in community play projects being managed by third sector providers from April 2015, lifting the Council's management burden and protecting valuable front line play services.

Between 2010 and 2014 Government funding for Children's Services fell by £12.3m - approximately a third. As a big spending department the Council's Play Service is inevitably affected.

These plans would yield the greatest levels of savings for the Council (over £1.3 million in the first three years), whilst preserving a comprehensive childcare offer for working parents and at the same time protecting community play projects. Up and down the country only a very small minority of local authorities provide play and childcare services directly.

Six of the borough's primary schools are already providing high quality after school childcare and play services that reflect local needs at no cost to the Council. In the autumn, the Council will provide schools with business support so that this model can be replicated borough-wide from April 2015.

Primary schools will also be given transitional funding so this service remains affordable, ensuring that any fee increases are gradual and in line with the introduction of the new childcare benefit. From September 2015 working families will be able to access the new tax-free childcare scheme allowing them to recover 20 per cent of their childcare costs. Families on low incomes will continue to be supported.

Councillor Elizabeth Campbell, the Royal Borough's Cabinet Member for Family and Children's Service, said:

"We know how vital it is that our parents can access affordable, high quality after school childcare and primary schools in Kensington and Chelsea are already successfully delivering this service.

"Faced with large reductions in Government funding we can no longer afford to subsidise childcare for working parents, especially when most will be receiving the new childcare benefit next year.

"We firmly believe that primary schools and social enterprises have the expertise needed to build upon our existing play service so that it remains one of the best in the Capital."
shortdescription: Last night (Thursday 17 July) Cabinet agreed a strategy to protect play services in the Royal Borough and place them on a sustainable financial footing for the future.
shorttitle: Protecting Kensington and Chelsea's play services

headline: Future of Thamesbrook to be debated
prcopy:
The Royal Borough's Cabinet last night (Thursday 17 July) gave officers the go-ahead to review options for Thamesbrook, a nursing and care home for older people in Chelsea.

The 56-bed home* is currently temporarily closed following the discovery of intractable Legionella bacteria in the water system, which, despite the best efforts of the staff, led to an unacceptable reduction in care standards at the home and a planned evacuation of residents was carried out.

Built in the 1960s, Thamesbrook is one of the few homes in the UK still run by a local authority and the only one run by the Council. As well as Legionella, the building has many other defects. It is tired and institutional. Rooms are some 16 per cent smaller than modern standards. None can be classified as wheelchair compliant. The furniture layout is relatively fixed, meaning residents have less choice about where things go and what personal items they can bring in and several rooms cannot meet current care standards because it is impossible to provide care from either side of the bed.

In addition, the overall layout of narrow winding corridors and units spread across three floors makes supervision much more difficult and contributes to far higher running costs than the norm. A place at Thamesbrook costs approximately twice as much as a place in a private nursing home offering objectively higher standards of accommodation**.

During last night's debate, the Cabinet heard that to simply reopen Thamesbrook on an `as was' basis would require extensive repair and plant modernisation necessitating many months of further closure. And the cost of that would be considerable at a time when the traditional old people's home looks increasingly outdated.

Rather than the one size fits all service offered by Thamesbrook, local authorities are these days trying to deliver care tailored or `personalised' to individual need. The review will consider four options including refurbishing the home, remodelling it, replacing it with extra care units either on the site or elsewhere.

In extra care housing schemes older people rent, lease or buy their own homes in developments where care is available on site in the quantity and type needed, and which can "scale up" as people become older and frailer. The evidence is that the extra care approach produces more years of good health and independence but there is a severe shortage of this kind of accommodation in the Royal Borough ***.

Commenting on the Cabinet decision to order a fundamental review, Cllr Mary Weale, Cabinet Member for Adult Social Care, said:

"The building simply does not meet the standards we want for our older people. It is also very expensive to run in its current configuration. It was a difficult decision to move residents but having been convinced of the advisability and done so, we should now pause and reflect on the future of Thamesbrook to make sure that we provide the best possible facilities for elderly residents.

"Before we take any decision about its future, we intend to consult."
shortdescription: The Royal Borough's Cabinet last night (Thursday 17 July) gave officers the go-ahead to review options for Thamesbrook, a nursing and care home for older people in Chelsea.
shorttitle: Future of Thamesbrook to be debated

headline: FOUR LEGAL NOTICES SERVED ON BASEMENT DEVELOPERS IN SW7
prcopy:
Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea planners have ordered work on basement developments at three properties on Clareville Grove and Clareville Street in SW7 to stop unless the developers stick to agreed construction traffic management plans following residents' concerns that vehicles were causing disruption along the two streets.

The three properties, 3C Clareville Grove, 19 Clareville Grove and 42-44 Clareville Street, are all currently implementing planning permissions for basement developments and other associated works. The granting of each of these permissions was subject to a condition that disturbance to residents by construction traffic would be minimised through adherence to a Construction Traffic Management Plan (CTMP).

Following complaints received by the Council about traffic associated with the developments, planners made a series of visits to the two streets during which time construction works at all three properties were found to be in breach of the requirements of the respective CTMPs. Consequently, the Council's Planning Enforcement Team issued Breach of Condition Notices on the property owners and the development companies Alonso Builders, Capitol Construction and M J Rooney. Furthermore, a Temporary Stop Notice was served on Capitol Construction at 19 Clareville Grove due the repeated nature of the offence. The effect of these notices means any future breaches of the CTMP by the developers will be a criminal offence. Each breach witnessed could lead to a maximum penalty of £20,000 in a magistrates court and unlimited if heard in a crown court.

Cllr Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: "The Council is increasingly clamping down on developers who fail to comply with planning conditions, and the action taken in these two streets underlines our concerted efforts to hold developers to their word and prevent their actions from disrupting the lives of our residents."

Construction traffic in residential areas, particularly from basement developments, can have a big impact on the lives of neighbouring residents if developers ignore their planning conditions. The Royal Borough will use all legal powers at its disposal to ensure planning conditions are followed. Over the last two months nine legal notices have been served by the Planning Enforcement Team on developers for breaching their CTMPs.
shortdescription: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea planners have ordered work on basement developments at three properties on Clareville Grove and Clareville Street in SW7 to stop unless the developers stick to agreed construction traffic management plans following residents' concerns that vehicles were causing disruption along the two streets.
shorttitle: Four legal notices served on basement developers in SW7

headline: TWO DAYS LEFT TO RESPOND TO TfL'S CROSSRAIL 2 STATION CONSULTATION
prcopy:
Residents and businesses have just two days left to respond to TfL's consultation on the route for Crossrail 2 and the Council is urging residents to help make sure the line stops in Chelsea.

In the past six weeks TfL has been consulting on three options: one with a station at Dovehouse Street, another with a station further west at Cremorne, and one that bypasses the borough altogether.

The consultation ends on Friday 25 July and residents can have their say online at www.crossrail2.co.uk

"After so many years of campaigning for Crossrail 2 it would be a disaster if we were to fall at the final hurdle," said Cllr Tim Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Transport.

"Chelsea is poorly served by public transport. Our streets are congested and our air quality is poor. A Crossrail station would make a massive difference so it's worrying at this late stage to see an option there that bypasses Chelsea altogether. We urge as many residents as possible to get involved in the consultation and demand our station."

The Council has long supported the idea of a new rail line connecting south-west and north-east London and last year it checked to make sure the people of Chelsea agreed.

About 3,000 Chelsea residents and businesses replied to the Council's survey, with around 70 per cent expressing support for the new line and a station in Chelsea.

There was more support than opposition right across the survey area, although support was particularly high to the west. And while there was strong support for a station at the Chelsea Fire Station site on Dovehouse Street, opinion was divided almost equally between those who felt this was the best location and those who thought it might be better placed further west.

The Council itself supports the Chelsea Fire Station option because it believes this site offers the best combination of public transport and economic benefits.


Crossrail 2 would relieve pressure on major London stations such as Euston, Victoria and Clapham Junction and ease congestion on very busy Tube lines. In some cases, journey times could be more than halved.

The line would pass deep under Chelsea and a station on the King's Road would, among other things, link residents to Clapham Junction, the West End and four of London's busiest mainline stations.

The idea for Crossrail 2, formerly called the Chelsea-Hackney Line, has been around for many decades, with the Chelsea Fire Station having long been earmarked as a potential site for the station.

Parts of Chelsea remain poorly served by public transport and the Council believes the line would:

 dramatically improve local transport options

 relieve local and city-wide congestion

 ease pressure on the transport network

 improve air quality

 dramatically improve journey times

 help the hard-pressed retail sector


Residents can also participate online at http://www.crossrail2.co.uk
shortdescription: Residents and businesses have just two days left to respond to TfL's consultation on the route for Crossrail 2 and the Council is urging residents to help make sure the line stops in Chelsea.
shorttitle: Two days left to respond to TfL's Crossrail 2 station consultation

headline: COUNCIL STEPS IN TO FUND EMERGENCY HELP
prcopy:
Emergency financial support for people in crisis will be protected in Kensington and Chelsea next year despite the cancellation of the government grant which funds it.

Previously paid by the Department of Work and Pensions (DWP), emergency support grants were delegated to local authorities in 2013. However the DWP has now indicated that it intends to withdraw the money which pays for them. As a result, Kensington and Chelsea has decided to step in and meet the cost itself which is estimated to be £435,000 in 2015/16.

In 2013/14 Royal Borough emergency grants helped hundreds of people on benefits to move from B&Bs into unfurnished homes, flee domestic violence, repair or replace broken down cookers and fridges or simply keep body and soul together following crime, flood or other misfortune.

Councillor Warwick Lightfoot, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's Cabinet Member for Finance and Strategy, said: "It is plain that the public finances remain a serious constraint and that the government and local authorities are having to take very difficult decisions to ensure that they are sustainable in the future.

"But no one should believe it is easy for local government to absorb this cut. Our decision to use the Council's money to replace central government funding means that we have to make further progress in increasing our efficiency, getting better value for the money we spend and more efficient use of the property assets that we own. It is increased efficiency and economy that enables the Council to continue to help vulnerable people in practical ways."

In addition to paying emergency support grants Kensington and Chelsea is also intending to again bridge the gap between the government grant to pay council tax benefit and the full cost. The government grant covers only 90 per cent of the cost of the benefit but rather than ask its poorest residents to find the remainder the Council will for a third year pay the difference at a cost of £1million.
shortdescription: Emergency financial support for people in crisis will be protected in Kensington and Chelsea next year despite the cancellation of the government grant which funds it.
shorttitle: Council steps in to fund emergency help

headline: COMMEMORATION OF THE BEGINNING OF THE FIRST WORLD WAR AT ST MARY ABBOTS
prcopy:
On Monday 4 August the nation will be commemorating the centenary of the outbreak of the First World War, and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea will be marking the occasion with great solemnity.

At the war memorial, outside St Mary Abbots Church, off Kensington High Street, there will be an opportunity for members of the public to light a candle and leave it burning, in remembrance of the outbreak of the war. Candles have been generously sponsored by JH Kenyon Funeral Directors and any donations collected at the war memorial will go to the Royal British Legion.

During the day the church will be open as usual for people to come in for quiet contemplation and prayer. In addition, at each hour, passages from the Great War poets and scripture will be read aloud. The first reading will be read at 11am by Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds, Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, who will also lay a wreath at the memorial to the postal workers who died between 1914-18. In addition, a bell will be tolled for each of the 177 men from St Mary Abbots who died during the first war.

Speaking about the event the Mayor said: "The sheer scale of death and injury during the First World War is almost unimaginable. Services like this one at St Mary Abbots help us to remember the effect it had on local people's lives. It brings home the sacrifice made for us by a previous generation of Kensington residents."

There will be an opportunity for members of the public to write their own prayers, and display them on a prayer wall. These prayers will be read at the services of Morning and Evening Prayer, and Holy Communion during the rest of the week. At 1.05pm, there will be a very simple service of Holy Communion, with a particular focus on the beginning of the war (and the breaking of the peace), to which all are welcome.

At 10pm, the day culminates with a vigil, lasting about an hour, including some music, readings, and silence. Once again, all are welcome to this service. It will begin in church, and end with a candlelit procession to the war memorial, where the candles will finally be extinguished, in recollection of the words of Sir Edward Grey after war had been declared, "The lamps are going out all over Europe."
shortdescription: On Monday 4 August the nation will be commemorating the centenary of the outbreak of the First World War, and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea will be marking the occasion with great solemnity.
shorttitle: Commemoration of the beginning of the First World War at St Mary Abbots

headline: FOOD GLORIOUS FOOD FOR OXFORD GARDENS PRIMARY SCHOOL PUPILS
prcopy:
Pupils from Oxford Gardens Primary School had food on the brain when they took part in a week-long Food Explorers programme designed to raise awareness about where their food comes from, encourage healthy eating and increase the number of children who have breakfast.

As well as beginning to plant in their new edible teaching garden the pupils took to the road to visit Phoenix Farm, Jamie Oliver's Recipease and Whole Foods on Kensington High Street for hands-on cooking demonstrations and lessons.

The school also had visits from local food champions and activities included: baking with The Crazy Baker (Sophie Grey), burger making with the Provenance Village Butcher, learning to read food labels and finding hidden sugars with a registered dietitian and a school-wide smoothie making competition.

Funding, to enable the children to take part in the week's activities, was allocated by St Helens and Notting Dale Councillors through the City Living Local Life programme.

Councillor Judith Blakeman of Notting Dale ward commented: "Notting Dale councillors supported Food Explorers because many children from our ward attend Oxford Gardens School. We believe it is vitally important that children learn both how to grow food and how to cook and eat healthily. These skills will now be transmitted down the generations and be invaluable for local families for years to come."

Councillor Eve Allison of St Helen's ward, said: "Inquiring, enthusiastic, passionate and enthralled from years one to six, the drive and energy was clearly there as the children and I mucked in to plant the seeds. This will enhance and serve as a platform in instilling and engaging with the earth the role we all have from children to councillors to get involved and to be resourceful."

Commenting on the week, Oxford Garden's Head Teacher, Sarah Cooper, said: "I can't thank Food Explorers enough for involving us in the project

"The children had a fabulous week with so many experiences that I know they will remember for a very long time."
shortdescription: Pupils from Oxford Gardens Primary School had food on the brain when they took part in a week-long Food Explorers programme designed to raise awareness about where their food comes from, encourage healthy eating and increase the number of children who have breakfast.
shorttitle: Food glorious food for Oxford Gardens primary school pupils

headline: PLANNERS SERVE NOTICE TO STOP WORKS ON BASEMENT DEVELOPMENT
prcopy:
Alterations to a listed building, including the construction of a basement and the erection of a mews house, have been ordered to stop by planners from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea unless the developer sticks to the agreed plans.

A failure by the developer, BlackOnyx Developments Ltd, to ensure vehicles associated with the works kept to an agreed Construction Traffic Management Plan (CTMP) led to complaints from residents.

Planning permission for the work on the listed building at 12 Pembroke Square, W8 was granted subject to a condition that disturbance to residents from construction traffic would be minimised by adherence to the CTMP.

After complaints were received about traffic associated with the development planners visited the site and witnessed a breach of the CTMP. Consequently, the Council's Planning Enforcement Team issued Breach of Condition Notices and a Temporary Stop Notice on the Wednesday 30 July 2014 to deter any further breaches. The effect of these notices means any future breaches of the CTMP by the developers will be a criminal offence. Each breach witnessed could lead to a maximum penalty of £20,000 in a magistrates court and unlimited if heard in a crown court.

Construction traffic in residential areas, particularly from basement developments, can have a big impact on the lives of neighbouring residents if developers ignore their planning conditions. The Royal Borough will use all legal powers at its disposal to ensure planning conditions are followed. Over the last three months 14 legal notices have been served by the Planning Enforcement Team on developers for breaching their CTMPs.
shortdescription: Alterations to a listed building, including the construction of a basement and the erection of a mews house, have been ordered to stop by planners from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea unless the developer sticks to the agreed plans.
shorttitle: Planners serve notice to stop works on basement development

headline: HEALING WORDS
prcopy:
Residents who'd like to hear how the written word can help in the battle to beat the black dog of depression are invited to support a special mayoral fundraiser at Kensington Town Hall on Thursday 9 October.

Along with a chance to find out more about depression and other mental health conditions, guests can hear readings from celebrities whilst being treated to champagne and canapés.

The event starts at 6.30pm and tickets are £45.

All proceeds will go to SANE, the Royal Borough's Mayoral charity of the year, which works to improve the lives of people affected by mental illness.

The Mayor, Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds, said: "I am very much looking forward to hearing some of our celebrity guests read extracts from their favourite works. SANE recognises that consoling poems and healing words are key weapons in the battle to beat depression and other mental ill-health, and their campaign shows how words can provide solace at a time of need."

Marjorie Wallace, chief executive of SANE, said: "We hope our #healingwords campaign will help people see their sadness in context. From the experience and writings of others who have fought depression, we know that words can provide comfort and strength at times of crisis."

The celebrity readers will be confirmed closer to the event.

Tickets can be purchased from the Mayor's Office by calling 020 7361 3659 or by emailing mayor@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Residents who'd like to hear how the written word can help in the battle to beat the black dog of depression are invited to support a special mayoral fundraiser at Kensington Town Hall on Thursday 9 October.
shorttitle: Healing words

headline: ROAD CLOSURES ON SUNDAY 10 AUGUST FOR PRUDENTIAL RIDELONDON
prcopy:
Roads in Kensington and Chelsea will be affected on Sunday 10 August when 24,000 amateur riders and 150 professional cyclists follow a route from east London out to Surrey before returning to London for a finish on The Mall.

Cyclists will enter the borough in Knightsbridge and travel along the A4 before passing into Hammersmith and Fulham. Later in the day cyclists will return to the borough via King's Road, Ashburnham Road, Cremorne Road, Cheyne Walk and Chelsea Embankment.

Closing 100 miles of roads and bridges across London and Surrey will have a major impact on traffic, public transport and parking. It is not just the roads the cyclists ride along that will be affected. Many other local roads will be closed to traffic from the early hours of Sunday 10 August to allow the event to pass safely through the borough. It is anticipated roads will remain closed until the early evening. Vehicles parked on the route will be removed. If you normally park your vehicle on any of the roads affected you will need to make alternative arrangements on Sunday 10 August.

Roads along the route will be closed from 5am on Sunday 10 August and will not fully reopen until the early evening.

In the borough it is anticipated that Knightsbridge, Brompton Road and the Cromwell Road will close at 5am and are not expected to open until approximately 3pm.

King's Road, Cheyne Walk and Chelsea Embankment are expected to close at 7.30am and will remain closed until about 7pm.

For further information and advice about travel disruption go to www.tfl.gov.uk/campaign/prudential-ridelondon/travel-disruption-and-advice

More information about Prudential RideLondon and details of the route can be found on the organiser's website www.prudentialridelondon.co.uk
shortdescription: Roads in Kensington and Chelsea will be affected on Sunday 10 August when 24,000 amateur riders and 150 professional cyclists follow a route from east London out to Surrey before returning to London for a finish on The Mall.
shorttitle: Road closures on Sunday 10 August for Prudential RideLondon

headline: EDIBLE FOREST FOR HOLLAND PARK
prcopy:
A major high street retailer and a local charitable foundation are joining forces to support the creation of a new edible forest teaching garden at the Holland Park Ecology Centre.

On Wednesday 6 August Whole Foods on Kensington High Street will work with the Kensington and Chelsea Foundation to raise funds for this exciting educational project. Five per cent of the day's net sales will go towards creating this new teaching garden.

The garden will allow children from local primary schools with limited access to green space to gain practical experience of where food comes from and how it is grown. This garden will be planted with fruit trees, berries, herbs, vegetables and flowering perennials with an emphasis on native planting.

The Council has planned to create an edible teaching garden since the new Ecology Centre opened last year. The aims of the garden are to:

 engage young people from local primary schools in growing food
 improve understanding of where food comes from, how it is grown and seasonality
 promote scientific knowledge of ecology in the context of growing food
 expose young people to more flavours and ingredients
 inspire young people to be more adventurous about what they eat, be more open to eating fruit and vegetables and help them make healthier choices
shortdescription: A major high street retailer and a local charitable foundation are joining forces to support the creation of a new edible forest teaching garden at the Holland Park Ecology Centre.
shorttitle: Edible forest for Holland Park

headline: USE OF UNAUTHORISED VEHICLE ROUTES LEADS TO FINE FOR CATALYST HOUSING LIMITED
prcopy:
Catalyst Housing Limited was fined £9,000 today Tuesday 12 August and ordered to pay the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea's costs of £6,900 at Hammersmith Magistrates' Court for failing to comply with a Breach of Condition Notice on six separate occasions. The notice was served as there was a failure to follow an agreed Construction Traffic Management Plan required as part of the conditional planning permission at the Wornington Green development in North Kensington

The decision by the Council to prosecute Catalyst Housing was taken after it became apparent that vehicles, used by Ardmore, the contractor employed by Catalyst, were not following agreed routes in and out of the construction site. This included unauthorised routes through the Golborne Market in Golborne Road. Repeated warnings by Council officers of the need to stick to the approved routes were not heeded.

The court heard that Catalyst had placed contractual obligations on Ardmore to follow the agreed route but, on occasions, these had not been followed. It also heard that Catalyst had now arranged for more traffic marshals to ensure the planning condition was followed.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: "It is very important that Construction Management Plans are followed. We live in a crowded borough and have to make sure that a balance between much needed regeneration and development and the safety and peace of residents is met."

Students from schools in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea are celebrating excellent A level results today (Thursday 14 August).

Overall the Royal Borough was well above the national average with 41 per cent gaining A* and A grades (national 26 per cent), 73 per cent A* to B (national 52 per cent) and 92 per cent A* to C (national 77 per cent).

headline: Sign up for a good singsong
prcopy:
Residents are invited to take part in an exciting singing for health programme in Kensington and Chelsea called Sing to Live, Live to Sing! organised by the Council.

The Council launched the initiative as a pilot programme in June and, due to its success, a new series of workshops will begin in September.

Drop-in taster sessions will run at Chelsea Theatre and Dalgarno Community Centre. The taster sessions are followed by a course of ten weekly workshops, which are free and registration is open to all residents aged 16 years and over. Further sessions at other venues in the borough are also planned. No previous singing experience is necessary. Participants will be invited to fill in a short health survey during the workshop series.

Singing can help to improve breathing, relieve stress, develop core muscles and improve posture. Participants from previous workshops have reported benefits such as meeting new people, confidence building, calming anxiety, feeling uplifted, and enjoying something new.

Irene Lyford, who attended the Dalgarno Community Centre workshops in June, said:

“I've just been to the singing workshop and want to let you know how much I enjoyed it. I thought the teacher was wonderful and made the evening such fun.”

All workshops are led by experienced leaders and focus on breathing, movement and relaxation, as well as learning to sing.

The taster sessions will run at:
Chelsea Theatre
Tuesday 9 September, from 7pm to 9pm
Friday 12 September, from 10am to12pm

Dalgarno Community Centre
Monday 22 September, from 2pm to 4pm
Thursday 25 September, from 5pm to 7pm

The weekly workshops will follow the taster sessions at the same venues and times for a further ten weeks.

Participants can sign up for the workshops by contacting the venues directly, dropping in to either venue to register, or by going along to a taster session.

michelle@chelseatheatre.org.uk

headline: Carnival mApp
prcopy:

It works with GPS to show you where you are and the maps still work on your smart phone even when there is no mobile reception.

The carnival mApp is available as a free download from Apple Store and Google Play, as well as from the web www.notting-hill-carnival-mapp.com

The Mayor of London, Boris Johnson said: “This useful free App will help guide thousands of people around the carnival footprint to enjoy the array of floats, sounds and delicious Caribbean cuisines. It will also come in handy when planning entrance and exit points, ensuring you make the most of your celebrations this bank holiday weekend. With the 50th Anniversary of steel pan, colourful costume parades and wealth of live music acts, I hope everyone has a truly amazing carnival.”

The mApp was commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and is run by the Carnival organisers, London Notting Hill Carnival Trust Enterprises Ltd.

headline: GCSE success for Royal Borough schools
prcopy:
Pupils from Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea schools are celebrating GCSE success after the exam results were announced today (Thursday 21 August).

This is the first year of results following a switch to a greater emphasis on exams at the end of a two-year course, rather than coursework and modular units and has resulted in the national percentage of students achieving A* to C grades in English falling.

At Holland Park School 86 per cent of students gained the all important five A* to C grades, including English and mathematics.

The school is particularly proud of its English Baccalaureate figure which has risen from 43 per cent to 46 per cent this year. This is the proportion of students who have gained the combination of English, mathematics, double science, a language and a humanities subject at GCSE.

This year, 63 per cent of Holland Park students achieved A* to B, a record for the school, whilst 86 per cent achieved grades A* to C. English results were unaffected by national changes to make the qualification tougher and 94 per cent of students gained A* to C in the subject.

There were outstanding performances from some of the school’s most gifted Year 11 students. Nine such students opened envelopes bringing the news of ten A*s in GCSEs. Olabimpe Popoola is one such student and, after reading her results, she commented: “I am absolutely delighted and overwhelmed by my wonderful results. I am now looking forward to returning to Holland Park’s sixth form to continue my studies.”

Hamish Iyer not only achieved a raft of A*s at GCSE but also an A grade in A2 mathematics a year early. Hamish described his results as “glorious” and said: “My aspiration for a career in medicine appears to be on course thanks to Holland Park.”

These figures make this year the highest recorded GCSE achievement in the school’s history. Colin Hall, Head of Holland Park School, said: I am incredibly proud of our students' achievements. They are a testament to the diligence and strongly collaborative working relationships that exist between students and teachers at Holland Park School."

It was also an historic day for the Chelsea Academy which received its first set of GCSE results.
