headline: London's largest clean-up
prcopy:
Street cleaners and refuge collectors from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea braved the elements last night to clear up after Europe’s biggest street festival.

Early estimates are that close to 200 tonnes have been removed from the streets of Notting Hill and North Kensington over the two days of the Carnival.

A well rehearsed operation kicked into gear when the police gave the go ahead for 30 refuse trucks, mechanical street cleaners, a specialised motorway cleaning vehicle and a team of 200 street cleaners to move on to the streets vacated by thousands of festival goers.

The operation which is carried out by SITA, the Council’s contractors, aims to restore the streets to their normal clean state by 5am on Tuesday. However, the Council will continue to patrol the Carnival area for the coming days to check that nothing has been missed.

Cllr Nick Paget Brown, Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: “Cleaning up after Europe’s biggest street festival is an enormous undertaking which we try to complete as quickly as possible. I would like to thank everyone who worked through the night to get the job down and of course our residents for their patience.”
shortdescription: Street cleaners and refuge collectors from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea braved the elements last night to clear up after Europe’s biggest street festival.

headline: Impressive Key Stage 2 results for borough schools
prcopy:
Royal Borough pupils have, once again, achieved amongst the very highest results in the country for Key Stage 2 (age 11) performance.

Results, published yesterday (Thursday 28 August) by the DfE, show that 84 per cent of children in Kensington and Chelsea schools achieved the expected Level 4+ in Key Stage 2 reading, writing and mathematics. This is in line with last year’s result, and is six percentage points above the published national (state-funded) result of 78 per cent. The results rank the borough third in inner London and eighth nationally.

The results for those achieving Level 5+ for reading writing and mathematics were also impressive with 36 per cent reaching the standard - thirteen percentage points above national average and ranking the borough second in England and first in inner London.

The percentage of children in the borough making expected levels of progress in reading, writing and mathematics, reaching expected levels in grammar, punctuation and spelling and achieving the exceptional level 6 in individual subjects was also well above national figures.

Commenting on the results Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea’s Cabinet Member for Education, said: “These results confirm that an education in a Royal Borough school stands out as being amongst the very best in the country and I would like to thank head teachers and teachers for the excellent work they do in continuing to help children reach these standards.”
shortdescription: Royal Borough pupils have, once again, achieved amongst the very highest results in the country for Key Stage 2 (age 11) performance.
shorttitle: Impressive Key Stage 2 results for borough schools

headline: Raising the curtain on slavery
prcopy:
Residents of the Royal Borough are being invited to mark Anti-Slavery Day on Monday 20 October by attending a performance of the play 'Hurried Steps' by Nobel Prize for Literature nominated, Dacia Maraini at Kensington Town Hall.

The play looks at issues including child trafficking and is based on real stories.

Following each performance there will be a discussion with a panel of experts, including representatives from the Council and charities involved in the issues, such as Rahab, who work both locally, supporting women who have been trafficked, and internationally to prevent sex trafficking.

There are two performances on the day, at 12.30pm and 7.30pm in the Small Hall.

Tickets are £10 for adults and £7 concessions. There are also discounts for community and school groups. Email commsafe@rbkc.gov.uk for more information or go to http://www.ticketsource.co.uk/search to buy tickets.

headline: Grade I listed building protected
prcopy:
Planners from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have ordered the owners of the Grade I listed building, Debenham House on Addison Road, W14 to stop unauthorised works or face prosecution.

The Council granted planning permission in 2009.  However, following a number of visits to the property to monitor compliance, planning officers noticed discrepancies between the work carried out on site and the contents of the planning permission. Due to the historical significance of the building, planning officers immediately took action to prevent any further unauthorised works to the property.

Consequently, the Council’s Planning Enforcement Team issued a Temporary Stop Notice on Friday 28 August 2014 which prevents all development that does not have the benefit of planning permission. If unauthorised works continue the owner, Blue Oval Holdings Limited, will have committed a criminal offence which could lead to a maximum penalty of £20,000 in a magistrates' court and unlimited if heard in a crown court.

Cllr Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: “We are justly proud of the historic assets and built environment of the Royal Borough and our planners will ensure that people do not abuse them.

“While we understand people want to make their homes fit their lives, if you own a building with such an important character you must accept you are the custodian of the building for future generations and act accordingly.”

The house was originally commissioned in 1905 by department store owner Ernest Ridley Debenham, who lived there with his family. It was designed by the architect Halsey Ricardo in the Arts and Crafts style. The house was built using ceramic tiles, pale terracotta and coloured glazed bricks. It received its Grade I listing in 1969 and has been the set of several films and TV shows. Grade I listed buildings are considered to be of exceptional interest and part of the country’s built heritage.

shorttitle: Grade I listed building protected

headline: New Kensington Leisure Centre a step closer
prcopy:
The new Kensington Leisure Centre reached a major milestone today (Monday 8 September) when the highest point was marked with a traditional topping out ceremony.

Historically, the topping out ceremony marks the topmost beam being placed on the building to complete the structure. Its origins hark back to pagan times when the purpose of the ceremony was to ward off evil spirits and bless the building.

The topping out ceremony was attended by the Leader of the Council, Councillor Nick Paget-Brown, the Cabinet Member for Leisure, Councillor Tim Ahern and the Mayor of the Royal Borough, Councillor Maighread Condon-Simmonds.

Highlights of the proposals include: a 25-metre, eight-lane swimming pool for teaching and swimming at all levels; 250-seat spectator gallery; 20-metre teaching pool with mobile floor; 120-station gym; eight-court multi-use hall; two fitness studios and sauna/steam facilities with treatment rooms. The development is being delivered by Bouygues UK.

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Leisure, said:

“Work on site is progressing in leaps and bounds and we are on track for Kensington Leisure Centre to be open to the public by early next year.

“Physical exercise is one of the most important things we can do to stay healthy and we are committed to ensuring that all of our residents can access state-of-the-art sports facilities.

“Our substantial investment in a new leisure centre will ensure that it is one of the best public sports facilities in the Capital.”

The Royal Borough is spending £29.4m on a new Kensington Leisure Centre and Chelsea Sports Centre on Chelsea Manor Street recently benefitted from a new gym following a £1.36m refurbishment.

For more information on the scheme visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/kalc

shorttitle: New Kensington Leisure Centre a step closer

headline: Carers' views on support sought
prcopy:
Residents who look after a family member, partner or friend who is in need of support may be asked to take part in a national survey over the next few weeks. The Royal Borough is supporting the survey organised by the Department of Health and is asking that residents who receive it take time to make their views known. The survey will ask carers for their thoughts on the support available and how caring for others has affected their quality of life.

It will take place between October and December 2014. Residents, who are included in the survey, will receive a postal questionnaire and be asked to respond to it by a set date. All answers will be treated confidentially and information will not be shared with individuals or teams delivering services to the carer or the person they are looking after.

If you receive a questionnaire and have difficulty completing it, you can ask a friend, relative or an advocate to help you.  Advice and assistance is also available by contacting Nadia Husain on 020 7361 2552, free phone number 0800 587 0072 or via email at HSSCustomercare@rbkc.gov.uk.

Staff involved in providing services to the carer or the individual they care for are not permitted to help complete the questionnaire.

headline: Borough scoops array of gold London in Bloom awards
prcopy:
The Royal Borough’s green credentials were well and truly recognised by London in Bloom when the Council won a bunch of awards in this year’s competition.

Kensington and Chelsea, which is one of London’s most densely populated boroughs, won the In Bloom award for biodiversity, gold in the City Category while seven parks received gold awards and two earned silver gilt awards.

Little Wormwood Scrubs won gold and the prestigious Large Park of the Year Award

The St Quintin Avenue Community Kitchen Garden was named Allotment Award runner up – not bad for a garden created just five years ago on a disused tennis court.

Eleven of the borough’s community gardens received an ‘It’s Your Neighbourhood’ Award, the most of any London borough.

The Churchill Arms, Kensington Church Street, won Best Pub Display and was runner up in the Floral Display Award.

The judges, who toured the borough in July, were particularly impressed by the Council’s work to enhance and protect biodiversity by working with partners such as the community group at Meanwhile Gardens and gardeners from the impressive wildlife garden at the Natural History Museum.

Commenting on the awards Cllr Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough’s Cabinet Member for the Environment, said: “It is wonderful to see that the commitment of our parks’ team, community gardeners and residents to develop and enhance our green spaces be rewarded with so many awards.

“Just five years ago the Council took over the management of Little Wormwood Scrubs. Since then we have worked closely with residents to improve it and enhance its facilities and now this hard work has seen it named Large Park of the Year.”

“However, we are not going to rest on our laurels because we’re always looking for new areas to green and new ways to enhance the borough’s biodiversity. Our gardeners, residents and parks teams are always up for the challenge of maintaining our high standards. “
shortdescription: The Royal Borough’s green credentials were well and truly recognised by London in Bloom when the Council won a bunch of awards in this year’s competition.
shorttitle: Borough scoops array of gold London in Bloom awards

headline: Have your say on a new policy for busking in the Royal Borough
prcopy:
Buskers, residents, businesses and market traders are being asked for their views on a draft policy to control busking in Kensington and Chelsea’s markets.

On a Saturday there are often large numbers of musicians and entertainers in the Portobello Market area. Following complaints from market traders, residents and businesses the policy seeks to control busking in a pilot area* on Fridays and Saturdays, between 10am and 6pm.

The consultation will run until Sunday 19 October 2014. If implemented, the new policy will be trialled for 12 months, coming into effect in spring/summer 2015. Buskers would need to apply to the Council for a licence to perform in the pilot area during controlled hours (Fridays and Saturdays 10am to 6pm). Busking would continue to be permitted outside of these hours, likewise it will be uncontrolled in the rest of the Royal Borough.

“Portobello and Golborne markets have a rich cultural history which attracts buskers and their audiences. However, the Council has received a number of complaints from traders and residents related to busking. We are looking to adopt a policy which will allow the Council to balance the different needs of traders, residents and buskers and are consulting on these proposals as required by the London Local Authorities Act,” said Councillor Tim Ahern, the Council’s Cabinet Member for Environment, Environmental Health and Leisure.

The draft policy and questionnaire can be found at www.rbkc.gov.uk/streetentertaining or picked up from the Markets Office (72 Tavistock Rd, London, W11 1AN) or the Council Offices (37 Pembroke Road, London W8 6PW).

Consultation stands will take place on the following days from 11am to 2pm inside the Street Trading Office, 72 Tavistock Road, W11 1AN:

Wednesday 17 September
Friday 3 October
Monday 6 October
Thursday 9 October
Tuesday 14 October

headline: Kensington Aldridge Academy opens
prcopy:
Kensington Aldridge Academy welcomed students today (Monday 15 September), as the £28 million school opened for the first day of term.

The Academy is a brand new school and will provide much needed school places for children in the area, as previously more than 50 per cent of students had to travel outside the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea for their secondary education. Today’s intake is in Year 7 only, and the school will grow year-on-year until it offers 900 places for 11 to 16 year olds and up to 240 places for sixth form students. First admissions to the sixth form will be in 2016.

The Academy is sponsored by the Aldridge Foundation, the educational charity whose academies combine a strong academic focus with the development of students’ entrepreneurial skills, and provide support and training to help develop business and social enterprises in local communities. Co-sponsor the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea donated the site to the Academy and has contributed £10.4m towards the building.

Principal David Benson was appointed a year ahead of opening to work with the sponsors on the development of the Academy, and with local schools and parents as interest in the school grew. The Academy received over 500 applications for 184 places last October.

David Benson said: “It is very exciting to welcome our first students to this wonderful new building today. The past year has been about thorough preparation and planning. We have recruited an excellent team of teachers, many of whom have been with us for the last few terms helping to lead the school set up. Recently the Department for Education stated we were ‘one of the best new academies they had ever seen’ in terms of our planning and curriculum development. A strong validation and an excellent foundation on which we can now build.”

“Our Year 6 parents’ information evening in July was a big success, and it was great to see all our parents and students together for the first time. There was an unmistakable buzz of excitement that has been mirrored this morning!

“Today is all about our students getting to know their teachers, classmates and this superb new campus. They have had a chance to explore our specialist classrooms – including for art, science, DT and music; our three libraries, theatre, sports hall and enclosed rooftop sports pitch. Each day of this first induction week has a different theme, from understanding our school motto ‘Intrepidus’ to exploring each of our core values of Excellence, Citizenship, Creativity and Resilience. It will be a great introduction that helps every student make the move from primary to secondary school, feel at home in their new surroundings and enjoy learning with us.”

New student Kashele Phillips said: “I’m very excited to be joining KAA because I know that I’m lucky to be joining a brand new school. All the teachers are really friendly.”

Parent Stephanie Tyrer added: It is clear a lot of thought had gone into making the Academy a serious but welcoming environment. We've been so impressed during the project with the determination of the school's senior management to build a centre of excellence: not just in creating a great facility
noteslabel:
but in recruiting the teaching staff."

Councillor Emma Will

“After years of hard work it is a proud moment for the Council to see the magnificent building that now stands in the heart of North Kensington.

“I’m delighted to be here today to see the pupils looking so fine in their new school uniforms. It’s an exciting chapter for these new students and we look forward to celebrating their future successes.”

The 90-second film, which carries a £1,000 prize, is to be based on the theme of ‘Good neighbours stop rogue traders’ and is aimed at encouraging people to help prevent elderly and vulnerable neighbours, family and friends from falling victim to exploitative doorstep traders.

Completed films must be received by midnight on Wednesday 1 October with an accompanying entry form. You can email your film to pressoffice@tsi.org.uk or send it to:

headline: Nour Festival announces its 2014 programme
prcopy:
The Nour Festival, which celebrates contemporary Middle Eastern and North African arts and culture, takes place in October and November across the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

The six week festival featuring music, film, food, exhibitions, talks and dance launches on Monday 20 October and runs through to Sunday 30 November.

This year, we welcome for the first time new partners including the Royal College of Music, the Finborough Theatre, the Electric Cinema and the Royal Geographical Society.

Festival highlights include: the popular Algerian singer Souad Massi at the Royal Albert Hall; food events curated by chef and author Anissa Helou at Portobello Road Market; and the first UK exhibition by the Tunisian artist Nadia Kaabi-Linke, at the Mosaic Rooms.

It also includes ‘Zoom in Yemen’ a short film competition, which showcases new Yemeni filmmaking talent and is organised in association with the British Council.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough’s Cabinet Member for the Arts, said:

“In just five years Nour has grown from being a pioneering arts education programme based at Leighton House Museum to an all-encompassing cultural festival which this year features 32 partners. Each year Nour introduces more new friends and welcomes new audiences.
 
“Through the diversity and quality of the work it presents, Nour challenges stereotypes of the Arab world and its peoples, fostering friendship and understanding.  Nour defines city life in Kensington and Chelsea in late autumn. I hope as many people as possible join with us in celebrating and enjoying this year’s festival.”

For the full programme and more information visit www.nourfestival.co.uk

Follow Nour on Twitter @NourFestival #NourFestival and Facebook at facebook.com/NourFestival

"

headline: Courtfield ward signs up to City Living, Local Life
prcopy:
Courtfield Ward residents can work with their councillors to make a difference in their neighbourhood after the ward signed up to the City Living, Local Life scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Launched in 2011, City Living, Local Life is a councillor-led, ward-based initiative committed to building stronger connections between people in their local area. It enables residents and community groups to take a lead role in bringing about practical, positive change in their neighbourhoods. The aim of City Living, Local Life is to build on what is already going on in communities, encouraging local people to come forward with their experiences of neighbourhood issues and working with ward councillors to come up with solutions.

The programme gives small amounts of money and lots of practical support to the best ideas. Each ward that takes part in the initiative has a small budget that can be used to help make projects a reality. For wards with three councillors, this is up to £20,000 per year. For those with two councillors, it is up to £14,000. Each area of Kensington and Chelsea is unique, and so are the approaches taken by different wards and the projects supported.

Cllr Gerard Hargreaves, Cabinet Member for Voluntary Organisations and Resident Engagement said: “I am delighted that Courtfield is now part of City Living, Local Life. I’m sure that the local councillors and residents will work closely together to come with plenty of worthwhile projects to enhance and improve their area”

Courtfield councillors will soon be meeting with officers to decide how to kick-start City Living, Local Life activity in their ward. If you live in Courtfield, and want to share an idea go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/citylivinglocallife

For more information about City Living, Local Life go to www.citylivinglocallife.org
shortdescription: Courtfield Ward residents can work with their councillors to make a difference in their neighbourhood after the ward signed up to the City Living, Local Life scheme run by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

headline: Volunteers needed for Poppy Appeal
prcopy:
Volunteers are needed to help the Royal British Legion Poppy Appeal in Kensington and Chelsea.

The money collected by the sale of poppies provides help and support to service men and women and their families. 

Volunteers are being asked to help for a little as just two hours anytime between Saturday 25 October and Sunday 9 November.  There are a variety of jobs available including: collecting, organising collection points, counting and banking the money.

The appeal for volunteers is supported by Royal Borough’s Mayor Cllr Maighread Condon-Simmonds who said: “I hope we can mobilise an army of volunteers this autumn to sell poppies and to do all the tasks behind-the-scenes that support the collectors.  Our Armed Forces give so much for us.  I hope we can respond, not only by giving money, but by giving a couple of hours of our time.

“This year, as the deployment of British Forces in Afghanistan comes to an end and as we pause to remember the centenary of the outbreak of the First World War, the Poppy Appeal will, I am sure, attract even more generous donations than usual.  However, people will not be able to give if there aren't people out there to collect.

If you can volunteer to help contact Nicola Heywood at nahgc@me.com or 07949 441662 or Tim Connolly at: tpaulconnolly1@gmail.com or 07766 752062

"

headline: Dog show raises funds for mental health charity Sane
prcopy:
Some 40 dogs took part in Kensington Memorial Park’s Dog Show on Saturday 14 September wagging their tails, strutting their stuff, performing their best tricks and in the process helping to raise over £280 for the mental health charity, Sane.

The show, organised by the Council’s Parks’ Police was registered with the Kennel Club. Prize for ‘best in show’ went to a Taylor a French Bulldog owned by Jade Conway.  The 'waggiest tail in the show’ was judged to belong to a Cockapoo called Binti owned by Leila Kandouche. Scooby the Toy Poodle was judged the dog that the judges would most like to take home.  A Yorkshire terrier called Lewis won the prize for top canine owned by a resident.

Sane, has been chosen as the mayoral charity by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea’s Mayor Cllr Maighread Condon-Simmonds who said: “The money raised will help fund the charity’s work to improve the life chances of people affected by mental illness. I would like the thank the Parks’ Police for organising the show, all the dog owners who turned up to support it and the judges who had the unenviable job of selecting winners.”

To contribute to Cllr Condon-Simmonds’ mayoral charity Sane go to www.rbkc.gov.uk/mayor.

headline: Planners serve four legal notices on owner of Grade II listed building
prcopy:
The owner of a property in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea has been served with four legal notices, over a three month period, following unauthorised works to a listed building and the Council's concern about the condition and appearance of the property dragging down the rest of the neighbourhood.

Works were carried out on the property at 186 Holland Park Avenue without planning permission and listed building consent. In June 2014, a Temporary Stop Notice was served to prevent unauthorised work continuing and a second notice was also served which required that the condition and appearance of the property be improved. The owner subsequently applied for planning permission retrospectively for the unauthorised works but the planning permission was refused on Friday 19 September 2014.

As a result, a Listed Building Enforcement Notice and Enforcement Notice have been served on the property today (Thursday 25 September) requiring the owner to remove the unauthorised works by Saturday 1 November 2014 or face further legal action.

The property is Grade II listed and the first building both pedestrians and drivers see when entering the Royal Borough from Shepherd's Bush. Its poor condition has attracted many complaints over the years. The property is part of a unified composition which includes the Royal Crescent and numbers 170 to 178 Holland Park Avenue. The set of buildings are inspired by the Royal Crescent’s namesake in Bath, Somerset.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Council's Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: Taken in their entirety
noteslabel: this set of buildings are a work of art and it is the owner’s responsibility to look after and care for their property so future generations can appreciate what has been created. However
notestextcopy: if the owner is not willing to look after their property in a manner befitting a listed building we have the will

resources and legal powers to take action when necessary.”

prcopy:
A blue plaque commemorating Clementine Churchill’s early life in the borough was unveiled by the Mayor, Cllr Maighread Condon-Simmonds yesterday (Thursday 25 September) at 51 Abingdon Villas, W8.

Joining the Mayor was Sir Winston and Lady Churchill’s grandson, Rt Hon Sir Nicholas Soames MP; the three local ward Councillors, Victoria Borwick, Joanna Gardner and James Husband. Also in attendance were the current owners of 51 Abingdon Villas, Ben Wisen and Margaret O’Riordan and also local residents David Charlesworth and Charles Mickleworth who researched and proposed the idea of a blue plaque to the ward Councillors.

Clementine Hozier lived on Abington Villas from 1903 until her marriage to Winston Churchill in 1908.

As Clementine Churchill she took an active role on the home front in both world wars. During the first she organised canteens for munitions workers on behalf of the Young Men’s Christian Association for which she was awarded a CBE in 1918.

In World War 2 Lady Churchill was again involved, this time as Chairman of the Red Cross Aid to Russia Fund, the President of the Young Women's Christian Association War Time Appeal and the Chairman of Fulmer Chase Maternity Hospital for Wives of Junior Officers.

The Mayor, Cllr Condon-Simmonds said: “Lady Clementine Churchill did an huge amount during both world wars, not to mention having to deal with the pressure Sir Winston was under as Prime Minster in such a dark hour. She also worked hard as a cross-bench peer in the House of Lords in later life. I am delighted we are able to recognise her and mark her early life in the Royal Borough.”

Sir Nicholas Soames added: “On behalf of my whole family can I thank the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea for their generosity and kindness in commemorating my grandmother Lady Churchill’s early life in the borough. Can I also thank the current owners of 51 Abingdon Villas and David Charlesworth and Charles Mickleworth, local residents, who proposed the idea of the blue plaque. She would have been very touched to have been remembered in this way.”

The blue plaque is part of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea’s City Living, Local Life initiative. This allows ward Councillors to recommend funding for local schemes which would benefit from a financial contribution from the Council.
shortdescription: A blue plaque commemorating Clementine Churchill’s early life in the borough was unveiled by the Mayor, Cllr Maighread Condon-Simmonds yesterday (Thursday 25 September) at 51 Abingdon Villas, W8.
shorttitle: Blue Plaque for Lady Churchill

headline: Green screen aims to improve playground air quality
prcopy:
St Cuthbert with St Matthias School has held a special assembly to celebrate the installation of a living green screen, made up of ivy, clematis, jasmine and lonicera, which aims to significantly reduce the pupils’ exposure, whilst at school, to nitrogen dioxide and particulate matter vehicle pollution at this busy roadside location in Earl’s Court.

An air quality education programme has seen pupils from year six map their lowest pollution routes to school, create images for no-idling engine posters and script and produce an animated film. To see the film go to http://youtu.be/T4kpqIIYBNI

The assembly was attended by Cllr Tim Ahern, the Royal Borough’s Cabinet Member for Environment, Environmental Health and Leisure, who said: “It is projects like this that have the potential to make a real difference in directly reducing children's exposure to poor air quality. I am impressed with the students' level of understanding of air pollution, its causes and how it may be tackled.

Results from monitoring

headline: Young people and families express themselves through film
prcopy:
Three short films made by young people and families who have worked closely with the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea’s Families Forward Service were given their premier at a special screening at Kensington Town Hall.

The films were made after participants, aged between eight and 38 attended a series of courses, run by See Change Films, designed to provide families and young people with creative ways to express themselves and explore the world around them. In learning to create film, photography and music of a high standard, the participants also learned how to collaborate and work as a team.

Three very different films were screened:

One tells the story of Richard – a former gang member, who lived on the Aylesbury Estate. He shares a candid account of what it was like to be part of a gang – the positive and negative aspects - and how he perceives gangs today. Following the death of his cousin from gang-related violence, Richard transformed his life and is now studying business and marketing at university and training to become a professional boxer. He wants to share the perils of gang life and encourage more young people to speak out about their experiences in gangs.

Another film, about parkour, explores this sport from the perspective of the practitioners who work at Parkour Generations in London. It explains the philosophy, when the sport was introduced and why people love it. It’s a fast-paced film with lots of examples of people using parkour to move from one place to another in London.

The final film is about food and culture and begins with a number of individuals from different cultures and ethnic backgrounds in Notting Hill sharing their favourite cuisine. The story centres on Adam, the owner of Maramia, the only Palestinian restaurant in the UK. Adam gives his perspective on living among many different cultures and how this is different from his experience of growing up in Palestine. He also shares details of his love of food and how his mother, who works with him in the restaurant, is the person who taught him everything he knows.

It was not just the moving image that was celebrated. Photographers produced a multi-media piece which focuses on the young people from groups who went on a trip to Wales, organised by Mountain Wise. The group reflects on where they are from and how this trip to the countryside provided them with the chance to overcome mental and physical challenges.

The filmmakers, composers and photographers were presented with certificates to mark their achievements by the Leader of the Council, Cllr Nick Paget-Brown.

Commenting on the evening, Cllr Paget-Brown, said: “I was very impressed by the quality and content of what were three very different films. I’d like to congratulate all those who worked so hard to make them and thank the Council officers and See Change Films who supported them.”
Al-Kabir Basem, a graduate filmmaker, said: “Oh my god this evening is impressive – it’s very, very joyful for me and I can see what I did and I’m very glad that I can see what we did.
“Basically I’ve learned a lot not just one thing, I’ve learned communication skills, filming skills, interviewing skills, a lot of things. I’ve started to think, maybe I’ll like to be a cameraman. I’m studying at college IT and web design and so I’m thinking I’ll do media as well.”

For more information about the film course go to www.seechangefilms.com/projects/see-change-film-training/ (please note the film profiled on the page is the first film produced by the group and not one of those mentioned above)


For information on the photography course go to
http://seechangephotographytraining.wordpress.com/

headline: Royal Borough's Executive Director for Planning and Borough Development to retire in 2015
prcopy:
Jonathan Bore, the Executive Director for Planning and Borough Development, will be retiring before the end of 2015. A search for his successor is already underway.

Jonathan has worked in different branches of planning for 37 years. Before coming to the Royal Borough he spent 15 years in the Planning Inspectorate making decisions on major developments and planning appeals, and five years with urban designers and master planners Urban Initiatives. Jonathan joined the Council as its Executive Director for Planning and Borough Development at the beginning of 2010; a time when the Royal Borough was already renowned for having some of the most intense development pressures to be found anywhere in the world.

It has been his job to help balance those development pressures against the need to conserve the traditional character of Kensington and Chelsea and the quality of life of its residents. His many contributions to that task include:
• Gaining an exemption for the entire borough from a measure that would have permitted the conversion of offices to homes without planning permission, thus risking a loss of enterprises based in the borough offering local employment
• Reducing turnaround times for planning registration, planning applications and land charge searches and making the major application service the fastest in London
• Getting rid of a backlog of more than 600 overdue planning applications whilst dealing with a 60 per cent increase in workload
• Developing fully electronic working in the Planning Department
• Leading London’s fightback against mega-basements and super-prime flats through the development of tough new policies that include reducing the size of basements to 50 per cent of the garden’s length and just one storey (instead of 85 per cent of the garden and unlimited depth)
• Launching the new and highly popular pre-application advice service which helps to support the Department’s resources
• Expanding the Development Management and Conservation and Design teams
• Creating the Neighbourhood Planning Team
• Creating a dynamic new Planning Enforcement team that takes on developers and contractors who ignore the rules
• Bringing in the policy that stopped pubs from being converted to houses
• Starting the programme of new appraisals for the borough’s conservation areas
• Overseeing the work leading to the production of the SPD and then the planning permission for the Earl’s Court development

When there was last a vacancy for this role, it took time to find a candidate with the right skills. Jonathan has kindly agreed to continue in post through 2015, working fewer days but flexibly to complete important tasks such as bringing in the tougher policy on basement developments; strengthening planning enforcement; maintaining the high standards of service achieved under his leadership; and offering a handover period for a successor. This minimises the risk of a temporary gap if the first search for a new Executive Director comes up short.

Commenting on Jonathan’s decision to retire, Cllr Timothy Coleridge, Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: “With many planning decisions in Kensington and Chelsea, there is a very great deal at stake, both financially and in terms of quality of life. That means that our planning decisions are often fiercely contested, even bitterly so.

“Jonathan Bore has never wilted under that intense pressure. He has been tough, fearless in the face of powerful developers armed with expensive lawyers, and at all times fair. In his time with us, he has done a great deal to conserve the best of this borough for its current residents and to plan improvements for the benefits of its future residents. We are in his debt.”
shortdescription: Jonathan Bore, the Executive Director for Planning and Borough Development, will be retiring before the end of 2015. A search for his successor is already underway.
shorttitle: Royal Borough's Executive Director for Planning and Borough Development to retire in 2015

headline: Hundreds try-out activities aimed at 65+
prcopy:
Dancing, gardening, visiting museums, learning to skype and taking part in phone-in creative writing classes were some of the activities that older residents enjoyed as part of Silver Sunday celebrations.

Hundreds of people aged 65+ took the opportunity to try-out new activities showcased by the borough’s voluntary organisations and Council staff as part of a weeklong promotion of events and activities designed to keep older residents active and engaged in their communities.

The 2011 Census identified 8,200 lone pensioner households in the borough and estimates that just over four in ten older people aged 65+ (43 per cent) live alone.

The Silver Sunday campaign aims to raise awareness among residents of the activities available to help older people stay active and involved in their communities and to give them the opportunity to try-out a new activity and meet others.

Commenting on the activities the Royal Borough’s Silver Sunday champion, Cllr Julie Mills, said: “It was wonderful to see so many well attended events and people enjoying themselves and having fun. The great thing is that these activities are going on throughout the year and can help older people keep active and involved.”

Anyone who missed the opportunity to take part in a Silver Sunday event can email silversunday@rbkc.gov.uk or call 020 7361 2677 to get details of the activities organised by the borough’s voluntary organisations throughout the year.

shorttitle: Hundreds try-out activities aimed at 65+

headline: BT Openreach fined after works breach regulations
prcopy:
Work carried out by Carillion Telent on behalf of BT Openreach, which put pedestrians and motorists at risk, resulted in BT Openreach being fined a total of £6,900 on Tuesday 7 October at Hammersmith Magistrates’ Court after it pleaded guilty to a Section 65 offence and a breach of Regulation 19 of the London Permit Scheme.

The works, which were being carried out on Holland Park Avenue in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, were planned heavy cable recovery operations. The contractors had not applied for a street works permit and therefore the method of pedestrian and traffic management had not been agreed with the Council’s Network Management team

The court heard how the company had previous convictions for this type of offence and had been warned by the Council in November 2013 after it breached the same safety requirements leading to the suspension of workers on the site. However, safety requirements were breached weeks later which resulted in the decision to prosecute.

The Magistrate remarked that the breaches observed had put pedestrians and road users at risk.

After the fines were announced, counsel for the defence had requested consideration of mitigating circumstances. However, the Magistrate noted they did not see any mitigating factors.

Costs of £2,569.12 were also awarded by the court to the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and BT was ordered to pay a victim surcharge of £120.

headline: Businesses develop local volunteering initiatives
prcopy:
Business & Community Together is a new programme designed to help local businesses make a positive impact on the local community by developing volunteering opportunities for their employees.

The programme, supported by the Council, the Kensington & Chelsea Foundation and the Volunteer Centre Kensington & Chelsea, will help businesses support local projects while also developing their staff.

Over 130 guests, representing businesses and charities from across the borough, attended the recent launch in Notting Hill at the headquarters of Made.com

As part of the programme the Council this week launched an Edible Teaching Garden at the Holland Park Ecology Centre to help local schoolchildren understand where food comes from and how it grows.  The garden was made possible thanks to the partnership between Food Explorers, Tools Group UK and Whole Foods Market all members of Business & Community Together.

During the summer the Business & Community Team helped a local hotel in Earl’s Court, Hotel Indigo, distribute a bursary fund to two local charities the Earls Court Community Trust and the ClementJames Centre both of which received grants of £500 from the hotel.

For more information contact Business & Community Together’s corporate engagement manager, Jaq Cameron, on 020 7229 5499.

headline: First World War remembered
prcopy:
Visitors to Kensington Town Hall can find out about the role of Chelsea residents during the First World War at an exhibition in the Council Chamber foyer from Wednesday 15 October until Wednesday 12 November.

The exhibition, which is part of the Chelsea Society’s commemoration of the Great War, looks at the beginning of the conflict, which saw young men enthusiastically joining up for the London Irish Rifles as crowds on the street cheered them, through to Peace Day and a victory parade down Sloane Street.

A football used by the London Irish Rifles to play German troops on Christmas Day 1914 is part of the exhibition. The role of woman on the home front is also featured.

The Mayor of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Cllr Maighread Condon-Simmonds said: “The exhibition is free and it is a great opportunity to get a more personal view of the Great War and its effect on the people and places in Chelsea.”

headline: Six borough primary schools get gold status
prcopy:
Six Royal Borough primary schools have been awarded Gold Club status under a scheme set up by the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, to recognise exceptional schools in the capital.

The Gold Club is part of the Mayor's drive to help push up standards and raise attainment for all schoolchildren wherever they live in the capital and regardless of background.

Borough primary schools that won the award are:
Our Lady of Victories RC
St Barnabas and St Philips C of E
St Charles RC
St Joseph’s RC
Fox Primary
Thomas Jones Primary

The Gold Club celebrates schools that are achieving academic success with all their pupils, in particular those where they may be disadvantaged or be affected by circumstances that could have an impact on their learning. In highlighting schools bucking the trend, particularly those with children on Pupil Premium or previously low attainment, the aim is to inspire others in London to strive for similar academic success and offer them the chance to learn the best practice in the classroom of the Gold Club schools.

Commenting on the awards, the Mayor of London, Boris Johnson, said: “Congratulations to all the schools that have been recognised by our Gold Club programme. The Gold Club is based on the belief that all schools can aspire to attain excellence for all their pupils, whatever their circumstances. I see Gold Club schools as exemplars because they enable terrific results for all their young people.”

Cllr Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea’s Cabinet Member for Education, said: “Congratulations to all the primary schools recognised by the Mayor. Their efforts to continually raise standards are to be applauded.”

95 schools have been awarded Gold Club status in 2014 - year two of the scheme. They are being asked to share their good practice through seminars and hosting visits to their school so that other schools can learn from a range of approaches that have delivered success and achieved extraordinary performance of their pupils.

End

headline: Planners serve notice after traffic breaches planning conditions
prcopy:
Planners from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have ordered works on the new housing development at Campden Hill, W8, to stop unless the developers stick to the agreed Construction Traffic Management Plan (CTMP). The move follows residents’ concerns that construction vehicles were causing disruption along Campden Hill and Campden Hill Road.

Developers of the site, formerly part of Holland Park School, are currently implementing a planning permission for the creation of 72 new residential units. This was granted subject to a condition that disturbance to residents would be minimised through adherence to a CTMP.

Following complaints to the Council about traffic associated with the development, planners made a series of visits to the site and found construction vehicles to be in breach of the requirements of the CTMP.

Consequently, the Council's Planning Enforcement Team issued a Breach of Condition Notice and a Temporary Stop Notice on both the owner of the site, GC Campden Hill LLP, and on the site contractor, McGee Group Limited, on Monday 20 October 2014. The effect of these notices means any future breaches of the CTMP will be a criminal offence. Each breach witnessed could lead to a maximum fine of £20,000 in a magistrates’ court and unlimited if heard in a crown court.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea’s Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: “The Council is continuing with its efforts to tackle developers who blatantly disregard their planning conditions and cause our residents disruption in the process.

“We will use all the powers available to us, regardless of the size of the development or the contractor involved.”

Construction traffic in residential areas can have a big impact on the lives of neighbouring residents if developers ignore their planning conditions. The Royal Borough will use all legal powers at its disposal to ensure planning conditions are followed. Over the past five months 25 legal notices have been served by the Planning Enforcement Team on developers for breaching their CTMPs.

headline: Borough's GCSE results are second best in the country
prcopy:
Pupils at schools in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea have achieved the second best GCSE performance in the country, according to figures released by the Department for Education.

In total 72.5 per cent of pupils in the borough’s schools achieved five or more A* to C GCSEs (including English and mathematics), placing the borough second in the national table behind the Isles of Scilly. The national average for maintained schools was 52.6 per cent and the average for inner London was 58.4 per cent.

Councillor Emma Will, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea’s Cabinet Member for Education, said: “It has been well documented that the marking for this year’s English exams has been more rigorous than in recent years. Therefore I'm very pleased to see our continued strong ranking in this table. It reflects a tremendous amount of hard work by teachers and pupils and confirms the high quality of the educational offer in the Royal Borough.
"

headline: Platform turned `plotform' scoops Big Challenge biodiversity award
prcopy:
A disused platform at Olympia Station which has been turned into a thriving community garden with 89 vegetable plots has won a Big Challenge award as an example of work that goes beyond normal practice in order to enhance biodiversity.

The 'plotform-garden' which is used by 200 residents to grow a wide range of fruit, vegetables and flowers, was developed by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea working with Network Rail, and won the award for ‘Large Scale Temporary Structure’.  

The brightly coloured raised beds, which provide residents with a manageable 1.5m x 1.5m plot, were specially made so they are movable should Network Rail needs to access the platform.

A weekly gardening workshop is held on the site to provide plot holders, many of whom have not grown anything before, with free advice and encouragement. In addition to the vegetable plots the garden features a small orchard with over 30 fruit trees including a variety of apple, pear, cherry and plum trees.

The garden was praised by the judges for being a sustainable project with long-term considerations. The judges said thought had been given into how it could be replicated or extended beyond initial life span.

The Royal Borough’s Cabinet Member for the Environment, Cllr Tim Ahern, said: “The garden has already proven a winner with our local residents and wildlife. But it is great that its work to improve biodiversity has won a Big Challenge award. It is an excellent example of how partnership working between the Council and Network Rail can create a community hub where residents can meet and while also enjoying the challenge of growing their own fruit and vegetables.”

Since 2009 the Council has created over 50 community garden sites which feature over 500 plots/allotments or “aplotments” as some residents refer to them. As a result there are now some 1,000 residents growing their own produce.  To help community gardeners across the borough the Council employs two part-time gardeners who run workshops and offer advice to the new gardeners.
shortdescription: A disused platform at Olympia Station which has been turned into a thriving community garden with 89 vegetable plots has won a Big Challenge award as an example of work that goes beyond normal practice in order to enhance biodiversity.
shorttitle: Platform turned `plotform' scoops Big Challenge biodiversity award

headline: Help to combat doorstep scams
prcopy:
Helping to prevent vulnerable neighbours and relatives from becoming victims of doorstep crime is the theme for this year’s National Consumer Week (Monday 3 to 7 November).

Despite vast under reporting, latest research shows there could be as many as 170,000 incidents of doorstep crime each year. Doorstep criminals exploit vulnerable people by convincing them to pay for shoddy or incomplete repair work, charging extortionate fees for their services, or threatening residents who do not comply.

The 'Good neighbours stop rogue traders' campaign focuses on preventing doorstep crime by encouraging neighbours, family, friends and carers to look out for those most at risk in their communities.

During the week, Trading Standards Officers from the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham will be involved in a number of events. These include the signing of two Illegal Money Lending charters encouraging local partners to work together to combat this illicit trade. Presentations are also being given to police cadets to inform them about doorstep crime and illegal money lending issues.

At Barclays pop-up shop 132 to134 Kensington High Street, London W8 7RP, Trading Standards officers will be available between 11am and 2pm to give advice on doorstep crime and scam issues.

Anyone who has any information on possible doorstep scams in the borough should alert Trading Standards by contacting them on 020 7361 3002.
shortdescription: Helping to prevent vulnerable neighbours and relatives from becoming victims of doorstep crime is the theme for this year’s National Consumer Week (Monday 3 to 7 November).
shorttitle: Help to combat doorstep scams

headline: Brothers and sisters need adoptive families
prcopy:
National Adoption Week, which runs from Monday 3 to Sunday 9 November, is focusing on brothers and sisters who need adoptive families.

Nearly half of all children for whom families are being sought are part of a sibling group according to research carried out by the British Association for Adoption and Fostering (BAAF) but there is a shortage of adopters coming forward to adopt siblings. According to the Adoption Register for England, out of the 663 children on the register, 366 are part of sibling groups.

The Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, Westminster City Council and the London Borough of Hammersmith & Fulham are inviting people who are considering adoption to come along to one of the four information events planned during November.

Cabinet Member for Family and Children’s Services for the Royal Borough, Cllr Elizabeth Campbell said: “We need people from every background to come forward. You can find out more about adoption by attending one of our information events. This year we are asking people consider adopting siblings. It will be hard work but will be incredibly rewarding experience. Children who need to be adopted have usually had a hard start in life and it is even more important for them to experience the stability and support that being with their brothers and sisters can bring.”

The information events take place on Thursday 6 November 2014 at Westminster City Hall and Thursday 27 November 2014 at Kensington Town Hall. Two sessions run each day between 10am and 12 noon and 6pm and 8pm.

To register to attend, or to request an information pack, phone 0800 183 781 2332.
shortdescription: National Adoption Week, which runs from Monday 3 to Sunday 9 November, is focusing on brothers and sisters who need adoptive families.
shorttitle: Brothers and sisters need adoptive families

prcopy:

headline: New future for major Council facility in Kensington
prcopy:
The Cabinet of the Royal Borough last night agreed (Thursday 30 October 2014) to consider the redevelopment of two 1960s Council buildings in Kensington, with the potential to provide nearly 300 new homes.

A 3.3 acre site on Pembroke Road currently houses a depot for refuse vehicles, Council offices and a car park that are increasingly surplus to the Council’s requirements. There are also 116 homes above the depot and car park.

The Council is under fierce pressure to provide more housing and to find new income to support front line services to residents. A redevelopment enables it to achieve both. Amongst other things, the scheme would deliver:

• new affordable housing
• new private housing for sale
• a new environmentally friendly depot that is less noisy and smelly
• energy efficient buildings, and
• much improved streetscape.

As well as authorising the appointment of a development team to draw up a scheme to be considered by residents and the Cabinet, a set of safeguards was agreed to protect the interests of the tenants and leaseholders who live above the depot and car park.

If the scheme is approved, all Secure Tenants will be rehoused by the Council, ideally in a brand new home on the redeveloped estate, or elsewhere in the borough if they prefer.
They will be entitled to a Home Loss Payment of £4,900 plus a Disturbance Payment to cover the reasonable costs of moving home. All resident leaseholders will have their property purchased at the full market value.

They will also be entitled to an additional ten per cent of the market value up to a maximum of £49,000 and a Disturbance Payment to cover the reasonable costs of moving. In addition the Cabinet agreed the Council will develop an offer of an equity share for all resident leaseholders to enable them to purchase and live in one of the new properties on the site. This means the existing mixed community of Council tenants and resident leaseholders will be protected and able to continue living on that site, if they so choose.

Non-resident leaseholders will have their property purchased at the full market value with the owners entitled to a basic loss payment of 7.5 per cent of the value up to a maximum of £75,000 plus the reasonable costs of acquiring a new investment property. Non-resident leaseholders will be entitled to apply to become resident leaseholders if they wish to obtain the same compensation as resident leaseholders.

“Pembroke Road costs a great deal to run and we simply don’t need to continue using much of the depot or offices anymore,” said the Deputy Leader of the Council, Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen. “What we do need is new affordable homes and new income to help protect our front line services. If at the same time we can dramatically improve the streetscape and local environment of this corner of the borough that would be a tremendous bonus.

“But we won’t be taking this development forward unless we can be sure we are being fair to our existing tenants and leaseholders,” he added. “We have put together a cast-iron compensation package which responds to the concerns and worries residents have expressed over the last 18 months. We will make sure to protect the strong mixed-community that currently lives there.”

There will be extensive consultation with residents and if the development plans go ahead, up to 116 new affordable homes could be provided on the site, double what is currently there. There could also be up to 176 new private homes for sale and rent. In addition, there may be office space and new retail units at ground floor level. The existing nursery will be retained and as part of the design process, the viability of a new school building will be explored.

The appointment process for an architect-led development team will get underway in the New Year.
shortdescription: The Cabinet of the Royal Borough last night agreed (Thursday 30 October 2014) to consider the redevelopment of two 1960s Council buildings in Kensington, with the potential to provide nearly 300 new homes.
shorttitle: New future for major Council facility in Kensington

headline: Social landlords efforts to help tenants find work commended
prcopy:
Five organisations that have helped residents of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea find routes into employment were recognised at a ceremony in the Mayor’s parlour on Thursday 30 October.

The special event celebrated the achievements of the Pathways to Work Charter, a partnership between housing providers and local agencies to tackle worklessness in the Royal Borough.

Since 2012 the partnership has seen:

• over 200 residents referred to local services that provide employment-related assistance and support
• 45 residents engaged in employment, training or work placements
• over 9,000 residents in social housing directly alerted to a range of jobs and training support, welfare benefits advice and other services
• over 400 jobs, training and related opportunities shared directly with tenants, local community agencies working with residents and with 17 housing providers in the borough.

The awards presented were:

• Outstanding Partnership Working – Kensington and Chelsea Tenant Management Organisation
• Creating the Highest Level of Employment and Training Opportunities for Borough Residents – Catalyst Housing
• Outstanding Engagement and IT Support to Help Residents Towards Employment – Affinity Sutton
• Highest Level of Tenants Referred to the Pathways to Work Charter Gateway Services – Notting Hill Housing
• STAR Award for Outstanding Employer Brokerage – Peabody Housing


Cllr Rock Feilding-Mellen, Deputy Leader of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, said: “I’d like to congratulate all the award winners. Finding employment can change people’s lives, but for some it can be a difficult task. By supporting training and promoting opportunity these housing providers have made a real, and hopefully lasting, difference to many individuals and families in the borough.”
shortdescription: Five organisations that have helped residents of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea find routes into employment were recognised at a ceremony in the Mayor’s parlour on Thursday 30 October.
shorttitle: Social landords efforts to help tenants find work commended

headline: Options for a new and expanded Barlby Primary School and wider estate regeneration a step closer
prcopy:
Last night (Thursday 30 October) the Royal Borough’s Cabinet agreed to explore options for redeveloping Barlby Primary School and regenerating the area around the Treverton Estate.

Ofsted judge Barlby to be an outstanding school but its buildings are outdated, tired and don’t make best use of the site. The proposals could see a brand new school expanded to two forms of entry to help meet demand for primary school places.

At the same time, a new school for children with special educational needs could be built on the Barlby site. The profile of special educational needs in Kensington and Chelsea has changed dramatically in recent years. Most notably, the number of children with autistic spectrum disorder has more than quadrupled, from 28 in 2003 to 121 in 2013.

Adjoining Barlby Primary School is the Treverton Estate (adjacent to the Balfour of Burleigh Estate), parts of which are in need of investment. The Council believes there may be the opportunity to improve existing homes, provide additional new affordable homes and also deliver significant public realm improvements.

The Council will now commission a design team to come up with potential design options for the new schools and a masterplan for the wider area. The Council aims to consult on these options early in 2015. For more information visit www.rbkc.gov.uk/BarlbyTrev

Councillor Rock Feilding-Mellen, Deputy Leader and Cabinet Member for Housing, Property and Regeneration, said: “Developing this masterplan is part of our ongoing commitment to regenerating North Kensington.

“Once the design team has formulated viable options for the new schools and for the estate we will consult on these options with the local community.

“We want to reiterate that no final decision has been reached and we are now exploring options for the site. However, what we want to stress from the outset is that whatever development might take place, the Council is committed to ensuring that existing tenants can continue to live in the same area.”
shortdescription: Last night (Thursday 30 October) the Royal Borough’s Cabinet agreed to explore options for redeveloping Barlby Primary School and regenerating the area around the Treverton Estate.
shorttitle: Options for a new and expanded Barlby Primary School and wider estate regeneration a step closer

headline: Planning enforcement officers issue record number of notices
prcopy:
The first ten months of 2014 have been especially busy for the Council’s Planning Enforcement team with a record number of notices served.

Over the previous five years the average number of notices served in a year was 35 but this year 94 have already been issued.

Basement developments that have fallen foul of agreed planning permission have accounted for 30 notices. Basement developers not following their construction traffic plans have accounted for 14 notices.

Notable cases have included Catalyst, the developer of Wornington Green being prosecuted for not ensuring their contractor stuck to their Construction Traffic Management Plan.

The owner of 104 Portland Road refused to take down extensions which did not have authorisation and as a result was prosecuted and fined. It hasn’t just been bricks and mortar that has attracted the attention of the Council’s enforcement team – an advertiser was successfully prosecuted for displaying advertisements on a phone box in Sloane Square without the proper consent.

The enforcement team looks set to remain busy for the rest of the year and further prosecutions are in the pipeline including a basement developer who has been displaying adverts without advertisement consent, a developer who made alterations to a listed building without listed building consent and a developer who didn’t properly maintain a listed building.

Councillor Timothy Coleridge, the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea’s Cabinet Member for Planning Policy, said: “There is a very clear message here. When planning permission is given, and conditions attached, we expect people to stick to them. If they don’t, be they well known developers or a one-man-band, we will act and if required will look to the courts to back us.

“I believe that this is what our residents want us to do.”
shortdescription: The first ten months of 2014 have been especially busy for the Council’s Planning Enforcement team with a record number of notices served.
shorttitle: Planning enforcement officers issue record number of notices

headline: Thomas Jones Primary School shows Deputy Mayor why it's one of London's healthiest
prcopy:
London’s Deputy Mayor, Cllr Victoria Borwick, visited Thomas Jones Primary School in North Kensington, on Tuesday 4 November, to see first hand the work it has done to achieve the Mayor’s Healthy Schools London silver status.

Healthy Schools London is an awards scheme funded by the Mayor, Boris Johnson, which supports and recognises schools’ achievements in pupil health and well-being. More than 1,000 schools across the capital have already signed up to the scheme; so far 447 schools have achieved bronze award, 54 silver and two gold.

Healthy Schools London encourages schools to teach their pupils about the importance of healthy eating, regular physical activity, emotional health and general wellbeing.

Thomas Jones has succeeded in promoting a healthy lifestyle to all pupils at the school, teaching them about growing fresh produce, making healthy food choices and good oral health. The school’s achievements include:

• 100 per cent of packed lunches now include fruit, vegetables, dairy, carbohydrate and a healthy drink
• 100 per cent of children are engaged in food and cookery lessons at school
• the number of nursery children registered with a dental surgery and visiting the dentist regularly has increased from 64 to 100 per cent.

Deputy Mayor Victoria Borwick, said: “To receive the silver Healthy Schools London award is a huge achievement and the teachers, staff and pupils should all be extremely proud of themselves.

“I’m honoured to have been able to visit and see all their brilliant initiatives first hand. It’s great to think that the children who attend the school now understand why eating healthily and getting actively involved in preparing food is so important.”

David Sellens, Head Teacher at Thomas Jones Primary, said: “We are delighted to have achieved the Mayor's Healthy Schools London Silver Status at Thomas Jones School and recognise the commitment of all staff along with pupils, including our pupil-led School Nutrition Action Group, in achieving this.

“Through our work towards obtaining the silver status we have ensured that all pupils at the school are engaged in growing and cooking their own healthy food and have developed an understanding of food provenance along with ethical and environmental issues surrounding their own food choices. We hope to continue to build upon this in order to achieve our gold award in early 2015.”

Year 5 pupil, Dina Elawad, said: “I feel very lucky to be in a school that ensures that the lunches provided are so healthy and are prepared with fresh produce. It is wonderful that the pupils at our school are given the opportunity to plant, grow and eat fresh fruits and vegetables.”
shortdescription: London’s Deputy Mayor, Cllr Victoria Borwick, visited Thomas Jones Primary School in North Kensington, on Tuesday 4 November, to see first hand the work it has done to achieve the Mayor’s Healthy Schools London silver status.
shorttitle: Thomas Jones Primary School shows Deputy Mayor why it's one of London's healthiest

headline: Don't be a victim of a loan shark
prcopy:
The scourge of illegal money lending and the problems associated with it was targeted by Royal BoroughTrading Standards officers during National Consumer Week.

Trading Standards officers have been working with England Illegal Money Lending Team (IML) to tackle illegal money lenders in the borough. Also known as loan sharks, illegal money lenders operate without a consumer credit licence and offer loans at extremely high interest rates. While they can try to give the impression of offering a community service their practices are often illegal.

As debts to illegal money lenders are actually unenforceable in law the lenders can look to enforce debts through intimidation, violence and other illicit means.

On Wednesday 5 November a charter was signed at Kensington Town Hall which will result in further work between IML, the Council and key partners which will see:

• improved intelligence gathering about the scale of the problem in Kensington and Chelsea

• promotion of alternative solutions for people in debt, such as credit unions

• potential victims discouraged from going to loan sharks in the first place

• training for front line staff.

Cllr Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said: “We intend to clamp down on the misery and worry that loan sharks bring. This practice is illegal and it is important that residents are aware of this. It is equally important that they are aware of the safe and regulated places they can get loans such as Your Credit Union.

“I am very pleased that the signing of this charter signals a new chapter in our efforts to put an end to illegal money lending in the borough.”

For further information about illegal money lending contact Trading Standards on 020 7361 3002 or email trading.standards@rbkc.gov.uk

For more information on Your Credit Union and how to contact it www.rbkc.gov.uk/communityandlocallife/yourcreditunionycu.aspx
shortdescription: The scourge of illegal money lending and the problems associated with it was targeted by Royal BoroughTrading Standards officers during National Consumer Week.
shorttitle: Don't be a victim of a loan shark

headline: Food Standards Agency urges you to 'look before you book' for Christmas
prcopy:
If you’re planning that special Christmas meal with work colleagues, friends or family the Food Standards Agency would like to remind you to ‘look before you book’.

Christmas is a time to enjoy good company and good food without worrying about food poisoning. But the truth is, you can’t tell a restaurant’s hygiene standards by how clean and tidy the staff look or by how busy it is.

It’s the things you can’t see – like germs spread by bad hygiene practices - that you need to consider. There’s one easy way to set your mind at rest – check the food hygiene rating.

The food hygiene rating tells you about hygiene standards in restaurants and other food businesses. It’s really easy to check. Just go online and check the Food Standards Agency website: www.food.gov.uk/ratings or if you’re out and about look for the green and black sticker; if you can’t see one, just ask.

The ratings are determined by local authority food safety officers and run from 0 to 5, with a 5 rating meaning a very good level of food hygiene. Ninety three per cent of food businesses are rated 3 or better so there are plenty of places with good standards and you can easily making a bad choice.

Catherine Brown, Chief Executive for the Food Standards Agency, agrees: “This Christmas, do this one little thing for peace of mind when eating out.Take a moment to check the food hygiene rating, pick the right place and enjoy a great meal out.”

Councillor Tim Ahern, Cabinet Member for Environmental Health, said “It’s easy for people in Kensington and Chelsea to check hygiene ratings online and choose a restaurant for their Christmas parties that takes food hygiene seriously. This is an important time for local businesses. A good food hygiene rating is something to be proud of. It matters to customers so we are encouraging all businesses in the borough to display their rating and have a prosperous Christmas season.”

For more information, visit www.food.gov.uk/business-industry/caterers/hygieneratings
shortdescription: If you’re planning that special Christmas meal with work colleagues, friends or family the Food Standards Agency would like to remind you to ‘look before you book’.
shorttitle: Food Standards Agency urges you to 'look before you book' for Christmas

headline: Fraud team warns of text messages that can lock mobile phones
prcopy:
Trading Standards officers are urging residents to be on the lookout for text messages containing a virus which can lock a mobile phone and result in a ‘ransom’ demand to unlock it. The warning comes after the City of London Police’s National Fraud Intelligence Bureau (NFIB) issued an alert.

The NFIB said the virus is currently being aimed at the US with text messages purporting to come from the FBI. It is likely that the UK has already been, or is likely to be affected, but to date the NFIB has not received any reports detailing this type of ransomware.

The text messages activate a new variant of the “Android.Koler.A” malware called Worm.koler. They typically read “someone made a profile named - (the contact’s name) and has uploaded some of your photos! Is that you?” This will then be followed by a ‘bit.ly’ URL. If clicked, the link will redirect the phone user to a file hosting service where they are encouraged to download an app called ‘Photoviewer’.

Once this app is installed, a pop up screen will appear stating that your device has been locked by the police and you must pay to unblock it.

Whilst this is happening on the screen, in the background, text messages are spammed out to all the contacts stored on the phone. The message is only sent once to make it appear more authentic.

It is recommended that any victims of this ransomware complete a ‘factory reset’ of their device and then reinstall their apps afterwards. This could cause a potential loss of data such as photos, if they have not already been backed up.

If the malware restricts you from getting into your phone’s settings, put the phone into safe mode (please refer to your phone’s instruction manual) and remove the app. Once this is done, perform a complete reset of your phone.

It is also recommended that if you are unsure about any messages containing a link do not click on them, and think about contacting the sender for verification that they intended to send you the message.

It is important to remember only to download apps from a reputable source.

If you’ve lost money, information or your computer/smartphone has been taken over by a phishing or malware attack please report it to www.actionfraud.police.uk/report_fraud

For further information please contact Trading Standards on 020 7361 3002 or email trading.standards@rbkc.gov.uk
shortdescription: Trading Standards officers are urging residents to be on the lookout for text messages containing a virus which can lock a mobile phone and result in a ‘ransom’ demand to unlock it. The warning comes after the City of London Police’s National Fraud Intelligence Bureau (NFIB) issued an alert.
shorttitle: Fraud team warns of text messages that can lock mobile phones

headline: Raising cycling awareness
prcopy:
Last week nearly 50 cyclists attended an event organised by the Council, Metropolitan Police and the Victoria and Albert Museum entitled Exchanging Places on Exhibition Road which raised awareness of cycle safety.

The location was chosen as there are currently building works at the museum, which will continue until 2016 and mean a increase in traffic in the area. The contractor, Wates, was on hand to provide details of what they are doing to ensure safety around the site.

In particular the event, which aimed to combat accidents involving cyclists and lorries, gave cyclists an idea of what a HGV driver actually sees on the road and where the danger zones are.

The police offered free security marking and the Royal Borough offered on the spot maintenance checks.

Those cyclists who missed the event will have more opportunities to find out about the issues of cycle safety, maintenance and crime prevention during future Council organised events.

If you’re interested in coming along to our next Exchanging Places event, please check www.bikeminded.org for upcoming dates.
